headline: Proud Boys’ Views on Violence Take Center Stage at Jan. 6 Trial
abstract: The far-right group has maintained that it only uses physical force defensively, but testimony in the seditious conspiracy trial of five of its members has focused on its culture of aggression.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Proud Boys burst into the spotlight nearly seven years ago, the far-right group has done a complicated dance around the issue of political violence.

headline: When Black Characters Double-Deal to Make Ends Meet, It’s Never Enough
abstract: In three Broadway plays this season, a quest for financial stability can’t undo the trauma of the past or dismantle the architecture that places a ceiling on Black futures.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Tyre Nichols Cried in Anguish. Memphis Officers Kept Hitting.
abstract: Video footage of the fatal encounter included critical moments in which police officers kicked, punched and pepper-sprayed Mr. Nichols, 29, while he screamed.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — The police officers kicked Tyre Nichols in the head, pepper-sprayed him and hit him repeatedly with a baton, even as he showed no signs of fighting back. At one point, after Mr. Nichols stood up, one officer struck him with at least five forceful blows while another held Mr. Nichols’s hands behind his back.

headline: L.A. County to Pay $20 Million for Land Once Seized From Black Family
abstract: California officials seized a beachfront property from Willa and Charles Bruce in 1924. Los Angeles County returned it to their great-grandsons last year. Now they’re selling it back.
lead_paragraph: The great-grandchildren of a Black couple whose beachfront property in Southern California was seized by local officials in 1924, and returned to the family last year, will sell it back to Los Angeles County for nearly $20 million, an official said on Tuesday.

headline: A Black Composer’s Legacy Flourishes 500 Years After His Birth
abstract: The reputation of Vicente Lusitano, one of the earliest known composers of African descent active in Europe, was thwarted for centuries.
lead_paragraph: On a day in June 2020, Alice Jones was in her Brooklyn apartment getting ready to attend a Black Lives Matter rally. Dr. Jones, a flutist and composer who serves as an assistant dean and faculty member at the Juilliard School, was adamant about expressing herself as a Black classical musician.

headline: From Sacramento to Memphis, Tyre Nichols Cut His Own Path
abstract: Social media posts show that Mr. Nichols harbored a mistrust of prevailing government and economic systems, yet, a friend says, he also considered trying to change policing from the inside.
lead_paragraph: Before Tyre Nichols moved to Memphis — before he was brutally beaten on a Saturday night by police officers there — he lived in California, in the Sacramento area, where he hung out with a crowd of skateboarders.

headline: A Lasting Impact
abstract: “The 1619 Project” continues to provoke national debate about race and history.
lead_paragraph: Three and a half years ago, The New York Times Magazine published The 1619 Project. It argued that 1619, the year the first slave ship is widely believed to have arrived in what is now the U.S., was as foundational to America as the year 1776, and that the legacy of chattel slavery still shapes our society. Essays from historians, scholars and others covered issues including capitalism, criminal justice and music, and sparked a national debate about race and history that is still raging.

headline: The Death of Tyre Nichols: A Place for Teenagers to Respond
abstract: We invite you to post your thoughts, emotions, reactions and questions in this moderated forum.
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers: As always, please preview this to make sure it is appropriate for your students. You can find additional teaching resources on systemic racism, policing, protesting and more at the bottom of this post.

headline: A Farewell to Maya Moore, a Team Player Who Is Also One of a Kind
abstract: Moore, who has officially retired from the W.N.B.A., will be remembered for her brilliance on the court and her fight for justice away from it.
lead_paragraph: One of my clearest memories of Maya Moore has nothing to do with basketball, and nothing to do with her fight for justice.

headline: Police, Paramedics Accused in Elijah McClain Killing Plead Not Guilty
abstract: The 23-year-old Black man died three years ago after being placed in a chokehold and injected with a powerful sedative. The defendants will be tried in three separate trials.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The five police officers and paramedics accused of killing Elijah McClain, a young Black man who had been walking home when he was stopped by the police in Aurora, Colo., were formally arraigned in a Colorado district court on Friday, more than three years after his death.

headline: Violent History Echoes in the Killing of Tyre Nichols
abstract: Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Memphis father, became the latest Black man to join a horrific line of abuse in the city.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — On April 3, 1968, shortly before the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. would deliver what turned out to be his last speech, “I’ve Been to the Mountaintop,” at a Memphis church packed with striking sanitation workers, the Rev. James M. Lawson Jr., a local minister and national strategist of nonviolent direct action, stepped up to the church’s pulpit. A colleague and friend of Dr. King, Mr. Lawson spoke passionately to the crowd about a teenager named Larry Payne. A few days before, a Memphis police officer had shot and killed Mr. Payne in a doorway outside the housing project where he lived, unbeknown to his mother, who was at home in their apartment less than a hundred yards away.

headline: Why Has America Fallen So Hard for Harry and Meghan?
abstract: Inside a vast, and somewhat peculiar, celebrity obsession.
lead_paragraph: Whether out of Anglophilia, nostalgia, masochism, traditionalism or just a particular strain of fealty to the rich and famous, America’s quixotic devotion to the British monarchy remains strong.

headline: Tyre Nichols’s Death Is America’s Shame
abstract: He is now a marquee victim of a predacious system that America has lost its willingness to confront.
lead_paragraph: The spectacle of a televised countdown to the showing of the video in which Tyre Nichols was savagely beaten by Memphis police officers doesn’t just theatricalize Black death; it is a damning indictment of American perversion.

headline: Review: In ‘Field of Mars,’ a March Toward Oblivion
abstract: Presented by Richard Maxwell’s New York City Players as part of this year’s Under the Radar Festival, the two-act play tries to measure humanity’s progress.
lead_paragraph: “Field of Mars,” written and directed by the experimental playwright Richard Maxwell, is mainly set in a chain restaurant with a menu globalized to the point of comedy, where a character is asked if he’d like to upgrade his “Blue Hawaiian” drink to “mucho” size.

headline: The Power Politics of Social Change
abstract: From civil rights and apartheid to the protest movements of today.
lead_paragraph: Monday was Martin Luther King Day in the United States, a time when Americans honor his legacy, and the civil rights movement that he helped lead.

headline: Ex-Head of N.Y.P.D. Sergeants’ Union Admits to Stealing From His Members
abstract: Edward D. Mullins pleaded guilty to wire fraud after spending about $1 million on luxuries. He had been a furious and sometimes profane critic of the de Blasio administration.
lead_paragraph: Edward D. Mullins, one of the most powerful and combative leaders in the history of the New York City sergeants’ union, pleaded guilty to federal wire fraud on Thursday in a scheme to steal hundreds of thousands of dollars from the organization and its members.

headline: New Details Emerge of Meeting Between Proud Boys and Oath Keepers
abstract: Prosecutors in the Proud Boys sedition trial disclosed more about an encounter in a garage between leaders of the far-right groups the day before the attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: It has always been one of the most intriguing stories surrounding the storming of the Capitol: On the evening of Jan. 5, 2021 — a day before the building was attacked — the leaders of the two far-right groups that ultimately played a central role in the assault came face-to-face in an underground parking garage on Capitol Hill.

headline: Tyre Nichols Beating Opens a Complex Conversation on Race and Policing
abstract: The five officers charged with the murder of the young Black man are also Black, complicating the anguish and efforts at police reform.
lead_paragraph: The killing of Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man in Memphis, at the hands of police has prompted outrage and condemnation from racial justice activists, police reform advocates and law enforcement officials, including the chief of the Memphis Police Department, a Black woman who lobbied for policing changes in the wake of George Floyd’s murder.

headline: Keep Your Politics Out of My Arugula
abstract: Whether to eat meat shouldn’t be a red-blue issue.
lead_paragraph: When I was 14, I was asked to fetch some baklava from the basement of the Turkish restaurant where I worked after school. Whatever startling vision I confronted down there has grown blurry with time, but the resulting epiphany is clear to this day: Meat, I realized, wasn’t just a dish you forked into your mouth at dinner. It was flesh — muscle and fat, parts of an animal that once lived and moved and felt — stuff that could take a while to chew. The tongue in the tongue passed to me on a plate wasn’t just the name of the dish; it was actually a cow’s tongue. Chopped liver was once a functioning liver.

headline: Podcast Overload
abstract: How I kicked the “Red Scare” habit.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the pandemic my wife and I moved to Manhattan from Brooklyn. There would be less space for Gerda, our husky, but no more 45-minute car commutes and no more road rage. I would walk everywhere. And I would take Gerda with me.

headline: The Fraudulence of Investigating the Investigators
abstract: This new committee is no Church Committee; it’s a coven of conspiracy theorists.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have decided to hound the hounds.

headline: Who Are the Proud Boys on Trial for Seditious Conspiracy?
abstract: The five defendants are members of one of the nation’s best-known far-right groups and are accused of helping to lead the assault on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s most prominent far-right extremist groups, the Proud Boys have embraced a violent version of patriarchal nationalism since forming in 2016 and aligning themselves with former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: How the Whitney’s Top Latino Curator Is Shaking Up the Art World
abstract: In her five years at the museum, Marcela Guerrero has helped broaden the scope of artists and audiences as the Hispanic population continues to grow and museums try to reflect more diverse audiences.
lead_paragraph: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.

headline: ‘She Comes Back to Where She Belongs’
abstract: Why the return of colonial art is a powerful and necessary statement.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1995, Russia’s two major art museums, in St. Petersburg and Moscow, mounted exhibitions a month apart that attracted considerable attention. Not so much because of the art, although much of it was spectacular, but because Russia openly identified it as art looted from Nazi Germany at the end of World War II.

headline: We Can’t Just Give Up and Shrug in Silence
abstract: The horror doesn’t just lie in the carnage. It’s that we’ve become accustomed to it.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I have a lot to ask you about government spending and deficits and … all that stuff. But first, we really need to talk about all the recent mass shootings and what to do about them, right?

headline: Video of Memphis Officers Beating Tyre Nichols Elicits Widespread Horror
abstract: As public officials and others condemned the actions they viewed, initial reactions from protesters around the country were largely peaceful.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — The release of video footage showing Memphis police officers pummeling, kicking and pepper-spraying Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man, drew a swift avalanche of reaction from law enforcement officials, lawmakers from both parties, Black Lives Matter activists and many other people across the country.

headline: Skeptical About Trump ’24? These 12 Republicans Will Set You Straight.
abstract: G.O.P. voters discuss Trump’s 2024 candidacy, the 2022 midterms and the second anniversary of the Capitol attack.
lead_paragraph: G.O.P. voters discuss Trump’s 2024 candidacy, the 2022 midterms and the second anniversary of the Capitol attack.

headline: As Historians Gather, No Truce in the History Wars
abstract: At the annual meeting of the American Historical Association, the raging battle over how to write about the past — and why — was uncomfortably front and center.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — As nearly 3,000 scholars gathered over the weekend for the annual meeting of the American Historical Association, even the attempts at institutional lightheartedness carried an edge.

headline: Memphis Had Avoided Most Bitter Divisions Over Policing. Until Now.
abstract: Despite a series of conflicts, the Memphis police force had not been in the center of the recent national debates over policing. The death of Tyre Nichols changed that.
lead_paragraph: The story of policing in Memphis has often mirrored in miniature the story of policing across America over the last decade.

headline: Video images of Tyre Nichols being beaten draw comparisons to Rodney King’s beating by police officers.
abstract: A camcorder video of L.A.P.D. officers repeatedly striking King in 1991 circulated widely, long before police body camera footage and cellphone video of altercations involving officers became common.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Video images of Memphis police officers beating Tyre Nichols have drawn comparisons to shocking footage of a watershed episode more than three decades ago, in which a group of officers repeatedly struck a Black motorist as he lay on the street.

headline: Prosecutors Open Arguments Against Proud Boys in Sedition Trial
abstract: The Justice Department began its case by telling the jury that five members of the far-right pro-Trump group had led scores of others in a coordinated attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: Encouraged by former President Donald J. Trump, five members of the Proud Boys led scores of others in the far-right group in a coordinated attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, using violence at key moments during the assault to disrupt what prosecutors described on Thursday as “the heart of our democracy”: the lawful transfer of presidential power.

headline: How Montana Took a Hard Right Turn Toward Christian Nationalism
abstract: What happened to a state known for its political independence?
lead_paragraph: The fifth season of the hit show “Yellowstone” premiered on the Sunday after the midterm elections, with Kevin Costner’s character, the rancher John Dutton, assuming Montana’s governorship. “This was never my plan,” he says, wearing a cowboy hat outside the State Capitol building in Helena. Dutton has reluctantly entered politics in part to stop an influx of rich outsiders he believes are transforming his home. In the last three years, Montana has become the second-fastest-growing state in the nation, largely because of the arrival of wealthy transplants. Unlike Dutton, many influential figures in the state’s real Republican Party have welcomed them, sometimes calling them “political refugees” fleeing blue states. Montana’s actual governor, the Republican Greg Gianforte, is himself a multimillionaire who was raised in Pennsylvania. Since assuming office in 2021, Gianforte has presided over this period of demographic change and economic growth, which has coincided with a hard shift to the right in state politics.

headline: Women’s March Holds Nationwide Rallies on 50th Anniversary of Roe
abstract: The annual march, which was started in 2017 as a reaction to the election of President Donald J. Trump, this year focused on abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: With signs declaring “Abortion Is Health Care” and chants about fighting back, activists in dozens of cities nationwide rallied in support of abortion rights on Sunday, the 50th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision that was overturned by the Supreme Court, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion.

headline: The Philip Guston Hoard: A Boon or Overkill?
abstract: The gift of 220 artworks from the artist’s foundation to the august Metropolitan Museum of Art seems at odds with the institution it hopes to become.
lead_paragraph: How much is too much? It’s a question that consumers should ask themselves every time they shop, build or step onto a fuel-guzzling jet.

headline: Duh!
abstract: The theme of David Steinberg’s puzzle may suddenly seem obvious.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: During George Floyd Protests, 2 Lawyers’ Futures Went Up in Flames
abstract: Colinford Mattis, who was sentenced Thursday, and Urooj Rahman burned a police car. They lost their licenses to practice law. He may lose his foster children.
lead_paragraph: Colinford Mattis’s trajectory from a working-class upbringing in East New York to the Ivy League and corporate law abruptly ended at about 1 a.m. on May 30, 2020, when a Molotov cocktail ignited the center console of an empty police car during a Black Lives Matter protest.

headline: Beloved Peacocks Are Retiring From St. John the Divine
abstract: Harry, Jim and Phil have lived for years on the grounds of the Morningside Heights cathedral, but they are moving to an animal sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll meet the peacocks who live on the grounds of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. They’re about to retire. We’ll also find out about the inflated expense-account claims that led to a guilty plea by the former leader of the New York City sergeants’ union.

headline: Minneapolis City Council Votes to Remove $8 Million From Police Budget
abstract: The move comes as the city grapples with efforts to overhaul the department after the police killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Months after their pledge to dismantle the Police Department fell apart, members of the Minneapolis City Council voted early Thursday to divert nearly $8 million from the proposed policing budget to other city services, a move heralded by some as an important step toward transforming public safety in a city where law enforcement has long been accused of racism.

headline: A ‘Messiah’ for the Multitudes, Freed From History’s Bonds
abstract: A polyglot, nonsectarian, gender-inclusive film from Canada remakes the Handel classic for today’s world.
lead_paragraph: A gay Chinese-Canadian tenor struts through the streets of Vancouver, joyously proclaiming that “ev’ry valley shall be exalted” as the camera focuses in on his six-inch-high stiletto heels.

headline: The Best TV Episodes of 2020
abstract: Jackie Daytona. Dave Chappelle’s monologue. John Wilson’s risotto lesson. These are the episodes that cut through the clutter this year.
lead_paragraph: Even deep into the binge-watching era — and in a year when most of us binged more than ever before — individual episodes still matter. Here, the television critics of The New York Times recall which, of the thousands they watched this year, cut through the clutter and stuck with them in 2020.

headline: A Year Filled With Death Changed Lives Forever
abstract: As Covid-19 swept the world, the killing of George Floyd galvanized a racial justice movement, and the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg upended the makeup of the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Death has rarely so shaped a year as it did in 2020. It swept a world plagued by the coronavirus. It galvanized a Black Lives Matter movement across the United States and abroad, sending people of all colors into the streets to demand social justice. It altered the ideological makeup of the United States Supreme Court so decisively that the consequences of that shift will assuredly be felt for decades.

headline: As France Shifts Right, a Hard-Line Minister Proves Indispensable to Macron
abstract: Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin has become a useful tool for the French president as he responds to growing calls for law and order following a spate of terror attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He has declared war on the Islamist “enemy within” and halal food shelves in supermarkets. He launched what he described as a “massive” operation against 76 of France’s mosques, and sought to criminalize the filming of police officers. And he announced that he “can’t breathe” when he hears the term “police violence” — mocking a cry against police brutality that originated in the United States and resonated around the world.

headline: Two Cities and Two Weddings — but Only One Couple
abstract: Kelly Orians and Thomas Frampton had two weddings in one day, one in Washington and the other in New Orleans, so family members would not have to risk traveling during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Orians and Thomas Frampton had two weddings in two cities in one day.

headline: Democrats, Stay United
abstract: Even though significant compromises will be required in Congress and not every progressive idea will be embraced.
lead_paragraph: Here we are, just four weeks past Election Day, and renewed skirmishing has already broken out within the Democratic Party. Having mostly rallied behind Joe Biden after the primaries, progressives now want their policies and their people embedded in the new administration.

headline: Gone but Never Forgotten in a Quilt
abstract: Members of the national Women of Color Quilters Network draw on personal experiences of injustice, turning their needlework into symbols of liberation, resistance and empowerment.
lead_paragraph: Peggie Hartwell, a fourth-generation quilter from South Carolina, has found it hard to return to her needlework since she completed “Ode to George Floyd,” in which she renders Mr. Floyd’s face in subtle brown batiks, and an image of his mother barely visible behind a grove of trees. “I had to talk to him, get to know him,” the 81-year-old quilter said of the process. “I pick up a piece of fabric and see his face.”

headline: Why Do So Many Americans Think the Election Was Stolen?
abstract: Looking for the reasons behind a seemingly unreasonable belief.
lead_paragraph: There have been few surprises this past month in how Donald Trump has dealt with the reality of his electoral defeat.

headline: 2 Cleveland Police Officers Avoid Federal Charges in Killing of Tamir Rice
abstract: Finding a lack of evidence to prosecute, the Justice Department ended a five-year inquiry into the death of the 12-year-old Black boy, who had been carrying a pellet gun when an officer shot him.
lead_paragraph: Two Cleveland police officers will avoid federal criminal charges for their role in the killing of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old Black boy who had been carrying a pellet gun when he was shot in 2014, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday, citing a lack of evidence in the high-profile case.

headline: How Politics, Protests and the Pandemic Shaped a Year in Books
abstract: From “American Dirt” to “Apropos of Nothing” to “A Promised Land,” here is what happened in the literary and publishing world’s unforgettable 2020.
lead_paragraph: The year in books, like the year everywhere else, was a simultaneously breakneck and slow-motion mixture of exhaustion, peril, controversy, inspiration and resilience.

headline: Inside One Woman’s Quest to Preserve the Disappearing Southern Appalachia
abstract: Among the last in her community, an 89-year-old woman self-published a memoir about life in the mountains, where a number of Black families settled after the end of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Mary Othella Burnette was born and raised in western North Carolina, in a small community in the mountains where a number of Black families settled after the end of the Civil War. Enslaved people, newly freed from local plantations, put down roots there, and Ms. Burnette is related to many of the earliest settlers of what is known as Southern Appalachia.

headline: 6 Injured When Driver Rams Into Protest Against ICE in Manhattan
abstract: The driver, a 52-year-old woman, was charged with reckless endangerment after the police said she hit several people marching in support of immigrant detainees.
lead_paragraph: About a half-dozen people stand around a black BMW sedan on a Manhattan street. At least one slaps a hand onto one of the car’s windows as the vehicle edges through the group.

headline: 10 Powerful ‘Daily’ Episodes From 2020
abstract: In a year defined by a pandemic, protests and politics, “The Daily” sought out personal stories. Here’s a holiday playlist of the episodes that Michael Barbaro and our team can’t forget.
lead_paragraph: In moments of crisis, the journalistic urge to chronicle and memorialize becomes a kind of civic duty. That’s what 2020 was for “The Daily.” A rolling catastrophe that summoned us — to track down the most memorable characters, the most searing sounds, the most unforgettable scenes.

headline: This Police Union Suspended 8 Members. Seven Are Black.
abstract: The union in a small New Jersey city punished the officers after they expressed support for two chiefs, both of whom are also Black.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. — The tensions within the Englewood Police Department had simmered for months: at disciplinary hearings, during Black Lives Matter marches and in the fallout over no-confidence votes by the officers’ union in the chief and deputy chief.

headline: The Champions League’s New Twist: Injury Roulette
abstract: With muscle injuries rising and an unforgiving, pandemic-compressed schedule looming, Europe might not crown its best team this season, but the one that’s still standing.
lead_paragraph: The procession was nearly over. Ninety-five of the 96 games that constitute the group phase of the Champions League, six weeks of phony war that largely serve to check boxes, cross Ts and dot Is, were complete. Most of the heavyweights had long since advanced to the knockout rounds.

headline: The Decency Agenda
abstract: Joe Biden promised to be a president for all Americans. Here’s a way to start.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden won the presidency because, at a moment when so many Americans were exhausted by the chaos and nastiness of the Trump era, he promised stability, decency and healing. At the heart of his candidacy was the vow to be “a president for all Americans” as he labored “to restore the soul of the nation.”

headline: An Autistic Man Is Killed, Exposing Israel’s Festering Police Brutality Problem
abstract: The police killing of a disabled Palestinian fueled nationwide protests. But the authorities have failed to rein in the use of excessive force, which has a long history.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The school for the mentally disabled in Jerusalem’s Old City made a point of preparing its Palestinian students for interactions with the Israeli police.

headline: An Unprepared N.Y.P.D. Badly Mishandled Floyd Protests, Watchdog Says
abstract: “I look back with remorse,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said after a city oversight agency found the department’s tactics “produced excessive enforcement.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department badly mishandled protests against police brutality over the summer, engaging in “excessive enforcement” that only heightened tensions with demonstrators, according to a report from a city oversight agency released on Friday.

headline: Without Crowds, Is Times Square Really Times Square? Take a Look
abstract: The throngs of visitors have disappeared from New York City’s famous neighborhood, and there is an eeriness to the emptiness.
lead_paragraph: A tour bus agent desperately tried to discern which passers-by were New Yorkers and which ones were out-of-towners. Newlyweds from Maryland, hoping to celebrate their nuptials with a special dinner, had to settle for McDonald’s. Four homeless men sat on a sidewalk, sharing cigarettes and a pipe filled with marijuana.

headline: Black Man Is Beaten on Camera, Thrusting French Police Into Spotlight
abstract: A music producer believes he’d be in jail unjustly if not for a video showing how officers assaulted him. Instead, the police are now in the eye of a political storm. And so is he.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Without the video, Michel Zecler believes his case would have been reduced, at most, to a brief news item.

headline: The Usual Ending to an Odd Formula 1 Season
abstract: The pandemic provided the drama as F1 put together a season after a delayed start. But Mercedes and Lewis Hamilton still won.
lead_paragraph: Another Formula 1 season, another title for Lewis Hamilton and Mercedes. While that is more of the same, this season has been anything but.

headline: Rep. Max Rose Launches Exploratory Bid to Run for N.Y.C. Mayor
abstract: The congressman, who lost his re-election bid last month, is casting himself as a blunt populist who would end New York’s cycle of “broken politics.”
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: A Year of Radical Political Imagination
abstract: Mass protest movements changed the world’s attitude toward social justice.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: Bosses: Consider Caring a Bit
abstract: Workplace activism is here to stay. You might as well embrace it.
lead_paragraph: Hey managers, I know what you’re thinking: Now that we are getting a new president, will your employees finally pipe down?

headline: ‘Small Axe’ Review: The Agonies and Ecstasies of Black British Lives
abstract: Steve McQueen’s anthology of five films is a revelatory look at Afro-Caribbean neighborhoods in Britain from the 1960s to the ’80s.
lead_paragraph: When the British filmmaker Steve McQueen conceived the five films he collectively named “Small Axe,” he could not have foreseen the drastically disrupted world into which they would be released — a world that could shift, and perhaps intensify, the impact with which they would land.

headline: This Time, a Cartoon Depiction of Naomi Osaka Is More True to Life
abstract: Last year, the tennis champion was shown with light skin in an instant noodle ad. Now, she’ll be portrayed as a manga character, and illustrators insisted on getting details right.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The last time an illustration of the tennis star Naomi Osaka made headlines, it was for all the wrong reasons.

headline: Best Songs of 2020
abstract: Tracks responding to real-time events and a spectrum of moods captured the hodgepodge feelings of life in lockdown.
lead_paragraph: No short list can sum up the plenitude of remarkable songs that appear every year, from commercial bangers to standout album tracks to one-time digital apparitions. So don’t treat this as a ranking. Enjoy it as a playlist.

headline: ‘Like a Cattle Yard’: How Justice Is Delivered in Australia’s Bush Courts
abstract: In some remote Aboriginal communities, judges and lawyers arrive by plane and handle dozens of cases in a single day. Critics say language barriers and the rapid pace infringe on human rights.
lead_paragraph: WADEYE, Australia — After an hourlong flight over the ocher sands of northern Australia, the judge stepped off the plane and made her way to the makeshift courthouse, a single white-walled room next to a new $20 million police station ensconced in barbed wire.

headline: A Year When Even Sports Wasn’t an Escape
abstract: Social activism and the pandemic dominated 2020, and the sports world responded in kind.
lead_paragraph: In early May the ascendant tennis star Naomi Osaka declared on Twitter, “I’m done being shy.” Weeks later, after speaking out against police brutality following the killing of George Floyd, she addressed critics on social media who were suggesting in no uncertain terms that she stick to sports.

headline: The ‘Mexican Beverly Hills’
abstract: How a former white enclave became an aspirational suburb for Latinos in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: I was having dinner at some fancy beach-side eatery in early March when someone said they had just moved to Downey, a Southeast Los Angeles suburb 12 miles south of downtown.

headline: For Opponents of Native American Nicknames, 2020 Has Brought Hope
abstract: Leaders in the movement to rid sports of such nicknames and the logos that accompany them saw a domino effect building in public schools after two major professional teams made changes. But there are staunch holdouts.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our July report on schools’ considering dropping Native American nicknames and mascots.

headline: Nikki Giovanni, Finding the Song in the Darkest Days
abstract: Part of the Black Arts Movement in the 1960s, part of a Biden campaign ad in 2020, she has never stopped writing.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of her 52-year career, Nikki Giovanni has written 12 children’s books and eight nonfiction books, and she has released 10 spoken word albums. But the genre for which she is best known is poetry.

headline: As Trump Rages, Voters in a Key County Move On: ‘I’m Not Sweating It’
abstract: Pre-election tensions ran high in Bucks County, Pa. But Biden supporters there are increasingly comfortable tuning President Trump out and moving on, with an eye toward January.
lead_paragraph: DOYLESTOWN, Pa. — Even before the presidential transition was underway, Mike Carr had started to move on with his life.

headline: How Pop Music Fandom Became Sports, Politics, Religion and All-Out War
abstract: On social media this year, the stan was ascendant, fueling commercial competition, trolling and other arcane battles. How did we get here?
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Cordero, a high school student from western New York, has a thing for pop divas, but especially Lady Gaga.

headline: A Black Student’s Mother Complained About ‘Fences.’ He Was Expelled.
abstract: A dispute about the reading of August Wilson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play in an English class escalated at the mostly white Providence Day School in Charlotte, N.C.
lead_paragraph: When the mother of a Black ninth grader at a private school in Charlotte, N.C., learned last month that his English class was going to be studying August Wilson’s “Fences,” an acclaimed play examining racism in 1950s America, she complained to the school.

headline: Sentences That Matter, Mentor and Motivate
abstract: Two teachers show how their middle and high school students work with sentence structure using New York Times models. They also pose a sentence-writing challenge for your students.

headline: This Is Why You Heard About TikTok So Much in 2020
abstract: Business, entertainment, news, activism and social connection will never be the same.
lead_paragraph: It’s been well over two years since TikTok arrived in the United States in August 2018, offering a rejoinder to anyone who thought social media had lost its way. The app had everything: social commentary, comedy, crafting, memes, challenges, makeup tutorials and, of course, dances. Even those who weren’t totally sold on it couldn’t avoid the videos, which proliferated across platforms like Instagram, YouTube and Twitter.

headline: An N.B.A. Veteran Turns Wisdom Into Wins, On and Off the Court
abstract: At 36, Andre Iguodala is on the back end of his N.B.A. career, as an elder statesman with the Miami Heat, but he’s hitting his stride in the tech world.
lead_paragraph: Andre Iguodala’s family members were reluctant card game participants.

headline: Columbus Police Kill Black Man Weeks After Protests Against Brutality
abstract: “Our community is exhausted,” said the mayor of the Ohio capital, which is still reeling from the fatal shooting of Casey Goodson Jr.
lead_paragraph: A police officer fatally shot a Black man early Tuesday in Columbus, Ohio, three weeks after a county sheriff’s deputy killed a Black man in the state capital, which ignited a round of protests against police brutality.

headline: Kansas City Star Apologizes for Racism in Decades of Reporting
abstract: The newspaper said it had “disenfranchised, ignored and scorned” generations of Black people. The apology comes after one in September by The Los Angeles Times.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When Mará Rose Williams, an education reporter for The Kansas City Star, was assigned to cover a local Black Lives Matter protest over the summer, she was struck by the difference between what she said she witnessed and what had been reported in previous days.

headline: ‘Sylvia Pankhurst: Natural Born Rebel,’ by Rachel Holmes: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Sylvia Pankhurst: Natural Born Rebel,” by Rachel Holmes
lead_paragraph: ‘Love and enthusiasm are the two great moving factors which make life worth living. This I aver in spite of all the materialists.’ A free spirit and a visionary, Estelle Sylvia Pankhurst was by nature an artist. Yet she became one of the greatest unsung political figures of the twentieth century.

headline: How to Reimagine Policing and Public Safety that Works for Everyone
abstract: A group of police chiefs, activists and policymakers gathered to debate how to reform law enforcement in America in a time of unrest and upheaval.
lead_paragraph: In a year of near universal upheaval brought on by the global spread of a new disease, Americans also confronted a crisis that has long plagued the nation: racism and its brutal manifestations in policing.

headline: In His Autobiography, the College Basketball Giant John Thompson Is Plainspoken and Profound
abstract: The longtime Georgetown coach, who died in August at 78, writes about his upbringing and his remarkable career in “I Came as a Shadow.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m six feet 10 inches tall,” the longtime Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson writes in his posthumously published autobiography. “I have a large mouth, a big head and a deep voice. I naturally make a big noise. Not only am I Black, but I have dark skin. My feet are big, my body is big. Sometimes I’m loud, but I’m loud because I’m composed of big things.”

headline: Kelly Loeffler, a Wall Street Senator With a Hardscrabble Pitch
abstract: The hard right turn of Ms. Loeffler, one of two Republican candidates in Georgia’s pivotal Senate runoff elections, reflects the ideological gymnastics embraced by her party in the Trump era.
lead_paragraph: In the year since Kelly Loeffler was appointed to the Senate, the largely unknown financial executive has crafted a narrative of her life and built a campaign around it.

headline: Weeks-Old Statue of Breonna Taylor Is Battered in Oakland, Calif.
abstract: The vandalism of the ceramic sculpture of Ms. Taylor near City Hall is under investigation, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The clay took several months for a Bay Area sculptor to shape with his hands into a likeness of Breonna Taylor, which he finished with a dark brown satin glaze.

headline: Events to Shake, or Gently Rattle, the World in 2021
abstract: Planning your calendar for next year? Here are a few events to look out for.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year may mean for the year ahead.

headline: Perez Hilton vs. the Fan Armies
abstract: The celebrity blogger was banned from TikTok on Saturday in a move he said was influenced by the app’s biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: Perez Hilton, the early gossip blogger turned media personality, has been permanently banned from TikTok for violating community guidelines, effective Dec. 12.

headline: Naomi Osaka: Athletes, Speak Up
abstract: We’re affected by bias and racism, just like everyone else. Why shouldn’t we say so?
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: With Germany’s Theaters Closed, the Drama’s Online. Again.
abstract: The show must go on, despite a second lockdown, with livestreamed premieres and recent recordings.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Perhaps it’s the onset of winter, the shorter days and the longer evenings, but right now, watching theater at home, online, doesn’t seem quite as dreary or tiresome as it did during the spring lockdown.

headline: The New York City Sheriff’s Office has a crucial role during the pandemic.
abstract: When it came time to crack down on Mac’s Public House, the Staten Island bar that has notoriously defied Covid-19 restrictions, New York City sent in law enforcement officers from the Sheriff’s Office, a relatively tiny force that relies on 150 deputies and remains unknown even to most New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: When it came time to crack down on Mac’s Public House, the Staten Island bar that has notoriously defied Covid-19 restrictions, New York City sent in law enforcement officers from the Sheriff’s Office, a relatively tiny force that relies on 150 deputies and remains unknown even to most New Yorkers.

headline: Violent Year in New York and Across U.S. as Pandemic Fuels Crime Spike
abstract: A time without precedent saw huge increases in homicides and shootings in the city as some other types of crime plummeted.
lead_paragraph: The first disaster in a year of perpetual crises hit the New York Police Department in March, when the virus tore through the force, killing dozens and sickening entire detective squads.

headline: When Culture Really Began to Reckon With White Privilege
abstract: Black artists didn’t wait around for institutional change. They are making it happen.
lead_paragraph: “Dear White American Theater.” So opened the scathing statement released on June 8 and signed by some of our most influential playwrights and directors who are Black, Indigenous and people of color. “We see you. We have always seen you,” the letter read a few lines later. “We have watched you pretend not to see us.”

headline: These Businesses Thrived as Others Struggled to Survive
abstract: As the pandemic ravaged small businesses across America, some were surprised — and conflicted — about their success.
lead_paragraph: Small businesses were devastated in 2020. They have pivoted so frequently to deal with state-mandated shutdowns, new customer needs and pandemic safety protocols that many aren’t sure what direction they’re facing anymore. Nine months into the coronavirus crisis, more than a quarter remain closed, at least temporarily, according to data from Opportunity Insights, a research group at Harvard University.

headline: Make Schools More Human
abstract: The pandemic showed us that education was broken. It also showed us how to fix it.
lead_paragraph: If a measure of a society is how well it takes care of its young, the past nine months are a damning indictment of our nation.

headline: The Most Important Moments in Art in 2020
abstract: This was a year of protests and pivots. Monuments fell, museums looked inward. On the bright side, galleries persisted despite the pandemic’s grip and curators rolled out magisterial retrospectives.
lead_paragraph: The year was a 12-month stress test. When I asked friends “how are you?” the repeat answers came: “anxious,” “depressed,” “bored.” The first two I could relate to, but bored is something I rarely am. As a journalist, I’m addicted to art-specific information, to taking it in, parsing it, sorting it, trying to make sense of it. And there’s been a ton of it this year, all pretty intense. So as long as I’ve had a laptop, a home library, and at least some access to “live” art, I’ve been OK in lockdown mode. Here are some things that have kept me focused.

headline: In 2020, These Things Came Out on Top
abstract: A tough year turned out to be good for rescue animals, rotten bananas and more.
lead_paragraph: We may think of 2020 as a year of seemingly endless bad news as the pandemic threatened our health, forced us to stay at home and upended most facets of life. But it wasn’t all bad. Here’s a look at some of the things that managed to come out on top.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Stabbing at D.C. Election Protest
abstract: The confrontation near the White House between supporters and opponents of President Trump was one of several on Saturday in Washington and in state capitals across the country.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Washington, D.C., said on Sunday that they had arrested a man in connection with the stabbing of four people on Saturday night as supporters and opponents of President Trump clashed blocks from the White House.

headline: When You Can’t Just ‘Trust the Science’
abstract: The vaccine debate is the latest example of how our coronavirus choices are inescapably political.
lead_paragraph: One of many regrettable features of the Trump era is the way that the president’s lies and conspiracy theories have seemed to vindicate some of his opponents’ most fatuous slogans. I have in mind, in particular, the claim that has echoed through the liberal side of coronavirus-era debates — that the key to sound leadership in a pandemic is just to follow the science, to trust science and scientists, to do what experts suggest instead of letting mere grubby politics determine your response.

headline: The Evictions Are Coming. Housing Activists Are Ready.
abstract: Orders to halt evictions in New York expire soon. What happens next?
lead_paragraph: Housing activists in New York have spent much of the year preparing for the end of it. Tenant evictions have been halted or delayed by coronavirus relief measures, for the most part, until January 2021.

headline: The Fashion Awards Get a New Look — and Purpose
abstract: Why the format for this year’s Fashion Awards, or the British equivalent of the Met Gala, got a shake-up in the wake of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Traditionally, the Fashion Awards ceremony is one of the glitziest events on the annual industry calendar. The British answer to the Met Gala, it is celebrated during the first week of December at the Royal Albert Hall in London with several thousand guests and a vast red carpet on which celebrities promenade under a wintry night sky.

headline: The Fate and Fortunes of the Fashion-Adjacent Economy
abstract: Influencers and street-style photographers changed the fashion ecosystem, creating an entirely new way of selling fantasy. Then came a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Tamu McPherson, one of the original street-style stars and a former editor of Grazia Italia, has 319,000 followers on Instagram. For years, many have watched her pose in immaculately styled outfits at runway shows, glittery parties and on vacation. During the fashion weeks in September 2019, Ms. McPherson, who was born in Jamaica and lives now in Milan, flew to New York and back four times to produce content for her Rolodex of clients, which include the jewelry brand Bulgari, the fashion label Etro and the fast-fashion retailer Mango.

headline: ‘A Tsunami of Change’: How Protests Fueled a New Crop of Prosecutors
abstract: The new Los Angeles district attorney announced major changes in the nation’s largest court system, part of a growing movement to rethink criminal justice across the country.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After George Floyd was killed by the police in Minneapolis this summer and America erupted in protest, cash started flooding the race for district attorney of Los Angeles County.

headline: Denny O’Neil Changed the World of Superheroes
abstract: The comic-book writer took stock of a country’s turmoil and put it into his work.
lead_paragraph: The comic-book writer took stock of a country’s turmoil and put it into his work.

headline: Mike Hoare Was a Soldier for Hire Who Led a Spectacularly Failed Coup
abstract: Mad Mike was already in his 60s when he tried to overthrow the Marxist president of the Seychelles.
lead_paragraph: Mad Mike was already in his 60s when he tried to overthrow the Marxist president of the Seychelles.

headline: The Great News Quiz of 2020
abstract: It’s been a newsy year. As 2020 comes to a close, how well do you remember it all?
lead_paragraph: It’s been a newsy year. As 2020 comes to a close, how well do you remember it all?

headline: Tad Jones Lived Alone in Nature, Until Nature Revolted
abstract: He spent decades under the redwoods. Then came this summer’s fire season.
lead_paragraph: He spent decades under the redwoods. Then came this summer’s fire season.

headline: The Afterlife of Breonna Taylor
abstract: People shared her name and image in grief and solidarity, but why didn’t it feel like enough?
lead_paragraph: People shared her name and image in grief and solidarity, but why didn’t it feel like enough?

headline: Tom Seaver Was the Greatest Met Ever. The Mets Still Broke His Heart.
abstract: He put the franchise on the map — and was traded away in return.
lead_paragraph: He put the franchise on the map — and was traded away in return.

headline: A Year Like No Other: 2020 in Pictures
abstract: In a world where life changed seemingly overnight, photographers transformed how they worked, trading intimacy for distance. This is what they captured.
lead_paragraph: In a world where life changed seemingly overnight, photographers transformed how they worked, trading intimacy for distance. This is what they captured.

headline: How Parade Underwear Took Over Instagram
abstract: Free underwear went a long way for this small business.
lead_paragraph: The tagged photo section on the Instagram page for Parade, an underwear start-up founded in fall 2019, shows a surfeit of images of young women modeling brightly colored briefs and bikinis. Many of them pose in studio apartments, stretched out on velvet couches and propped up on dressers. Some press against vinyl shower curtains, donning the neon underwear in mirror selfies. All of them look effortless.

headline: Alex Padilla Will Replace Kamala Harris in the Senate
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California selected Mr. Padilla to serve the final two years of Ms. Harris’s term. Mr. Padilla will be the first Latino senator to represent the state.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Alex Padilla, California’s secretary of state, has been appointed to fill the Senate seat held by Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced on Tuesday, capping months of intense political jockeying among Democratic factions in the state.

headline: The 20 Phrases That Defined 2020
abstract: We picked up a whole new vocabulary this year — some of it words that have been around forever.
lead_paragraph: Happy Blursday! Now quit doomscrolling, grab a quarantini and please keep social distancing.

headline: How Putting on a Mask Raised Naomi Osaka’s Voice
abstract: She used her time away from competing during the pandemic to reflect on the world and her place within it. When the time came to speak, she approached it in her own distinct way.
lead_paragraph: As usual, Naomi Osaka’s postmatch interview struck an emotional chord.

headline: With Each Run, a City Shaken by Racism Is ‘Finding the Greater Good’
abstract: The route William Jones III designed 15 years ago through predominantly Black neighborhoods in Charlottesville, Va., has become the impetus for a diverse running group that’s grown since the summer.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, William Jones III moved with his wife, Yolonda, to Charlottesville, Va. Two years before, Jones, who is Black, had started jogging regularly. But when he looked around Charlottesville, he saw only white people running.

headline: All Alone With a Microphone
abstract: In 2020, pop learned how much simple physical proximity affects music, and how to cope with isolation.
lead_paragraph: The last time I applauded live music with a roomful of strangers was sometime back in February. Applauding was an unremarkable reflex: the punctuation between one song and the next, a wordless expression of approval, clearing the air for the next organized vibrations. In decades of concertgoing I had often heard applause as a distraction, just noise that interrupted the musical experience. But during these long pandemic months I’ve realized that applause is really a bond: listeners communicating with performers, listeners communicating with one another and sometimes musicians applauding what they have just done together, with the audience as both witness and co-conspirator.

headline: Vaccines, Brexit, Biden: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Thousands of Photographs, and a Year Like No Other
abstract: The Year in Pictures project is an annual celebration of photojournalism. In 2020, photographers were living what they captured.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Stimulus Checks, Virus Variant, Breonna Taylor: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: He Wanted to Count Every Vote in Philadelphia. His Party Had Other Ideas.
abstract: When Donald Trump’s campaign tried to overturn the election results in Pennsylvania, Al Schmidt found himself trapped between his party and his principles.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Surprise Ending for Publishers: In 2020, Business Was Good
abstract: With people stuck at home and so many other activities shut down, a lot of reading — or at least a lot of book buying — happened this year.
lead_paragraph: Like everybody else, book publishers will be happy to see the end of 2020. But for many of them, the year has brought some positive news, which has been as welcome as it was surprising: Business has been good.

headline: 50 Years On, the Feminist Press Is Radical and Relevant
abstract: A mission to unearth forgotten female writers became a full-fledged publishing house. It has risen and fallen with the tides of feminism. And it’s not going away.
lead_paragraph: — Gloria Steinem

headline: In 2020, Sports Was About Staying Safe and Speaking Out
abstract: This was the year of the bubble and of players forcefully demanding racial justice.
lead_paragraph: The troubled, truncated 2020 sports season will be remembered as the Year of the Bubble. As a pandemic raged and protests of systemic racism rocked the United States, athletes played on. Those who competed in the controlled environment of a bubble had the most success over the novel coronavirus. Science, for the win.

headline: East Village Fire Damages 128-Year-Old Church
abstract: The fire tore through a vacant building early Saturday morning and then spread to Middle Collegiate Church on Second Avenue. Four firefighters had minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: A fire in a vacant building in the East Village early Saturday morning spread to a 128-year-old church that houses the New York Liberty Bell, destroying its Gothic-style sanctuary and blowing out the Tiffany stained-glass windows that adorned the stone facade, fire and church officials said.

headline: Meritocracy, Silicon Valley and Other Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Vaccine, Brexit, Trump: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The 2020 Good Tech Awards
abstract: This year, technology firms big and small stepped up to help with the Covid-19 pandemic and other thorny challenges.
lead_paragraph: Some years, I have to dig deep to come up with worthy honorees for the Good Tech Awards, my annual column that honors what I consider the most humane and altruistic tech projects of the year.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Teachers’ Politics, Memorable Scents and Text Messages
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked teenagers if they believed teachers should be allowed to wear political symbols on the job, what types of smells trigger powerful memories for them and to write a story about a text message-related image.

headline: Who Is Jeffrey Rosen, Who Will Lead the Justice Dept. for Trump’s Endgame?
abstract: Attorney General William P. Barr’s resignation makes his low-profile deputy the nation’s top law enforcement official for President Trump’s last month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the deputy attorney general, Jeffrey A. Rosen, testified at his confirmation hearing in April 2019, he seemed to pledge to keep politics out of law enforcement decisions, telling the Senate: “I would expect in all prosecutorial matters to proceed on the facts and the law and not any improper political influences.”

headline: Responding to Terrorism in France
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron and others there have been angered by outside criticism.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of two horrific incidents of Islamist terrorism in France, President Emmanuel Macron and many of his countrymen have reacted angrily to criticism from abroad suggesting that French policies, and especially the French version of state-enforced secularism, somehow contributed to the lethal radicalization of a sliver of the country’s large Muslim population.

headline: Columbus Officials Move to Fire Officer in Fatal Shooting of Black Man
abstract: The police chief said Officer Adam Coy “must be terminated immediately” for not quickly turning on a body camera and not providing aid to the man he shot.

headline: A Racial Slur, a Viral Video, and a Reckoning
abstract: A white high school student withdrew from her chosen college after a three-second video caused an uproar online. The classmate who shared it publicly has no regrets.
lead_paragraph: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: Police Drones Are Starting to Think for Themselves
abstract: In one Southern California city, flying drones with artificial intelligence are aiding investigations while presenting new civil rights questions.
lead_paragraph: CHULA VISTA, Calif. — When the Chula Vista police receive a 911 call, they can dispatch a flying drone with the press of a button.

headline: Minnesota Releases Myon Burrell, Man Given Life Sentence After a Murder
abstract: Mr. Burrell, who has maintained his innocence, was 16 when an 11-year-old was killed by a stray bullet. The case posed challenges for Senator Amy Klobuchar during her presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Myon Burrell, 34, was released from a state prison on Tuesday after the Minnesota Board of Pardons commuted his life sentence in a murder case that angered advocates of criminal justice reform and hampered Senator Amy Klobuchar’s presidential campaign.

headline: As Premier League Gates Reopen, a Soothing Soundtrack Returns
abstract: The return of a few thousand fans to Premier League stadiums was a reminder that it’s not only their roars that we’ve missed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The stillness spoke volumes. There were 12 minutes left to play, but the game was over. Manchester United’s players were swarming around Marcus Rashford, scorer of his team’s third goal, the one that had settled matters. West Ham’s were staring blankly at the turf, unsure of quite how things had slipped away from them.

headline: How Cities Lost Control of Police Discipline
abstract: In the chaos of 1960s Detroit, a fledgling police union laid the groundwork for a system that, to this day, constrains discipline for officers accused of misconduct.
lead_paragraph: It took Portland, Ore., almost $1 million in legal fees, efforts by two mayors and a police chief, and years of battle with the police union to defend the firing of Officer Ron Frashour — only to have to bring him back. Today, the veteran white officer, who shot an unarmed Black man in the back a decade ago, is still on the force.

headline: Talking About Race Made Two N.F.L. Teammates Partners in Activism
abstract: The friendship between Ricardo Allen, an undersized cornerback, and Matt Ryan, the heralded quarterback, has shaped the Falcons’ activism against racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: Six years later, the photo remains one of Ricardo Allen’s favorites. Standing in a Dick’s Sporting Goods, the Atlanta Falcons defensive back is smiling ear to ear, having just been promoted to the active roster after spending most of his rookie season on the practice squad. Matt Ryan, the team’s star quarterback, is walking into the frame to shake his hand.

headline: Lawrence Byrne, Former Lawyer for New York Police, Dies at 61
abstract: His younger brother, a police officer, was assassinated by a drug gang at 22, a key moment in the city’s crack epidemic of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence M. Byrne, who as the top lawyer for the New York City Police Department defended several hotly disputed police policies and who also kept alive the legacy of his brother, a rookie police officer who was executed by a drug gang, died on Dec. 6 in Manhattan. He was 61.

headline: Why This Force of 150 Sheriff’s Deputies Is Enforcing Virus Rules
abstract: The New York City Sheriff’s Office, a law enforcement team unknown to most New Yorkers, has been thrust into the spotlight during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When it came time to crack down on Mac’s Public House, the Staten Island bar that has notoriously defied Covid-19 restrictions, the city sent in a law enforcement team in familiar blue officers’ uniforms wearing badges and carrying guns.

headline: What We’re Looking Forward To in 2021
abstract: Amid the challenges of 2020, there are reasons to be optimistic heading into the new year.
lead_paragraph: To say that 2020 was stressful is an understatement, what with a pandemic that the world hasn’t yet emerged from, a sharply divisive U.S. presidential election whose controversies have yet to ebb, social unrest over vast inequalities … need we go on?

headline: Mimi Jones Understood the Power of Public Resistance From a Young Age
abstract: When she was 17, she leapt into a segregated Florida swimming pool — and landed on the front page.
lead_paragraph: When she was 17, she leapt into a segregated Florida swimming pool — and landed on the front page.

headline: Helen Reddy Embodied Her Feminist Anthem, ‘I Am Woman’
abstract: She hit No. 1 with that song, and her own life was proof of what it took to get there.
lead_paragraph: She hit No. 1 with that song, and her own life was proof of what it took to get there.

headline: Mary J. Wilson Was Baltimore’s First Black Senior Zookeeper
abstract: She had no specialized training, but she did have a way with the fiercest and most vulnerable animals.
lead_paragraph: She had no specialized training, but she did have a way with the fiercest and most vulnerable animals.

headline: Just How White Is the Book Industry?
abstract: New data shows the extent of the race problem in the publishing world.
lead_paragraph: New data shows the extent of the race problem in the publishing world.

headline: Diane di Prima Was a Rare Woman Among the Beatniks
abstract: A writer and poet who came of age before the women’s movement, she forged a path toward her own desires.
lead_paragraph: A writer and poet who came of age before the women’s movement, she forged a path toward her own desires.

headline: News Quiz: Iran, Utah, Emergency Approval
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: James Harvey Celebrated the Pleasure of a Packed Movie Theater
abstract: No one was more passionate about the cinema, one more experience we lost this year.
lead_paragraph: No one was more passionate about the cinema, one more experience we lost this year.

headline: Stanley Crouch Was a Critic Who Didn’t Hold Back Punches
abstract: He was an intellectual, a holder of court, a jazz connoisseur, a snob and a contrarian of the Black condition.
lead_paragraph: He was an intellectual, a holder of court, a jazz connoisseur, a snob and a contrarian of the Black condition.

headline: Konrad Steffen Was a Prophet of Climate Change, and its Victim
abstract: The very ice melt he warned would threaten the planet turned out to be his undoing.
lead_paragraph: The very ice melt he warned would threaten the planet turned out to be his undoing.

headline: 2020: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics
abstract: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories from the year.
lead_paragraph: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories from the year.

headline: Sy Sperling Brought Dignity to the Bald
abstract: You didn’t need to be ashamed to join the Hair Club for Men.
lead_paragraph: You didn’t need to be ashamed to join the Hair Club for Men.

headline: Stanley Chera Was a Mogul Who Made Covid-19 Personal for Trump
abstract: The New York real estate titan was in some ways a foil to the president — and was on his mind as he went to Walter Reed.
lead_paragraph: The New York real estate titan was in some ways a foil to the president — and was on his mind as he went to Walter Reed.

headline: John Thompson Was Every Black Boy’s Longed-For Coach
abstract: A stern disciplinarian with a white towel on his shoulder, he made Georgetown’s basketball team champions.
lead_paragraph: A stern disciplinarian with a white towel on his shoulder, he made Georgetown’s basketball team champions.

headline: Shere Hite Explained How Women Orgasm, and Was Hated for It
abstract: “The Hite Report” provoked a sexual revolution. Then came death threats and the paparazzi.
lead_paragraph: “The Hite Report” provoked a sexual revolution. Then came death threats and the paparazzi.

headline: The Lives They Lived
abstract: Remembering some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year.
lead_paragraph: Remembering some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year.

headline: Chadwick Boseman Played Great Men, and Created One
abstract: He built his career portraying giants of American history. But it was a fictional character that transformed him into a kind of political figure.
lead_paragraph: He built his career portraying giants of American history. But it was a fictional character that transformed him into a kind of political figure.

headline: Grant Imahara Was a Geek Before (and After) It Was Cool
abstract: His lifelong love of robotics led to a star turn on “Mythbusters.”
lead_paragraph: His lifelong love of robotics led to a star turn on “Mythbusters.”

headline: Cecilia Chiang Lost Everything in China, and Built It Back in California
abstract: She twice escaped war in China, and eventually landed in an America that was hungry for a new kind of Asian cuisine.
lead_paragraph: She twice escaped war in China, and eventually landed in an America that was hungry for a new kind of Asian cuisine.

headline: Linda Tripp Was Cast as a Villain During the Clinton Impeachment
abstract: Recent years have been kinder to women once judged harshly. But she is unlikely to ever get redemption.
lead_paragraph: Recent years have been kinder to women once judged harshly. But she is unlikely to ever get redemption.

headline: Bill Withers Was a Working Man Who Became a Star
abstract: He went from manual labor to musical phenomenon in a matter of months, but his struggles were always there in the music.
lead_paragraph: He went from manual labor to musical phenomenon in a matter of months, but his struggles were always there in the music.

headline: How the Pandemic Has Been Devastating for Children From Low-Income Families
abstract: In communities struggling with poverty and gun violence, the coronavirus has only inflamed the difficulties that many families already were enduring.
lead_paragraph: Since the coronavirus arrived in her neighborhood in Southeast Washington, D.C., this past spring, 11-year-old Grenderline Etheridge has burst into tears many times for reasons she cannot explain. She has crawled into bed with her mother, something she had not done for a very long time.

headline: What We Learned About California in 2020
abstract: Wednesday: The year’s almost over. It’s been illuminating.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Best Dance of 2020
abstract: Theaters shut down, but dance didn’t. There was dancing in the streets and dancing on screens. Old treasures spilled out of the vaults.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has interrupted and upended the performing arts, but it’s also made something clear about dance: It isn’t beholden to a proscenium stage. Its visibility, through TikTok, Instagram, YouTube and, yes, even people on the street, has been undeniable, even with theaters shut down. Dancers are still performing and choreographers are still creating, be it for a premiere on video, a reinvention of a classic or a combination of the two. While there’s no denying that this is an incredibly difficult time for dance and dance artists, it’s also been a privilege to witness such imagination and resilience.

headline: Relief Deal Would Give Small Businesses a Shot at a Second Loan
abstract: The stimulus package being negotiated in Washington includes $285 billion for a renewed Paycheck Protection Program.
lead_paragraph: Federal lawmakers have agreed to revive the signature small-business relief effort established last spring, committing $285 billion for additional loans under the Paycheck Protection Program and allowing particularly hard-hit companies to get a second loan.

headline: After Much Sparring, Dan Le Batard Is to Leave ESPN in January
abstract: Le Batard, a radio- and television-show host, had recently criticized his bosses for laying off one of his producers, and he has bashed the network’s reluctance to allow commentary on politics.
lead_paragraph: Dan Le Batard, the flame-throwing host of sports television and radio shows, will leave ESPN in January, the company announced Thursday.

headline: Teaching My Kids to Drive While Black
abstract: I’ve raised them to be confident and to advocate for themselves. Now here I was saying, don’t do it with the police.
lead_paragraph: There was lightning, thunder and heavy rain the recent day I accompanied my 18-year-old son and 19-year-old daughter to get their driver’s licenses in Austin, Texas.

headline: Why Did Racial Progress Stall in America?
abstract: The answer may show us the path out of our fractured and polarized present.
lead_paragraph: In the popular narrative of American history, Black Americans made essentially no measurable progress toward equality with white Americans until the lightning-bolt changes of the civil rights revolution. If that narrative were charted along the course of the 20th century, it would be a flat line for decades, followed by a sharp, dramatic upturn toward equality beginning in the 1960s: the shape of a hockey stick.

headline: Police Took Their Son Away. Then the Merchants of Hope Showed Up.
abstract: The police seize and kill young men in Nigeria. Then pastors, lawyers and so-called human rights advocates squeeze money out of their families, promising to help find them.
lead_paragraph: AWKA, Nigeria — In the small family portrait gallery hanging above the television in the cozy home of the Iloanya family, only two framed photographs remain that include the youngest son, Chijioke.

headline: The Met Casts New Light on its Greatest Hits and History
abstract: Goya, Caravaggio, Rubens, Velázquez and more are in skylit splendor in the European galleries. And the museum is acknowledging the shaping force on art of colonialism, slavery, the disenfranchisement of women.
lead_paragraph: “In a dark time, the eye begins to see,” the poet wrote. And after the dark, dark time we’ve been through, this year’s winter solstice, marking the start of slow climb back into light, may carry more metaphorical weight than usual.

headline: Best of Late Night in 2020: The Show Must Go Home
abstract: This year late-night hosts took their shows remote during the pandemic, got serious about America’s biggest problems and prepared to say goodbye to President Trump (eventually).
lead_paragraph: Late-night television has been dominated by the foibles of President Trump for the last four years, but 2020 was perhaps the most daunting of all. Leading up to the November election, hosts tried to expand their focus to other candidates, but when it came to staying topical, Trump continued to dominate the news, especially once the coronavirus forced the country to more actively consider its leadership (or lack thereof) during the crisis.

headline: Robert E. Lee Statue Is Removed From U.S. Capitol
abstract: The statue of the Confederate general will be replaced with one of the civil rights leader Barbara Johns, who led a school walkout in Virginia in 1951.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s statue of the Confederate general Robert E. Lee was removed from its post in the U.S. Capitol on Monday morning, closing a year that saw Confederate statues toppled as the nation reckoned with racism in its history and institutions.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race: A Subway Pledge and Police Scrutiny
abstract: Some New York City candidates vowed to reform the Police Department — or to ride the subway more often than Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: For Cameron Kinley and Navy, the Army Game Can Give 2020 a Highlight
abstract: The rivalry is being played at West Point, the first time the game has not been at a neutral site in 77 years.
lead_paragraph: Cameron Kinley, one of the captains of the Navy football team, read the text on his phone in late October and refused to believe it.

headline: Best Classical Music of 2020
abstract: A host of livestreamed concerts, the sounds of silence, time-hopping quartets and at-home divas were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: “Then everything stopped.”

headline: The Most-Read Stories of 2020
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: What were the most-read stories in The New York Times this year? You may not be surprised to learn that two topics — the election and the pandemic — dominate the list, accounting for 90 of the top 100 entries. Here’s a selection of those stories, plus some other subjects that drew big reader interest.

headline: ‘I Want to Be at the Table When the Next Donald Trump Shows Up’
abstract: What’s your resolution for the next four years?
lead_paragraph: The last four years have been divisive and exhausting. But, for many, they were also a call to change what we can control: our own lives.

headline: How Fake News Is Hatching in Immigrant Communities
abstract: Right-wing conspiracy theories are reaching Asian and Latino voters through platforms like WeChat, KakaoTalk and WhatsApp. Democrats must take notice.
lead_paragraph: In August I was on the phone with my mother, a 70-year-old Korean immigrant, to discuss the upcoming election. In the past, she had complained that President Trump was a lunatic, so I naturally assumed that she would support — or at least be neutral about — Joe Biden.

headline: Just How Dangerous Was Donald Trump?
abstract: He failed to bend the state to his will, but he still broke the country.
lead_paragraph: Throughout Donald Trump’s presidency, there’s been an argument on the left over the sort of threat he poses.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Finds a New Joe Biden After Jim Carrey Exits
abstract: Alex Moffat became the latest “S.N.L.” cast member to portray Biden, following Carrey’s announcement that he was stepping down from the role.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s what you need to know about President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s Inauguration Day.]

headline: When Sports Made Us Happy in 2020
abstract: Sports were not a simple salve for the events of 2020, but they still provided some moments of joy, levity and shared humanity.
lead_paragraph: In a year in which Covid-19 caused more than 1.7 million deaths worldwide, sports competitions took place amid much debate over their necessity and the wisdom of their proceeding during a global health crisis. Did any good come from them?

headline: The Future Was Supposed to Be Better Than This
abstract: Thanksgiving — like the rest of life — just isn’t the same through a screen.
lead_paragraph: At the end of September, the Centers for Disease Control posted a list of recommendations for how Americans can safely celebrate Thanksgiving this year. Eat all the pie you want (but only with your immediate family). Attend parades and big games (but only on TV). Shop till you drop (from the couch). Skip the flight back home (Zoom with your relatives instead). Give thanks (while maintaining social distance).

headline: The 2020 Masters: Dustin Johnson Sets Scoring Record
abstract: Dustin Johnson won the Masters at 20 under, five strokes ahead of Australia’s Cameron Smith and Sungjae Im of South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Dustin Johnson won the 2020 Masters and set a scoring record at 20 under par, two strokes better than the former record, held jointly by Tiger Woods and Jordan Spieth. Johnson, who grew up an hour away, in South Carolina, became the first world No. 1 to win the event since Woods in 2001.

headline: ‘The Far Left Is the Republicans’ Finest Asset’
abstract: An intense battle between moderates and progressives has already spilled into public view.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party is struggling with internal contradictions, as its mixed performance on Election Day makes clear.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Thanksgiving Myth Gets a Deeper Look This Year’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how some Native Americans are re-envisioning Thanksgiving during a year of racial reckoning and Covid-19 deaths.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “The Thanksgiving Myth Gets a Deeper Look This Year” by Brett Anderson

headline: Justice Amy Coney Barrett Hears Her First Supreme Court Argument
abstract: But she did not take part in a pair of unsigned decisions in favor of a Black Lives Matter activist and a prisoner held in abusive conditions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Amy Coney Barrett heard her first Supreme Court argument on Monday, asking assured and probing questions in a case on the Freedom of Information Act.

headline: What the ‘Fresh Prince’ of the ’90s Tells Us About Race Now
abstract: A generation ago, sitcoms with largely Black casts were must-see TV, balancing humor and drama. Will the “Bel-Air” reboot resonate in the era of Black Lives Matter?
lead_paragraph: Two Black teenagers in a Mercedes-Benz are pulled over by the police.

headline: Voters Say Black Lives Matter Protests Were Important. They Disagree On Why.
