abstract: About a fifth of all voters said the protests were the single most important factor in their decision at the ballot box, according to a new survey.
lead_paragraph: The protests that broke out after the police killing of George Floyd in May were some of the biggest racial justice marches organized in decades. In the early weeks, polling showed broad and deep support for them across the country.

headline: Could Limiting Corporate Candidates Hurt Biden’s Diversity Push?
abstract: Narrowing the candidate pool may not lead to the diverse representation the incoming administration is seeking.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joe Biden has made assembling a diverse team a priority. He also faces pressure from the progressive wing of his party to limit corporate influence on hires for his administration, avoiding candidates from Wall Street or company boardrooms. But narrowing the candidate pool that way won’t help create a more representative administration, some suggest.

headline: The Books of the Year
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Every November, after the editors of The Times Book Review have wrapped up their big end-of-year issues, they immediately turn their attention to the following year. They start by creating a working list of nominees for the next iteration of 100 Notable Books — the one that will be published almost a year later.

headline: The Cities Central to Fraud Conspiracy Theories Didn’t Cost Trump the Election
abstract: Yet Philadelphia, Milwaukee and Detroit have become the targets of G.O.P. allegations of voting shenanigans.
lead_paragraph: In Pennsylvania, much of President Trump’s attention since the election has focused on Philadelphia, where he has baselessly insisted there is a “mountain of corruption.” In Michigan, litigation by Mr. Trump’s campaign has concentrated on Detroit, where Republican poll watchers say they felt intimidated by election workers in Black Lives Matter apparel. And in Wisconsin, legal challenges and rumors have circled around Milwaukee, where one internet conspiracy  theory turns on a briefly misplaced flash drive of election results.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 11, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Tuesday about negotiations for a trade agreement between Britain and the European Union misstated the reason for Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s appearance at a ceremony at the Cenotaph. He was commemorating the anniversary of the end of World War I, not honoring coronavirus victims.

headline: Bob Good, Stressing Religious Conservatism, Holds Virginia House Seat for G.O.P.
abstract: He defeated Cameron Webb, a Democratic doctor, after upsetting the Republican incumbent in a show of continued G.O.P. strength on rural terrain.
lead_paragraph: Bob Good, a self-described “biblical conservative” who tied himself closely to President Trump, maintained Republicans’ hold on Virginia’s largest House district early Wednesday, beating back an aggressive challenge by a University of Virginia doctor focused on the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Black Voters Helped Deliver Biden a Presidential Victory. Now What?
abstract: Joe Biden thanked Black voters in his victory speech, saying “you’ve always had my back, and I’ll have yours.” But many remained skeptical that he would usher in real change.
lead_paragraph: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: ‘Muslim Women Are Everything’ Turns the Page on Stereotypes
abstract: Dr. Seema Yasmin’s book, born from her frustration with narrow, one-sided narratives about Muslim women, breaks apart tired old tropes.
lead_paragraph: — Dr. Seema Yasmin, author of “Muslim Women Are Everything”

headline: Sterling Brown Agrees to $750,000 Settlement in Lawsuit Against Milwaukee
abstract: The city would also have to admit wrongdoing in its arrest of the Milwaukee Bucks player, who sued the city after the police used a Taser to subdue him during a confrontation over a parking violation in 2018.
lead_paragraph: The Milwaukee Bucks player Sterling Brown has reached a tentative agreement under which he would receive $750,000 to settle a lawsuit that he filed against the city in 2018, after the police used a Taser to subdue and arrest him in a confrontation over a parking violation.

headline: Grammys Snubs and Surprises: The Weeknd, Luke Combs and BTS
abstract: Some of pop music’s biggest names didn’t get nominations for the 2021 awards, while a diverse list of lesser-known acts filled out the ballot.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé, Taylor Swift and Dua Lipa led the 2021 Grammy nominations on Tuesday, topping a list filled with smaller names (and missing some of the biggest players in pop). Who got left out, and what do the picks say about both the past year in music and where the Grammys are heading? Our chief pop music critic Jon Pareles, pop music critic Jon Caramanica, pop music reporter Joe Coscarelli and music business reporter Ben Sisario discussed the day’s big takeaways, snubs and surprises.

headline: Women and Leadership: Looking Beyond the Global Health Crisis
abstract: We asked female leaders in crucial disciplines to talk about the role women can have in determining what the world looks like after the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the news of Covid-19 broke around the world, it became clear that it would be a health crisis of pandemic proportions. But it also became apparent early on that there was much more at risk than health.

headline: This Is an Election Story That Mentions Neither Biden Nor Trump
abstract: Here are the (other) races and issues our national correspondents are watching.
lead_paragraph: Update: Here are the results of the races and measures we were watching.

headline: Biden Says Trump Is ‘Not Who We Are.’ Do Voters Agree?
abstract: Election Day came to a close with no clear winner, but it affirmed the persistence of deep national divisions.
lead_paragraph: From the start of his 2020 campaign, Joseph R. Biden Jr. insisted that President Trump was an aberration, his norm-breaking, race-baiting tenure anathema to the national character.

headline: Oxford’s 2020 Word of the Year? It’s Too Hard to Isolate
abstract: Instead of crowning a single word as the winner, Oxford Languages looks at the pandemic’s swift and widespread impact on the English language.
lead_paragraph: Oxford Languages’s annual Word of the Year is usually a tribute to the protean creativity of English and the reality of constant linguistic change, throwing a spotlight on zeitgeisty neologisms like “selfie,” “vape” and “unfriend.”

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Lil Buck Feels the Dancing Spirit All Over Again’
abstract: In this lesson, students watch a short film by the dancer Lil Buck, then consider his contention that street dance is fine art and can be “a tool to help bring change.”
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Lil Buck Feels the Dancing Spirit All Over Again,” by Gia Kourlas

headline: Video of Police Beating Black Man in Paris Fuels Debate on Filming Officers
abstract: Footage from security cameras and bystanders suggested the officers had lied about the beating, bolstering critics of a new bill that would restrict circulating videos of security forces.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Video of police officers beating a Black man in Paris caused an outcry in France on Thursday, fueling criticism of a new bill that would place restrictions on sharing footage of security forces as the French authorities grapple with longstanding accusations of police racism and brutality.

headline: A Pattern of Leniency Toward Officers Accused of Misconduct
abstract: A New York Times analysis found that the Police Department routinely reduced or ignored a review board's recommendations for disciplining officers.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: What Went Wrong With Polling? Some Early Theories
abstract: Pollsters thought they had learned from the errors of 2016. It’s possible that they did, and that this election reflects new problems.
lead_paragraph: Asking for a polling post-mortem at this stage is a little bit like asking a coroner for the cause of death while the body is still at the crime scene. You’re going to have to wait to conduct a full autopsy.

headline: In a Swing County in a Swing State, the Verdict Is In: It’s Going to Be Close
abstract: Pinellas County, Fla., has it all: Jeep clubs for Biden, Trump fans who think Fox News is too mainstream — and the potential to decide the race.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]

headline: The Disinformation Is Coming From Inside the White House
abstract: The president and his allies have united right-wing media and internet trolls with false messaging that legitimate vote counting should stop.
lead_paragraph: A disinformation push to subvert the election is well underway, and it is coming straight from President Trump and his allies. The goal: to somehow stop a victory by former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., or, failing that, undermine his legitimacy before he can take office.

headline: A Time to Reflect, and Look Forward
abstract: We asked for your thoughts after this chaotic election. You saw hope, sadness, determination, hopelessness … and reasons to carry on.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Film Club: ‘What Do We Do About Q?’
abstract: Why do people believe in conspiracy theories?
lead_paragraph: Note to Teachers: The film contains some graphic images and disturbing themes. Please watch it in advance to make sure it is appropriate for your students.

headline: A Watchdog Accused Officers of Serious Misconduct. Few Were Punished.
abstract: An analysis by The New York Times found that the N.Y.P.D. has reduced or rejected recommendations for stiff discipline of officers in about 71 percent of 6,900 serious misconduct charges.
lead_paragraph: One New York City police officer was accused of pepper-spraying a woman, then denying her medical treatment while she was handcuffed in a Bronx holding cell.

headline: Who Will Succeed Mayor de Blasio? New York’s Future May Ride on the Answer
abstract: The pandemic has reshaped the 2021 mayoral race, with the city’s economic and health challenges casting a shadow over social justice issues.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Rem Koolhaas Gives Beleaguered City Folk a Trip to the Countryside
abstract: In the last eight months, events have proved the celebrated architect’s premise prescient. By focusing on cities, planners have missed propulsive changes in the hinterlands.
lead_paragraph: This much we knew by Tuesday night: at the electoral level, at least, the divide between America’s cities and its hinterlands seems deeper than ever, with urban and rural having become almost synonyms for blue and red.

headline: Mallory Merk’s Music Feels Different Now
abstract: The 20-year-old singer and model writes about rehab and addiction, but her lyrics describing isolation have taken on new meaning during the pandemic
lead_paragraph: Name: Mallory Merk

headline: ‘A Black Eye’: Why Political Polling Missed the Mark. Again.
abstract: As politics becomes a high-stakes spectator sport, pollsters are reviewing their latest failures. But is part of the problem the public’s overly high expectations of precision?
lead_paragraph: Senator Susan Collins did not lead in a single publicly released poll during the final four months of her re-election campaign in Maine. But Ms. Collins, a Republican, won the election comfortably.

headline: Cabinet Picks, Michigan Vote, Vaccines: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Even From the Desert, Danny Lyon Still Speaks to the Streets
abstract: The indefatigable photographer on the struggles of getting his new film to the next generation of activists.
lead_paragraph: BERNALILLO, N.M. — On Nov. 4, the morning after the election, hope and uncertainty mingled in the air outside the adobe house of the photographer and filmmaker Danny Lyon. Wind ruffled the branches of the golden cottonwoods he planted when he built the place in the early 1970s; it was sunny out. “I’m an eternal optimist,” he said. Mr. Lyon wore a Stetson hat, a blue button-down shirt, a face mask; green suspenders hitched up his jeans. In some parts of the country he has occasionally been mistaken for his University of Chicago classmate Bernie Sanders, for whom he stumped in 2019. “I just wave back at everybody,” he said.

headline: Mitch McConnell, Vaccine, Stock Market: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Stocks, Joe Biden, Thanksgiving Naps: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Mississippi voters approve flag with magnolia instead of Confederate symbol.
abstract: And about 70 percent of voters approved the new flag, which had to include the words “In God We Trust.”
lead_paragraph: Mississippi voters on Tuesday approved a new state flag with a magnolia flower and red, yellow and blue stripes, replacing the one from 1894 that featured the Confederate battle emblem and was decommissioned by lawmakers in June.

headline: Trump vs. Biden on Policing, Crime and Guns
abstract: Some of the candidates’ sharpest policy disagreements have been on these issues. Here’s where they stand.
lead_paragraph: Some of the candidates’ sharpest policy disagreements have been on these issues. Here’s where they stand.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Rethinking the Thanksgiving myth. The fashion of Princess Diana. The cutthroat market for N95 masks. Skiing during a pandemic. And more.
lead_paragraph: Rethinking the Thanksgiving myth. The fashion of Princess Diana. The cutthroat market for N95 masks. Skiing during a pandemic. And more.

headline: A New Political Force Emerges in Georgia: Asian-American Voters
abstract: The Asian-American population in the state has doubled in two decades, and many live in the Atlanta suburbs, which voted for Joseph R. Biden Jr. by large margins.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga. — Four years ago, Maliha Javed, an immigrant from Pakistan, was not paying attention to politics. A community college student in suburban Atlanta, she was busy paying for books and studying for classes. She did not vote that year.

headline: Man Arrested Over Threat to Schumer and Vow to ‘Blow Up’ F.B.I.
abstract: Federal prosecutors said the Staten Island man cited the reactionary anti-government novel “The Turner Diaries.”
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, as votes were still being tallied in one of the most hotly contested elections in United States history, Brian Maiorana took to social media with a dark and violent message, prosecutors say.

headline: There’s Another Runoff in Georgia, and the Winner Gets a Month in Congress
abstract: The winner of Tuesday’s runoff will have the distinction of succeeding John Lewis, a giant of the civil rights era, and serving what would have been the final days of his 17th term in Congress.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Kwanza Hall and Robert M. Franklin Jr. have been campaigning for months, planting signs in grassy medians along busy Atlanta roadways and onto windows of popular brunch spots.

headline: Riz Ahmed Finds the Beat Between Qawwali and House Music
abstract: The actor and rapper, who is shooting the sci-fi thriller “Invasion” with Octavia Spencer, talked about the things that he turned to “at different moments to recalibrate or go back to the well,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Riz Ahmed, the British actor, rapper and activist, tends to speak in paragraphs filled with vivid details. But in his latest role, as a punk-metal drummer who loses his hearing, he learned a different way to express himself.

headline: Padma Lakshmi: Vice President-Elect Kamala Harris Moved Me to Tears
abstract: Imagine how wide the ripples of impact can be when a woman of color is vice president.
lead_paragraph: I was on a hike in Garrison, N.Y., when I heard the news of Kamala Harris and Joe Biden’s victory. I felt elated. Then suddenly I felt this heat welling up from my chest into my throat and it burst out of me in tears I could not control. At first I didn’t even know why I was sobbing.

headline: In Brooklyn, Grand Army Plaza Gets an Intervention
abstract: The Memorial Arch, a granite monument to soldiers and sailors in the plaza, is about to get desperately needed restoration work.
lead_paragraph: In the moments after the Presidential election was called in favor of Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Nov. 7, a jubilant crowd gathered spontaneously in Brooklyn’s Grand Army Plaza, whooping and dancing around the Soldiers’ and Sailors’ Memorial Arch, atop which the bronze allegorical figure of Columbia, representing America, thundered forth in her horse-drawn chariot, flanked by trumpeting figures of winged Victory.

headline: Players Have Been Kneeling for Months. Now What?
abstract: In protests and meetings, Black players have pushed M.L.S. for better representation. Now, as the playoffs open, and with the league’s help, they are focused on follow through.
lead_paragraph: It was the final day of Major League Soccer’s regular season and — right on schedule — the moment for kneeling arrived.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Fruit butters, a classic Palm Springs hotel reopens — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: N.B.A. Players Meet With Pope Francis on Social Justice Efforts
abstract: The players and officials from their union were invited last week to discuss their campaign at the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: A delegation of five N.B.A. players and officials from the players association met privately with Pope Francis at the Vatican on Monday to discuss their efforts toward addressing social justice and economic inequality.

headline: The Challenge of Black Patriotism
abstract: For Black Americans, loving the country and criticizing it have always been inseparable — something other Americans have often struggled to understand.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Democrats Went All Out Against Susan Collins. Rural Maine Grimaced.
abstract: The $180 million Senate contest, a political scientist said, “was like being a local in Woodstock in 1969: When it first started, it was exciting and fun, but by the end, it was muddy and dirty.”
lead_paragraph: RUMFORD, Maine — In the great Democratic heave to remove Susan Collins from her Senate seat in Maine, Matt Gilbert should have been low-hanging fruit.

headline: The Transition Begins
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans have spent weeks, if not months, asking some version of this question: What if President Trump refuses to leave office?

headline: When Political Theater Ditches the Disguises of Fiction
abstract: Four new shows are part of a movement to engage more directly in the debates of our times — sometimes even stealing the script.
lead_paragraph: “How is it politicians and artists have switched jobs?”

headline: The War on Truth Reaches Its Climax
abstract: Trump is telling two big lies, and a third will come soon.
lead_paragraph: I began writing a column for The Times way back in 2000. My beat was supposed to be economics and business. But I couldn’t help noticing that one of that year’s contenders for the presidency was systematically making false claims about his policy proposals. George W. Bush kept insisting that his one-percent-friendly tax cuts were targeted on the middle class, and his plan to privatize Social Security just wished away the system’s obligations to older Americans.

headline: This American Mess
abstract: Thanksgiving is here. Unfortunately, America is all over the place.
lead_paragraph: After a record-setting election and record-setting unemployment claims, within a frightening pandemic and between strict diets of misinformation and disinformation, America is ready to have a great meal with loved ones, put our feet up and breathe … on each other.

headline: How a Minneapolis Suburb Turned Blue, Despite Trump’s Law-and-Order Pitch
abstract: President Trump comfortably carried Chaska, Minn., in 2016. This time, he lost by nine percentage points — a dramatic shift that similarly played out in suburban counties across the country.
lead_paragraph: CHASKA, Minn. — As some protests over police brutality and systemic racism descended into vandalism and looting in Minneapolis over the summer, President Trump insisted that he was the candidate to restore “law and order” to the city. In the nearby suburb of Chaska, Minn., Mike Magusin bristled. In his view, he said, the president had fueled the unrest.

headline: Alison Saar on Transforming Outrage Into Art
abstract: Ahead of her biggest exhibition to date, the sculptor talks about Black Panther imagery, the goddess Yemoja and her own quest to balance anger and beauty.
lead_paragraph: Alison Saar likes to make sculptures of strong Black women standing their ground: broad shoulders, wide stance, unmovable in their convictions. She made a bronze monument of Harriet Tubman that presides over a traffic island at 122nd Street in Harlem. She created a small army of enslaved girls turned warriors, inspired by Harriet Beecher Stowe’s character Topsy, for a major gallery show in Los Angeles. And now Ms. Saar, 64, has a new public sculpture on the Pomona College campus, commissioned by the Benton Museum of Art there: “Imbue,” a 12-foot-tall bronze evoking the Yoruba goddess Yemoja.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Loved Ones With Opposing Political Views, Expectations for an Unusual Winter and Taking Naps
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week, we asked teenagers how important it is to share the same political beliefs as their friends and family, how they are feeling about the impending winter and what are their opinions of napping.

headline: Black Voguers Populate Billboards in a Times Square ‘Midnight Moment’
abstract: The opportunity to stage “Black Magic” in Times Square “was a great proposition to do something transgressive,” said the artist Rashaad Newsome.
lead_paragraph: Just before midnight every evening in December, some 70 digital billboards encircling the gaudy canyon of Times Square will be co-opted for three minutes by slow-motion images of Black voguers, performing dances of resistance, resilience and liberation.

headline: Minneapolis residents say new leaders can’t always solve old problems.
abstract: MINNEAPOLIS — At the site where George Floyd was killed by the Minneapolis police in May, Romell Jernagin said on Friday that persistent issues plaguing his community, such as police brutality and gang activity, were unlikely to be solved by new political leadership.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — At the site where George Floyd was killed by the Minneapolis police in May, Romell Jernagin said on Friday that persistent issues plaguing his community, such as police brutality and gang activity, were unlikely to be solved by new political leadership.

headline: It Had Aerialists, Fire Eaters and Glitter. Is Brooklyn’s Wildest Party Over?
abstract: House of Yes was a revolution in New York nightlife: A space at once wild and safe, challenging and inclusive. Can it ever come back?
lead_paragraph: It was just a year ago that Jacquelyn Feliciano and Jonathan McDonald were swinging upside down through the sticky, neon-colored air at House of Yes.

headline: Is Margaret Thatcher’s Hometown Ready to Put Her on a Pedestal?
abstract: The first woman to be prime minister of Britain is seen as a political colossus abroad, but her 11 years in power have a complicated legacy at home.
lead_paragraph: GRANTHAM, England — Statues of the politically unpalatable have this year been toppled, beheaded and graffitied from the American South to Belgium, and Britain to New Zealand. Not even Winston Churchill was spared.

headline: The Afrobeats Star Davido, an Upbeat Voice in a Turbulent Time
abstract: The 27-year-old musician focuses on lighthearted topics. But one of his latest songs has become an anthem of resistance.
lead_paragraph: Davido — the American-born Nigerian Afrobeats artist David Adedeji Adeleke — has built an international career on songs about love and lust that have collectively amassed more than a billion streams. The album he is releasing on Friday, “A Better Time,” is filled with them.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The transition to Biden’s administration begins.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘From the Front Lines,’ Stories of Resistance and a Movement for Black Lives
abstract: In an interview, Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr., the creator of the podcast, Resistance, talked about the movement unfolding in Nigeria, with regular demonstrations against police brutality.
lead_paragraph: The hashtag #EndSARS first surfaced in 2017 as activists in Nigeria sought to abolish a federal police unit called the Special Anti-Robbery Squad that residents said had misused its power. Known as SARS, demonstrators accused the unit of inflicting violence on residents.

headline: New Yorkers Have Had Enough of ‘Donald From Queens’
abstract: An exhausted city heads to the polls.
lead_paragraph: An anxious quiet settled on New York City like a blanket of fog.

headline: ‘Between the World and Me’: From Page to Stage to Screen
abstract: An all-star cast came together, remotely and in socially distanced shoots, to turn Ta-Nehisi Coates’s memoir into a vivid amalgam of art, music and performance for HBO.
lead_paragraph: Back in August, when Covid-19 had loosened its chokehold on New York City, the director Kamilah Forbes and various cast and crew members gathered in Central Park for a location shoot, one of the first the city had allowed. It was the final week of filming for “Between the World and Me,” a television special based on Ta-Nehisi Coates’s memoir, a meditation on the history and lived experience of Black people in America.

headline: ‘Tokenized’: Inside Black Workers’ Struggles at the King of Crypto Start-Ups
abstract: Coinbase, the most valuable U.S. cryptocurrency company, has faced many internal complaints about discriminatory treatment.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One by one, they left. Some quit. Others were fired. All were Black.

headline: Biden Asked Republicans to Give Him a Chance. They’re Not Interested.
abstract: Joe Biden promised not only to win, but to “restore the soul of the nation.” But the deep divisions that animated President Trump’s tenure show no signs of receding.
lead_paragraph: MASON, Texas — The change at the Sunday prayer service was so subtle it went unnoticed by several congregants. Tucked in between calls for divine health and wisdom, the Rev. Fred Krebs of St. Paul Lutheran Church, who rarely brings up politics, fleetingly mentioned this month’s presidential election.

headline: Some Suburban Strongholds Swing Back to G.O.P. in N.Y. and Across U.S.
abstract: Republicans are ahead in key congressional races in New York State, mirroring a national trend of apparent success in winning back swing districts.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on Joe Biden’s president-elect acceptance speech.]

headline: He’s a Former Cop. He Wants to Be Mayor of New York.
abstract: Over a Zoom call, Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, officially announced his run for New York City mayor.
lead_paragraph: Over a Zoom call, Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, officially announced his run for New York City mayor.

headline: Protests Spread Across U.S. as Votes are Counted
abstract: A wide range of demonstrators gathered on Wednesday night in cities including Portland, Ore., Philadelphia, Chicago and New York. Marchers showed support for counting all votes in the election, for Black Lives Matter and for other causes.
lead_paragraph: A wide range of demonstrators gathered on Wednesday night in cities including Portland, Ore., Philadelphia, Chicago and New York. Marchers showed support for counting all votes in the election, for Black Lives Matter and for other causes.

headline: Video Shows Scene Outside TCF Center in Detroit
abstract: A group of President Trump supporters faced off against Black Lives Matter protesters in Detroit on Thursday morning outside of the TCF Center where the city’s votes had been tallied.
lead_paragraph: A group of President Trump supporters faced off against Black Lives Matter protesters in Detroit on Thursday morning outside of the TCF Center where the city’s votes had been tallied.

headline: ‘Democracy Should Not Be Taken for Granted’
abstract: Readers around the world tell us about the global ripple effect of the U.S. election.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Biden has vowed to turn the page on the ‘aberration’ of Mr. Trump’s foreign policy,” wrote Robert Malley and Philip H. Gordon in the Op-Ed “Trump Still Has 70 Days to Wreak Havoc Around the World.” But is that what people around the world really want?

headline: Residents Feared Low-Income Housing Would Ruin Their Suburb. It Didn’t.
abstract: President Trump told suburban voters that affordable housing would hurt property values and increase crime. The story of one Wisconsin community challenges those assumptions.
lead_paragraph: NEW BERLIN, Wis. — When John Blaguski first heard about a proposal to build an affordable housing complex near his home in the Milwaukee suburb of New Berlin, Wis., his mind drifted to stereotypes of crime-ridden, shoddily constructed projects.

headline: ‘I stay up all night waiting and praying,’ says one protester in Detroit.
abstract: DETROIT — Holly Lambert, part of a thinning crowd in front of the TCF Center in Detroit, has been anxiously awaiting the outcome of the presidential election. She said on Friday that she believed her freedoms were at stake if Joseph R. Biden Jr. were declared the winner.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Holly Lambert, part of a thinning crowd in front of the TCF Center in Detroit, has been anxiously awaiting the outcome of the presidential election. She said on Friday that she believed her freedoms were at stake if Joseph R. Biden Jr. were declared the winner.

headline: Why Stacey Abrams Is Confident Georgia Will Stay Blue
abstract: Democrats agree that Ms. Abrams’s political vision helped deliver Georgia to Joe Biden. In an interview with The New York Times, she lays out why 2020 was the year it came together.
lead_paragraph: After years of close calls, red herrings, and electoral margins that grew closer and closer, Democrats won Georgia in this year’s presidential election for the first time since 1992.

headline: How Joe Biden Won the Presidency
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigned as a sober and conventional presence, concerned about the “soul of the country.” He correctly judged the character of the country, and benefited from President Trump’s missteps.
lead_paragraph: On a January evening in 2019, Joseph R. Biden Jr. placed a call to the mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, a personal friend and political ally who had just announced he would not pursue the Democratic nomination for president.

headline: Photos From The 1960s: Black Americans Voting For the First Time
abstract: As the nation awaits results in what has turned out to be a historic election in a historic year, we look back to the elections after the Voting Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: Today marks the conclusion of a fraught political season like no other, with the denouement coming amid deep divisions over the future of the country and a coronavirus pandemic that has claimed more than 230,000 American lives. It also has come in the wake of a number of police killings, which sparked tremendous unrest and demonstrations against systemic racism and police brutality.

headline: Outcry in France After Police Clear Paris Migrant Camp
abstract: With Parliament considering a security bill, officers used tear gas and dispersal grenades in their response to a camp set up in a prominent square to protest against a lack of housing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The police cleared out a temporary migrant camp in central Paris, forcing people out of tents, chasing them in the streets and firing tear gas in a crackdown that fueled growing outrage over the government’s tough new security policies.

headline: Nigeria Goes on Offensive Against Youth Protesting Police Brutality
abstract: Young people staged the biggest anti-government uprising in a generation, triggered by relentless police brutality. Rattled, politicians are promising reforms, but using repressive tactics, large and small.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Nigeria’s leaders have made a show of responding to the demands of a massive youth-led uprising over police brutality that recently brought the country to a standstill and captured global attention.

headline: Taxes, Heroin and Statehood: A Glimpse Into This Year’s Ballot Measures
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has put a dent in the signature-gathering process, but voters still managed to put forward dozens of measures nationwide.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If ever there was a doubt about the coronavirus’s impact on American democracy, look no further than the sharp decline in citizen initiatives this year. There are 38 such measures slated across the country, around half the level in the last presidential election, when there were 72.

headline: Gay in Nigeria, Black Male in America
abstract: I learned how to carry myself to protect my safety back home, only to come to the U.S. and face a different danger.
lead_paragraph: I came to the United States in 2019 as a scholar-at-risk fellow at Harvard University. After I was kidnapped and tortured in Nigeria for being gay and daring to speak openly about it America offered me refuge. But this spring after videos of the killings of Ahmaud Arbery and George Floyd surfaced, I’m coming to terms with the fact that the country that promised me safety is one where Black men like me face a different kind of danger.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Anti-Harassment Official Accused of Racist Rants
abstract: The official was relieved of his command after City Council investigators amassed evidence that he posted vitriolic messages online under the name “Clouseau.”
lead_paragraph: For more than 20 years, an online chat board called the Rant has been the place where New York City police officers have gone in secret to complain about their jobs — not infrequently using blatantly racist and misogynistic language.

headline: N.F.L. Announces the Weeknd for Its Super Bowl Halftime Show
abstract: The hitmaker, who blends R&B and cutting-edge grooves, will perform at a show that may have to bend to pandemic precautions.
lead_paragraph: The Weeknd, the Canadian pop star, has been chosen to play the halftime show at the Super Bowl in Tampa, Fla., in February, a performance that may face challenges because of pandemic restrictions.

headline: Facebook Struggles to Balance Civility and Growth
abstract: Employees and executives are battling over how to reduce misinformation and hate speech without hurting the company’s bottom line.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the tense days after the presidential election, a team of Facebook employees presented the chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, with an alarming finding: Election-related misinformation was going viral on the site.

headline: How Hasan Piker Took Over Twitch
abstract: The 29-year-old progressive political commentator has risen to the top of the platform after 80-plus hours of live election coverage.
lead_paragraph: On election night, Hasan Piker, 29, was dressed in a navy blue “Bernie 2020” sweatshirt and a “Democracy Now!” baseball hat when he plopped down in a chair to address his digital audience.

headline: LaTasha Benton, Who Pitched In Despite Obstacles, Dies at 43
abstract: She’d had strokes and two kidney transplants, but she remained active in social justice causes in Lexington, Ky. She died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Gift Giving Will Be Different This Year
abstract: Finances may be tight, but shopping will go on. And at least one person is thinking of reviving Christmas cards.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus already has changed the way we work, shop, spend leisure time and see friends and extended family. Now it is altering the way we think about gifts — and giving them — this holiday season.

headline: ‘A Long Time Coming’: Black Women Celebrate Harris’s Ascension
abstract: As Kamala Harris heads toward the highest levels of power, many rejoiced and saw her achievement as a particularly poignant reminder to Black girls that anything is possible.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live analysis of the Biden inauguration.]

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Lessons from South Korea’s vaccine campaign.
lead_paragraph: As scientists dealing with Covid-19 worry about the rise of the anti-vaccine movement, South Korea’s response to fighting misinformation may offer the world a model for when vaccines become widely available.

headline: ‘Count Every Vote’: Protests Over Ballot Tallies Sweep Through U.S. Cities
abstract: Protesters marched in Minneapolis, New York and elsewhere against President Trump, while some of his supporters gathered near a Phoenix building where crucial votes were being counted.
lead_paragraph: [As he prepares to assume the presidency, Biden confronts the ultimate test of his approach to governing.]

headline: The Rainbow Man Brings His Mishmash Appeal to TikTok
abstract: Mark Kanemura’s ebullient videos showcase what’s appealing about TikTok: escapism and originality, rather than slick perfection.
lead_paragraph: Need a hit of serotonin right about now?

headline: No, there is not a lot of good evidence behind the Trump suits.
abstract: Almost from the moment the election ended, President Trump and his allies have relentlessly attacked the integrity of both the voting and vote counting, a narrative they have sought to advance in nearly 20 lawsuits filed in the past eight days.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the moment the election ended, President Trump and his allies have relentlessly attacked the integrity of both the voting and vote counting, a narrative they have sought to advance in nearly 20 lawsuits filed in the past eight days.

headline: Chinese State Media Reacts to Biden Victory With Cautious Optimism
abstract: Propaganda outlets said a Biden presidency would most likely restore stability to frayed U.S.-China relations, but warned that tensions would continue.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese state news media reacted with cautious optimism to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the United States presidential election, expressing hope that he would stabilize the fast-deteriorating relations between the two countries.

headline: Macron’s Rightward Tilt, Seen in New Laws, Sows Wider Alarm in France
abstract: One bill would reach into Muslim life, and another would place new restrictions on filming of police. Critics say they’re part of a drift toward repressive government policies.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A rightward push by the French government is alarming civil liberties advocates in France and raising questions about President Emmanuel Macron’s positioning ahead of an expected electoral challenge from the far right in 2022.

headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Latest Updates
abstract: Upper Manhattan and the southern part of Staten Island face stricter restrictions as officials battle a second wave of the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: With New Show, Tschabalala Self Explores Black American Identity
abstract: The 30-year-old artist is having her first major gallery exhibition in New York City.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — It was warm for October, the sun flooding Tschabalala Self’s paint-splattered studio here, and the last piece left to finish for her first major gallery exhibition in New York City was giving the artist “a lot of trouble.”

headline: Even With a New President, Sports at the White House Won’t Be the Same
abstract: The politicization of the ceremonial visit to the Rose Garden by champions is one sign the presidential connection to sports is fraught, maybe inalterably.
lead_paragraph: Awe and tension filled the air on that sunny afternoon in the Rose Garden four years ago this week. I could feel it, and so could everyone else on hand: The sense of celebration mixed with a gnawing worry for the future.

headline: False News Targeting Latinos Trails the Election
abstract: Rampant falsehoods evolved online on Wednesday, intended to make Spanish speakers question the unfolding election results and believe that President Trump was being robbed of victory.
lead_paragraph: [Joe Biden has won the 2020 U.S. presidential election. Read our story]

headline: Fatal Shooting of 2 Black Teenagers by Florida Deputy Is Under Investigation
abstract: Relatives are demanding answers about the shooting deaths of Angelo Crooms, 16, and Sincere Pierce, 18, by a sheriff’s deputy in Cocoa, Fla.
lead_paragraph: The authorities are investigating the fatal shooting by a Florida sheriff’s deputy of two Black teenagers who were in a moving car during an encounter with law enforcement.

headline: Burna Boy’s Cry for Nigeria, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Jade Bird, Nothing, Fred Hersch and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: ‘A New Day in America’: Biden Victory Prompts Spontaneous Celebrations
abstract: Scenes of jubilation spread minutes after news outlets had called the election for Joseph R. Biden Jr. They lasted into the night.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — People shouting from their windows, ringing cowbells on their porches and blaring car horns in the streets: As the news spread through cellphones and television screens that Joseph R. Biden Jr. had won the presidential election, spontaneous celebrations erupted within minutes across the nation, and many persisted as street parties into the night.

headline: Democrat Warnock Leads Loeffler as Georgia Senate Race Heads to Runoff
abstract: The Rev. Dr. Raphael Warnock, a Democrat, was leading Senator Kelly Loeffler after a race in which she was bloodied by a fellow Republican. The race will be decided in a January runoff.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Raphael G. Warnock, a Democrat, emerged as the leader Tuesday over Senator Kelly Loeffler, a Republican, in a special election to fill a Georgia Senate seat that will now be decided in a January runoff.

headline: In a Year of Protest Cries, Now It’s ‘Count Every Vote!’ and ‘Stop the Steal!’
abstract: Demonstrations have broken out all year long across America, and they have not let up as states tally ballots after Election Day.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In downtown Portland, Ore., they shouted, “Count every vote!” At the Detroit convention center, they urged those tallying ballots to stop. And outside a Philadelphia vote-counting site, they said they just wanted to watch.

headline: Buffeted by Trump, China Has Little Hope for Warmer Relations With Biden
abstract: Many in Beijing believe that the United States will remain hostile to the country’s rise, regardless of who is president.
lead_paragraph: All along China’s leaders publicly professed indifference to the American presidential election, having concluded that no matter who won, the United States would remain irreconcilably opposed to the country’s rise.

headline: What Happened When a School District Banned Thin Blue Line Flags
abstract: Some students in a mostly white New York suburb said the flag made them feel unsafe. Banning it prompted accusations of political bias.
lead_paragraph: In late October, administrators in a suburban New York school district told employees that some of their apparel was making students feel uncomfortable, and even threatened.

headline: Biden Can’t Be F.D.R. He Could Still Be L.B.J.
abstract: He has the power to make transformational progress look like “C’mon Man” common sense. Will he use it?
lead_paragraph: Let’s never do that again.

headline: With Trench Warfare Deepening, Parties Face Unsettled Electoral Map
abstract: Voters delivered a convincing victory for Joe Biden, but a split decision for the two parties. Now Democrats and Republicans face perhaps the most up-for-grabs electoral landscape in a generation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s two major parties had hoped the 2020 presidential election would render a decisive judgment on the country’s political trajectory. But after a race that broke records for voter turnout and campaign spending, neither Democrats nor Republicans have achieved a dominant upper hand.

headline: France to Rewrite Contentious Security Bill on Sharing Images of Police
abstract: Opposition to a provision that restricts circulating images of on-duty police officers had ballooned over the past week, sending tens of thousands of protesters into streets around France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French lawmakers will completely rewrite a legislative provision restricting the sharing of images of police officers that was pushed by the government but has faced fierce opposition over the past week, a top official in President Emmanuel Macron’s party announced on Monday, in an effort to defuse a mounting crisis over the measure.

headline: In ‘Small Axe,’ Steve McQueen Explores Britain’s Caribbean Heritage
abstract: The director’s ambitious anthology series for Amazon and the BBC is his first film work about Black life in Britain. “I needed to understand myself, where I came from,” he said.
lead_paragraph: It took Steve McQueen a long time to make a film about Black life in Britain.

headline: What We Know About Sidney Powell, the Lawyer Behind Wild Voting Conspiracy Theories
abstract: A frequent guest on conservative radio and TV, she briefly became a public face of the Trump campaign before being cut loose on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Until late last week, most Americans who aren’t regular consumers of right-wing talk radio and cable news probably had not heard of Sidney Powell, an appellate lawyer from Texas who joined President Trump’s legal team earlier this month as it undertook a fruitless pursuit to prove that fraud cost him the election.

headline: A Gift Guide Featuring Black-Owned Businesses, for Those Who Like to Pamper
abstract: Do you want to be a conscientious shopper? Right this way.
lead_paragraph: While the holidays may seem different this year one thing that won’t change is that Americans love to buy things. Despite the fact that millions of Americans have lost their jobs this year, spending on consumer goods from January to September increased by 7.2 percent, according to the Bureau of Economic Analysis.

headline: Choose a Gift That Changes Lives
abstract: Educate a girl. Send a young person to college. Restore a person’s sight.
lead_paragraph: This will be a painful holiday season in many households, with fewer people hugging and handing out gifts. But if you’re feeling that the holidays have been “canceled” and you’re struggling to find hope and meaning this season, have I got some uplifting ideas for you!

headline: Can We Make Our Robots Less Biased Than We Are?
abstract: A.I. developers are committing to end the injustices in how their technology is often made and used.
lead_paragraph: On a summer night in Dallas in 2016, a bomb-handling robot made technological history. Police officers had attached roughly a pound of C-4 explosive to it, steered the device up to a wall near an active shooter and detonated the charge. In the explosion, the assailant, Micah Xavier Johnson, became the first person in the United States to be killed by a police robot.

headline: ‘I Still Believe in Our City’: A Public Art Series Takes On Racism
abstract: After a wave of anti-Asian discrimination, the artist Amanda Phingbodhipakkiya wanted to “turn these hurts into something beautiful.” Her panels will transform a Brooklyn subway station.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, New Yorkers commuting through the Atlantic Avenue-Barclays Center subway station will find it transformed with vibrant portraits of Black, Asian and Pacific Islander people along with anti-discriminatory messages like “I did not make you sick” and “I am not your scapegoat.”

headline: How a Brooklyn Sisterhood of Black Women Became National Power Brokers
abstract: Ten years ago, the Olori Sisterhood was a small-time “political sorority.” Now they’re ready for a seat at the table.
lead_paragraph: Last November, when Democratic presidential candidates were still jockeying for the nomination, before the coronavirus pandemic killed more than 250,000 Americans and fervent protests against police brutality swept the nation, Senator Kamala Harris of California appeared before a group of mostly Black women in South Carolina to file officially for the state’s critical primary.

headline: Beyoncé, Taylor Swift and Dua Lipa Dominate 2021 Grammy Nominations
abstract: The major categories include some surprising, lesser-known names and notable absences as a Recording Academy in transition plans its pandemic awards show.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé, Taylor Swift and Dua Lipa dominate the nominations for the 63rd annual Grammy Awards, leading a diverse if somewhat scattershot collection of artists for January’s edition of music’s top awards show.

headline: Stream These 15 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in November
abstract: Like Brad Pitt and Jake Gyllenhaal? How about Wednesday Addams? Catch them on the streaming service while you can.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Brad Pitt and Jake Gyllenhaal will be disappointed to learn that Netflix is losing not one, but two vehicles for each star in November (and more than that for Pitt if you count all the “Ocean’s” movies that are leaving, at least temporarily). Elsewhere, we have cop movies, a Broadway musical, a musical documentary (?), indies aplenty and Oscar nominees galore. (Dates identify the last day a title will be available.)

headline: Business Leaders, Drawn Into Fray by Trump, See Chance to Step Back
abstract: Since President Trump took office, corporate America has been thrust into the culture wars like never before. The atmosphere would probably be different with a Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: From the moment President Trump took office, big businesses were thrust into the culture wars like never before.

headline: Trump, Covid-19, Terrorism: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How ‘Defund the Police’ Roiled Competitive Races in New York
abstract: Democrats are debating whether the party’s stances alienated moderates, but progressives like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez challenged that narrative.
lead_paragraph: The feelings of betrayal seemed to begin about a year ago, when Representative Max Rose, a first-term Democratic congressman representing a swing district that includes Staten Island, voted in favor of impeaching President Trump.

headline: Abolitionist Is Earliest Black Londoner Honored With Blue Plaque
abstract: Ottobah Cugoano, who became a writer and campaigner after surviving slavery in the West Indies, has been honored by a heritage program that long focused on white men.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An 18th-century antislavery campaigner and author, Ottobah Cugoano, has become the earliest Black figure to be honored with one of London’s iconic blue plaques, the heritage organization that manages the program said on Friday.

headline: What These Athletes Learned From Their Pandemic Pauses
abstract: The coronavirus disrupted lives around the world and sent the gymnast Sunisa Lee, the swimmer Rudy Garcia-Tolson, the Seattle Storm’s Breanna Stewart and the Seattle Mariners’ Kyle Lewis on unexpected journeys.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic had been blanketing countries and devastating populations for months by the time the American sports landscape was touched in mid-March. As positive cases were confirmed in professional athletes, leagues shut down completely, postponed entire seasons and, in the case of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, delayed culminating events until 2021.

headline: Thousands rally in Washington as clashes erupt.
abstract: Thousands of supporters of President Trump protesting the outcome of the election rallied in Washington on Saturday, earning a brief drive-by visit from the president himself, in a day of orderly demonstrations that devolved into violence as the night wore on.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of supporters of President Trump protesting the outcome of the election rallied in Washington on Saturday, earning a brief drive-by visit from the president himself, in a day of orderly demonstrations that devolved into violence as the night wore on.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: India’s cases are falling — for now.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, India looked like a coronavirus disaster zone, with nearly 100,000 new infections a day and deaths shooting up. Today, reported infections, deaths and the share of people testing positive have all fallen significantly.

headline: How the Owner of a Coffee Shop With a Community Fridge Spends Sundays
abstract: Zenat Begum is into self-care, which includes burning incense, setting intentions and binge-watching ‘Girlfriends.’
lead_paragraph: You can be an entrepreneur and also an activist. Just ask Zenat Begum, the founder and owner of Playground Coffee Shop, which used to be a hardware store in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, that was run by her family.

headline: Trading Blame and Worry, Notre Dame Grapples With Celebration’s Fallout
abstract: The university’s president promised strict punishments for students who break virus protocols. But his credibility on campus is wearing thin.
lead_paragraph: As soon as the final whistle blew, signaling that last-gasp laterals would not prevent the Notre Dame football team from its biggest win in a generation — a 47-40 double-overtime defeat of top-ranked Clemson on Saturday night — a can’t-look-away scene unfolded at Notre Dame Stadium.

headline: For a Trump Fan, a Week When Victory Ebbed Away
abstract: Nick Rocco, a passionate Trump follower in the Democratic bastion of Massachusetts, slowly realized it wasn’t going his way.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Mass. — Nick Rocco went into Election Day amped up. A 26-year-old hair stylist, he spent the past few months campaigning for President Trump, taking special satisfaction in offending Biden supporters.

headline: Students Vote and Work the Polls, Despite the Pandemic
abstract: Students are fighting for voting access and helping at the polls, despite the difficulties of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Historically, most young Americans don’t vote. In the 2016 presidential election, fewer than half of eligible voters between 18 and 29 cast a ballot.

headline: How misinformation can affect Facebook employees’ morale.
abstract: According to internal surveys, ‘decision-making related to hate speech and misinformation’ has been a factor in employee sentiment.
lead_paragraph: How much does Facebook’s handling of misinformation affect its employees’ morale?

headline: What Does It Mean to Love Your Country?
abstract: Readers tell us how their faith in the American ideal has fared this election season.
lead_paragraph: In her essay, “Don’t Give Up on America,” Marilynne Robinson describes the “deep if sometimes difficult affinity” she has for her country. At the end of a long, contentious election season, it’s not surprising that Ms. Robinson has become disillusioned with that love affair. “Resentment displaces hope and purpose the way carbon monoxide displaces air,” she writes.

headline: U.N. Panel: Technology in Policing Can Reinforce Racial Bias
abstract: The use of artificial intelligence and facial recognition programs may lead communities to lose trust in law enforcement, human rights experts say.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Police departments across the United States have been drawn to the use of digital technology for surveillance and predicting crime on the theory that it will make law enforcement more accurate, efficient and effective. The alarming reality, United Nations human rights experts warned on Thursday, is that they risk reinforcing racial bias and abuse.

headline: What to Expect From Facebook, Twitter and YouTube on Election Day
abstract: The sites are key conduits for communication and information. Here’s how they plan to handle the challenges facing them before, on and after Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]

headline: Canada Hasn’t Slept Well Since the U.S. Election
abstract: Canadians have been ripping their cuticles off while they wait for the United States to pick its next president.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It was Robin Williams, of all people, who coined the phrase that I’ve heard repeatedly in Toronto over the past few weeks.

headline: Businesses Trying to Rebound After Unrest Face a Challenge: Not Enough Insurance
abstract: Some activists have downplayed the damage to businesses from looting and arson in racial justice protests around the country. But some small entrepreneurs are struggling.
lead_paragraph: KENOSHA, Wis. — It’s a prominent refrain these days from activists in the aftermath of arson and looting — businesses have insurance. Buildings can be repaired. Broken glass is a small price to pay in a movement for justice.

headline: Abby Phillip Is Next-Gen CNN
abstract: In an election dominated by fast-talking policy dudes, her deliberate commentary and context stood out.
lead_paragraph: “Black women did that,” said Abby Phillip, a CNN political correspondent.

headline: Should Teachers Be Allowed to Wear Political Symbols?
abstract: How should districts define political speech? Is a so-called thin blue line flag an example of political speech? What about a Black Lives Matter T-shirt?
lead_paragraph: Many school districts have policies prohibiting employees from expressing political speech while carrying out their professional duties. For example, in such districts teachers can have a “Trump 2020” yard sign in front of their home, but they cannot wear a similar T-shirt to school. But sometimes determining what is, and what is not, political speech can be more tricky.

headline: Biden’s Cabinet and Senior Advisers
abstract: President Biden’s nominees are slowly making their way through Senate confirmation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden has chosen a team of cabinet members and senior advisers who bring government experience and expertise in their fields to confront four fronts of challenges: getting control of Covid-19, systemic racism, the economy and climate change.

headline: Carl Lentz, Pastor to Celebrities, Is Fired From Hillsong Church
abstract: Mr. Lentz has been a rising star on the evangelical stage thanks in part to his connection to the singer Justin Bieber. In a statement, he said he had been “unfaithful in my marriage.”
lead_paragraph: Carl Lentz, a prominent Christian pastor known for his celebrity connections and outspoken position in support of the Black Lives Matter movement, was fired on Wednesday from Hillsong East Coast, the New York-based branch of the international megachurch.

headline: On Running While Black, With More Hope Than Before
abstract: As Black Lives Matter signs popped up in recent months, our columnist grew less wary of running in predominantly white neighborhoods. But is that optimism premature?
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The bloom of the Black Lives Matter signs. That is what my son and I saw as we jogged through our mostly white neighborhood. Everywhere we looked, we could see what felt like change.

headline: Are Cities Our Greatest Invention?
abstract: "Metropolis,” by Ben Wilson, examines the history of civilizations and the “connective tissue” that makes them thrive.
lead_paragraph: METROPOLIS A History of the City, Humankind’s Greatest InventionBy Ben Wilson

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: France and Germany tussle over defense policy.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What Biden’s Win Could Mean for New York: 5 Takeaways
abstract: A Biden presidency could bring more recovery funds to the city and boost plans to build a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: Leaders in New York City have been counting on one thing to help the city recover from the pandemic: a Joseph R. Biden Jr. presidency.

headline: A Country Facing High Joblessness, Virus Rates and Anxiety Picks Its President
abstract: Voters describe a fundamental unease about America’s future.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — A nation with nearly 8 percent unemployment and mourning more than 231,000 Covid deaths, where four out of five Americans say they feel nervous about the country’s future, gets a final chance Tuesday to decide which candidate is best equipped to lead it past those daunting numbers.

headline: London Police to Recruit 40% of Officers From Minority Backgrounds
abstract: The Metropolitan Police also announced a review of all road traffic stops, as Commissioner Cressida Dick acknowledged that her force was “not free from racism or discrimination.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The London Metropolitan Police will aim to hire 40 percent of new recruits from Black, Asian and other minority backgrounds by 2022, Mayor Sadiq Khan said on Friday, the centerpiece of a sweeping effort to make the city’s main police force more representative as it tries to address accusations of racism and discriminatory practices against minorities.

headline: Tucker Carlson Dared Question a Trump Lawyer. The Backlash Was Quick.
abstract: The president’s allies quickly closed ranks behind Sidney Powell and her pro-Trump conspiracy theory, accusing the Fox host of betrayal.
lead_paragraph: For more than a week, a plain-spoken former federal prosecutor named Sidney Powell made the rounds on right-wing talk radio and cable news, facing little pushback as she laid out a conspiracy theory that Venezuela, Cuba and other “communist” interests had used a secret algorithm to hack into voting machines and steal millions of votes from President Trump.

headline: How Democrats Missed Trump’s Appeal to Latino Voters
abstract: The election was a referendum on Trump’s America, but plenty of Latino voters liked it just fine.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Democrats thought it would be enough.

headline: How Hispanic Voters Swung Miami Right
abstract: Many expected that liberal young Hispanic voters would propel a Democratic wave. But Miami, a city where Hispanics hold the levers of power, confounded expectations.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As the mayor of reliably Democratic Miami-Dade County in Florida, Carlos A. Gimenez, a Republican, was a pragmatist who avoided partisan politics and in 2016 voted for Hillary Clinton. But after President Trump’s election, things started to change.

headline: Macy’s, Saks and Small Stores Brace for Potential N.Y.C. Unrest
abstract: On the eve of Election Day, stores in the city’s Manhattan shopping districts boarded up, reflecting an anxiety among retailers across the nation.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]

headline: Trump, Trying to Cling to Power, Fans Unrest and Conspiracy Theories
abstract: The president’s refusal to concede has entered a more dangerous phase as he blocks his successor’s transition, withholding intelligence briefings, pandemic information and access to the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s refusal to concede the election has entered a more dangerous phase as he stokes resistance and unrest among his supporters and spreads falsehoods aimed at undermining the integrity of the American voting system.

headline: Layoffs at Police Watchdog Agency Prompt Claims of Retaliation
abstract: The agency said it was restructuring to hire more investigators, but employees said the officials were all critics of the agency’s performance.
lead_paragraph: Four senior officials at the New York City agency that examines allegations of police misconduct were laid off abruptly on Thursday in what officials described as a restructuring meant to expand its investigative muscle.

headline: Ex-Police Officer Charged With Manslaughter in 2017 Killing of Suspect
abstract: The San Francisco police rookie, Christopher Samayoa, was on his fourth day of field training when he shot and killed Keita O’Neil, an unarmed carjacking suspect, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A former rookie police officer in San Francisco was charged with manslaughter on Monday, nearly three years after he fatally shot an unarmed carjacking suspect, the authorities said.

headline: Hong Kong, Gun Crime in Britain, WeChat: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The U.S. Open Is Looking a Bit Closed
abstract: Because of the coronavirus, there will be no fans in the stands and several top players just won’t be coming.
lead_paragraph: Kristie Ahn tried to block out the din.

headline: Families Priced Out of ‘Learning Pods’ Seek Alternatives
abstract: Should public school systems provide teachers for small-group instruction?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Shy Rodriguez heard about one of the hottest trends in education during the pandemic — “learning pods,” where parents hire teachers for small-group, in-home instruction — she knew immediately it was something she could never afford for her sons.

headline: The Billionaire Behind Hudson Yards Thinks New York Is Too Expensive
abstract: Stephen Ross, a friend of President Trump, talks about politics, philanthropy and his pet peeve: wastefulness.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Ross — the billionaire real estate developer who founded Related Companies, owns the Miami Dolphins and has an interest in brands including SoulCycle and Equinox — is a man of contradictions.

headline: In Ohio, a Father and Stepdaughter Show the Political Shifts in the Trump Era
abstract: He’s a union worker and former Democrat now solidly behind President Trump. She’s a onetime Republican now worried about her sons growing up in the Trump era. Family get-togethers can be difficult.
lead_paragraph: NEWTON FALLS, Ohio — An hour after Kamala Harris was announced as Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate last week, Dan Moore sat in his living room watching the Fox News coverage of her selection.

headline: Salt Lake City Suspends Use of Police Dogs in Arrests After Black Man Is Bitten
abstract: The Police Department said that the use of the dogs in arrests would be suspended until the city could review its policies and practices.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Officer who ordered police dog to bite a Black man is charged with assault.]              The authorities in Salt Lake City suspended the use of police dogs in arrests after one bit a Black man who was on one knee with his hands in the air during an incident in April, the mayor said on Wednesday.

headline: After Three Years of Attacking L.G.B.T.Q. Rights, Trump Suddenly Tries Outreach
abstract: L.G.B.T.Q. advocates say the president has tried to divide their coalition by targeting transgender people in policy rollbacks.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our daily updates on the latest presidential election polls.]

headline: Facebook Must Better Police Online Hate, State Attorneys General Say
abstract: The call from 20 state officials adds to the rising pressure facing Mark Zuckerberg and his company.
lead_paragraph: Twenty state attorneys general on Wednesday called on Facebook to better prevent messages of hate, bias and disinformation from spreading, and said the company needed to provide more help to users facing online abuse.

headline: Texas Governor Proposes Freezing Taxes in Cities That ‘Defund’ Police
abstract: Reacting to a vote in Austin to cut millions from its police budget, Gov. Greg Abbott is backing legislation to deprive cities of control over a major revenue source if they follow suit.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Slamming the Austin City Council for cutting millions of dollars from its police budget, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas proposed legislation on Tuesday that would punish any Texas city that does the same by denying it the power to increase property taxes.

headline: Instead of Evolving as President, Trump Has Bent the Job to His Will
abstract: In a 40-minute phone call this week, Mr. Trump struggled to describe how he has changed in office. “I think I’ve just become more guarded than I was four years ago,” he said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a man on the edge of history, President Trump sounded calm and relaxed. If he believes that he is on the verge of losing, he betrayed no sign of it. Instead, he trotted out one of his favorite polls, boasted about his popularity with Republican voters and talked about his convention’s television ratings.

headline: Black Chefs Are Landing More Cookbook Deals. Is That Enough?
abstract: African-American food writers are seeing more interest among publishers, but the ones who have been burned by the experience warn that the industry’s problems go further than advances and paychecks.
lead_paragraph: When Nicole Taylor’s agent suggested three years ago that she write a Juneteenth cookbook, Ms. Taylor, a food writer, shelved the idea. She didn’t think any publisher would buy it.

headline: Kenosha Tells Us More About Where the Right Is Headed Than the R.N.C. Did
abstract: The conservative media’s embrace of Kyle Rittenhouse speaks volumes about its priorities.
lead_paragraph: The most revealing thing to happen in conservative politics this week did not involve the Republican National Convention, at least not directly. Instead, it took place in Kenosha, Wis., in the aftermath of a shooting on Tuesday night that killed two people and wounded a third.

headline: What’s It Like to Live With a Beauty Queen? Ask Miss Universe, She Rooms With Miss USA
abstract: The two pageant winners traditionally share a New York apartment, but that has taken on new meaning in the pandemic, since neither can travel for her usual appearances.
lead_paragraph: When Zozibini Tunzi moved into the Midtown apartment where Cheslie Kryst was living last December, some roommate tension might have been expected.

headline: ‘Godspell’ in 2020: Masks, Partitions and a Contactless Crucifixion
abstract: The first professional musical staged in the United States since theater shut down is also a de facto public health experiment.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — And on the eighth day, Jesus wept.

headline: Revisionist History at the R.N.C.
abstract: On the first night of the Republican National Convention, speaker after speaker tried to revise reality.
lead_paragraph: Good morning and welcome to a special convention recap edition of On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics.

headline: This Is Where I Stand
abstract: The power of conservative radicalism in an age of upheaval.
lead_paragraph: Radicals are not my cup of tea, but I’m grateful for them. The radicals who brought us Occupy Wall Street and the Bernie Sanders campaign gave the problem of income inequality a prominence it wouldn’t have had without them.

headline: New York’s Sidewalk Prophets Are Heirs of the Artisans of France’s Lascaux Caves
abstract: A critic’s tour deciphers the signs and symbols of the street art adorning boarded-up storefronts. What it tells us about our shared political realities and the ways our stories are connected.
lead_paragraph: About 17,000 years ago, in the caves of Lascaux, France, ancestors drew on grotto walls, depicting equines, stags, bison, aurochs and felines. They wanted to convey to other humans a political reality crucial to their survival: They shared their environment with other beings that looked and behaved differently from them.

headline: The Turmoil in Portland and Kenosha
abstract: Readers write that President Trump is stoking fear for his political advantage.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Can Love Survive This Election?
abstract: The presidential race is in full swing, and more couples (some on the left, some on the right) are finding themselves fighting about politics.
lead_paragraph: Julie Sanchez, a business operations consultant in Orcutt, Calf., recently celebrated her 15th wedding anniversary — a milestone that she wasn’t sure she would hit, given the recent strain politics has brought to her marriage.

headline: Belarus’s Leader Vows to Crush Protests After Claiming Landslide Election Win
abstract: Violent clashes between the police and protesters erupted across Belarus on Monday after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko declared victory in a vote widely dismissed as fraudulent.
lead_paragraph: MINSK — A day after the leader of Belarus, often called “Europe’s last dictator,” claimed a landslide re-election victory, his capital slipped into mayhem late on Monday as protesters barricaded streets and riot police officers beat back crowds of demonstrators with violent baton charges, stun grenades, tear gas and rubber bullets.

headline: How to Watch the Democratic National Convention
abstract: Joe Biden will finally take the stage Thursday night, as will several of his former primary opponents.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the fourth and last night of the Democratic National Convention, Joseph R. Biden Jr. will finally take the stage — a stage, anyway, albeit hundreds of miles from the one in Milwaukee where he would have accepted the presidential nomination he has sought for more than 30 years.

headline: The Extra Stigma of Mental Illness for African-Americans
abstract: In my Black community, therapy was stigmatized as something for people who could not handle challenges.
lead_paragraph: I was a 22-year-old temp working for a high-profile company when I collapsed on the bathroom floor at work. I had no clue what was happening and neither did anyone around me. My heart was beating loudly, making it difficult to think, move or speak.

headline: How a New Wave of Black Activists Changed the Conversation
abstract: George Floyd’s killing galvanized a nation. But small groups like the queer-led collective Black Visions are channeling that energy into a movement for political change.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Two Indianapolis Police Officers Charged With Assaulting Protesters
abstract: The two were indicted after videos taken by TV crews showed officers repeatedly striking one woman with batons and shoving another to the ground, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two Indianapolis police officers have been charged with assaulting two women at a protest, the authorities said Wednesday, the latest officers to face criminal charges that they used excessive force against protesters demanding an end to police violence.

headline: ‘Christianity Will Have Power’
abstract: Donald Trump made a promise to white evangelical Christians, whose support can seem mystifying to the outside observer.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Calls Push for Social Justice a ‘Lifelong Fight’
abstract: Anthony’s career seemed to be over not long ago. But he has reclaimed the spotlight with the Portland Trail Blazers, and he’s using it for something personal: speaking out about police brutality.
lead_paragraph: There was a time in Carmelo Anthony’s nearly two-decade N.B.A. career when his maturity was called into question. As recently as last summer, there was even uncertainty about whether Anthony, the aging 10-time All-Star, was employable as a professional basketball player and could accept being a part of a supporting cast.

headline: Joe’s Fearsome Weapon Against Trump: Simple Decency
abstract: Biden takes on Donnie Darkness and promises to bring us into the light.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whenever I called my mom to tell her something bad had happened, she said, “I know.”

headline: Republican Convention: Best and Worst Moments From Night 2
abstract: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 2 of the Republican National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rank the evening on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the night was a disaster for Republicans; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump for the Trump-Pence ticket. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which highlighted Eric Trump, Tiffany Trump, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Melania Trump.

headline: Feminist Factions United and Filled the Streets for This Historic March
abstract: In 1970, on the 50th anniversary of suffrage, the Women’s Strike for Equality brought together a diverse group of protesters.
lead_paragraph: The 1970 Women’s Strike for Equality was the largest women’s rights demonstration since the era of suffrage — and more inclusive than anything that had been seen before. Fifty years to the day after suffragists secured the vote for American women, tens of thousands of women took to the streets of New York to commemorate this past success and to demand “the unfinished business of our equality.”

headline: In the Wake of Covid-19 Lockdowns, a Troubling Surge in Homicides
abstract: “People have gotten to the point where they just don’t give a damn,” said a minister in Kansas City, which is on pace for a record number of killings.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — It started with an afternoon stop at a gas station. Two customers began exchanging angry stares near the pumps outside — and no one can explain exactly why.

headline: How Decades of Racist Housing Policy Left Neighborhoods Sweltering
abstract: Redlining helped reshape the urban landscape of U.S. cities. It also left communities of color far more vulnerable to rising heat.
lead_paragraph: Redlining helped reshape the urban landscape of U.S. cities. It also left communities of color far more vulnerable to rising heat.

headline: The Vail All-Stars, San Francisco Dreaming and Black Lives Matter
abstract: This week’s standouts in streaming dance, plus something to get the kids involved and moving.
