headline: Two Children Killed in Trenton, Where Violence Is Surging
abstract: Killings in New Jersey’s capital city have more than doubled since last year, officials said.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON, N.J. — The neighbors gathered outside a blue-and-white building in Trenton on Wednesday morning, coming together in shock, anger and grief on a block filled with abandoned homes just two miles from New Jersey’s gilded State House.

headline: Jacob Blake Is My Nephew. My Family Is Suffering.
abstract: Police violence takes a largely invisible toll on Black families.
lead_paragraph: Hotels, hospitals, rehabilitation centers, media interviews. In recent months, this has been the daily ordeal of my brother, Jacob Blake Sr. — or as we call him in our family, “Big Jake.”

headline: Maya Wiley, ex-lawyer for Mayor de Blasio and commentator, is running for mayor of New York.
abstract: Maya D. Wiley, a former top lawyer for Mayor Bill de Blasio who has gained a national following as a political and legal analyst for MSNBC, announced Wednesday night that she was running for mayor of New York City and immediately sought to distance herself from her former boss.
lead_paragraph: Maya D. Wiley, a former top lawyer for Mayor Bill de Blasio who has gained a national following as a political and legal analyst for MSNBC, announced Wednesday night that she was running for mayor of New York City and immediately sought to distance herself from her former boss.

headline: N.Y.P.D.’s Top Latino Official Resigns After Clashing With Mayor
abstract: Chief Fausto Pichardo told colleagues that he felt insulted by Mayor Bill de Blasio during a turbulent time for the city, a police official said.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department’s highest-profile Latino official resigned abruptly on Tuesday after complaining to colleagues that Mayor Bill de Blasio had insulted him, two police officials said.

headline: Now Circulating on Social Media: 4 Election Falsehoods
abstract: The misinformation touches on ballot boxes, the “deep state,” and a conspiracy involving the coronavirus and the vote.
lead_paragraph: Falsehoods about election interference are swirling online, stoking calls for violence on Election Day. The rumors touch on everything from ballot boxes to how the “deep state” — a so-called secret cabal of elites — is involved.

headline: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From Jack Kerouac to Black Lives Matter
abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: THE PURPOSE OF POWER: How We Come Together When We Fall Apart, by Alicia Garza, read by the author. (Random House Audio.) The co-creator of the Black Lives Matter movement shares the lessons she’s learned — about activism and civil rights — the hard way.

headline: Arrest Leads to Tragedy in the Rio Grande Valley
abstract: Jorge Gonzalez Zuniga’s death after a brutal arrest prompted protests that are rare in a region where undocumented immigrants often prefer to stay silent.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURG, Texas — Officer Coltynn Williams was the first person at the Hidalgo County Jail to actually see Jorge Gonzalez Zuniga.

headline: Black LinkedIn Is Thriving. Does LinkedIn Have a Problem With That?
abstract: The social network’s tone has long reflected corporate America: staid, monolithic, white. Now Black users are speaking up — and saying the site is limiting their voice.
lead_paragraph: One day in September, Elizabeth Leiba opened the LinkedIn app and saw a post by Aaisha Joseph, a diversity consultant with nearly 16,000 followers on the platform.

headline: A Farewell to Norms
abstract: While a pandemic altered the fundamentals of human interaction, millions of activists took to the streets to protect democratic institutions and defend human rights.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from World Review: The State of Democracy, a special section that examines global policy and affairs through the perspectives of thought leaders and commentators, and is published in conjunction with the annual Athens Democracy Forum.

headline: How Joe Biden Became the Unlikeliest of Online Fund-Raising Superstars
abstract: Four inflection points transformed Mr. Biden from a pauper during the primaries to a powerhouse against President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Long before Joseph R. Biden Jr. was smashing online fund-raising records, long before it was clear he would become the Democratic nominee, his campaign was facing a serious cash crisis.

headline: G.O.P. centrism gives way to fringe views in Biden’s home state, where a QAnon fan is running for Senate.
abstract: WILMINGTON, Del. — Lauren Witzke, a dabbler in QAnon, a self-proclaimed “flat earther” and the Republican Party’s nominee in Delaware for the Senate, was exhorting her supporters last month to “Go get ’em — America First,” as they squared off against a handful of Black Lives Matter protesters.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Lauren Witzke, a dabbler in QAnon, a self-proclaimed “flat earther” and the Republican Party’s nominee in Delaware for the Senate, was exhorting her supporters last month to “Go get ’em — America First,” as they squared off against a handful of Black Lives Matter protesters.

headline: The Fury Against Trump Has Begun a Great Democratic Awakening
abstract: Many Americans have lost the comfortable bliss of not paying attention to politics.
lead_paragraph: What did we talk about before Donald Trump? What will we talk about after Donald Trump? Will there even be an after? And was there ever really a before?

headline: In a Small Alabama Town, Suddenly All Politics Is National
abstract: The race for mayor in Montevallo used to be low-key and nonpartisan. In the Trump era, one candidate learned the hard way that’s no longer the case.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVALLO, Ala. — Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.

headline: Their Buzzy Off Broadway Play Shut Down. Here’s What They Did Next.
abstract: When the virus forced New York theater to go dark, it upended thousands of lives, from actors to ticket takers. An anatomy of one production.
lead_paragraph: Seven months ago, on a brisk Thursday in March, New York’s theater world came to a sudden halt. Lives were upended, fortunes evaporated, dreams put on hold. Why do people come to New York, if not for some version of the dream embodied by theater: to experience the new, the fantastic, the tragic — some to witness, some to participate in its creation?

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Baroque Music
abstract: Listen to spirited, sublime works by Bach, Handel, Purcell and others.
lead_paragraph: In the past, we’ve asked some of our favorite artists to choose the five minutes or so they would play to make their friends fall in love with classical music, the piano, opera, the cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers and the violin.

headline: After a Summer of Racial Reckoning, Race Is on the Ballot
abstract: The coronavirus and battered economy are focal points in national campaigns. But in many local elections, systemic racism and police reform have emerged as dominant themes.
lead_paragraph: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more provocative stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: Coronavirus, Britain, Transgender Rugby: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: British health workers brace for a second wave.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Following Falsehoods: A Reporter’s Approach on QAnon
abstract: Kevin Roose, a Times tech columnist, has watched the baseless conspiracy theory grow from fringe internet subculture to mass movement, carefully calibrating his coverage along the way.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Barbara Kruger Offers a Dark Mirror for Our Meme-Driven Age
abstract: For nearly five decades, the artist has blurred the lines between political slogans, poetry and the language of advertising, establishing herself as a serious architect of protest and provocation.
lead_paragraph: For nearly five decades, the artist has blurred the lines between political slogans, poetry and the language of advertising, establishing herself as a serious architect of protest and provocation.

headline: A New Oath for 140 Future Doctors in Pandemic N.Y.
abstract: The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai welcomed first-year students with a virtual “white coat” ceremony, during which they referenced the coronavirus and Black Lives Matter.
lead_paragraph: The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai welcomed first-year students with a virtual “white coat” ceremony, during which they referenced the coronavirus and Black Lives Matter.

headline: FKA Twigs Has Reached New Heights
abstract: Known for her haunting blend of R&B and art-pop, the singer is already a singular presence, but remains unwavering in her pursuit of technical virtuosity.
lead_paragraph: Known for her haunting blend of R&B and art-pop, the singer is already a singular presence, but remains unwavering in her pursuit of technical virtuosity.

headline: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Google Lawsuit, Supreme Court, Found Painting
abstract: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

headline: The Year in Misinformation, So Far
abstract: Dubious stories about George Soros, Ukraine and vote-by-mail have spread widely on social media this year, and we may just be warming up.
lead_paragraph: Dubious stories about George Soros, Ukraine and vote-by-mail have spread widely on social media this year, and we may just be warming up.

headline: Angela Davis Still Believes America Can Change
abstract: Since the 1970s, the academic and activist has been an icon of feminism and Black liberation. Today, as the battle for equality wages on, the ideas for which she’s long advocated have finally entered mainstream thought.
lead_paragraph: Since the 1970s, the academic and activist has been an icon of feminism and Black liberation. Today, as the battle for equality wages on, the ideas for which she’s long advocated have finally entered mainstream thought.

headline: A Nation Adrift
abstract: Scenes from Trump's America
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Trump's America

headline: The Swamp That Trump Built
abstract: A businessman-president transplanted favor-seeking in Washington to his family’s hotels and resorts — and earned millions as a gatekeeper to his own administration.
lead_paragraph: A businessman-president transplanted favor-seeking in Washington to his family’s hotels and resorts — and earned millions as a gatekeeper to his own administration.

headline: The Pandemic Has Hindered Many of the Best Ideas for Reducing Violence
abstract: That may be one part of this year’s rise in violent crime.
lead_paragraph: That may be one part of this year’s rise in violent crime.

headline: For Gen Z, Voting Is New. Being Politically Active Isn’t.
abstract: Snapchat has helped more than 1.2 million young people register to vote.

headline: My Mustache, My Self
abstract: A quarantine facial-hair experiment led me to a deep consideration of my Blackness.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of men, in pursuit of novelty and amusement during these months of isolation, I grew a mustache. The reviews were predictably mixed and predictably predictable. “Porny”? Yes. “Creepy”? Obviously. “ ’70s”? True (the 18- and 1970s). On some video calls, I heard “rugged” and “extra gay.” Someone I love called me “zaddy.” Children were harsh. My 11-year-old nephew told his Minecraft friends that his uncle has this … mustache; the midgame disgust was audible through his headset. In August, I spent two weeks with my niece, who’s 7. She would rise each morning dismayed anew to be spending another day looking at the hair on my face. Once, she climbed on my back and began combing the mustache with her fingers, whispering in the warmest tones of endearment, “Uncle Wesley, when are you going to shave this thing off?”

headline: Taylor Swift, leaning further into politics, endorses Joe Biden and Kamala Harris.
abstract: Taylor Swift, the pop megastar who has increasingly leveraged her fame and platform to weigh in on political matters and social causes, announced Wednesday that she would support Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris in the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift, the pop megastar who has increasingly leveraged her fame and platform to weigh in on political matters and social causes, announced Wednesday that she would support Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris in the presidential election.

headline: LeBron James on Black Voter Participation, Misinformation and Trump
abstract: In an interview, the recently crowned N.B.A. champion discussed the work of More Than a Vote, a collective of athletes trying to combat misinformation among Black communities before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: More Than a Vote, the collective of athletes headlined by the basketball star LeBron James, on Wednesday will introduce its final political push before Election Day, a rapid response and advertisement operation meant to combat the spread of misinformation among younger Black voters.

headline: 4 Current Affairs Podcasts for Curious Children
abstract: Daily, biweekly and weekly shows deliver kids the news at their level, and help contextualize the world around them.
lead_paragraph: What do children make of the day’s headlines? The endless deluge of news is staggering and tough to get a handle on, even for grown-ups. And with disinformation packaged as journalism rampant on social media, there is an urgent need to help kids tell the difference between truth and propaganda. These news podcasts are perfect for young people seeking a better understanding of what the adults are fussing about and for parents who want to help their children learn how to engage critically with the world around them.

headline: Fraternity That Reveres Robert E. Lee Faces Revolt Over Racism
abstract: How a racial awakening unfolded in a white-dominated brotherhood known for its veneration of the Confederate general.
lead_paragraph: Kappa Alpha, one of the nation’s largest and oldest college fraternities, is not unaccustomed to fending off charges of racism.

headline: Derek Chauvin, Ex-Officer Charged in George Floyd’s Death, Is Released on Bail
abstract: The former Minneapolis police officer is awaiting trial on murder and manslaughter charges after a video captured him kneeling on Mr. Floyd’s neck in May.
lead_paragraph: For months, protesters trained their anger on Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer who was shown on video holding his knee on the neck of George Floyd before his death. They demonstrated outside of Mr. Chauvin’s home, posted his mug shot across the internet and chanted outside his first in-person court appearance last month.

headline: The Erasure of Mesut Özil
abstract: A year ago, he was one of the Premier League’s highest-paid players. Now, after angering China and refusing a pay cut, he has simply vanished.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Everything started with a tweet. Mesut Özil knew the risks, in December last year, when he decided to offer a startling, public denunciation both of China’s treatment of the Uighurs, a largely Muslim minority in the region of Xinjiang, and the complicit silence of the international community.

headline: Justice Dept. Is Said to Quietly Quash Inquiry Into Tamir Rice Killing
abstract: Supervisors denied civil-rights prosecutors’ request to use a grand jury for their investigation into the 2014 shooting of a Black boy by a Cleveland police officer, but did not tell his family.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department decided more than a year ago to effectively shut down its civil-rights investigation into the high-profile killing of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old Black boy carrying a pellet gun who was shot by a Cleveland police officer in 2014, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Former Philadelphia Officer Charged With Murder in 2017 Shooting
abstract: Eric Ruch Jr.’s killing of Dennis Plowden, an unarmed Black man, after a high-speed chase was unjustified, a grand jury found.
lead_paragraph: A former Philadelphia police officer has been charged with first-degree murder in connection with the fatal shooting of an unarmed Black man after a high-speed chase in December 2017 that ended in a crash, prosecutors said Friday.

headline: What Is a Militia? And Why Is the Word So Controversial These Days?
abstract: Federal authorities and academics have long described private paramilitary organizations as “militias.” Some critics say the term gives the groups more legitimacy than they deserve.
lead_paragraph: When Special Agent Richard J. Trask II of the F.B.I. took the witness stand in federal court in Grand Rapids, Mich., last week to detail a plot to kidnap the governors of Michigan and Virginia, the prosecutor first asked him what the men involved had in common.

headline: How Kelly Loeffler Went From Atlanta Elite to Trump Loyalist
abstract: Senator Loeffler, one of the richest people in Congress,  came to office as a political moderate. But in today’s Republican Party, that didn’t last long.
lead_paragraph: DALTON, Ga. — Kelly Loeffler is not just a United States senator and a successful businesswoman. She is also one of the social doyennes of Buckhead, the Atlanta neighborhood of the wealthy and aspiring rich, where she has often thrown open the gates of her $10.5 million European-style manse, known as Descante, for charity fund-raisers.

headline: First Coronavirus Hit, Then They Got Bedbugs
abstract: Three roommates support each other through the pandemic and fumigation, and luck into a bigger apartment for the same price.
lead_paragraph: By June, things were looking up for Posey Bartol and Theresa Alexander, two actors who lost their jobs and their third roommate at the start of the pandemic. They had finally found someone to take over the empty bedroom in their Hamilton Heights apartment, their unemployment checks had come through, and after 90 days of rarely venturing out, they had started volunteering with the #OpenYourLobby campaign for Black Lives Matter protesters.

headline: Lili Reinhart Is Just Being Honest
abstract: The “Riverdale” star is reluctant to call herself an activist. But she has a lot to say and isn’t afraid to do so.
lead_paragraph: Lili Reinhart has been outspoken for almost as long as she’s been famous. The star of the popular teen soap “Riverdale” has openly discussed her struggles with anxiety, depression and body dysmorphia. She has also been vocal about women’s reproductive rights, white privilege, her disapproval of President Trump and the public’s undying fascination with Brad Pitt and Jennifer Aniston.

headline: Adrienne Warren: ‘I Needed a Break’
abstract: After a grueling run and tumultuous summer, the Tony-nominated star of “Tina — The Tina Turner Musical” relishes the time to heal.
lead_paragraph: The last time Adrienne Warren slipped on the towering blonde wig she wears in “Tina — The Tina Turner Musical” was seven months ago. But when she received the second Tony Award nomination of her career on Thursday, for best actress in a musical, she was recording voice-overs and didn’t have the chance to look at her phone until nearly 5:30 p.m.

headline: The Final Debate Will Cover Six Main Issues. Here’s Where Trump and Biden Stand.
abstract: President Trump and Joe Biden will have their last major opportunity on Thursday to promote their record and criticize their opponent as they address questions on the coronavirus crisis, race, national security and more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When they meet for their second and final debate on Thursday night, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. are expected to face questions over issues of deep consequence like the coronavirus, climate change and national security.

headline: Campaign 2020: Let’s Never Do This Again
abstract: It’s not hope or change. It’s not making anything great. It’s just about making it through.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The masks, when used, can muffle the dueling chants of a live-action partisan clash. But the messages of this election season still have a way of carrying.

headline: Should N.J. Legalize Marijuana? The Voters Will Decide
abstract: A question on November’s ballot asks residents if they support changing the state Constitution to allow recreational use of the drug.
lead_paragraph: For two years, New Jersey lawmakers had failed to mobilize enough support to pass a bill to fully legalize marijuana. Instead, they agreed in December to put the question directly to voters: “Do you approve amending the Constitution to legalize a controlled form of marijuana called ‘cannabis’?”

headline: H.B.C.U. Homecomings Are Canceled, but Students and Alumni Will Feast Anyway
abstract: Brunch, a major part of homecoming at historically Black colleges and universities, is still on for this year, even if it has to be virtual.
lead_paragraph: Matriculation at historically Black colleges and universities is more than late-night study sessions: It’s a balancing act between academics and discovering merriment, and learning how to be. It’s routine to walk the same grassy quadrant as ancestors who believed education was a weapon, while making plans to let off steam.

headline: Michigan Man Charged With Hate Crime After Attack on Black Teen
abstract: A white man, Lee James Mouat, repeatedly used racial slurs before striking the teenager with a bike lock, witnesses told prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: A white Michigan man was charged with a federal hate crime on Tuesday in an attack on a Black teenager during which he repeatedly used racial slurs before striking him in the face with a bike lock, prosecutors said.

headline: Kushner, Employing Racist Stereotype, Questions if Black Americans ‘Want to Be Successful’
abstract: In a “Fox & Friends” interview, President Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser also criticized protesters as more concerned with what he called “virtue signaling” than in coming up with “solutions.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has repeatedly bragged about what he has done for Black America, pointing to his administration’s funding for Black colleges and universities, the creation of so-called opportunity zones and criminal justice reform.

headline: Oscar Grant’s Killing Will Be Investigated Again, D.A. Says
abstract: In 2009, a transit officer fatally shot Oscar Grant III in the back in Oakland, setting off protests over the police treatment of Black people. A district attorney said she would reopen the investigation.
lead_paragraph: The district attorney in Alameda County, Calif., said on Monday that she would reopen an investigation into the 2009 killing of Oscar Grant III, an event that spurred mass protests in Oakland and more than a decade of calls for justice after he was fatally shot in the back by a transit officer.

headline: A Divided Nation Agrees on One Thing: Many People Want a Gun
abstract: Gun buyers say they are motivated by a new destabilizing sense that is pushing them to purchase weapons for the first time, or if they already have them, to buy more.
lead_paragraph: CHANTILLY, Va.— Like many Americans, two women a thousand miles apart are each anxious about the uncertain state of the nation. Their reasons are altogether different. But they have found common ground, and a sense of certainty, in a recent purchase: a gun.

headline: Can Trump Squeeze More From His White Base in Pennsylvania and Beyond?
abstract: With President Trump trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Pennsylvania in nearly every poll, his last refuge and perhaps best hope is to maximize the turnout of working-class white voters.
lead_paragraph: OLYPHANT, Pa. — President Trump’s narrowing path to victory in Pennsylvania, and the country, runs through small towns like Olyphant, where Dave Mitchko’s street might be quieter if not for the large sign he put on his front lawn urging supporters of the president to honk when they pass.

headline: The Promise of Pawpaw
abstract: Issues like climate change, economic inequity and access to food have brought more attention to this creamy fruit and its resilient tree.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The new pawpaw patch at the Woodlands, a sprawling historic property along the Schuylkill, still isn’t much to look at. But just give those trees time, said Alkebu-Lan Marcus, the farmer who tends to them.

headline: The Lakers and Basketball’s Momentous Year
abstract: Tuesday: Catch up on the Lakers’ 17th championship win. Also: An uproar over fake “official” ballot boxes distributed by Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: It’s Election Day. Do You Know How Your Matches Are Voting?
abstract: Singles are putting their political affiliations front and center on the apps.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Cibbarelli, 23, was texting with a man on Hinge while Senator Kamala Harris and Vice President Mike Pence debated on her TV screen in early October. When she told her match what she was watching, he said he didn’t know who either of the people in the debate were, or which political office they were running for.

headline: How Kelly Loeffler went from Atlanta elite to Trump loyalist.
abstract: DALTON, Ga. — Kelly Loeffler is not just a U.S. senator and a successful businesswoman. She is also one of the social doyennes of Buckhead, the Atlanta neighborhood of the wealthy and aspiring rich, where she has often thrown open the gates of her $10.5 million European-style manse, known as Descante, for charity fund-raisers.
lead_paragraph: DALTON, Ga. — Kelly Loeffler is not just a U.S. senator and a successful businesswoman. She is also one of the social doyennes of Buckhead, the Atlanta neighborhood of the wealthy and aspiring rich, where she has often thrown open the gates of her $10.5 million European-style manse, known as Descante, for charity fund-raisers.

headline: Is There a Place for the President of the Confederacy?
abstract: Moving troubled monuments to museums for context may sound like an easy answer, but the story of trying to send a statue of Jefferson Davis back to his hometown shows how difficult that really is.
lead_paragraph: FAIRVIEW, Ky. — Drive down Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Way in western Kentucky, past Martin Luther King Jr. Elementary School and take a right onto Jefferson Davis Highway, and a gray spike will begin to rise in the air.

headline: The White Issue: Has Anna Wintour’s Diversity Push Come Too Late?
abstract: Vogue’s September issue celebrated Black culture and contributors. But some employees say the magazine’s powerful editor fostered a workplace that sidelined women of color.
lead_paragraph: Vogue’s September issue was different this year. Anna Wintour and her staff put it together when more than 15 million people were marching in Black Lives Matter protests nationwide and employees at Vogue’s parent company, Condé Nast, were publicly calling out what they viewed as racism in their own workplace. At 316 pages, the issue, titled “Hope,” featured a majority of Black artists, models and photographers, a first for the magazine.

headline: The Radicalizer in Chief
abstract: Violent extremists and conspiracy theorists found their tribune in Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: This month, federal and state authorities arrested 13 Michigan men on terrorism, conspiracy and weapons charges. Six of the men are alleged to have been plotting to kidnap the state’s governor, Gretchen Whitmer, with whom they were furious for imposing shutdowns, as most other governors did, in the early weeks of the pandemic.

headline: He Was a Rising Jazz Pianist. Then His N.Y.C. Dreams Were Shattered.
abstract: The police said an attack on the pianist was not a hate crime, but social media disagreed. Now he’s considering a return to Japan.
lead_paragraph: He came to New York from Tokyo to make it as a jazz musician, and he did, landing gigs in several touring bands and leading a trio of his own. He was elegant but never flashy on the piano, always well prepared and on time.

headline: Win or Lose, It’s Donald Trump’s Republican Party
abstract: The G.O.P.’s politicians, activists and voters are still figuring out what that means.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: In the Rising Voices of 10 Young Poets, a Call for Change
abstract: The special project Young Black Poets showcases a promising new generation of writers whose verses respond to this moment in America.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Democracy, Caring For Plants and “Flights to Nowhere”
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: For this roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to reflect on how their generation is fighting for democracy, to tell us if they have ever grown anything and to muse about if they would take a “flight to nowhere.”

headline: In Biden’s Home State, Republican Centrism Gives Way to the Fringe
abstract: The Republican Party’s slide from statewide power to irrelevance in Delaware mirrored its swerve from moderation to the fringe. Now a QAnon fan is running for the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Lauren Witzke, a dabbler in QAnon, a self-proclaimed “flat earther” and the Republican Party’s nominee in Delaware for the Senate, was exhorting her supporters last month to “Go get ’em — America First,” as they squared off against a handful of Black Lives Matter protesters.

headline: From 2 Artists, 2 Ways to Tell Stories of Black America
abstract: Works by Bisa Butler and Barbara Earl Thomas are featured in major museum shows in Chicago and Seattle. It’s a star turn that many feel is long overdue.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Fine Arts & Exhibits special report, which focuses on how art endures and inspires, even in the darkest of times.

headline: Despite Billions in Fees, Banks Predict Meager Profits on P.P.P. Loans
abstract: Banks collected at least $13 billion in fees on Paycheck Protection Program loans, according to a New York Times analysis. But the largest lenders say costs wiped out most of what they took in.
lead_paragraph: Loath to be seen profiting from the economic disaster caused by the coronavirus, the nation’s biggest banks were quick to pledge that they would donate to charity any money earned from helping deliver the government’s signature small-business relief plan.

headline: Could Dance Be a Weapon All Over Again?
abstract: It’s a scary time for body-based art. What will survive after the pandemic? As dance artists fight the old ways, a new empowerment is in the air.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic started, the first thing I did was panic. I didn’t want to bum anyone out, but it didn’t take me long to leap to a certain conclusion: With theaters and studios shutting down, the dance world would be devastated. What would come out of the ashes?

headline: Trump Attack on Diversity Training Has a Quick and Chilling Effect
abstract: A presidential executive order banning the “malign ideology” of racial sensitivity training has rippled through government into academia and corporate America.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the diversity consulting industry, this summer was like no other. Amid the racial reckoning spurred by the death of George Floyd, a wave of senior-level executives began to look critically at their companies, and consultants like Melanie Miller and Loretta VanPelt found themselves deluged with work.

headline: Maren Morris Pleads With America, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Halsey, Priya Ragu, Jorja Smith and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: A Crush of Early Voters Makes for Long Waits in N.Y.C.
abstract: For the first time ever, New Yorkers cast their ballots early for a presidential election, sometimes standing in line for five hours.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Why Nigeria Is Now Erupting’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about recent demonstrations against police brutality in Nigeria. Then, they will use media literacy skills to analyze and evaluate the social media campaign behind the movement.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Why Nigeria Is Now Erupting” by Rick Gladstone and Megan Specia

headline: Megan Thee Stallion: Why I Speak Up for Black Women
abstract: I’m not afraid of criticism, and “Protect Black women” should not be controversial.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks leading up to the election, Black women are expected once again to deliver victory for Democratic candidates. We have gone from being unable to vote legally to a highly courted voting bloc — all in little more than a century.

headline: Jeremy O. Harris, Author of ‘Slave Play,’ on the Show’s Record Haul
abstract: Twelve nominations, including one for Best Play, is an encouraging sign: “It feels very invigorating that the community wants to have this conversation right now.”
lead_paragraph: Jeremy O. Harris’s phone was binging like a hijacked “Jeopardy!” buzzer on Thursday afternoon, after the Tony nominations were announced. “I’m sorry,” said the 31-year-old playwright. “I’m just so excited!”

headline: A Memphis poll worker was fired for turning away voters wearing ‘Black Lives Matter’ shirts.
abstract: A poll worker in Memphis was fired last week after he improperly turned away several voters wearing T-shirts that said “Black Lives Matter” and “I Can’t Breathe,” a local election official said.
lead_paragraph: A poll worker in Memphis was fired last week after he improperly turned away several voters wearing T-shirts that said “Black Lives Matter” and “I Can’t Breathe,” a local election official said.

headline: How a Virus Surge Among Orthodox Jews Became a Crisis for New York
abstract: New York City had been holding off a second wave, but an uptick in cases in Brooklyn and Queens now threatens to bring one on.
lead_paragraph: All summer, life had been returning to normal in the Orthodox Jewish neighborhoods of Brooklyn. On Eastern Parkway and along 13th Avenue, throngs of men in black hats and coats once again visited synagogues three times a day. Children went off to camp. Weddings filled large banquet halls.

headline: ‘City So Real’ Is an Election Story Pulsing With Life
abstract: In Steve James’s documentary of the 2019 Chicago election and its aftermath, politics is local, and it’s fascinating.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the documentary “City So Real,” Christie Hefner, the former chief executive of Playboy, hosts a “salon dinner” for some Chicago luminaries. With a stunning high-rise view as a backdrop, they talk about their town’s future: whether it will become a gleaming “global city” or descend into “chaos.”

headline: 4 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Ficre Ghebreyesus’s artistic legacy; Steve Mumford’s combat-zone drawings; Manal Kara’s adoring gaze; Cheyenne Julien’s iridescent paintings.
lead_paragraph: The painter Ficre Ghebreyesus (1962-2012), whose work makes its New York solo debut with the show “Gate to the Blue,” traveled a long way in his cut-short life. He was born in Eritrea, East Africa, and left at 16 to escape the country’s brutal war of independence with Ethiopia. He traveled on foot to Sudan and lived as a refugee in Italy and Germany. In 1981, he settled in the United States, where he studied painting at the Art Students League in New York and at the Yale School of Art and supported himself for years as a restaurant chef in New Haven, Conn.

headline: WeChat, Wild Rumors and All, Is Their Lifeline. Washington May End That.
abstract: The app has reshaped the experience of Chinese-Americans for the better, but also spreads misinformation and government propaganda.
lead_paragraph: When Sin Yee Tsui immigrated to New York in 1982 to work as a seamstress, it took so long for her to receive letters from China that she did not learn of her father’s death until after his funeral.

headline: The Year in Misinformation, So Far
abstract: Dubious stories about George Soros, Ukraine and vote-by-mail have spread widely on social media this year, and we may just be warming up.
lead_paragraph: This has been, by any measure, a bad year for consensus reality.

headline: LeBron James has a new push to fight misinformation among Black voters. Don’t ask him about Trump.
abstract: LeBron James’s voter mobilization group, More Than a Vote, has a new initiative aimed at countering misinformation targeting young Black voters.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James, fresh off the Los Angeles Lakers’ championship, is stepping up his political activities on behalf of More Than a Vote, a voter mobilization group that debuted a rapid response operation on Wednesday to combat misinformation among young Black voters.

headline: Can I Tell My Friend Her Halloween Costume Is Problematic?
abstract: A reader feels that Scarlett O’Hara-style period dress may be seen as whitewashing the antebellum South.
lead_paragraph: A new friend in the Midwest was invited to an outdoor Halloween party where mask-wearing was requested. We went shopping for an art-inspired costume for her. But I saw that she was gravitating toward period costumes. After the party, she posted pictures online. I was stunned! She wore a full-blown Scarlett O’Hara-type gown — to a mansion, no less! If I’d known, I would have tried to talk her out if it. This year’s widespread Black Lives Matter protests, along with the traditional whitewashing of the antebellum South, make her choice seem insensitive. I’ll be seeing her soon, and I already feel awkward. I know she’ll share details of the party, and I feel obligated to enlighten her. Any advice?

headline: Opinion Today: Trump’s Blueprint for Dystopian Policing
abstract: If this expert is worried, you should be too.
lead_paragraph: This article was originally published in our Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here.

headline: Can Trump Woo Enough Black Men to Hurt Biden in Battleground States?
abstract: On the ground and in TV ads, the candidates are in an intense and surprising battle for Black male voters, who are crucial for Democrats trying to win back Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: [Read our 2020 presidential election electoral college explainer.]

headline: An Update on a Crucial District Attorney Race
abstract: Tuesday: What’s at stake in the fight to be Los Angeles’s top prosecutor. Also: A history-making nomination to the California Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Give Hong Kong the Autonomy It Was Promised
abstract: Hong Kong’s opposition has proved that it does not lack the ability to rule — only the opportunity.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from World Review: The State of Democracy, a special section that examines global policy and affairs through the perspectives of thought leaders and commentators, and is published in conjunction with the annual Athens Democracy Forum.

headline: ‘Straight to Gunshots’: How a U.S. Task Force Killed an Antifa Activist
abstract: New accounts from the scene raise questions about whether Michael Reinoehl, suspected of killing a far-right Trump supporter, pulled out a gun before officers fatally shot him.
lead_paragraph: Michael Reinoehl was on the run.

headline: In a small Alabama town, a mayoral candidate found herself at the center of rumors that she wanted to ‘defund the police.’
abstract: Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.

headline: Protesters in Portland Topple Statues of Lincoln and Roosevelt
abstract: The demonstrations highlighted a mass execution overseen by Abraham Lincoln and also targeted Theodore Roosevelt.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Protesters in Portland, Ore., swept through the city on Sunday night, toppling statues of Abraham Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt and damaging the entrance to the Oregon Historical Society in a demonstration against colonization and the treatment of Native Americans.

headline: What Topics Do Our Readers Want Trump and Biden to Debate?
abstract: In a year racked by crises, many important issues have been overshadowed. Times readers weighed in on what they want the candidates to address.
lead_paragraph: This year’s presidential election has been shaped by crises: Protests over police brutality and systemic racism. Fears about safe voting and election integrity. And above all, the devastating human and economic toll of the coronavirus.

headline: Nigerians Protest Police Brutality
abstract: Tens of thousands of Nigerians across the country have been protesting for weeks against police brutality. Several people were shot during demonstrations in Lagos Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of Nigerians across the country have been protesting for weeks against police brutality. Several people were shot during demonstrations in Lagos Tuesday night.

headline: Grateful for a Wedding in Prison
abstract: Chelsea Moore, a law student, married Christopher Blackwell, who is incarcerated, at the Monroe Correctional Complex in Washington State. He will be released in 2045.
lead_paragraph: On the day Chelsea Moore got married, it had been six months since she last saw her fiancé, Christopher Blackwell.

headline: ‘Tsunamis of Misinformation’ Overwhelm Local Election Officials
abstract: From Philadelphia to Sonoma County, Calif., election officials said they were working marathon hours to fight a flood of falsehoods.
lead_paragraph: The morning after last month’s presidential debate, the phones inside the Philadelphia election offices that Al Schmidt helps oversee rang off the hook.

headline: Putting Pencil to Paper, in Galleries and in the Voting Booth
abstract: New exhibitions of up-to-the-moment drawings illustrate our historic moment, even as it unfolds.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Fine Arts & Exhibits special report, which focuses on how art endures and inspires, even in the darkest of times.

headline: Open Mike Eagle Turned a Very Bad Year Into a Very Honest Album
abstract: The 39-year-old indie rapper’s therapist told him, “Write your feelings.” So he did, on the new LP “Anime, Trauma and Divorce.”
lead_paragraph: Open Mike Eagle has a wildly creative imagination, but even he was stunned by his circumstances last month at the Aut-O-Rama Twin Drive-In in North Ridgeville, Ohio. On his left side, cars and trucks rumbled by on Interstate 80. On his right, noisy trains roared over railroad tracks every 30 minutes. Eagle was on a stage between them, performing his emotionally candid brand of DIY art-rap, as the opening act for his friend, the comedian Hannibal Buress.

headline: Are You Having a Tough Time Maintaining Friendships These Days?
abstract: Has the pandemic brought you closer together with friends? Or moved you farther apart?
lead_paragraph: Do you find it difficult to keep up with your friendships in a time of social distancing? Do you find it hard to make new friends in the era of remote schooling, and when people are spending so much time more at home? Has the pandemic brought you closer together, or moved you farther apart, from friends?

headline: Captain Chain Saw’s Delusion
abstract: The Amazon was never a “land without men.”
lead_paragraph: Amid political strife and smoke visible from space, the future of the Amazon has rarely been so hazy. Environmentalists see a vanishing rainforest of global consequence. Indigenous leaders see an ancestral home still being exploited by settlers after 500 years of genocidal violence. Brazil’s president, Jair Bolsonaro, sees valuable acreage wasted by “cave men” and Marxists.

headline: California House Races to Watch
abstract: Wednesday: Here’s what to know about key congressional contests. Also: An update on fires; and the Dodgers’ win.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Will the Diamond District Survive?
abstract: The pandemic has given the famous stretch of Midtown, long a hub and destination for all things jewelry, its share of troubles.
lead_paragraph: In Manhattan’s diamond district, Mascha Seiden is known as the queen of 47th Street, at least the stretch of it between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. For more than 50 years, she has been inspecting pieces of jewelry and chatting with customers from behind the counter of her store, Paul Seiden Jewelers. These days, though, fewer customers have been coming in.

headline: The New Trustbusting
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: When two Stanford University graduate students, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, founded Google in 1998, the U.S. economy looked different than it does today.

headline: Nigerian Forces Fire on Protesters
abstract: The toll was unclear, but witnesses said several people were shot during  demonstrations against police brutality in Lagos. The governor said “miscreants” had hijacked mostly peaceful protests.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Nigerian security forces opened fire Tuesday night at a demonstration in Lagos against police brutality, hitting several people according to witnesses, in a major escalation of the unrest that has gripped the country for two weeks.

headline: Races to Watch in California
abstract: Here are some of the key local and statewide races and measures to watch in California.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, California and its concerns have been more visible than ever in this presidential election.

headline: Manslaughter Charge Urged for Israeli Officer in Killing of Autistic Palestinian
abstract: Palestinians assail the failure to recommend a murder charge in the case, which has become a cause célèbre in the fight against police brutality.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli prosecutors recommended on Wednesday that a police officer who shot and killed an unarmed Palestinian man with autism be charged with manslaughter in a case that became a rallying cry against police brutality.

headline: Biden vs. Trump: ‘Who Won? The Moderator’
abstract: Readers share their thoughts on the final presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Did Thursday’s debate — the final for this election — change anyone’s mind about who should lead the country? Opinion’s political writers have shared their thoughts and we’ve asked readers to do the same. On the whole, they found the evening’s proceedings far more palatable than the first matchup between President Trump and Joe Biden:

headline: U.S. Attorney Moves In on Brooklyn D.A.’s Territory, Citing Crime Surge
abstract: Federal prosecutors will take more lower-level gun cases, in an initiative that thrusts the borough into the national debate about law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities in New York have traditionally touted big organized crime and drug-trafficking cases, using powerful racketeering laws to arrest kingpins and dismantle criminal enterprises that drive violence.

headline: Protest Movements Without a Public Face
abstract: Do 21st-century social struggles need traditional leaders, or are they better off without them?
lead_paragraph: This is an article from World Review: The State of Democracy, a special section that examines global policy and affairs through the perspectives of thought leaders and commentators, and is published in conjunction with the annual Athens Democracy Forum.

headline: Reimagining Lady Liberty’s Torch to Meet This Moment
abstract: In her first New York solo exhibition at Madison Square Park, Abigail DeVille conjures a long line of freedom fighters.
lead_paragraph: When Abigail DeVille began site research for her public art project in Manhattan’s Madison Square Park, she stumbled on a wild 1876 photograph of the Statue of Liberty’s detached hand and flaming torch in the park. For six years, the surreal fragment was on view there to generate excitement and raise funds for the pedestal to hold the colossal statue coming to New York from France.

headline: Looking Back on Baseball’s Silent Season
abstract: Empty stadiums, player protests and Covid-19 outbreaks shook up the sport. Maybe that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Two words that have been on my mind constantly these recent months are “room tone.” Room tone is the sound a space makes when there is no other sound but the sound of the space itself. The subtle sounds in a high-ceilinged room with brick walls and wide windows are different from those of a small room with wood-paneled walls and narrow windows, or those of the upper deck of a completely empty stadium, or those of the lower deck of a completely empty stadium.

headline: Could Ray McGuire Be N.Y.C.’s 2nd Black Mayor?
abstract: One of the highest-ranking and longest-serving Black executives on Wall Street is entering the Democratic race eight months before the primary.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: How Three Election-Related Falsehoods Spread
abstract: The lies took off so rapidly on Facebook and Twitter that local election officials could not contain them.
lead_paragraph: Falsehoods about Tuesday’s election have overwhelmed local election officials, who said they were dealing with “tsunamis of misinformation,” have lost sleep and were working extra long hours.

headline: Examining the Fraught Subject of Guns and Police
abstract: Three new books take very different angles in exploring a topic that is never far from today’s headlines.
lead_paragraph: STANDOFFRace, Policing, and a Deadly Assault That Gripped a NationBy Jamie Thompson320 pp. Holt. $27.99.

headline: How Far Might Trump Go?
abstract: No one is quite sure.
lead_paragraph: On election night and the days that follow, the country may be in for a roller-coaster ride, with ups and downs that raise and dash expectations, provoking anger and frustration.

headline: ‘There Are Tons of Brown Faces Missing’: Publishers Step Up Diversity Efforts
abstract: The push in book publishing for more authors and workers of color hasn’t abated, and companies are increasingly making lasting changes to the way they do business.
lead_paragraph: This summer, as people across the United States gathered to protest police brutality and racial injustice, Krishan Trotman, an executive editor at Hachette Books, approached the head of the company with a proposal.

headline: N.Y.C. Was Once a Bastion of G.O.P. Moderates. Then Trump Came Along.
abstract: For decades, Republicans in Manhattan carved out a niche by embracing socially liberal causes. President Trump’s election destroyed that centrism.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Despite Everything, People Still Have Weddings at ‘Plantation’ Sites
abstract: Weddings help pay for education at American labor camp sites and connect us with history. Is that good enough?
lead_paragraph: The resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement this spring spelled the end for many Confederate symbols. Monuments have been removed, by vote and by force.

headline: Do Cuomo’s New Covid Rules Discriminate Against Religion?
abstract: I almost always side with protecting houses of worship. But there are limits.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has imposed new restrictions on businesses, mass gatherings and places of worship in towns and New York City neighborhoods with high rates of coronavirus infections — some of which also have large populations of Orthodox and Hasidic Jews. An Orthodox advocacy group, Agudath Israel of America, has filed a federal lawsuit against the new regulations on the grounds that they violate the right to free exercise of religion.

headline: Around Atlanta, Many White Suburbanites Are Sticking With Trump
abstract: Nationwide, such voters are tilting toward Biden. But in Georgia, the president’s law-and-order message seems to be keeping the bulk of them in his column.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Pontius is an interior decorator, married with two children and a University of Georgia alumna. She was born and raised in Atlanta, but moved to the city’s exurbs with her family several years ago, drawn to the region’s quality of public education. In November, she’s voting for Donald Trump.

headline: Without the Right to Protest, America Is Doomed to Fail
abstract: Black Americans have always fought for the good of our country, even when that country has denied them their own rights.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from World Review: The State of Democracy, a special section that examines global policy and affairs through the perspectives of thought leaders and commentators, and is published in conjunction with the annual Athens Democracy Forum.

headline: Misinformation in America Thrives in Two Languages
abstract: False and misleading information is being spread widely in Spanish, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: QAnon conspiracy theory videos on YouTube. Homespun “remedies” for the coronavirus sent via text messages on WhatsApp. Socialist and communist memes on Twitter. Anti-Black Lives Matter posts on Facebook.

headline: Will SoHo Be the Site of New York City’s Next Battle Over Development?
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to rezone SoHo to accommodate new affordable housing in a wealthy, white neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: SoHo, the upscale Manhattan neighborhood known for its chic stores, art galleries, cobblestone streets and multimillion-dollar lofts, will be the next focal point in New York City’s effort to create more affordable housing.

headline: In Reversal, Twitter Is No Longer Blocking New York Post Article
abstract: The latest change underlined how rapidly social media platforms are shifting their positions in the days leading up to the election.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the 11th hour before the presidential election. But Facebook and Twitter are still changing their minds.

headline: Black Women’s Hair and Horror Movies: What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: An evil weave turns a shy character into a serial killer in “Bad Hair,” but the film doesn’t understand that styling locks can be a source of intimacy and communal pride.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through “Bad Hair,” Justin Simien’s horror-comedy on Hulu, a group of Black women sit in a conference room and debate the merits of changing their hairstyles to conform to the new corporate climate at Culture, the Black music television network where they work.

headline: Orchestras Are Rushing to Add Black Composers. Will It Last?
abstract: Ensembles shut by the coronavirus pandemic are shaking up their programming. Artists of color are hoping it’s for the long haul.
lead_paragraph: In June, as millions of Americans filled city streets with Black Lives Matter demonstrations and millions more rushed to share their solidarity online, the composer Jessie Montgomery noticed something unusual.

headline: A Dozen Protesters in Nigeria Reported Killed by Security Forces
abstract: Nigerians are stunned after police and soldiers opened fire on protesters against police brutality. The largely peaceful demonstrations have grown into a challenge for the government.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — With music playing and food being passed around, a festive atmosphere hung over the protest encampment on Tuesday night, despite the anger over police brutality that in recent weeks had driven youthful demonstrations that were the biggest Nigeria had seen in a generation.

headline: Maya Wiley Enters Mayor’s Race: ‘I Am Not a Conventional Candidate’
abstract: Ms. Wiley, a former analyst for MSNBC, wants to distance herself from New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio and cast herself as an outsider.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: What Do Polls Say About the Issues on the Agenda for Tonight’s Debate?
abstract: On topics from climate change to leadership, most Americans say they prefer Joe Biden over President Trump.
lead_paragraph: At the presidential debate on Thursday, President Trump may not be looking for an exact repeat of his performance last month, when voters widely panned his blunt-ended attacks on Joseph R. Biden Jr. at their first face-off.

headline: In Kalamazoo, Old High School Classmates Reckon With a Divided Country
abstract: The Michigan city, like the state, is a battleground of cultural and racial tensions. I should know: I grew up there.
lead_paragraph: From a gauzy distance, Kevin Swift describes his high school years in the 1980s in Kalamazoo, Mich., as a carefree time of basketball games, English classes and beer parties. “We had it great there,” said Mr. Swift, who is Black and grew up in a majority-white neighborhood.

headline: Lil Buck Feels the Dancing Spirit All Over Again
abstract: In “Nobody Knows,” the jookin star presents a short film that explores his struggles as a Black man and his relationship to dance.
lead_paragraph: Lil Buck, the willowy dancer who spins on the toes of his sneakers as if they were point shoes, was a little boy — probably around 6 — when a church choir filled him with such spirit that he got up and began to dance.

headline: How The Epoch Times Created a Giant Influence Machine
abstract: Since 2016, the Falun Gong-backed newspaper has used aggressive Facebook tactics and right-wing misinformation to create an anti-China, pro-Trump media empire.
lead_paragraph: For years, The Epoch Times was a small, low-budget newspaper with an anti-China slant that was handed out free on New York street corners. But in 2016 and 2017, the paper made two changes that transformed it into one of the country’s most powerful digital publishers.

headline: Kamala Harris, Mass Incarceration and Me
abstract: Many progressives mistrust her for her past as a prosecutor. As an ex-convict — and also the son of a crime victim — I can tell you it’s not that simple.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Cushnie, a Fashion Label That Broke Barriers, Is Closing
abstract: One of the most prominent Black-owned brands in American fashion said it could not survive the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: From the early days of the pandemic, Carly Cushnie was worried.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A potentially game-changing lawsuit against Google.
lead_paragraph: Scientists at Imperial College London plan to deliberately infect volunteers with the coronavirus early next year, beginning the world’s first effort to study how vaccinated people respond to being intentionally exposed to the virus and opening up a new, uncertain path to identifying an effective vaccine.

headline: ‘An End to the Chapter of Dictatorship’: Chileans Vote to Draft a New Constitution
abstract: Voters overwhelmingly approved a bid to scrap the charter inherited from Gen. Augusto Pinochet’s dictatorship, a move that could set a new course for the country.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — The protests started over a small hike in metro fares, then exploded into a broad reckoning over inequality that shook Chile for weeks. Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators poured into the streets, calling for sweeping change in their society, with higher wages and pensions, better health care and education.

headline: Black Art and Poetry Elevate a Tribute to Civil Rights Leaders
abstract: In “The Baptism,” Carrie Mae Weems and Carl Hancock Rux find an abstract, elegiac voice in their video honoring John Lewis and C.T. Vivian.
lead_paragraph: During the last several months, between the scourge of Covid-19 and the spate of Black deaths resulting from police brutality, Blackness has become a concept loaded with fresh injuries. In “The Baptism,” a short, abstract video tribute to Representative John Lewis and the civil rights leader C.T. Vivian, Blackness isn’t divorced from the tragedies but carefully picked apart and examined through an existential lens. The result is a work that is freeing and radical in a way that Black art so often doesn’t get to be.

headline: Nigerians Demand End to Police Squad Known for Brutalizing the Young
abstract: The government said it would bow to the demands of Nigerians protesting police abuses, but skeptical protesters vowed to keep the pressure on.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — With protests breaking out across Nigeria and in expatriate Nigerian communities around the world, the country’s president vowed to a skeptical public on Monday that he would crack down on rogue police officers accused of brutalizing citizens.

headline: Proposition 16 and Debates About Racial Equity
abstract: Wednesday: A deeper dive into the way the debates over ballot propositions reflect Californians’ views on race.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Paid Time Off, Free Fries: How Corporate America Is Getting Out the Vote
abstract: Spurred by recent social unrest, many U.S. companies are trying to make it easier for workers, and urging their customers, to cast their ballots.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America is offering employees up to three hours of paid time to vote this year. The spirits company Diageo North America has declared a no-meeting day on Nov. 3. Best Buy is closing stores until noon that day, and PayPal is offering a half day, paid, to workers who volunteer at polling places.

headline: East Germany’s Love Affair With Angela Davis
abstract: An exhibition looks back at a point in the 1970s when the philosopher and activist was a state-promoted hero behind the Iron Curtain.
lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany — The philosopher, feminist and Black liberation activist Angela Davis is everywhere right now. In the wake of Black Lives Matter protests around the world, TV networks, magazines and newspapers have turned to her, drawing on her decades of activism and scholarship to explain the current moment.

headline: What Will New York Real Estate Look Like Next Year?
abstract: City planners, developers and local officials weigh in on how the pandemic could change the city’s housing markets, land use and policy.
lead_paragraph: One in five New York City tenants did not pay rent in September, by one estimate, and there is growing concern of “an eviction tsunami.”

headline: A New Life of Malcolm X Brimming With Detail, Insight and Feeling
abstract: Thirty years in the making, “The Dead Are Arising,” by Les Payne and Tamara Payne, sharpens our understanding of the Black activist and thinker whose influence continues to reverberate.
lead_paragraph: THE DEAD ARE ARISING The Life of Malcolm X By Les Payne and Tamara Payne

headline: The One Name the W.N.B.A. Won’t Say
abstract: Players have united to depose a sitting senator in Georgia, who has clashed with the Black Lives Matter movement and is an owner of the Atlanta Dream.
lead_paragraph: They will not say her name. Not now, after what these players have been through. It is important not to give her recognition.

headline: The 25 Most Influential Works of American Protest Art Since World War II
abstract: Three artists, a curator and a writer came together to discuss the pieces that have not only best reflected the era, but have made an impact.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, the artists Dread Scott, Catherine Opie and Shirin Neshat, as well as T contributor Nikil Saval and Whitney Museum of American Art assistant curator Rujeko Hockley, joined me on Zoom for a conversation about protest art. I had asked each to nominate five to seven works of what they considered the most powerful or influential American protest art (that is, by an American artist or by an artist who has lived or exhibited their work in America) made anytime after World War II. We focused specifically on visual art — not songs or books — and the hope was that together, we would assemble a list of the top 25. But the question of what, precisely, constitutes protest art is a thorny one — and we kept tripping over it. Is it a slogan? A poster? Does it matter if it was in a museum, in a newspaper or out on the street? Does impact matter? Did it change what you think or believe? Must it endure? What does that mean? And what is the difference, anyway, between protest art and art that is merely political?

headline: PBS Showed TV the Future. But What Does Its Own Look Like?
abstract: It created the blueprint for what TV has become. And, while networks and streaming services reap the benefits of PBS’s successes, it is still struggling to survive.
lead_paragraph: As satires go, Robert Wuhl’s “Open Season” seemed particularly far-fetched when it was released in 1996. The film’s high concept? After the television industry’s all-powerful ratings system malfunctions, a thinly disguised Public Broadcasting Service becomes the most popular network in the country. Educational programs such as “Kennedy: What’s Left to Say?” and a history of Limoges china shoot up the charts. (“What’s Limoges?” asks Regis Philbin in a cameo.)

headline: Stanford Study Seeks to Quantify Infections Stemming From Trump Rallies
abstract: The researchers used a statistical model to extrapolate infections tied to 18 rallies, and the study’s figures were not based on individual cases traced directly to particular campaign events.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]

headline: Trump continues to take swipes at pandemic-stricken New York.
abstract: In the final weeks of the presidential race, President Trump cannot seem to stop harping on New York City.
lead_paragraph: In the final weeks of the presidential race, President Trump cannot seem to stop harping on New York City.

headline: Bike Thefts Are Up 27% in Pandemic N.Y.C.: ‘Sleep With It Next to You’
abstract: As more people are buying bikes, more bikes are being swiped from sidewalks, garages and basements. Locks are not always a deterrent.
lead_paragraph: One of the more unexpected side effects of the pandemic has been a surge in cycling, fueled by people avoiding trains and buses and seeking a way to stay in shape. That triggered an extreme shortage of bicycles. Then came the thieves.

headline: Trump Appointee Is Turning Voice of America Into Partisan Outlet, Lawsuit Says
abstract: Michael Pack, the chief executive of the U.S. Agency for Global Media, and his aides repeatedly meddled in the editorial affairs of Voice of America, the suit says.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five officials suspended from the government’s global media agency sued its chief executive and top aides on Thursday, claiming they broke the law in repeatedly seeking to turn a news service under its purview into a mouthpiece for pro-Trump propaganda.

headline: What We Can Learn From the Rise and Fall of ‘Political Blackness’
abstract: Before “people of color” and BIPOC, Britain had its own inclusive concept for nonwhite people.
lead_paragraph: How Black is Kamala Harris? That the question gets posed speaks to the ill-defined contours of an ill-defined concept. Ms. Harris, the daughter of an Indian-born mother and a Jamaican-born father, has been called in the media “half Black,” “biracial,” “mixed race” and “Blasian.” In online posts, people have ventured that she’s “partly Black” or — for having attended Howard University, a historically Black school — an “honorary full Black.” Others persist in asking whether she’s “Black enough.”

headline: The World According to Bad Bunny
abstract: The Puerto Rican reggaetonero has come to dominate global pop on his own terms.
lead_paragraph: The Puerto Rican reggaetonero has come to dominate global pop on his own terms.

headline: Why You’re Never Too Old to Fight for Racial Justice
abstract: For weeks, I’d bike by this group of older New Yorkers holding placards in front of a Foodtown near Harlem. One day I asked them what they were up to.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, I’d bike by this group of older New Yorkers holding placards in front of a Foodtown near Harlem. One day I asked them what they were up to.

headline: Dawoud Bey, Chronicler of Black American Life
abstract: The photographer takes pictures of everyday subjects and scenes that at once distill this country’s troubled past and provide a glimpse of a better future.
lead_paragraph: The photographer takes pictures of everyday subjects and scenes that at once distill this country’s troubled past and provide a glimpse of a better future.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Objects of Comfort, Lessons From TV and Political Divisions
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to share with us the objects that are bringing them comfort in these uncertain times, tell us about the values they’ve learned from television, and analyze the messages in an illustration related to the upcoming election.

headline: My Screens Are Filled With Black Death, but I Won’t Look Away
abstract: Scenes of racist brutality both real, in news videos, and imagined, in series like “The Boys,” can veer between exposure and exploitation. But sometimes we need to pay the price of our contentment.
lead_paragraph: This essay includes spoilers from the current season of “The Boys.”

headline: 2 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Justine Hill makes more with less in her multipart abstract paintings; Kevin Beasley mixes the political with the personal in “Reunion.”
lead_paragraph: Justine Hill’s bright, multipart paintings are good and good fun, but it has taken some serious work to get them there. You can see it happening in “Touch,” her latest solo show in New York.

headline: 100-Plus Mentor Texts for Documenting Your Life in 2020
abstract: Work by teenagers and adults, in a variety of mediums and genres, that can inspire your own account of this extraordinary year.
lead_paragraph: Update: Aug., 2021: This piece was first written to accompany our Coming of Age in 2020 contest for teenagers. In March, 2021 both a digital and a special print section featured the work of some of the winners.

headline: Kyle Rittenhouse Must Go to Wisconsin for Trial, Illinois Judge Rules
abstract: Mr. Rittenhouse, 17, is accused of shooting three protesters, two fatally, during a protest against the police in Kenosha, Wis.
lead_paragraph: WAUKEGAN, Ill. — Kyle Rittenhouse, the Illinois teenager accused of killing two men during protests over a police shooting in Kenosha, Wis., will be tried in Wisconsin, a judge ruled on Friday.

headline: New York City Shopping Inches Back. No Store Required.
abstract: Secondhand and independent clothing sellers take to the streets.
lead_paragraph: The city is woollier than it’s been in a while — everyone seems to be crimping the usual boundaries. E-bikes and scooters zip through the middle of the street, and restaurants have annexed the pavement outside their doors in hopes of keeping their businesses afloat. After a brutal spring and summer of pandemic uncertainty and economic instability, New York is doing its best to pass for its old self, but in truth, things haven’t felt this unsteady since right after 9/11.

headline: Jalen Rose’s N.B.A. Finals Diary: ‘I Can’t Wait for the Game’
abstract: The ESPN analyst is enthralled by the 2020 series, with players isolating and “Black Lives Matter” painted on the court.
lead_paragraph: Even in a pandemic, Jalen Rose gets his hair cut about twice a week. He likes to look sharp when he’s on TV, and these days, he and his well-groomed head are highly visible. From the basement of his house in Connecticut, the ESPN analyst and former N.B.A. player tapes “Jalen & Jacoby,” his afternoon talk show with the commentator David Jacoby. And at ESPN’s studio at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, he helps anchor “NBA Countdown” before and during halftime of N.B.A. games — including the championship finals, which started this week between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Miami Heat.

headline: In Emptier Subways, Violent Crime Is Rising
abstract: Reports of homicides, rapes and burglaries are posing another challenge to regaining the confidence of passengers during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: It began in the early days of the pandemic in March, when someone lit a fire inside a subway car that killed the train operator and injured 16 others. In the following months, nearly 500 subway car windows were smashed on the No. 7 line. In August, a man tackled and tried to sexually assault a young woman at a station on the Upper East Side. And in September, a train derailed after a man threw metal clamps that he had stolen onto the tracks.

headline: A Common Retort After Insensitive Remarks by Elected Leaders: Resign
abstract: Officials have long atoned for their racist and inappropriate comments. But unlike years past, when apologies might have been enough, they have also been asked to step down.
lead_paragraph: On a tiny barrier island in South Carolina, the three dozen protesters lined up on a muggy Saturday morning this month for the third time in six weeks.

headline: The New Museum Is World Class, but Many Find It a Tough Place to Work
abstract: Critics acknowledge the success the New Museum in New York has achieved. But they say it has come at the expense of many people who work there.
lead_paragraph: Considered one of the finest small museums in America, the New Museum is routinely acclaimed for its exhibitions of contemporary art under the stewardship of its longtime director, Lisa Phillips.

headline: Giving Recipe Creators Their Due
abstract: The NYT Cooking team created a new way to credit the original sources of recipes. But applying the change to The Times’s vast archive of dishes took months of collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Lil Wayne, Latest Rapper in Trump’s Orbit, Sees Backlash Over Photo
abstract: Following Kanye West, 50 Cent and Ice Cube before him, the rapper faced criticism on social media after posting a seeming endorsement of the president.
lead_paragraph: For as long as Donald J. Trump has been a brand name — representing playboy bling and New York business savvy in the 1990s up through his freestyle approach to presidential politics today — he has flirted with hip-hop. Sometimes, famous rappers reciprocate.

headline: A 2nd 911 Call: What to Know About the Amy Cooper Case
abstract: The case of a white woman who called the police on a Black bird-watcher prompted a  conversation amplified by the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Freedom as the Muzzle of a Glock
abstract: In western Colorado, the election is about “not having the government think for us, the right to protect ourselves.”
lead_paragraph: RIFLE, Colo. — At the Shooters Grill, whose waitresses pack heat, I found Gary Nichols enjoying a burger. A man with bright blue eyes and a shock of gray hair, he got right to the point.

headline: The Election’s Big Twist: The Racial Gap Is Shrinking
abstract: Racial and ethnic divides? Actually, Biden is making gains with white voters, and Trump with nonwhite ones.
lead_paragraph: American politicians, including presidents, have often sought to exploit the nation’s racial and ethnic divides for political gain. During the Trump era, voters are not responding as expected.

headline: What We Know About Daniel Prude’s Case and Death
abstract: For months, officials in Rochester, N.Y., tried to keep body camera footage of the police encounter that led to his death from becoming public. A grand jury declined to bring an indictment against the officers involved.
lead_paragraph: Against the backdrop of a national discussion over police brutality and racism, officials said Tuesday that police officers in Rochester, N.Y. who placed a mesh hood on Daniel Prude last year and pressed his face into the pavement would not be charged in his death after a grand jury convened to investigate the case declined to bring an indictment.

headline: False Political News in Spanish Pits Latino Voters Against Black Lives Matter
abstract: On family WhatsApp groups and in Spanish-language media, misinformation paints 2020 as a zero-sum game.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Even by the permissive standards of partisan talk radio, the grave warning from the host of a program on a popular Spanish-language station in Miami one afternoon in September was outlandish.

headline: Finally, the Resistance Gets to Vote
abstract: Now is our chance to put an end to this presidency.
lead_paragraph: We are now entering the homestretch. Voters will finally have a say in whether Donald Trump’s reign of terror and idiocy continues or ends.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Trump’s business pursuits in China.
lead_paragraph: President Trump spent a decade unsuccessfully pursuing projects in China, operating an office there during his first run for the presidency and forging a partnership with a major government-controlled company. Now our investigative reporters have found a bank account there in his name.

headline: We Dared to Assemble. For That, We Were Killed.
abstract: The people of Nigeria are standing up to a government that seems to hate us.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — The High Court of Justice is on fire. Behind my home, it has been ablaze since noon. But in reality, the justice system the court claims to represent has been burning for nearly 60 years.

headline: White House Releases New Plan for Seismic Tests in Arctic Refuge
abstract: The survey would bring heavy trucks looking for signs of oil reserves into one of the most remote and pristine parts of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has relaunched long-delayed plans to conduct a seismic survey in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska as a prelude to drilling for oil there.

headline: With Black Artists’ Input, One Gallery Is ‘Starting to Look Different’
abstract: The Los Angeles dealer David Kordansky is using this moment to get more serious about helping and hiring people “left out of the conversation.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — David Kordansky keeps one of Bob Weir’s guitars and Jerry Garcia’s amplifiers in the office of his gallery here in Mid-City. Love of the Grateful Dead, says the artist Mary Weatherford, helps explain Mr. Kordansky’s approach to being an art dealer. “The Grateful Dead is how Kordansky thinks,” she said. “There is a structure, but within the structure is improvisation.”

headline: Can Fashion Photography Survive the Pandemic?
abstract: Glossy magazines are going digital. Brands are shutting down. The fantasy images of women in ball gowns with elephants may soon be no more.
