abstract: The former vice president’s allies and some of the Democratic Party’s leading progressives have quietly started to forge common ground to shape a climate plan before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the earliest days of his presidential campaign, progressive climate advocates viewed Joseph R. Biden Jr. with deep skepticism. He declined to fully endorse the Green New Deal. He opposed a total ban on fracking. Young activists were scathing in their criticism of him, and he was at times openly dismissive of their concerns.

headline: College Democrats, Citing Racism, Force Change in Leadership
abstract: After a Black executive board member described racism and classism in the leadership ranks of the College Democrats of America, the president of the organization resigned.
lead_paragraph: The president of the College Democrats of America resigned on Wednesday, and members of the executive board pledged not to run for re-election, after the board’s only Black member said he had experienced racism and classism from the organization’s leadership.

headline: Thousands Join N.Y.C. Bike Protests: ‘It’s Like Riding in the Cavalry’
abstract: Black Lives Matter bicycle rides have grown in size and popularity and have evolved into distinctive displays.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 15 minutes, an uninterrupted stream of bicyclists passed through Myrtle Avenue in Brooklyn on Saturday, moving in a line that stretched several blocks in both directions.

headline: A Stadium at Iowa State Says His Name: Jack Trice
abstract: Iowa State is the only major college football team to have named its stadium after a Black man, a player named Jack Trice who died from injuries sustained in a game in 1923 and whose story resonates amid today’s social justice movement.
lead_paragraph: Of the 130 universities that play major college football, only one — Iowa State — has a stadium named after an African-American person.

headline: N.Y.C.’s Budget and a Cut to N.Y.P.D. Funding, Explained
abstract: A city government reporter for The Times explains New York's grim fiscal reality, and the moves meant to placate calls to defund the police.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Fighting Discrimination, a French Woman Becomes a Champion of Men
abstract: Assa Traoré had long demanded justice for her half brother, Adama, who died in police custody. Now, she embodies France’s fight against discriminatory police violence.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Standing on a truck, her fist clenched high and her back turned to a row of police vans, Assa Traoré galvanized the crowd before her.

headline: ‘An Elder and a Humble Giant’: Why They Came to Say Goodbye to John Lewis
abstract: Scores of people lined up to pay respects to Representative John Lewis, the civil rights icon and “conscience of Congress,” as he lay in state in the Capitol on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Scores of people lined up to pay respects to Representative John Lewis, the civil rights icon and “conscience of Congress,” as he lay in state in the Capitol on Monday.

headline: News Quiz: China, Twitter, Disney
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: Live Analysis: New Jersey and Delaware Election Results
abstract: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.

headline: Finally, N.Y.C. Beaches Are Open for Swimming. Thank God.
abstract: Last week, cooped-up New Yorkers were finally able to enjoy the city’s beaches, and a sense of normalcy, even as the threat of coronavirus lingered.
lead_paragraph: Last week, cooped-up New Yorkers were finally able to enjoy the city’s beaches, and a sense of normalcy, even as the threat of coronavirus lingered.

headline: New Jersey Primary Election Results: Eighth Congressional District
abstract: See full results and maps from the New Jersey primaries.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the New Jersey primaries.

headline: Ben & Jerry’s Radical Ice Cream Dreams
abstract: “There wasn’t any other business talking about dismantling white supremacy.”
lead_paragraph: “There wasn’t any other business talking about dismantling white supremacy.”

headline: Inside the Battle for Downtown Portland
abstract: Night after night, calm gave way to chaos. See how the clashes between federal agents and protesters unfolded.
lead_paragraph: Night after night, calm gave way to chaos. See how the clashes between federal agents and protesters unfolded.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Says It Used Restraint During Protests. Here’s What the Videos Show.
abstract: Police officials say there were “isolated cases” of inappropriate force. But 64 videos show many attacks on protesters that appear unwarranted.
lead_paragraph: Police officials say there were “isolated cases” of inappropriate force. But 64 videos show many attacks on protesters that appear unwarranted.

headline: Nearly a Century After a Tulsa Massacre, the Search for Burial Sites Finally Breaks Ground
abstract: A city investigates its traumatic history
lead_paragraph: A city investigates its traumatic history

headline: Live: New Jersey State Primary Election Results 2020
abstract: Detailed results and maps from the New Jersey primary election.
lead_paragraph: Detailed results and maps from the New Jersey primary election.

headline: ‘Hidden Gem’ Made Popular by TikTok Is Shut to Keep Out-of-Towners Away
abstract: A lake in New Jersey was closed to curb the spread of the coronavirus, but some complaints about recent crowding there focused on the ethnicity of visitors.
lead_paragraph: HIGH BRIDGE, N.J. — Lake Solitude it was not.

headline: Death of John Lewis Fuels Movement to Rename Edmund Pettus Bridge
abstract: The bridge became a flash point on March 7, 1965, as protesters, led by Mr. Lewis and other civil rights leaders, were stopped and beaten by state troopers as they marched to Alabama’s capital.
lead_paragraph: The death of Representative John Lewis on Friday has renewed interest in a campaign to rename the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., the site of a turning point in the fight for civil rights.

headline: ‘I Have to Go in and Decolonize’: Europe’s Black Theater Makers Discuss the Scene
abstract: Kwame Kwei-Armah, Julia Wissert and Eva Doumbia met online this week to talk about challenging the establishment, Black Lives Matter and the issue of white universality.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This summer, a coalition of American theater artists issued a statement, “We See You, White American Theater,” calling for an overhaul of the country’s theater landscape. There should be term limits on theater industry leaders to improve representation, it said, and at least half of casts and creative teams should be people of color.

headline: Connections on Air France
abstract: Amanda Rafkin and Ross Trudeau take flight.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — In an interesting take on the “trickle-down” theory of economics, the constructors Amanda Rafkin and Ross Trudeau offer us a Downs-only theme that will make us richer in puns when we’ve finished solving.

headline: Amy Cooper’s 911 Call, and What’s Happened Since
abstract: The white woman who called police on a Black bird-watcher in Central Park is facing charges. But not everyone agrees that's the right course of action.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Kicked Out of China, and Other Real-Life Costs of a Geopolitical Meltdown
abstract: When countries clash, here’s what happens to those of us caught in the middle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Soon after I was informed in mid-March that my journalist visa for China had been canceled, I faced a dilemma: what to do with my collection of wooden staffs used in a style of Chinese martial arts that I had been practicing for nearly 10 years.

headline: Felony Charges Filed Against St. Louis Couple Who Pointed Guns at Protesters
abstract: “It is illegal to wave weapons in a threatening manner,” a prosecutor in the city said.
lead_paragraph: Felony charges have been filed against a St. Louis couple who pointed guns at protesters marching past their home last month in an episode that was captured on video and drew the attention of a divided nation, including President Trump.

headline: He Videotaped the Rodney King Beating. Now, He Is Auctioning the Camera.
abstract: “How much does something like this go for?” asked George Holliday. “I have no idea.” Bidding begins at $225,000.
lead_paragraph: When Rodney King was on the ground, getting kicked, hit with batons and shot with Tasers by several members of the Los Angeles Police Department in 1991, the episode was captured on video by a man who lived across the street from the attack and happened to have a new camcorder.

headline: How 2 New York Schools Became Models for Coping in a Pandemic
abstract: Vulnerable children need creative solutions, educators say: “The entire system has missed something if they don’t rethink what the fall semester looks like.”
lead_paragraph: Around 3 a.m. one day this past spring, a math teacher at Mott Haven Academy was stirred awake by the buzz of a text message. It was from a student, who wrote that his mother had just died from the coronavirus.

headline: ‘The Whole of Liberal Democracy Is in Grave Danger at This Moment’
abstract: Trump’s America has accelerated “the authoritarian dynamic.”
lead_paragraph: In the continuing debate over whether liberals or conservatives are more open minded, whether those on the left or the right are more rigid in their thinking, a team of four Canadian psychologists studied patterns of “cognitive reflection” among Americans.

headline: U.K. Officials’ New Trump Dilemma: What if He Loses?
abstract: If Joe Biden wins the November election, Britain would face a president who opposed Brexit, would look out for Ireland, and may have little interest in a trade deal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II threw him an extravagant state banquet at Buckingham Palace. Former Prime Minister Theresa May welcomed him to Blenheim Palace, the family seat of his hero, Winston Churchill. Her successor, Boris Johnson, refused to join a global chorus of criticism after he ordered troops to break up a Black Lives Matter protest outside the White House.

headline: Federal Agents Envelop Portland Protest, and City’s Mayor, in Tear Gas
abstract: Mayor Ted Wheeler denounced federal agents for an “egregious overreaction,” and official reviews were started in Washington, D.C.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The mayor of Portland, Ted Wheeler, was left coughing and wincing in the middle of his own city on Wednesday night after federal officers deployed tear gas into a crowd of protesters that Mr. Wheeler had joined outside the federal courthouse.

headline: Watching My Child Experience Racism in a Country of Contentment
abstract: A Black mom reflects on what it’s like raising a biracial child in Sweden, where the weeds of racism can look like green grass.
lead_paragraph: I sensed a looming presence next to me while I was punching away at my keyboard, hard at work. When I turned, it was to face my 8-year-old daughter standing close, her eyebrows arched inward.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Halfway Through 2020
abstract: January feels like a decade ago. Here’s what you may have forgotten.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: He Says a Union Fired Him Over His Push for Police Reform
abstract: A clash at a Maryland local shows the tensions in a labor movement whose ranks include law enforcement officers along with many nonwhite, nonpolice members.
lead_paragraph: When Gabriel Acevero, a Maryland state legislator employed by a union local, introduced a bill last year to roll back protections for police accused of misconduct, he was stepping on a potential fault line. His union, Local 1994 of the United Food and Commercial Workers, represents thousands of Black and Latino workers in food services and at a variety of government agencies. It also includes a small portion of workers in law enforcement.

headline: All Spikes Aren’t Equal
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Much of the world is now coping with a coronavirus resurgence.

headline: British Vogue Editor Says the Magazine’s Security ‘Racially Profiled’ Him
abstract: Edward Enninful, who is Black, said in an Instagram post that he was told by a guard this week to “use the loading bay” as he arrived at work.
lead_paragraph: The editor of British Vogue, Edward Enninful, said he was racially profiled after being told by a security guard to “use the loading bay” as he entered the magazine’s offices in London this week.

headline: The West Village: A Pause, and a Reset, for a Coveted Area
abstract: The neighborhood’s low-key, small-scale charms are gradually returning following the lockdown, although residential sales and prices are way down.
lead_paragraph: Store owners have barricaded their shops. West Fourth Street is missing its brunch-hour crowds. And shouting about masks occasionally erupts in packed Hudson River Park.

headline: Want More Diversity? Some Experts Say Reward C.E.O.s for It
abstract: Only a small number of large companies have tied executive compensation to goals for hiring and promotion of workers from underrepresented groups.
lead_paragraph: When Charles E. Jones, the chief executive of a large Ohio-based utility, realized that his senior executives weren’t fully behind his push to hire and promote people of color and women, he decided to do something to get their attention.

headline: Newark Artists, Thriving Amid Crisis and Catharsis
abstract: Laid low by the coronavirus crisis, the city’s artists were then raised on the energy of protests. They have been on the front lines all the while.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — This city prides itself on its resilience, and its artists share in that spirit. Ever since the coronavirus arrived, Newark’s creative community has been on the front lines, responding to the crisis and, now, the catharsis.

headline: A Black Republican Feels the Sting of Racism but Is Silent on Trump
abstract: John James, a candidate for Senate in Michigan, is grappling with heavy and complicated questions as he tries to lead in President Trump’s Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — John James still feels the sting from the harrowing encounters and indignities he has experienced as a young Black man crossing paths with the police.

headline: The Anthem Debate Is Back. But Now It’s Standing That’s Polarizing.
abstract: As games return and dozens of players drop to one knee, leagues that once tried to tiptoe around the issue won’t be able to avoid it.
lead_paragraph: A strange thing happened while most professional sports were away, shuttered by the coronavirus.

headline: 12 Artists On: The Financial Crisis
abstract: As the pandemic continues to derail the global economy, artists share works that reflect on uncertainty, capitalism and racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 virus has sent the global economy spinning into a state of profound disturbance, casting the livelihoods of individuals and small businesses into doubt and leaving entire industries devastated. The financial impact of the pandemic on local communities, as cities and states slash budgets, and on the world at large will continue to play out in the months and years to come. For the fourth installment of our series T Agitprop, we asked 12 contemporary artists, including Torkwase Dyson, Tomashi Jackson, Isaac Julien and Agnieszka Kurant, to contribute works, most of them new and created exclusively for T, in response to this global emergency. Here are their pieces and statements.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Columbo’
abstract: In an era when viewers are re-evaluating the cop show, the detective series starring Peter Falk still stands out, the writer argues: Columbo was all about sticking it to the man.
lead_paragraph: My television goals were moderately ambitious these past few months under quarantine: “I’m finally going to finish ‘The Americans’ and start ‘The West Wing,’” I told myself. “And then I’ll investigate Korean dramas.”

headline: Black Lives Matter Protests Spawn Push for Athletes to Attend Historically Black Colleges
abstract: Makur Maker, a star basketball recruit, chose Howard University over offers from U.C.L.A. and Kentucky, and said he hoped other athletes would consider programs at historically Black institutions.
lead_paragraph: On June 2, as Black Lives Matter protesters swarmed America’s streets demanding an end to the racist vestiges of America’s troubled past, a teenager from a San Diego suburb posted eight words on Twitter that would soon ignite a less visible, though perhaps just as powerful, movement.

headline: Mothers’ Power in U.S. Protests Echoes a Global Tradition
abstract: When mothers take to the streets — particularly those from privileged groups — governments take note. The “wall of moms” in Portland has taken up the cause against police violence.
lead_paragraph: Wearing matching shades of white or yellow, the women of the “Wall of Moms” in Portland, Ore., have become instant icons of the city’s protests, though the mothers nightly gatherings only began last Saturday and the city’s protests have been going on for more than a month.

headline: Black Yoga Collectives Aim to Make Space for Healing
abstract: Instructors and students say that diverse communities can benefit from classes focused on people of color.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Beverly Grant spent years juggling many roles before yoga helped her restore her balance.

headline: Fourth of July Celebrations Dulled by Soaring Coronavirus Cases
abstract: Many Americans, fearful of the virus, stayed at home and held muted celebrations, although some went on undeterred.
lead_paragraph: Fear hung over the Fourth of July holiday this year as the worsening coronavirus pandemic caused many Americans to pull back from their usual celebrations.

headline: Trump’s Wag-the-Dog War
abstract: The president is looking for a dangerous domestic enemy to fight.
lead_paragraph: Some presidents, when they get into trouble before an election, try to “wag the dog” by starting a war abroad. Donald Trump seems ready to wag the dog by starting a war at home. Be afraid — he just might get his wish.

headline: Artists and Writers Warn of an ‘Intolerant Climate.’ Reaction Is Swift.
abstract: An open letter published by Harper’s, signed by luminaries including Margaret Atwood and Wynton Marsalis, argued for openness to “opposing views.” The debate began immediately.
lead_paragraph: The killing of George Floyd has brought an intense moment of racial reckoning in the United States. As protests spread across the country, they have been accompanied by open letters calling for — and promising — change at white-dominated institutions across the arts and academia.

headline: How Berkeley Could Remove the Police From Traffic Stops
abstract: Thursday: The city’s proposal appears to be the first of its kind in the country. Also: A coronavirus update.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Krip-Hop Nation Showcases Rappers With Disabilities. Meet 5 of Our Favorites.
abstract: Hear tracks by hip-hop musicians addressing otherizing media depictions, challenges and perseverance.
lead_paragraph: Since 2007, Krip-Hop Nation has been releasing mixtapes that showcase a worldwide network of hip-hop artists with disabilities. Here are five songs by members of its extended family that have appeared on them over the years.

headline: Protesting U.S. Immigration Policies, Artists Aim for the Sky
abstract: This Independence Day, 70 artists are having messages of solidarity and defiance typed in the sky to highlight the plight of immigrants held in detention centers.
lead_paragraph: The Thunderbirds and Blue Angels that President Trump plans to send flying over the National Mall this Fourth of July will have some stiff competition from a group of 70 artists looking to spread their own messages across the nation’s skies.

headline: Corrections: June 11, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about rising coronavirus infections misidentified the state where Chris Sununu is the governor. It is New Hampshire, not Vermont.

headline: Everyone’s an Antiracist. Now What?
abstract: Recognizing that Black people deserve dignity isn’t progress.
lead_paragraph: The new unbridled enthusiasm for the cause of Black lives reminds me of the Dr. Seuss fable “Horton Hears a Who.”

headline: Trump’s Re-election Message Is White Grievance
abstract: Republicans in D.C. just pretend not to see it.
lead_paragraph: A lot of Republicans are acting puzzled about Donald Trump’s re-election pitch. “He has no message,” one Republican source told Reuters. “He needs to articulate why he wants a second term,” said another. Some have expressed hope that Trump would find a way to become less polarizing, as if polarization were not the raison d’être of his presidency.

headline: Baptist Pastor Is Fired After Coming Out as Transgender
abstract: Junia Joplin, a Baptist pastor in Ontario, asked for acceptance in a sermon: “I want to be the person that God created me to be.” The congregation narrowly voted to terminate her contract.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the Rev. Junia Joplin told her Baptist congregation in a sermon about the importance of telling the truth without fear of the consequences. And then she revealed a secret truth of her own: She is a transgender woman.

headline: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Soar as 18 States Set Single-Day Records This Week
abstract: Friday was the fourth day running that the United States reported over 1,100 deaths. New research sheds light on male vulnerability to severe Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read the latest updates here.

headline: Charles Booker Says Progressives Should ‘Show Up and Listen’ to Deep Red Districts
abstract: Mr. Booker, who narrowly lost a Democratic Senate primary in Kentucky, talked about how to get rural voters on board with a progressive message, saying structural inequality affects all people who feel left behind.
lead_paragraph: For most of his Senate campaign in Kentucky, Charles Booker was considered a long shot. He was running in a Democratic primary against Amy McGrath, a former Marine fighter pilot who had the support of the party’s establishment and had raised over $40 million.

headline: In Stockton, a Powerful Program to Prevent Violence
abstract: With the pandemic, and then the eruption of protests in response to the killing of George Floyd, Julian Balderama’s work has become all the more challenging.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Obama (Privately) Slams Trump
abstract: Raking in cash for Biden, the former president eases off the gloves: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Obama takes the gloves off for Biden, and Congress grills tech executives. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: A Brief History of ‘Karen’
abstract: In 1965, it was the third-most-popular baby name in the United States. In 2018, it was the 635th — and today it’s even less popular. How did Karens fall so far?
lead_paragraph: Ask a woman named Karen what she used to think of her name and you’ll hear phrases like “generic,” “perfectly serviceable” and “an easy name.”

headline: Tapestry C.E.O. Resigns, Acknowledging Past Relationship
abstract: Tapestry, which owns Coach and Kate Spade, had hired a law firm to look into the claim against Jide Zeitlin, one of only five Black chief executives in the Fortune 500.
lead_paragraph: Jide Zeitlin, the chief executive of Tapestry and one of only five Black chief executives in the Fortune 500, resigned on Tuesday and later said the unexpected move, less than a year into his tenure, was related to a past relationship. The company’s board had been made aware of a misconduct allegation involving Mr. Zeitlin and hired a law firm to investigate, according to a person familiar with the situation who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Peaceful Protesters With ‘Room for Rage’ Sympathize With Aggressive Tactics
abstract: A forceful campaign by federal law enforcement in Portland, Ore., has prompted an escalation in tactics from some protesters, while others wonder whether they are losing their focus.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Minutes before midnight on Sunday, the first firework of the evening screeched low over the heads of protesters gathered in Portland, Ore., sprinkling them with white flecks of light and ricocheting into the courthouse that has become a symbol of an unwelcome federal incursion into a local outcry over police brutality.

headline: F.B.I. to Investigate Case of Black Man Pinned by White Man in Indiana
abstract: Vauhxx Booker said a group of white men surrounded him, pinned him against a tree and threatened to “get a noose” after he and his friends had gathered near Lake Monroe.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is investigating a confrontation between a Black man and a group of white men who pinned him against a tree at an Indiana lake over the Fourth of July weekend, after video of the episode drew broad condemnation.

headline: A Dispatch From Outer Space
abstract: A producer reflects on his childhood dream coming true on The Daily’s interstellar phone call.
lead_paragraph: Space, for the most part, is silent. The airless voids between galaxies are scattered with star dust — tiny molecules incapable of carrying sound waves through the dark.

headline: Top N.Y.P.D. Chief Injured While Making Arrest at a Protest
abstract: Terence A. Monahan, New York’s highest-ranking uniformed chief, was one of several officers who were attacked on the Brooklyn Bridge, officials said.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s top uniformed police officer, two lieutenants and a sergeant were injured on Wednesday in two separate incidents on the Brooklyn Bridge, including one that involved an attack with some kind of stick or pole as protesters marched nearby, officials said.

headline: Police Clear Seattle’s Protest ‘Autonomous Zone’
abstract: The so-called Capitol Hill Organized Protest area was taken over by protesters after the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. It was the site of at least four shootings last month.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For weeks, officials in Seattle have been grappling with what to do about a protest zone set up near downtown that became the scene of several shootings and a war of words between city leaders and President Trump: Support it as an exercise in populist democracy? Or shut it down?

headline: ‘The Moms Are Here’: ‘Wall of Moms’ Groups Mobilize Nationwide
abstract: The movement that started with a few dozen moms in Portland now has offshoots in cities across the country.
lead_paragraph: In the flurry of videos and social media posts that have emerged from the protests in Portland, Ore., activist moms are everywhere. They sing lullabies. They link arm–in–arm, forming a human barricade between protesters and federal agents. Some wear respirators, gas masks and helmets. Some hand out sunflowers.

headline: London Police to Review Handcuffing Procedures After Detention of Black Athletes
abstract: The London police commissioner apologized to the track star Bianca Williams and her partner after they were handcuffed during a traffic stop on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The head of the London Metropolitan Police said on Wednesday that the force’s handcuffing practices would be reviewed, after officers on Saturday pulled a top British sprinter and her partner from their car and handcuffed them in front of their 3-month-old son.

headline: The Case Against Ghislaine Maxwell
abstract: The socialite linked with Jeffrey Epstein is expected to appear in court Tuesday to face charges of facilitating the abuse of teenage girls.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: I’m a Black American. I Need a Gun to Feel Safe in This Country.
abstract: Some Black Americans never considered buying a gun. Until now.
lead_paragraph: What does it take for Black Americans to feel safe right now?

headline: Trump Is in Trouble in Pennsylvania, but ‘He’s Been Way Behind Before’
abstract: The president’s campaign and allies have sketched out a comeback path in the battleground state, which he narrowly won in 2016, hoping to capitalize on factors like energy policy.
lead_paragraph: In political speeches for 40 years, Joseph R. Biden Jr. has evoked his scrappy childhood in Scranton, Pa. He kicked off his presidential run last year in Pittsburgh, and as he takes tentative steps out of home confinement in Wilmington, Del., the campaign trail has often led to the state next door.

headline: Mondaire Jones Rides Insurgent Wave to a House Primary Win in N.Y.
abstract: Mr. Jones is likely to become among the first openly gay African-American members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Mondaire Jones, a progressive candidate supported by the institutional left, was declared the victor in a crowded Democratic House primary in the suburbs north of New York City, all but ensuring that he will join Congress next year as among its first openly gay African-American members.

headline: Why Trump Canceled the Convention
abstract: Readers react to the change of plan. One says the president’s ego was the motivation, not safety concerns. Also: Baseball’s mistake; hope and despair; a tribute to Brooks Brothers.

headline: Testing Results Take Too Long, U.S. Official Concedes
abstract: Florida has now recorded more cases than New York. Britain orders travelers from Spain into 14 days of isolation, upending vacation plans for thousands.
lead_paragraph: Read our live Coronavirus Pandemic coverage here.

headline: New & Noteworthy, From Free Speech to True Crime
abstract: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: DARE TO SPEAK: Defending Free Speech for All, by Suzanne Nossel. (Dey Street, $28.99.) The chief executive of PEN America revisits recent debates, arguing that “concerns of diversity and inclusion can — and must — be reconciled with robust protections for speech.”

headline: How Trump’s Use of Federal Forces in Cities Differs From Past Presidents
abstract: Legal scholars fear the president is trying to take on a job that the Constitution did not give the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Federal forces went into Los Angeles to control the Rodney King riots. They entered Washington, Chicago and Baltimore in the days after the killing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968. They went into Detroit during a race riot in 1943, and then again in 1967. They were in Little Rock, Ark., during school integration. For the Pullman Strike of 1894 in Chicago, and across numerous cities during the Great Railroad Strike of 1877, they were there, too.

headline: Trump Plays On Racist Fears About Low-Income Housing
abstract: President Trump said he and Vladimir Putin did not discuss reported Russian bounties for killing American troops. A new poll shows Mr. Trump and Joe Biden locked in a tight race in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the DNC Live: Biden’s speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

headline: Trump Is Dog-Whistling. Are ‘Suburban Housewives’ Listening?
abstract: Or are they too busy organizing protests, posting links to bail funds and discussing antidotes for tear gas?
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.There she is in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957, a white woman in a neatly ironed dress and a short-sleeved, pearl-button cardigan. Her hand is on her hip as she stands in the universal posture of “I would like to speak to your manager” and stares down a soldier defending the Black students who’d integrated Little Rock Central High School.

headline: DeSean Jackson Apologizes for Sharing Anti-Semitic Quotation
abstract: The Philadelphia Eagles condemned social media posts by Jackson, the team’s star wide receiver, saying they were “absolutely appalling.”
lead_paragraph: The star wide receiver DeSean Jackson apologized Tuesday for sharing an anti-Semitic quotation attributed to Hitler, after that and other social media posts were widely condemned, including by his team.

headline: The Wave of Gun Violence in N.Y.C.
abstract: Fifty-three people were shot from Friday through Monday. Officials have suggested  reasons, but it’s difficult to pinpoint one root cause.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Should We Cancel Aristotle?
abstract: He defended slavery and opposed the notion of human equality. But he is not our enemy.
lead_paragraph: The Greek philosopher Aristotle did not merely condone slavery, he defended it; he did not merely defend it, but defended it as beneficial to the slave. His view was that some people are, by nature, unable to pursue their own good, and best suited to be “living tools” for use by other people: “The slave is a part of the master, a living but separated part of his bodily frame.”

headline: White Supremacy Was Her World. And Then She Left.
abstract: To stop hate, we have to understand it.
lead_paragraph: The Sunday Review editor Honor Jones wrote about our decision to publish this story about the white supremacy movement in Friday’s edition of our Opinion Today newsletter.

headline: Information Contagion
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Sinclair Broadcast Group recently published an online interview with a conspiracy theorist who claimed that Dr. Anthony Fauci created the coronavirus using monkey cells. Sinclair — which operates almost 200 television stations — has also run segments downplaying the severity of the virus.

headline: Here Are Key Points About M.L.S.’s Return
abstract: The league removed F.C. Dallas from their tournament because of coronavirus infections, and one of the games scheduled for opening night on Wednesday was postponed.
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer is the first of North America’s major men’s professional sports leagues to return, with a makeshift mini-tournament beginning on Wednesday night. Here are the hows, whys and wheres for the event, which is taking place in Florida, one of the country’s coronavirus hot spots. The caveat is that the league’s plans could easily change: In the last few days, a game has been postponed and a team has dropped out of the field.

headline: Review: Apple-Picking Time Again, in ‘And So We Come Forth’
abstract: Richard Nelson’s fictional family returns, but for the first time this drama of connection in the age of American bewilderment feels smaller than life.
lead_paragraph: Are the Apples becoming must-see TV?

headline: How Democrats Can Win the Youth Vote in November
abstract: Youth organizers have the answers. When will party elites invest in them?
lead_paragraph: Yaniliz Rosario, 19, was making Snapchat playlists for a watch party for an event that some may assume teenagers don’t typically get excited about — a school board meeting. High schoolers logged on, flooding the chat box on Zoom with questions, as Ms. Rosario curated song suggestions and gave them shout-outs.

headline: Yoga, SoulCycle and Peloton Face Truths About How Black Lives Matter
abstract: Instructor walkouts and motivational messages in a predominantly white industry decimated by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic changed the way we work out, possibly forever, Sarah Levey was among the boutique fitness industry’s fastest-rising stars.  She and her husband, Mason Levey, are the founders of Y7, a yoga company with 14 studio locations in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with classes costing $25 each, taking place in candlelit rooms with the heat and hip-hop playlists on full blast.

headline: TV Reporter Dies After Accident Involving Revel Scooter
abstract: Nina Kapur was a passenger on a scooter rented from Revel, whose Vespa-style rental vehicles have become popular in New York City. It was believed to be the company’s first fatality.
lead_paragraph: A local television journalist died over the weekend, the police said, after she fell from a scooter that had been rented from Revel, a moped-sharing company whose Vespa-style vehicles have become a familiar sight on the streets of Brooklyn and Queens.

headline: New Jersey and Delaware Primary Elections: What to Watch For
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s home state is holding a presidential primary, and New Jersey has a full slate of congressional primaries on tap in an election that will be held mostly by mail.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey and Delaware are holding primary elections on Tuesday, with a presidential primary in Delaware and multiple congressional primaries across New Jersey.

headline: San Diego Sheriff’s Deputy Is Charged With Second-Degree Murder
abstract: Sheriff’s Deputy Aaron Russell, 23, is accused of fatally shooting an unarmed man, Nicholas Bils, 36, in the back.
lead_paragraph: The San Diego County District Attorney’s Office on Monday charged a sheriff’s deputy with second-degree murder in the killing of an unarmed man in May — a rare instance of criminal charges being brought against an officer for actions on the job.

headline: Review: Reliving ‘Private Lives,’ This Time Mostly Women’s
abstract: Eight short plays take cues from the 1930 Noël Coward comedy — but now the stakes are different.
lead_paragraph: An unlikely hodgepodge of names gets dropped in the course of Red Bull Theater’s Short New Play Festival: Virginia Woolf, Rachel Dolezal, Troilus, Cressida, Cervantes, Trump. But the name that gets dropped hardest — dropped in the sense that it all but disappears — is that of the production’s touchstone, Noël Coward.

headline: Anti-Asian Harassment Is Surging. Can Ads and Hashtags Help?
abstract: With more than 2,000 incidents and little action from the federal government, efforts to curtail pandemic-related racism have fallen to P.S.A.s and social media campaigns.
lead_paragraph: A new public service announcement makes a point that federal leaders have largely overlooked: Asian-Americans are facing a surge of harassment linked to fears about the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Were the Actions of Federal Agents in Portland Legal?
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security can point to federal statutes protecting property to justify the arrests of protesters in Portland, Ore., but whether they stretched the law would be up to a judge.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security’s deployment of federal agents to Portland, Ore., has shown the broad legal authority an agency created to protect the United States from national security threats has to crack down on American citizens.

headline: President Trump Bows to Reality: This Week in the 2020 Race
abstract: Mr. Trump tried to convey a measure of seriousness about the coronavirus pandemic, backtracking on previous positions and behavior. How long will it last?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.

headline: ‘David Makes Man’ and the Matters of a Young Black Life
abstract: This quietly brilliant coming-of-age series from 2019 has new resonance with its arrival to streaming in 2020.
lead_paragraph: In the pilot of “David Makes Man,” Dr. Woods-Trap (Phylicia Rashad) is speaking to her gifted middle school class about history and family origins. She talks about the complexities and unanswered questions of the past, then turns the focus to her students: “What is your story? Will there be one?”

headline: After #OscarsSoWhite, Disability Waits for Its Moment
abstract: Actors with disabilities are rarely tapped to play disabled characters. Ali Stroker, Marlee Matlin and others share their views on representation in the entertainment industry.

headline: John Lewis, Towering Figure of Civil Rights Era, Dies at 80
abstract: Images of his beating at Selma shocked the nation and led to swift passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. He was later called the conscience of the Congress.
lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis, a son of sharecroppers and an apostle of nonviolence who was bloodied at Selma and across the Jim Crow South in the historic struggle for racial equality, and who then carried a mantle of moral authority into Congress, died on Friday. He was 80.

headline: W.N.B.A. Star’s Role in Freeing Man From Prison Shows Female Athletes at Forefront
abstract: Largely outside of the limelight, athletes like Maya Moore, who helped win the freedom of Jonathan Irons in a questionable conviction, have led the charge for social change.
lead_paragraph: Still in her prime, Maya Moore sacrificed her career, stepping away as one of the greats in basketball for a long shot bid to help free a prisoner she was convinced had been wrongfully convicted.

headline: ‘Free Again’: New Yorkers, Virus in Mind, Head Back to Their Beaches
abstract: Shorelines are finally open for swimming, but outbreaks across the country have given officials pause about the city’s wider reopening.
lead_paragraph: After more than a month of closed beaches — and pitched battles over access to the ocean — Rachel Thompson, a schoolteacher, finally frolicked in the surf at Rockaway Beach in Queens.

headline: Goodbye to a Symbol That Told Black Americans to ‘Know Your Place’
abstract: The Mississippi flag is finally coming down.
lead_paragraph: The onslaught began the day I was born.

headline: At Mt. Rushmore and the White House, Trump Updates ‘American Carnage’ Message for 2020
abstract: His ominous remarks were a reflection of his political standing: trailing in the polls, lacking a booming economy or a positive message to campaign on, and leaning on culture wars to buoy his loyalists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump used the spotlight of the Fourth of July weekend to sow division during a national crisis, denying his failings in containing the worsening coronavirus pandemic while delivering a harsh diatribe against what he branded the “new far-left fascism.”

headline: Who Gets the Banhammer Now?
abstract: In a single week, some of the internet’s biggest platforms banned users and groups they had tolerated for years. What changed?
lead_paragraph: In a typical year, a good way for a company to handle an announcement it hoped to bury is to schedule it before a nice long holiday weekend. This is one way to interpret the last week of June online, when several internet giants took decisive action against mostly far-right communities and users, many of whom who had been sources of controversy for years.

headline: A Different Cold War
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between China and the United States continues to deteriorate, as The Times’s Steven Lee Myers and Paul Mozur explain. The two countries are clashing over Hong Kong, digital technology, trade, the South China Sea and more.

headline: Motorist Who Shot a Protester in Austin Claims Self-Defense
abstract: A ride-share driver fatally shot an armed demonstrator, Garrett Foster, over the weekend. The police are still trying to sort out what happened.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — The deadly confrontation between an armed motorist and an armed protester during a street demonstration in downtown Austin over the weekend began when the motorist made a turn toward a crowd of marchers and came to a stop.

headline: Why Trump’s Attacks on John Roberts Aren’t Working With Some Conservatives
abstract: The Supreme Court has faded somewhat in importance as frustration with the president grows, according to Republicans in the Indiana county where the chief justice grew up.
lead_paragraph: LA PORTE, Ind. — Mitch Feikes is one of many conservatives who disagreed with some of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s recent decisions, including striking down a restrictive Louisiana abortion law and ruling against the White House in its effort to undo an Obama-era immigration program.

headline: Who Helps Out in a Crisis?
abstract: Women and men are equally likely to step up in a time of crisis, but they tend to do so in different ways.
lead_paragraph: — Kathleen Tierney, a co-author of “Disasters, Collective Behavior, and Social Organization”

headline: Shootings Have Soared. Is the N.Y.P.D. Pulling Back?
abstract: As shootings go unsolved, some elected officials think that officers are staging a slowdown. But the department says it is stretched thin.
lead_paragraph: First, a gunman shot a 23-year-old man in the leg on Monday afternoon in eastern Brooklyn, then fled in a red sport-utility vehicle.

headline: Yeah, Let’s Not Talk About Race
abstract: Unless you pay me.
lead_paragraph: To fill the void created by not being able to play basketball for months, I’ve cobbled together a daily workout. I jump rope, I do some light weight lifting, I think real long and hard about doing some push-ups, and I take walks around my neighborhood. It’s a grid and it’s relatively flat, so it’s an easy walk. I follow a path that takes me up and down each street until I’ve reached 10,000 steps, the arbitrary point where I feel accomplished enough to give myself permission to eat an ice cream bar.

headline: ESPN Employees Say Racism Endures Behind the Camera
abstract: In meetings and conversations among colleagues, ESPN employees have criticized the career pipeline and diversity of top leadership, eliciting a promise from executives to do better.
lead_paragraph: The nationwide conversation over systemic racism and equality has prompted a series of discussions and forums at ESPN, where Black employees, many of them behind the cameras, have begun speaking out about the everyday racism and barriers they face at the sports media giant.

headline: Writer for Tucker Carlson Resigns After ‘Abhorrent’ Online Posts Are Revealed
abstract: Fox News condemned Blake Neff, a writer for “Tucker Carlson Tonight,” after he was revealed as the pseudonymous author of racist and misogynist online messages.
lead_paragraph: A writer for the Fox News star Tucker Carlson resigned after he was revealed as the pseudonymous author of several years’ worth of racist, sexist and obscene posts on an online message board.

headline: Who Gets to Be a ‘Naked Athena’?
abstract: On weirdness, whiteness and federal agents in Portland.
lead_paragraph: “Naked Athena.” Have you heard of her? She’s the woman who was so christened after she strolled into a recent Portland protest — one that was ostensibly, crucially, about Black lives — stark naked, save a mask (kudos to that) and skullcap. She sat down with her legs wide, and proceeded to do some yoga poses. Some say she was putting herself between protesters and police, that she was turning the cultural sacredness of a white (or at least a white-passing) woman’s body into a shield against rubber bullets and tear gas.

headline: 1-Year-Old Is Shot and Killed at Brooklyn Cookout
abstract: The child’s death capped another weekend of gun violence in New York City, where shootings in June and July have risen sharply.
lead_paragraph: The cookout in Brooklyn on Sunday night was like many other outdoor parties in New York City during the pandemic. People gathered around a smoldering grill near a park late on a warm summer evening. The group included a 1-year-old boy in a stroller.

headline: I Played in the N.F.L. It Needs Way More Than a Black Anthem.
abstract: If the league wants to show its commitment to its players, it should hire and promote more Black coaches and executives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In response to the Black Lives Matter protests, the N.F.L. has decided to play “Lift Every Voice and Sing,” known as the Black national anthem, in Week 1 of its coming season.

headline: Helping California’s Hard-Hit Central Valley
abstract: Tuesday: An announcement by Gov. Gavin Newsom signaled a shift in the state’s fight against Covid-19. Also: Taking stock of protests.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘A Slap in the Face’: N.Y. Town Rejects Black Lives Matter Painting
abstract: The debate over whether to allow the street art has exacerbated racial tensions in Catskill, where just over a fifth of the population is Black.
lead_paragraph: CATSKILL, N.Y. — The street painting would stretch about three blocks, from Village Pizza II to the stoplight at the southern end of Main Street, spelling out “Black Lives Matter” on the pavement.

headline: Suffrage Isn’t ‘Boring History.’ It’s a Story of Political Geniuses.
abstract: And by the way, it’s “suffragist” not “suffragette.”
lead_paragraph: As the story is often told, the path to women’s suffrage began ​in Seneca Falls, N.Y.,​ in 1848 and ended with the ratification of the 19th Amendment in 1920. Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton​ were the leaders of the movement. It granted all women in America the right to vote.

headline: The Ghost of Margaret Sanger
abstract: Planned Parenthood and the complexities of anti-racism.
lead_paragraph: This week, Planned Parenthood of Greater New York announced that it would remove Margaret Sanger’s name from its Manhattan Health Center. The grounds were Sanger’s eugenic ideas and alliances, which for years have been highlighted by anti-abortion advocates and minimized by her admirers. Under the pressures of the current moment, apparently, that minimization isn’t sustainable any more.

headline: Chaotic Scenes in Portland as Backlash to Federal Deployment Grows
abstract: The street demonstrations that have shuddered through Portland for 54 consecutive nights have drawn out a complicated mix of emotions and grievances.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — With a ski helmet and goggles on her head, Allison Hyder recounted how she had told relatives that she planned to stand at the rear of protests in downtown Portland. But, in the early hours of Tuesday, the grandmother of five found herself right up front, locking arms with other mothers dressed in yellow.

headline: Arizona Is #1, Bahrain Is #4
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: There is no country in the world where confirmed coronavirus cases are growing as rapidly as they are in Arizona, Florida or South Carolina. The Sun Belt has become the global virus capital.

headline: To Make Orchestras More Diverse, End Blind Auditions
abstract: If ensembles are to reflect the communities they serve, the audition process should take into account race, gender and other factors.
lead_paragraph: During the tumultuous summer of 1969, two Black musicians accused the New York Philharmonic of discrimination. Earl Madison, a cellist, and J. Arthur Davis, a bassist, said they had been rejected for positions because of their race.

headline: Coronavirus Cases, Portland, Erykah Badu: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For the N.B.A., a Long, Strange Road Trip to the Finals
abstract: The league has transported 22 of its 30 teams to a complex in Disney World in Florida to play out the season in a worsening pandemic. Can it succeed without the virus piercing the bubble?
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers has likened his new surroundings to a youth basketball tournament for grown men who happen to be some of the most recognizable sports stars on the planet.

headline: I Don’t Want to Spread Covid-19. Can I Sit Out the Protests?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on balancing political progress and public health, and more.
lead_paragraph: In normal times, I would feel an obligation to take part in the recent protests against police brutality. I’m worried, however, that these gatherings could lead to a coronavirus outbreak. Black Americans are suffering from Covid-19 at a disproportionately high rate — I don’t want to endanger the very lives that this movement is seeking to protect. I have done what I can to speak out in other ways, from signing petitions to making donations and even making a Black Lives Matter sign and carrying it for a solo march around my neighborhood (which definitely attracted a lot of laughter and scorn). I feel bad for not getting out there and standing up for what’s right. Is it ethical to support these protests only from a distance? Name Withheld

headline: ‘You Can’t Just Get Up and Steal a Police Horse’
abstract: Adam Hollingsworth, known in Chicago as the Dreadhead Cowboy, is trying to spread a positive message on horseback. But a popular video of him has been widely misinterpreted.
lead_paragraph: In late May, as protests against police brutality began to seize American cities, videos of a Black man on horseback wearing a bulletproof vest spread widely on social media. In many of the posts, users suggested that he had stolen a policeman’s horse.

headline: Federal Agencies Agree to Withdraw From Portland, With Conditions
abstract: Gov. Kate Brown of Oregon said the teams would begin a withdrawal on Thursday. Federal officials cautioned that they would withdraw only when they were confident the federal courthouse could be secured.
lead_paragraph: For days, as fireworks and tear gas erupted in the streets of Portland, Ore., during the deployment of federal tactical teams cracking down on raucous demonstrations, President Trump campaigned against protesters he described as “sick and deranged anarchists & agitators” who he said had threatened to leave Portland “burned and beaten to the ground.”

headline: Downward Dog
abstract: Chase Dittrich makes his New York Times Crossword debut by messing with his keyboard.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Another debut this week! Chase Dittrich joins the club with a puzzle that made me smile and really appreciate computer keyboard shortcuts.

headline: A Timely Case on Police Violence at the Supreme Court
abstract: The justices will hear arguments in October over whether excessive force claims against the police are barred when the people they shoot get away.
lead_paragraph: Early on a summer morning in Albuquerque in 2014, two state police officers in dark tactical gear arrived at a housing complex to serve an arrest warrant. In the parking lot, they came upon Roxanne Torres, sitting in her car with the engine running.

headline: ‘We Will Be a Voice for the Voiceless’: The W.N.B.A. Season Is Dedicated to Breonna Taylor
abstract: The Seattle Storm, with the league’s career assists leader, Sue Bird, and its 2018 M.V.P., Breanna Stewart, back in action, beat the Liberty’s seven-rookie squad in the season opener.
lead_paragraph: The W.N.B.A. season started with 26 seconds of silence and an empty court.

headline: LeBron James Still Reigns as the N.B.A. Returns
abstract: James’s beard has gone gray since the season was suspended in March, but the Los Angeles Lakers forward was as dominant as ever in his first game of the restart on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James has seen a great deal during his 17 seasons in the N.B.A. He has already won three championships, and now aspires to win his first with the Los Angeles Lakers. At 35, he is one of the oldest players in the league, with patches of gray showing in the beard he grew out during the four months he recently spent in relative seclusion.

headline: Kaepernick’s Deal With Disney Includes a Jemele Hill Project at ESPN
abstract: A first-look deal between Colin Kaepernick and Disney includes a documentary series at ESPN that will be produced by Jemele Hill, who left the network two years ago.
lead_paragraph: Colin Kaepernick and the Walt Disney Company announced a production deal Monday that will see the activist quarterback produce “scripted and unscripted stories that explore race, social injustice and the quest for equity” for the media giant’s various platforms, including ESPN.

headline: A Career Spent on Twitter Can’t Ever Tell the Whole Story
abstract: Ryan Babel, one of the first high-profile soccer players to use social media, has spent his career being defined by everything but his play.
lead_paragraph: If you are enjoying this newsletter every Friday, we’re glad. Now please pass it on to a friend (or two) and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: Lifting the Cone of Silence From Black Composers
abstract: Listen to how artists have explored what it means — and could mean — to be American.
lead_paragraph: A cone of silence hangs over the work of Black composers from Africa and its diaspora. It is not that Black men and women have not written music, but too often it has been ignored — and thus assumed not to exist at all.

headline: Drivers Are Hitting Protesters as Memes of Car Attacks Spread
abstract: In recent days, one person was killed in Seattle and two people were injured in Bloomington, Ind. Dozens of similar incidents have occurred across the United States.
lead_paragraph: The driver of a red Toyota first stopped, then unexpectedly accelerated into a crowd of dispersing demonstrators in Bloomington, Ind., on Monday night, injuring two of them in the latest of a disturbing rash of vehicular attacks targeting protesters.

headline: Disability Pride: The High Expectations of a New Generation
abstract: Millions of young people grew up knowing the landmark Americans With Disabilities Act as a birthright. They now demand its guarantees — and even more.
lead_paragraph: To get to her job as the communications director of a legal office in Philadelphia, Imani Barbarin gets in her car — when the coronavirus pandemic doesn’t require working from home — and drives to a train station 20 minutes away.

headline: Uighur Labor, Indian Arrests, Mars Mission: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Staying in New York
abstract: Most New Yorkers who own a second-home hit the road as soon as the virus hit, but a few stayed behind.
lead_paragraph: Jim Curtis was a man in conflict this past spring as he watched the pandemic-panicked flee New York City for their country homes.

headline: Twitter’s user count surged but its revenue fell in the second quarter.
abstract: Twitter’s daily users surged to 186 million in the second quarter, up 34 percent from a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s daily users surged to 186 million in the second quarter, up 34 percent from a year ago.

headline: Sports in a Pandemic Don’t All Stink
abstract: Virtual cycling offers lessons for how other sports can appeal to fans leading increasingly digital lives.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Asked About Black Americans Killed by Police, Trump Says, ‘So Are White People’
abstract: The president rejected the fact that Black people suffer disproportionately from police brutality and made startling remarks about the Confederate flag and a recent confrontation in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, whose re-election prospects have dimmed as Americans question his handling of the coronavirus outbreak and race relations, on Tuesday stoked racial grievances yet again with a series of startling remarks about the Confederate flag, victims of police violence and a St. Louis couple who pointed guns at protesters peacefully marching by their house.

headline: N.Y.C. Seal, With a Native American in Loincloth, Faces Scrutiny
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said it was worth examining if the seal, which dates to 1914, “makes sense for the 21st century.”
lead_paragraph: It features a Native American in a breechcloth and an early American settler holding a long rope with what appears to be a loop on its end, and for more than a century, it has served as the official seal of New York City — but perhaps not for much longer.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Civil Rights Icon Turned Conscience of Congress
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 19, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “This feels and looks so different. It is so much more massive and all inclusive. There will be no turning back.”

headline: The Reconciliation Must Be Televised
abstract: What is the next step as America confronts its racism? A broadcast spectacle, our critic writes, that could look like court, a telethon, therapy, an Oprah show — and more.
lead_paragraph: When someone wants to explain where the country’s been since Memorial Day, they refer to The Moment. “The Moment,” at first, seemed to name a finite period, the killing of George Floyd on May 25, and the moments his death comprised. “The Moment” then proved spongy quick, absorbing the bewildering madness of the deaths of Ahmaud Arbery and Breonna Taylor and expanding into more protests in more corners of the planet than seemed fathomable. (The demonstrations took place during a pandemic; The Moment had swelled inside a Moment.) It appealed to people whose response to such Moments has tended to be less than vociferous — white people. White people marched and chanted. They ate tear gas and pepper spray. White people said “Black Lives Matter,” “systemic racism” and, occasionally, “reparations.”

headline: When the Bake Sale Goes Global, Millions Are Raised to Fight Injustice
abstract: Online sales have become blockbuster events as long-sidelined pastry chefs lead a charge toward activism.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of 13-year-olds, Daniella Senior loved to bake, and thought she might become a pastry chef.

headline: ‘Occupy City Hall’ Encampment Taken Down in Pre-Dawn Raid by N.Y.P.D.
abstract: Officers in riot gear cleared the makeshift camp in City Hall Park, which began as a protest against police abuses but then turned into a gathering of homeless people.
lead_paragraph: Police officers in riot gear cleared out the “Occupy City Hall” encampment in City Hall Park near dawn on Wednesday, shutting down a monthlong demonstration against police brutality that recently had attracted numerous homeless people.

headline: The W.N.B.A. Is Out to Reclaim ‘Tremendous Momentum’ in New Season
abstract: A dramatic free agency period, a new collective bargaining agreement and a leading voice on social justice have set the stage for the W.N.B.A.’s players to capture the spotlight.

headline: Wall Street Journal Staff Members Push for Big Changes in News Coverage
abstract: A letter from a group of Journal reporters and editors calls for “more muscular reporting about race and social inequities,” as well as skepticism toward business and government leaders.
lead_paragraph: Staff members of The Wall Street Journal have been pressing newsroom leaders to make fundamental changes in how the newspaper covers race, policing, and its primary focus, the business world, along with other matters.

headline: Black Behind the Wheel
abstract: On a road trip to Detroit, reflections on the car as a symbol of aspiration and adventure. But if you’re Black in America, that lovely machine isn’t always a refuge.
lead_paragraph: Driving across Woodward Avenue in Detroit a few weeks ago amid a spirited George Floyd demonstration — this one a 30-mile motorcade into the suburbs, billed as the “I Have a Dream Protest Cruise” — my mind drifted strangely to an empty two-lane highway in Arkansas near the Texas border. The memory was jarring, sweeping me away from this raucous caravan — honking horns, Black-power fists thrust from car windows, the whir of sirens — back to my youth in the spring of 1986.

headline: Fary Isn’t Joking About Race in France Right Now
abstract: The comic is a leading figure in the country’s stand-up scene, known for confronting issues of discrimination and identity. Recently, though, being funny has taken a back seat.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As news of George Floyd’s killing by the police ricocheted around the world last month, the French stand-up comedian Fary Lopes, known as Fary, wasn’t telling jokes.

headline: N.Y.C.’s Wave of Gun Violence Continues With 3 Drive-By Shootings
abstract: The attacks in Brooklyn were among the latest in a recent surge that has pushed the number of shootings so far this year well above last year’s figure.
lead_paragraph: Five people were shot in Brooklyn on Monday in what the police described as three drive-by attacks within 20 minutes and about a mile of each other, continuing a wave of gun violence that has gripped New York this summer.

headline: Comedy via Zoom: It’s the Golden Age of Mugging
abstract: After four months of livestream stand-up sets, the format remains awkward. But comics are getting better at playing to the camera, and crowds are learning how to show their appreciation.
lead_paragraph: Before introducing Maria Bamford, the headliner of a livestreaming comedy show Saturday, Jackie Kashian, her opening act, posed a philosophical question: “Is it possible to warm up an audience on the internet?”

headline: How Safe Are Outdoor Gatherings?
abstract: With the virus raging in many parts of the country, new restrictions have left many wondering about the safety of a backyard barbecue or picnic.
lead_paragraph: Is it still safe to socialize outside?

headline: Why Are Fireworks Going Off Every Night in California?
abstract: It’s unclear if the problem is worse this year but complaints are on the rise in parts of California.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Goodbye to the Wild Wild Web
abstract: The internet is changing, and the freewheeling, anything-goes culture of social media is being replaced by something more accountable.
lead_paragraph: It felt like a dam breaking, or the changing of a guard.

headline: Refugee Resettlement Is Close to Collapse. That Was Trump’s Plan.
abstract: Its targeted destruction is too important to ignore.
lead_paragraph: Since the end of World War II, the United States has almost always viewed itself as a leader in resettling refugees forced to flee their homes around the world. But in just three years, President Trump has reduced the flow of refugees to a trickle.

headline: Maya Wiley Is Leaving MSNBC to Weigh Run for N.Y.C. Mayor
abstract: Ms. Wiley, who once led the city’s police oversight board, would enter a mayoral race that has been reshaped by Black Lives Matter protests.
lead_paragraph: Maya D. Wiley, a former top counsel for Mayor Bill de Blasio, is leaving her role as a contributor on MSNBC and NBC News to explore a run for mayor of New York City, an official at MSNBC confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Partyers Clash With German Police
abstract: Tensions are running high in the country amid a national debate on racial profiling in police ranks.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Violence erupted overnight in Frankfurt between police officers and youths who have been partying in a central city square on weekends, with bars and clubs shuttered to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: She Found Her Voice in a W.N.B.A. Locker Room, Then Used It in Sweden
abstract: Amanda Zahui B. wanted to rush back to the U.S. after George Floyd’s death. But she realized there was work to be done back home.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the Liberty became one of the first professional sports franchises to make a unified on-court statement against police brutality and racial injustice. Even before Colin Kaepernick drew widespread attention for kneeling during the N.F.L. preseason later that summer, the Liberty took the court for a game wearing black shirts that said #BlackLivesMatter.

headline: Someone Tore Down a Union Army Statue in Saratoga Springs. Why?
abstract: The monument in a New York park was dedicated to men who volunteered to fight for the Union during the Civil War. It is unclear who toppled it, and for what reason.
lead_paragraph: Early on Thursday morning, the police in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., found a cast iron and zinc statue torn down from its stone pedestal in Congress Park and scattered in pieces on the grass.

headline: A ‘Wall of Vets’ Joins the Front Lines of Portland Protests
abstract: Military veterans said they banded together to protect the free speech of demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — A week after federal officers in Portland, Ore., brutally struck a Navy veteran who said he had approached them simply to ask a question, a group of military veterans on Friday joined the front lines of the city’s growing protests.

headline: Life Inside the N.B.A. Bubble
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein describes his first 48 hours in quarantine at Walt Disney World and discusses recent comments by the former player Stephen Jackson.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: John Lewis: Together, You Can Redeem the Soul of Our Nation
abstract: Though I may not be here with you, I urge you to answer the highest calling of your heart and stand up for what you truly believe.
lead_paragraph: While my time here has now come to an end, I want you to know that in the last days and hours of my life you inspired me. You filled me with hope about the next chapter of the great American story when you used your power to make a difference in our society. Millions of people motivated simply by human compassion laid down the burdens of division. Around the country and the world you set aside race, class, age, language and nationality to demand respect for human dignity.

headline: Its Top Curator Gone, SFMOMA Reviews Its Record on Race
abstract: The senior curator resigned amid anger among staff that boiled over when he used the term “reverse discrimination” — and now the museum is trying to address additional staff complaints.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The meeting was about safety protocols in the time of coronavirus. There was talk of masks, sanitizers and Plexiglas barriers. But that is not what people will remember about the all-staff Zoom call at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday, July 7.

headline: Death and Testing
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: President Trump gave a confrontational interview to Chris Wallace of Fox News yesterday that included numerous untruths about the coronavirus. Trump claimed that the United States had the lowest death rate in the world; that new cases were surging here mostly because of the large number of tests; and that his virus response had saved “millions of lives.”

headline: Did Floyd Protests Lead to a Virus Surge? Here’s What We Know
abstract: Epidemiologists have braced for a surge of coronavirus cases. But it has not come yet.
lead_paragraph: For more than two months, the authorities had been urging New Yorkers to stay indoors and keep their distance from others. But after the police killed George Floyd in Minneapolis, tens of thousands of New Yorkers poured into the streets, day and night, to protest police brutality and racism.

headline: John Lewis, a Man of ‘Unbreakable Perseverance,’ Is Laid to Rest
abstract: The civil rights leader was eulogized by former presidents and family in Atlanta, the city he represented in Congress for more than three decades.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Three former presidents and dozens of other dignitaries were drawn to Ebenezer Baptist Church on Thursday to bid farewell to John Lewis, a giant of Congress and the civil rights era whose courageous protests guaranteed him a place in American history. But even as the funeral looked back over Mr. Lewis’s long life, it also focused very much on the tumultuous state of affairs in the country today.

headline: Country Music Struggles to Meet the Moment. Again.
abstract: The larger music industry has vowed to examine racism and bias. In Nashville, only the genre’s outsiders are dipping their toes in essential conversations.
lead_paragraph: Scornful and indignant, Eric Church — the most accessible of country music’s contemporary heretics — begins his new single, “Stick That in Your Country Song,” with an image of a decayed America:

headline: Anthony Fauci, Heat Wave, Hot Dogs: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Netflix Beat Hollywood to a Generation of Black Content
abstract: The company didn’t set out to build a big library of Black programming, but now it’s the envy of its rivals.
lead_paragraph: The Black documentarian Stanley Nelson says his phone has been “ringing off the hook” as America is looking again at racism and the Black experience. Justin Simien, the creator of “Dear White People,” says the reactions to his pitches have grown warmer. And the director Ava DuVernay reports a flood of calls to “me and every other Black person that’s ever picked up a camera.”

headline: In Campaign Against Racism, Team Names Get New Scrutiny
abstract: It is not just the N.F.L.’s Washington team that could get a name change. A number of schools are also reconsidering nicknames, though some are resisting any switch.
lead_paragraph: Guy Jones had been advocating for 21 long years, hoping for the day when Anderson High School, outside Cincinnati, would drop the nickname he found vulgar and insulting to his Native American heritage.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Black Is King’: Let’s Discuss
abstract: Six critics on the visual album rooted in her “Lion King”-inspired record “The Gift,” a grand statement of African-diaspora pride and creative power.
lead_paragraph: When Beyoncé took a speaking role as Nala — the eventual queen — in the 2019 remake of “The Lion King,” she decided to delve beyond Disney’s Hollywood version of Africa. She added a new, gospel-charged song, “Spirit,” to the film’s soundtrack, and gathered an international coalition, featuring up-and-coming African songwriters and producers, to join her on a full-length album, “The Lion King: The Gift.” Now she has turned songs from the album into a film of her own, working with various directors as she did on her visual albums “Beyoncé” and “Lemonade.” Here, critics for The New York Times discuss the imagery and implications of “Black Is King.”

headline: Take the Next Step Toward Racial Justice
abstract: This incipient movement risks being reduced to a fleeting instant of heightened consciousness.
lead_paragraph: Since George Floyd’s murder, America has begun a remarkable reckoning with racial injustice. People of every race and generation have come together in largely peaceful protests across the nation to halt police brutality, which is disproportionately directed at people of color. But many Americans are demanding much more — that we finally redress the systemic racism that persists in this country, understanding that it diminishes us all.

headline: Colonialism Made the Modern World. Let’s Remake It.
abstract: This is what real “decolonization” should look like.
lead_paragraph: “Decolonize this place!” “Decolonize the university!” “Decolonize the museum!”

headline: ‘It’s Got to Stop’: Atlanta’s Mayor Decries a Surge of Violence as a Girl Is Killed
abstract: Secoriea Turner, 8, was one of several children killed across the country over the holiday weekend. Her death has roiled Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Activists with Black Lives Matter had a vision for what the scorched remains of a Wendy’s restaurant could become: the Rayshard Brooks Peace Center, a gathering place in Atlanta with job training, counseling and youth programs that would be a living memorial named for the man whose fatal encounter with the police transformed the fast-food eatery into the heart of the city’s turmoil.

headline: Black Artists on How to Change Classical Music
abstract: Nine performers describe the steps they recommend to begin transforming a white-dominated field.
lead_paragraph: With their major institutions founded on white European models and obstinately focused on the distant past, classical music and opera have been even slower than American society at large to confront racial inequity. Black players make up less than 2 percent of the nation’s orchestras; the Metropolitan Opera still has yet to put on a work by a Black composer.

headline: Latinos Back Black Lives Matter Protests. They Want Change for Themselves, Too.
abstract: Many Latinos are pushing for an acknowledgment of the systemic racism they face, and a conversation about over-policing in their own communities.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — “Tu lucha es mi lucha,” several signs declared at a recent Black Lives Matter protest near the Arizona State Capitol. Your struggle is my struggle. The sea of faces included young Latinos who had marched before, during the immigrant rights movement in the state a decade ago, when Joe Arpaio championed draconian policies as the sheriff of Maricopa County. There was no doubt in these protesters’ minds: Their fights against racism are bound up together.

headline: A Harlem Restaurant That’s Withstood Gentrification, a Pandemic and Time
abstract: Long lines are still forming at Famous Fish Market, a Black-owned business that’s been in the same family for nearly 50 years.
lead_paragraph: At 145th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue in Harlem, a line begins outside a modest storefront near the subway station and extends down the avenue for about 10 hours straight.

headline: To Battle a Militarized Foe, Portland Protesters Use Umbrellas, Pool Noodles and Fire
abstract: With no clear leaders or blueprints, demonstrators have scrounged for items from home and largely embraced a strategy of spontaneous consensus.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Shields were made of pool noodles, umbrellas and sleds. The body armor was pieced together with bicycle helmets and football pads. The weapons included water bottles and cigarette lighters.

headline: Smithsonian’s Leader Says ‘Museums Have a Social Justice Role to Play’
abstract: Lonnie Bunch, who oversees a host of museums and libraries, says the role of cultural institutions is to make people “feel comfortable with nuance and complexity.”
lead_paragraph: In 2005, Lonnie G. Bunch III became the founding director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture. There was just one problem. The museum did not yet exist. There was no collection, no funding, no site and just one employee. Just over a decade later, the museum opened on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., to rave reviews and huge crowds.

headline: American Crime and the Baltimore Model
abstract: Cities across the country are in danger of making the same mistakes.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, there were 211 homicides in the city of Baltimore. The following year, there were 342, an astonishing increase of 62 percent. The murder rate has barely budged since.

headline: Family-Friendly Movies Made by Diverse Filmmakers
abstract: These 8 movies were written, directed by and star people of color, and depict complex stories that can spark conversation.
lead_paragraph: For parents trying to figure out how to talk to their children about racism, film can be a useful tool for generating empathy. But many family-friendly movies with diverse casts are told from a white perspective, for a white audience. That can rob people of color of their turns as the hero, nullifying their voices. And the stories are usually about racism, presenting the issue as a problem to be solved, wrapping up in a neat resolution.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Predicts Trump Will Say He Was the First to Wear a Mask
abstract: After the president finally wore a face mask in public, the “Tonight Show” host called it “a really smart move — if today were March 13th.”
