lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Jason Rodriguez’s Vogue Family Values: Positivity, Trust, Love
abstract: The dancer and choreographer strives to empower a generation: “If you’re not expressing your most confident self, you’re not voguing.”
lead_paragraph: Jason Rodriguez is worried. Not for himself — the dancer, actor and choreographer has been doing well during the pandemic. His concern is for those in the L.G.B.T.Q.I.A.+ community, specifically Black trans youth.

headline: Memers Have a New Campaign Aimed at Getting Trump Out of Office
abstract: Meme 2020, the social media collective that supported Michael Bloomberg’s presidential primary run, is back with a new focus: mail-in ballot registration.
lead_paragraph: Meme 2020, the collective of social media influencers and content creators that posted sponsored content in support of Michael Bloomberg’s Democratic presidential primary run, is back with a new campaign aimed at preventing the re-election of President Donald Trump.

headline: ‘Richard II’ Review: A Radio King With a Tottering Crown
abstract: Electric performances, led by André Holland, transcend didacticism in an audio rendition that replaced a Shakespeare in the Park production.
lead_paragraph: You say you want a revolution. Well, you know — we all wanna rule the world.

headline: 5 Guards and a Nurse Face Charges in Death of Inmate Who Pleaded, ‘I Can’t Breathe’
abstract: Five former detention officers and a nurse at a North Carolina jail were charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a Black man, John Neville, 56.
lead_paragraph: Five former detention officers and a nurse at a North Carolina jail have been charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a Black man who repeatedly exclaimed, “I can’t breathe,” as the officers tried unsuccessfully to remove his handcuffs, a prosecutor said on Wednesday.

headline: We May See Trump’s Taxes. Eventually.
abstract: The Supreme Court said President Trump couldn’t block a request for his financial records by prosecutors in New York.
lead_paragraph: Our DealBook Debrief conference calls are back, starting next week. On Thursday, July 16 at 11 a.m. Eastern, we will be joined by the White House correspondent Maggie Haberman to discuss how the Trump administration is addressing election-year concerns amid the risk of a renewed wave of infections. R.S.V.P. here for the call. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda and Disney: Timeline of a Collaboration
abstract: Disney+ is streaming a live-capture film of “Hamilton.” It’s just the latest chapter in a deepening relationship between the company and the musical’s creator.
lead_paragraph: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s relationship with Disney started inauspiciously. He wrote a song on spec for a holiday show. The company rejected it.

headline: Trump Is Trying to Bend Reality to His Will
abstract: Can his aggressive version of ethnonationalist populism prevail in 2020? The answer is not obvious.
lead_paragraph: Disruption, disorder and disease are gripping the United States as the 2020 election draws near, leading to an unusual degree of unpredictability about our political future. Despite current state and national polling that favors Democrats, we still can’t say for sure whether the nation will tip left or right.

headline: Hannibal Buress Meets the Moment
abstract: In ways large and small, the stand-up’s new special, released free on YouTube, taps into the national mood, once again showing what a talent he is.
lead_paragraph: In his dynamite, accidentally topical new special “Miami Nights,” released for free on YouTube over the July Fourth weekend, Hannibal Buress describes himself as “medium famous,” which he says translates to: “I constantly talk people out of recognizing me.”

headline: The Uncertain Future of Midtown
abstract: Midtown Manhattan faces an economic catastrophe, a cascade of loss upon loss in the city's corporate heart that threatens to alter its identity.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: What Are Federal Agents Doing in Portland?
abstract: A militarized crackdown raises an outcry from local leaders: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Armed federal agents are patrolling the streets of Portland against the wishes of local leaders, and the president refuses to guarantee that he won’t contest the official results of the election. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: A Protester, an Unmarked N.Y.P.D. Van and a Viral Video
abstract: Eyewitnesses and social media users drew a parallel with tactics used in Portland, Ore., and city and state officials voiced criticism.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: That Word
abstract: Few prominent women in power have publicly addressed a particular vulgarity that men have leveled against them for years. Today, on the floor of the House, that changed.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Playwrights Horizons Details First Season Under New Leadership
abstract: Though no dates are set, Adam Greenfield plans to present four plays, all directed by women, at the Off Broadway theater.
lead_paragraph: In his first season at the helm of Playwrights Horizons, Adam Greenfield is sending a message: The organization may be staging fewer shows because of the pandemic — four in its 2021 season, down from the six that were slated for the 2019-2020 season — but it is committed to showcasing work by writers of color.

headline: Trump, Please Quit Before You’re Fired
abstract: By walking away, he can save the lives of supporters who have listened to his lethal quackery.
lead_paragraph: It was clear when President Trump woke up on Thursday morning, with no pollster left to lie to him, and not enough Fox News sycophancy to fill his cereal bowl, that he would have to play one of the last tricks in the dictator’s handbook.

headline: The Return of Jane Elliott
abstract: Before anti-racist reading lists and Instagram allyship, white people were presented with the “Blue Eyes, Brown Eyes” exercise. Its 86-year-old creator can’t believe she’s still being asked about it.
lead_paragraph: The day after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968, the schoolteacher Jane Elliott scrapped her lesson plan — teaching her third graders the Sioux prayer about not judging another person until you have “walked a mile in his moccasins” — for an experiential learning exercise.

headline: Robert Fuller’s Hanging Was a Suicide, Investigation Finds
abstract: The case was one of two hangings in California that drew scrutiny amid nationwide protests after the killing of George Floyd. Both have been ruled suicides.
lead_paragraph: An investigation has confirmed that Robert Fuller, who was found hanging from a tree in a Southern California park on June 10, committed suicide, officials announced on Thursday.

headline: As a Flag Comes Down, Looking for a ‘New Mississippi’
abstract: Much of Mississippi galvanized around the effort to remove the state flag. Residents now want to seize on the momentum created by the triumph.
lead_paragraph: [Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

headline: Why a ‘Do No Harm’ General Election Strategy Could Work for Joe Biden
abstract: Mr. Biden is running a risk-averse campaign in states like Wisconsin, where a broad coalition of supporters is emerging. Even Republicans are noticing.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: Call a Thing a Thing
abstract: White supremacy is the biggest racial problem this country faces, and has faced.
lead_paragraph: Now that we are deep into protests over racism, inequality and police brutality — protests that I’ve come to see as a revisiting of Freedom Summer —  it is clear that Donald Trump sees the activation of white nationalism and anti-otherness as his path to re-election. We are engaged in yet another national conversation about race and racism, privilege and oppression.

headline: Val Demings Is on Biden’s V.P. List. Will Her Police Career Hurt or Help?
abstract: The former police chief in Orlando, Fla., Ms. Demings has emerged as a finalist to be Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate. A review of her record shows a complicated history with episodes involving police misconduct.
lead_paragraph: An Orlando police officer shoved a 27-year-old Hispanic woman down a flight of stairs, breaking her ankle. A jury ordered him to pay her medical bills.

headline: ‘White Fragility’ Is Everywhere. But Does Antiracism Training Work?
abstract: Robin DiAngelo’s best seller is giving white Americans a new way to talk about race. Do those conversations actually serve the cause of equality?
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Gerard Way Sneers at the Apocalypse, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Katy Perry, Dominic Fike, James Blake and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Coronavirus, Hagia Sofia, Frozen Drinks: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: At Wall Street Journal, News Staff and Opinion Side Clash
abstract: A heated dispute between the newsroom and the opinion section of one of the country’s most respected news organizations has spilled into public view.
lead_paragraph: In a rare display of internal strife, the opinion department of The Wall Street Journal openly antagonized the paper’s news staff Thursday by publishing a tersely worded note to readers just days after it found itself on the receiving end of a sharply worded critique signed by hundreds of newsroom employees.

headline: A Biden-Obama Reunion Pitches a Campaign as Comfort-Food TV
abstract: The polished video, business-casual and unsurprising, offered voters a show that wouldn’t raise their blood pressure.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has been a boom time for TV reunions: “30 Rock,” “Parks and Recreation,” “Community” and more. On Thursday, the Joseph R. Biden campaign premiered a reunion of the West Wing — not the NBC drama, but the previous, pointedly low-drama presidential administration.

headline: Trump Plays on Racist Fears of Terrorized Suburbs to Court White Voters
abstract: President Trump painted a false picture of suburbs under siege, saying he was protecting them from low-income housing, as he seeks to win over white voters who were key to his 2016 victory.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live analysis of the Biden inauguration.]

headline: Did New York Just Get the Nation’s Most Liberal Legislature?
abstract: Among those toppled by progressive insurgents was a Brooklyn assemblyman who was first elected in 1972.
lead_paragraph: A slew of progressive challengers upset entrenched incumbents in the New York Legislature in the recent Democratic primary, cementing their movement’s influence in Albany and making it likely that the state government will become one of the most liberal in the nation.

headline: As the Virus Surged, Florida Partied. Tracking the Revelers Has Been Tough.
abstract: With the coronavirus exploding, trying to trace the contacts of every positive case has become unrealistic in Florida, especially among elusive partygoers.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Miami’s flashy nightclubs closed in March, but the parties have raged on in the waterfront manse tucked in the lush residential neighborhood of Belle Meade Island. Revelers arrive in sports cars and ride-shares several nights a week, say neighbors who have spied professional bouncers at the door and bought earplugs to try to sleep through the thumping dance beats.

headline: Soledad O’Brien: A MeToo Moment for Journalists of Color
abstract: We’re finally feeling empowered to speak openly about racism in the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: Every journalist of color has a story.

headline: What Black Lives Matter Has Revealed About Small-Town America
abstract: A multiracial future has appeared, along with unprecedented conversations about race.
lead_paragraph: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa. — Nikki Wilkerson was used to thinking of herself as the “small brown girl” growing up in rural Pennsylvania.

headline: What to Know About N.Y.C.’s Surge in Shootings
abstract: Over the weekend, 64 people were shot, with 10 dead. A  surge of gun violence has shaken a city that was already on edge.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Selma Helped Define John Lewis’s Life. In Death, He Returned One Last Time.
abstract: The body of John Lewis crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge on Sunday, more than a half century after he helped change American history there.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — On a different Sunday in Selma, this one more than five decades ago, John Lewis was a 25-year-old activist wearing a long tan coat and carrying a backpack, helping to marshal hundreds of demonstrators across the Edmund Pettus Bridge. They were bombarded by clouds of tear gas and swarmed by state troopers wielding clubs, one of which fractured Mr. Lewis’s skull.

headline: North Carolina City Approves Reparations for Black Residents
abstract: The measure passed by the City Council of Asheville, N.C., would provide funding to promote homeownership and business opportunities, but stopped short of stipulating direct payments.
lead_paragraph: As Americans debate how far the country should go to make amends for slavery and other racial injustices, a conversation reawakened by the killing of George Floyd, a city in North Carolina has taken the first step: It approved reparations for Black residents.

headline: How One of America’s Whitest Cities Became the Center of B.L.M. Protests
abstract: In a state with a brutal racist history, the Black Lives Matter protests in Portland, Ore., have been overwhelmingly attended by white demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Seyi Fasoranti, a chemist who moved to Oregon from the East Coast six months ago, has watched the Black Lives Matter protests in Portland with fascination. A sea of white faces in one of the whitest major American cities has cried out for racial justice every night for nearly two months.

headline: Breanna Stewart Is Ready for Her Old Normal: Winning Championships
abstract: The Seattle Storm forward played in her first W.N.B.A. game in almost two years since rupturing her Achilles’ tendon. She returns in a season like no other.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Stewart’s previous installments here and here.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 7: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by July 31 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 11.
lead_paragraph: Update: Winners have been announced!

headline: Whole Foods Punished Workers for Black Lives Matter Masks, Suit Says
abstract: Over a dozen workers at Whole Foods stores in four states claim in a class-action lawsuit that the company retaliated against them for wearing the movement’s apparel.
lead_paragraph: From colorful patterns and vegetable prints to SpongeBob SquarePants, creative masks have been embraced by Whole Foods employees across the country since the pandemic began.

headline: The Dangers of the N.B.A.’s Short Run-Up to the Restart
abstract: Players have about three weeks to re-acclimate their bodies to full five-on-five speed and physicality. But if they push too hard, injuries could become a serious problem.
lead_paragraph: One of the go-to mantras from the Gregg Popovich coaching handbook is a leaguewide credo now. No one in the N.B.A., as Popovich has been saying in San Antonio for years, wants to be caught “skipping steps” as the league begins the most challenging undertaking in its history.

headline: The Week in Business: Twitter’s Mystery Hackers
abstract: Twitter’s hackers could have made chaos. Why didn’t they?
lead_paragraph: Good morning. A financial tip: When someone on the internet asks for Bitcoin and promises double your money back, it’s probably a lie. Here’s what else you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead.

headline: Tucker Carlson to Take ‘Long-Planned’ Vacation After Writer’s Resignation
abstract: On his Monday evening show, the Fox News host said racist and sexist posts by one of his writers, Blake Neff, were “wrong,” while castigating his detractors as “ghouls.”
lead_paragraph: The Fox News star Tucker Carlson said on Monday evening that he would leave on a vacation, starting immediately, days after a writer on his program, Blake Neff, resigned over racist, sexist and misogynist messages that Mr. Neff published pseudonymously on an online message board.

headline: Michael Bennett, a Protest Pioneer, Retires From the N.F.L.
abstract: The defensive end announced his retirement on Instagram after an 11-year career in which he won a Super Bowl with the Seattle Seahawks and became a leading voice on race and police brutality.
lead_paragraph: Michael Bennett, the standout defensive end who spoke out forcefully against racial injustice during his career, said he was retiring after an 11-year N.F.L. career, primarily with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Seattle Seahawks.

headline: The Real Reason Biden Is Ahead of Trump? He’s a Man
abstract: It’s a lot easier to run a cautious, inoffensive campaign when you’re not up against a culture of misogyny.
lead_paragraph: A narrative has formed around the presidential race: Donald Trump is losing because he’s botched the current crisis. Americans are desperate for competence and compassion. He’s offered narcissism and division — and he’s paying the political price.

headline: They Can’t Stomach Trump. They’re Sufficiently Comfortable With Biden.
abstract: Some voters who disliked both nominees in 2016 chose a third-party candidate instead. Now, many of them are shunning President Trump and are ready to back Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: In Florida in 2016, J.C. Planas, a former Republican state representative, was uncomfortable with Hillary Clinton but detested Donald Trump, so he wrote in former Gov. Jeb Bush for president.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 5: On ‘Hamilton Review: You Say You Want a Revolution’
abstract: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Ava Hyde, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: Thank you to the 859 teenagers who participated in the fifth week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest, and congratulations to Ava Hyde, our winner, as well as to our many runners-up and honorable mentions.

headline: The View From Waukesha
abstract: The 29-year-old Democratic Party chairman in this key Wisconsin county has a plan for Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Astead Herndon, reporting on the road in Wisconsin while Lisa Lerer is away.

headline: Don’t Call Him Machine Gun Kelly
abstract: The rapper and actor has a real name: Colson Baker. And he’s finding his voice during the lockdown.
lead_paragraph: A few days before Los Angeles announced a shelter-in-place order in March, Colson Baker, who raps under the name Machine Gun Kelly, sat down on a sofa with an acoustic guitar. His tattoos peeked through a white tank top. Tousled blond hair poked out of a Cleveland Cavaliers cap.

headline: 2020 Election Updates: Polls Suggest Trump Is Losing His Edge on the Economy
abstract: Last month, a majority of voters said they trusted President Trump over Mr. Biden to handle the economy, but a new poll shows the opposite. Mr. Trump visited Georgia as the G.O.P. turned to Senate battles there.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the DNC Live: Biden’s speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

headline: Ja’Ron Smith’s Balancing Act: A Black Republican Navigates the Trump White House
abstract: As a congressional staff member, Mr. Smith once wore a hoodie in a demonstration on Capitol Hill protesting the death of Trayvon Martin. Now President Trump calls him “my star.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days after Trayvon Martin was shot and killed by a white neighborhood watch volunteer, Ja’Ron Smith was among a group of congressional aides who pulled on hoodies and stood on the steps of the U.S. Capitol in protest.

headline: N.Y.C. Paints ‘Black Lives Matter’ in Front of Trump Tower
abstract: The public art project is the latest battle in a feud between President Trump and Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: New York City painted “Black Lives Matter” in large yellow letters on the street outside Trump Tower on Thursday, the latest flare-up in a yearslong feud between President Trump, who rose to fame as a Manhattan real estate developer, and Mayor Bill de Blasio, who once sought to replace him.

headline: In the Autonomous Zones
abstract: Autonomous zones, protest camps and intentional communities alike thrive on hard work and consensus — and can become disastrous rapidly.
lead_paragraph: At first they called it the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone.

headline: The White House Called a News Conference. Trump Turned It Into a Meandering Monologue.
abstract: The president spoke in the Rose Garden for 63 minutes. He spent only six of those minutes answering questions from reporters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In theory, President Trump summoned television cameras to the heat-baked Rose Garden early Tuesday evening to announce new measures against China to punish it for its oppression of Hong Kong. But that did not last long.

headline: The Left Is Remaking the World
abstract: “Defund the police” and “cancel rent” aren’t reforms, but paths to revolution.
lead_paragraph: The uprisings in response to the killing of George Floyd are far different from anything that has come before. Not just because they may be the largest in our history, or that seven weeks in, people are still in the streets (even if the news media has largely moved on). But also because, for the last few years, organizers have been thinking boldly.

headline: At Old St. Pat’s, a History of Defiance
abstract: A pink brick wall protected the basilica in NoLIta last month during days of civil unrest, just as it did during riots two centuries ago.
lead_paragraph: Early last month, amid protests against police violence in the wake of the George Floyd killing, the pink brick wall surrounding the cemetery of the original St. Patrick’s Cathedral in NoLIta was spray-painted with graffiti, while a storm window protecting one of the church’s soaring stained-glass windows was broken.

headline: ‘Bébé’s Kids’ Shared a Lesson About Racial Injustice
abstract: This 1992 animated movie about Black children running into trouble at a theme park is meant to be a comedy. But for one viewer, it no longer seems so funny.
lead_paragraph: “The Boondocks,” “Atlanta,” “black-ish,” “Dear White People,” “Sorry to Bother You” — there are a few shows and movies that have dared to use comedy to address the grim state of Black people in America. But lately, I’ve been thinking about a movie I hadn’t seen in more than 20 years: “Bébé’s Kids.” This animated Black comedy explicitly spoke about police brutality and our broken judicial system years before the first utterance of “Black Lives Matter.”

headline: Two Teenagers Are Among 8 Killed on Deadly Day in New York City
abstract: The spate of shootings on Sunday came as the city wrestles with a spike unlike anything it has seen in decades.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Mendez did not think twice on Sunday when her teenage son, Kleimer, asked if he could go play basketball near their home in Brooklyn’s Cypress Hills neighborhood.

headline: Boom Time for Death Planning
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has drawn new business to start-ups that provide end-of-life services, from estate planning to a final tweet.
lead_paragraph: One day in April, as the coronavirus ravaged New York City, 24-year-old Isabelle Rodriguez composed a tweet she would send from the grave.

headline: Jamaal Bowman Proves Ocasio-Cortez Was No Fluke
abstract: Mr. Bowman beat Representative Eliot Engel, a 16-term incumbent, in a race that pitted the Democratic Party’s progressive wing against the establishment.
lead_paragraph: After a little-known candidate named Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez stunned a powerful Queens congressman in a 2018 primary, Democratic Party leaders were determined to never be surprised the same way again, vowing to protect incumbents and clashing with Ms. Ocasio-Cortez and other upstarts for pushing for more progressive candidates.

headline: ‘The Better I Got in Sports, the Worse the Racism Got’
abstract: Patty Mills, a key reserve for the San Antonio Spurs, said he developed an emotional shield from a lifetime of racial abuse, but he is using the platform of the N.B.A.’s restart to speak out against racism.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — There were a few must-pack accessories for Patty Mills of the San Antonio Spurs for his stay at Walt Disney World. Mills brought a stack of books on Black history in the United States and his native Australia. He made sure to carefully transport his favorite flat-brimmed hat, which bears two flags representing Australia’s Indigenous populations.

headline: In the Hudson Valley: Live Dancers, Real Sweat, Natural Beauty
abstract: Almost all dance in the United States has gone virtual. But Kaatsbaan will fill the void, hosting its first-ever festival.
lead_paragraph: TIVOLI, N.Y. — This summer, as stages around the country lie empty and unused, Kaatsbaan, in Tivoli, N.Y., will be something precious and rare: one of the few places in America where dancers will be performing live, in person, in front of a living and breathing, if well-distanced and masked audience.

headline: As Galleries Reopen, Two Critics Find Rewards Eclipse the Angst
abstract: Holland Cotter masks up on the Lower East Side and SoHo; Jillian Steinhauer discovers eco-feminist art taking root in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: In the New York art world, normal is still a long hike down the pike, but some of the city’s galleries are tiptoeing in that direction with socially distanced reopenings.

headline: A Retelling of American History — in Neon
abstract: Maya Stovall, known for her dance performances in public spaces, shares a new artwork.
lead_paragraph: In this new series, The Artists, an installment of which will publish every day this week and regularly thereafter, T will highlight a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist, putting the work into context. First up is a piece by Maya Stovall, who is best known for her dance performances in public spaces, as documented in her “Liquor Store Theater” video series, which will screen this summer as part of the citywide digital-art exhibition “Art Mile Detroit.”

headline: Stir-Crazy New Yorkers Discovered an Idyllic Spot. Will They Trample It?
abstract: During the pandemic, people are venturing deeper into the city’s forests, wetlands and grasslands, just as budget cuts threaten the spaces’ upkeep.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks into the coronavirus pandemic, Steve Maing, his partner and their 2-year-old daughter, Rosie, discovered the spot that would make their life in locked-down New York bearable.

headline: The N.Y.P.D. Has Rejected Reform for Decades. It Can’t Anymore.
abstract: New York is finally giving its Police Department the scrutiny it deserves.
lead_paragraph: In New York, a 1-year-old boy was fatally shot over the weekend, one of the latest victims in a surge of violence that has rattled an already traumatized city. As of Monday, New York City had had 634 shootings this year, up from 394 at the same time last year, according to Police Department data.

headline: 14 People Are Shot Near Chicago Funeral Home
abstract: The shooting comes during a dispute between Mayor Lori Lightfoot and President Trump, who had said he would send federal agents to the city as it contends with violence.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Fourteen people were shot on Tuesday evening near a funeral home on the South Side of Chicago, an episode of the kind of urban violence that President Trump has made a cornerstone of his re-election campaign.

headline: FaZe Clan President Departs: ‘It’s Time for Gaming to Clean Up Its Act’
abstract: Greg Selkoe is leaving the successful esports conglomerate to start a new venture that’s less “frat house” and more diverse.
lead_paragraph: FaZe Clan, an esports lifestyle conglomerate, helped turn gamers into a new class of social media influencers. Now, several top executives behind FaZe Clan are leaving to start a competing organization called XSET.

headline: 2 People Charged With Hate Crime After Black Lives Matter Mural Is Vandalized
abstract: If convicted, the two residents of Martinez, Calif., could face up to a year in jail, prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: Two white people in California were charged on Tuesday with a hate crime and other offenses after video appeared to show them vandalizing a Black Lives Matter mural on July 4, officials said.

headline: George Floyd’s Killing Prompts Africans to Call for Police Reform at Home
abstract: Africans are increasingly pushing to hold police agencies to account and “decolonize” the repressive institutions they inherited from colonial rulers.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyan and American protesters knelt outside the United States Embassy in Nairobi one morning last month, outraged at George Floyd’s killing and the racism and brutality they saw across the Atlantic. But they were also furious about police abuses at home, in Kenya.

headline: 7 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: How can you get your cultural fix when many arts institutions remain closed? Our writers offer suggestions for what to listen to and watch.
lead_paragraph: Madonna beat Beyoncé to the title “Queen of Pop,” but Beyoncé’s more open-ended honorific, “Queen Bey,” turned out to be quite fitting: These days, she hardly limits herself to just the one medium. Since 2013’s self-titled LP, her albums have been cinematic feats as much as musical events. Her latest opus, due out on Friday, is “Black Is King,” a visual corollary to last year’s album, “The Lion King: The Gift” — itself a companion to Disney’s blockbuster remake of the 1994 animated classic.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 5: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by July 17 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 28.
lead_paragraph: Update: Winners have been announced!

headline: What Is Your True ‘Character’? And Who’s to Judge It?
abstract: Marjorie Garber’s new book prods at the cloud of confusion surrounding the word — its philosophical roots, literary history, political uses and inadvertent comedy.
lead_paragraph: In the ungainly, interminable pageant of public apologies of late, one statement about misbehavior is proving strangely popular.

headline: In Russia, They Tore Down Lots of Statues, but Little Changed
abstract: “Waging war on bronze men doesn’t make your life any more moral or just,” one observer noted. “It does nothing really.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Elated by the defeat of a hard-line Communist coup in August 1991, thousands of mostly young Muscovites gathered in front of the K.G.B. headquarters and argued over how best to seal their victory with a bold, symbolic act.

headline: So Y’all Finally Get It
abstract: America just won’t let us rest.
lead_paragraph: Excerpts from our June 12 live event, where we caught up about the uprisings and resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement. This is the first of three special summer episodes.

headline: Trump’s Threat of Force
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has been preoccupied with big-city crime for more than 30 years.

headline: The Latest in School Segregation: Private Pandemic ‘Pods’
abstract: If they become the norm, less privileged kids will suffer.
lead_paragraph: As school districts across the nation announce that their buildings will remain closed in the fall, parents are quickly organizing “learning pods” or “pandemic pods” — small groupings of children who gather every day and learn in a shared space, often participating in the online instruction provided by their schools. Pods are supervised either by a hired private teacher or other adult, or with parents taking turns.

headline: The ‘Black Lives Matter’ Street Art That Contains Multitudes
abstract: The works in Harlem and Lower Manhattan are much more than a challenge to President Trump; they are opportunities for Black artists and community togetherness.
lead_paragraph: The first word, Black, was designed by Tijay Mohammed, a Ghanaian-born artist, and used vibrant Kente fabric design and Adinkra symbols, which represent concepts like royalty, unity and legacy.

headline: Will It Take a Clever Acronym to Stop Racially Motivated 911 Calls?
abstract: A San Francisco politician thinks a new bill — named the “CAREN Act” — could be what it takes to get people’s attention, and limit potential harm.
lead_paragraph: The stories showed up in Shamann Walton’s social media feeds with alarming regularity: An eight-year-old selling water to raise money to go to Disneyland. A family barbecuing food on a charcoal grill near Lake Merritt. A man bird watching in Central Park. A woman sitting, leisurely, on a public bench in Manhattan. All of these activities — and several more like them — had been reported to law enforcement, often by strangers passing by.

headline: A #MeToo Moment Emerges for Military Women After Soldier’s Killing
abstract: Women in the military say the horrific killing of Army Specialist Vanessa Guillen has swept the nation, galvanizing even civilians to the cause.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the #MeToo movement gained ground, propelled by stories of women in Hollywood, the news media, restaurants and other industries, women in the military have remained in the shadows.

headline: How the Police Ousted ‘Occupy City Hall’
abstract: After a pre-dawn raid with officers in riot gear, tarps were torn down and graffiti was scrubbed off, shutting down a monthlong protest.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Why Protest Tactics Spread Like Memes
abstract: When items like umbrellas and leaf blowers are subverted into objects of resistance, they become very shareable.
lead_paragraph: A video frame captured in Hong Kong in August 2019 shows a group of pro-democracy protesters, smoke pluming toward them, racing to place an orange traffic cone over a tear-gas canister. A video taken nine months later and 7,000 miles away, at a Black Lives Matter protest in Minneapolis, shows another small group using the same maneuver. Two moments, two continents, two cone placers, their postures nearly identical.

headline: India Rounds Up Critics Under Shadow of Virus Crisis, Activists Say
abstract: The Indian authorities arrested dozens of people during a nationwide lockdown. Human rights groups say many of the detentions are based on scant evidence.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After spending several anxious days in prison, Natasha Narwal, a student activist accused of rioting by the New Delhi police, thought her ordeal was nearing an end.

headline: Can Trump Come Back?
abstract: Not under his own power. Only events can save him now.
lead_paragraph: Here is what Donald Trump can realistically do to right his poll numbers, regain his lost supporters and make the 2020 presidential race close instead of a 10-point Joe Biden blowout.

headline: The N.B.A. Is Back. This Is What Pandemic Basketball Looks Like.
abstract: Back in action for the first time since March, the N.B.A. and its players are adjusting to playing without fans and experimenting with new approaches to the game.
lead_paragraph: What kinds of moments are you missing as a fan in the stands? We’d like to hear from you in the callout at the bottom of this article.

headline: Hearst Employees Say Magazine Boss Led Toxic Culture
abstract: At Cosmopolitan staff meetings, workers complain of discrimination and tokenism. Former employees say the Hearst Magazines president, Troy Young, made sexually offensive remarks.
lead_paragraph: Update: Troy Young has resigned, the chief executive of Hearst told employees.

headline: Four Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Works by Jonathan Berger and Liu Xiaodong can be viewed virtually, but if you’re up for venturing out, you’ll want to see Cristine Brache and Vanessa Thill’s art in person.
lead_paragraph: “An introduction to Nameless Love,” Jonathan Berger’s large, text-based installation at Participant Inc., is one of the sleeping beauties of the New York gallery lockdown. Luckily, it will reawaken Sept. 9 for a month.

headline: Garrett Foster Brought His Gun to Austin Protests. Then He Was Shot Dead.
abstract: The police in Austin, Texas, have not identified the motorist who fatally shot a protester after driving his car in the direction of marchers.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — It was not unusual for Garrett Foster to be at a protest against police brutality on a Saturday night. And it was not out of character for him to be armed as he marched.

headline: Pentagon Sidesteps Trump to Ban the Confederate Flag
abstract: The defense secretary lists the types of flags that are allowed to appear on bases worldwide. That flag does not fit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon, without once mentioning the word “Confederate,” announced a policy on Friday that essentially banned displays of the Confederate flag on military installations around the world.

headline: Washington N.F.L. Team Faces Sexual Harassment Claims from 15 Women
abstract: The organization hired a Washington-based law firm after 15 women said that they were sexually harassed while employed by the team.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. team in Washington has hired the law firm Wilkinson Walsh to review the claims of 15 women who, in an article published by The Washington Post on Thursday, said they were sexually harassed while employed by the team.

headline: Trump Hosts July 4 Event at White House as U.S. Coronavirus Cases Soar
abstract: Hospitals in Houston near capacity. Iraq’s health care system is on the verge of breakdown. The Supreme Court rejected Illinois Republicans’ request to hold big political gatherings.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Click here for the latest updates.

headline: Photos: Federal Forces Clash With Demonstrators in Portland
abstract: Thousands gathered downtown to protest as the conflict with law enforcement intensified overnight.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Fueled by a wide array of grievances, including against police brutality, protests have rocked Portland for eight weeks, persisting even as demonstrations have waned in many other parts of the country since the killing of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis.

headline: The Specter of Caste in Silicon Valley
abstract: Indian immigrants from Dalit backgrounds are rising up against caste discrimination at their workplaces in the United States.
lead_paragraph: On June 30, California’s Department of Fair Employment and Housing regulators sued Cisco Systems Inc., for discrimination. The cause was not, like most workplace discrimination lawsuits, based on race, gender, age or sexual orientation. It was based on caste.

headline: He Beat Trump and Weinstein. Why Is This D.A.’s Standing Still Shaky?
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., has two big recent victories, but still has not said whether he is seeking re-election.
lead_paragraph: He just won a landmark victory in the Supreme Court over President Trump that paved the way for prosecutors to obtain the president’s tax returns. In February, he won a conviction against Harvey Weinstein in perhaps the biggest criminal case to arise from the #MeToo movement.

headline: Californians Support Black Lives Matter and Wearing Masks
abstract: Wednesday: A recent survey shows Californians are largely aligned, but differences of opinion reflect disparities. Also: L.G.B.T.Q. coronavirus data; and Emmy nominations.
lead_paragraph: Let’s begin with an update on the coronavirus crisis, which has hit the state particularly hard. California had two of the earliest deaths from Covid-19 in the United States. It has had more cases than any other state in the nation, and the pandemic is showing few signs of letting up.

headline: From the Start, Federal Agents Demanded a Role in Suppressing Anti-Racism Protests
abstract: Twin government memos show how a gung-ho federal law enforcement response to anti-racism protests may have been driven by a shaky understanding of the demonstrations’ roots.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the earliest days of the recent protests against police brutality and racism, some top federal law enforcement officials viewed the demonstrators with alarm and called for an aggressive federal response that two months later continues to escalate.

headline: Who Is Behind Those N.B.A. ‘Bubble Life’ Tweets?
abstract: The @NBABubbleLife Twitter account has amassed more than 100,000 followers in less than two weeks with quirky commentary on the social media posts of basketball’s biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two weeks, the Twitter accounts @NBABubbleLife and @WNBABubbleLife have anonymously chronicled the world’s best basketball players shotgunning beers, dancing with their teammates, failing at fishing and going about everyday activities, like getting haircuts and eating pancakes.

headline: Trump Adds to Playbook of Stoking White Fear and Resentment
abstract: With a defense of Confederate flags and a false accusation against a Black NASCAR driver, Bubba Wallace, President Trump is focusing on racial and cultural flash points to appeal to his base.
lead_paragraph: President Trump mounted an explicit defense of the Confederate flag on Monday, suggesting that NASCAR had made a mistake in banning it from its auto racing events, while falsely accusing a top Black driver, Darrell Wallace Jr., of perpetrating a hoax involving a noose found in his garage.

headline: In Japan, the Message of Anti-Racism Protests Fails to Hit Home
abstract: A view that institutional racism is a faraway problem is keeping the country from more fully confronting entrenched discrimination.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As protests were spreading around the globe in response to George Floyd’s killing by the police, Sierra Todd, an African-American undergraduate in Japan, organized a march last month in Tokyo to show solidarity with American demonstrators.

headline: Could This City Hold the Key to the Future of Policing in America?
abstract: As protesters across the country call for police departments to be defunded and dismantled, Camden’s experience offers some lessons.
lead_paragraph: CAMDEN, N.J. — As officials across the United States face demands to transform policing, many have turned to a small New Jersey city that did what some activists are calling for elsewhere: dismantled its police force and built a new one that stresses a less confrontational approach toward residents who are mostly Black and Latino.

headline: Trump Promotes Caricature of What Conservatives Want
abstract: A series of events during his White House tenure has made clear that Mr. Trump views the voters he calls “my people” through the lens of what he imagines they like.
lead_paragraph: Standing in the White House colonnade this week, President Trump told an interviewer that he’s “comfortable” with “freedom of speech” extending to the Confederate flag.

headline: Three Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Galleries and museums are getting creative about presenting work online during the pandemic. Some are open for in-person visits. Here are shows worth viewing either way.
lead_paragraph: “Pull With a Direction,” a lovely and engrossing show at Talwar Gallery, presents a compressed, in-a-nutshell version of the development of Nasreen Mohamedi (1937-1990), one of the most original modernist artists of post-World War II India. While following the trajectory of the much larger retrospective at the Met Breuer in 2016, this show’s 25 works is dominated by the early drawings and some prints of the 1950s and ’60s, when Mohamedi had various styles and materials under consideration. (The years to come are signaled by a handful of photographs, paintings and later abstract drawings.) There’s an alluring wildness to the proceedings, as different artists often emerge from work to work.

headline: George Soros’s Foundation Pours $220 Million Into Racial Equality Push
abstract: Mr. Soros’s group will invest $150 million in grants for Black-led racial justice groups, and another $70 million toward local grants for criminal justice reform and civic engagement opportunities.
lead_paragraph: The Open Society Foundations, the philanthropic group founded by the business magnate George Soros, announced on Monday that it was investing $220 million in efforts to achieve racial equality in America, a huge financial undertaking that will support several Black-led racial justice groups for years to come.

headline: Statue of Black Protester Is Raised in Place of Bristol Slave Trader
abstract: The image of Jen Reid, fist clenched atop the plinth in the English city where Edward Colston once stood, became a symbol of protest online. Now, it’s there in resin and steel.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jen Reid had never marched in a Black Lives Matter protest before she took to the streets of Bristol, England, on June 7. By the end of that angry day, she had clambered up to stand in the place of a 17th-century slave trader, whose bronze statue had been pulled down and dumped in the city’s harbor.

headline: Trump’s Health Officials Warn More Will Die as Covid Cases Rise
abstract: They struck a sober note on Sunday’s news programs, strongly urging the vast majority of people in hard-hit cities and states to wear masks and avoid large gatherings.
lead_paragraph: Two of the Trump administration’s top health officials acknowledged Sunday that the country is facing a very serious situation with the onslaught of rising coronavirus cases in several states, striking a far more sober tone than President Trump at this stage of the pandemic in the United States.

headline: Trump Backs Out of Throwing Pitch at Yankees Game
abstract: After saying he would do the ceremonial honor at a game on Aug. 15, causing a stir on social media, the president tweeted he would skip it to focus on combating the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said he would no longer be throwing out the ceremonial first pitch before a Yankees game on Aug. 15 — days after he said he would be doing so, causing a political ruckus.

headline: U.N. Panel Takes Aim at Heavy-Handed Police Tactics at Protests
abstract: The comments by the United Nations Human Rights Committee come as the Trump administration faces growing criticism for deploying federal agents to confront Black Lives Matter protesters.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Law-enforcement authorities are obligated to protect and facilitate peaceful demonstrations, an influential United Nations human rights panel said on Wednesday, challenging tactics the police have used against anti-racism protests in American cities and around the world.

headline: Overlooked No More: Brad Lomax, a Bridge Between Civil Rights Movements
abstract: A member of the Black Panthers, he helped lead a historic, and successful, sit-in in San Francisco as part of a nationwide anti-discrimination campaign on behalf of people with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This latest installment is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for disabled people. Share your stories or email us at ada@nytimes.com.

headline: A Fashion Model For the Moment
abstract: How a digital avatar helped the fashion designer Hanifa go viral during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: How to have a fashion show during a pandemic is one of the immediate questions facing designers this week, as what would have been the couture runway season is replaced with three days of digital mini-films. Can video ever replace the runway experience?

headline: Officer Who Pressed His Knee on George Floyd’s Neck Drew Scrutiny Long Before
abstract: In more than 19 years on the Minneapolis police force, Mr. Chauvin had a reputation as a rigid workaholic with few friends. He sometimes made other officers uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The four teenagers drove around playing a game of Nerf Gun Assassin on a May evening before graduation in 2013. One of them randomly fired an orange dart out the window.

headline: Black Lives Matter May Be the Largest Movement in U.S. History
abstract: Recent polls suggest that about 15 million to 26 million people in the U.S. have participated in recent protests.
lead_paragraph: Recent polls suggest that about 15 million to 26 million people in the U.S. have participated in recent protests.

headline: The Teenagers at the End of the World
abstract: Young climate activists like Jamie Margolin are building a movement while growing up — planning mass protests from childhood bedrooms and during school.
lead_paragraph: Young climate activists like Jamie Margolin are building a movement while growing up — planning mass protests from childhood bedrooms and during school.

headline: N.Y.C. Paints ‘Black Lives Matter’ Mural Outside Trump Tower
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, the city’s first lady, Chirlane McCray, and the Rev. Al Sharpton joined workers and activists in painting the words “Black Lives Matter” in front of Trump Tower.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, the city’s first lady, Chirlane McCray, and the Rev. Al Sharpton joined workers and activists in painting the words “Black Lives Matter” in front of Trump Tower.

headline: ‘It’s an Amazing Feeling:’ Statue of Black Protester Replaces Slave Trader
abstract: A statue of Jen Reid, who became a symbol of Bristol, England’s Black Lives Matter protest, replaced one of the 17th-century slave trader Edward Colston.
lead_paragraph: A statue of Jen Reid, who became a symbol of Bristol, England’s Black Lives Matter protest, replaced one of the 17th-century slave trader Edward Colston.

headline: Children Lead Black Lives Matter Protest in Berkeley
abstract: On Wednesday, dozens of people attended a Black Lives Matter march led by children in Berkeley, Calif.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, dozens of people attended a Black Lives Matter march led by children in Berkeley, Calif.

headline: ‘Occupy City Hall’ Encampment Is Taken Down
abstract: New York police officers cleared the makeshift camp in City Hall Park in a pre-dawn raid. The site began as a protest against police brutality.
lead_paragraph: New York police officers cleared the makeshift camp in City Hall Park in a pre-dawn raid. The site began as a protest against police brutality.

headline: Bristol Takes Down Statue of Black Protester a Day After It Went Up
abstract: City authorities in Bristol, England, had a statue of the Black Lives Matter protester Jen Reid removed after it was covertly raised in place of a toppled memorial to the slave trader Edward Colston.
lead_paragraph: City authorities in Bristol, England, had a statue of the Black Lives Matter protester Jen Reid removed after it was covertly raised in place of a toppled memorial to the slave trader Edward Colston.

headline: Love Letter: For Interracial Couples, Love is Allyship
abstract: Plus: For the love of emus.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, systemic racism, police brutality and discrimination against Black people in America have been catalysts for tough conversations, including between Black and white interracial couples. The tragic deaths of George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and countless others has led many interracial couples to prioritize open and honest conversations about how society treats them differently and why allyship and advocacy are essential.

headline: ‘Black Lives Matter’ Art Outside Trump Tower Is Being Vandalized
abstract: In five  incidents, people have thrown paint on the bright-yellow street display on Fifth Avenue. Each time, city workers have restored the lettering.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Mistrust of a Coronavirus Vaccine Could Imperil Widespread Immunity
abstract: Billions are being poured into developing a shot, but the rapid timetable and President Trump’s cheerleading are creating a whole new group of vaccine-hesitant patients.
lead_paragraph: Almost daily, President Trump and leaders worldwide say they are racing to develop a coronavirus vaccine, in perhaps the most urgent mission in the history of medical science. But the repeated assurances of near-miraculous speed are exacerbating a problem that has largely been overlooked and one that public health experts say must be addressed now: persuading people to actually get the shot.

headline: There Is a ‘Great Silent Majority.’ But It Stands Against Trump.
abstract: And the minority he represents.
lead_paragraph: President Trump believes he represents the “silent majority” of the country against a dangerous, radical minority. He says as much on Twitter, frequently yelling “SILENT MAJORITY” at his followers. Accordingly, his campaign for re-election has tried to appeal to this “majority” with displays tailored to its perceived interests.

headline: ‘At First I Didn’t Want to Show My Face’
abstract: Three Black jewelry designers talk about thriving in an industry that hasn’t always embraced them.
lead_paragraph: Reverberations from the Black Lives Matter protests of recent weeks have reached some unlikely frontiers, including the rarefied realm of fine jewelry ateliers. Suddenly, Black designers in the field have found themselves with elevated profiles, part of the wave of attention recently directed toward supporting Black-owned businesses.

headline: The Lakers Hold On to Beat the Clippers in Thriller
abstract: LeBron James defended both Paul George and Kawhi Leonard on the Clippers’ final possession. Zion Williamson played in the first game of the night’s doubleheader, but the Pelicans missed a game-winner at the buzzer against Utah.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: A Momentous First Night Back for the N.B.A.
abstract: Close games, social justice protests and a principal role for Rudy Gobert, again.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — When his postgame Zoom interview was over, before making a triumphant exit to the team bus, Rudy Gobert of the Utah Jazz acknowledged that the historic play he was savoring did not go exactly as planned.

headline: Ava DuVernay’s Fight for Change, Onscreen and Off
abstract: The award-winning film director on the role of artists in a time of widespread unrest, and how film can help hold police to account.
lead_paragraph: — Ava DuVernay, award-winning writer, producer and film director

headline: Coronavirus Cases in U.S. Are Rising, Even as Death Rates Trend Down
abstract: At least five U.S. states set single-day records on Friday as the country’s daily infection report passed 50,000 again. President Trump, in a speech at Mount Rushmore, barely mentioned the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Click here for the latest updates.

headline: Massachusetts Detective Is Fired Over Black Lives Matter Post
abstract: Florissa Fuentes of the Springfield Police Department shared a photo on Instagram of her niece at a Black Lives Matter protest holding a sign that her colleagues said was offensive.
lead_paragraph: A police detective in Springfield, Mass., said she was fired after sharing a photo of her niece at a Black Lives Matter protest on Instagram.

headline: Trevor Noah Thinks Trump Is ‘Oddly Chilled Out’ About Russia
abstract: The president said he didn’t ask Vladimir Putin whether Russia paid to have U.S. troops killed. The “Daily Show” host can see why that talk would have been “super awkward.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Race Takes Center Stage as Rashida Tlaib Faces Primary Challenge
abstract: Some of Detroit’s most prominent Black leaders are backing a challenger to Ms. Tlaib, a Palestinian-American who has gained celebrity status since winning her seat in 2018.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich. — Representative Rashida Tlaib, one of Congress’s most famous members, is perhaps best known for her membership in the progressive group known as “the squad” and her strident attacks on President Trump.

headline: ‘Blue Lives Matter’ and ‘Defund the Police’ Clash in the Streets
abstract: A recent number of pro-police rallies have led to fights and arrests as civilian New Yorkers turn on one another over their view of the N.Y.P.D.
lead_paragraph: Clashes between protesters and the police were familiar sights in the days after the death of George Floyd under the knee of a police officer. But a new kind of unrest has emerged in recent days: confrontations between New Yorkers who support law enforcement and those who are pressing for an overhaul of the Police Department.

headline: Say One Thing, Donate to Another
abstract: A new analysis shows how companies have funded political efforts that undermine their public stances.
lead_paragraph: Breaking: Carlyle announced this morning that one of its chief executives, Glenn Youngkin, will step down, leaving Kewsong Lee as the investment giant’s sole C.E.O. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)

headline: How André Holland and Company Brought ‘Richard II’ to Radio
abstract: What was meant to have opened Shakespeare in the Park’s season has found new life as a four-part audio play with resonance in the wake of Black Lives Matter.
lead_paragraph: On the list of questions you’ve probably never considered is how to describe what spitting sounds like.

headline: Lucius Barker, Expert on Race in American Politics, Dies at 92
abstract: He was a passionate Jesse Jackson delegate at the 1984 Democratic National Convention and, later, a mentor to future politicians like Senator Cory Booker.
lead_paragraph: Lucius J. Barker, a revered political scientist and professor whose professional expertise in race in American politics informed his personal role as a delegate for Jesse Jackson at the 1984 Democratic National Convention, died on June 21 at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Republican Senators in Arizona and Georgia Have a Problem: The Base
abstract: This November, the uneasy relationship between the most right-wing voters in the Republican Party and the statewide lawmakers who rely on their votes will burst into the open.
lead_paragraph: DILLARD, Ga. — As Representative Doug Collins went booth to booth at a recent Republican jamboree in northeast Georgia’s Rabun County, he was a hero, not an insurgent. No one knocked him for splitting the party with his bid against the state’s junior senator, Kelly Loeffler, who is also a Republican. For many voters in the deeply conservative region, Mr. Collins was the candidate who most represented the values of their political icon: President Trump.

headline: What a Second Trump Term Would Look Like
abstract: He won’t overthrow the Constitution. But he might persuade Americans that democracy just does not work.
lead_paragraph: Back when Donald Trump was running for president in 2016, Republican leaders claimed to believe that, as president, Mr. Trump would respect the rule of law. “I still believe we have the institutions of government that would restrain someone who seeks to exceed their constitutional obligations,” Senator John McCain said. “We have a Congress. We have the Supreme Court. We’re not Romania.”

headline: Some Republicans Have Grown Wary of Protests Against Racism, Poll Shows
abstract: A month ago, polls reflected a new consensus around the need for racial justice. But after weeks of attacks by President Trump, some Republicans’ views have shifted.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans continue to support the nationwide protests against racial injustice, but with President Trump issuing an ever-more-combative barrage of attacks, new polling shows that some Republicans have grown wary of demonstrators’ demands and retreated toward saying that racism is not in fact a big problem in the United States.

headline: What Will Happen to All of the Faces?
abstract: If you thought the coronavirus would bring a slowdown in cosmetic procedures, you’d have been wrong. Here’s what to expect in a Covid-19 world.
lead_paragraph: In late June, Holly Aubry, who owns a public relations firm in New York, got the first aesthetic treatments she’d ever had in her life: Botox, filler and a brow suture lift.

headline: Alabama Votes for Tommy Tuberville, and Democrats Name a Challenger in Maine
abstract: A former college football coach defeated Jeff Sessions in a Republican runoff in Alabama, and Sara Gideon will challenge Susan Collins for the Senate in Maine. Key races also took place in Texas.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow the latest Biden vs Trump 2020 live elections briefing here.

headline: Everlane’s Promise of ‘Radical Transparency’ Unravels
abstract: Employees past and present are challenging management, saying the company’s ethical image was an illusion.
lead_paragraph: Michael Preysman, a founder and the chief executive of Everlane, a fashion brand that targets the ethically minded with minimalist basics, stood onstage in May 2019 at the Copenhagen Fashion Summit and preached the gospel of his company.

headline: Why Trump’s Blunt Appeals to Suburban Voters May Not Work
abstract: People living the “Suburban Lifestyle Dream” tend to support recent protests and disapprove of the president’s handling of race.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s latest campaign ads warn of left-wing mobs destroying American cities. His recent White House comments have depicted a rampage of violence and a “radical movement” to dissolve the police. His Twitter feed has sounded alarms over an Obama-era fair housing rule he has framed as a threat to “The Suburban Housewives of America” and the “Suburban Lifestyle Dream.”

headline: Help Me Find Trump’s ‘Anarchists’ in Portland
abstract: The president has his politically driven narrative. And then there’s reality.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — I’ve been on the front lines of the protests here, searching for the “radical-left anarchists” who President Trump says are on Portland streets each evening.

headline: Los Angeles School District Cut Its Police Budget, Then the Chief Resigned
abstract: The former chief called the decision “potentially life-threatening” for students and staff members.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Trump Wants a Backlash. Can He Whip One Into Shape?
abstract: Inevitably, the electorate’s response to the George Floyd protests has begun to run along familiar ideological fault lines.
lead_paragraph: The public response to the demonstrations over the killing of George Floyd is now beginning to take shape more clearly along familiar ideological lines — in ways that are likely to propel politics this year and beyond, dividing left and right as Democrats and Republicans take opposing stands on the efficacy and even the legitimacy of this year’s protests against racism.

headline: Biden’s Big Opportunity
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden doesn’t seem like an obvious candidate to be a transformational president.

headline: These Radical Black Thrillers Fantasized About Dismantling the Police
abstract: In the late 1960s and early 1970s, a series of novels by Black authors married revolutionary politics with pulp fiction. Their plotlines remain distressingly relevant.
lead_paragraph: You could almost say these novels predicted their own fates. A telling bit of dialogue appears midway through “Operation Burning Candle,” Blyden Jackson’s 1973 thriller about a Black disciple of Jungian psychoanalysis who fakes his death in Vietnam and returns to America with a group of other veterans to take down the white establishment.

headline: Atlanta Mourns John Lewis and Ponders Carrying On With ‘Good Trouble’
abstract: The congressman and civil rights leader preached in support of nonviolent resistance, a message that some say must live on in his absence.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A motorcade on Wednesday led John Lewis on one final tour of Atlanta, the city he represented in Congress for more than three decades and a place he helped establish as the spiritual home of a nonviolent movement to protest racism.

headline: Occupy City Hall Struggles as Homeless Move In
abstract: Organizers said they were helping vulnerable people. But nearby residents said the camp had turned into an unruly — and at times violent — shantytown.
lead_paragraph: When it first kicked off last month, the activist encampment that billed itself as Occupy City Hall was viewed as the latest wave of the city’s George Floyd protests — an innovative political space that, under summer skies, attracted peaceful crowds to speeches and teach-ins focused on a narrow goal: cutting $1 billion from the New York Police Department’s budget.

headline: Trump vs. the Women Who Lead Michigan: A Battle With 2020 Implications
abstract: The president has picked fights with Michigan’s governor, attorney general and secretary of state over voting rights and the coronavirus. They haven’t backed down.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — Beyond being the women leading Michigan’s state government, Gretchen Whitmer, Dana Nessel and Jocelyn Benson have a lot in common.

headline: Trump Continues Criticism of Movement to Defund the Police
abstract: The president is embracing law enforcement, a tactic that won him support in the 2016 campaign, while ignoring calls for reform.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Monday assailed a broad movement to defund police departments, invoking the kind of pro-police language that won him support with the law enforcement community in 2016 and ignoring the calls for reform that have helped shape this election.

headline: A W.N.B.A. Owner Clashes With Players on Protests
abstract: Kelly Loeffler, who is also campaigning for a Senate seat in Georgia, opposes the league’s plan to allow players to wear jerseys in support of the movement.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the W.N.B.A. announced that its upcoming season would be “dedicated to social justice with games honoring the Black Lives Matter movement.”

headline: City That Once Guided a Nation Now Shows Its Cracks
abstract: Peoria, Ill., was a place where marketers and politicians honed their messages. The pandemic and protests have made clear the sharply different realities of its Black and white residents.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Daily Stegall hated how the plywood looked covering the smashed windows at her parents’ jewelry store in Peoria, Ill. So she asked a local artist to paint flowers on the boards. “The goal is to make people happy,” said Ms. Stegall.

headline: A Company Backs a Cause. It Funds a Politician Who Doesn’t. What Gives?
abstract: As the world expects more of corporations, it is untenable to support social and environmental causes while giving money, even indirectly, to candidates who oppose them.
lead_paragraph: Walmart calls its employees “heroes” for putting their health at risk to work during the pandemic. AT&T champions L.G.B.T.Q. rights. Microsoft is undertaking one of the country’s most ambitious corporate efforts to eliminate its carbon emissions.

headline: I’m a Lip Reader in a Masked World
abstract: There are ways to accommodate people like me. But if our collective pandemic experience has taught us anything, it’s that small sacrifices to help others are not exactly America’s strong suit.
lead_paragraph: When my mammogram was done, the technician looked at me and smiled. “Nice boots,” she said.

headline: What to Know About N.Y.’s Traveler Restrictions
abstract: The state is trying to track visitors from 19 states, who now must fill out a  form with their travel plans. Enforcing quarantine will still be tricky.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Trump, the Master of Distraction
abstract: A reader says his record in office is one he can’t run on. Also: Getting corporate America to change its ways.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Australia Faces Its Own Reckoning Over Diversity in Media
abstract: The Black Lives Matter movement has inspired Australians to examine issues of race in our own country.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, my mother was a reporter in Melbourne, where much of her work focused on the Indigenous communities in Victoria. She recently told me about a time when she went to her editors at The Age and suggested that they actively seek out and recruit young Indigenous reporters because — while she felt she had earned the trust of her sources — their stories would be better told by people from that community. Hiring a more diverse staff, she explained, would be better for journalism and better for the newspaper.

headline: What Do Portland Protesters Want, and How Have the Police Responded?
abstract: Eight weeks after the death of George Floyd, here’s a look at why longstanding protests in the city have recently intensified.
lead_paragraph: When a video showing George Floyd’s death in police custody spread across social media, cities and towns nationwide soon erupted in protests against systemic racism and police brutality. But while protests in many places subsided after a few weeks, Portland, Ore., has been holding demonstrations every night since May 29.The arrival of federal forces in the city this month — and concerns they were exceeding their authority and violating protesters’ rights — drew the ire of local officials and reinvigorated nightly demonstrations. With renewed force, marchers have spray-painted the walls of the U.S. District Court building, demanding that federal agents go home. Groups of mothers have banded together, locking arms and chanting: “Feds stay clear. Moms are here.”

headline: ‘A Conflicted Cultural Force’: What It’s Like to Be Black in Publishing
abstract: An author, literary agent, marketer, publicist, editors and booksellers talk about how race affects their careers — and the books you read.
lead_paragraph: The nationwide protests against police brutality and racial injustice have set off conversations in nearly every industry about the treatment of Black workers, and book publishing is no exception.

headline: After an Arrest at a Black Lives Matter Protest: Deportation Proceedings
abstract: A Phoenix activist was supporting one cause, and caught up in the unresolved fight of another.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Máxima Guerrero had seen it before: young people gathering in anger and frustration, not waiting for the guidance of major organizations or longtime political leaders.

headline: An Unlikely Source of Catharsis for a Black M.L.B. Player: Social Media
abstract: Tony Kemp felt depressed after George Floyd’s death in police custody. Then he invited fans to have uncomfortable conversations on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Tony Kemp felt, in his words, depressed.

headline: Federal Officers Deployed in Portland Didn’t Have Proper Training, D.H.S. Memo Said
abstract: Rather than tamping down persistent protests in Portland, Ore., a militarized presence from federal officers seems to have re-energized them.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The federal agents facing a growing backlash for their militarized approach to weeks of unrest in Portland were not specifically trained in riot control or mass demonstrations, an internal Department of Homeland Security memo warned this week.

headline: The Cafe Has Black Lives Matter Signs. The Owner Voted for Trump.
abstract: “I’m a liberal guy,” said Thomas Bosco, who is facing backlash after he said in an MSNBC interview that he voted for the president in 2016 and was likely to do so again.
lead_paragraph: At Indian Road Cafe in Upper Manhattan, a Black Lives Matter sign hangs in a front window. Local writers, artists, musicians and political activists are regulars. And for years, two drag queens have hosted a monthly charity bingo tournament there.

headline: Biden Addresses Racial Justice, Saying Trump Adds ‘Fuel to the Fire’
abstract: Joe Biden also said he would “have a choice” on his running mate by the first week in August. President Trump wondered aloud why his approval ratings were not as high as Dr. Anthony S. Fauci’s.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: ‘Can We Please Talk About Black Lives Matter for One Second?’
abstract: Should a Black protest movement be used to advance other progressive priorities?
lead_paragraph: The night after a handful of activists in Seattle dragged some barricades onto the street and announced the establishment of the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone, more than a thousand people marched to City Hall for a rally. The action was notable because of the presence of Kshama Sawant, a City Council member. A Trotskyist and avowed radical, Sawant has a key to City Hall. She simply opened the front door and let the protesters in.

headline: Officers Shot Latino Man Five Times in the Back, Autopsy Says
abstract: Andres Guardado was killed in Southern California last month. His family said he was working as a security guard for an auto body shop the day he was shot.
lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old Latino man who was killed in a confrontation with Los Angeles County sheriff’s deputies last month was fatally shot five times in the back, according to an autopsy released Friday in a killing the man’s family contends was unjustified.

headline: The Next Phase of Reopening
abstract: Nail salons and tattoo parlors reopen, but indoor dining remains on hold, considered too risky given coronavirus outbreaks elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: ESPN Suspends N.B.A. Reporter for Vulgar Reply to Senator
abstract: Adrian Wojnarowski, who is known for his “Woj bombs” of breaking news, emailed a different kind to a U.S. senator.
lead_paragraph: ESPN’s most prominent basketball reporter has been suspended for a two-word vulgar email reply to the office of a United States senator on Friday morning in response to the senator’s critical statements about the N.B.A.’s relationship with China.

headline: In the Twin Cities’ Robust Dining Scene, Few Black-Owned Businesses
abstract: In the wake of George Floyd’s killing, chefs and restaurateurs are looking for ways to fix the racial imbalance.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Before the coronavirus decimated the restaurant industry, Minneapolis and St. Paul were being hailed around the country for their up-and-coming culinary scene.

headline: Bristol Removes Statue of Black Protester After Just One Day
abstract: The statue of Jen Reid, a Black Lives Matter protester, was raised on Wednesday in place of a toppled memorial to the slave trader Edward Colston.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jen Reid, the Black Lives Matter protester whose statue was erected in place of a toppled slave trader in Bristol, England, on Wednesday, said just before the unauthorized installation that she did not know whether the city’s authorities would let it stand there for a few months or a single day.

headline: A Liberal Town Built Around Confederate Generals Rethinks Its Identity
abstract: In Lexington, Va., where Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson are buried, people are reassessing the town’s ties to a legacy that symbolizes slavery and oppression.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Va. — It’s a short drive in Lexington from a home on Confederate Circle past the Stonewall Jackson Memorial Cemetery and over to the Robert E. Lee Hotel, where locals like to stop for a drink.

headline: Seeing ‘Black Lives Matter’ Written in Chalk, One City Declares It a Crime
abstract: In a small Washington town where people of color say they have faced discrimination, activists ran into trouble for drawing “Black Lives Matter” in the streets. Then their white neighbors came to their defense.
lead_paragraph: SELAH, Wash. — First came the warning: A police officer in the small city of Selah, Wash., told a group of young people that if they continued drawing “Black Lives Matter” chalk art on the sidewalk in front of City Hall, they would be charged with a crime.

headline: The Fight Over the Future of the Democratic Party
abstract: Thomas Frank’s “The People, No” and Gene Sperling’s “Economic Dignity” offer differing prescriptions for America’s liberals.
lead_paragraph: THE PEOPLE, NOA Brief History of Anti-PopulismBy Thomas FrankECONOMIC DIGNITYBy Gene Sperling

headline: ‘Nothing About Us Without Us’: 16 Moments in the Fight for Disability Rights
abstract: The disability civil rights movement has many distinct narratives, but the prevailing themes are of community, justice and equity.
lead_paragraph: As with every other civil rights movement, the fight for disability rights is one that challenges negative attitudes and pushes back against oppression. But it is also more complex.

headline: Chicago Gun Violence Spikes and Increasingly Finds the Youngest Victims
abstract: Nine children under the age of 18 have been shot dead in Chicago since June 20.
lead_paragraph: As Yasmin Miller drove home from a laundromat in Chicago’s Englewood neighborhood last weekend, a gunman in another car peppered her red Hyundai sedan with bullets, grazing her head and striking her son, Sincere Gaston, in the chest. Sincere died in his car seat. He was 20 months old.

headline: Who Tore Down This Frederick Douglass Statue?
abstract: President Trump and others have speculated about why vandals destroyed a Rochester, N.Y., statue of the prominent Black abolitionist even as protests against systemic racism continue.
lead_paragraph: The authorities know that a statue of the renowned Black abolitionist Frederick Douglass was torn from its base in a park in Rochester, N.Y., and then dumped some 50 feet away, where it was discovered near a river gorge.
