headline: Meet the Supporters Trump Has Lost
abstract: A significant majority of people who voted for him in 2016 are planning to do so again. What is different about those who’ve had a change of heart?
lead_paragraph: For some, the disenchantment started almost as soon as Donald J. Trump took office. For others, his handling of the coronavirus and social unrest turned them away. For all of them, it’s highly unlikely they will vote for him again.

headline: Twitter, Russia, Comet NEOWISE: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Opera Can No Longer Ignore Its Race Problem
abstract: As the industry rebuilds from the coronavirus pandemic, it must face long-simmering issues of representation.
lead_paragraph: In late May, shortly after the killing of George Floyd, the mezzo-soprano J’Nai Bridges was invited by Los Angeles Opera to give a virtual recital.

headline: Talking With Your Teen About Anti-Racism? Be Ready to Listen
abstract: Many of today’s teenagers have a keener understanding of what constitutes racism than their predecessors, based on what they have learned both in school and online.
lead_paragraph: While adults often have a lot to teach young people about the world and how it works, those of us raising adolescents should not assume that we are the resident experts on racism. In many cases young people are not only opposed to racism, but they have embraced the call to work actively against it. Indeed, as many parents have already discovered, our teenagers are often more adept at recognizing and challenging bigotry than we are.

headline: As Federal Forces Confront Protesters
abstract: Readers condemn President Trump’s use of armed forces in Portland, Ore. One reader describes “a real war on American cities in a feeble attempt to save his presidency.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Felony Charges for Detroit Officer Accused of Shooting 3 Journalists With Rubber Pellets
abstract: “They were a threat to no one,” the Wayne County prosecutor said. “There are simply no explicable reasons why the alleged actions of this officer were taken.”
lead_paragraph: A Detroit police corporal is facing felony assault charges amid accusations that he shot rubber pellets at three photojournalists who covered a protest in May against police brutality in the city.

headline: Election Day in Paradise (New Jersey)
abstract: Today’s primaries are the perfect excuse to check in on our newsletter writer’s favorite state.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.

headline: Why We Published the Story of a Former White Supremacist
abstract: Racist backlash thrives in times of social upheaval.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every weekday.

headline: University of Texas Won’t Drop Song With Racist History
abstract: “The Eyes of Texas,” once sung at minstrel shows, will remain a campus anthem at the University of Texas at Austin, the school announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The University of Texas at Austin said it would rename a building named for a racist professor, erect a statue of the school’s first Black football player and commission a monument to its first Black undergraduates. What’s not changing? “The Eyes of Texas,” a campus anthem with minstrel roots that student-athletes want abolished.

headline: European Union Fund, Bulgaria Protests, Mars Mission: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Shoppers Should Wear Masks. Shouldn’t Protesters, Too?
abstract: A reader believes there’s a “double standard” for cooperation with public safety measures.
lead_paragraph: I have a question that I hope you won’t take the wrong way. I am 72 years old and have been isolating for months. I take Covid-19 very seriously. But I’ve noticed a double standard about safety measures: People who refuse to wear face masks on principle, as a statement of their personal freedom, are shamed about it (often on the internet). But protesters in the Black Lives Matter movement seem to get a free pass on not wearing them. People get agitated when I bring this up. Am I wrong to?

headline: Andrew Gillum and the Long Shadow of the Florida Governor’s Race
abstract: The magnetic former Democratic nominee for Florida governor went from being a breakout political star to checking into rehab.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Andrew Gillum sounded like a prophet. His words quick, his tone urgent, the man who nearly became Florida’s governor predicted in a podcast interview that the coronavirus would cripple the state’s tourism industry, hide in nursing homes and proliferate amid rampant misinformation.

headline: As Trump Pushes Into Portland, His Campaign Ads Turn Darker
abstract: The Trump campaign is spending millions on ads that promote a dark and exaggerated portrayal of Democratic-led cities, a tactic that reinforces his “law and order’’ campaign message.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: An Artist Having Fun While Waiting for Catastrophe
abstract: Heather Phillipson’s works make viewers smile, but underneath their bright, over-the-top exteriors are dark, urgent messages.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The artist Heather Phillipson’s latest work is a 31-foot statue of a dollop of whipped cream, with a fly on it.

headline: We Have Questions
abstract: How to get answers from the tech executives testifying at a high-profile congressional hearing today.
lead_paragraph: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.

headline: Driver Charged With Vehicular Homicide in Death of Seattle Protester
abstract: The driver, Dawit Kelete, 27, struck two demonstrators with his car early Saturday, one of whom later died, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Seattle man who the authorities said drove into a protest on a closed section of Interstate 5 over the weekend, killing one demonstrator, was charged on Wednesday with vehicular homicide, vehicular assault and reckless driving.

headline: Biden Announces a $775 Billion Plan for Caregivers Amid Coronavirus
abstract: President Trump spoke at his first coronavirus task force briefing since April, a concession to his diminished standing in his re-election effort. New filings revealed his campaign paid $4 million to Trump businesses and spent more than $2 million on his Tulsa rally, which drew few attendees.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the DNC Live: Biden’s speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

headline: Can the N.Y.P.D. Handle a $1 Billion Cut? Yes
abstract: Protests and a fiscal crisis shine a new light on the biggest Police Department budget in America.
lead_paragraph: In a city staring down $9 billion in lost revenue, it is hardly revolutionary to ask the Police Department to share the pain.

headline: For Interracial Couples, Advocacy Is a Love Language
abstract: Having tough conversations about racism, police brutality and current events aren’t an option for Black and white couples — they’re essential.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, people all over the world have taken to social media and to the streets to reject police brutality and injustice toward Black people.

headline: Why Is a Tech Executive Installing Security Cameras Around San Francisco?
abstract: Chris Larsen knows that a crypto mogul spending his own money for a city’s camera surveillance system might sound creepy. He’s here to explain why it’s not.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It sounds sinister. A soft-spoken cryptocurrency mogul is paying for a private network of high-definition security cameras around the city. Zoom in and you can see the finest details: the sticker on a cellphone, the make of a backpack, the color of someone’s eyes.

headline: No Charges for Ferguson Officer Who Killed Michael Brown, New Prosecutor Says
abstract: The St. Louis County prosecutor had reopened an investigation into Darren Wilson, who was previously cleared by a grand jury after fatally shooting Mr. Brown in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Six years after a white police officer shot and killed Michael Brown, a Black teenager, in Ferguson, Mo., another investigation into the killing has come to the same conclusion as the first: The officer should not be charged.

headline: Emmys 2020 Snubs and Surprises: Baby Yoda Breaks Through
abstract: In troubling times, the nominations made room for some popcorn TV.
lead_paragraph: Heading into an Emmys season eclipsed by both Black Lives Matters protests and the Covid-19 pandemic, the question was whether we would see new trends in the nominations or business as usual. Tuesday’s announcement wasn’t stuffed with surprises, but you could read a few signs of the times into the nominees, beginning with …

headline: Jonathan Irons, Helped by W.N.B.A. Star Maya Moore, Freed From Prison
abstract: The W.N.B.A. star took time away from basketball to help Irons overturn his conviction.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Irons, whose bid for freedom from a 50-year prison sentence was embraced and pushed by the W.N.B.A. star Maya Moore, walked out of a Missouri penitentiary on Wednesday, nearly four months after a judge overturned his conviction on charges of burglary and assault.

headline: ‘Disabled People Love Clothes Too’
abstract: But #disabledandcute influencers say the fashion industry has been slow to embrace them.
lead_paragraph: I have always believed that fashion is the window to the soul. As a Black disabled woman with cerebral palsy, a neurological disorder that affects movement on the right side of my body, I have gone through what I call the stages of fashion grief.

headline: The Path to Trump’s Tax Records
abstract: Manhattan prosecutors scored a win with the Supreme Court's ruling that President Trump could not a block a subpoena of his financial records.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: This Year Will End Eventually. Document It While You Can.
abstract: Museums are working overtime to collect artifacts and ephemera from the pandemic and the racial justice movement, and they need your help.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, a nerdy joke went viral on Twitter: Future historians will be asked which quarter of 2020 they specialize in.

headline: How Local Covid Deaths Are Affecting Vote Choice
abstract: A rise in coronavirus-related deaths in a given community tends to reduce support for Republicans.
lead_paragraph: On March 18, Donald J. Trump declared himself a wartime president against “the invisible enemy” of coronavirus and invoked the Defense Production Act. Now he’s facing a downside of presiding over a war: American casualties.

headline: Trump Is Selling White Grievance. The Suburbs Aren’t Buying It.
abstract: As the president casts himself as a bulwark against “angry mobs,” there are signs that he is alienating voters in bedroom communities who view him as a deeply flawed messenger on issues of race.
lead_paragraph: CORNELIUS, N.C. — On a humid Wednesday morning in this leafy lakeside suburb of Charlotte, American flags fluttered from porches along Main Street, traffic was slow, and the occasional resident ambled out for a walk.

headline: A Rush to Use Black Art Leaves the Artists Feeling Used
abstract: Black creative professionals say they have been used to lend legitimacy to diversity campaigns while being underpaid and pigeonholed.
lead_paragraph: The streets of New York were crowded with protesters when Shantell Martin received an email from an ad agency last month.

headline: Italian Fashion Hasn’t Changed Enough, Black Designers Say
abstract: A new letter sent by independent designers to fashion executives demands reform, or at least a serious conversation about race.
lead_paragraph: The designer Stella Jean wanted to make something clear about an impassioned letter she sent to Italian fashion’s governing body: “It’s not a protest,” she said. “I’m not protesting. It’s a proposal.”

headline: ‘A Big Correction’: Pandemic Brings Change to ‘Bloated’ Ad Industry
abstract: The marketing business is going through a period of innovation as it sheds workers and tries to hold on to clients.
lead_paragraph: The advertising industry’s tendency toward excess — catered parties in Las Vegas headlined by pop stars; unwieldy internal hierarchies stuffed with countless director roles; throw-it-at-the-wall ad placement — has persisted for years despite concerns about wastefulness.

headline: Barack Obama and Joe Biden Join Forces in Video Targeting Trump
abstract: The former president and vice president released a new video Thursday meant to cast President Trump as unbefitting of the office, while trumpeting the credentials of Mr. Biden.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 6: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by July 24 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 4.
lead_paragraph: Update: Winners have been announced!

headline: 87 Face Felony Charges After Protesting Breonna Taylor’s Death
abstract: The demonstrators were arrested at the home of Kentucky’s attorney general in Louisville, where they had gathered to demand charges against the officers who killed Ms. Taylor.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of protesters were charged with a felony on Tuesday after they gathered on property owned by Kentucky’s attorney general to demand charges against the police officers responsible for the shooting death of Breonna Taylor.

headline: Federal Employees Can Express Support for Black Lives Matter, Watchdog Says
abstract: The Office of Special Counsel’s finding came weeks after President Trump called Black Lives Matter a “symbol of hate.”
lead_paragraph: Federal employees may express support for Black Lives Matter in the workplace, an independent federal agency said this week.

headline: State Attorney General Calls for Stripping N.Y.P.D. Control From Mayor
abstract: Citing police misconduct at protests, the attorney general said an independent panel should oversee the city police and hire the commissioner.
lead_paragraph: One officer in Brooklyn pulled down a protester’s mask and pepper-sprayed him. Another officer shoved a young woman to the ground, knocking her head against the pavement and giving her a concussion. An officer in Manhattan pulled a gun and waved it at protesters after one of his colleagues was hit in the head with an thrown object.

headline: As N.F.L. Fights Racism and Sexism, Team Owners Undercut the Message
abstract: The league has often focused its progressive efforts at employees, players and public displays. But the actions of team owners have undermined attempts at change.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has taken strides to repair its image as being insensitive to issues facing women and people of color. But the league continues to be confronted by an uncomfortable reality: Its efforts can be undercut by reports of toxic behavior at the tops of its franchises.

headline: Washington and the N.F.L. Might Change the Redskins Name. Why Now?
abstract: The move toward changing a mascot name after decades of complaints underscores how America’s most popular sport has scrambled to keep up with shifts in public opinion.
lead_paragraph: By the time they take the field this fall — that’s assuming there is a season given the coronavirus pandemic — the National Football League team in Washington, D.C., might have a new nickname.

headline: What We Know About the Killing of Tech C.E.O. Fahim Saleh
abstract: Mr. Saleh, a young entrepreneur with international businesses, was found dismembered this week in his luxury condo on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Fight Over Abortion Rights Feels Less Urgent for a Generation
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 1, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not that young people don’t care about abortion, it’s that they don’t think it applies to them.”

headline: 50 Nights of Unrest in Portland
abstract: Robert Evans of Bellingcat says the city “is being used as a bellwether to see what this administration can get away with.”
lead_paragraph: Thursday night marked the 50th consecutive night of demonstrations in Portland, Ore. The protests began after the killing of George Floyd — tens of thousands of people took to the streets to protest police violence and racial injustice. Since then, the protests have grown smaller, but clashes between law enforcement officers and protesters have escalated — on July 12, videos circulated of a federal officer shooting a protester in the head with a nonlethal munition, resulting in a skull fracture. Coverage of the unrest has caught the attention of President Trump, who vowed to “dominate” the protesters with federal law enforcement officers.

headline: We Interrupt This Gloom to Offer … Hope
abstract: Yes, America is suffering needlessly. That may save us.
lead_paragraph: Just one in six Americans in a poll last month was “proud” of the state of the country, and about two out of three were actually “fearful” about it. So let me introduce a new thought: “hope.”

headline: 2020 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Tuesday
abstract: With Novak Djokovic’s disqualification, Tuesday’s men’s quarterfinalists are all vying for their first appearance in a Grand Slam final. Naomi Osaka remains the favorite to make it to the women’s singles final from her half of the draw.
lead_paragraph: How to watch: From noon to 6 p.m. and from 7 to 11 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN; and streaming on the ESPN app.

headline: City in California Reaches $4 Million Settlement in Fatal Police Shooting
abstract: Miles Hall, 23, was killed after his family called the police in Walnut Creek as he was experiencing a mental health crisis.
lead_paragraph: A California city has reached a $4 million settlement with the family of a Black man who was fatally shot last year as he was having a mental health breakdown.

headline: How N.Y.C.’s Mayor Ignored Warnings and Mishandled Reopening Schools
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio delayed the start of school for a second time, leading to an uproar among parents.
lead_paragraph: With unease growing in August about New York City’s plan to bring children back into public schools, Mayor Bill de Blasio insisted that classrooms would reopen on Sept. 10, saying that he would not “run away and hide” from a challenge.

headline: Why New Mexico’s 1680 Pueblo Revolt Is Echoing in 2020 Protests
abstract: Indigenous groups in the Southwest are imbuing their activism this year with commemorations of the 340-year-old Pueblo Revolt, one of Spain’s bloodiest defeats in its colonial empire.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — While protests over police violence against African-Americans spread from one city to the next in the aftermath of George Floyd’s killing in May, the missive scrawled in red paint on the New Mexico History Museum reached further back in time: “1680 Land Back.”

headline: Reform the Police? Guess Who Funds My State’s Officials
abstract: If the protests are to translate into laws, contributions for politicians from law enforcement must become toxic rather than coveted.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In late August, Los Angeles sheriff’s deputies shot a Black man, Dijon Kizzee, whom they had stopped for a suspected traffic violation as he rode his bicycle. He became the seventh man killed by deputies in Los Angeles since the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis on Memorial Day weekend.

headline: Biden, in Kenosha, Makes Case for Healing and Unity, Not Division
abstract: Two days after President Trump traveled to Wisconsin to focus attention on violence and disorder, Joe Biden sought to strike a drastically different tone, repudiating the president’s divisive approach to matters of racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: KENOSHA, Wis. — Drawing a sharp contrast with President Trump, Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday aligned himself strongly and sympathetically with protesters of racial injustice and with Black voters during an afternoon of raw interactions with people still grappling with the police shooting of Jacob Blake.

headline: What Is the Future of Black Appalachia?
abstract: We spoke to the curators of a cultural center in rural Virginia who have redoubled their efforts to help shape the future of Black Appalachia.
lead_paragraph: On a warm July day, Ron and Jill Carson sat in a former one-room schoolhouse in Pennington Gap, Va., that until 1965 was the only primary school in town for Black children. The first seven years of Mr. Carson’s education took place in that building, which was built by his great-great-grandmother in 1939.

headline: In Oakland, Breaking Down Barriers With Cookies
abstract: Asian-American and Black leaders described how the combination of the pandemic and the Black Lives Matter movement is changing relations between the two groups.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Voters Seem to Think Biden Is the ‘Law and Order’ Candidate
abstract: Extracting political power from racism and fear is a Trump specialty, but will it work in 2020?
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 20, Time magazine asked Henry Louis Gates Jr, the director of the Hutchins Center for African and African-American Research at Harvard, about America’s “missed opportunities for racial equality.”

headline: Suspect Is Charged in Shooting of 2 Louisville Police Officers
abstract: Demonstrators marched downtown without police intervention a day after a grand jury decided not to charge the officers who fatally shot Ms. Taylor. After curfew, protesters took refuge at a church.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Louisville, Ky., have charged Larynzo Johnson, 26, with 14 counts of wanton endangerment and two counts of assault on a police officer after two officers were shot during protests in the city, according to the Louisville Metro Department of Corrections.

headline: Draymond Green Doesn’t Mind Missing the N.B.A. Finals. This Year.
abstract: In this newsletter, Marc Stein talks to Green about the Golden State Warriors’ down year, analyzes the many coaching vacancies, and looks at the Lakers-Heat finals.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: What We Know About the Death of the Suspect in the Portland Shooting
abstract: The suspect, Michael Forest Reinoehl, 48, was killed by law enforcement agents just five days after the deadly shooting of a right-wing protester.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement agents in Washington State killed a suspect on Thursday night in the shooting death of a right-wing activist in Portland, Ore., last week, the latest development in the protests and counterdemonstrations that have escalated tensions in the city and drawn the nation’s attention.

headline: ‘They Stand on the Shoulders of Giants’: The Next Generation to March on Washington
abstract: Many protesters came to inspire their children and pass down a legacy of action against racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As crowds swelled against the backdrop of the Lincoln Memorial on Friday, activists spoke of a generational moment.

headline: Trump Moves to Cut Federal Funding From Democratic Cities
abstract: The president directed officials to identify “anarchist jurisdictions” and move to withhold funds as he tries to build his campaign around the unrest that has accompanied racial justice protests.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has directed federal officials to find ways to cut funding to a string of cities controlled by Democrats, citing violence amid protests against systemic racism in policing, a move that threatens billions of dollars for many of the country’s largest urban hubs as the president makes the unrest a centerpiece of his re-election campaign.

headline: Overlooked No More: Before Kamala Harris, There Was Charlotta Bass
abstract: She was the first Black woman to run for vice president, in 1952. She was also a pioneering journalist.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Opening the Doors of Design
abstract: A tiny proportion of designers are Black, but a host of new initiatives, as well as evolving tastes, are working to right the imbalance.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Design special report, which is about taking creative leaps in challenging times.

headline: Celebrities Plan an ‘Instagram Freeze,’ but Reaction Is Icy
abstract: Stars including Kim Kardashian West, Katy Perry and Mark Ruffalo said they would protest Facebook by freezing their Instagram accounts on Wednesday. The responses were far from positive.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — One by one, celebrities came forward this week to say they were sick of the misinformation and hate speech on Instagram and Facebook, its parent company. Many of them — Kim Kardashian West, Katy Perry, Leonardo DiCaprio — have tens of millions of followers on social media.

headline: Katrina Scott Wasn’t Supposed to Reach the U.S. Open. She’s in the Second Round.
abstract: Scott, 16, received a wild card after players withdrew because of coronavirus concerns. She faces the 22nd-seeded Amanda Anisimova on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: As more and more players withdrew from the United States Open because of travel and safety concerns during the coronavirus pandemic, a spot finally opened for a player who picked up the sport accidentally and hasn’t let go since.

headline: Trump Resumes the Rallies He Cherishes, but Virus Vexes His Plans
abstract: With hyperbole and falsehoods, the president has increased stops at airports that resemble campaign rallies, his favorite type of politicking. But Nevada said the events violated health restrictions and canceled two rallies there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With cheering crowds, inflated and false claims, and inflammatory partisan rhetoric, President Trump has resumed the mode of politicking he enjoys most: entertaining his supporters at campaign-style rallies.

headline: Go Live in Another Decade. I Recommend It.
abstract: Watching TV news from the past helps me get a grip on the present.
lead_paragraph: After the 2016 election, I was deeply shaken not just by the outcome, but by the terrifying sense that I did not understand the nation as well as I’d thought I did. To blunt the shock, I went on a bender through American history. I dove into books about the Civil War, the Progressive era and, finally, Robert Caro’s titanic biography of Lyndon B. Johnson, where I washed up on the shores of the turbulent 1960s.

headline: Pandemic, Unrest, Fires? An M.L.B. Rookie Still Smashes Home Runs
abstract: Kyle Lewis of the Seattle Mariners is a top contender for the American League Rookie of the Year Award in a shortened season upended by postponements and delays.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Lewis’s first two installments here and here.

headline: What I Learned Inside the N.B.A. Bubble
abstract: Against all odds, it really was a refuge of competence, normalcy and transcendent play. But the outside world has a way of sneaking in.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Melania Trump Statue Returns in Slovenia. (This One Is Harder to Burn.)
abstract: The wooden original, erected last year near the first lady’s hometown, was set on fire in July. The replacement, made from bronze, is intended to last a bit longer, the commissioning artist said.
lead_paragraph: When a wooden statue of Melania Trump was erected near her hometown in Slovenia last year, it was mocked as looking like a Smurfette or a scarecrow. Then it was set on fire.

headline: University Investigates Claim That White Professor Pretended to Be Black
abstract: George Washington University said it was looking into a blog post written under the name of Jessica A. Krug detailing a long history of deception about her racial identity.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Professor has resigned her position, university says.]

headline: A’ja Wilson for M.V.P., and More W.N.B.A. Awards Picks
abstract: Wilson, the Aces’ All-Star forward, isn’t the only one from Las Vegas deserving of honors this year.
lead_paragraph: Talent in the W.N.B.A. runs so deep that many teams have bench players who would start on other teams. With some of the league’s most familiar faces sitting out or having received medical exemptions for this season because of the coronavirus pandemic, under-the-radar players have seized their increased minutes as opportunities to shine. And while lesser-known players were compiling breakout seasons, some established stars were helping their teams win in unexpected ways.

headline: We Need to Recruit More Black Americans in Vaccine Trials
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies and the government must step up their efforts to enroll a diverse group of volunteers.
lead_paragraph: The global race is on for a vaccine to combat the coronavirus, but the question is: Who will be included?

headline: D.H.S. Downplayed Threats From Russia and White Supremacists, Whistle-Blower Says
abstract: Brian Murphy, the former head of the Department of Homeland Security’s intelligence division, accused senior leaders of warping the agency around President Trump’s political interests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top officials with the Department of Homeland Security directed agency analysts to downplay threats from violent white supremacy and Russian election interference, a Homeland Security official said in a whistle-blower complaint released on Wednesday.

headline: BBC Lost a Battle Over British Songs, and the War Is Far From Over
abstract: Boris Johnson came into office aiming to defund the BBC and let in rivals. The coronavirus has delayed that, but the broadcaster again finds itself a punching bag for Conservatives.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It had all the ingredients for a juicy skirmish in Britain’s simmering culture war, so when the BBC announced last week that it would strip the lyrics from two popular patriotic songs in its telecast of a beloved annual concert, Conservative leaders predictably lined up to express their outrage.

headline: Since 2015: 48 Black Women Killed by the Police. And Only 2 Charges.
abstract: For many, the grand jury announcement in Breonna Taylor’s case was more of the same, underscoring the need for systemic change.
lead_paragraph: — Andrea Ritchie, author of “Invisible No More: Police Violence Against Black Women and Women of Color”

headline: How Can You Be an Ally? Go to a Black-Owned Bank
abstract: If you’re looking for innovative ways beyond the ballot box to be an ally, look to the small and minority-owned banks anchoring your community.
lead_paragraph: Four years before this summer of unrest in New York City, I attended the protests after Alton Sterling and Philando Castile were shot and killed by police officers that July.

headline: Pandemic Imperils Promotions for Women in Academia
abstract: Even as faculty members are given more time to meet a deadline for tenure, many say they are getting less work done because of child care needs.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — Like millions of parents, Kimberly Marion Suiseeya, a political-science professor at Northwestern University, saw her work life upended when her third grader’s school shut down in March. Later, she was demoralized to learn that local schools would not reopen this fall.

headline: Trump Gets a Mixed Welcome in Kenosha
abstract: In Massachusetts, Ed Markey held off Joe Kennedy: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Markey fends off Kennedy in the Massachusetts Senate primary, as Trump tours wreckage in Kenosha. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: F.B.I. Investigates Louisiana Man’s Death After Police Chase
abstract: The Louisiana State Police said Ronald Greene died in a crash after leading troopers on a high-speed chase. Over a year later, photos of his injuries have raised new questions about his death.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have opened a civil rights investigation as new questions have surfaced about the death of a Black man after a high-speed police chase in northern Louisiana last year.

headline: Patrick Mahomes Flexes Chiefs’ Muscle to Beat the Ravens
abstract: The Chiefs’ star beat his Ravens rival Lamar Jackson for the third time, showing off an efficient and varied offense as Kansas City moved to 3-0.
lead_paragraph: This year, the brain trust at Electronic Arts gave Baltimore Ravens quarterback Lamar Jackson a well-publicized and worthy honor by putting his likeness on the cover of its Madden NFL 21 video game. Jackson had earned it: He was voted the N.F.L.’s most valuable player last season, and has quickly emerged as one of the most exciting players in the league.

headline: How the Show ‘Alone’ Sparked a Solo Trip and a Tough Realization
abstract: Had my fiancée and I, like so many of the contestants on the series, reached the end of our endurance?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.

headline: How George Floyd Died, and What Happened Next
abstract: Mr. Floyd, a Black man, died in May 2020 after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by Minneapolis police officers in an episode that was captured on video, touching off nationwide protests.
lead_paragraph: The death of George Floyd, a 46-year-old Black man, in May 2020 drew widespread outrage after a video circulated online showing Officer Derek Chauvin holding his knee on Mr. Floyd’s neck on a Minneapolis street corner as he gasped for breath.

headline: How Do You Open an Interactive Museum in a Pandemic? Very Carefully
abstract: Curators of the new Makeup Museum had to completely rethink their first exhibition.
lead_paragraph: New York’s first Makeup Museum, an immersive, interactive concept focusing on touch and experimentation, was slated to open in May. Its premiere exhibition, “Pink Jungle: 1950s Makeup in America,” would encourage visitors to take part in experiences like mixing their own makeup or indulging in facials modeled on the ones given to Marilyn Monroe and Greta Garbo. Artifacts of that halcyon era, like elaborate compacts or rhinestone-studded lipstick cases, would be available for handling.

headline: Seats? Empty. Crowd Noise? Artificial. Giants? Still Bad.
abstract: A team that has scraped together only 12 wins in their last three seasons, combined, started this one with another loss.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Under normal circumstances, MetLife Stadium in New Jersey would have been awash in the blues and reds worn by the home fans. But against the backdrop of the coronavirus pandemic, the Giants and Pittsburgh Steelers opened their seasons within the drab gray interior of the stadium.

headline: Anthony McGill, ‘Citizen Musician,’ Wins $100,000 Award
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s principal clarinet, and a leader in promoting racial representation, was chosen for the Avery Fisher Prize.
lead_paragraph: Anthony McGill, the New York Philharmonic’s principal clarinet, hasn’t been heard onstage at Lincoln Center since the coronavirus pandemic abruptly ended the orchestra’s season in March. But he has been difficult to miss online, whether as the instigator of #TakeTwoKnees performances in response to the killing of George Floyd, or as a prominent voice in subsequent conversations around racial representation in classical music.

headline: How Latinos Can Win the Culture War
abstract: First, white gatekeepers have to stop hoarding power.
lead_paragraph: The story about Latinos in America is an old one. And it isn’t true. Created generations ago by whites to demonize Mexicans and then Puerto Ricans, the racist caricature of Latinos as a menacing foreign monolith persists, even as two-thirds of us were born here and we come from more than 20 different countries.

headline: Young Women Take a Frontline Role in Thailand’s Protests
abstract: Women, many of them students, are speaking out against a patriarchy that controls the military, the monarchy and the Buddhist monkhood, Thailand’s most powerful institutions.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — As tens of thousands of people have gathered for a series of pro-democracy protests in Thailand in recent weeks, their ranks have been dominated by an emerging political force: young women.

headline: What Polls Say About the 2020 Race as Biden and Trump Square Off
abstract: A crucial fraction of the millions who watch the first presidential debate on Tuesday will have yet to make up their minds. Here’s what polling tells us about the issues that will come up.
lead_paragraph: [Watch the presidential debate live and follow along with our real-time analysis.]

headline: A Law-and-Order Push by Trump, but Little Change in Biden’s Lead
abstract: The president’s effort to reframe the election at the convention hasn’t helped his standing much, according to a big wave of polls.
lead_paragraph: Despite the spotlight of the Republican convention and the unrest in Portland, Ore., and Kenosha, Wis., a big wave of new polls Wednesday showed that President Trump continues to trail Joe Biden by a significant margin both nationwide and in the critical battleground states.

headline: The Truth About ‘The Truth About’ Memes
abstract: Videos and viral images claiming to tell “the truth about” Black victims of police shootings are years old. This week, they are circulating about Breonna Taylor.
lead_paragraph: This week, protests erupted around the nation after a Louisville grand jury did not charge any police officers in the killing of Breonna Taylor. And on social media, false and exaggerated claims about Ms. Taylor began recirculating, using a years-old format that was popularized years ago by far-right YouTube personalities.

headline: In Wisconsin Poll, Unrest Concerns Don’t Translate Into Surge for Trump
abstract: Worries about law and order have become so prevalent that likely voters say it’s just as important as solving the coronavirus pandemic. But voters aren’t favoring Mr. Trump on the issue.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

headline: How Joe Biden Is Preparing for the Biggest Debate of His Life
abstract: The first debate between Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Trump on Tuesday represents one of the president’s last, best chances to move a race that polls show him losing. There are risks for Mr. Biden, too.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election.]

headline: ‘The Time Has Come’: Barbados Casts Off the Queen as Head of State, and Others May Follow
abstract: The Black Lives Matter movement has revived a simmering debate about the legacy of colonialism, potentially inspiring change in other Caribbean countries.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The last time a string of distant dominions cast off Queen Elizabeth was in the 1970s when the Black power movement emboldened three Caribbean countries to declare themselves republics. Now, in the heat of the Black Lives Matter movement, the Caribbean may once again turn against the queen.

headline: Gen X, Right-Wing Bastion?
abstract: What it means that my generation is the future of the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: If, as seems possible, Joe Biden wins the presidency by peeling away older white voters from the Republican coalition, liberals won’t just win the White House; they’ll gain a new generational villain to bemoan. Instead of laments about The Villages and sneers of “OK Boomer,” there will be a realization that the last bastion of conservatism in a leftward-shifting country may soon lie with my own Generation X.

headline: A Black Venture Capitalist Sees Challenges as an Investing Edge
abstract: “Black Founders Matter” started out as a T-shirt design. Now, a once-jilted start-up founder is trying to turn it into a moneymaking strategy.
lead_paragraph: Marceau Michel’s idea for a new on-demand staffing company, Werkhorse, was good enough to win a start-up pitch competition and a coveted spot in a tech incubator in Portland, Ore., two years ago. But no matter what he did, Mr. Michel could not seem to land the funding he needed.

headline: Supreme Court, Europe Lockdowns, Electric Cars: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Los Angeles Sheriff’s Deputies Fatally Shoot a Black Man They Say Had a Gun
abstract: The man, who was identified as Dijon Kizzee, 29, had been stopped while riding a bicycle, the Sheriff’s Department said.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles sheriff’s deputies fatally shot a Black man who they said had a handgun on Monday afternoon after a stop turned into a violent altercation, the authorities said.

headline: A Brief Guide to 21st-Century Blackface
abstract: Twenty years ago, Spike Lee’s “Bamboozled” skewered America’s love of minstrelsy. Has Hollywood learned anything about blackface since?
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Spike Lee’s “Bamboozled” skewered America’s love of minstrelsy. Has Hollywood learned anything about blackface since?

headline: Live Analysis: Massachusetts Election Results
abstract: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.

headline: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Trump Taxes, Supreme Court, World Records
abstract: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

headline: What Is Celebrity?
abstract: You voted on the most— and least — important categories of American celebrity. The results surprised us!
lead_paragraph: You voted on the most— and least — important categories of American celebrity. The results surprised us!

headline: John Cusack Never Understood His Cusackness
abstract: “Perhaps in a way, I had my own brand. I would have denied it, because that would be pretty unartistic.”
lead_paragraph: “Perhaps in a way, I had my own brand. I would have denied it, because that would be pretty unartistic.”

headline: Faces of Power: 80% Are White, Even as U.S. Becomes More Diverse
abstract: See the 922 faces of power behind Hollywood, the justice system, big businesses and more; 180 of them identify as Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, multiracial or otherwise a person of color.
lead_paragraph: See the 922 faces of power behind Hollywood, the justice system, big businesses and more; 180 of them identify as Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, multiracial or otherwise a person of color.

headline: What Our Reporter Is Seeing on the Ground in Kenosha
abstract: President Trump arrives today for a visit over the objections of the mayor and governor, who asked him to come later to avoid inflaming tensions in this boarded-up, traumatized city.
lead_paragraph: President Trump arrives today for a visit over the objections of the mayor and governor, who asked him to come later to avoid inflaming tensions in this boarded-up, traumatized city.

headline: Ilhan Omar Is Not Here to Put You at Ease
abstract: “You’re agitated by my tone because you think people like me should be sitting in a corner, not heard and not seen.”
lead_paragraph: “You’re agitated by my tone because you think people like me should be sitting in a corner, not heard and not seen.”

headline: New York’s Arts Shutdown: The Economic Crisis in One Lost Weekend
abstract: We zero in on one moment in New York City’s cultural calendar that’s been wiped clean — what it means, what it looks like, what it cost and what’s ahead.
lead_paragraph: We zero in on one moment in New York City’s cultural calendar that’s been wiped clean — what it means, what it looks like, what it cost and what’s ahead.

headline: Surviving Fashion’s Summer From Hell
abstract: Tibi is giving pandemic-era lessons in personal style, and finding new paths forward for its business.
lead_paragraph: In late April, Amy Smilovic began streaming live from the Instagram account of her fashion label, Tibi. About once a week, she and Dione Davis, her styling director, would put on Tibi outfits and talk — easily, authoritatively — about how the clothes made them feel.

headline: Few Police Officers Who Cause Deaths Are Charged or Convicted
abstract: A wide gulf remains between the public perception of police violence and how it is treated in court.
lead_paragraph: Since Breonna Taylor was awakened in the night and shot to death by the police in her own home, Louisville has banned no-knock warrants. A police chief was fired, and so was an officer who was on the scene. But despite demands from across the country, no one was charged in Ms. Taylor’s death.

headline: Playing Jesus in a Pandemic Summer
abstract: Nicholas Edwards starred in the closely watched “Godspell” production. “Usually the stage is a safe place,” he said, “but it became a place where I was anxious all the time.”
lead_paragraph: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — On Sunday afternoon, Nicholas Edwards rolled the white gaiter over his nose and mouth for the last time.

headline: 7 Police Officers Suspended as a Black Man’s Suffocation Roils Rochester
abstract: Daniel Prude, who was having a psychotic episode, died after police officers placed a mesh hood over his head in March.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — Seven Rochester police officers were suspended on Thursday in the suffocation of a Black man as he was being detained in March, although the mayor and senior state officials faced escalating questions about why more than five months passed before action was taken.

headline: For the Met Opera, the Pandemic Could Be a Necessary Reset
abstract: The company seems to be using a long break as a reboot, with more vital, representative programming coming soon.
lead_paragraph: This spring, after the coronavirus pandemic forced the closure of performing arts institutions around the world, Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, faced the truth.

headline: Strike. This Could Be Our Last Stand.
abstract: If we can’t get our government to help us now, when will we ever?
lead_paragraph: Labor Day hit with an extra knife-twist of cruel irony this year, in an America that is barely trying to pretend anymore that the plight of tens of millions of working people merits national concern.

headline: Life in ‘Anarchist’ New York City
abstract: I saw a woman drinking iced coffee in 57 degree weather. OK, chaos agent!
lead_paragraph: Right after I learned that the Department of Justice this week designated New York City an “anarchist jurisdiction,” alongside Portland, Ore., and Seattle, I took a walk around my Brooklyn neighborhood with freshly fearful eyes. There was an older man in a plaid shirt leaning against the fence of a basketball court, eyes closed, face turned up toward the autumn sunlight. Perhaps he was enjoying a moment of solace with nature before winter, when we will surely be driven back indoors by the coronavirus. Or was he gathering strength before smashing up the local Victoria’s Secret and bringing home the lacy loot to his wife, most likely another senior citizen demented by lawlessness?

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Russia’s outbreak, TikTok deal, schools reopening: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The number of coronavirus cases passed 1 million on Tuesday, the Russian government said, despite an official declaration in early August that the country had a vaccine. About 5,000 new infections are reported daily.

headline: Facebook Has Been a Disaster for the World
abstract: How much longer are we going to allow its platform to foment hatred and undermine democracy?
lead_paragraph: For years, Myanmar’s military used Facebook to incite hatred and genocidal violence against the country’s mostly Muslim Rohingya minority group, leading to mass death and displacement. It took until 2018 for Facebook to admit to and apologize for its failure to act.

headline: For Biden to Win, Listen to Minneapolis
abstract: Not everyone is for defunding the police. Especially those in communities that would be most affected.
lead_paragraph: There’s one thing about the people on the Trump team that I almost admire: When they do blurt out the truth, they really tell you the truth — in a way that’s so raw you’re left asking, “Did they really say that out loud?”

headline: In ‘The Field’ Podcast, Voters Are the Main Characters
abstract: After a pandemic-induced hiatus, the show has returned, with a focus on the voices of Americans throughout the country as they grapple with the weightiest questions of the November election.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Jazz Has Always Been Protest Music. Can It Meet This Moment?
abstract: Over the past 50 years, the music has become entrenched in academic institutions. As a result, it’s often inaccessible to, and disconnected from, many of the very people who created it: young Black Americans.
lead_paragraph: If the Black Lives Matter movement has an anthem, it’s probably Kendrick Lamar’s “Alright.” Five years after its release, it’s still chanted en masse by demonstrators and blasted from car stereos at protests, fluttering in the air like a liberation flag.

headline: Executives to Step Down After Rio Tinto Destroys Sacred Australian Sites
abstract: The mining giant’s chief executive was among those pushed out after shareholders revolted over the destruction of ancient Indigenous sites in Western Australia.
lead_paragraph: DARWIN, Australia — The caves, set deep in a desert gorge, had yielded a treasure trove of artifacts tracing Aboriginal people’s long history in Australia: a 28,000-year-old kangaroo bone sharpened into a blade; a 4,000-year-old plait of human hair believed to have been worn as a belt.

headline: Police, Protests and Violence: How Times Video Experts Examine a Scene
abstract: In analyzing footage involving fatalities or accusations of brutality, the Visual Investigations unit pursues the truth, frame by frame.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Chiefs Fans, Used to Chops and Cheers, React to N.F.L.’s New Climate
abstract: Kansas City’s fans are among the loudest in pro football. But the celebratory start to their season silenced game rituals and drew mixed opinions on players’ protests of racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Kent Gaines stepped out of his car on Thursday evening, a red mask swinging from his finger, and took in the scene around him in the parking lot of Arrowhead Stadium. It was just before the Kansas City Chiefs and the Houston Texans kicked off to start an N.F.L. season unlike any he had ever experienced as a season-ticket holder.

headline: As Hurricane Sally Looms, the Gulf Coast Braces Itself Yet Again
abstract: Forecasters expect the storm to bring rain to Louisiana before making landfall in Mississippi with potentially lethal storm surge and powerful winds.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Hurricane Sally updates and our map tracker.]

headline: Federal Prosecutors Intervene to Charge 2 Over Rochester Protests
abstract: The men are accused of civil disorder, in the latest move by the federal authorities to target those they say are bent on causing violence.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Wednesday filed charges against two men accused of causing civil disorder in attacks on police officers during a night of sometimes violent protests in Rochester, N.Y., over the weekend.

headline: One Musician’s Plan to Make the Concert Industry More Diverse
abstract: Noelle Scaggs from Fitz and the Tantrums has an initiative, Diversify the Stage, that aims to direct more touring business opportunities to people of color, women, and L.G.B.T.Q. people.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before Covid-19 shut the concert industry down, Noelle Scaggs, one of the singers in the alt-pop band Fitz and the Tantrums, began noticing that there was seldom anyone else like her on the road.

headline: Trump Visits Kenosha, Offering Support for Police With Little Mention of Shooting
abstract: The president, touring the city that is the latest focal point of anger over police shootings of Black Americans, called attention instead to the street violence that he blamed on liberal politicians.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of the Biden inauguration.]

headline: Minneapolis officials said they would defund the police. Some now regret that pledge.
abstract: Over three months ago, a majority of the Minneapolis City Council pledged to defund the city’s Police Department, making a powerful statement that reverberated across the country. It shook up Capitol Hill and the presidential race, shocked residents, delighted activists and changed the trajectory of efforts to overhaul the police during a crucial window of tumult and political opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Over three months ago, a majority of the Minneapolis City Council pledged to defund the city’s Police Department, making a powerful statement that reverberated across the country. It shook up Capitol Hill and the presidential race, shocked residents, delighted activists and changed the trajectory of efforts to overhaul the police during a crucial window of tumult and political opportunity.

headline: N.Y.C. Reports Large Uptick in Virus Cases
abstract: The daily rate of positive tests rose to 3.25 percent, the highest it had been in months, as more public school students returned to classrooms.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials announced on Tuesday a significant uptick in the citywide daily rate of positive virus tests, which was in part attributable to a rise in cases in nine ZIP codes in Brooklyn and Queens — some in predominantly Orthodox Jewish communities that have largely ignored public health guidance, like wearing masks.

headline: Kevin Young, Poet and Author, Is Named to Lead African American Museum
abstract: The poetry editor of The New Yorker will retain that position while undertaking his new role.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian on Wednesday named Kevin Young, a poet, archivist, author and editor, as the new director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture.

headline: Voting Alone
abstract: The national bard of community long warned about what isolation would do to us. Now our democracy is in the midst of an experiment no one asked for.
lead_paragraph: From his back deck in southwestern New Hampshire, Robert D. Putnam sees his yard slope past a few hardwood trees and an overturned canoe down to a pond, beyond which looms Mount Monadnock, one of Henry David Thoreau’s favorite peaks to hike.

headline: How a Pledge to Dismantle the Minneapolis Police Collapsed
abstract: When a majority of City Council members promised to “end policing as we know it” after George Floyd’s killing, they became a case study in how idealistic calls for structural change can falter.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Over three months ago, a majority of the Minneapolis City Council pledged to defund the city’s police department, making a powerful statement that reverberated across the country. It shook up Capitol Hill and the presidential race, shocked residents, delighted activists and changed the trajectory of efforts to overhaul the police during a crucial window of tumult and political opportunity.

headline: What Does TikTok Mean to You?
abstract: Are you a user or content creator on TikTok? Have you been following the news about the threatened ban, and then sale, of TikTok? Do you think we should we care about what happens to TikTok?
lead_paragraph: TikTok is used by nearly 100 million Americans for everything from education about climate change and the Black Lives Matter movement to dance videos and comedic skits. The app has been downloaded more than two billion times. Do you use TikTok? What role does it play in your life?

headline: Fox News Is Accused of Hiding George Soros’s Influence
abstract: It’s a twist for the cable channel, which regularly airs criticism of the billionaire investor and Democratic donor.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no figure gets more attention in conspiracy circles than George Soros, the billionaire investor and Democratic donor. For years, he has been cast as an anticonservative villain by a loose network of activists and political figures on the right. And in recent months, he has become a convenient boogeyman for misinformation artists who have falsely claimed that he funds spontaneous Black Lives Matter protests as well as antifa, the decentralized and largely online, far-left activist network that opposes President Trump.

headline: Gen Zers Say Silicon Valley Is Elitist and Exclusive. Can They Build a New System?
abstract: A group of young tech enthusiasts are carving their own path on Discord.
lead_paragraph: For young people, breaking into the cutthroat tech industry — or any industry, really — has become far more difficult during the pandemic. In-person networking events and club meetings are on hold; there aren’t many online hubs for informal connection; and the investors and founders whose buy-in can make or break a product are harder to reach.

headline: Unwitting Progressives for Trump
abstract: Does Joe Biden have the nerve to stand up to the far left?
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, as Donald Trump was about to accept the Republican nomination from the South Lawn of the White House with warnings that “No one will be safe in Biden’s America,” National Public Radio was doing its small part to make sure the president would be re-elected.

headline: How ‘Sophocles in Staten Island’ Gains in Translation
abstract: This comic short about an actor and his kids staging Greek tragedies under lockdown slyly comments on links between the politics of the family and the state.
lead_paragraph: Sophocles knew: Every family has its issues. And in his famed Theban plays, the social ramifications of this are devastating. In “Oedipus Rex,” Oedipus kills his father and beds his mother, which causes a plague to descend onto Thebes. In “Antigone,” his daughter Antigone defies her uncle, Creon, and the family strife results in a string of deaths.

headline: Documenting Teenage Lives: A Guide for Participating in Our Contest
abstract: Four practical steps for cataloging what you already have, deciding what you most want to express, and playing with medium and genre.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Aug. 2021 to reflect our new writing unit and related contest.

headline: Trump Spread Multiple Conspiracy Theories on Monday. Here Are Their Roots.
abstract: The unfounded ideas have been circulating online for months.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of the Biden inauguration.]

headline: How a Restaurateur and Activist Spends Her Sundays
abstract: When she has free time, Claire Sprouse makes a point of supporting small local businesses, since she runs one herself.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Claire Sprouse moved from San Francisco, where she had become an outspoken activist on sustainability in bars, to New York in an effort to continue her mission here. Three years later, she opened Hunky Dory, her eclectic and earthy restaurant and bar in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, which focuses on minimizing waste and features herbs and fruit from a community garden in its cocktails and dishes.

headline: The 22-Year-Old Coordinating Protests in Belarus, From a Small Office in Poland
abstract: Stepan Svetlov hasn’t set foot in Belarus for two years. But his social media profile is now a lodestar for demonstrators back home.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Stepan Svetlov’s computer sits on a desk in Warsaw, nearly 300 miles from Minsk, the capital of Belarus. But when Belarusians poured into the streets in the hours and days after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko fraudulently claimed a re-election victory on Aug. 9, it was thanks in no small part to Mr. Svetlov, 22, and his computer.

headline: F.B.I. Director Sees No Evidence of National Mail Voting Fraud Effort
abstract: The comments undercut the president’s claims about mail-in ballots.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has not seen evidence of a “coordinated national voter fraud effort,” its director, Christopher A. Wray, told lawmakers on Thursday, undercutting President Trump’s efforts to stoke fears about mail-in ballots by claiming without evidence that they are an election threat.

headline: Four Louisiana Officers Charged in Death of Black Man With Mental Illness
abstract: Prosecutors said a coroner had determined that Tommie McGlothen’s death in Shreveport in April was preventable because the officers should have known he needed medical treatment.
lead_paragraph: Four Louisiana police officers were indicted Friday on charges of negligent homicide and malfeasance after they used excessive force and a Taser to arrest a mentally ill Black man and then failed to give him medical attention, prosecutors said.

headline: Efforts to Channel Protests Into More Votes Face Challenges in Kenosha
abstract: Some Black residents of Kenosha, upended by the police shooting of Jacob Blake, weren’t convinced that an election would solve the problem.
lead_paragraph: KENOSHA, Wis. — Gerald Holmes, a forklift operator from Kenosha, Wis., was so passionate about the importance of the election four years ago that he drove people without rides to the polls. But this year, Mr. Holmes says he is not even planning to vote himself.

headline: How New York City’s Police Unions Embraced Trump
abstract: The unions’ leadership is mostly white, suburban and Republican, setting it apart from an increasingly diverse police force and the city itself.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s largest police union had not endorsed a candidate for president in decades when its leader, Patrick J. Lynch, stepped to the lectern last month at President Trump’s golf club in New Jersey.

headline: ‘Antebellum’ and the Horrors of History That Persist Today
abstract: Janelle Monáe and her directors tackled slavery’s terrible legacy. But re-enacting scenes of bondage demanded reserves of strength.
lead_paragraph: The filmmakers Gerard Bush and Christopher Renz were only in Los Angeles a short time when they were suddenly at the center of a bidding war over their ambitious debut movie, “Antebellum.” “It really surprised us,” Bush recalled. “We found ourselves in the tornado of studios pursuing us and the script.”

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Black Lives Matter Reached Every Corner of America’
abstract: In this lesson, students will use more than 200 photographs to learn about the protests that swept across the United States in late May and June.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How Black Lives Matter Reached Every Corner of America”

headline: Police or Prosecutor Misconduct Is at Root of Half of Exoneration Cases, Study Finds
abstract: Wrongly convicted Black defendants were slightly more likely than whites to be victims of misconduct, especially in drug and murder investigations.
lead_paragraph: Official misconduct played a role in the criminal convictions of more than half of innocent people who were later exonerated, according to a new report by a registry that tracks wrongful convictions.

headline: The Best Part of Layshia Clarendon’s Game? ‘Fearlessness’
abstract: “It doesn’t matter if I get blocked — I’m going to go right back in the paint again,” the Liberty guard said. They bring that same tenacity to their role on the W.N.B.A. union’s executive committee.
lead_paragraph: On the court, Layshia Clarendon has become the leader of a young Liberty team coursing through a season with many unexpected challenges. As an executive committee member of the W.N.B.A.’s players’ union, Clarendon has also become a voice for social justice for the league this year.

headline: ‘Coloured Lives Matter’: A South African Police Shooting Like No Other
abstract: He was a young man from the projects gunned down by officers near his home. But race is complicated in South Africa, and so is his story.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa — The deadly encounter between the police and a young man from the projects, set off public outrage with all the familiar scenes: shrines of flowers and stuffed animals, clouds of tear gas and barrages of rocks aimed at officers in riot gear, and impassioned slogans.

headline: Trump Vaccine Chief Casts Doubt on Coronavirus Vaccine by Election Day
abstract: Just as Thailand reached 100 days without a new local case, it found one. The New York Times surveyed more than 1,500 colleges and found that over two-thirds had reported at least one case.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

headline: Documents Reveal How the Police Kept Daniel Prude’s Death Quiet
abstract: Officials in Rochester, N.Y., spent months trying to suppress video footage of the police encounter that led to Mr. Prude’s death.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — It was early June, days after the death of George Floyd, and cities around the country were erupting in protests against police brutality.

headline: 7 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually or in person in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The composer Sarah Kirkland Snider is an artistic director of the consistently rewarding label New Amsterdam Records. Her third full-length release, “Mass for the Endangered,” due out on Friday, features the vocal ensemble Gallicantus and the conductor Gabriel Crouch.

headline: Seeing Ourselves in Bloom
abstract: Cristina Martinez makes paintings for hyphenated American life.
lead_paragraph: Cristina Martinez paints women as if they are flowers. In her brightly hued renderings, their heads loom and droop over their bodies, like blooms too heavy for their stems. Often, they are dressed in vibrant gowns with flecks of paint to mimic sequins; the color of their skin, a moist terra cotta, similar in shades to the Black and brown women who raised the artist.

headline: A Civil War Political Movement Reawakens — Complete With Capes
abstract: In 1860, the Wide Awakes mobilized against slavery and for Abraham Lincoln. A new collective is tapping into their spirit today.
lead_paragraph: In January, the artist Hank Willis Thomas began enigmatically summoning designers, musicians and activists he knew to his studio in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He was working on something big, bringing a force of history back to life.

headline: Breonna Taylor and Perpetual Black Trauma
abstract: The system erased her as if she never existed.
lead_paragraph: I filed this column late. Very late. I couldn’t find the words — an unsettling experience for a writer. The words I did conjure failed, not because the message was difficult to convey, but rather because the conveyance is maddeningly depressive in repetition.

headline: The Truth About Today’s Anarchists
abstract: “Insurrectionary anarchists” have been protesting for racial justice all summer. Some Black leaders wish they would go home.
lead_paragraph: On the last Sunday in May, Jeremy Lee Quinn, a furloughed photographer in Santa Monica, Calif., was snapping photos of suburban moms kneeling at a Black Lives Matter protest when a friend alerted him to a more dramatic subject: looting at a shoe store about a mile away.

headline: Breonna Taylor’s Family to Receive $12 Million Settlement From City of Louisville
abstract: In the aftermath of the botched police raid in which Ms. Taylor was killed, the city also agreed to institute changes aimed at preventing future deaths by officers.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — After months of protests that turned Breonna Taylor’s name into a national slogan against police violence, city officials agreed to pay her family $12 million and institute changes aimed at preventing future deaths by officers.

headline: ‘One of the Worst, Strangest Years’: An N.B.A. Season Like No Other
abstract: Coronavirus and conflict, protest and mourning: Five people tell what they learned about basketball, and themselves, in a turbulent season that changed the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — It was a perfect moment for an imperfect season.

headline: What We Learned From the R.N.C.
abstract: In a live discussion, Times national reporters talked about the themes at the Republican convention and the strategies in play to help President Trump get re-elected.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Trump has a long history of language that incites and demonizes.
abstract: President Trump has employed provocative and sometimes incendiary words and images to focus attention on demonstrations and away from the human and economic costs of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has seized on the response in the streets to police brutality against Black men and women to bolster his re-election campaign, employing provocative and sometimes incendiary language and images to incite his followers, demonize his opponents or both.

headline: Claudia Rankine on the Ways Race Haunts Her Imagination, and America’s
abstract: In her new book, “Just Us,” the poet and essayist repeatedly asks how race is understood and manifested in American culture.
lead_paragraph: JUST USAn American ConversationBy Claudia Rankine

headline: Trump Uses E.P.A. Office to Widen ‘Anarchist’ War vs. New York
abstract: The president has painted New York as an “anarchist jurisdiction,” but his administration’s threats to withhold funds are being dismissed as a politicized campaign tactic.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s politicized campaign to label New York City an “anarchist jurisdiction” broadened on Tuesday, with the head of the Environmental Protection Agency threatening to move its regional headquarters out of Lower Manhattan.

headline: Emmys Toast ‘Watchmen’ and ‘Schitt’s Creek’ as Stars Stay Home
abstract: HBO’s ‘Succession’ won best drama. But ‘Schitt’s Creek,’ which swept the comedy awards, and ‘Watchmen,’ with its socially resonant themes, stole the show.
lead_paragraph: [ Stay up to date on the full nominees list from the 73rd Emmy Awards nominations.]

headline: Louisville’s Police Force Feels Besieged on Two Fronts
abstract: Officers say that city and police officials were slow to release crucial details in the Breonna Taylor case. Protesters are fed up with what they consider abusive tactics. Calm seems a long way off.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — When gunshots rang out shortly before 9 p.m. on Wednesday, Lt. William Vogt of the Louisville Metro Police Department saw a fallen colleague just 15 feet away. He quickly dragged his fellow officer to safety, but then looked up to a scene that put him even more on edge: several of his colleagues with their guns drawn, facing a crowd of protesters.

headline: N.Y.C. Schools Reopen for a First Day Unlike Any Other
abstract: Up to 90,000  in pre-K as well as students with advanced disabilities streamed into about 700 school buildings for  in-person classes.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Marian Wright Edelman Steps Down, and a New Generation Takes Over
abstract: A Ferguson activist will lead the Children’s Defense Fund at a time when an impassioned civil rights movement is challenging racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: Marian Wright Edelman, 81, took to the streets this summer, joining millions of people around the country in protesting police brutality after the killing of George Floyd.

headline: Disney Wanted to Make a Splash in China With ‘Mulan.’ It Stumbled Instead.
abstract: A political controversy over a filming location was a rare blunder for one of the world’s savviest companies in dealing with China.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Executives at Walt Disney Studios were celebrating. “Mulan,” a $200 million live-action spectacle five years in the making, had arrived on Disney’s streaming service to strong reviews, with critics lauding its ravishing scenery and thrilling battle sequences.

headline: Authentic Wins the Kentucky Derby, Run Without Fans
abstract: The race in Louisville ran with a smaller field than usual, no spectators and in spite of nearby protests over the police killing of Breonna Taylor in the city earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — No one really expected a horse race.

headline: Chiefs’ New Normal Looks Familiar in Win Over Texans
abstract: Kansas City’s Super Bowl title defense began with boos from a reduced capacity home crowd and ended with a resounding victory.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Just about the only thing that looked familiar about the N.F.L.’s long-awaited return Thursday night was the sight of Patrick Mahomes effortlessly leading the Kansas City Chiefs up and down the field.

headline: After Unrest, Kenosha Wrestles With What Comes Next
abstract: Some residents saw the shooting of Jacob Blake as proof that the city’s policing needs a fundamental overhaul. Others spoke of getting back to normal.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s what we know about the Jacob Blake shooting in Kenosha, Wisconsin.]

headline: The Fall Surge Is Here
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Public health experts have long been worried that the end of the summer — as some students returned to school and the weather cooled — would bring a surge in coronavirus cases.

headline: ‘All That Death in His Life’: Daniel Prude’s Tragic Journey to Rochester
abstract: Mr. Prude had a somewhat troubled life in Chicago, with a series of personal tragedies disrupting his attempts at finding meaningful stability.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On the last day anyone on Chicago’s West Side saw Daniel Prude alive, he was his usual self, shooting the breeze with a loose band of neighbors outside of a local carwash.

headline: Pull Out of the Kentucky Derby? Pressure on a Black Owner Mounts
abstract: Greg Harbut, the rare Black owner of a horse in America’s biggest race, says the predominantly white sport must change. But at a moment of social unrest, others question why he is racing at all.
lead_paragraph: In any other year, Greg Harbut would be enjoying the achievement of a lifetime. On Saturday, he will watch his horse Necker Island enter the starting gate for the 146th running of the Kentucky Derby, a moment of pride for a family that over the generations has built its success in the thoroughbred business.

headline: A Painter Who Puts It All on the Line
abstract: At 81, Virginia Jaramillo is having her first solo museum exhibition, at the Menil Collection. What took so long?
lead_paragraph: HAMPTON BAYS, N.Y. — The abstract painter Virginia Jaramillo has gotten very good at lines — physically, drawing them to great effect, but also metaphorically crossing them, as a woman of Mexican heritage in the art world.

headline: False Rumors That Activists Set Wildfires Exasperate Officials
abstract: Law enforcement agencies said claims on social media that antifascist activists had set fires on the West Coast were unfounded.
lead_paragraph: Officials dealing with catastrophic fires on the West Coast have had to counter social media rumors that the blazes were set by antifascist activists, publicly pleading that people verify information before sharing it.

headline: At Pentagon, Fears Grow That Trump Will Pull Military Into Election Unrest
abstract: Defense Department officials said top generals could resign if Mr. Trump ordered the active-duty military into the streets to quell protests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Pentagon leaders have a lot to worry about — Afghanistan, Russia, Iraq, Syria, Iran, China, Somalia, the Korean Peninsula. But chief among those concerns is whether their commander in chief might order American troops into any chaos around the coming elections.

headline: Veterans Fortify the Ranks of Militias Aligned With Trump’s Views
abstract: The vast majority of veterans do not join militias, but some fast-growing militias have many veterans among their ranks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Emboldened by President Trump’s campaign platform of law and order, militia groups have bolstered their strength before Election Day by attracting military veterans who bring weapons and tactical skills viewed as important to the organizations.

headline: Basketball and Social Justice: Bucks Say ‘It’s Harder to Do Both’
abstract: “But that’s what we chose as a team,” said Giannis Antetokounmpo after Milwaukee was eliminated.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Everything was simpler in November and December, back when the Milwaukee Bucks were rolling through the regular season and chasing a championship and no one knew anything about the coronavirus. Giannis Antetokounmpo had somehow improved his game, and the future was rife with possibility.

headline: Biden’s Vulnerability
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/Siena College poll showed Joe Biden to be leading President Trump in four important swing states. But it also showed how Biden could lose the election.

headline: The First Presidential Face-Off
abstract: Biden and Trump prepare to confront each other onstage: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: [Watch the presidential debate live and follow along with our real-time analysis.]

headline: Estate’s Racially Divisive Name Threatens Future of Premier Equestrian Event
abstract: The Olympic equestrian sport of eventing will no longer be held at a Pennsylvania estate that has resisted calls to change its name, which some say evokes slavery.
lead_paragraph: For two decades, the Olympic equestrian sport of eventing has held prestigious competitions on a Pennsylvania estate with a landscape perfect for horses and riders to demonstrate strength, endurance and grace while jumping over a variety of solid and natural obstacles.

headline: Michelle Wu, a progressive, mounts a challenge to Boston’s mayor.
abstract: Michelle Wu, a 35-year-old Taiwanese-American city councilor and progressive Democrat,  announced on Tuesday that she would enter the 2021 Boston mayoral race, asserting a moment of change for a city that has been led by white men since its incorporation in 1822.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Wu, a 35-year-old Taiwanese-American city councilor and progressive Democrat,  announced on Tuesday that she would enter the 2021 Boston mayoral race, asserting a moment of change for a city that has been led by white men since its incorporation in 1822.

headline: Is an Algorithm Less Racist Than a Loan Officer?
