abstract: Colin Kaepernick’s decision to sit or take a knee during the national anthem exploded into a national conversation about race. Here, high school students tell us why they sit or kneel during the national anthem or the Pledge of Allegiance — or why they stand and participate.
lead_paragraph: In August, 2016, the National Football League quarterback Colin Kaepernick began sitting, and then kneeling, during the national anthem before games as a protest against racist treatment of black people in the United States. His gestures created a new front in the national conversation about race, policing and patriotism.

headline: ESPN Is Terrified of Jemele Hill’s Honesty on Racism
abstract: By suspending her, the sports network is making a desperate move not to alienate some viewers and sponsors.
lead_paragraph: I’ve watched the N.F.L. on ESPN for more than 20 years in part because I grew up with the kind of father who pretty much refused to talk to me until I showed interest in the game. One Sunday when I was 12, I parked myself on the couch next to him, and because we were watching Brett Favre, I asked him what an interception was. “When you throw it to the other team,” Dad said. That quarterback would go on to set the N.F.L. record for passing interceptions.

headline: Officer’s Indictment Makes Good on Prosecutor’s Plea for Patience
abstract: Activists praised the murder indictment of Sgt. Hugh Barry as fulfilling a promise by the Bronx district attorney to fully investigate the killing of Deborah Danner in October.
lead_paragraph: A week after a New York City police sergeant shot and killed a woman who had a mental illness in her apartment last October, the Bronx district attorney, Darcel D. Clark, summoned more than two dozen members of the clergy and other community leaders to her office and urged them to give her a chance to investigate the case fully and to hold off on protests.

headline: The Problem With Participatory Democracy Is the Participants
abstract: Our politics are broken because of ordinary people who are doing it the wrong way.
lead_paragraph: At backyard barbecues this holiday weekend, liberals will gab with one another about how much time they’re spending on politics. More than ever, they are watching cable news, and refreshing Twitter and Facebook feeds.

headline: N.R.A. Ad Condemning Protests Against Trump Raises Partisan Anger
abstract: An advertisement for the National Rifle Association featuring Dana Loesch has become this week’s latest flash point for partisan anger.
lead_paragraph: An advertisement for the National Rifle Association that features a spokeswoman calling on the group’s supporters to strike back against protests by the left “with the clenched fist of truth” has become one of the latest flash points for partisan anger.

headline: Terrorist or Disturbed Loner? The Contentious Politics of a Label
abstract: Debate erupted over whether Monday’s attack near a London mosque would be labeled terrorism.
lead_paragraph: When a 48-year-old man rammed a van into a crowd near a London mosque on Monday morning, controversy quickly erupted over whether the attack would be treated as less significant than others because it was committed against Muslims but not by them.

headline: Civil Rights Groups Sue Chicago Over Abuses by Police
abstract: The lawsuit seeks sweeping changes to a police force with a well-documented pattern of excessive force and other misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Hoping to step into the breach left by the end of the Obama administration’s aggressive approach to civil rights abuses by the police, a coalition of civil rights groups filed a federal lawsuit against the City of Chicago on Wednesday.

headline: Megyn Kelly Calls Alex Jones’s Sandy Hook Denial ‘Revolting,’ but Still Plans to Air Interview
abstract: Ms. Kelly responded to criticism of her decision to feature Mr. Jones, who has called the 2012 Sandy Hook school massacre a hoax, on her news program.
lead_paragraph: A gun violence prevention organization named for the victims of the 2012 Sandy Hook school massacre has dropped Megyn Kelly of NBC as the host of its annual gala amid protests of Ms. Kelly’s upcoming interview with Alex Jones, the conspiracy theorist who says the shooting was a hoax.

headline: Tracing the Origins of the New York Police Department
abstract: In “Law and Disorder: The Chaotic Birth of the NYPD,” Bruce Chadwick reveals how incompetent constables, riots and rising crime convinced New Yorkers they needed an official police force.
lead_paragraph: LAW AND DISORDER The Chaotic Birth of the NYPD By Bruce Chadwick Illustrated. 368 pp. Thomas Dunne Books/ St. Martin’s Press. $28.99.

headline: A ‘Queen Sugar’ Rush Heralds a ‘Silver Age’ for African-American TV
abstract: Facing a television landscape more competitive than ever, OWN and BET have added creative ambition to their business models.
lead_paragraph: “Queen Sugar” wasted no time announcing its boldness. Debuting on the Oprah Winfrey Network last September, the very first scene of the series opened with a tight shot of Nova (Rutina Wesley) in bed. She was an image of African-American beauty rarely seen on television — flowing dreadlocks, a tattooed arm, and lean and muscular legs — while the cool tone of the lighting enhanced the richness of her dark brown skin.

headline: Milwaukee County Sheriff Says He Will Not Join Homeland Security Department
abstract: David A. Clarke Jr., an ardent supporter of President Trump, had claimed in May that he would accept a senior position with the agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David A. Clarke Jr., the polarizing Milwaukee County sheriff and a vocal supporter of President Trump, has said he would not accept a senior position that he had been offered at the Homeland Security Department.

headline: What Was Bill Maher’s Big Mistake?
abstract: The host of “Real Time With Bill Maher” overstepped his privilege as a famous comedian. That’s bad. But it’s not a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: I know what he meant. Lots of people know what he meant. Nonetheless, the thing about some jokes is that they’re open to interpretation, and the interpretation isn’t up to him.

headline: How Glenn Ligon Is Using Black and Blue to Begin a Dialogue
abstract: He has organized “Blue Black” at the Pulitzer Arts Foundation in St. Louis, hoping to spark discussion about power, spirituality and the blues.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning was the word: Fragments of prose by James Baldwin, jokes by Richard Pryor and, later, the testimony of a youth wrongly accused of a crime. All have served as the basis for Glenn Ligon’s series of text paintings and neons exploring race, identity, language and abstraction. Now an Ellsworth Kelly painting, “Blue Black” (2000), has become the departure point for Mr. Ligon’s latest project.

headline: Why Are So Many Young Voters Falling for Old Socialists?
abstract: People like Jeremy Corbyn and Bernie Sanders have carried the leftist torch in a long-distance relay. Now they’re handing it to the millennials.
lead_paragraph: At 68, Jeremy Corbyn has been on the Labour Party’s left flank longer than many of his most enthusiastic supporters — the ones who nearly propelled him to an upset victory in this month’s British general election — have been alive. Bernie Sanders, who won more votes from young people in the 2016 primaries than Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton combined, is 75, and has a demeanor that, honestly, reminds me of my Jewish grandfather. Jean-Luc Mélenchon, the Communist-backed candidate who, thanks to support from young people, surged in the polls ahead of the first round of France’s presidential election, is a sprightly 65.

headline: The Tupac Biopic: What Took So Long?
abstract: With skepticism from Hollywood and no support from the rapper’s estate, the makers of “All Eyez on Me” are under pressure to produce a hit.
lead_paragraph: Though he had been releasing music for only five years when he was killed in 1996 at age 25, Tupac Amaru Shakur’s surplus star power has fueled dozens of posthumous albums, books, documentaries, online conspiracy theories and even a short-lived Broadway musical. In recent years, he has popped up as a hologram in concert and as a guiding spirit on Kendrick Lamar’s “To Pimp a Butterfly”; in April, Shakur became the sixth rap act to be inducted into the Rock and Rock Hall of Fame. His relevance has rarely waned.

headline: 'Men Need to Step Up': Readers and Experts Reflect on Raising Feminist Boys
abstract: We invited readers to share their stories of raising boys to believe in the full equality of men and women. Here is a selection, with responses from experts in the field.
lead_paragraph: We invited readers to share their stories of raising boys to believe in the full equality of men and women. Here is a selection, with responses from experts in the field.

headline: The 25 Best Films of the 21st Century So Far.
abstract: A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis rank the best films made since 2000.
lead_paragraph: A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis rank the best films made since 2000.

headline: Attack Tests Movement Sanders Founded
abstract: The bloody shooting of Republican lawmakers by a Bernie Sanders supporter could prove to be an opportunity for the senator’s fans to consider their message.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most ardent supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders have long been outspoken about their anger toward Republicans — and in some cases toward Democrats. Their idol, the senator from Vermont, has called President Trump a “demagogue” and said recently that he was “perhaps the worst and most dangerous president in the history of our country.”

headline: What Can Queer and Dance Do for Each Other?
abstract: “What makes a dance queer?” was one of many questions considered at Explode! Queer Dance, a festival that brought together artists and academics.
lead_paragraph: As audience members took their seats for the final performance of Explode! Queer Dance on Saturday night, the choreographer, performer and dance scholar Thomas F. DeFrantz roamed among us, collecting suggestions.

headline: The Problem With Kaepernick’s Political Views: He Plays Football
abstract: If Colin Kaepernick were a professional basketball player instead of a football player, he might already have a job.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Colin Kaepernick is in the wrong league.

headline: Review: The Unspeakable Pain of an African-American Afterlife
abstract: In James Ijames’s play “Kill Move Paradise,” four young black men try — and fail — to understand how and why they died.
lead_paragraph: Many emotions vie for dominance among the young men living in limbo in “Kill Move Paradise,” the bleak and beautiful new drama by James Ijames at the National Black Theater in Harlem. Fear, rage, disgust, helplessness, a sardonic amusement and a sorrow beyond tears — these responses ebb and flow in a seemingly unending cycle during the show’s time-bending 80 minutes.

headline: Bill Maher Apologizes for Use of Racial Slur on ‘Real Time’
abstract: Mr. Maher and his guest, Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, were swiftly criticized on social media after Mr. Maher’s comments were broadcast.
lead_paragraph: The HBO late-night host Bill Maher apologized on Saturday for using a racial epithet during an interview with Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, on a live broadcast of his show on Friday night. HBO denounced the remark as “completely inexcusable and tasteless,” and said it would be edited out of future airings.

headline: Review: In BET’s ‘Tales,’ Rap Lyrics Get Lost in Translation
abstract: An anthology series based on hip-hop songs is an audacious idea, but the voice goes missing.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, Chuck D of the group Public Enemy called rap “the black CNN.” Now “Tales,” an anthology series beginning Tuesday on BET, asks if rap can also be HBO — a font of stories instead of headlines.

headline: Kylie and Kendall Jenner, Accused of Exploitation, Apologize for T-Shirts
abstract: The sisters recalled their “vintage” T-shirts, which had their images superimposed over musicians like Tupac Shakur, the Notorious B.I.G. and the Doors.
lead_paragraph: A T-shirt bearing an image of the hip-hop artist Tupac Shakur was briefly on sale this week. It featured his photograph in black and white, with two bright yellow letters, “kk,” splashed across his torso.

headline: He Sued Police 75 Times. Democrats Want Him as Philadelphia’s Top Prosecutor.
abstract: Larry Krasner, a civil rights lawyer who has been a police gadfly, is promising to hold fewer poor people in jail, prosecute fewer crimes and avoid the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Larry Krasner has sued the Philadelphia Police Department 75 times. He has promised not to seek the death penalty. He has even called law enforcement “systemically racist.”

headline: Why the Far Right Wants to Be the New ‘Alternative’ Culture
abstract: The hard-right fringe is billing itself as today’s “punk rock” counterculture — even as it gleefully seizes power and influence over the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: An always-useful thought experiment is to imagine seeing all the media around you for the first time — consciously, like a teenager freshly awakened to the existence of politics or an artificial intelligence that has just blinked across some humanoid threshold. This is especially handy lately, in our strange moment of flux. A wide-​eyed observer of today’s political media wouldn’t just see different voices and outlets with contrasting tendencies. It would see a disorienting game of rhetorical appropriation, in which it is constantly unclear who stands for which principles and why.

headline: Seattle Storm Take Progressive Tack With Planned Parenthood Partnership
abstract: The W.N.B.A. franchise, one of the few professional teams owned by women, will donate part of the proceeds from a July home game against the Chicago Sky to a chapter of the organization.
lead_paragraph: Professional sports teams work with other businesses and organizations all the time. But the W.N.B.A.’s Seattle Storm announced on Thursday that they were wading into the current political climate in a way that contrasts with the practices of many other sports teams: a partnership with Planned Parenthood.

headline: Black Queer Brooklyn on Film Focuses on Diverse Voices
abstract: A program of 16 shorts at the Brooklyn Museum showcases young and gender-nonconforming filmmakers producing work within the borough.
lead_paragraph: For those with a limited attention span or little time, short films can offer something appealing: brevity without necessarily sacrificing quality. Some short productions can peel back layers of emotion, stoke a discussion or propel the career of a budding director.

headline: Some Hires by Betsy DeVos Are a Stark Departure From Her Reputation
abstract: The education secretary, often criticized as an out-of-touch billionaire, has staffed her administration with a diverse set of subordinates, some from unlikely sources.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since her confirmation as the education secretary, Betsy DeVos has been the Trump cabinet member liberals love to hate, denouncing her as an out-of-touch, evangelical billionaire without the desire or capacity to protect vulnerable poor, black, immigrant, gay or transgender students.

headline: The Democratic Party Is in Worse Shape Than You Thought
abstract: Declining turnout among minority, young and single voters is even more dangerous for Democrats than white flight.
lead_paragraph: Sifting through the wreckage of the 2016 election, Democratic pollsters, strategists and sympathetic academics have reached some unnerving conclusions.

headline: Religious Liberals Sat Out of Politics for 40 Years. Now They Want in the Game.
abstract: Faith leaders whose politics fall to the left of center are getting more involved in politics to fight against President Trump’s policies.
lead_paragraph: In Nashville, a crowd of ministers carrying palm fronds occupied the governor’s office during Holy Week, demanding the expansion of Medicaid to cover more of the uninsured. In California and 16 other states, an interfaith network has organized thousands of volunteers to swoop into action when immigrants are arrested or houses of worship are vandalized.

headline: Columbia’s New Harlem Museum Opens, With Art From Its Neighbors
abstract: “Uptown” inaugurates the Wallach Art Gallery’s new home in a Renzo Piano building, the fraternal twin of the Whitney.
lead_paragraph: New York, New York, is the city so nice it got two of everything: two baseball teams, two decrepit airports and now two riverside art galleries designed by the Italian architect Renzo Piano. His Whitney Museum of American Art has packed in visitors since the spring of 2015, spellbound as much by its balconies and switchback staircases as by its light-filled, column-free galleries. Now it has a fraternal twin a hundred blocks north: the Lenfest Center for the Arts, which serves as a new hub for Columbia University’s art, film, theater and writing programs. Both rise eight stories beside the Hudson River, though the Lenfest is a bit farther inland. To reach the Whitney, you walk past former meatpacking warehouses that now sell thousand-dollar cashmere sweaters; the Lenfest, for its part, is a stone’s throw from that Fairway with the walk-in freezer.

headline: Reality Winner, N.S.A. Contractor Accused of Leak, Was Undone by Trail of Clues
abstract: Reality Leigh Winner expressed outraged political views on social media after President Trump was elected, suggesting a possible motive for leaking classified material.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the months after President Trump was elected, Reality Leigh Winner frequently expressed outraged political views about him on social media, in between photos of her cats and favorite quotations. But on the afternoon of May 9, she posted an unusually anodyne message on Facebook, noting that she would be teaching two yoga classes that evening.

headline: New York City and James Blake Resolve Excessive-Force Claim
abstract: As part of the deal with the former pro tennis player, the city will create a new position within the agency that investigates police misconduct.
lead_paragraph: James Blake, a retired tennis star, had the makings of a lucrative lawsuit when a New York City police officer roughed him up two years ago: vivid surveillance video, the officer’s history of force complaints, and hasty apologies from the mayor and the police commissioner. But Mr. Blake spurned a potential payout from the city for a less orthodox resolution: The city is set to announce on Wednesday that it will create a legal fellowship in Mr. Blake’s name within the agency that investigates police misconduct.

headline: Embracing What’s Natural
abstract: Why some women go back to their roots
lead_paragraph: This week we’re turning over the Race/Related newsletter to participants in The New York Times Student Journalism Institute.

headline: The Unexpected Afterlife of American Communism
abstract: Although grass-roots activists have long been painted as alien agitators, a proud homegrown tradition persists.
lead_paragraph: The Communist, in the American imagination, has always been the ultimate outside agitator.

headline: Tell Us Your Stories From the Newark Riots
abstract: Five decades after the Newark riots, The Times wants to hear from those who lived in Newark at the time or were otherwise affected by what happened.
lead_paragraph: Next month, 50 years will have passed since a violent uprising erupted in Newark, fueled by the anger of many black residents over police brutality, racism and corruption, as well as a broader sense of disenfranchisement. Over several days in July 1967, more than 20 people were killed and hundreds were injured.

headline: Trumpocalypse: The End Game
abstract: Our once bright and shiny democracy may be going down the drain before the holidays are out.
lead_paragraph: You can see where this is headed, the once bright and shiny democracy going down the drain before the holidays are out. The Russians, the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III and his agents, desperate men flipped and singing to save their souls — all may soon be gone, by President Trump’s design.

headline: Propane, Peapods and Perplexities
abstract: In “Vacationland,” John Hodgman wrestles with the comic trials of home ownership in Maine and Massachusetts, along with the indignities of middle age.
lead_paragraph: VACATIONLANDTrue Stories From Painful BeachesBy John Hodgman257 pp. Viking. $25.

headline: Gateway Pundit Writer Will Not Face Charge in UConn Scuffle
abstract: Lucian Wintrich was arrested in November after a scuffle with a woman who took papers from his lectern.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors have dropped the breach of peace charge against Lucian Wintrich, the conservative pundit who grabbed a woman after she took papers from his podium during an appearance last month at the University of Connecticut, his lawyer said on Monday.

headline: A Look at the Heart-Wrenching Moments From Equal Rights Battles
abstract: All the major battles for equal rights — racial, ethnic, gender, sexual orientation, disability — are explored in “The Good Fight.”
lead_paragraph: The 54-mile march for voting rights from Selma to Alabama’s state capital, Montgomery, took more than good legs and sturdy shoes. It took defying the police, who ambushed hundreds of men, women and children — on a bridge named for a Klu Klux Klan leader — and beat them bloody. It took a court order and it took journalists covering the struggles to tell and shock the world.

headline: Kaepernick vs. the N.F.L.: A Primer on His Collusion Case
abstract: Colin Kaepernick has filed a grievance accusing the league of colluding to keep him out of work because of national anthem protests he inspired.
lead_paragraph: As protests by N.F.L. players during the national anthem seem to have settled down, the grievance case against the league by the man who started it all, the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick, is proceeding.

headline: Past Debates Echo in Split Between Cornel West and Ta-Nehisi Coates
abstract: There was no Twitter to fan the flames when W.E.B. Du Bois sparred with Booker T. Washington and Malcolm X argued with Martin Luther King Jr.
lead_paragraph: For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.

headline: Trump, Rejecting Calls to Stay Away, Speaks at Civil Rights Museum
abstract: In Jackson, Miss., the president hailed heroes of the civil rights movement even as activists and politicians said his presence insulted the effort to confront the state’s history.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — President Trump’s presence jolted the opening of a civil rights museum here on Saturday, generating boycotts from some leaders in the movement and small protests by activists as the state’s attempt to confront its racially violent past clashed with more recent divisions wrought by Mr. Trump’s presidency.

headline: From Ancient Myths to Modern Day, Women and the Struggle for Power
abstract: In “Women & Power: A Manifesto,” the Cambridge classicist Mary Beard describes the scale of the problem and suggests some exciting remedies.
lead_paragraph: According to Aristotle, women’s voices were proof of their wickedness. Virtue expressed itself in deep, full-throated sounds — the noise of the lion, the bull and (no surprise here) the human male. Women’s speech, however, its pitch and prattle, was considered dangerous, even unsanitary. The very sound of their voices, it was believed, could sink the state.

headline: Making It Relevant: Helping Students Connect Their Studies to the World Today
abstract: Four ideas for showing how the themes, issues, questions and ideas students explore in school play out in the news and in our culture.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Dec. 6, 2018: We originally created this lesson plan to accompany the first year of our Connections Contest. We have just announced this year’s contest, and updated all related links below. For more inspiration, please take a look at the work of the 2017-18 winners.

headline: Papa John’s Chief Executive to Step Down, Weeks After Blaming N.F.L. for Sales Slump
abstract: John Schnatter will be replaced in January by the company’s chief operating officer. In November, Mr. Schnatter blamed a decline in sales on national anthem protests.
lead_paragraph: The pizza franchise Papa John’s announced Thursday that its chief executive, who recently blamed the National Football League’s handling of the national anthem controversy for the company’s declining sales, will step down from the position at the end of the month.

headline: France Fails to Face Up to Racism
abstract: The Macron government caves in and ousts a critic of police brutality.
lead_paragraph: Rokhaya Diallo is a French journalist whose most noted work addresses a concept that doesn’t officially exist in France.

headline: Fingerprints of Russian Disinformation: From AIDS to Fake News
abstract: In the 1980s, the Soviets peddled “bum dope about AIDS” around the world. Moscow’s tactics haven’t changed much in the years since.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The spurious story line alarmed Americans. It spread like wildfire, distorting facts into outlandish fictions, despite being attributed only to obscure sources. And it inflamed already divisive politics before the United States government concluded — perhaps too late — that it was a Russian disinformation campaign.

headline: Roy Moore Drowns Us Out
abstract: He is a symbol of the way injustices fester and grow.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — At every home game at the University of Alabama, where I am a sophomore, the fraternities sit in a reserved corner of the stadium. My freshman year, they wore Trump stickers. This year, they traded them in for Roy Moore-style white cowboy hats.

headline: Kirsten Gillibrand, Long a Champion of Women, Finds the Nation Joining Her
abstract: Ms. Gillibrand, a senator from New York, has seen her rising star lifted higher by her run-ins with President Trump over his treatment of women.
lead_paragraph: For much of the year, Kirsten Gillibrand’s critics — sensing a presidential aspirant in their midst — had assumed that the New York senator could not hear enough about herself. For one day at least, it appeared she had.

headline: ‘I’d Never Seen My Fears as an African-American Man Onscreen’
abstract: Jordan Peele, writer-director of “Get Out,” says his own concerns almost prevented it from being made. Now prize givers love it. Will the academy agree?
lead_paragraph: “Get Out,” the box office smash and awards season honey, almost didn’t get made, because its writer and director Jordan Peele figured it couldn’t happen.

headline: Erica Garner, Activist and Daughter of Eric Garner, Dies at 27
abstract: Ms. Garner, whose father died in 2014 after being put in a police chokehold, was a prominent critic of policing tactics.
lead_paragraph: Erica Garner, the daughter of Eric Garner who became an outspoken activist against police brutality after her father’s death at the hands of a New York police officer, died on Saturday, according to her mother. She was 27.

headline: Trump’s Racist Tweets. My Growing Patriotism.
abstract: The upside to him attacking outspoken black people? We can fight back and declare what America really stands for.
lead_paragraph: It has been a busy presidency for Donald Trump, who, between absorbing huge doses of Fox News directly into his veins and taking numerous trips to his golf courses, somehow finds time to promote a tax bill that would disembowel the middle class and to attack prominent black people via tweets.

headline: Who’s Winning the Culture War? Corporate America
abstract: The realignment of our parties by region has left a bigger imprint on economic policy than on cultural issues.
lead_paragraph: At the 1992 Republican National Convention, Pat Buchanan famously declared that American politics had become a “cultural war.” In the years since, social issues and identities have become more important in dividing Democrats from Republicans.

headline: Stephen Colbert Was ‘Like an Alien’ Before He Was Famous, Louis C.K. Says
abstract: Louis C.K. reminded the “Late Show” host that before he was the “king of the late-night” shows, he was just a quirky guy.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Power and Punishment: Two New Books About Race and Crime
abstract: James Forman Jr.’s “Locking Up Our Own” and Chris Hayes’s “A Colony in a Nation” compel readers to wrestle with very tough questions about racism, inequality and punishment.
lead_paragraph: (“Locking Up Our Own: Crime and Punishment in Black America” by James Forman Jr. was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2017. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Black and Proud. Even if Strangers Can’t Tell.
abstract: “You’re so lucky,” my son said to me. “People look at you and know that you are black.”
lead_paragraph: My 11-year-old is understated, but not shy. He likes to bake, loves video games, is loyal to his friends and, biased as I may be, is a pretty good-looking kid. He gets mad sometimes, though, that people don’t immediately register him as black. “You’re so lucky,” he said to me a few months ago. “People look at you and know that you are black.”

headline: Beyoncé’s Pregnancy Photographer Is Opening an ‘Anti-Trump’ Art Show
abstract: The artist Awol Erizku is opening his first solo show in Europe with his most political work to date.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — By one measure of success, the 28-year-old artist Awol Erizku has possibly already peaked. In February he was revealed to be the photographer behind Beyoncé’s pregnancy announcement, which quickly became the most popular Instagram post ever with over 10 million likes.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: March 2017
abstract: Our roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the March 2017 edition of Teenagers in The Times, our monthly roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. You can find our next installment on May 5.

headline: A Pepsi Commercial’s Lesson for Advertisers
abstract: It’s no surprise that co-opting a cause for marketing went terribly wrong.
lead_paragraph: Pepsi on Wednesday pulled a disastrous advertisement after it was met with widespread ridicule. Titled “Jump In,” the two-and-a-half minute spot was full of clumsy, glib references to police brutality and Black Lives Matter protests. Nearly every tone-deaf frame has become a mocking meme. And the commercial (Pepsi calls it a “short film”) drew the most intense disgust from the very people whose experiences it tried to reflect.

headline: ‘It Did Not Stick’: The First Federal Effort to Curb Police Abuse
abstract: In 1997, the Justice Department entered its first consent decree, with the Pittsburgh police. Nineteen cities later, it has learned from its mistakes.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Federal intervention to curb police abuse did not begin after chants of “I can’t breathe,” viral cellphone videos or the Black Lives Matter movement.

headline: New York Today: Taxpayer Questions, C.P.A. Answers
abstract: Tuesday: Tax questions common in New York, radiant weather, and staying safe from security scams.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:38 a.m.

headline: An Ad Woman at the Top of an Industry That She Thinks Still Has Far to Go
abstract: Carol H. Williams, who was behind major campaigns for Pillsbury, Secret and Disney, will be only the second black woman in the Advertising Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Carol H. Williams started working in the advertising business in 1969, when young African-American women like her were a rarity in the industry.

headline: The Real Reason Black Kids Benefit From Black Teachers
abstract: Outside the classroom, we inhabit the same world.
lead_paragraph: For black students, having even one black teacher can make a huge difference. That’s the conclusion of a new study, which found that that black boys who had a black teacher during their elementary school years were less likely to drop out of high school. It also linked the presence of black teachers to kids’ expectations of attending college.

headline: Reviews: Abundant Tap Talent and Doug Varone After 30 Years
abstract: Our dance critic on the “Rhythm in Motion” tap showcase at the Duke on 42nd Street, and Doug Varone and Dancers’ 30th-anniversary season at BAM.
lead_paragraph: RHYTHM IN MOTION

headline: America, From Exceptionalism to Nihilism
abstract: The U.S. leads the free world in its helplessness before the dissolution of its most cherished values.
lead_paragraph: MASHOBRA, India — “The world is going America’s way,” Fareed Zakaria wrote in 2008. “Countries are becoming more open, market friendly and democratic.” Since the fall of communism, American leaders in politics, business and journalism have repeatedly broadcast the conceit that we live, or will soon live, in the best of all possible worlds. Not even 9/11, the bloody stalemates in Iraq and Afghanistan or the worst economic crisis since the Depression challenged faith in a benignly Americanized world. Barack Obama declared last year that “if you had to choose any time in the course of human history to be alive, you’d choose this one. Right here in America, right now.”

headline: Beyoncé 3.0: The Maternal Ideal
abstract: By making her pregnancy a dazzling performance, is the singer raising the bar too high?
lead_paragraph: She may have dropped out of headlining Coachella this month because of her pregnancy, but Beyoncé has not dropped out of public life. Instead, she has swapped a festival stage for an Instagram stage, and so — just in time for what would have been her second concert performance — she released a performance of a different kind: a photo shoot showcasing not her songs but her stomach, framed by a batwing tunic, over-the-knee suede boots and mirrored glasses. Followed shortly thereafter by a white-gowned Easter extravaganza.

headline: Syria, Stephen Bannon, Pepsi: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Berkeley Is Being Tested on 2 Fronts: Free Speech and Safety
abstract: The university that championed free speech in the 1960s has become known as a meeting ground for those wanting to express themselves with wooden clubs and fists.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — In explaining why it had canceled a speech by Ann Coulter scheduled for next week, the University of California, Berkeley, said that it had “very specific intelligence” that Ms. Coulter might be in “grave danger.”

headline: Ferguson Re-Elects White Mayor 2 Years After Mike Brown Incident
abstract: A national movement for racial justice flared in the predominantly black Missouri city after a white police officer shot Michael Brown. But few people voted.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — When a national movement for racial justice flared here two and a half years ago, activists nationwide hoped to upend the political order. Ferguson was one of many predominantly black communities across the country that were under white control, and they strategized about ways to change that.

headline: The Ramapoughs vs. the World
abstract: Will an oil pipeline proposed for tribal lands destroy the Ramapough Lenape Nation along the New Jersey-New York border? Or will it be the catalyst that once again unites the tribe?
lead_paragraph: The phone rang in his study and Dwaine Perry answered with the weary resignation of a man who knew what was coming. The sun was setting on a late March evening as Mr. Perry listened to the voice on the other end of the line. “Go on,” he said, drooping his chin into his neck. Then came an extended pause, followed by a well-practiced recital of sympathies and condolences. “Well, I’ll get to work,” he finally said before hanging up. Time to plan another funeral.

headline: Syria, Stephen Bannon, Pink Star: Your Morning Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: In ‘Black Power!,’ Art’s Political Punch and Populist Reach
abstract: An exhibition at the New York Public Library’s Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem chronicles the history of a dynamic movement.
lead_paragraph: Given the economic, environmental and social policies emanating from the White House, the United States could be headed for its most dynamic era of public resistance since the 1960s, one for which the Women’s March last winter was just a warm-up. Such an era would demand fresh developments in political art, meaning art with a populist reach. Where will that come from?

headline: XOXO Campaign: Will It Spell Profit or Trouble for Condom Maker?
abstract: In a time when social media outrage can be prompted with one misstep, Trojan is unveiling an ad campaign directed at women.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a sensible advertising strategy. When a company discovered that women accounted for less than one-third of the purchases of its products, it shifted direction to appeal more directly to them.

headline: Nivea Pulls ‘White Is Purity’ Ad After Online Uproar
abstract: Nivea, again accused of racial insensitivity, halted a campaign promoting its Invisible For Black & White deodorant.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The skin care brand Nivea set off a controversy this week with an ad featuring the phrase “White is purity,” again finding itself accused of racial insensitivity over a campaign that seemed to be embraced by white supremacists.

headline: In Ann Coulter’s Speech Battle, Signs That Conservatives Are Emboldened
abstract: Conservatives like Ms. Coulter are eagerly throwing themselves into volatile situations on college campuses, inspired by a backlash against political correctness.
lead_paragraph: Without uttering a word to students at the University of California, Berkeley, Ann Coulter on Wednesday made herself the latest cause célèbre in the rapidly escalating effort by conservatives to fight liberals on what was once the left’s moral high ground over free speech on campus.

headline: Trump, Syria, Pepsi: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: An Artist’s Mythic Rebellion for the Venice Biennale
abstract: Mark Bradford’s concern: How can he represent the United States when he no longer feels represented by his government?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Mark Bradford, one of America’s most acclaimed painters, could not figure out what to put in the grand rotunda.

headline: ‘Locking Up Our Own,’ What Led to Mass Incarceration of Black Men
abstract: James Forman Jr. examines how people, acting with the best intentions, could create a problem even more devastating than the one they were trying to solve.
lead_paragraph: LOCKING UP OUR OWNCrime and Punishment in Black AmericaBy James Forman Jr.Illustrated. 306 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $27.

headline: Battling to Save James Baldwin’s Home in the South of France
abstract: Alarmed by a plan to turn the former home of this American writer into apartments, a group dedicated to building a writers’ retreat runs afoul of the Baldwin family.
lead_paragraph: SAINT-PAUL-DE-VENCE, France — From 1970 until his death in 1987, James Baldwin lived and wrote in a house with an idyllic garden in this medieval village on the Côte d’Azur, with the Alps at its back and the Mediterranean visible far below.

headline: What ‘Snowflakes’ Get Right About Free Speech
abstract: Campus protests against speakers like Richard Spencer are not censorship. They help secure the basic rights of others.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to add a disclaimer.

headline: Mud-Smeared Jeans? (Things May Get Messy)
abstract: Social media users sounded off on denim pants and a jacket that come pre-stained and sell for $425 each.
lead_paragraph: April has been a cruel month for big brands trying to look cool.

headline: A How-to Book for Wielding Civic Power
abstract: Want to instigate change? Form or join a club, know the issues, gather money and allies, and exercise your political muscle.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the RAND Survey Research Group asked 3,037 Americans about their political preferences and found that the factor that best predicted support for Donald Trump wasn’t age, race, gender, income, educational attainment or attitudes toward Muslims or undocumented immigrants. It was whether respondents agreed with the statement “People like me don’t have any say about what the government does.”

headline: Pepsi Pulls Ad Accused of Trivializing Black Lives Matter
abstract: The beverage company apologized for an ad featuring Kendall Jenner giving a smiling officer a soda at a protest.
lead_paragraph: Pepsi has apologized for a controversial advertisement that borrowed imagery from the Black Lives Matter movement, after a day of intense criticism from people who said it trivialized the widespread protests against the killings of black people by the police.

headline: ‘Encyclopedic’ Brooklyn Museum Vies for Contemporary Attention
abstract: The myriad challenges for Anne Pasternak, director of this institution, include remaining true to Brooklyn’s identity while embracing a shift in trends.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn’s time may have come. But what of the Brooklyn Museum’s?

headline: United and Pepsi Affairs Force Brands to Respect Social Media
abstract: The potential perils that come with broad access to consumers have led companies to take it very seriously.
lead_paragraph: When Jason Marker, the new chief executive of the company that owns Carl’s Jr. and Hardee’s, met with several of his marketing executives this week, one of his first requests was for screens to be installed in the company’s headquarters to display real-time social media conversations about its brands.

headline: Officer’s Confrontation With a Pedestrian, Caught on Video, Spurs Investigations
abstract: Sacramento police have placed the unidentified white officer on leave after releasing videos that show him repeatedly striking a black man.
lead_paragraph: It began innocuously enough.

headline: 28 Ways to Teach and Learn About Poetry With The New York Times
abstract: Ideas for helping even the most verse averse find something to enjoy.
lead_paragraph: We go hard for National Poetry Month here on The Learning Network, and as The Times keeps publishing news and features about poetry and poets, we keep adding more and more ways to teach about it — during April or any other month.

headline: Police Unions Hail Trump’s Easing of Scrutiny. Local Officials Worry.
abstract: While mayors and police chiefs welcome federal oversight of the police, unions say it keeps officers from doing their jobs and makes the public less safe.
lead_paragraph: Black pedestrians in Baltimore stopped without reasonable suspicion. Black drivers in Ferguson, Mo., searched much more frequently than whites. Cleveland residents punched and kicked by officers and subjected to stun guns, without posing any threat.

headline: South L.A. Revisited, 25 Years After the Rodney King Riots
abstract: The unrest I reported on in 1992 is a distant memory. But resentment still smolders here.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a corner of this city where stores burned, and rocks flew through windows, I found a garden growing.

headline: Review: 3 Anniversary Programs Look at Los Angeles in Flames
abstract: A&E, Showtime and the Smithsonian Channel reflect on the moment in 1992 when the Rodney King verdict set off a wave of violence.
lead_paragraph: If any anniversary should still resonate today, it’s the one surrounding the verdicts in the beating of Rodney G. King 25 years ago this month and the events that followed. Three television specials in the next few days revisit that dismaying moment in American history, but all seem reluctant to spend much time exploring the connections between 1992 and more recent headline-making events in various cities that have left black residents dead. Maybe the producers felt they’d be stating the obvious; maybe they were just seduced by the fascinating but oft-told tales from 1992. Either way, it leaves the specials feeling incomplete.

headline: ‘The Good Fight’ Season 1, Episode 9: Blinding Privilege
abstract: Maia proves to be a character with no moral center or desires of her own.
lead_paragraph: Memory is unreliable. It is colored by emotions, shaped by biology and underscored by morality. The memories you carry aren’t so much unvarnished facts as they are the truth you believe in. The fact that memory is so mutable isn’t always a problem. But it becomes one for Maia on this week’s episode of “The Good Fight,” as she learns quite painfully that her unreliable memory and lack of self-preservation are damning qualities.

headline: Syria, Pepsi, Stephen Bannon: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: American Poets, Refusing to Go Gentle, Rage Against the Right
abstract: Like virtually everything else in the Trump era, poetry has gotten sharply political these days.
lead_paragraph: The poet Jane Hirshfield has never thought of herself as an agitator. A self-described “genuine introvert,” Ms. Hirshfield likes to spend her days gardening, hiking and writing verses about nature, impermanence and interconnectedness.

headline: The Playlist: Nicki Minaj Strikes Back, and Fleet Foxes Return With a Folky Epic
abstract: Listen to 13 of the week's most notable new tracks, from Lorde's "Liability" to San Fermin's "Belong."
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

headline: The Horror of Smug Liberals
abstract: An ingenious movie takes bloody issue with the idea of a postracial America.
lead_paragraph: Oh, those smooth-talking, self-congratulating white liberals. Listen to them moon over Barack Obama. Look at how widely they open their arms to a black visitor. Don’t be duped. They’re wolves in L. L. Bean clothing. There’s danger under the fleece.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates on Creating Black Superheroes
abstract: Mr. Coates, the author of “Between the World and Me,” talks about his Black Panther comic books and a new series set in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: When Marvel Comics announced in September 2015 that Ta-Nehisi Coates would be writing a new Black Panther series, the timing could not have been more fortuitous. That same month, Mr. Coates, who writes regularly for The Atlantic, was awarded a John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation “genius grant,” and, two months later, a National Book Award for nonfiction for “Between the World and Me,” his passionate letter to his son about being black in America.

headline: Why the Whitney’s Humanist, Pro-Diversity Biennial Is a Revelation
abstract: This much-anticipated show displays a strength and focus doubly important when art and the humanities seem under attack in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Since moving downtown, the Whitney Museum of American Art has grown up, thanks to a larger, dashing new building, more ambitious exhibitions and new responsibilities brought by rising attendance and membership. No surprise, its biennial has grown up, too. Perhaps less expected: So has the art in it. This show’s strength and focus make it doubly important at a time when art, the humanities and the act of thinking itself seem under attack in Washington.

headline: France Investigating Police Killing of Chinese Man in Paris
abstract: An officer fatally shot the man, Liu Shaoyo, 56, at his home on Sunday amid murky circumstances, setting off violent protests.
lead_paragraph: The French authorities confirmed on Tuesday that they were investigating the fatal shooting by the police of a Chinese man at his home in Paris during the weekend. A lawyer for the man’s family said the killing was not justified, and the Chinese government called for a thorough investigation.

headline: ‘Zoot Suit’ Draws Crowds and Decked-Out Fans in Los Angeles
abstract: Some of the musical’s most devoted fans are showing up to the performances dressed in zoot suits and vintage attire. We spoke to some of them to find out what the Chicano play means to them.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When “Zoot Suit” made its debut in New York in 1979, it was the first time a Chicano show had made it to Broadway. But the musical, by Luis Valdez, was a distinctly Los Angeles production: It was commissioned by the Mark Taper Forum and portrayed a 1940s murder trial involving zoot-suit-wearing Mexican-American youths known as pachucos. The trial is set against the backdrop of the infamous Zoot Suit riots, a series of racially motivated attacks against Mexican-Americans in summer 1943.

headline: White Artist’s Painting of Emmett Till at Whitney Biennial Draws Protests
abstract: The canvas, based on open-coffin photographs of the 1955 lynching victim, speaks to the images’ power to address race and violence.
lead_paragraph: The open-coffin photographs of the mutilated body of Emmett Till, the teenager who was lynched by two white men in Mississippi in 1955, served as a catalyst for the civil rights movement and have remained an open wound in American society since they were first published in Jet magazine and The Chicago Defender at the urging of Till’s mother.

headline: ‘The Good Fight’ Season 1, Episode 6: Potency and Perspective
abstract: “The Good Fight” is at its most political and confounding this week.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, Joss Whedon’s genre bending, pop feminist masterwork “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” aired “The Zeppo” in Season 3. The episode had several of the qualities that made the series an enduring cult hit, with one noticeable difference: It was told from the perspective of a sidekick, Xander Harris (Nicholas Brendon). Giving Xander his own adventure separate from the rest of the cast gave viewers a new prism through which to filter “Buffy”’s potent ideas. “The Zeppo” illustrates how different a show can be when a character that exists in the margins is brought to the center. Watching Sunday’s episode of “The Good Fight,” I couldn’t help but wonder how different an episode would be if it took on the perspective of one of the black members of the firm. If any character on “The Good Fight” deserves its very own “Zeppo” episode, it’s Barbara.

headline: The Image of Emmett Till
abstract: What would his mother have thought of the painting at the Whitney Biennial?
lead_paragraph: With all the controversy surrounding the painting of Emmett Till’s mutilated remains at the Whitney Biennial, one important voice is missing from the dialogue. What would Mamie Till-Mobley, Emmett’s mother, have to say about a white artist’s rendering of the iconic Jet magazine coffin photograph of her son, a 14-year-old African-American from Chicago who was lynched while visiting relatives in Mississippi in 1955?

headline: Review: ‘Shots Fired’ Complicates Black, White and Blue
abstract: This new Fox drama centers on the repercussions of the shooting of a white youth by a black sheriff’s deputy in a North Carolina town.
lead_paragraph: The debate over police violence in America is often framed as Black Lives Matter versus Blue Lives Matter. “Shots Fired,” a new 10-episode series on Wednesdays on Fox, starts with a shooter whose life is both black and blue.

headline: What Racial Terms Make You Cringe?
abstract: A shortlist of the Race/Related team’s least favorite phrases.
lead_paragraph: This is a version of the weekly Race/Related newsletter. To get it in your inbox, sign up here.

headline: Unity, Instead of Fear, After Swastikas Are Carved Into a Church Door
abstract: Speculation persists as to the reason Fourth Universalist on Central Park West was the target of a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve done a pretty good job of covering them up,” the Rev. Schuyler Vogel said.

headline: ‘The Good Fight’ Season 1, Episode 4: Body Politics
abstract: The politics and legality concerning the black body creates the show’s most moving episode yet.
lead_paragraph: As a child I learned early and often the value of the black body in American culture. Black music, style, cuisine and literature have great worth both financially and artistically. But the black people that create these works are often treated with little humanity, a fact inadvertently highlighted by “La La Land,” with its treatment of jazz and near lack of black characters.

headline: Baltimoreans Mourn a Man Said to Have Been Killed by Their Neighbor
abstract: The murder of a black man in New York reminds a Baltimore neighborhood of its own complicated racial history.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Under a gloomy sky, a crowd of a few dozen people assembled in the yard outside a stone church, a mostly white group who carried posters and wore T-shirts with messages like “Black Lives Matter,” “Stay Woke” and, simply, “BMORE Kind.” They had come on a Saturday evening to mourn a man they did not know, killed some 200 miles from here.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: This week, we’ve got a number of books on our list that are certain to get people talking. Cordelia Fine’s latest, “Testosterone Rex,” addresses head on some of the sexism that poses as neuroscience. Barry Friedman’s important new book, “Unwarranted,” takes on the volatile question of how to address abusive policing. And Angie Thomas’s “The Hate U Give” offers teenage readers a way to look at the Black Lives Matter movement. For sheer fun and entertainment? I recommend Bill Schutt’s “Cannibalism.” As readers will discover, that’s not as strange as it sounds. Bon appetit.

headline: Colin Kaepernick Is Unemployed. Is It Because of His Arm, or His Knee?
abstract: Other quarterbacks, perhaps lesser ones, have landed spots on N.F.L. rosters. Some wonder if Kaepernick’s protests have kept teams away.
lead_paragraph: Mark Sanchez found a job. Mike Glennon found a job. So did Josh McCown and E. J. Manuel.

headline: A Brooklyn Charter School Looks Past ‘No Excuses’
abstract: The Ascend Public Charter Schools network tries doing away with unforgiving disciplinary codes.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, while reporting on the difficulties of life in Brownsville, Brooklyn, one of the poorest neighborhoods in New York, I met a school administrator named Marsha Gadsden who worked for the Ascend Public Charter Schools network. Ms. Gadsden had grown up not far away, attended prep school on a scholarship and later went to Georgetown and Harvard, and she told me she worried about the unforgiving disciplinary codes used by her employer and so many urban charter schools around the country.

headline: Three Iconic Musicians on Artistic Creation — and Its Importance Now
abstract: Beck, Kendrick Lamar and Tom Waits articulate the creative impulse.
lead_paragraph: LATE LAST YEAR, a week before his final record was released and not quite four weeks before he died, Leonard Cohen held a press conference at the Canadian consulate in Los Angeles. Dapper in a dark suit, seeking support in his seat from a cane, the 82-year-old fielded questions. With a wit and candor and gentleness and wisdom that felt extraterrestrial, he spoke as though he’d traveled here from a civilization more advanced than our own to offer us a few gifts that could ensure the survival of our species. Near the end, there was a kind of apotheosis. A Japanese reporter asked Cohen about one of the lyrics from the new record’s title song, “You Want It Darker,” in which Cohen sing-speaks, “Hineni, hineni, I’m ready my Lord.”

headline: New Crop of Young Adult Novels Explores Race and Police Brutality
abstract: A new generation of authors is embracing writing as activism, tackling issues like racial bias, police violence and the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: Angie Thomas started writing her young-adult novel, “The Hate U Give,” in reaction to a fatal shooting that took place some 2,000 miles away. But to her it felt deeply personal.

headline: ‘The Good Fight’ Season 1, Episode 7 Recap: Quandaries
abstract: Maia’s divided loyalties control the future of Reddick, Boseman & Kolstad.
lead_paragraph: Familial bonds are often the trickiest ones to navigate. But as Maia learns, family need not be made up of one’s actual relations. This week’s episode of “The Good Fight” is full of clever twists and scintillating reveals, all of which work to break down Maia’s illusions about the privileged life her parents have swaddled her in. On one hand, this finally integrates her more fully within the culture of her new firm, which she has felt disconnected from despite the fact that her presence has been a disruptive one. On the other hand, there is something disturbing about the way Mike Kresteva’s witch hunt against Reddick, Boseman & Kolstad primarily circles around the white characters rather than the black lawyers who have built the firm from the ground up. That Barbara and Boseman — both finely acted characters — remain ciphers mars an otherwise stellar episode.

headline: Museums Tell Teenagers: We’re Here for You
abstract: In a growing movement, museums nationwide are offering programs for adolescents that let them explore challenging subjects, sometimes working directly with artists.
lead_paragraph: Elkeyshia Webster, 11, had no interest in going to a program at the Pérez Art Museum Miami on a Saturday when she could be home, watching TV. And she was particularly angry when she found out that the event involved working with the police.

headline: Kamasi Washington Follows ‘The Epic’ With a New Work in Whitney Biennial
abstract: The saxophonist discusses “Harmony of Difference,” a piece accompanied by video from A.G. Rojas, in this preview of the show.
lead_paragraph: For two years the tenor saxophonist Kamasi Washington has ridden on the strength of “The Epic,” his hit triple album from 2015, playing almost 200 concerts last year and cementing a level of cultural prominence rarely afforded to jazz musicians.

headline: Review: In BET’s Police Drama ‘Rebel,’ Blaxploitation Matters
abstract: Is it too soon? John Singleton’s new series makes pulp fiction out of polarizing issues.
lead_paragraph: A young, unarmed black man is gunned down by the police. A black officer is implicated, the force is divided along color lines, the news media descends. Just a week after the premiere of “Shots Fired” on Fox, here comes another topical series about race and police brutality.

headline: Stop Beating Black Children
abstract: By hitting our kids, we are serving the goals and carrying on the legacy of white supremacy.
lead_paragraph: “This is gonna hurt me more than it hurts you.”

headline: ‘Four Days That Changed the World’: Unintended Consequences of a Women’s Rights Conference
abstract: “Divided We Stand” by Marjorie J. Spruill recalls a 1977 women’s rights conference that ended up energizing the anti-feminist opposition.
lead_paragraph: DIVIDED WE STANDThe Battle Over Women’s Rights and Family Values That Polarized American PoliticsBy Marjorie J. SpruillIllustrated. 436 pp. Bloomsbury. $33.

headline: From Raising Consciousness to Raising Hell
abstract: Activism today is “still women sitting in a circle with each other.”
lead_paragraph: ELLISVILLE, Mo. — They called it consciousness-raising.

headline: How Egypt’s Activists Became ‘Generation Jail’
abstract: Six years after the Arab Spring, the country’s democracy activists live under constant threat of prison — or worse.
lead_paragraph: Every morning at 5:30, an alarm clock awakens Ahmed Maher from his mattress below a stairwell at his neighborhood police station in Cairo. An officer then escorts him to the toilet and signs a notebook that Maher carries, authorizing his release until 6 that evening. Maher walks a mile to his apartment — “It is my only exercise,” he said — in the Third Settlement, a grid of dun-colored tenements at the edge of the desert. After breakfast with his wife and two small children, he takes care of chores aimed at rebuilding his life — renewing his driver’s license, reactivating his cellphone; he visits friends and family and searches for a job in civil engineering, his occupation before he was clapped into prison. Whatever he does, he must be back at the police station before sundown. “Every second now is important,” said Maher, a slight 36-year-old with a full beard, large eyes obscured behind tinted yellow lenses and a gray woolen ski cap that covered his bald pate. “If I want to visit my mother in Maadi, I can spend three hours getting there and back.” The clock is ticking. “If I delay for 15 minutes, the police have the right to send me back to prison,” he said.

headline: Live Chat: The Future of Feminism
abstract: On Wednesday, March 29, Susan Chira, a senior correspondent and editor on gender issues, and Tina Brown, the founder of Women in the World, were on hand for a live chat about the future of feminism.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, March 29, Susan Chira, a senior correspondent and editor on gender issues, and Tina Brown, the founder of Women in the World, were on hand for a live chat about the future of feminism.

headline: 25 Songs That Tell Us Where Music Is Going
abstract: A curated playlist featuring Future, Kelela, Adele and more, with essays by Margo Jefferson, Wesley Morris, Angela Flournoy and others.
lead_paragraph: A curated playlist featuring Future, Kelela, Adele and more, with essays by Margo Jefferson, Wesley Morris, Angela Flournoy and others.

headline: Deconstructing the ‘Ferguson Effect’
abstract: The idea that the police have retreated under siege will not go away. But even if it's true, is it necessarily bad?
lead_paragraph: The idea that the police have retreated under siege will not go away. But even if it's true, is it necessarily bad?

headline: Where Fiction and Reality Collide: Books and Black Lives Matter
abstract: A look at several recent and pending young adult novels that explore racial profiling and police violence against young African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment near the end of Angie Thomas’s debut novel, “The Hate U Give,” when fiction and reality collide.

headline: Quotation of the Day: To the Young, Authors Find, Racial Issues Matter
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 20, 2017
lead_paragraph: “I say, ‘It probably will make you uncomfortable. I’m not here to give you comfort.’”

headline: Can Populism Take Paris?
abstract: Imagining a presidential path for Marine Le Pen.
lead_paragraph: For some time now it has felt as though God or the muse of History or some mischief-making demiurge has been placing thumbs upon the scales of Western politics, with an eye toward achieving the most disruptive and unlikely seeming outcomes.

headline: How America Fails Black Girls
abstract: A viral image has drawn attention to a big problem: Nonblacks aren’t stepping up to help missing black kids.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday in Washington, hundreds of people crowded into a town-hall meeting about the district’s many missing black and Latino kids. A photo of the event, circulated on Twitter the following morning, showed that nearly all the attendees were black.

headline: 2 Black Women Sue Fox News, Claiming Racial Discrimination
abstract: The suit says that Judith Slater, then the company’s comptroller, made racially charged comments, including suggestions that black men were “women beaters.”
lead_paragraph: Fox News, whose chairman, Roger Ailes, was ousted last year after a string of sexual harassment claims, is facing new allegations of discrimination.

headline: Ice-T Hasn’t Totally Lost His Taste for Rage
abstract: The rapper and actor on the new album of his thrash-metal band, Body Count; Black Lives Matter; and his shift from shocking to philosophical music.
lead_paragraph: Ice-T claims that original copies of the album featuring “Cop Killer” are so rare, even he doesn’t have one. “The only way you can get it now is on YouTube,” he said. “They’re on Amazon, and they’re pretty expensive, too.” (Interested collectors would be advised to check out eBay.)

headline: Republican Party, Neil Gorsuch, Martin McGuinness: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Discord at Middlebury: Students on the Anti-Murray Protests
abstract: “Student protesters were not violating Mr. Murray’s First Amendment rights when they spoke out against him. They were changing the terms of the discussion.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, a guest lecture at Middlebury College by   Charles Murray, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, was disrupted by hundreds of student protesters.  Allison Stanger, a political science professor at the college, subsequently interviewed Mr. Murray at an alternate location on campus. As they left the second venue, they were violently confronted by masked protesters, and Ms. Stanger was injured. On Campus  reached out to several students to reflect on the event.

headline: Questions for: ‘New Crop of Young Adult Novels Explores Race and Police Brutality’
abstract: How is writing fiction a form of activism?
lead_paragraph: Article: New Crop of Young Adult Novels Explores Race and Police Brutality

headline: Kellyanne Conway Casually Sits, and Etiquette Arbiters Take a Stand
abstract: Photos of the counselor to the president sitting casually on a couch in the Oval Office were all the kindling needed to ignite into a battle over decorum.
lead_paragraph: During President Trump’s meeting with dozens of leaders of historically black universities on Monday, Kellyanne Conway, the White House counselor, made herself at home in the Oval Office. She hopped onto a couch, sat back on her heels and tapped on her phone.

headline: The F.B.I.’s Dangerous Crackdown on ‘Black Identity Extremists’
abstract: The effort to target racial justice activists has chilling echoes of Cointelpro.
lead_paragraph: An F.B.I. report leaked in October and scrutinized during an oversight hearing of the House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday warns of an emergent domestic terror threat sweeping the nation and threatening the lives of law enforcement officers: the “Black Identity Extremist” (“B.I.E.”) movement. This designation, just recently invented by the F.B.I., is as frightening and dangerous as the bureau’s infamous Cointelpro program of the 1960s and ’70s, under which J. Edgar Hoover set out to disrupt and destroy virtually any group with the word “black” in its name. Today, entirely nonviolent black activists face violations of their civil liberties and even violence if they’re deemed part of B.I.E.

headline: Competition Is Ruining Childhood. The Kids Should Fight Back.
abstract: Unions aren’t just good for wage workers. Students can use collective bargaining, too.
lead_paragraph: Like the crack of a starting pistol, November begins the official college application season. But for students, this race started long ago.

headline: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 comedians. Over 20 venues. Over eight days. This 14th edition of this festival is upon us, with fresh-faced newcomers and comedy veterans alike descending upon our fair city. Below are highlights.

headline: Pussy Riot Takes Aim at Trump and Putin in New Song
abstract: The dissident Russian band’s release deals with state surveillance and police brutality, with a cameo by Chloë Sevigny.
lead_paragraph: “Big smile for the camera,” begins a barbed new song from the dissident Russian band Pussy Riot about state surveillance and police brutality.

headline: Road Rage, Then a Shot. For a Police Officer, It is Called Self-Defense
abstract: The jury’s acquittal of an off-duty officer who shot and killed an unarmed man shows how much leeway we give law enforcement authorities when it comes to using force.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of two days in early July of last year, three black men, each of them under 40, were killed by police officers in different parts of the country — Alton Sterling in Baton Rouge, La.; Philando Castile, outside of St. Paul, and Delrawn Small, in a case that drew far less national attention, in the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn.

headline: Cornel West Doesn’t Want to Be a Neoliberal Darling
abstract: The Harvard professor on his criticisms of Barack Obama, the importance of free speech and what Ta-Nehisi Coates gets wrong.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a year of the Trump presidency, do you regret your criticisms of Barack Obama? Oh, no. I told the truth. When I said drone strikes are crimes against humanity, when I said Obama bailed out Wall Street rather than Main Street — I shall forever support that. I was just speaking to the reality that people are hurting, and we have to do the same thing under Trump as we did under Obama.

headline: Franken and Trump, Hiding Behind Their ‘Jokes’
abstract: Men get away with bad behavior under the guise of show business in both comedy and politics. Too often, women are just the material.
lead_paragraph: In the 2006 documentary “Al Franken: God Spoke,” Mr. Franken, the comedian, activist and future senator from Minnesota, offered a quote that would prove prescient for more than its choice of verb: “Celebrity trumps ideology.”

headline: Colin Kaepernick and the Myth of the ‘Good’ Protest
abstract: Colin Kaepernick and Rosa Parks are more alike than we think.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, the editors of GQ named the quarterback Colin Kaepernick its Citizen of the Year for his work protesting racial injustice. Mr. Kaepernick has been heavily criticized by people like President Trump, who claims that an N.F.L. player who kneels during the playing of the national anthem “disrespects our flag” and should be fired; others argue that he is out of bounds as an activist who mixes sports with politics.

headline: Campaign to Prevent Violent Traffic Stops Tells Drivers to Keep Cool
abstract: The campaign seeks to inform citizens how to act during police stops to defuse sometimes-violent confrontations. Some say the ads are blaming the victim.
lead_paragraph: Shaquille O’Neal wants to talk about traffic stops. So does a former New York Giants linebacker, as well as a bishop from Newark, police officers and a detective from local police departments, the president of the New Jersey chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., and the executive director of a local branch of the American Civil Liberties Union.

headline: Brandeis Cancels Play About Lenny Bruce After Protests
abstract: A play about Lenny Bruce-style comedy that was to be performed on the Brandeis campus was canceled amid backlash from students and faculty.
lead_paragraph: Brandeis University canceled an upcoming play about the comedian Lenny Bruce after some students and faculty expressed outrage about its content, the school announced on Monday.

headline: Bill Clinton, Roy Moore and the Power of Social Identity
abstract: How a partisan lens leads people to different interpretations of the same facts.
lead_paragraph: It may feel to Americans that an intense state of us-versus-them is something new,  but it’s not. People have been using party as a lens to filter information for decades and beyond.

headline: How the ‘Resistance’ Helped Democrats Dominate Virginia
abstract: For campaign managers like Kathryn Sorenson, much of their job was simply channeling the enormous wave of energy that came their way.
lead_paragraph: on the morning of the Women’s March on Washington in January, Kathryn Sorenson was an hour west of D.C., en route to her new apartment, when a car broadsided her and broke her neck. She had been passing through a dangerous intersection — busy roads, no stoplights — and her first thought, as she waited for the ambulance to arrive, was about the inadequacy of local governance: In the Northern Virginia exurbs, rapid growth has long outstripped traffic oversight. Still, as a young Democratic campaign manager, it seemed to her vaguely unprofessional to have broken her neck on such a politically momentous day. “I wasn’t even out fighting the machine,” she said, “just coming back from the dry cleaners.” The first to arrive at her hospital bed — before her mother — were David Reid, a local businessman, and his wife, who had called around to every regional emergency room until they found her.

headline: De Blasio: 4 Years Later, Managing Expectations and Time
abstract: The mayor said in an interview that he has focused on clear numerical goals and timelines, stressing outcomes rather than the process.
lead_paragraph: The government of New York City is enormous, with more than 295,000 full-time employees and an annual budget of $85 billion, presenting a host of challenges for any manager. The New York Times asked Mayor Bill de Blasio, the Democrat who is seeking a second term, about his approach to management, the experiences that inform his decisions as a manager and his vision for New York City over the next four years.

headline: Stephen Colbert Unloads on Roy Moore
abstract: Mr. Colbert highlighted reports that Mr. Moore had a reputation in the 1980s for hanging out in shopping malls, trying to chat with teenage girls.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Texas Church Shooting Video Raises an Unsettling Question: Who Should See It?
abstract: Texas officials have not said whether they will release a video of the church massacre that left 26 people dead. Whether they should is a different question.
lead_paragraph: SUTHERLAND SPRINGS, Tex. — The scene captured by video is almost too terrible to imagine, much less contemplate watching: seven minutes of gunfire as a black-clad gunman executes his victims — many of them small children — inside the First Baptist Church here.

headline: At 83, Ex-Inmate Still Pleading Not Guilty to a 1968 Murder
abstract: Sam Sommer has been fighting his first-degree murder conviction for decades. Now, he simply wants to win exoneration before he dies.
lead_paragraph: A half-century ago, Sam Sommer was arrested — “kidnapped,” is how he describes it — by Suffolk County police detectives outside a Dunkin’ Donuts on Long Island.

headline: In Alan Bennett’s Diaries, Life’s Pleasures Alongside Civic Outrage
abstract: “Keeping On Keeping On” collects the British playwright’s diaries from 2005 to 20015, which include his thoughts on everything from pigeons to politics.
lead_paragraph: A partial list of the charges Alan Bennett brings against himself in “Keeping On Keeping On,” a collection of his diaries: He is dull. He is lazy. He is “shy, furtive, prurient.” He has varicose veins. He ruined his civil partnership ceremony. He is excessively modest.

headline: Mel Rosenthal, Seeking Justice With a Camera
abstract: Mel Rosenthal, the photographer and teacher whose “In the South Bronx of America” showcased his passion for the underdog, is remembered by Ricky Flores, one of his many former students.
lead_paragraph: When I decided in 1980 to be a photographer, I went out and started taking pictures of my family, friends and neighborhood. I was a typical beginner, even if I didn’t live in your typical neighborhood: This was the South Bronx during the era when arson and abandonment fueled by government dysfunction turned it into a globally-infamous and desolate urban landscape.

headline: Notable Children’s Books of 2017
abstract: The best in picture books, middle grade and young adult fiction and nonfiction, selected by the children’s books editor of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: The best in picture books, middle grade and young adult fiction and nonfiction, selected by the children’s books editor of The New York Times Book Review.

headline: Country Music Association Tells Journalists Not to Talk About Guns, Politics or Las Vegas
abstract: The association later apologized and rescinded its guidelines, which threatened to revoke journalists’ access to an awards show if they focused on politics.
lead_paragraph: The country music industry just learned the same lesson the National Football League and others have: No matter how much some people may wish for it, there’s no escape from politics.

headline: Black Vegans Step Out, for Their Health and Other Causes
abstract: African-Americans are going meatless in growing numbers, for reasons that range from politics to pop culture.
lead_paragraph: Aph Ko got tired of hearing that eating vegan was something only white people did. So in 2015, she created a list of 100 black vegans for a website. It included pioneering figures like Dick Gregory and Coretta Scott King and younger, less famous writers, filmmakers, cooks and activists.

headline: Rap Disrupted Music First. Now It’s TV and Film.
abstract: Questlove, Salamishah Tillet and Jon Caramanica discuss depictions of rap’s old-school days as well as new series and movies with hip-hop embedded into their frameworks.
lead_paragraph: For decades, hip-hop made it to the screen — big and small — only intermittently. But recently, there’s been something of a boom: a slew of rap-infused shows, movies and documentaries that look back to both the old-school era and the mid-1990s, revisiting the periods when hip-hop was becoming the driving force of pop culture. These projects underscore the music’s role as a social and political bellwether, and some even demand a dive into its hidden histories, like the involvement of women and the ways in which violence has shaped the music.

headline: Silence, Sneakers, Risk-Taking and Poetry: Our Favorite Student Comments of the Week
abstract: The best student comments from last week, and an invitation to join the conversation this week.
lead_paragraph: Most weeks we call out particular schools for being active participants in our writing forums, but this week we’d like to call out individual students. Maggie Yang and Brooke Myers, both from King of Prussia, Pa., commented on nearly every prompt we offered, and had interesting things to say about them all. Thank you for your contributions, Maggie and Brooke!

headline: Can Donald Trump Save Roy Moore After All?
abstract: Will a sex scandal cause Alabama to break with its long tradition of electing embarrassing showmen?
lead_paragraph: DAPHNE, Ala. — Election season is always a tense time in Alabama, still shadowed as we are by George Wallace’s “segregation forever” antics and the dread among educated voters that our latest political star will humiliate the state yet again in the eyes of the nation.

headline: After ‘Hope,’ and Lawsuit, Shepard Fairey Tries Damage Control
