abstract: The street art star has gone from great heights to dramatic lows. Now he’s moving on, with his biggest gallery show yet — and big targets.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — By just about any measure, it’s been a long time since the street artist Shepard Fairey managed to capture the optimism of Barack Obama’s candidacy in his “Hope” poster, the stylized portrait in red, white and blue tones that easily ranks as the most famous, also ubiquitous, artwork of 2008.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 6, 2017
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Nov. 9, 2017

headline: The Unsung Role That Ordinary Citizens Played in the Great Crime Decline
abstract: Local nonprofit groups that cleaned streets, built playgrounds and mentored children had a real effect on the crime rate, a sociologist finds.
lead_paragraph: Most theories for the great crime decline that swept across nearly every major American city over the last 25 years have focused on the would-be criminals.

headline: Why Antifa Dresses Like Antifa
abstract: A brief history of Antifa fashion.
lead_paragraph: In late August, a crowd of thousands — primarily leftists and liberals — cascaded down Martin Luther King Jr. Way in Berkeley, Calif. They were marching on a spattering of right-wingers, Trump supporters and Nazis who were gathering under the mission to say “no to Marxism in America.” At the front of the march were about 100 people dressed in head-to-toe black.

headline: Political Clashes in Kenya Leave Several Dead
abstract: The opposition politician Raila Odinga returned from abroad, and his supporters fought with the police.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Several people were killed on Friday in clashes between the Kenyan police and supporters of the opposition politician Raila Odinga after a disputed contest in which President Uhuru Kenyatta was re-elected, despite reports of voting irregularities.

headline: Malliotakis as Manager: Lessons From Hurricane Sandy and Albany
abstract: Nicole Malliotakis, the Republican candidate for mayor of New York City, discusses her management style, President Trump and coffee preferences in an interview.
lead_paragraph: The government of New York City is enormous, with more than 295,000 full-time employees and an annual budget of $85 billion, presenting a host of challenges for any manager. The New York Times asked Nicole Malliotakis, the Republican candidate for mayor, about her approach to management, the experiences that would inform her decisions as a manager of city government and her vision for New York City over the next four years.

headline: Players Criticize N.F.L. Over Donation Proposal
abstract: After the league put together a plan to contribute to groups that aid African-American communities, Eric Reid of the 49ers said the league was “trying to buy an end to the protests.”
lead_paragraph: Three N.F.L. players who have been kneeling during the national anthem have questioned a tentative plan negotiated this week by the N.F.L. to donate millions of dollars to groups that aid African-American communities, calling it an effort by the league to get them to stop their protests.

headline: In Atlanta, a Thorny Question: Should the Next Mayor Be Black?
abstract: Voters in the “Black Mecca” are asking themselves how important it is to maintain a streak of black mayors dating to 1974.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — How important is it that the next mayor be black?

headline: Manhattan Attack Is Called Terrorism. What About Vegas?
abstract: The authorities were quick to brand the Manhattan bike path attack terrorism. But the term has become about much more than just defining an attack.
lead_paragraph: Hours after a truck plowed along a Manhattan bike path on Tuesday, Americans returned to a debate that has become a vessel for some of the most contentious questions dividing an increasingly polarized society: When is an attack terrorism?

headline: Xi Jinping, Saudi Arabia, APEC: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Crooked House’ and ‘Who Killed Tupac?’
abstract: A new Agatha Christie adaptation streams ahead of its theatrical release. And a documentary mini-series explores the death of the rapper Tupac Shakur.
lead_paragraph: A new Agatha Christie adaptation streams ahead of its theatrical release. And a documentary mini-series explores the death of the rapper Tupac Shakur.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: The Macy’s Parade and ‘She’s Gotta Have It’
abstract: A variety of programs to watch with your family, or to help you avoid talking to them.
lead_paragraph: Shows to watch with your family, or to help you avoid talking to the relatives.

headline: In the Studio With the Artist Who Painted Jay-Z
abstract: Henry Taylor, who made two works for T magazine’s holiday issue, reflects on his art — and on the music mogul.
lead_paragraph: The artist Henry Taylor painted a portrait of Jay-Z, which appears on the cover of T’s Holiday issue, while he was in a hotel room in Madrid at the end of October. It was just after the French art fair FIAC, and with his deadline looming, Taylor was mining the internet on his iPhone in search of inspiration: photographs of Jay-Z, photographs of Jay-Z and Beyoncé and lyrics from the rapper’s music.

headline: Review: ‘Mudbound’ Is a Racial Epic Tuned to Black Lives, and White Guilt
abstract: Dee Rees’s new film illuminates the daily cruelties in post-World War II Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: “Mudbound” is a movie about how things change — slowly, unevenly, painfully. It is also, as the title suggests, about how things don’t change, about the stubborn forces of custom, prejudice and power that lock people in place and impede social progress. Set mainly in the Mississippi Delta in the years just after World War II, when Jim Crow was still enshrined in law and practice, the film, directed by Dee Rees, tests and complicates William Faulkner’s much-quoted claim about the not-even-pastness of the past. It’s a work of historical imagination that lands in the present with disquieting, illuminating force.

headline: Comedy in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

headline: Muhammad Ali, Beginning to End for the First Time in a Book
abstract: Jonathan Eig’s “Ali: A Life” is the first major biography to include the fighter’s final years, Parkinson’s and all.
lead_paragraph: ALI A Life By Jonathan Eig  Illustrated. 623 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $30.

headline: These Are the Ads Russia Bought on Facebook in 2016
abstract: A look at some of the ads designed by Russia to exploit divisions in American society and to tip the 2016 election in favor of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: They made for a wildly varied slide show, designed by Russia to exploit divisions in American society and to tip the 2016 presidential election in favor of Donald J. Trump and against Hillary Clinton. The House Intelligence Committee provided on Wednesday the biggest public platform to date for a sample of the Facebook ads and pages that were linked by a trail of ruble payments to a Russian company with Kremlin ties.

headline: Black Voters Could Sway an Alabama Senate Race Rocked by Scandal
abstract: White conservatives face tough decisions in the wake of sex allegations against Roy Moore. But black voters’ attention, and enthusiasm, could be equally important.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — The volatile Alabama Senate race has generated national headlines with the allegations of sexual misconduct by the Republican candidate Roy S. Moore — and the question of whether Mr. Moore’s white evangelical base will stick by him.

headline: Lawmakers Confront F.B.I. Director Over Report on Black Extremists
abstract: The F.B.I. director faced sharp questioning over an internal report that some have said called to mind the F.B.I.’s illegal spying on blacks during the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress confronted Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, on Wednesday over an F.B.I. intelligence report that said that black extremists were targeting law enforcement because of police abuses in minority communities.

headline: How Trump’s Hands-Off Approach to Policing Is Frustrating Some Chiefs
abstract: The president says the Justice Department has meddled too much in policing. But even police chiefs in Republican areas are frustrated with his rollback.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Six years ago, a police officer in this city in eastern Washington was convicted of beating a disabled man to death and trying to cover it up. After other alarming episodes involving Spokane officers came to light, the city asked federal officials to suggest changes to the police department as part of an Obama-era policing program.

headline: Laurence Fishburne on the Role That Made Him Cry
abstract: Mr. Fishburne of “Last Flag Flying” talks about the anguish of military sacrifice, the winning formula of “black-ish,” and why he doesn’t mind acting older than he actually is.
lead_paragraph: It’s a scenario ripped from the headlines: A grief-stricken family member is summoned to meet the coffin of a fallen soldier, and complications ensue.

headline: Denver Cafe ‘Happily Gentrifying’? Neighbors Aren’t So Happy
abstract: The flippant message on a sidewalk sign touched a nerve in a city where housing costs are shooting up and newcomers are pricing out residents of modest means.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The sign outside Ink Coffee was supposed to be a joke: “Happily gentrifying the neighborhood since 2014,” read the sidewalk board, displayed in a rapidly changing part of Denver once full of black and Latino families.

headline: The Culture Caught Up With Spike Lee — Now What?
abstract: After more than three decades as a provocateur, the filmmaker has returned to the movie that made him famous.
lead_paragraph: Before he had even made his first movie, Spike Lee used to fantasize about three things: season tickets at the Garden, a brownstone in Fort Greene like the one that he was raised in and a house in the historically black Oak Bluffs section of Martha’s Vineyard. In 1986, after writing, producing, directing and acting in his infectious debut, “She’s Gotta Have It,” a stylish, edgy rom-com about a libidinous young woman juggling three lovers, those Knicks seats came first. The two homes swiftly followed, and within a decade, Lee’s status and celebrity had catapulted him, practically against his will, from Da Republic of Brooklyn, as he likes to call it in emails, into a 8,200-square-foot Upper East Side townhouse that was previously home to Jasper Johns. But the getaway in Massachusetts, situated next to the 18th hole at the Farm Neck Golf Club, has never required upgrading.

headline: Nate Dern Narrates His Schizophrenic but Substantive Collection of Writings
abstract: In the audiobook edition of “Not Quite a Genius,” a senior writer for Funny or Die explores an impressive medley of forms, themes and voices.
lead_paragraph: NOT QUITE A GENIUS By Nate Dern Read by the author 7 hours, 43 minutes. Simon & Schuster Audio.

headline: House Intelligence Committee Releases Incendiary Russian Social Media Ads
abstract: The congressional intelligence committees are investigating Russian interference in the election and want to know more about how social media was used to sow discord and spread misinformation.
lead_paragraph: • Facebook, Google and Twitter were on Capitol Hill on Wednesday after a hearing a day earlier, this time to face questions from the Senate and House intelligence committees.

headline: 4 Black Suspects Charged in Videotaped Beating of White Teenager in Chicago
abstract: The charges, including hate crimes and aggravated assault, came two days after the victim was found wandering in distress on the city’s West Side.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A white teenager cowers in a corner, his hands bound with orange cords and his mouth covered with tape. Four African-Americans kick and hit him and slash at his scalp. As a cellphone camera captures their blurry images and broadcasts the ordeal on Facebook, the attackers hurl racial insults and denounce President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Two Great Shows Return Tonight
abstract: “The Fosters” is back with its winter premiere, and “Switched at Birth” has its first new episode since October 2015.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Fosters,’ 8 p.m., Freeform (Winter Premiere)

headline: Baltimore Agrees to Broad Change for Troubled Police Dept.
abstract: A scathing Justice Department report last year accused officers of systematically harassing black residents. Now, the city has agreed to a consent decree.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Nearly two years after the death of a black man in police custody led to violent riots here, the Justice Department and city leaders announced on Thursday a long-sought agreement to impose greater oversight and training on a police force found to have routinely harassed minorities.

headline: Review: ‘The Bitter Game’ Brings Black Lives Matter to the Fore
abstract: The play, by Keith A. Wallace, follows an African-American boy, Jamel, who from childhood on learns to keep his head up.
lead_paragraph: They are instructions to commit to memory, essential tools in a young man’s defense system: Keep your head up. Keep your eyes forward. Keep your ego down.

headline: ‘Zoot Suit,’ a Pioneering Chicano Play, Comes Full Circle
abstract: After opening at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles nearly 40 years ago, Luis Valdez’s production is revived at its home theater.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When “Zoot Suit” first opened at the Mark Taper Forum in 1978, little about the production screamed hit. Much of the cast had scant acting experience. The story itself was a Brechtian take on a relatively obscure unsolved murder in 1942 Los Angeles; its climax involved a humiliating assault on a Latino man by racist United States servicemen. Just a decade earlier, its writer and director, Luis Valdez, was creating short skits for audiences of striking farmworkers in the fields of the Central Valley in California.

headline: No Trump or Goodell at Super Bowl, at Least According to N.F.L. Transcripts
abstract: Reporters asked players about the two men, but when the N.F.L. posted transcripts of the interviews, almost no references could be found.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The N.F.L. seems to have built a virtual wall around the New England Patriots when it comes to public discussion of two lightning-rod topics for the team: President Trump (a friend of the team’s owner, coach and star quarterback) and Roger Goodell, the league’s commissioner, who punished the team after a cheating investigation.

headline: Defiant Voices Flood U.S. Cities as Women Rally for Rights
abstract: In cities across the country and beyond, demonstrators protested the new president after an election that placed gender in the spotlight as never before.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after what many had assumed would be the inauguration of the first female president, hundreds of thousands of women flooded the streets of Washington, and many more marched in cities across the country, in defiant, jubilant rallies against the man who defeated her.

headline: Michael Eric Dyson Believes in Individual Reparations
abstract: The author and Georgetown professor on police brutality, telling white people the truth and why charity isn’t a substitute for justice.
lead_paragraph: Your forthcoming book, “Tears We Cannot Stop,” is subtitled “A Sermon to White America.” Which part of white America do you envision reading it? I envision the audience to be that ocean of white folk I encounter who are deeply empathetic to the struggles of minorities — they are the ones who ask me, “What can I do, as a white person?” This is my attempt to address them in the most useful and, hopefully, edifying manner.

headline: A Goth Male Soprano Who Plumbs the Darkness
abstract: M. Lamar’s new show, “Funeral Doom Spiritual,” is an assemblage of old spirituals; it has its New York premiere at the National Sawdust in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: What kind of music does M. Lamar play?

headline: Jolted by Deaths, Obama Found His Voice on Race
abstract: Tensions across the country prompted the president to abandon his early reticence on race again and again.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only weeks after 70 million Americans chose a black man for president, shattering a racial barrier that had stood for the entirety of the nation’s 232-year history, no one in the White House, especially the man in the Oval Office, wanted to talk about race.

headline: Who Didn’t Go to the Women’s March Matters More Than Who Did
abstract: Millions of women turned out to march last Saturday. But were they marching for everyone?
lead_paragraph: There’s a photo making the rounds from the women’s march in Washington of a black woman named Angela Peoples (taken by her friend Kevin Banatte) holding a sign that reads, “Don’t Forget: White Women Voted for Trump.” In the photo, she stands nonchalantly, casually sucking on a lollipop with a jaded look in her eyes that suggests her familiarity with the ritual of protest, of demonstrating for civil liberties. Behind her stand three white women, all wearing the pink knitted “pussyhats” that the march made famous. Two are on their phones, pleased grins beaming from their faces. One appears to be taking a triumphant selfie.

headline: Why 5 Trump Voters Are Going to the Inauguration
abstract: Supporters of Donald J. Trump from very different backgrounds and geography talk about why they are traveling to the inauguration.
lead_paragraph: What is it about President-elect Donald J. Trump that appeals to so many Americans?

headline: Laurie Carlos, Actress in ‘For Colored Girls,’ Dies at 67
abstract: The inner lives of black women was often the focus of Ms. Carlos, a multifaceted award winner who was also a writer and director.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Carlos, an actor who appeared in the original production of Ntozake Shange’s acclaimed poetic drama “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf” and a playwright whose work expressed the inner lives of black women in the United States, died on Dec. 29 in St. Paul. She was 67.

headline: The Playlist: Arcade Fire and Gorillaz Return, With Money and Power on Their Minds
abstract: Our pop critics on the week's most important new songs, from Diamanda Galás's "O Death" to J Cole's "High for Hours."
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

headline: Anti-Semitic Note Promises ‘Mayhem’
abstract: These hate crimes and incidents of harassment were reported in recent days.
lead_paragraph: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of Donald Trump. The Southern Poverty Law Center and other groups are keeping detailed counts of these incidents as concerns increase about a rise in hate crimes. Here are some that have drawn public attention in recent days.

headline: The Intellectual Life of Violence
abstract: Resisting violence means knowing many of your efforts will fail. But that doesn’t mean there’s no hope.
lead_paragraph: This is the 11th installment in a series of dialogues with philosophers on the question of violence. This conversation is with Richard J. Bernstein, Vera List professor of philosophy at the New School for Social Research in New York. His latest book is “Violence: Thinking Without Bannisters.”

headline: Review: ‘Accidental Courtesy’ Is Gentle Persuasion for Bigots
abstract: A man who confronts racism with friendliness in his travels.
lead_paragraph: The African-American musician Daryl Davis, a journeyman who has played backup for Chuck Berry, has an unusual hobby. He cultivates cordial relationships with prominent racists — Ku Klux Klan leaders, front men for neo-Nazi groups and so on — and through a form of friendly persuasion, tries to steer them from their bigotry.

headline: Racial Progress Is Real. But So Is Racist Progress.
abstract: What if President Trump does not represent a step back, but a step forward?
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama said in his final news conference that he planned to use his time off from politics “to do some writing.” I am hoping in his post-presidency, he begins to write a different racial history from the one he proclaimed from his presidential pulpit.

headline: What the Marchers in Washington Want
abstract: The women and men who joined the protest in Washington have messages for the new president.
lead_paragraph: Many of those marching in Washington on Saturday were concerned about their futures under President Trump. They worried about the administration turning back the clock on hard-won civil rights and reproductive rights.  Here are some of the women and men who joined the protest and the messages they carried for the new president.

headline: The Non-Politics of Disability
abstract: Outrage over Donald Trump’s insensitivity is fine, but it isn’t serious political action.
lead_paragraph: The morning after Donald J. Trump’s election victory I posted a status update on Facebook that drew praise from both my liberal and conservative social media friends, and revealed something I’d thought impossible — a limit to his stalwart supporters’ loyalty. The post wasn’t exactly neutral; I lamented what Mr. Trump’s election means to me, a wheelchair user, and recalled the boorish example he set in mocking Serge Kovaleski, the Times reporter, who has a congenital joint disorder.

headline: What the Women’s March Stands For
abstract: Once-mainstream proposals, like protecting constitutional rights and improving safety-net programs, are now the subject of a protest manifesto.
lead_paragraph: Affordable birth control. Equal pay for equal work. Full access to health care for transgender Americans.

headline: Obama Races to Overhaul Police in Baltimore and Chicago Before Trump Era
abstract: Federal officials want to lock in oversight to address police bias against African-Americans, an effort they fear will be abandoned by the new administration.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — With just days until Donald J. Trump is sworn in as president, the Obama administration is making a last-minute push for police overhauls in two of the nation’s most violent cities, Baltimore and Chicago, where officers have been accused of routinely mistreating African-Americans.

headline: Preview NYC Winter Jazzfest in 7 Tracks
abstract: At this year's event in Brooklyn and Manhattan, social justice is on the agenda.
lead_paragraph: The NYC Winter Jazzfest is best described as a hectic but euphoric convergence of musicians and fans in a range of spaces around Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn. Typically the sheer abundance of bands is the main story — an encouraging reminder of how much energy and curiosity reside in the current scene, whatever market indicators might say.

headline: Student Winners from Our 2016 Year in Rap Contest
abstract: “2016 took a whole new direction/The Celebrity Apprentice guy, he won the election”: Winning rhymes from our sixth annual contest for teenagers.
lead_paragraph: 2016 has been a long year, but there’s a recap for ya right hereOur nation’s in distress and wonderin’ what’s nextDivided we stand over our president electSome protest, saying “Love Trumps Hate”Others chant “Make America Great”

headline: Looking at an Artist’s Portraits of the Charleston Shooting Victims
abstract: For years, Rudy Shepherd has made watercolor paintings to humanize people in the news.
lead_paragraph: Five days after the massacre of nine black parishioners in Charleston, S.C., in 2015, the artist Rudy Shepherd painted 9-inch-by-12-inch portraits of two of the victims, Myra Thompson and Tywanza Sanders, and posted them to Instagram.

headline: ‘black-ish’ Creator and Actor Again Walk on a Political Tightrope
abstract: Kenya Barris, this ABC sitcom’s creator, and Anthony Anderson, its star, discuss an episode about the fallout from the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: As Kenya Barris, the creator of ABC’s “black-ish,” and Anthony Anderson, that sitcom’s star, watched the 2016 presidential election results at their homes, they exchanged texts of increasing bafflement throughout the evening. “Then I woke up the next morning and said, I have to write about this,” Mr. Barris said. “I have something I want to say.”

headline: In Trump’s Hometown, a Clear Message of Defiance From Women
abstract: In concert with other Women’s March protests around the country, thousands of New Yorkers rallied for women’s rights, and against the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers flooded the streets of Manhattan on Saturday aiming to send a message to President Trump that his hometown would be a center of resistance during his administration.

headline: ‘Perpetual Revolution’ Shows Artists Shaping Their Times
abstract: In the digital present, captured here at the International Center of Photography, visual culture does more than reflect reality: For better and for worse, it creates it.
lead_paragraph: In an interview, the singer Nina Simone once said, “An artist’s duty is to reflect the times,” by which she meant, basically, politics of the day, and in her case, racial politics. “I think that is true of painters, sculptors, poets, musicians,” she added. “As far as I’m concerned, it’s their choice, but I choose to reflect the times.”

headline: Columbia Unearths Its Ties to Slavery
abstract: A new historical report prepared by the university illuminates how human bondage seeped into the life of the institution.
lead_paragraph: In 1755 a New York City newspaper carried an account of the swearing-in of the governors of the newly founded King’s College, which later grew into Columbia University. At the bottom of the page ran an advertisement for a rather different occasion: the sale of “TWO likely Negro Boys, and a Girl.”

headline: Review: A Jazzfest Marathon With Protest at Its Heart
abstract: The centerpiece of a winter festival, two music-filled days downtown, had a sharp focus this year.
lead_paragraph: “The weight of rage/Can hold you back,” the poet Marvin Tate declared late on Friday, during the first night of the NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon. “The weight of rage/Will hold you down,” he added, and then paused expectantly, as if holding onto a secret.

headline: No Racial Barrier Left to Break (Except All of Them)
abstract: We can’t create a more just nation simply by dressing up institutions in more shades of brown. Now we must confront structural racism.
lead_paragraph: In a moving farewell speech before an enormous crowd in Chicago last week, President Obama evoked the American creed of unity and aspiration as the foundation of our democracy. He has always embraced a vision of America as a “melting pot.”

headline: Video and Analysis: Jeff Sessions Confirmation Hearing
abstract: Live coverage from Times reporters of the confirmation hearings in the Senate Judiciary Committee for Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s nominee for attorney general.
lead_paragraph: Live coverage from Times reporters of the confirmation hearings in the Senate Judiciary Committee for Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s nominee for attorney general.

headline: Inauguration Day: Live Coverage
abstract: Live updates and analysis from Times reporters and editors covering the inauguration of President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Live updates and analysis from Times reporters and editors covering the inauguration of President Trump.

headline: How the Presidency Changed Obama
abstract: A president who transformed the country and learned the limits of the possible.
lead_paragraph: A president who transformed the country and learned the limits of the possible.

headline: A ‘Resistance’ Stands Against Trump. But What Will It Stand For?
abstract: Some of the most consequential movements in American law and politics began amid defeat and panic.
lead_paragraph: If we lived in normal political times, our new president would be enjoying his honeymoon period, those few blissful weeks of good will and high hopes that usually accompany the start of an administration. Instead, the election of Donald J. Trump to the nation’s highest office has provoked an opposition movement that is extraordinary in American history, with millions of people devoted to stopping whatever it is he might want to do.

headline: What Does Your Party Want?
abstract: As allegiances shift, neither Republicans nor Democrats are really sure.
lead_paragraph: How do Republicans hold on to the voters Donald Trump brought to the party?

headline: Review: August Wilson’s ‘Jitney’ Magnifies Marginalized Souls
abstract: With soaring language and an improvisatory jazz spirit, Ruben Santiago-Hudson’s revival brings lives shaped by privation to throbbing life.
lead_paragraph: Conversation sings and swings, bends and bounces and hits heaven smack in the clouds, in the glorious new production of August Wilson’s “Jitney,” which opened on Thursday night at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. In Ruben Santiago-Hudson’s vital revival of a 1982 play only now making its Broadway debut, words take on the shimmer of molten-gold notes from the trumpets of Louis and Miles.

headline: The Youth Group That Launched a Movement at Standing Rock
abstract: In the fight over the Dakota Access Pipeline, Native American activists achieved one of the most galvanizing environmental victories in years — and it all began with a group of teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Jasilyn Charger was 19 when she learned her best friend had killed herself. Charger was Lakota Sioux, and she had left the Cheyenne River Reservation in South Dakota for Portland, Ore., just a few months earlier. But in the summer of 2015, she flew home for her friend’s funeral. Then, two days later, while she was still in Eagle Butte — the largest town on the Cheyenne River Reservation with a population of 1,300 — another friend killed herself. Charger was shocked. “It hurt all of us because these were people who we thought we knew but really we had no idea what they were going through,” she said. “It really woke us up.”

headline: After Success of Women’s March, a Question Remains: What’s Next?
abstract: The challenge facing the organizers is figuring out how to channel the resolve and outrage of an organic protest into action that produces political change.
lead_paragraph: More than a million people who turned out on Saturday for women’s marches in all 50 states have put down their placards, taken off their pink hats and ended their chants after what was an extraordinary display of dissent against the Trump presidency.

headline: Women’s March on Washington Opens Contentious Dialogues About Race
abstract: Conversations surrounding the march on Jan. 21, the day after Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, are alienating some women even as organizers stress unity and inclusion.
lead_paragraph: Many thousands of women are expected to converge on the nation’s capital for the Women’s March on Washington the day after Donald J. Trump’s inauguration. Jennifer Willis no longer plans to be one of them.

headline: Nearly 8 Decades Later, an Apology for a Lynching in Georgia
abstract: The police chief in LaGrange, Ga., who is white, apologized for the death of a young black man by a white mob in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LaGRANGE, Ga. — Some people here had never heard about the lynching of Austin Callaway — about how, almost 77 years ago, he was dragged out of a jail cell by a band of masked white men, then shot and left for dead.

headline: How the Women’s March Could Resurrect the Democratic Party
abstract: The march shows why “identity politics” are central to the future of the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: The Women’s March on Washington, which is expected to bring hundreds of thousands of participants to the capital on Saturday, was intended to demonstrate opposition among progressive women to the policies of President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: An Apology for a Lynching
abstract: A reader writes, “It is heartening to see a police chief acknowledge his town’s history of white terrorism.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Text to Text: On Empathy and ‘Moral Imagination’
abstract: Can empathy help make us better people? Can it help make the world a better place? Or, is it overrated?
lead_paragraph: Browse all our Text to Text lesson plans.

headline: How Cool Works in America Today
abstract: Wokeness shares cool’s rebel posture, but it is the opposite of cool in certain respects.
lead_paragraph: If you grew up in the 20th century, there’s a decent chance you wanted to be like Miles Davis, Billie Holiday, Humphrey Bogart, Albert Camus, Audrey Hepburn, James Dean or Jimi Hendrix. In their own ways, these people defined cool.

headline: A Patriotic Fourth: What Does That Mean Now?
abstract: Are Americans still feeling pride in a bitterly divided country? We hit the road to find out.
lead_paragraph: Even a divided country can come together to celebrate its birthday. Can’t it?

headline: One Family, Many Revolutions: From Black Panthers, to Silicon Valley, to Trump
abstract: Ben Horowitz is helping define the modern tech age. His father shaped the ’60s radical left — before taking a hard right turn. Family chats get interesting.
lead_paragraph: CAMARILLO, Calif. — For generations, the Horowitz family has cheered on the revolution.

headline: Bill Maher and Fran Lebowitz: When Comedy Cuts Deep
abstract: The TV talk show host and the author of “Metropolitan Life” discuss political correctness, the presidency of Donald Trump and when a joke goes awry.
lead_paragraph: “No one dies in New York without my speaking,” Fran Lebowitz said, arriving for lunch with Bill Maher in late June, a few hours before speaking at a memorial service that afternoon. “That’s how I know I’m immortal. Who would speak at all those services without me?”

headline: Ex-Prisoner Finally Found Stability Before Killing Police Officer
abstract: Alexander Bonds, after years of crime and mental problems, had a job, an apartment and a girlfriend, before he snapped and shot Miosotis Familia in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: After a lifetime of trouble, Alexander Bonds finally seemed to have everything under control. At 34, he had escaped New York City’s shelter system and moved into his own apartment in the Bronx. He had a girlfriend, and a job at a fast-food restaurant. His five-year stint on parole was almost up, and he had not had a run-in with the police in years.

headline: Campus Political Fights Come Home for the Summer
abstract: With boycotts and protests erupting at colleges across the country, politically active students find new debate partners: their parents.
lead_paragraph: College in the summer: Dorms and quads are quiet, and it seems that the whole community is catching its breath. No marches, sit-ins, shout-downs, protesters giving professors whiplash. No arguments over free speech, Black Lives Matter, Israeli boycotts, abortion, Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton, President Trump.

headline: Three New Books Discuss How to Confront and Reform Racist Policing
abstract: Books by former Dallas police chief David O. Brown and the law professor Paul Butler, and a collection edited by Angela J. Davis, call for transformation of the system.
lead_paragraph: CALLED TO RISE A Life in Faithful Service to the Community That Made Me By David O. Brown with Michelle Burford Illustrated. 255 pp. Ballantine Books. $28.

headline: Sentence in Aboriginal Teen’s Death Is Too Lenient, Protesters in Australia Say
abstract: Protesters said the manslaughter acquittal in the death of Elijah Doughty, 14, was yet another injustice against the indigenous community. More protests are expected.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Shouting “shame,” protesters on Monday held demonstrations across Australia to express their anger over what they said was a lenient sentence in the death of a 14-year-old Aboriginal boy.

headline: President Trump’s Really Weak Week
abstract: What Trump learned from George Steinbrenner: Bullies rule, so pick on your top guys in public until they’re in tatters, and then fire them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump was promising to destroy a vile criminal cartel.

headline: Ousted Pakistan Leader Passes Baton to Brother, Shehbaz Sharif
abstract: Where his older brother, Nawaz Sharif, has been criticized for a low-energy style in power, Shehbaz Sharif has nurtured a nearly opposite reputation.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — With his term as Pakistan’s prime minister cut short, and with his governing party facing critical national elections in less than a year, Nawaz Sharif announced publicly on Saturday that he was choosing his younger brother, Shehbaz Sharif, to be his long-term replacement as prime minister and as the party’s standard bearer.

headline: Review: A Kyle Abraham Dance, Stripped Down to the Pain
abstract: In “Dearest Home,” Mr. Abraham avoids music (mostly) and politics for something more personal: an intimate work about the difficulty of intimacy.
lead_paragraph: A man approaches, almost near enough to touch. He’s wearing next to nothing, and you can tell he’s upset by the stricken look on his face and the way he thrashes in fits and starts. Soon enough, he breaks into sobs. How does that make you feel?

headline: The Most Pitiful Job in Brazil
abstract: Writers are ignored. Human rights observers are brushed off. Can anyone induce Brazil’s government to change its ways?
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Until recently, I thought that being a writer was the most pitiful profession ever, especially in Brazil. Nobody reads our books, and we can easily spend an entire life just railing against the same things again and again. In general, we Brazilian writers have no impact at all. A bunch of local capybaras that are also believed to tell fortunes garner more respect than we do.

headline: ‘First They Came For ...’
abstract: All the targets of Trump’s ire must push back with a united front before it is too late.
lead_paragraph: It is no longer sufficient to brand Donald Trump as abnormal, a designation that is surely applicable but that falls significantly short in registering the magnitude of the menace.

headline: 23 Arrested and Tear Gas Deployed After a K.K.K. Rally in Virginia
abstract: About 50 Klansmen rallied against Charlottesville’s decision to remove a statue of Robert E. Lee. More than 1,000 people showed up in response.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Members of the Ku Klux Klan rallied here on Saturday afternoon in a protest meant to assail the city’s decision to remove a statue of Robert E. Lee, the Confederate general.

headline: Let Black Kids Just Be Kids
abstract: The concept of childhood innocence itself has a deep and disturbing racial history.
lead_paragraph: George Zimmerman admitted at his 2012 bail hearing that he misjudged Trayvon Martin’s age when he killed him. “I thought he was a little bit younger than I am,” he said, meaning just under 28. But Trayvon was only 17.

headline: What the 2018 Pirelli Calendar Says About Race
abstract: The Italian company’s latest offering is a reimagining of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” with an all-black cast.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a muggy afternoon in May, in a heavily guarded studio hidden along a nondescript industrial North London back road, RuPaul, the actor, drag queen and TV personality, was holding court inside a padded box, wearing a resplendent scarlet red ball gown from which oversize playing cards tumbled from the voluminous skirt. Inches away, the actor Djimon Hounsou stood staring, shirtless, sporting a gold crown and pinstripe trousers.

headline: Neil Welch, F.B.I. Mastermind in Abscam Sting Operation, Dies at 90
abstract: The political investigation ensnared a senator and seven congressmen. He also negotiated the surrender of the escaped killer of Kitty Genovese.
lead_paragraph: Neil J. Welch, a maverick F.B.I. official who helped mastermind the political corruption sting operation that ensnared a senator and six congressmen and negotiated the surrender of the escaped killer of Kitty Genovese, died on June 29 in Omaha. He was 90.

headline: O.J. Simpson Wins Parole, Claiming He Has Led a ‘Conflict-Free Life’
abstract: Mr. Simpson will be released in October after spending nine years in prison on charges stemming from an armed robbery.
lead_paragraph: He has tumbled in the public eye from revered football hero and actor, to reviled wife abuser and murder defendant, to indebted and hapless convicted robber, but O.J. Simpson went before a Nevada parole board on Thursday flashing his usual self-assurance, telling the board that he was “a good guy” and asserting, implausibly, “I basically have spent a conflict-free life.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: A reader responds to a misstated metaphor, an author defends his work and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Michael Vick’s Advice for Unemployed Colin Kaepernick: Cut Your Hair
abstract: Kaepernick is still not signed to an N.F.L. team, and everyone has an opinion why. The newest one comes from the former star quarterback, who thinks Kaepernick should ditch his Afro.
lead_paragraph: Does Colin Kaepernick want a job as a quarterback in the N.F.L.? Michael Vick said he thought a haircut would help.

headline: Why I’m Leaving the Southern Baptist Convention
abstract: I am a minister, and black lives matter to me. I am not confident they matter to the convention.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The first time I was called a nigger to my face was by a fellow camper at a Southern Baptist Convention retreat near Oklahoma City. I was 13, and it was 1995. Devastated, I complained to a counselor who suggested I pray for the ability to turn the other cheek. Since then, I have done just that and more: I’ve been an ordained minister in the convention for almost a decade.

headline: Five Days of Unrest That Shaped, and Haunted, Newark
abstract: Fifty years ago, starting on July 12, 1967, racial tensions in Newark exploded. Here are some recollections of that time and how it has shaped the present.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The fuse that ignited this city — violent clashes with the police, gunfire, flames from burning buildings — was a rumor. Word spread that a black cabdriver had been killed inside a police precinct house. It was not true — the driver had been arrested and injured.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from Julie Bloom, Gina Lamb and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘Flee at Once’: China’s Besieged Human Rights Lawyers
abstract: As the global spotlight on the nation’s domestic policies has dimmed, lawyers for dissidents increasingly face a terrible choice: acquiescence or imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: Liang Xiaojun had just finished breakfast when he received the first instant message: His friends were disappearing from their homes and offices. By itself, this news was unremarkable. As a human rights lawyer in China, Liang had come to accept that periodic spasms of repression were an unavoidable risk of his profession. He also had grown intimately familiar with the rituals of pressure and coercion by which China kept its dissidents in line — the meetings over tea with government minders, the frequent check-ins from the judicial bureau, the police harassment. But on the morning of July 10, 2015, Liang knew that something far graver was underway.

headline: A Tour of Ghosts, History and the South’s Civil Rights Past
abstract: History matters in the South. But there was something particularly instructive about seeing the region’s Civil Rights past through the eyes of visiting high school students.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala., — In the lobby of the antebellum St. James Hotel, on a desolate street in Selma, Ala., around the corner from the Edmund Pettus Bridge, there’s a photograph of a resident ghost.

headline: Y.A. Crossover
abstract: New young adult crossover books include a novel inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement, a fantasy about a sinister magic carnival, and more.
lead_paragraph: THE HATE U GIVEBy Angie Thomas 444 pp. Balzer & Bray/HarperCollins, $17.99.

headline: The ‘Shameful’ Silencing of Elizabeth Warren in the Senate
abstract: The action “is a sad day in 21st-century America,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Super Bowl Awash in Politics, on Social Media and Off the Field
abstract: As the biggest football game of the season unfolded in Houston, fans outside the stadium and across the country expressed partisan views about more than just their teams.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — There was the game on the field, and there was the one watched through the political prism of these times.

headline: ‘Everyone Is Welcome Here’
abstract: When they heard about an alleged hate crime in their community, high school students took a stand.
lead_paragraph: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

headline: Anarchists Respond to Trump’s Inauguration, by Any Means Necessary
abstract: With far-right groups edging into the mainstream, self-described “anti-fascists” and anarchists are vowing to confront them, even if it means resorting to violence.
lead_paragraph: The videotaped sucker punch that staggered the white nationalist Richard Spencer on Inauguration Day quickly inspired mockery on social media. But it echoed loudly in an escalating confrontation between extreme ends of the political spectrum.

headline: Two Books Argue the Case for Police Reform From Within
abstract: Frank Zimring’s “When Police Kill” and Barry Friedman’s “Unwarranted” take up the case of police use of force and surveillance.
lead_paragraph: WHEN POLICE KILL By Franklin E. Zimring Illustrated. 305 pp. Harvard University Press. $35.

headline: A History of Race and Racism in America, in 24 Chapters
abstract: A decade-by-decade history of race and racism in America, compiled by a National Book Award Winner.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans might not know the more polemical side of race writing in our history. The canon of African-American literature is well established. Zora Neale Hurston, Richard Wright, James Baldwin are familiar figures. Far less so is Samuel Morton (champion of the obsolete theory of polygenesis) or Thomas Dixon (author of novels romanticizing Klan violence). It is tempting to think that the influence of those dusty polemics ebbed as the dust accumulated. But their legacy persists, freshly shaping much of our racial discourse.

headline: Samsung, Kim Jong-un, Rex Tillerson: Your Morning Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Should Athletes Stick to Sports?
abstract: How the current moment has changed the pressures on players, coaches and other to speak out or be silent.
lead_paragraph: For the past few months, the sports media has been embroiled in a fight over “stick to sports.” The phrase comes from a common online rebuke directed at sportswriters and pundits and players and coaches and anyone in the world of sports, really, who takes a political stance on anything that doesn’t occur on a field or a court or in a locker room or front office. The dividing line is predictable: Many jocks and traditionalists argue for a separation of church and state; many young fans say that sports, just like everything else, is politics. But as the sports media critic Bryan Curtis has pointed out in The Ringer, the debate is mostly moot now: Trump’s presidency, with its daily explosions, has made it impossible to cover pro sports, even in the simplest box-score ways, without detouring onto the White House lawn. This comes, in part, from the way basic sports coverage works. Reporters ask questions before and after every game, and when the only thing anyone wants to talk about is Trump, some of those questions will be about the president.

headline: Highlights and Analysis of the 2017 Oscars
abstract: “Moonlight” won the Oscar for best picture, but not before Warren Beatty mistakenly named “La La Land” the winner in a bizarre misstep. Our reporters and critic weighed in on the show.
lead_paragraph: “Moonlight” won the Oscar for best picture, but not before Warren Beatty mistakenly named “La La Land” the winner in a bizarre misstep. Our reporters and critic weighed in on the show.

headline: Donald Trump, Mexico, Mideast Policy: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Beyond ‘Hidden Figures’: Nurturing New Black and Latino Math Whizzes
abstract: A free math camp for middle-school students from New York’s poorest neighborhoods was an effort to increase the number of blacks and Latinos with advanced math degrees.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon last summer at BEAM 6, an experimental program in downtown Manhattan for youths with a high aptitude for math, a swarm of 11- and 12-year-olds jockeyed for a better view of a poster labeled “Week One Challenge Problem.”

headline: The Power of Disruption
abstract: History shows that it works.
lead_paragraph: The Trump resistance movement is stretching its wings, engaging its muscles and feeling its power. It is large and strong and tough. It has moved past debilitating grief and into righteous anger, assiduous organization and pressing activism.

headline: A Designer, and a Collection, Inspired by an Immigrant Father
abstract: Kerby Jean-Raymond, the founder of Pyer Moss, is known for his activism. This season, he turned his attention close to home.
lead_paragraph: For those who want their fashion designers to be both creative and political, Kerby Jean-Raymond is a case study.

headline: In a Stand-Up Act, Leslie Jones Finds the Humor in Being Hacked
abstract: The “S.N.L.” performer said that when nude photos of her were posted online, she laughed: “You really just helped a sister out. Thank you for the distribution.”
lead_paragraph: Not long into a raucous, high-volume stand-up set she performed on Thursday night at Carolines on Broadway, Leslie Jones described the experience of having to explain to an elderly aunt why there were pictures of Ms. Jones’s naked body on her computer screen.

headline: Celebrating Black History With The New York Times
abstract: Recent and archival articles, essays, photographs, videos, infographics, writing prompts, lesson plans and more.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Feb. 3, 2021

headline: Israel, NATO, Real Madrid: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Moonlight,’ ‘La La Land’ and Everything Else That Happened at the Oscars
abstract: Talk about a Hollywood twist ending. “Moonlight” took best picture, but not until after it was mistakenly announced that “La La Land” had won.
lead_paragraph: • “Moonlight” is best picture. In a bewildering end to the show, “La La Land” was first announced as the winner before its jubilant cast and crew were interrupted with a scarcely believable correction.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Hulu, Amazon and HBO in February
abstract: Here are the new streaming titles we think are the most interesting, broken down by service.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.

headline: The Smothers Brothers: Laughing at Hard Truths
abstract: Millions watched a comedy show that was canceled when its jokes got too serious.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday nights at 9, 50 years ago, more than a quarter of American households were watching NBC’s “Bonanza.” That comfortable and comforting western series was so dominant that CBS felt it had nothing to lose by taking a chance and giving that time slot to two brothers, musical satirists who interrupted songs like “Boil That Cabbage Down” and “Dance, Boatman, Dance” with ridiculous bouts of sibling rivalry.

headline: A Fresh Narrative in Gaming
abstract: Two video games allow players to step into the shoes of an African-American in the Jim-Crow-era South, and in today’s society.
lead_paragraph: A mixed-race man comes home from the Vietnam War to more carnage: His adoptive father, the leader of the black mob, is betrayed and killed by the Italian mafia, the main criminal power in a fictional city based on New Orleans. So the veteran, Lincoln Clay, starts taking retribution, leaving hundreds dead in his wake.

headline: Beyoncé Is Pregnant, and Twitter Loses It
abstract: The reactions on social media included joyous congratulations, jokes, questionable tweets by brands — and a deleted warning from the Atlanta police.
lead_paragraph: The reaction on social media to the news that Beyoncé is pregnant with twins was by turns swift, sweet and strange.

headline: Roommates Wanted. Trump Supporters Need Not Apply.
abstract: Since Inauguration Day, some Washington residents have been tailoring rental ads to exclude Trump backers from consideration. Call it a “no-Trump clause.”
lead_paragraph: She calls it the “no-Trump clause.”

headline: ‘The Good Fight’ Recap: On the Other Side
abstract: Seeing depictions of women who mentor and rely on one another with such fierce loyalty is still a rarity on TV.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, “The Good Fight” has much in common with its predecessor, “The Good Wife.” The power plays among Chicago’s elite lawyers lend the series a bracing wit. Role reversals happen with breakneck speed. Clothing informs characterization as much as dialogue does. There are, of course, familiar faces and names. Occasionally Alicia Florrick, the prickly lead of the original series, is mentioned in passing. But “The Good Fight” stands on its own because of the way it traffics in the thorny dynamics that arise among women who are navigating professional minefields, complex desires and identity politics. The way these women relate to each other as colleagues, lovers and friends powers the entire show.

headline: Michael Flynn, Justin Trudeau, Emmanuel Macron: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Home Is Where the Resistance Is
abstract: Homeowners around the country have opened up their living rooms for political causes and to help build community.
lead_paragraph: A casserole can be a potent weapon.

headline: ‘The Good Fight’ Season 1, Episode 3: Who Voted for Trump?
abstract: A surface level exploration of black conservatism leads to an uneven episode.
lead_paragraph: In 1921, Greenwood, Okla., a suburb of Tulsa that was home to a thriving and prosperous black community, was burned to the ground by a white mob. The community, colloquially referred to as “Black Wall Street, represented a legacy that black people are still trying to rebuild. It is estimated that as many as 300 black people were killed and more than 8,000 were left homeless. But what’s most profound was the silence that followed. It was only in 2012 that this brutal event began to be taught in Tulsa’s public schools. Its lack of historical prominence carries a lesson many black people in America learn in one way or another — legacies are important and can easily be rewritten by outside forces.

headline: How a Fractious Women’s Movement Came to Lead the Left
abstract: Feminism brought the opposition together. But how long will that last, and how many converts can it win?
lead_paragraph: Hours before the start of the Women’s March on Washington on Jan. 21, every Metro car leading to the National Mall was packed so tight that it could take on no more riders. At station after station, the train doors would open, and the passengers would look out on throngs of fellow protesters — women, men, children, babies, the occasional dog — waiting on the platform. As people emerged from underground into the morning air, it was hard to tell where to go, so they found their way by gauging the human density, moving until they reached a spot so full of people that they could no longer move at all. There was an enormous rally happening somewhere in there — activists and celebrities speaking into microphones — but much of the crowd couldn’t see or hear anything except rumbling waves of cheers. By the time they were meant to march, the crowd was so large that it already stretched across the entire route, from the rally site near the Capitol to the Ellipse near the White House.

headline: A Liberal Wanted to Agitate Ole Miss From Inside. He’s Succeeding.
abstract: Allen Coon, a student at the University of Mississippi, is reviled, but also revered, for challenging Old South symbols on a conservative campus.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — Allen Coon, perhaps the most reviled student at the University of Mississippi, was walking to his public policy class at the Trent Lott Leadership Institute on a recent weekday morning, sporting a red faux Trump cap emblazoned with the message MAKE AMERICA NATIVE AGAIN.

headline: Review: ‘I Am Not Your Negro’ Will Make You Rethink Race
abstract: Raoul Peck’s documentary is an important introduction to James Baldwin’s work and an advanced seminar in racial politics.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, in reaction to something we had written about blackness and whiteness in recent movies, my colleague Manohla Dargis and I received a note from a reader. “Since when is everything about race?” he wanted to know. Perhaps it was a rhetorical question.

headline: Events for Children in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

headline: Viola Davis and Other Speech Highlights at the Oscars
abstract: Ms. Davis won best supporting actress for “Fences.” Mahershala Ali, Asghar Farhadi and Ezra Edelman provided other memorable moments.
lead_paragraph: The Oscars host Jimmy Kimmel joked that Viola Davis should get an Emmy for her acceptance speech upon winning best supporting actress for her performance in “Fences.” And it was a rousing speech, an ode to artists as well as a thank you to, among others, the playwright August Wilson, whose drama was the basis for the film, and her director, Denzel Washington. Here are edited excerpts from some of the evening’s acceptance speeches.

headline: Afropunk: Feeling Black Activism’s Joy, and Its Pain
abstract: As Black History Month winds down, events in Harlem explore the emotions of bearing witness, with music, art, film screenings, discussions and comedy.
lead_paragraph: As Black History Month commemorations start to wind down, one festival is just gearing up. Afropunk the Takeover — Harlem, running from Tuesday through Feb. 25, will celebrate black culture with music, art, film screenings, discussions and comedy.

headline: Even in Texas, Mass Imprisonment Is Going Out of Style
abstract: In many states, reducing the rate of incarceration has become a bipartisan goal.
lead_paragraph: It promises to be a bleak four years for liberals, who will spend it trying — and, most likely, failing — to defend health care, women’s rights, climate change action and other good things. But on one serious problem, continued progress is not only possible, it’s probable. That is reducing incarceration.

headline: Liberal Activists Join Forces Against a Common Foe: Trump
abstract: Progressives are exchanging civil disobedience tactics, pooling resources and attending demonstrations about issues that they may not have previously focused on.
lead_paragraph: For years, Justin Boyan worried about the effects of climate change but focused on his wife, his two daughters and his work as a computer scientist in Rhode Island. Then Donald J. Trump became president, and Mr. Boyan was jolted into political activism.

headline: NATO, Donald Trump, Samsung: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A Different Super Bowl Matchup: Politics vs. the N.F.L.
abstract: Despite the national tumult over immigration spilling over, Commissioner Roger Goodell said, “I’m singularly focused on the Super Bowl right now.”
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — N.F.L. officials pointed to the country’s obsession with the presidential campaign as a big reason the league’s television ratings fell during much of the regular season.

headline: A Small Ohio Town Clamors to Curb Aggressive Policing
abstract: When a black man ended up face down on the ground after a New Year’s celebration, residents of a predominantly white village were outraged.
lead_paragraph: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio — The scene was an all-too-familiar one on the streets of America’s cities: a black suspect on the ground, roughed up by white police officers as an angry crowd looked on.

headline: Department of Justification
abstract: Stephen Bannon and Jeff Sessions, the new attorney general, have long shared a vision for remaking America. Now the nation’s top law-enforcement agency can serve as a tool for enacting it.
lead_paragraph: One night in September 2014, when he was chief executive of Breitbart News, Stephen Bannon hosted cocktails and dinner at the Washington townhouse where he lived, a mansion near the Supreme Court that he liked to call the Breitbart Embassy. Beneath elaborate chandeliers and flanked by gold drapes and stately oil paintings, Jeff Sessions, then a senator from Alabama, sat next to the guest of honor: Nigel Farage, the insurgent British politician, who first met Sessions two years earlier when Bannon introduced them. Farage was building support for his right-wing party by complaining in the British press about “uncontrolled mass immigration.” Sessions, like other attendees, was celebrating the recent collapse in Congress of bipartisan immigration reform, which would have provided a path to citizenship for some undocumented people. At the dinner, Sessions told a writer for Vice, Reid Cherlin, that Bannon’s site was instrumental in defeating the measure. Sessions read Breitbart almost every day, he explained, because it was “putting out cutting-edge information.”

headline: This Season, Art Gets Noisy
abstract: Exhibitions from Florida to Cleveland this winter are asking visitors to consider the affinities between sound and visual art — and the way we see (and hear) artwork.
lead_paragraph: Exhibitions from Florida to Cleveland this winter are asking visitors to consider the affinities between sound and visual art — and the way we see (and hear) artwork.

headline: ‘So-Called’ Judge Criticized by Trump Is Known as a Mainstream Republican
abstract: Judge James Robart, who blocked the president’s immigration order, is described by those who know him as a “judge’s judge” unafraid of making unpopular rulings.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge who blocked President Trump’s immigration order is described by former colleagues and acquaintances as a “mainstream” Republican who went from a career as a highly respected corporate lawyer in Seattle to an appointment by President George W. Bush to the federal bench.

headline: Women Rule Halftime. Can Lady Gaga Make It Rock Again?
abstract: Since 2011, female pop stars like Beyoncé, Madonna and Katy Perry have dominated the big game’s halftime spectacle. Lady Gaga is this year’s headliner.
lead_paragraph: Where did all the rocker guys go? In recent years, women have almost completely taken over the most highly visible gig in American pop: the Super Bowl halftime show, 12 minutes of music beamed worldwide. It is a ratings magnet, a marketing tool, a sponsor’s flagship, a cultural event and, of course, a live performance with no second chances, to be applauded or ruthlessly dissected, virtually in real time, via every internet resource.

headline: ‘Training Day’ and ‘A.P.B.,’ Where the Rogue Cop Rules
abstract: These new shows depict urban America as a hellscape that needs a results-oriented boor to break regulations, crack skulls and restore order.
lead_paragraph: “Cops don’t even want to make a damn traffic stop. Afraid they’ll wind up on Anderson Cooper.”

headline: Black History Month: Pressing Forward on the Heels of Progress
abstract: Cultural figures talk about the continued importance of the month at a time of divisiveness over race, politics and civil rights.
lead_paragraph: As Black History Month draws to a close, we asked several cultural figures to reflect on its continued importance — especially in this moment of divisiveness over race, politics and civil rights.

headline: The 2.5.17 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: RUSSELL WESTBROOK

headline: Harry Belafonte Knows a Thing or Two About New York
abstract: The city native, about to turn 90, looks back at a glorious past and wonders what his next act will be.
lead_paragraph: Harry Belafonte’s New York was a lot like yours and mine. He was born in Harlem, got his first singing gig through Lester Young, his first acting role in a company with Sidney Poitier and his first lessons in a class with Marlon Brando, Rod Steiger, Bea Arthur, Elaine Stritch and Tony Curtis. He met the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a Harlem church basement through Adam Clayton Powell Jr., and met W. E. B. Du Bois through Paul Robeson; his uncle Lenny, who ran a numbers racket, introduced him to the elite of Harlem’s gangsters. He took Nelson Mandela to Yankee Stadium, planned an Amos and Andy movie with Robert Altman and, at 89, he was a co-chairman of the Women’s March on Washington last month, along with Gloria Steinem, though his health kept him from the event.

headline: Joe Buck Knows Why You Hate Him
abstract: The Fox Sports play-by-play announcer on sports and politics, his hair-transplant surgery and, sometimes, not talking at all.
lead_paragraph: I really didn’t want to ask you about being hated, but — truly — when I told people I was going to interview you, the first thing out of everyone’s mouth was “I hate that guy.” You’ve taken this reputation with some humor, but has anything ever really gotten to you? I get more frustrated than I get hurt by it. It’s like, come on, I’m just the guy in the suit telling you your team lost.

headline: The Preacher and the Sheriff
abstract: A young, shackled black man is shot to death — and the police say he killed himself. The resulting investigation has pitted the victim’s father against the most powerful man in New Iberia, La.
lead_paragraph: No one would tell The Rev. Victor White how his son died. Everyone seemed to know — but no one would tell him.

headline: Jordan Peele on a Truly Terrifying Monster: Racism
abstract: The sketch comedian takes on racial politics and the “liberal elite” in his debut feature, the horror movie “Get Out.” Here, he talks about his life and work.
lead_paragraph: No serious fan of the sketch comedy show “Key & Peele” will be surprised that Jordan Peele (the shorter half of its starring duo) is making his directorial debut with a horror film. Their acclaimed Comedy Central series may have been best known for President Obama’s “anger translator,” but it often lampooned scary movies with a specificity that could come only from a connoisseur of things that go bump in the night. (No one has made a funnier parody of “The Shining.”)

headline: Hateful Threats Against a Jewish Blogger
abstract: When he got the messages, Marc Yellin wondered, “Have we come to this?”
lead_paragraph: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: ‘The Social Contract Is Broken’: Inequality Becomes Deadly in Mexico
abstract: Security, the bedrock of the social order, has become deeply inequitable, fraying Mexican society and politics.
lead_paragraph: MONTERREY, Mexico — Viewed from above, greater Monterrey, with its corporate headquarters and golf resorts, appears as one city stretching between the mountains that surround it.

headline: Sessions Calls for ‘Recommitment’ to Free Speech on Campus, Diving Into Debate
abstract: Speaking at Georgetown University’s law school, Attorney General Jeff Sessions backed unrestricted speech on campuses as he faced scores of protesters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions dived into the debate over free speech on college campuses on Tuesday, inserting the Justice Department into a little-known lawsuit against a Georgia college and, in a speech that embraced First Amendment protections, comparing the tactics of one student group to the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: In Praise of the Black Men and Women Who Built Detroit
abstract: In “Black Detroit,” Herb Boyd celebrates the city’s rich history through its unsung heroes.
lead_paragraph: BLACK DETROITA People’s History of Self-DeterminationBy Herb BoydIllustrated. 416 pp. Amistad/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

headline: New York Expands Relief Efforts for Puerto Rico After Hurricane Maria
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a statewide partnership to provide aid to the island territory days after viewing the damage wrought by Hurricane Maria.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a statewide partnership on Sunday to provide aid to Puerto Rico in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria, as he called on the federal government to step up efforts to help its Caribbean territories.

headline: The ‘Madman’ Is Back in the Building
abstract: I returned to work after my psychotic break, but my bipolar disorder did, too.
lead_paragraph: What do you wear the first day back to work after a 90-day leave of absence because of a psychotic break? This is the question I found myself asking a little more than a year after I joined the Legal Aid Society of New York. The last time my colleagues had seen me, I’d been wearing a handlebar mustache better suited to a Hell’s Angel than a 26-year-old public defender. I’d also taken to wearing a Mohawk — tried a case like that even. We won, thank God.

headline: What is Your Reaction to President Trump’s Tweets About Professional Sports Leagues and Athletes?
abstract: What do you think of how players, owners, teams and leagues have responded?
lead_paragraph: By now you may have heard about, or even seen for yourself, the various demonstrations of protest made by N.F.L. players on Sunday, as well as by a Major League baseball player on Saturday.

headline: Waiting for a Perfect Protest?
abstract: Well-intended moderates have used unrealistic standards to judge anti-racism activism. But this is nothing new — just ask Martin Luther King Jr.
lead_paragraph: Media outlets and commentators representing a range of political persuasions have called attention to recent outbreaks of violence in Berkeley, Calif., Boston and other locations where anti-racist and anti-fascist demonstrators have gathered. Intentionally or not, they have often promoted a false equivalency between groups that advocate white supremacy and those that seek to eliminate it.

headline: Is Democracy Endangered?
abstract: In advance of the Athens Democracy Forum, The Times solicited essays on some of the challenges facing nations today.
lead_paragraph: Looking across the globe, it might appear at times that violence, chaos and fear are getting the upper hand over order, democracy and reason.

headline: Von Miller of the Broncos Took a Knee, Then a Sponsor Drew Scrutiny
abstract: A car dealership in Denver faced an internet backlash after a retracted TV news report saying it had fired him. The facts were more complicated.
lead_paragraph: Von Miller, a star linebacker for the Denver Broncos, was one of many N.F.L. players who knelt on Sunday during the playing of the national anthem in what became a sweeping and stark show of solidarity against police brutality and a silent admonition of President Trump.

headline: Might Athlete Protests Reach Podiums at the Winter Olympics?
abstract: “As athletes, we have a very unique opportunity to speak up about things that we believe in,” the American figure skater Adam Rippon said.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — The protesting of racism and police brutality by American athletes started with W.N.B.A. players at a news conference in July 2016 and soon spread to the playing fields of the N.F.L. and the hardwood courts of the N.B.A. In less than five months, the Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea, will present a far larger stage for demonstration: an Olympic podium.

headline: Inner Racism Revealed
abstract: Being president has not changed Trump but exposed him.
lead_paragraph: Allow me a moment of personal indulgence: When I began writing a column many years ago, it quickly dawned on me that although I had strong and firm views on some things, there were many others about which my opinions weren’t fully formed. I believe that many of us have areas in our lives where our opinions are fungible. It was only through my experience in this job that my own opinions became so clear to me. Doing the job honed me, revealed me, exposed me.

headline: First Encounters With Race and Racism: Teaching Ideas for Classroom Conversations
abstract: Using firsthand accounts from teenagers to guide classroom discussions around race and racism.
lead_paragraph: This is a guest lesson from Jinnie Spiegler, the director of curriculum at the Anti-Defamation League. She has written for us previously on 10 Ways to Talk to Students About Sensitive Issues in the News.

headline: In a Quiet Ohio Town, Who Started the Fire, and Why?
abstract: Celeste Ng’s “Little Fires Everywhere” witnesses the mysteries of arson, kinship and community in late-’90s suburban America.
lead_paragraph: Readers of Celeste Ng’s second novel, “Little Fires Everywhere,” will recognize a few elements from her acclaimed debut, “Everything I Never Told You.” There are the simmering racial tensions and incendiary family dynamics beneath the surface of a quiet Ohio town. There are the appeal and impossibility of assimilation, the all-consuming force of motherhood and the secret lives of teenagers and their parents, each unknowable to the other.

headline: Reading Something in the N.F.L. Ratings? You’re Probably Wrong
abstract: Amid protests against police brutality and in the wake of the president’s tweets, the war over television ratings has become explicitly political.
lead_paragraph: Nielsen’s television ratings are traditionally an industry metric, used by networks and advertisers to buy and sell commercial time. But on this Monday, and every Monday for the next four months, the N.F.L. ratings will be dissected far and wide in search of broader meaning.

headline: Fueled by Trump’s Tweets, Anthem Protests Grow to a Nationwide Rebuke
abstract: The wave of demonstrations at N.F.L. games on Sunday even included some of Trump’s supporters in the league, but it drew a mixed reception from fans.
lead_paragraph: On three N.F.L. teams, nearly all the football players skipped the national anthem altogether. Dozens of others, from London to Los Angeles, knelt or locked arms on the sidelines, joined by several team owners in a league normally friendly to President Trump. Some of the sport’s biggest stars joined the kind of demonstration they have steadfastly avoided.

headline: Call a Lynching By Its Name
abstract: As parents of biracial kids, we shudder to say the word. But we have to.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, we have read gut-wrenching accounts of an alleged attack on an 8-year-old biracial boy in Claremont, New Hampshire. Like the local police, who did not issue any public statements until more than a week after the incident, under pressure from the boy’s family, state media have also been circumspect in their coverage. Nowhere in the reporting by top state media outlets on this tragic event does the word “lynching” occur.

headline: What Every N.F.L. Team Did During the National Anthem on Sunday
abstract: Across the country, players, coaches and owners staged protests during performances of the national anthem, reacting to comments from President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Widespread calls for demonstrations at Sunday's games erupted after President Trump's comments this weekend criticizing players for kneeling during the national anthem and owners for tolerating the displays. Starting with Jacksonville’s game against Baltimore in London, players, coaches and several owners protested across the league.

headline: Trump’s N.F.L. Critique a Calculated Attempt to Shore Up His Base
abstract: White House officials said President Trump is deeply worried that his recent show of bipartisanship endangers his standing with conservatives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was restless on the flight home from his rally on Friday night in Alabama, griping about the size of the crowd, wondering how his pink tie played with his audience and fretting about the low energy of the Senate candidate he was there to bolster.

headline: The Awakening of Colin Kaepernick
abstract: In college, Kaepernick began a journey that led him to his position as one of the most prominent, if divisive, social activists in sports.
lead_paragraph: The standout college quarterback went to the meeting alone that winter night, looking to join. The fraternity brothers at Kappa Alpha Psi, a predominantly black fraternity with a small chapter at the University of Nevada, knew who he was. He was a tall, lean, biracial junior, less than a year from graduating with a business degree.

headline: What I Saw on the Way to the Revolution
abstract: In 1967, I dropped out of college to be an artist. Six months later, I was a violent radical. What happened?
lead_paragraph: In June 1967, in the freewheeling spirit of the times, I dropped out of Antioch College, in Ohio, and hitchhiked to New York. I was 19, mildly though not madly political. In junior high, I had joined civil rights demonstrations. Now I opposed the Vietnam War. But my ideology was simply the counterculture’s: peace and love, plus anything fun that could undermine convention.

headline: Eric Reid: Why Colin Kaepernick and I Decided to Take a Knee
abstract: We chose the gesture purposefully. Our bodies were like flags flown at half-mast to mark a tragedy.
lead_paragraph: In early 2016, I began paying attention to reports about the incredible number of unarmed black people being killed by the police. The posts on social media deeply disturbed me, but one in particular brought me to tears: the killing of Alton Sterling in my hometown Baton Rouge, La. This could have happened to any of my family members who still live in the area. I felt furious, hurt and hopeless. I wanted to do something, but didn’t know what or how to do it. All I knew for sure is that I wanted it to be as respectful as possible.

headline: Making Chicano Life Visible
