abstract: J.D. Beck and DOMi are so young and virtuosic that it feels as if they must be kidding you.
lead_paragraph: J.D. Beck and DOMi are so young and virtuosic that it feels as if they must be kidding you.

headline: Read the document
Vaccinations, Schools, Meghan Fallout: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Mass shooting at a Colorado grocery store.
lead_paragraph: A gunman opened fire at a grocery story in Boulder, Colo., on Monday afternoon, killing at least 10 people, including a police officer, the authorities in Boulder said. A suspect, who was injured during the shooting, is in custody. Here’s the latest.

headline: The Social Justice Purge at Idaho Colleges
abstract: Republican lawmakers try to cancel diversity programs.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I wrote that right-wing legislatures trying to ban critical race theory from public schools and institutions were a far more direct threat to free speech than what’s often called cancel culture.

headline: The Fashion World Promised More Diversity. Here’s What We Found.
abstract: Tracking an industry where Black representation has been rare.
lead_paragraph: Against the backdrop of the 2020 Black Lives Matter protests, and amid a flurry of racist incidents in the fashion industry, the fashion world vowed it would change.

headline: Drew Brees Retires, His Focus on the Details Until the End
abstract: Brees, who won seven division titles as the Saints’ quarterback, including the most recent four, retired after 20 seasons with the most completions and passing yards in N.F.L. history.
lead_paragraph: Every great quarterback has a defining characteristic.

headline: Why Amazon’s Union Vote Matters
abstract: The vote in Alabama is a temperature check on beliefs about Amazon and labor unions in the United States.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: What Is a Ballet Body?
abstract: With performances on pause, many dancers are rethinking their relationship to weight.
lead_paragraph: Like many ballet dancers, Lauren Lovette has had some questions during the pandemic. One keeps rising to the top of her list. What is a ballet body? And a corollary: What does healthy look like? “Am I really working on being a better dancer?” Lovette said. “Or am I just trying to starve and get skinnier, so now I have the line?”

headline: El Museo Looks to Define ‘Latinx Art’ With a Major Survey
abstract: The museum’s first triennial, imperfect but stimulating, has successfully landed.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past year, New York City’s museum clock has been running on Covid time. When lockdown hit last March, exhibitions in progress went dark. Some later reopened for a last-gasp run. Others never saw the light again. Still others, originally scheduled to debut during the past several months, have had to carve out new slots. “Estamos Bien — La Trienal 20/21” at El Museo del Barrio, is one of the late-landing arrivals.

headline: Menthol Cigarettes Kill Many Black People. A Ban May Finally Be Near.
abstract: Advocates are hoping that President Biden will soon come out in favor of banning mint-flavored cigarettes and other tobacco products.
lead_paragraph: The banning of menthol cigarettes, the mint-flavored products that have been aggressively marketed to Black Americans, has long been an elusive goal for public health regulators.

headline: Golden Globes 2021: Where to Stream the Winners
abstract: Nearly all of the big winners from the evening are available to stream. Here’s a look at where to find them and what The Times first had to say about them.
lead_paragraph: During a normal year, when many of the awards-contending movies are released late in the season, home viewers often have to wait for a month or two to catch the winners on various streaming services. But the one benefit to an awards show during a pandemic year is that all the winners are immediately available — or so we might have assumed.

headline: Biden Endorses Female Generals Whose Promotions Were Delayed Over Fears of Trump’s Reaction
abstract: The unusual strategy to slow the promotions until after the election — intended to protect the officers’ accomplished careers — was devised by top Pentagon leaders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden has nominated two female generals to elite, four-star commands, the Defense Department announced, months after their Pentagon bosses had agreed on their promotions but held them back out of fears that President Donald J. Trump would reject the officers because they were women.

headline: What we know about the judge in the Derek Chauvin trial.
abstract: Judge Peter A. Cahill, a 14-year veteran of the bench in Hennepin County, ordered that the trial be televised, a first in Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: Judge Peter A. Cahill is a 14-year veteran of the bench in Hennepin County. He has previously worked as a public defender, private defense lawyer and prosecutor, rising to become chief deputy under Amy Klobuchar, now a U.S. senator, when she served as the county attorney.

headline: George Floyd’s Family Settles Suit Against Minneapolis for $27 Million
abstract: The settlement is one of the largest of its kind, but it may make it harder to seat an impartial jury for the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer charged with murder in Mr. Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: [Watch Live: Derek Chauvin on trial for George Floyd’s Death]

headline: An Alliance of Autocracies? China Wants to Lead a New World Order.
abstract: As President Biden predicts a struggle between democracies and their opponents, Beijing is eager to champion the other side.
lead_paragraph: President Biden wants to forge an “alliance of democracies.” China wants to make clear that it has alliances of its own.

headline: Cracks in a Legal Shield for Officers’ Misconduct
abstract: The Supreme Court has hinted that it is ready to trim the doctrine of qualified immunity, which makes it difficult to sue government officials for violence and cruelty.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, the Supreme Court has been hostile to lawsuits from victims of police violence, prisoners subjected to appalling cruelty and others who sought to sue government officials for violations of their constitutional rights.

headline: Who Wants ‘A Touch of Disney’? A Lot of People.
abstract: Monday: The demand to walk around and buy food at a Disney park is astronomical. Also: A recall update.
lead_paragraph: (This article is part of the California Today newsletter. Sign up to get it delivered to your inbox.)

headline: Grammys Ready Pandemic Show, as the Weeknd Boycotts Future Awards​
abstract: The event on Sunday will address the challenges of a music industry hit hard by the pandemic. The Weeknd, who was snubbed, says he will boycott the awards going forward, in a sign of continuing friction with artists.
lead_paragraph: When music fans tune in to the 63rd annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night, with Trevor Noah as host and performances by nearly two dozen stars including Taylor Swift, Cardi B, Dua Lipa and BTS, they will see the music world coming together in celebration and friendly competition after a grueling year.

headline: Policing at Sarah Everard Vigil in London Faces Official Scrutiny
abstract: The killing of Ms. Everard, 33, has prompted soul-searching over violence against women in Britain. And the breaking up of a banned vigil in her memory has focused criticism on London’s police.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The mayor of London and the British cabinet minister responsible for policing called Sunday for an independent inquiry into how the city’s main police force broke up a vigil for Sarah Everard, the 33-year-old marketing executive whose killing has sparked a reckoning over violence against women.

headline: Meyers Leonard Will Be Away From Heat ‘Indefinitely’ After Use of Anti-Semitic Slur
abstract: Leonard, a reserve center for the Miami Heat, lost gaming sponsorships after a video emerged of him using the slur while playing a video game on the livestreaming site Twitch.
lead_paragraph: Meyers Leonard, a reserve center for the Miami Heat, will be “away from the team indefinitely,” the team said Tuesday night, following his use of an anti-Semitic slur while he was playing a video game on a public livestream.

headline: How Has the Pandemic Changed Your Relationship to Your Body?
abstract: Do you feel less or more pressure to have a “perfect body” right now?
lead_paragraph: Note: If you are struggling with disordered eating, contact the National Eating Disorders Association hotline at 800-931-2237. If you are in crisis, talk to a trusted adult or text “NEDA” to 741741.

headline: Review: Live Theater Returns, With Mike Daisey and His Beefs
abstract: The monologuist appeared onstage, indoors, in front of a real audience, on the first day possible. Maybe he shouldn’t have rushed.
lead_paragraph: Mike Daisey has been a monologuist for more than 20 years. Not continuously — though it has sometimes felt like it.

headline: Amazon Workers Vote Down Union Drive at Alabama Warehouse
abstract: The company’s decisive victory deals a crushing blow to organized labor, which had hoped the time was ripe to start making inroads.
lead_paragraph: Amazon workers at a giant warehouse in Alabama voted decisively against forming a union on Friday, squashing the most significant organizing drive in the internet giant’s history and dealing a crushing blow to labor and Democrats when conditions appeared ripe for them to make advances.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Takes On Matt Gaetz Over His Bid for a Pre-emptive Pardon
abstract: Trump aides denied him a blanket pardon for fear it would set a bad precedent, Kimmel said: “At the time, they were only interested in setting terrible precedents.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Policing Is Not Broken. It’s ‘Literally Designed to Work in This Way.’
abstract: Jane Coaston debates three proposals to fix America’s broken policing.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin has been found guilty of the murder of George Floyd. But whatever bittersweet feelings the rare outcome elicited were short-lived, since instances of police brutality compound almost daily. There’s no debate: Policing is broken in America. But how do we fix it?

headline: A Jane Austen Museum Wants to Discuss Slavery. Will Her Fans Listen?
abstract: Exhibits at the house where the writer lived in the early 1800s are being updated to add historical context. Not everyone is thrilled.
lead_paragraph: As part of the discussion over racism that followed the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last year, museums have asserted solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement and begun to rethink and recast how they portray history.

headline: You Should Go Back and Watch the Chauvin Trial
abstract: The guilty verdict notwithstanding, the case demonstrated the wide latitude police officers are given to kill people.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Covering a Coup from Afar
abstract: How our correspondent is capturing the chaos in Myanmar. Plus, what else you need to know in global news this week.
lead_paragraph: Hi everyone, Happy Friday! This week, our team has been thinking about this military reunion (very sweet); the mystical particles known as muons that scientists say might upend our understanding of the universe (wild); and international news (the focus of this newsletter).

headline: Capitol Police Told to Hold Back on Riot Response on Jan. 6, Report Finds
abstract: Despite being tipped that “Congress itself is the target” on Jan. 6, Capitol Police were ordered not to use their most powerful crowd-control weapons, according to a scathing new watchdog report.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Capitol Police had clearer advance warnings about the Jan. 6 attack than were previously known, including the potential for violence in which “Congress itself is the target.” But officers were instructed by their leaders not to use their most aggressive tactics to hold off the mob, according to a scathing new report by the agency’s internal investigator.

headline: I’m in a Police Union That Holds Bad Cops Accountable
abstract: The Ethical Society of Police isn’t afraid to speak out against police misconduct.
lead_paragraph: This week, a veteran officer in Brooklyn Center, Minn., killed an unarmed man, claiming to have mistaken her gun for her Taser. The Ethical Society of Police, a St. Louis group consisting mostly of Black officers, was quick to comment on the shooting, calling out the negligence of the officer.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Natalie Wynn and Will Wilkinson
abstract: The April 27 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Natalie Wynn and Will Wilkinson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: In Photos: America Reacts to the Derek Chauvin Verdict
abstract: Scenes from around the country after Mr. Chauvin was found guilty of murdering George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Cheers erupted in Minneapolis on Tuesday after a jury found the former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty on all counts in the murder of George Floyd last May.

headline: A New York Intellectual Bastion Finds a New Home
abstract: The New York Institute for the Humanities, founded in 1977 as a venue for cross-disciplinary conversation, is moving to the New York Public Library.
lead_paragraph: For a certain kind of intellectually inclined New Yorker, the weekly Friday lunch of the New York Institute for the Humanities has long been a coveted invitation. Held for more than four decades in a succession of sometimes cramped rooms at New York University, it’s the kind of gathering where you suddenly realize that the seriously dressed-down person who had just abruptly put down a paper plate of deli sandwiches to pose a sharp question about a talk on Nietzsche’s concept of anti-education or the legacy of the documentary “Paris Is Burning” is actually an eminent philosopher, a prizewinning novelist, or maybe a downtown musician or painter.

headline: ‘Gentle Steering of the Ship’: How Keith Ellison Led the Prosecution of Chauvin
abstract: Years before he won a murder conviction for the death of George Floyd, Mr. Ellison, the Minnesota attorney general, was a young civil rights lawyer taking on police misconduct.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — As a young civil rights lawyer almost 20 years ago, Keith Ellison took on a client who accused two Minneapolis police officers of sodomizing him with a toilet plunger.

headline: With George Floyd, a Raging Debate Over Bias in the Science of Death
abstract: Critics say the profession of forensic pathology has been slow to acknowledge how big a role bias may play in decisions such as whether to classify a death in police custody as a homicide.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — From the beginning, the death of George Floyd disrupted the field of forensic pathology in much of the way it challenged policing.

headline: How to Double the Vaccination Pace
abstract: With Covid cases rising, more experts think the U.S. should start delaying second vaccine shots.
lead_paragraph: The development of the Covid-19 vaccines happened with great urgency, for obvious reasons.

headline: The ‘Herald Square Bomber’ Who Wasn’t
abstract: After 9/11, U.S. authorities used informants to secure hundreds of terror convictions. But did they help create plots where none existed?
lead_paragraph: Shahawar Matin Siraj first met the older man late in the summer of 2003. He would see him at the mosque in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, sobbing loudly during prayers and hovering near the imam. But when the man entered the bookstore nearby, where Siraj worked, he was warm and easygoing. He said his name was Osama Eldawoody, and the two men struck up an unlikely friendship.

headline: N.Y.P.D. to Limit Use of ‘Sound Cannon’ on Crowds After Protesters’ Lawsuit
abstract: The Police Department has agreed to stop using an “alert” noise on the devices after demonstrators and photographers sued, saying it caused migraines and dizziness.
lead_paragraph: Police officers first deployed the earsplitting beeps against protesters more than a decade ago in Pittsburgh: Painfully loud noises emitted from a powerful speaker atop a police vehicle, a crowd-control device known informally as a “sound cannon.”

headline: The Island Is Idyllic. As a Workplace, It’s Toxic.
abstract: Globe-trotting diners flock to the Willows Inn’s serene Northwest setting. But former employees say faked ingredients, sexual harassment and an abusive kitchen are the real story.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: India’s Covid Crisis
abstract: “The current Covid-19 crisis reflects India’s horrendous health care situation,” a reader writes. Also: TikTok as political tool.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After Nearly a Year of Unrest, Portland Leaders Pursue a Crackdown
abstract: Mayor Ted Wheeler said he wanted to “unmask” demonstrators who engaged in property destruction. The Oregon city has seen regular demonstrations since the murder of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — After the protests have concluded, sometimes in the early morning hours, Margaret Carter finds herself climbing into her gray Toyota Camry and cruising the streets of Portland so she can see the latest damage for herself.

headline: Chris Magnus, the police chief of Tucson who criticized Trump, is chosen by Biden to lead Customs and Border Protection.
abstract: If confirmed, Mr. Magnus would step into a major challenge facing the Biden administration: how to handle a record number of border crossings that are projected to increase in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: President Biden picked Chris Magnus, the police chief of Tucson, Ariz., and a critic of the Trump administration’s anti-immigration policies, to lead Customs and Border Protection, one of six new leaders at the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Derek Chauvin Is Guilty: ‘A Huge Nationwide Sigh of Relief’
abstract: Readers hail the verdict in Derek Chauvin’s trial, but one writes, “Justice will be when people of color can live in a country where they do not have to fear the bias of racist law enforcement.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Marriage Between Republicans and Big Business Is on the Rocks
abstract: But the internal contradictions of “woke capitalism” are a mixed blessing for the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: “Woke capitalism” has been a steadily growing phenomenon over the past decade. The muscle of the movement was evident as early as 2015 in Indiana and 2016 in North Carolina, when corporate opposition forced Republicans to back off anti-gay and anti-transgender legislation.

headline: Biden Administration Plans to Propose Banning Menthol Cigarettes
abstract: The move has been long sought by public health and civil rights groups, after decades of marketing aimed at Black smokers.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is planning to propose a ban on menthol cigarettes, a long-sought public health goal of civil rights and anti-tobacco groups that has been beaten back by the tobacco industry for years, according to a federal health official.

headline: Inside Corporate America’s Frantic Response to the Georgia Voting Law
abstract: Companies like Delta are caught between Democrats focused on social justice and populist Republicans. They face major political consequences no matter what they do.
lead_paragraph: On March 11, Delta Air Lines dedicated a building at its Atlanta headquarters to Andrew Young, the civil rights leader and former mayor. At the ceremony, Mr. Young spoke of the restrictive voting rights bill that Republicans were rushing through the Georgia state legislature. Then, after the speeches, Mr. Young’s daughter, Andrea, a prominent activist herself, cornered Delta’s chief executive, Ed Bastian.

headline: The Biggest Mayor’s Race in Years? New Yorkers’ Minds Are Elsewhere.
abstract: Two months before the Democratic primary for mayor, arguably the most consequential New York City election in decades, many voters are focused on other things.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: ‘Master,’ ‘Slave’ and the Fight Over Offensive Terms in Computing
abstract: Nearly a year after the Internet Engineering Task Force took up a plan to replace words that could be considered racist, the debate is still raging.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who joined a video call during the pandemic probably has a global volunteer organization called the Internet Engineering Task Force to thank for making the technology work.

headline: A Guide to Neopronouns
abstract: Are you a person, place or thing? We have good news.
lead_paragraph: A personal pronoun is a form of speech that stands in for a person or group of people. She is having opinions online; they are fighting in the comments; and, of course, as in the Prince song made famous by Sinead O’Connor, “Nothing Compares 2 U.”

headline: Alibaba’s Big Fine Is a Warning Shot
abstract: Beijing regulators are sending a message to Chinese internet giants.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, Chinese officials fined Alibaba a record $2.8 billion over antitrust violations. It was the biggest penalty yet as the Chinese government scrutinizes Jack Ma’s business empire — and it served as a warning for the country’s other internet giants.

headline: A Brooklyn Artist Wants Sports Fans to Wear Their Names
abstract: A Brooklyn artist uses sports iconography to commemorate Trayvon Martin, George Floyd and other Black victims of violence.
lead_paragraph: The irony has always troubled Raafi Rivero. “People love Black athletes,” he said. “But they don’t love Black people.”

headline: Justice Dept. Opens Broad Inquiry Into Minneapolis Police
abstract: The investigation was a sign that President Biden intends to wield federal law enforcement as a tool to combat police abuses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced on Wednesday a sweeping investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department, signaling that the Biden administration will seek to combat police abuses around the country and apply stricter federal oversight to local forces.

headline: Minnesota students walk out of schools in solidarity with the racial justice movement.
abstract: The organizers of the walkout, Minnesota Teen Activists, said that students at more than 100 schools participated.
lead_paragraph: Students streamed out of schools across Minnesota on Monday afternoon to protest racial injustice, in a coordinated action that coincided with closing arguments in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged with killing George Floyd.

headline: G.O.P. Bills Target Protesters (and Absolve Motorists Who Hit Them)
abstract: As the nation reacts to the guilty verdict a jury handed to Derek Chauvin in the killing of George Floyd, Republican-led states are introducing punitive new measures governing protests.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Classical Music Podcasts Begin to Flourish, at Last
abstract: During the past year, established shows have evolved while others have joined. And one, “Mission: Commission,” is breaking new ground.
lead_paragraph: Classical music has been surprisingly slow to embrace podcasting, a medium ideally suited to illuminate its sounds and stories.

headline: What Students Are Saying About The Verdict in the Derek Chauvin Trial
abstract: We invited teenagers to share what they were feeling and wondering about the verdict in a trial that shook the nation. Here is what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, was found guilty of second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in the death of George Floyd, whose killing last May drew millions into the streets for the largest racial justice protests in generations.

headline: Let’s Stay Angry About Jan. 6
abstract: Rather than taking things in stride, I’m still saying, “How dare you?”
lead_paragraph: The events of Jan. 6 taste as bitter in my mouth as they did the day they took place. Nearly three months later, the simmering bad feeling isn’t boiling over anymore, but it’s still hot to the touch.

headline: California Beach Seized in 1924 From a Black Family Could Be Returned
abstract: Nearly a century ago, the city of Manhattan Beach shuttered a resort that belonged to Willa and Charles Bruce. Though the county is trying to give the land back, the city has declined to apologize.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a century after a Southern California city shuttered a beach resort owned by a Black couple, the city, county and state are still reckoning over how to right past wrongs.

headline: House Approves D.C. Statehood, but Senate Obstacles Remain
abstract: The vote reflected broad support among Democrats. But Republican opposition could stall the measure in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted along party lines on Thursday to grant statehood to Washington, D.C., as Democrats moved to use their congressional majority to accomplish a long-held goal that has become a central plank in the party’s push to expand voting rights and address racial inequity.

headline: In the Roaring Twenties, Ads Make a Comeback
abstract: Subscriptions may be the rage, but businesses of all sorts are pouring money into advertising — digital most of all.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to sound smart at a media business conference or sell your start-up over the last couple of years, you’d talk about the rise of digital subscriptions. Netflix and Spotify led the way in getting consumers to pay every month for their content, and The New York Times, The Washington Post and many others followed. By last week, everyone was hawking media subscriptions, from the owners of the SpongeBob SquarePants TV show ($5.99 a month) to the staid newswire Reuters ($35) to my friend Isaac who wanders aimlessly around New York ($7).

headline: Pet Peeves
abstract: Adam Wagner packs it in.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — If a sign of a good puzzle is one that leaves a solver smiling at the end, then I posit that the sign of a good theme is one that makes you snort. Maybe you chuckle a little, too. Sometimes, you may just be astonished that someone thought of the idea.

headline: Derek Chauvin Verdict Brings a Rare Rebuke of Police Misconduct
abstract: A jury deliberated for just over 10 hours before pronouncing Mr. Chauvin guilty on all three charges: second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: [Follow live coverage of the Derek Chauvin sentence hearing.]

headline: The Death of George Floyd Reignited a Movement. What Happens Now?
abstract: Calls for racial justice touched nearly every aspect of American life on a scale that historians say has not happened since the civil rights movement of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: For a U.K. Satirist and His Online Fans, Comedy Is Catharsis
abstract: Lockdown has helped establish Munya Chawawa as a sardonic voice for young people who don’t often recognize themselves in the comedians they see on TV.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He is the hyperbolic news anchor with an agenda, the disgruntled Meghan Markle skeptic vying for Piers Morgan’s job, the British aristocrat insisting he is simply middle class — and those are just a few of the characters in Munya Chawawa’s arsenal.

headline: Some New Yorkers Don’t Want the Superrich to Return
abstract: Sure, the tax revenue is nice. But ….
lead_paragraph: Even without final data from New York City about how many people remained in the city during the pandemic, an abundance of anecdotal evidence exists about the exodus of its wealthiest residents.

headline: Fallen British Empire Soldiers Were Overlooked Because of Racism, Inquiry Finds
abstract: The graves of 45,000 to 54,000 people who died in service during World War I did not receive proper memorials, the report said. At least 116,000 others were not commemorated at all.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tens of thousands of soldiers from Africa and Asia who died during World War I in the service of what was then the British Empire were not properly commemorated, partly because of prejudice and racism, according to the findings of an inquiry issued on Thursday.

headline: Taking Over Victory Gardens to Make a ‘Theater for All’
abstract: Ken-Matt Martin, the esteemed Chicago theater’s first Black artistic director, is going in with his eyes open.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Ken-Matt Martin, the incoming artistic director of Victory Gardens Theater here, said he never has revealed this publicly before, but he has a Sankofa bird tattooed on his back.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Verdict in the Derek Chauvin Trial?
abstract: Do you feel that justice has been served? Does the verdict mark a turning point in American history, or is there much work still to be done?
lead_paragraph: Note to teachers: The trial of Derek Chauvin, and recounting of the murder of George Floyd, include painful and graphic subject matter. You might consider some of the resources listed at the bottom of this post, from The Learning Network and from other educational organizations, to help your students make sense of and process these events before you ask them to comment in this open forum. (Please also note that all comments are moderated by the Learning Network to follow Times standards.)

headline: The Blue Wall of Silence Is Starting to Crack
abstract: Police say, ‘This is not who we are.’ Prove it.
lead_paragraph: I was driving around the other day when I realized that the license tabs on my car had expired. I didn’t panic, because I didn’t have to. If the cops pulled me over, I could feel assured as a white male: My life would not be in danger.

headline: A New Line Inspired by Dancehall and Handicraft
abstract: The designer Rachel Scott has honed her skills at brands in Milan and New York, but when it came to creating her own label, Diotima, she looked homeward to Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: As a teen in 1990s Kingston, Jamaica, the fashion designer Rachel Scott was acutely aware of the tension between the decorum dictated by her Jesuit high school, where skirt lengths were checked on a regular basis, and the liberating dancehall scene she was swept up into at night. “There was this idea of being proper and having to present a certain way in the daytime — it was ridiculous,” says Scott, 37, speaking over Zoom from the lush green garden of her family’s house in Kingston, where she is visiting. But the soundtrack of her adolescence — the hip-swaying hits of local artists like Lady Saw, Shabba Ranks and Chaka Demus & Pliers that she heard at parties — left the more lasting impression. “Dancehall will forever be influential to me,” she says of the genre, which has roots in music of the African diaspora. “It’s like this explosion of exuberance.”

headline: White Police Officer to Face Charge She Intimidated Son’s Black Friend
abstract: Officer Patricia Lio of the Milton Police Department in Massachusetts is accused of berating her son’s 14-year-old Black friend about his stance on the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: A white Massachusetts police officer will face criminal charges in connection with an off-duty episode in which she is accused of berating a Black teenager, a friend of her son, over his support of the Black Lives Matter movement, a court official ruled this week.

headline: Helping Homeless People in N.Y.C. Get Stimulus Payments
abstract: Many homeless people in the city did not receive their stimulus checks, but it's not too late.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Here’s What New York’s Mayoral Candidates Would Do About the Police
abstract: Some candidates in the Democratic primary want to cut $1 billion or more from the N.Y.P.D. budget, while others have more moderate proposals, frustrating activists.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Target says it will spend more than $2 billion with Black-owned businesses.
abstract: The company joins a growing list of retailers that have pledged to increase their economic support of companies owned by Black entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: Target will spend more than $2 billion with Black-owned businesses by 2025, it announced on Wednesday, joining a growing list of retailers that have promised to increase their economic support of such companies in a bid to advance racial equity in the United States.

headline: Is an Activist’s Pricey House News? Facebook Alone Decides.
abstract: The New York Post has complained that Facebook is blocking and downplaying its stories. But the platform doesn’t pay any special deference to journalists.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, I learned a new way to get a news article erased from much of the internet.

headline: Girl, Wash Your Timeline
abstract: Rachel Hollis, the best-selling author and motivational speaker, built a blockbuster business sharing her “authentic” self. Then things got a little too real.
lead_paragraph: May 14 was supposed to mark Rachel Hollis’s return to her happy place: a stage in front of an adoring audience.

headline: Does SoHo, Haven for Art and Wealth, Have Room for Affordable Housing?
abstract: The Manhattan neighborhood is locked in a contentious battle with city officials over whether, and how, it should change.
lead_paragraph: As a child growing up in SoHo, Akeela Azcuy remembers seeing her father, the drummer Rashied Ali, talking music with neighbors like the renowned jazz performer Ornette Coleman, who lived over on Prince Street.

headline: Oscars Ratings Plummet, With Fewer Than 10 Million Tuning In
abstract: Sunday night’s pandemic-restricted telecast drew 58 percent fewer viewers than last year’s record low.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For the film industry, which was already fighting to hold its place at the center of American culture, the Nielsen ratings for Sunday night’s 93rd Academy Awards came as a body blow: About 9.85 million people watched the telecast, a 58 percent plunge from last year’s record low.

headline: In ‘Exterminate All the Brutes,’ Raoul Peck Takes Aim at White Supremacy
abstract: After the success of “I Am Not Your Negro,” HBO gave Peck carte blanche for his next big project. What resulted is a sweeping meditation on colonialism and the nature of truth itself.
lead_paragraph: After completing his 2016 documentary “I Am Not Your Negro,” the director Raoul Peck felt he’d had his say on the topic of U.S. race relations. Or at least his subject, the writer James Baldwin, had.

headline: Charli Collier Is the No. 1 Pick in the W.N.B.A. Draft
abstract: Collier, a 6-foot-5 center from the University of Texas, was selected by the Dallas Wings, which also picked Awak Kuier and Chelsea Dungee in the first round.
lead_paragraph: Charli Collier, a center from the University of Texas, was selected No. 1 over all by the Dallas Wings in the W.N.B.A.’s virtual draft on Thursday, fulfilling the dream of her late father that she be the top pick. Collier, who is from Texas and was widely projected to be the first pick, averaged 19 points and 11.3 rebounds per game in the 2020-21 season.

headline: A lawyer and judge in the Chauvin trial suggest comments by Maxine Waters could be grounds for appeal.
abstract: Representative Maxine Waters said that demonstrators should “get more confrontational” if the jury doesn’t return a guilty verdict.
lead_paragraph: Following closing arguments on Monday, both Derek Chauvin’s lawyer and Judge Peter A. Cahill suggested that a Democratic congresswoman’s comments suggesting that racial justice protesters should “get more confrontational” could affect the outcome of the former officer’s trial.

headline: How Teachers Are Exploring the Derek Chauvin Trial With Students
abstract: In Minneapolis, where George Floyd was killed, educators have used the trial as an opportunity to help their students examine the complex issues of race, policing and the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: At this point in the school year, Lacrissha Walton typically focuses her social studies lessons on the 50 U.S. states and their capitals. But last week, the Minneapolis teacher scrawled a question that had nothing to do with geography on her fourth-grade classroom’s whiteboard: “Have you watched the Derek Chauvin trial?”

headline: Colorado Judge Will Resign After Using Racial Slur, Court Says
abstract: Natalie T. Chase, a District Court judge in Arapahoe County, agreed to step down after the Colorado Supreme Court censured her for insensitive remarks to Black judicial employees.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado judge has agreed to resign after the state Supreme Court censured her for repeatedly using a racial slur and making insensitive comments to Black judicial employees regarding police brutality and systemic racism.

headline: Late Night Addresses the Derek Chauvin Verdict
abstract: “It’s hard to celebrate, because a man is still dead, but there is a sense of relief that at least this one injustice was not compounded with indifference,” said a somber Stephen Colbert.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Republicans’ Fake War Against ‘Woke Capital’
abstract: If they really wanted to help the working class, there is plenty they could do.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party may not have much of an agenda to sell to the public right now, but it does have an enemy with which to rally its troops: “woke capital,” or those corporations that have adopted progressive rhetoric on social issues and used their platforms to support voting rights or back movements like Black Lives Matter.

headline: After a Year of Turmoil, Elite Universities Welcome More Diverse Freshman Classes
abstract: The aftermath of the George Floyd protests and a decreased reliance on standardized tests have led to more diverse admissions at elite universities.
lead_paragraph: Jianna Curbelo attends a career-focused public high school in New York City, works at McDonald’s and lives in the Bronx with her unemployed mother, who did not graduate from college.

headline: Tim Scott, delivering the G.O.P. rebuttal, accuses Biden of abandoning bipartisanship.
abstract: Mr. Scott leaned heavily on his extraordinary biography to argue against Mr. Biden’s infrastructure plan.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina on Wednesday night dismissed President Biden’s latest ambitious economic package and accused him of abandoning his pledge to work with Republicans, advancing instead a divisive and partisan agenda.

headline: Letter From the Family of Tamir Rice to Attorney General Merrick B. Garland
abstract: The family of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was shot and killed in 2014 by the Cleveland police, has asked Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to reopen the Justice Department’s investigation into the shooting.
lead_paragraph: The family of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was shot and killed in 2014 by the Cleveland police, has asked Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to reopen the Justice Department’s investigation into the shooting.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: This week, the late-shows hosts took on the Matt Gaetz scandal and Biden's announcement about U.S. troops in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: This week, the late-shows hosts took on the Matt Gaetz scandal and Biden's announcement about U.S. troops in Afghanistan.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: Hosts discussed Earth Day, the Chauvin verdict and the MyPillow guy’s new social media platform.
lead_paragraph: Hosts discussed Earth Day, the Chauvin verdict and the MyPillow guy’s new social media platform.

headline: As protests against police violence surge, Florida passes a bill to combat ‘public disorder.’
abstract: Critics call the measure racist and anti-democratic, and say it could criminalize peaceful demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-led Florida Senate on Thursday passed a bill that was intended to crack down on rioting, but that critics said would criminalize the peaceful demonstrations against police brutality that have swept across the state and the country since the killing of George Floyd last year.

headline: ‘We Matter’: A Moment of Catharsis After the Derek Chauvin Verdict
abstract: People across the country reacted with a variety of emotions to the news of the former officer’s conviction on all charges in the killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: [Follow live news updates from Derek Chauvin’s sentence hearing.]

headline: Seth Meyers: Chauvin Verdict Confirms ‘What We Saw With Our Own Eyes’
abstract: “As we’ve explained on this show many times before, the culture and system of policing in this country must be dismantled and reformed,” Meyers said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Georgia Is Facing a Political Onslaught. At the Masters, It’s Business as Usual.
abstract: Major League Baseball pulled its All-Star Game from the Atlanta area, but Georgia’s most cherished sporting event remains firmly rooted in the state.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Georgia and its new elections law are caught up in a political riptide.

headline: Late Night Gets Serious About Police Brutality
abstract: Trevor Noah and Stephen Colbert criticized officers’ use of force against Black men, citing two cases in which traffic stops turned violent.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: ‘More Than Just Tragic’: Ma’Khia Bryant and the Burden of Black Girlhood
abstract: Two academics discuss the fatal shooting of the 16-year-old in Columbus, Ohio, highlighting the different standards that young Black girls are held to.
lead_paragraph: — Brittney Cooper, the author of “Eloquent Rage” and associate professor of women’s and gender studies and Africana studies at Rutgers University

headline: With Closing Arguments Finished, Chauvin’s Fate Is Now in Jury’s Hands
abstract: The jury will be sequestered in a hotel during their deliberations over Derek Chauvin, who is charged with second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The two sides in one of the nation’s most closely watched police brutality trials returned one last time to the graphic video of George Floyd’s final moments on Monday, with the prosecution asking jurors to “believe your eyes” and the defense warning them not to be “misled” by a freeze-frame view.

headline: Prosecutor in Derek Chauvin trial makes closing argument: ‘This wasn’t policing, this was murder.’
abstract: In his last comments to jurors before they begin deliberating over a verdict, a Minnesota prosecutor argued that Mr. Chauvin had acted with cruelty and indifference unbefitting of a police officer.
lead_paragraph: In his last comments to jurors before they begin deliberating over a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial, a Minnesota prosecutor argued that Mr. Chauvin had acted with cruelty and indifference unbefitting of a police officer and should be convicted of murder in George Floyd’s death.

headline: Let’s Cut Our Ridiculous Defense Budget
abstract: President Biden wants to change the paradigm. That may be easier than changing the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: President Biden loves spending money. Last month, he signed the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan to stimulate the economy. Now he’s pushing the $2 trillion American Jobs Plan to rebuild the nation’s infrastructure. He vows to follow that with the American Families Plan to improve health care, child care and education, which could cost billions or trillions more.

headline: A Teacher Marched to the Capitol. When She Got Home, the Fight Began.
abstract: Kristine Hostetter was a beloved fourth-grade teacher. Then came the pandemic, the election and the Jan. 6 riot in Washington.
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. — Word got around when Kristine Hostetter was spotted at a public mask-burning at the San Clemente pier, and when she appeared in a video sitting onstage as her husband spoke at a QAnon convention. People talked when she angrily accosted a family wearing masks near a local surfing spot, her granddaughter in tow.

headline: Michelle T. Boone Named President of Poetry Foundation
abstract: Boone, a former cultural commissioner for Chicago, will take the helm after tumult over racial justice at the foundation, one of the country’s wealthiest literary organizations.
lead_paragraph: Michelle T. Boone, a former commissioner of cultural affairs for the City of Chicago, has been named president of the Poetry Foundation, nearly a year after the previous president resigned amid an intense outcry over the Chicago-based organization’s perceived lack of commitment to social justice.

headline: On the Oscars Red Carpet: A Lot of Style, Little Substance
abstract: A return to in-person awards meant a return to fashion form for many celebrities. Have we learned nothing from the past year?
lead_paragraph: The 93rd annual Academy Awards were a night of historic firsts: first woman of color to win the directing Oscar; first Black women to win the makeup and hairstyling Oscar; oldest woman ever to win an Oscar; first Korean actor to win an Oscar. But in at least one area it was more like same-old, same-old: the red carpet.

headline: Sheriff’s Deputy Kills Black Man in North Carolina
abstract: The Pasquotank County Sheriff’s Office said that a deputy who was executing a search warrant and an arrest warrant fatally shot Andrew Brown Jr. in Elizabeth City. Residents gathered at the scene to demand answers.
lead_paragraph: A sheriff’s deputy shot and killed a Black man on Wednesday morning in Elizabeth City, N.C., while executing a search warrant and an arrest warrant on drug charges, the authorities said.

headline: Hollywood’s Anti-Black Bias Costs It $10 Billion a Year
abstract: If the industry won’t change on principle, it can at least change for the money. Reform would enrich people of color, and everyone else.
lead_paragraph: Days after a Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin, suffocated George Floyd and the video went viral, I watched my social media feed fill with blackout tiles and corporate publicity statements. They poured in from every industry, proclaiming solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement. Hollywood — where I have worked for almost two decades — was no exception.

headline: Georgia Sheriff Faces Civil Rights Charges Over Use of Restraint Chairs
abstract: Clayton County Sheriff Victor Hill is accused of ordering detainees to be strapped down for hours at a time as punishment, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: An Atlanta-area sheriff with a history of legal troubles faces federal civil rights charges for ordering several detainees to be strapped to restraint chairs for hours at a time even though they posed no danger to deputies, prosecutors said.

headline: Thousands Protest Against Policing Bill in Britain, With Clashes in London
abstract: Protesters have rallied across cities in England and Wales to denounce new legislation that would give the police more powers to dislodge demonstrators at gatherings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thousands of people protested Saturday in several cities across England and Wales against a sweeping crime and policing bill, with some in London clashing with the police in scenes that may further fuel a raging national debate over law enforcement tactics in Britain.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A jury finds Derek Chauvin guilty.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer, was found guilty yesterday on all three charges he faced in the death last year of George Floyd, capping one of the most-watched trials in the U.S. in recent memory. Follow live reactions.

headline: New Yorkers React to Derek Chauvin Verdict
abstract: New York residents and public figures responded with surprise, elation and resignation.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: English Soccer Will Boycott Social Media to Protest Online Abuse
abstract: The boycott, set to begin on Friday, is the most direct effort yet by a sport to pressure social media companies like Twitter, Instagram and Facebook to take action against abuse.
lead_paragraph: English soccer will conduct a social media blackout this weekend to protest “the ongoing and sustained discriminatory abuse received online by players and many others connected to football.”

headline: ‘God Knows What’s Going to Happen’: Minneapolis Braces for Verdict in Floyd’s Death
abstract: Businesses boarded up and residents held their breath, fearing a repeat of last year’s unrest if the jury brings back a decision that the public sees as unjust.

headline: Thank God for the Poets
abstract: Their words remind us that suffering is not our only birthright. Life is also our birthright — life and love and beauty.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When the poet Amanda Gorman stepped to the lectern at President Biden’s inauguration, she faced a much-diminished crowd of masked people on the National Mall, but she was speaking directly to the heart of a bruised nation:

headline: How You Can Help the Climate This Earth Day
abstract: Thursday: Reducing and recycling can still go a long way. Plus, a surprising pandemic shortage.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: When Blackness Is a Superpower
abstract: From Falcon to Black Panther to a potential new Superman, a wave of rejuvenated heroes, reimagined by Black creators, are rewriting superhero mythologies.
lead_paragraph: After the success of the Star Wars series “The Mandalorian” and the Marvel series “WandaVision,” the bar was set high for “The Falcon and the Winter Soldier.” But the series that focuses on two secondary characters — one Black and one white — from the Captain America comic book story line surpassed those expectations as the most watched premiere in Disney+ history. As the show’s first season comes to an end on Friday, its success can be seen as part of a wave of Black superheroes that have conquered our screens and comic book pages in recent years, in numbers — and with a nuance — never seen before.

headline: Joe Biden Has Something Else He’d Like to Transform
abstract: Next up? Early childhood education.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: President Biden has a big speech coming up this week, Bret. Before we delve deep — or, hey, maybe at least deepish — can I use it as an excuse to talk for a minute about Walter Mondale?

headline: ‘Sense of Disappointment’ on the Left as the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Unfolds
abstract: Even as New York has veered toward the left, two more-moderate candidates, Andrew Yang and Eric Adams, lead the mayoral race.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: M.L.B. Pulls All-Star Game From Georgia in Response to Voting Law
abstract: The move served as a warning to Republicans in other states who are trying to restrict voting, and is likely to put new pressure on other organizations and corporations to consider pulling business out of Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball sent a warning shot on Friday to Republicans considering new laws to restrict voting, pulling its summer All-Star game out of suburban Atlanta in a rebuke to Georgia’s new election rules that will make it harder to vote in the state’s urban areas.

headline: ‘This is not the end,’ Minnesota’s attorney general says after a guilty verdict.
abstract: The state’s case, which relied heavily on video evidence from bystanders, is a major victory for Keith Ellison and his team.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison, the lead prosecutor in the state’s case against Derek Chauvin, said during a news conference on Tuesday that “this is not the end,” and that his office expects to present another case this summer.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘As New Police Reform Laws Sweep Across the U.S., Some Ask: Are They Enough?’
abstract: In this lesson, students will consider efforts to reform policing since the killing of George Floyd, then share their own opinions on reimagining public safety.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “As New Police Reform Laws Sweep Across the U.S., Some Ask: Are They Enough?” by Steve Eder, Michael H. Keller and Blacki Migliozzi

headline: A Surprise Ending for the Oscars’ Inclusive Night
abstract: Six years after #OscarsSoWhite, a diverse roster of artists won awards, though Anthony Hopkins’s win over Chadwick Boseman as best actor surprised many.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a break with tradition, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences decided to end its Oscars ceremony on Sunday with the prize for best actor instead of the one for best picture.

headline: Vijay Iyer’s New Trio Is a Natural Fit. Its Album Is ‘Uneasy.’
abstract: The pianist teamed up with the bassist Linda May Han Oh and the drummer Tyshawn Sorey for a record that came together during a period of tragedy and unrest.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Vijay Iyer composed the title track to his new trio album, “Uneasy,” back in 2011 for a collaboration with the dancer and choreographer Karole Armitage. It was still a few years before the 2016 presidential campaign, when so many of the country’s old wounds and resentments would burst onto public display, but he already felt some undercurrents stirring.

headline: Where to Stream ‘Nomadland’ and Other Big Oscar Winners
abstract: All of the Oscar winners can be watched at home. Here’s a guide.
lead_paragraph: Every single Oscar winner is available for home viewers to watch right now, including “Nomadland,” which won major prizes for best picture, best director and best actress, and has been streaming on Hulu for months. The big questions are where, how and how much: Some are exclusive to popular streaming services like Netflix, some are affordable rentals while a couple more recent releases are $19.99, and some can be streamed and bought but not rented while others can be rented but not bought. Sound confusing? The list of Oscar winners below will put you a click away from knowing all the options and discovering whether or not the Academy got it right.

headline: George Floyd’s Girlfriend Says Opioid Addiction Was a Struggle They Shared
abstract: The testimony was partly an effort by the prosecution to show that Mr. Floyd had a high tolerance for fentanyl, which could undercut any argument that he died of a drug overdose.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — They met one evening four summers ago, and she was instantly drawn to his “great, deep, Southern voice.” She gave him her phone number that night, and they became close, exploring the city’s sculpture garden and its vibrant restaurant scene. Soon she was simply calling him “Floyd,” just like his friends did.

headline: Sports world celebrates Chauvin verdict amid controversy over Raiders’ ‘I can breathe’ tweet.
abstract: Davis said: “If I offended the family, then I’m deeply, deeply disappointed.”
lead_paragraph: The reverberations throughout the sports world came swiftly after a jury in Minnesota convicted Derek Chauvin on Tuesday of murdering George Floyd, as athletes, teams and leagues weighed in on the verdict in a case that had reignited fierce debate about racism and policing in the United States.

headline: ‘I Could Feel Their Pain’: A Juror on the Chauvin Trial Speaks Out
abstract: She was known as Juror 96 and sat through three weeks of testimony, but Lisa Christensen didn’t get to decide Derek Chauvin’s fate. She was selected as an alternate.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Lisa Christensen stood feet from the blue angel painted on a patch of pavement she had become intimately familiar with over the past month. Under the spittle of rain droplets, she clasped her hands in front of her chest and said a prayer to George Floyd.

headline: On the Scene: Week 1 of the Trial of Derek Chauvin
abstract: Times photographers captured the events across Minneapolis as the trial over the death of George Floyd began.
lead_paragraph: Minneapolis was a city of protest and remembrance during the first days of the trial of Derek Chauvin, the white former police officer who is on trial in the death of George Floyd, the Black man whose neck he knelt on for more than nine minutes during an arrest last May.

headline: Democrats and Republicans No Longer Speak the Same Language
abstract: A dictionary for these polarized times.
lead_paragraph: President Biden campaigned on a promise to unify America. An inspiring goal, to be sure, but one that ain’t anywhere close to happening. Decades of polarization, turbocharged by the us-versus-them philosophy of former President Donald Trump, have left the nation so divided that it can feel as though the two political teams are not only talking past each other but speaking in entirely different tongues.

headline: His Fence Says ‘Black Lives Matter.’ His City Says Paint Over It.
abstract: West St. Paul, Minn., says the nearly 75-foot message violates multiple portions of city code. The conflict is brewing as the Twin Cities region uneasily awaits a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial.
lead_paragraph: The colorful mural, adorned with hearts, a portrait of a local activist and the words “Black Lives Matter,” stands out at a busy intersection in West St. Paul, a community nestled against the Twin Cities. It is a cherished symbol for many Black residents, a site of reflection and pride.

headline: As New Police Reform Laws Sweep Across the U.S., Some Ask: Are They Enough?
abstract: States have passed over 140 police oversight bills since the killing of George Floyd, increasing accountability and overhauling rules on the use of force. But the calls for change continue.
lead_paragraph: In February, Illinois enacted a law that rewrote many of the state’s rules of policing, and mandated that officers wear body cameras. In March, New York City moved to make it easier for citizens to sue officers. This month, the Maryland legislature — which decades ago became the first to adopt a Law Enforcement Officers’ Bill of Rights — became the first to do away with it.

headline: What Might Bring Changes to Policing in Minneapolis?
abstract: The Justice Department has opened up a new avenue for potentially major policy shifts in the city.
lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin had worked for almost two decades at the Minneapolis Police Department, amassing a history riddled with accusations of abuse, before he murdered George Floyd on May 25, 2020.

headline: More Businesses Are Standing for Justice
abstract: The corporate response to civil rights has changed over the years.
lead_paragraph: Andrew here. Yesterday’s guilty verdict against George Floyd’s murderer, a former Minneapolis police officer, was a symbol of something profound: a demonstrable shift in the way this country, increasingly supported by business, has strived for civil rights.

headline: Guard Watched as Man Hanged Himself in Jail, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Capt. Rebecca Hillman was charged with criminally negligent homicide in the death, which has added to criticism of New York City’s jail system.

headline: ‘A Horrendous Tragedy’: The Chaotic Moments Before a Police Shooting in Columbus
abstract: New video and 911 calls shed light on what led to the fatal shooting of 16-year-old Ma’Khia Bryant, who the police said was wielding a knife when an officer fired four shots at her.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — It was Valentine’s Day when Ma’Khia Bryant, 16, moved into the foster home where her younger sister had lived for more than a year. The girls were close, and would dance and make TikTok videos together, while Ms. Bryant nurtured a constant hope: to one day live again with her biological mother.

headline: State Department authorizes U.S. embassies to fly the Pride Flag.
abstract: The action reversed a decision by the Trump administration, which rejected requests from embassies to raise it on their flag poles during the month of June, which in the United States and many other countries is Pride month.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken has authorized U.S. diplomatic missions across the world to fly the rainbow pride flag on the same pole as the American flag at embassies and consulates, according to a State Department cable reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Should Biden Emphasize Race or Class or Both or None of the Above?
abstract: A new paper heats up an old debate.
lead_paragraph: Should the Democratic Party focus on race or class when trying to build support for new initiatives and — perhaps equally important — when seeking to achieve a durable Election Day majority?

headline: Hundreds of Companies Unite to Oppose Voting Limits, but Others Abstain
abstract: Amazon, Google, G.M. and Starbucks were among those joining the biggest show of solidarity by businesses over legislation in numerous states.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, BlackRock, Google, Warren Buffett and hundreds of other companies and executives signed on to a new statement released on Wednesday opposing “any discriminatory legislation” that would make it harder for people to vote.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Guilty on all counts.

abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how schools across the country are addressing the trial of the former police officer charged with the murder of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Teachers: Have you talked about the Derek Chauvin trial in your classroom already? How are you incorporating the trial and upcoming verdict into your curriculum, if at all? What are you weighing as you decide if, when and how to address it? Let us know us know what lessons and activities you have used.

headline: Teachers Address Derek Chauvin’s Guilty Verdict
abstract: After a tumultuous year, classrooms are talking about the murder of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, many teachers will have a big topic to discuss with their students: the news that a jury convicted Derek Chauvin of murder for the killing of George Floyd. We reached out to some of the educators who have been in touch with this newsletter to see how they’ll handle it.

headline: How the Trial Over Floyd’s Death Flipped the Script for Black Victims

abstract: It’s report card time for the Biden administration. Have the president’s actions met your expectations?
lead_paragraph: When President Biden took office in January, we asked students what the new administration’s priorities should be. We heard from teenagers who wanted Mr. Biden to distribute coronavirus vaccines, support veterans, address police brutality, curb climate change and prioritize unity and bipartisanship.

headline: Charlottesville Can Remove Confederate Statues, High Court Rules
abstract: Monuments to the Confederate generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson are not protected by state law and can come down, the Virginia Supreme Court ruled on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the city of Charlottesville can remove statues of two Confederate generals, including one of Robert E. Lee that was at the center of a deadly white nationalist rally in 2017.

headline: Why Settle for Boring Glassware?

abstract: After the deaths of Breonna Taylor and George Floyd and other instances of violence against Black people, many athletes engaged in activist efforts last year.

abstract: Black Pound Day was created to find a sustainable way to support Black-owned businesses after the Black Lives Matter street protests faded.

headline: Why This N.Y.P.D. Detective Is Suing a Protester
abstract: In an unusual move, Detective Vincent Cheung is suing a man who hurled racist insults at him. The lawsuit raises thorny questions about free speech.
lead_paragraph: When demonstrations against racism and brutality in policing filled New York’s streets last summer, the police confronted protesters with tactics so aggressive and at times violent that a remorseful Mayor Bill de Blasio later issued a public apology.

headline: Facebook, preparing for Chauvin verdict, to limit posts that might incite violence.
abstract: The company said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Monday said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with the murder of George Floyd, to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.

headline: ‘The 2021 Oscar Nominated Short Films’ Review: Major Issues in Brief
abstract: From social justice themes to stories about grief and reckoning with the past, this year’s nominated shorts get serious.
lead_paragraph: This year, the Oscar-nominated short films are being presented in three programs: live action, animation and documentary. Each program is reviewed below by a separate critic.

headline: Breonna Taylor Show Puts Art Museums on a Faster Track
abstract: Assembled in a mere four months, pivoting off an important national event, the Speed Museum offers a new, relevant model for aging institutions.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — People talk a lot about getting back to pre-Covid normal. But our traditional art museums can forget about that. After a year of intense racial justice reckoning, a paralyzing pandemic and crippling economic shortfalls, aging hidebound institutions are scrambling just to stay afloat. And the only way for them to do so is to change. Strategies for forward motion are needed. One is in play here at the Speed Art Museum, in the form of a quietly passionate show called “Promise, Witness, Remembrance,” which might, with profit, be studied by other institutions in survivalist mode.

headline: Is Big Business the Democrats’ New Best Friend?
abstract: When C.E.O.s speak out against Republican priorities, it isn’t the flip-flop of alliances it appears to be.

abstract: As I walk around my hometown, I see so many boarded up buildings. Who is really being protected?

abstract: Chris Magnus, the Tucson police chief who carried a Black Lives Matter sign at a protest, was chosen to lead Customs and Border Protection.

headline: Watching the Derek Chauvin Trial With Families Affected by Police Violence
abstract: What happened to George Floyd is the latest in a long line of incidents of police violence captured on camera. We watched the Chauvin trial with the families of Rodney King, Oscar Grant and Stephon Clark to see this moment in history through their eyes.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t watch the footage of my dad’s incident because it is torture,” said Lora Dene King, whose father, Rodney G. King, was brutally beaten by the police in Los Angeles. “Here it is 30 years later and nothing has changed.”

headline: Court Vindicates Black Officer Fired for Stopping Colleague’s Chokehold
abstract: Cariol Horne acted to keep a white officer from using what she saw as excessive force. Fifteen years later, a judge said her firing was wrong.
lead_paragraph: It was a cold November day in Buffalo when Officer Cariol Horne responded to a call for a colleague in need of help. What she encountered was a white officer who appeared to be “in a rage” punching a handcuffed Black man in the face repeatedly as other officers stood by.

headline: Amid Awakening, Asian-Americans Are Still Taking Shape as a Political Force
abstract: Divided by generation, ethnicity and class, but currently galvanized by a surge of racially motivated attacks, Asian-Americans are growing rapidly as political players.

headline: On TV, a tense wait, and then an emotional response.
abstract: Every major broadcast and cable news network — and even ESPN — broke into regular programming on Tuesday for live coverage of the Derek Chauvin verdict.
lead_paragraph: Every major broadcast and cable news network — and even ESPN — broke into regular programming on Tuesday for live coverage of the verdict, ensuring that millions of Americans watched in unison as a Minnesota jury found the former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty on all charges in the death of George Floyd.

headline: What Kind of Flag Can I Fly Outside My House?
abstract: If you live in a community with a homeowners association, chances are good that you may be limited to just the Stars and Stripes.
lead_paragraph: David Pendery’s rainbow pride flag had only been waving outside his house for a few days when a letter arrived ordering him to take it down.

headline: Gabriela Garcia Remembers the Women Who Helped Make Her a Best Seller
abstract: “Of Women and Salt” is a novel about sisters and mothers — and its author is an expert on these subjects.
lead_paragraph: MUJER POWER Gabriela Garcia dedicated her debut novel, “Of Women and Salt,” to Iraida Rosa López, her 101-year-old grandmother who emigrated to the United States from Cuba in 1968. In a photograph pinned at the top of Garcia’s Twitter feed, López is wearing jazzy sneakers and holding a Black Lives Matter sign; even without a neatly printed Spanish expletive, it would be clear that this is a woman with strong convictions.

headline: France Lawmakers Pass Contentious Bill Extending Police Powers
abstract: The legislation was criticized by civil rights groups and political opponents, who intend to challenge its constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French Parliament passed a contentious security bill on Thursday that extends police powers, despite criticism from political opponents and civil rights activists who have vowed to challenge the legislation before France’s Constitutional Council.

headline: $300,000 Homes in Massachusetts, Ohio and North Carolina
abstract: An 1876 clapboard cottage in New Bedford, a two-bedroom condo in Cincinnati and a Cape Cod-style house in Winston-Salem.
lead_paragraph: New Bedford is a coastal city of about 95,000 that was a 19th-century whaling capital. This house, in the downtown County Street Historic District, has easy access to stores, restaurants, bars, tea shops and bakeries. The New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park, a 13-block district that commemorates the area’s maritime heritage, is less than a mile east. Just beyond that is the Acushnet River, where ferry terminals provide service to Nantucket and other destinations. Buttonwood Park, a 97-acre park with a zoo, is less than a mile west.

headline: Maryland Passes Sweeping Police Reform Legislation
abstract: The measures, enacted over the objections of Gov. Larry Hogan, placed the state at the forefront of a national debate over police brutality and officers’ excessive use of force.
lead_paragraph: Maryland lawmakers voted on Saturday to limit police officers’ use of force, restrict the use of no-knock warrants and repeal the nation’s first Bill of Rights for law enforcement, taking sweeping action to address police violence after nationwide demonstrations following the death of George Floyd.

headline: Activism Was Unusual for Baseball, but Not for Sports
abstract: Pulled by public opinion and sometimes their own players, leagues and teams are wading in to issues around race and social issues as never before.
lead_paragraph: For major American sports leagues that long have taken pains to stay out of divisive issues around race and social activism, the past few years have seen a remarkable awakening.

headline: Simon & Schuster Says It Won’t Distribute Book by Officer Who Shot Breonna Taylor

headline: California Is Making Liberals Squirm
abstract: If progressivism can’t work there, why should the country believe it can work anywhere else?
lead_paragraph: You may have heard that San Francisco’s Board of Education voted 6 to 1 to rename 44 schools, stripping ancient racists of their laurels, but also Abraham Lincoln and Senator Dianne Feinstein. The history upon which these decisions were made was dodgy, and the results occasionally bizarre. Paul Revere, for instance, was canceled for participating in a raid on Indigenous Americans that was actually a raid on a British fort.

headline: Trump Loyalists Spurn ‘Failed Republican Establishment of Yesteryear’
abstract: At an annual gathering of conservatives, devotees of Donald J. Trump pledged their fealty to him and issued grave warnings about the political left.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — One month after Donald J. Trump left office, thousands of his conservative allies and other far-right leaders on Friday began trying to center the Republican Party around the grievances of his presidency, pushing false claims about the American voting system, denouncing what they called liberal cancel culture and mocking mask-wearing.

headline: Digidog, a Robotic Dog Used by the Police, Stirs Privacy Concerns
abstract: The New York Police Department has been testing Digidog, which it says can be deployed in dangerous situations and keep officers safer, but some fear it could become an aggressive surveillance tool.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A Russian court sentences Aleksei Navalny.
lead_paragraph: A Moscow court sentenced Aleksei Navalny, President Vladimir Putin’s loudest critic, to more than two years in prison on Tuesday for violating parole from a 2014 suspended sentence by not checking in with the authorities, including while he was in Germany recovering from being poisoned in August. The decision is likely to send him to a far-flung penal colony for the first time.

headline: ‘Right Now Feels So Long and Without Any End in Sight’

headline: Man Shoved by Officers During Protest Sues Buffalo Police

headline: Why William Barr Rejected a Plea Deal in the George Floyd Killing

lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It was a cherished ritual that Joyce Fernandes saved for the end of the shift of a job she despised.

headline: Bringing Stages to Storefronts in a Theater-Hungry City
abstract: Miami New Drama gave audiences a window on the “Seven Deadly Sins” when it took over part of a pedestrian mall for a production.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As the final performance of Miami New Drama’s “Seven Deadly Sins” ended Sunday night, the actors streamed onto Lincoln Road, thanking the company’s artistic director, Michel Hausmann. They had spent months performing separately, inside adjacent vacant storefronts on this South Beach pedestrian mall, to an audience that watched and listened from a distance.

headline: After Officer’s Racist Post, New York’s Top Judge Demands ‘Zero Tolerance’
abstract: A Buffalo area court officer did not face a disciplinary hearing after he wrote a Facebook post saying George Floyd “deserved what he got.”
lead_paragraph: Just days after George Floyd’s death, a court officer in New York posted two pictures side-by-side on his Facebook page.

headline: After the Riot, What’s the Future of Art in the Capitol?
abstract: Built largely by enslaved people, the building includes just one small object honoring their work.
lead_paragraph: In the culture wars that spilled over during President Donald Trump’s time in office, the most visible flash point was whether to preserve or destroy monuments depicting figures from America’s racist history.

headline: Can We Put Fox News on Trial With Trump?
abstract: Even if we can’t impeach media companies, we can do more to hold them accountable for sowing sedition.
lead_paragraph: As America debates whether to hold former President Donald Trump accountable for inciting insurrection, what about his co-conspirator Fox News?

headline: What’s a Dance Theater Without an Audience?
abstract: A food pantry or a place to vote — or a place to make dance with different expectations: “What we’ve taken off the table is the pressure of the result.”
lead_paragraph: At the Henry Street Playhouse on the Lower East Side, the seats are empty but the stage is crowded. The audience is gone, banned by pandemic restrictions, yet since last summer the stage has been covered every Tuesday in hundreds of bags of groceries, lined up to be delivered by stagehands, theater staff and artists to nearby housing projects and senior homes.

headline: Our Eighth Annual Student Editorial Contest
abstract: We invite middle school and high school students to write opinion pieces on the issues that matter to them. Contest dates: Feb. 23 to April 13.
lead_paragraph: Update, Nov. 24, 2021: We have published the announcement for our 2021-22 Editorial Contest.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Summer School, Outspoken Athletes and Zoom Mishaps
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked teenagers if they think summer school is a good solution for students who have fallen behind academically this year; if athletes should speak out on political issues; and if they have experienced any embarrassing Zoom mishaps.

headline: Atlanta Dream Are Sold After Players’ Revolt Against Kelly Loeffler
abstract: Renee Montgomery, a former Dream guard, is part of a group buying the W.N.B.A. team from Loeffler, the former Georgia senator who upset players by attacking the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Dream, the W.N.B.A. team whose players revolted against a co-owner, Kelly Loeffler, and campaigned against her in a Georgia Senate race she lost, are being sold to an ownership group led by two real estate executives and a former star player for the team.

headline: Public Buildings Set Ablaze in Chile After Police Shoot Street Juggler
abstract: Protesters were outraged by the killing, which was recorded on video. Ten public offices burned to the ground, leaving a city of almost 34,000 practically without public services.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Demonstrators angered by the fatal police shooting of a popular street juggler set several public buildings ablaze in southern Chile Friday night, leaving a city of almost 34,000 people practically without public services.

headline: Polk Awards Honor Pandemic Reporters
abstract: The Washington Post led all news organizations, with four prizes. The infectious-disease reporter Helen Branswell, of Stat, took the public service award for a yearlong chronicle of the coronavirus and its effects.
