lead_paragraph: Journalism on the coronavirus pandemic dominated the George Polk Awards, with nearly half the prizes in recognition of work by print, digital and television reporters who sounded warnings early in the year and later tracked the devastating effects on large swaths of society and those who suffered personally as the death count rose.

headline: The Real Rosa Parks Story Is Better Than the Fairy Tale
abstract: The way we talk about her covers up uncomfortable truths about American racism.
lead_paragraph: Mug shot No. 7053 is one of the most iconic images of Rosa Parks. But the photo, often seen in museums and textbooks and on T-shirts and websites, isn’t what it seems. Though it’s regularly misattributed as such, it is not the mug shot taken at the time of Mrs. Parks’s arrest in Montgomery, Ala., on Dec. 1, 1955, after she famously refused to give up her seat on a bus to a white passenger. It was, in fact, taken when she was arrested in February 1956 after she and 88 other “boycott leaders” were indicted by the city in an attempt to end the boycott. The confusion around the image reveals Americans’ overconfidence in what we think we know about Mrs. Parks and about the civil rights movement.

headline: How a Hard-Core Liberal Lawyer Joined the Pro-Trump Mob
abstract: W. McCall Calhoun Jr., who ran for office in Georgia as a Democrat, is a walking embodiment of his state’s political contradictions.
lead_paragraph: AMERICUS, Ga.— Over the past three decades, as the state around him turned ever more resolutely Republican, W. McCall Calhoun Jr. remained an outspoken and unwavering liberal. He gave money to Democrats, ran for office as a Democrat and zealously championed Democratic policies in social circles that were far from sympathetic. If friends admitted they voted for Donald J. Trump, his reaction could be blistering.

headline: Foreign Aid Is Having a Reckoning
abstract: The Black Lives Matter movement has given leaders from the Global South new traction for change.
lead_paragraph: Sending aid to Africa became popular in the 1980s, when a famine in Ethiopia prompted some of the most famous singers in the world to raise money for food aid with concerts and songs like “We Are the World.” Images of malnourished children with distended bellies primed an American public to support some of the most ambitious humanitarian relief efforts on record: airlifts of supplies to Sudan, which ran from 1989 to 2005, and a military intervention that aimed to deliver food to war-torn Somalia in the early 1990s. Such efforts have helped shaped outsiders’ perceptions of a diverse continent that is home to 54 countries and 1.3 billion people. Generations of American children were told to eat their vegetables “because there are starving children in Africa.”

headline: A YouTuber Shoots to Literary Fame in France, Ruffling Feathers
abstract: The social media star known as Léna Situations, 23, had a pretty eventful 2020. She racked up millions of followers, became a best-selling author — and attracted criticism from the Paris book world.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Léna Situations shot to fame in France by sharing fashion advice and tips for living a positive life with millions of her followers on social media.

headline: Watch Our Conversation about Diversity in Fashion
abstract: On March 11, Vanessa Friedman hosted a virtual event with Olivier Rousteing, Pierpaolo Piccioli and other industry leaders about the path to change.
lead_paragraph: The event was livestreamed on this page (directly above) and you can still watch the conversation if you missed it. If you prefer to read a summary of the event, we edited the text here.

headline: Behind the Weeknd’s Halftime Show: Nasal Swabs and Backup Plans
abstract: Putting on a Super Bowl halftime show is always a mammoth undertaking. The pandemic introduces many more logistical puzzles.
lead_paragraph: When the Weeknd headlines the Super Bowl halftime show on Sunday, the stage will be in the stands, not on the field, to simplify the transition from game to performance. In the days leading up to the event, workers have visited a tent outside Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Fla., to receive nasal swabs for Covid-19 tests. And though a smaller crew is putting on the show this year, the bathroom trailers have been going through three times as much water as usual — because of all that hand-washing.

headline: Takashi Murakami’s Smiling Flower Becomes a Hublot Watch
abstract: Bright colors are a hallmark of the Japanese artist’s creations, but in this case he chose black. With diamonds.
lead_paragraph: After collaborating on timepieces with brands like Louis Vuitton and Casio G-Shock, the Japanese artist Takashi Murakami wasn’t interested, at least initially, in creating a watch for Hublot.

headline: ‘Judas and the Black Messiah’: What to Know About the HBO Max Film
abstract: The Shaka King movie dramatizes the life and death of Fred Hampton, chairman of the Illinois Black Panther Party. Here’s a guide to the people and the issues of the day.
lead_paragraph: To Black Americans in the 1960s who were targeted and harassed by the police, 21-year-old Fred Hampton was an empowering figure.

headline: Blue Lives Matter Is Over
abstract: Once the Trump mob attacked officers, Republican hypocrisy was exposed.
lead_paragraph: Blue Lives Matter is officially dead. People may continue to chant and post the slogan, but it is dead. Senate Republicans killed it last week when they voted to acquit Donald Trump of inciting an insurrection that left one officer dead and 138 injured. (Two officers who responded to the insurrection later died by suicide.)

headline: He Threatened Pelosi. Agents Didn’t Wait to See if He Really Meant It.
abstract: After a “9/11 moment,” federal authorities have begun arresting people for domestic threats they might have just monitored in the past.
lead_paragraph: A Proud Boys supporter in New York accused of posting violent threats on the social media network Parler. A Colorado man charged with sending a text about “putting a bullet” in Speaker Nancy Pelosi. A man near Chicago implicated in a voice mail message about killing Democrats on Inauguration Day.

headline: What the Pandemic Revealed About ‘Progressive’ Prosecutors
abstract: At a time when radical change is needed most, too many have not been the heroes some hoped they would be.
lead_paragraph: In late September, with the Covid-19 pandemic raging, District Attorney Larry Krasner of Philadelphia, a leader of the so-called progressive prosecutor movement, spoke to a national virtual audience at the prestigious Atlantic Festival.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘In Cold Blood’ and ‘The Black Church’
abstract: Richard Brooks’s classic adaptation of Truman Capote’s “In Cold Blood” airs on TCM. And Henry Louis Gates Jr. looks at the history of African-American faith communities in a PBS documentary.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Southern Baptists Expel 2 Churches Over Sex Abuse and 2 for L.G.B.T.Q. Inclusion
abstract: In a fiery speech, the denomination’s president decried “fissures and failures and fleshly idolatries.”
lead_paragraph: The Southern Baptist Convention’s executive committee voted on Tuesday to expel four of its member churches, ousting two for policies that “affirm homosexual behavior” and the others for employing pastors who are convicted sex offenders.

headline: Give Dolly Parton a Statue Already
abstract: The Tennessee General Assembly’s vote to do so should be unanimous.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — To call the Republican supermajority of the Tennessee General Assembly extremist is merely to state a fact.

headline: Is This the Most Radical Film Ever Produced by Hollywood?
abstract: “Judas and the Black Messiah” is the rare Hollywood film to explore a vision of Blackness that has nothing to do with white audiences.
lead_paragraph: “Judas and the Black Messiah” is a very good — nearly great — movie about the charismatic Fred Hampton and the way the Black Panther Party was targeted by the United States government. Yet neither the standout performances from Daniel Kaluuya and Lakeith Stanfield nor the sensitive and insightful direction by Shaka King are the most remarkable aspects of the film: Not since Spike Lee’s 1992 biopic “Malcolm X” has there been a mainstream American film this thoroughly Black and radical.

headline: Why We Can’t Stop Talking About Betty Friedan
abstract: A 100th birthday celebration in honor of the feminist raises the question: What was Ms. Friedan’s legacy exactly? ‘As with everything Betty, it’s complicated.’
lead_paragraph: — Rebecca Jo Plant, a historian at the University of California, San Diego

headline: Police Forces Have Long Tried to Weed Out Extremists in the Ranks. Then Came the Capitol Riot.
abstract: At least 30 law enforcement officers from around the country took part in the rally on Jan. 6 that preceded the riot. Many are now being investigated.
lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, Sheriff Chris West of Canadian County, Okla., a large man whose uniform often includes a Stetson hat, a vest and a gold star badge, devoted his life to law enforcement.

headline: Learn About Lincoln and Attend a Symposium on the Power of Fashion
abstract: This week, celebrate Presidents’ Day, tune in to a discussion between two members of the Tuskegee Airmen Inc. and try a new recipe for Mardi Gras.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Vaccine Trials, Sports Without Spectators and a Chaotic Year
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked teenagers if they would volunteer for a Covid-19 vaccine trial, if they are missing live sports and how they have dealt with a chaotic year.

headline: Prince Harry and His Wife, Meghan, Expecting Second Child
abstract: The development is a joyful bit of news after a turbulent year in which the couple broke away from the British royal family, started new lives in California and suffered a miscarriage.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of Oprah’s Interview with Meghan and Harry]

headline: A New Generation Pushes Nashville to Address Racism in Its Ranks
abstract: A small contingent of country artists and industry players have been speaking up in a business that likes to shut down dissent.
lead_paragraph: Less than 30 minutes after TMZ posted a video of the country star Morgan Wallen using a racial slur on Feb. 2, Mickey Guyton, the only Black female country singer signed to a major label, tweeted her reaction: “The hate runs deep.”

headline: The Deep South Has a Rich History of Resistance, as Amazon Is Learning
abstract: Alabama is more than its shading on the electoral map.
lead_paragraph: The Deep South is not generally known for its labor agitation, which is why it might come as a surprise for some to learn that it is in Alabama where workers have mounted one of the largest and most aggressive efforts to unionize Amazon in recent memory.

headline: Bipartisan Senate Inquiry on Capitol Riot Will Begin With Scrutiny of Security Failures
abstract: A hearing on Tuesday will feature the testimony of the top two security officials at the Capitol on Jan. 6, who have since resigned, as well as police officials who responded to the riot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As House leaders haggle over the formation of a 9/11-style commission to investigate the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, a bipartisan group of senators is pressing ahead with a series of investigative hearings to scrutinize the security breakdowns that failed to prevent the deadly pro-Trump rampage.

headline: A Tense Lunar New Year for the Bay Area After Attacks on Asian-Americans
abstract: The attacks have renewed fears over a wave of anti-Asian violence and harassment that was spurred earlier in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The videos are graphic and shocking.

headline: The Economist Placing Value on Black Women’s Overlooked Work
abstract: Tracing community activism back a hundred years, Nina Banks says this labor by Black women should be counted as part of the economy.
lead_paragraph: Every year women do trillions of dollars’ worth of unpaid household work. In the United States alone, that total amounted to roughly $1.2 trillion in 2019, a figure nearly the size of the New York State economy.

headline: Should Athletes Speak Out On Social and Political Issues?
abstract: Do they have a responsibility to use their platform and influence to raise awareness? Or should they stick to sports?
lead_paragraph: Are you a sports fan? Do you follow tennis? What was your reaction to Naomi Osaka’s U.S. Open title win in September and her use of masks to honor Black victims of violence?

headline: Amazon’s Great Labor Awakening
abstract: Covid-19 has cemented the e-commerce giant’s hold on the economy — but it has also spurred employees all around the country to organize.
lead_paragraph: When Abdul Tokhi, a father of two small children, arrived in the United States from Afghanistan in 2017, a local church group helped him and his family find an apartment in Corona, a city in California’s Inland Empire — a 27,000-square-mile stretch of deserts, mountains, farmland and sprawling housing communities east of Los Angeles. The group collected furniture donations, bringing over sofas, tables and a bulky, outdated television. They also connected him to a hiring company, which landed him a job as a “picker” in an Amazon warehouse, a 12-mile drive from Corona in a town named Eastvale. He started at Amazon earning $12.25 an hour, while his wife stayed home to take care of the kids.

headline: Who Wants to Be Mayor of New York City?
abstract: The race for the next mayor of New York City may be one of the most consequential elections in a generation. Here are some of the leading candidates vying to run the nation’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: The race for the next mayor of New York City may be one of the most consequential elections in a generation. Here are some of the leading candidates vying to run the nation’s largest city.

headline: Read Trump’s Impeachment Defense Memo
abstract: In a 78-page brief submitted to the Senate, former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers put forward their first sustained legal defense since Mr. Trump was impeached by the House for the second time.
lead_paragraph: In a 78-page brief submitted to the Senate, former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers put forward their first sustained legal defense since Mr. Trump was impeached by the House for the second time.

headline: Indianapolis Museum of Art Apologizes for Insensitive Job Posting
abstract: The museum wrote that it was seeking a director who would work to maintain its “core, white art audience,” in addition to attracting a more diverse one.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields has edited and apologized for an employment listing that said it was seeking a director who would work not only to attract a more diverse audience but to maintain its “traditional, core, white art audience.”

headline: ‘It’s Embarrassing’: Marjorie Taylor Greene Tests the Limits of Some Voters
abstract: In her Georgia district, voters saw Ms. Greene as a conservative voice that would be impossible to ignore. Now the revelation of past social media posts has unsettled some who backed her.
lead_paragraph: SUMMERVILLE, Ga. — Billy Martin does not care much for politicians. But the retired teacher and coach liked what he heard from Marjorie Taylor Greene as she promised to take on Washington as a defiant force, intent on rattling the establishment.

headline: N.Y. Repeals Law That Critics Say Criminalized ‘Walking While Trans’
abstract: The anti-loitering law was designed to discourage street prostitution, but was viewed by L.G.B.T.Q. advocates as a cudgel to harass transgender people.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — For decades, a state loitering law, originally designed to discourage street prostitution, was interpreted far more broadly, resulting in what civil rights advocates said was a pattern of police harassment of anyone who they viewed as looking different or suspicious.

headline: Notes Toward Reinventing the American Orchestra
abstract: Flexible programming, broader racial representation and welcoming spaces would go a long way in recovering from pandemic closures.
lead_paragraph: Just think how overwhelming it will be to see the New York Philharmonic onstage at Lincoln Center this fall — when, we hope, it returns after an 18-month absence. The coronavirus pandemic has taught us never again to take live music for granted.

headline: How Andy Jassy, Amazon’s Next C.E.O., Was a ‘Brain Double’ for Jeff Bezos
abstract: Mr. Jassy, who will become Amazon’s chief this summer, has spent more than two decades absorbing lessons from Mr. Bezos.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In 2002, Andy Jassy, a young executive at Amazon, began closely shadowing Jeff Bezos, the founder of the online bookstore.

headline: Minneapolis Will Pay Influencers to Fight Misinformation During Officers’ Trials
abstract: The city will pay six social media influencers $2,000 each to share messages during the trials of Derek Chauvin and three other former police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: The City of Minneapolis plans to pay social media influencers to spread city-approved messages as part of an effort to combat misinformation during the upcoming trials of the four police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd, officials said.

headline: Promotions for Female Generals Were Delayed Over Fears of Trump’s Reaction
abstract: Under a Biden administration, the nominations are expected to go from the Pentagon to the White House within weeks and then to the Senate for approval.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last fall, the Pentagon’s most senior leaders agreed that two top generals should be promoted to elite, four-star commands.

headline: The Weeknd’s Super Bowl Halftime Show Breaks With Tradition
abstract: This time, the field won’t be swarming with fans crowding the stage. In fact, the stage won’t be on the field at all, but in the stands.
lead_paragraph: Whether it stars Al Hirt, Michael Jackson or Beyoncé, the Super Bowl halftime show has always taken center stage on the field.

headline: Mark Cuban Says He Told Mavericks to Stop Playing Anthem
abstract: The N.B.A. has long required the playing of the national anthem before games, but the league gave teams permission to skip the ritual this season.
lead_paragraph: Mark Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, said Tuesday night that he had instructed the team to stop playing the national anthem before its home games this season.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: Talking About Race and Racism in the Classroom Using The New York Times
abstract: In this webinar, Learning Network editors and educators share resources and strategies for engaging in these critical discussions.
lead_paragraph: Our students are living through history, from the protests following the killing of George Floyd while in police custody to the insurrection at the Capitol, all while dealing with a deadly pandemic that has disproportionately affected Black and brown communities. Though stories of police brutality and racial inequality are not new, the events of the last year have amplified the call to educators to create safe spaces for students to have critical conversations about race and racism. Navigating these conversations can be challenging. If you are struggling with where to start, or where to go next, you are not alone.

headline: The Rise of the Wellness App
abstract: They’re everywhere, but they can’t address the real problem: the alienation of 21st-century work.
lead_paragraph: Pandemic fatigue hits different. You know the feeling: You’ve been online all day, bouncing between video calls with colleagues and FaceTimes with family, maybe pausing for a quick vinyasa flow. Your eyeballs feel glassy, your brain parched and limbs sluggish. When your workday is finally over, you consider leaving the house but hear the voice of the comedian Elsa Majimbo — it’s a pandeeeemic — in your head. Instead, you get back online, maybe to listen to a talk, binge a costume drama, play a few hours of Fortnite, look up a dinner recipe or fire up Seesaw to help your kids with their homework. This is the sum of your life now. You’re essentially a husk. In sweatpants.

headline: Soccer Isn’t Blameless in Its Culture of Abuse
abstract: Leagues and teams have urged Twitter and Facebook to address the unfiltered hatred spewed on their platforms. But the game indulges, and sometimes even directs, that same outrage.
lead_paragraph: This time, it was Yan Dhanda. A few days ago, it was Axel Tuanzebe and Anthony Martial. Before that, it had been Alex Jankewitz and Romaine Sawyers. It happened to Lauren James, and to her brother, Reece, too. So pernicious, so constant is soccer’s problem with racist abuse that it is, at times, hard to keep up.

headline: California Man Died After Police Knelt on Him for 5 Minutes, Family Says
abstract: Shortly before he lost consciousness, Angelo Quinto, 30, asked officers not to kill him, according to a wrongful-death claim filed by his family against the City of Antioch.
lead_paragraph: When Maria Quinto-Collins started filming her son at her home in Antioch, Calif., on Dec. 23, he was already on the floor, unresponsive.

headline: Under Fire, a Portland Chef Tries to Build a Fairer Workplace
abstract: Gregory Gourdet has revamped his plans for a Haitian kitchen, after being caught up in a citywide furor over the treatment of restaurant workers.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — In an early-morning interview last February, back when it was still normal for strangers to meet for maskless conversation, Gregory Gourdet, one of Portland’s best-known chefs, shared his vision for 2020. Having just wrapped up his second stint as a contestant on “Top Chef,” he planned to accomplish two long-held goals: completing his first cookbook, “Everyone’s Table,” and opening his first restaurant, Kann.

headline: ‘The Black Church: This Is Our Story, This Is Our Song,’ by Henry Louis Gates Jr.: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Black Church: This Is Our Story, This Is Our Song,” by Henry Louis Gates Jr.
lead_paragraph: The right to vote was still a far‑off dream for many African Americans in postwar America, especially in the former Confederate states of the Deep South. Jim Crow laws, poll taxes, literacy tests, and violent terror tactics blocked African Americans’ access to full citizenship, despite the guarantees of the Fifteenth and Nineteenth Amendments, which barred discrimination by race or sex in the right to vote.

headline: With New Grand Jury, Justice Department Revives Investigation Into Death of George Floyd
abstract: As the state murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer charged in the death of George Floyd, approaches, the federal government has accelerated its own investigation.
lead_paragraph: A new federal grand jury has been empaneled in Minneapolis and the Justice Department has called new witnesses as part of its investigation of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer who will go on trial in state court next month on a murder charge for the death of George Floyd, according to two people with direct knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Cuomo Is Accused of Sexual Harassment by a 2nd Former Aide
abstract: The woman, 25, said that when they were alone in his office, Gov. Andrew Cuomo asked if she “had ever been with an older man.”
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — A second former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is accusing him of sexual harassment, saying that he asked her questions about her sex life, whether she was monogamous in her relationships and if she had ever had sex with older men.

headline: Barbara Dane’s Life of Defiance and Song
abstract: The 93-year-old musician and co-founder of the political label Paredon Records looks back on a history of resistance.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Dane keeps a copy of her four-inch-thick F.B.I. file in a binder in the living room of her Oakland home. One night in late December, the 93-year-old singer and activist’s daughter, Nina Menendez, was leafing through it and noticed a page she hadn’t spotted before: a Los Angeles Times clipping from a 1972 concert at the Ash Grove. Dane was the headliner that evening, where she first encountered the soulful folk band Yellow Pearl, whose music she would go on to release through her then-nascent record label, Paredon Records.

headline: Can a Comic Book Contain the Drama and Heat of Activism?
abstract: In his Graphic Content column, Ed Park looks at “The Black Panther Party,” a new history of the group, and “Come Home, Indio,” a memoir about growing up part Native American.
lead_paragraph: “Writing this book broke my heart,” David F. Walker admits in the afterword to his ambitious and informative graphic history THE BLACK PANTHER PARTY (Ten Speed, 183 pp., $19.99), crisply illustrated by Marcus Kwame Anderson. Founded in 1966 by Bobby Seale and Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther Party for Self-Defense was the most famous exponent of the Black Power movement. Its Ten Point Program (reproduced in full in these pages) was a forceful manifesto demanding “land, bread, housing, education, clothing, justice and peace” for the Black community. In the immediate wake of the horrific killings of Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery and George Floyd, Walker notes that “every single concern” the Panthers addressed — from police brutality to reparations — “is still relevant.”

headline: K.K.K. Member Who Drove Into Protesters Gets More Than 3 Years in Prison
abstract: When Harry H. Roger drove his pickup truck through protesters near Richmond, Va., his girlfriend’s 14-year-old son was in the vehicle with him, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A member of the Ku Klux Klan who drove his pickup truck through a crowd of Black Lives Matter protesters near Richmond, Va., last year while his girlfriend’s teenage son was in the vehicle was sentenced on Tuesday to three years and eight months in prison, officials said.

headline: Don’t Care for This Impeachment? Wait Until Next Year
abstract: Leaders of both political parties suggest that impeachments, Electoral College standoffs and Supreme Court nomination blockades may become frequent fights in American politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The second season of impeachment had ended less than a day earlier, but Republicans were already talking about next season. It sounded ominous.

headline: The Business of Basketball
abstract: Two new books chronicle the early stages of the evolution of the N.B.A. into the cultural and economic force it is today.
lead_paragraph: This originally appeared as part of the DealBook newsletter on Dec. 24, 2020. To sign up, click here.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Yuval Levin About the Future of the Republican Party
abstract: The Feb. 5 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode about the future of the Republican Party with guest Yuval Levin. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Spurning Calls to Resign, Liz Cheney Says G.O.P. Must Move Past Trump
abstract: Ms. Cheney, having fended off a challenge to her House leadership role, was defiant in defending her impeachment vote and called for Republicans to be “the party of truth.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming waded deeper into Republicans’ identity crisis on Sunday, warning her party on the eve of a Senate impeachment trial not to “look past” former President Donald J. Trump’s role in stoking a violent attack on the Capitol and a culture of conspiracy roosting among their ranks.

headline: Black History Month Is a Good Excuse for Delving Into Our Art
abstract: An African-American studies professor suggests ways to mark the month, from David Driskell’s paintings and Dance Theater of Harlem’s streamed performances to the rollicking return of “Queen Sugar.”
lead_paragraph: Black History Month feels more urgent this year. Its roots go back to 1926, when the historian Carter G. Woodson developed Negro History Week, near the February birthdays of both President Abraham Lincoln and the abolitionist Frederick Douglass, in the belief that new stories of Black life could counter old racist stereotypes. Now in this age of racial reckoning and social distancing, our need to connect with each other has never been greater.

headline: She’s the Dancing Force Behind Nia Dennis’s Viral Gymnastics Routines
abstract: Bijoya Das, a former gymnast with a deep relationship to dance, is training U.C.L.A. team members to let their personality light up the mat.
lead_paragraph: The Bruins gymnastics team of the University of California, Los Angeles, has more than one secret weapon. Yes, there’s Nia Dennis whose floor routine, an exuberant and powerful celebration of Black culture, went viral last week. But the team also has another rising star: the choreographer Bijoya Das.

headline: Tom Brady’s 7th Super Bowl Win Ends N.F.L.’s Most Challenging Year
abstract: The N.F.L. season persisted through challenges wrought by the coronavirus pandemic, political discord and a national reckoning on race to reach a familiar ending.
lead_paragraph: Every experiment sets out to prove a hypothesis, and Tom Brady formulated an outrageous one last March, when he chose to flee the empire he helped build in New England to sign with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

headline: New Anti-Racism Project Hopes to Push Soccer Past Gestures
abstract: Black players, joining with the charity Common Goal and backed by teams in North America, say they hope to reinvigorate the campaign against racism in the game.
lead_paragraph: Tony Sanneh saw the pattern while he was a player. It is precisely the same one he sees now, more than a decade after his retirement.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Flagging Effort to Hire Black Head Coaches
abstract: In the latest hiring cycle, Eric Bieniemy, the Kansas City Chiefs’ offensive coordinator, watched from the sideline as white peers were chosen as head coaches.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. can’t hide its Eric Bieniemy problem with poetry.

headline: Anti-Asian Racism Isn’t New
abstract: A frightening wave of attacks has Asian communities on edge. But I experienced street harassment long before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: One of the first English words I learned was an ethnic slur I heard whenever my parents and I walked around the city. I was 7 years old and had just moved to Brooklyn from China. One day, eager to show off, I turned to my father and declared, “We are chinks now!” in English. My father looked as if I had stabbed him. In a grave, low voice he told me to never utter that word again.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Heather McGhee about the Cost of Racism
abstract: The Feb. 16 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode about the cost of racism with Heather McGhee. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: America’s Brutal Racial History Is Written All Over Our Genes
abstract: Our country has struggled to reckon with the horrors of the past. Could DNA tests help?
lead_paragraph: The consumer genetics testing company 23andMe this month announced that it is going public through a merger with a company founded by the billionaire Richard Branson, in a deal that valued it at $3.5 billion. This was just the latest big deal for the industry: Last year, the Blackstone Group acquired a majority stake in Ancestry, a 23andMe competitor, for $4.7 billion.

headline: Berkeley Moves Closer to Ending Police Traffic Stops
abstract: Wednesday: A look at one city’s effort to remake policing. Also: Xavier Becerra’s confirmation hearings; and remembering Lawrence Ferlinghetti.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A Shared Sense of Alarm: Here’s What Americans Said About Two Impeachments
abstract: After a tumultuous year and the end of a presidency, voters say that Donald J. Trump’s second impeachment feels very different from his first.
lead_paragraph: It has been just over a year since former President Donald J. Trump first faced impeachment charges in the Senate, but it feels like a decade.

headline: The Story of ‘Team Molly’
abstract: While her daughter was hospitalized, one mother built more room for our national grief.
lead_paragraph: Strapped in the front seat of an ambulance as her daughter lay injured in the back, Kaye Steinsapir took out her phone and began to type.

headline: The Cost of Calling My Mom From Prison
abstract: For incarcerated people like me, access to communications comes at a steep price.
lead_paragraph: Mom will probably die before I get out of prison. Her Parkinson’s has advanced over the years, so she can’t visit. Until recently, I’d accepted that I’d never see her again. But lately, she’s been sending me 30-second videos: Mom and Magic, her fat, one-eyed black cat, showing me love through the seven-inch screen of a tablet made by a service provider called JPay. It costs her about a dollar to send each message; to me, they are priceless.

headline: Police Unions Lose Bid to Keep Disciplinary Records a Secret
abstract: A federal court ruling moves New York City closer to releasing a vast trove of records regarding police misconduct, a major milestone in a decades-long fight.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court in New York cleared the way on Tuesday for the city to release hundreds of thousands of police disciplinary records, a major milestone in a long and bitter political battle to open the records to public scrutiny.

headline: Is the Mayor of an Exclusive Hamptons Enclave a Squatter? It’s Complicated
abstract: Mayor Jesse Warren’s landlord happens to be one of his predecessors. He says a political rivalry is the reason he’s getting kicked out.
lead_paragraph: In one of the Hamptons’ most elite enclaves, amid shingle-style mansions and beachfront estates, a man has been living without authorization in a two-bedroom apartment in a house on David Whites Lane. His lease expired months ago. His latest rent check has gone uncashed.

headline: Ted Cruz, speaking at CPAC, jokes about his Cancún trip and tells media to ‘lighten up.’
abstract: “I gotta say, Orlando is awesome,” he said while opening his speech. “It’s not as nice as Cancún — but it’s nice!”
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Senator Ted Cruz has decided to own it.

headline: Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr. and the Voices of ‘Resistance’
abstract: The evocative podcast about people who “refuse to accept things as they are” is thriving in a historical blind spot of story-driven audio.
lead_paragraph: In late 2018, Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr. (pronounced “sai-eed”) heard something he couldn’t get out of his head.

headline: Exploring Race and Resistance for Young Audiences
abstract: A Harriet Tubman monologue, an animated “Sit-In” and a toy theater short about medical inequity deliver useful messages through varied mediums.
lead_paragraph: How can you build a hopeful future without first learning from the painful past?

headline: Henry Louis Gates Jr. on African-American Religion
abstract: Gates’s “The Black Church” recounts the foundational role of religion in the history of Black America.
lead_paragraph: THE BLACK CHURCHThis Is Our Story, This Is Our SongBy Henry Louis Gates Jr.

headline: A New Pregnancy and an Oprah Interview Refocus a Spotlight on Harry and Meghan
abstract: Buckingham Palace is steeling itself for embarrassing revelations, and there’s griping afoot in the British press.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, chose Valentine’s Day to announce they were expecting their second child, confirming the happy news with a dreamy black-and-white photo of themselves posed under a tree — a barefoot Harry stroking Meghan’s hair, her baby bump only slightly smaller than her smile.

headline: Shelia Washington Dies at 61; Helped Exonerate Scottsboro Boys
abstract: She fought for decades to get their names cleared from an egregious injustice in the Jim Crow South, and created a museum in their honor.
lead_paragraph: Shelia Washington was cleaning her parents’ room at their home in Scottsboro, Ala., in the 1970s when she discovered a paperback book hidden in a pillowcase underneath the bed.

headline: ‘Black Art: In the Absence of Light’ Reveals a History of Neglect and Triumph
abstract: An HBO documentary explores two centuries of art by African-Americans, and the path they forged for contemporary Black artists.
lead_paragraph: “This is Black art. And it matters. And it’s been going on for two hundred years. Deal with it.”

headline: A Pandemic Silver Lining for a San Francisco Institution
abstract: Friday: A look at how the de Young Museum in San Francisco is moving forward from the lockdowns. Also: Perseverance.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Life in a Day 2020’ Review: A Video Diary of a Difficult Year
abstract: This YouTube documentary seeks to be a time capsule during a period of great racial divide and pandemic distress.
lead_paragraph: Will we ever fully be ready to remember 2020? The masks. The quarantines. Racial injustice. So much death.

headline: Corey Johnson Exited the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race. Will He Run for Comptroller?
abstract: Mr. Johnson, the New York City Council speaker, said he expected to decide in the next two weeks whether to run to be the city’s fiscal watchdog.
lead_paragraph: Five months after dropping out of the race for mayor of New York City to focus on his mental health, Corey Johnson, the City Council speaker, said on Tuesday that he was considering a late entry into the race for city comptroller.

headline: 3 New Albums Retell the History of Black Composers
abstract: Recordings by the pianist Lara Downes, the Catalyst Quartet and the baritone Will Liverman aim to correct the canon.
lead_paragraph: Music can’t survive on its own. Composers not entrenched in the canon need support: from publishers, from foundations, from performers. Without these champions, it’s all too easy to slide into obscurity.

headline: Black History, Continued
abstract: This series explores pivotal moments and transformative figures in Black culture.
lead_paragraph: This series explores pivotal moments and transformative figures in Black culture.

headline: George Floyd Image With ‘You Take My Breath Away’ Prompts Internal Police Investigation
abstract: The valentine-style image was “passed around” the Los Angeles Police Department, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Police Department has opened an internal investigation after an inappropriate image of George Floyd, the man killed in police custody in Minneapolis last year, was reported to have been circulated in the department, officials said.

headline: Portland Welcomes Monument (Origin Unknown) to Black Man Who Reached Pacific in 1805
abstract: City officials say they have no idea who raised a monument to York, the enslaved Black man who traveled with Lewis and Clark, in the park where a statue of a conservative Oregonian had stood.
lead_paragraph: Over two years, York trekked some 8,000 miles from St. Louis to the Pacific Northwest and back, hunting, tracking, foraging and, at least once, voting as a Black man held in bondage by another, more famous member of the Lewis and Clark expedition.

headline: Gucci Is Staying in Trump Tower
abstract: Tiffany and other luxury companies have stepped away from deals with the former president’s organization, but not Gucci.
lead_paragraph: The day President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris were inaugurated in Washington, D.C., Melania and Donald Trump stepped off Air Force One in South Florida, bound for the confines of the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach.

headline: In the Battle for the Capitol, Veterans Fought on Opposite Sides
abstract: Military veterans trying to defend the Capitol on Jan. 6 were taunted by veterans in the pro-Trump mob who were storming it. Both felt they were doing their patriotic duty in a fractured country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Samuel Hahn of the Metropolitan Police Department struggled to hold back rioters storming the Capitol on Jan. 6, a group of veterans among the protesters repeatedly yelled the same refrain at him: “Remember your oath. You’re breaking your oath.”

headline: The Original ‘Real World’ Cast Reunites, Older but Still Not Polite
abstract: “The Real World Homecoming: New York” brings back the housemates from the inaugural season of the MTV series that set the standards of reality television, for better and for worse.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, Julie Gentry was in Atlanta helping her 19-year-old son, Noah, move into a house where he and four of his college classmates planned to live together while the pandemic kept them off-campus.

headline: The Activists Working to Remake the Food System
abstract: They’re committed not just to securing better meals for everyone, but to dismantling the very structures that have long exploited both workers and consumers.
lead_paragraph: AN ALTAR IS a sacred space, but you can make one anywhere, out of anything; out of what you’re given. On Dec. 5, a small group gathered in downtown Springdale, Ark., to line the cement steps of a public square with Our Lady of Guadalupe candles, chrysanthemums and white cards bearing the handwritten names of local poultry workers who had died of Covid-19. Under each name was the legend “¡Presente!” (“Here!”) at once invocation and exhortation, used in Latin America to proclaim the continuing presence of the dead among us, particularly victims of oppression. White helmets were set beside the cards, and blue vinyl aprons hung from the railings: part of the uniform the workers once wore as they stood shoulder to shoulder, breaking down up to 175 birds a minute even as the pandemic raged, in a city dominated by chicken and turkey plants and decreed by the state to be the Poultry Capital of the World.

headline: The Union Moved. The Beloved Mosaic Mural Couldn’t.
abstract: The architect David Adjaye spurred a painstaking re-creation of a doomed artwork for its new home — and added a homage to the union’s place in social justice history.
lead_paragraph: Not far from Times Square I walked west from Eighth Avenue on a recent afternoon to view a mural I had noticed on several occasions but never truly paused to appreciate.

headline: Take a Visual Tour Through California as It Reopens
abstract: Friday: Californians hope it’ll be their last time easing restrictions. See how it’s been going. Also: Capitol riot arrests; and SAG Award nominees.
lead_paragraph: (This article is part of the California Today newsletter. Sign up to get it delivered to your inbox.)

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Trump’s impeachment trial begins.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How a Trinidadian Communist Invented London’s Biggest Party
abstract: The Notting Hill Carnival was canceled last year. But it likely wouldn’t exist at all without the efforts of Claudia Jones.
lead_paragraph: For the Caribbean diaspora living in London, there may never have been a quieter weekend than the one in August 2020 that normally would have seen the Notting Hill Carnival.

headline: Trump Tower’s Neighbors Are Relieved as Barricades Come Down
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s presidency meant snarled traffic, blocked sidewalks and frequent protests outside his Manhattan home.
lead_paragraph: Traffic choked by cement barricades. Sidewalks blocked by police checkpoints. Protest after protest clogging the streets. For more than four years, life in the shadow of Donald J. Trump’s namesake tower on Fifth Avenue has been one intractable snarl.

headline: Making Black Lives, Not Just Black Deaths, Matter Onstage
abstract: The tragedy of racism is only part of the story in two very different plays from London that carry a dimension of meaning not usually seen in this country.
lead_paragraph: As far as theater is concerned, the pandemic has been a paradox, shrinking life down to lockdown bubbles and simultaneously expanding horizons. When you can stream plays from Europe as easily as from Brooklyn, the world seems more interconnected than in the past — tied together by bonds of humanity.

headline: Country Star Morgan Wallen Rebuked by Music Business After Using Racial Slur
abstract: The musician apologized in a statement to TMZ, saying, “I used an unacceptable and inappropriate racial slur that I wish I could take back.”
lead_paragraph: Morgan Wallen, one of country music’s biggest new stars, was swiftly rebuked on Wednesday by major radio stations, streaming services, record labels, fellow artists and the CMT network after a video surfaced of him using a racial slur.

headline: The Fun Police: Law Enforcement Comes to Carnival
abstract: Events like J’Ouvert in New York and Carnival in London have seen violent incidents. But the way they are policed says a lot about what happens when Black people gather.
lead_paragraph: J’Ouvert has its roots in denial.

headline: History Meets the Present on the ‘Judas and the Black Messiah’ Album
abstract: The songs inspired by Shaka King’s film about the 1969 police killing of the Illinois Black Panther Party chairman Fred Hampton mostly don’t appear in the movie, but they expand its story.
lead_paragraph: A movie’s message doesn’t have to end with the closing credits. Black filmmakers and musicians have been making the most of “inspired by” albums that are anything but afterthoughts; they boldly extrapolate from the story told onscreen. “Black Panther,” “The Lion King” and now “Judas and the Black Messiah” — the director Shaka King’s film about the 1969 police killing of the Illinois Black Panther Party chairman Fred Hampton — arrived with companion albums that connect fantasy and history to their repercussions in the here and now.

headline: How the Pandemic Is Coming to Prime Time (or Not)
abstract: As series roll out after pandemic delays, they’re trying to predict what audiences want: television that reflects our shared Covid reality? Or that provides a distraction from it?
lead_paragraph: Last June, when the “Grey’s Anatomy” writers room reconvened, virtually, after a longer than usual hiatus, Krista Vernoff, the longtime showrunner, asked whether or not the coming season should incorporate the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Over 160 Confederate Symbols Were Removed in 2020, Group Says
abstract: The Southern Poverty Law Center said more “symbols of hate” were removed from public property last year after the death of George Floyd than in the previous four years combined.
lead_paragraph: More than 160 Confederate symbols were removed from public spaces or renamed last year after the death of George Floyd, more than the previous four years combined, a watchdog group said on Tuesday.

headline: At the Super Bowl, the N.F.L.’s Social Message Is Muddled
abstract: The N.F.L. espoused racial unity and praised health care workers. But its inaction on racial diversity, its stereotypic imagery and its decision to host a potential superspreader event said something different.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. likes to project power and precision. Sideline catches are scrutinized with zoom lenses, first downs are measured in inches and Air Force jets fly over stadiums just as “The Star-Spangled Banner” reaches its peak.

headline: Why Are There So Few Monuments That Successfully Depict Women?
abstract: There’s still very little thought paid to how women are represented — as bodies and as selves.
lead_paragraph: IN HER 1792 TRACT “A Vindication of the Rights of Woman,” Mary Wollstonecraft argued that men and women should be educated together as equals, “for only by the jostlings of equality can we form a just opinion of ourselves.” Wollstonecraft was that rare thing in 18th-century England: a female public intellectual, one who argued passionately for women’s place in society. More than two centuries later, men and women jostle in all matters of public life, and yet their likenesses in the public space do not. In the United Kingdom, by one estimate, only some 3 percent of public statues are of nonroyal women. The number is thought to be about 7 percent in the United States, but in New York City, up until last summer, there were famously only five statues of historic women: the Catholic saint Joan of Arc, the former Israeli prime minister Golda Meir, the Modernist writer Gertrude Stein, the former first lady Eleanor Roosevelt and the abolitionist Harriet Tubman. If humankind vanished tomorrow and aliens arrived from another galaxy, they wouldn’t be faulted for believing that the whole of human history was composed of men on horseback.

headline: ‘Its Own Domestic Army’: How the G.O.P. Allied Itself With Militants
abstract: Actions taken by paramilitary groups in Michigan last year, emboldened by President Donald J. Trump, signaled a profound shift in Republican politics and a national crisis in the making.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — Dozens of heavily armed militiamen crowded into the Michigan Statehouse last April to protest a stay-at-home order by the Democratic governor to slow the pandemic. Chanting and stomping their feet, they halted legislative business, tried to force their way onto the floor and brandished rifles from the gallery over lawmakers below.

headline: A Teenager Went 3 Floors Down to Play Video Games. He Never Came Home.
abstract: Kahlik Grier, 16, was fatally shot in a random encounter in the stairwell of his Bronx apartment building, the police said.
lead_paragraph: It was a routine school night for Kahlik Grier, a 16-year-old student in the Bronx. After a day of online classes, he had Chinese takeout with his mother. Then he made his way to a friend’s apartment three stories below to play video games.

headline: Rampage at the Capitol
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has been attacking American democracy for much of his time as president.

headline: America in 2021: Racial Progress in the South, a White Mob in the Capitol
abstract: A jarring juxtaposition is forcing a 244-year-old nation to contend with its original conundrum: Whose democracy is it?
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The day after Georgia elected a Black descendant of sharecroppers and a young Jewish filmmaker to be U.S. senators, underscoring the rising political power of racial and religious minorities, the forces of white grievance politics struck back.

headline: How Do We Regain Trust in Institutions?
abstract: In “Mistrust,” Ethan Zuckerman looks at the forces in American society trying to work around eroding systems, and those trying to build them back up.
lead_paragraph: MISTRUSTWhy Losing Faith in Institutions Provides the Tools to Transform ThemBy Ethan Zuckerman

headline: Kirsten Gillibrand: ‘Yes, We Are Safe,’ I Texted From the Capitol
abstract: My fellow lawmakers and I just wanted to do our jobs and certify a free and fair election.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, I gathered with members of both chambers of Congress inside the Capitol to certify the electoral votes, a ceremonial and routine step in our nation’s process for a peaceful transition of power. As we sat in the Senate chamber listening to our colleagues, the Senate staff started to get up and move very quickly across the chamber. Vice President Mike Pence was abruptly removed from the presiding chair by his security detail, and Senator Chuck Grassley was shuttled across the floor into that seat. Moments later, a Capitol Police representative informed us the Capitol had been breached and that we were sheltering in place.

headline: Man With Extremist Right-Wing Views Is in Custody in Bomb Hoax
abstract: The man, 22, was under scrutiny after what looked like a bomb was found on the trunk of a Tesla at a Queens mall, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: The 911 call came in to the police around 7:30 a.m. on Monday: A car was stopped in the middle of the circular ramp at the Queens Place Mall parking garage, leaking fumes. A fuel canister with wires attached was sitting on the car’s trunk.

headline: The Inauguration Kept Crowds Out and Tried to Bring America In
abstract: At President Biden’s made-for-TV swearing-in, rituals of normalcy ran into reminders that these are anything but normal times.
lead_paragraph: Inauguration Day 2017 was notable, in part, for who wasn’t there: There were vast empty spaces on the National Mall, which the Trump Administration would soon deny in the opening shot of its four-year war on truth.

headline: We’ve Seen the Ugly Truth About America
abstract: But if the Democrats dare to use their power, a brave new world might be possible.
lead_paragraph: There are two images. In one, National Guard troops, most with no identifying information on their uniforms, stand on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in anticipation of violence from people peacefully protesting the killing of George Floyd. In the second image, thousands of protesters — domestic terrorists, really — swarm the Capitol. They wear red MAGA hats and carry Trump flags and show their faces because they want to be seen. They don’t seem to fear the consequences of being identified. More images — a man sitting in Nancy Pelosi’s office, his feet on a desk, a smirk on his face. A man carrying a stolen lectern, smiling at the camera. A man in the Senate chamber doing parkour.

headline: Twitter and Facebook Lock Trump’s Accounts After Violence on Capitol Hill
abstract: The moves came after critics and even some allies of the social media companies said they had failed to prevent the misinformation that led to chaos on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Update: Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, said on Thursday that President Trump would be blocked from its platforms “at least” through the end of his term.

headline: Proud Boys Under Growing Scrutiny in Capitol Riot Investigation
abstract: Officials are trying to determine to what extent far-right groups planned the assault in advance.
lead_paragraph: The leadership of the Proud Boys has come under increased scrutiny as agents and prosecutors across the country try to determine how closely members of the far-right nationalist group communicated during the riot at the Capitol this month and to what extent they might have planned the assault in advance, according to federal law enforcement officials.

headline: Day of Celebration or Mourning? Australia Grapples With Its National Holiday
abstract: For many, it’s a chance to kick back at beaches and barbecues. But for others, it’s a mark of the country’s shameful treatment of Indigenous people: Invasion Day.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Those who celebrate Australia Day, the country’s national holiday, associate it with barbecues and pool parties. But for those who protest against it, it is a reminder of the continent’s brutal colonization.

headline: ‘I Answered the Call of My President’: Rioters Say Trump Urged Them On
abstract: The defense from Trump supporters arrested in the Capitol assault is emerging in court papers and interviews — and could play a role in impeachment proceedings.
lead_paragraph: In the two weeks since a raging mob stormed the Capitol, President Trump has shown no sign that he believes he shares responsibility for the worst incursion on the halls of Congress in more than two centuries. Shielding him further, his loyalists have started shifting blame for the attack to an array of distracting bogeymen: far-left anti-fascists, Black Lives Matter activists, even vague conspiracies of a setup involving Vice President Mike Pence.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 30, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 30, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about protests in Poland over a ban on abortions in cases of fetal abnormalities misstated the name of an L.G.B.T. group protesting the laws. It is Queer Tour, not Queen Tour.

headline: How to Get Someone to Apologize
abstract: Advice from therapists, religious leaders and people who suffered terrible wrongs on ways to find repentance and resolution.
lead_paragraph: Despite President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s plea to let our “better angels prevail” and the comedian Dave Chappelle’s “Saturday Night Live” monologue where he told Americans, “We have to forgive each other,” reconciliation and forgiveness can be a long, difficult process. I learned that the hard way when the person who hurt me most wouldn’t apologize or express any remorse.

headline: Rare Pentagon Mission: Armed Troops in Capital
abstract: The troops will be the National Guard and not active-duty. But officials know such events are fraught with risk and cite Kent State in 1970, Tiananmen Square in 1989 and Tehran in 2009.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In deciding to arm the National Guard troops assigned to the Capitol complex for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration, the Defense Department crossed a Rubicon that for the last six months Pentagon officials have tried to avoid: potentially pitting armed military forces against American citizens in the streets.

headline: She saw her mother at the Capitol melee and called her out — publicly.
abstract: A Massachusetts teenager had been at odds with her mother over politics for years. Now their feud is a Twitter sensation.
lead_paragraph: For four years, Helena Duke, an 18-year-old high school senior in Massachusetts, had been growing further apart from her mother over their political views. She marched in protests for racial justice to her mother’s outspoken disapproval, she said. All the while her mother, a longtime Democrat, became ever more supportive of President Trump.

headline: The Metropolitan Opera Hires Its First Chief Diversity Officer
abstract: Marcia Sells has been brought on to rethink equity and inclusion at the largest performing arts institution in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Marcia Sells — a former dancer who became an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn and the dean of students at Harvard Law School — has been hired as the first chief diversity officer of the Metropolitan Opera, the largest performing arts institution in the United States.

headline: Kelly Loeffler Is Done in the Senate. But What About in the W.N.B.A.?
abstract: Loeffler, who co-owns the Atlanta Dream, lost her Senate race on Tuesday, renewing questions about whether she has a place in a league where many players want her gone.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, the Rev. Raphael Warnock made a final pitch to Senate-race voters in Georgia with a video on social media that prominently featured W.N.B.A. players campaigning on his behalf against the Republican incumbent, Senator Kelly Loeffler, who also happens to be a co-owner of a franchise, the Atlanta Dream.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Excessive Screen Time, Presidential Priorities and Fashion Statements
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked teenagers if they were concerned about soaring screen time during the pandemic, what they would do if they were president, and what fashion statements they’d like to make if money were no object.

headline: How High-End Restaurants Have Failed Black Female Chefs
abstract: Training and advancement as a chef can be hard to find in American fine-dining restaurants, according to Black women who have tried.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, Auzerais Bellamy landed what she thought was a big break: a stint as a stagiaire, or apprentice, at the French Laundry, Thomas Keller’s world-renowned restaurant in the Napa Valley. She wasn’t paid for her two days trailing the pastry team, but she saw it as an ideal training ground where, if asked to stay, she could learn from some of the best cooks in the business, sharpening her skills.

headline: Will Trump and His Republican Allies Ever Face Consequences?
abstract: The anti-democratic forces on display at the Capitol on Wednesday will not abate on their own.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: 7 Albums for Kids That Adults Will Want to Hear, Too
abstract: From infectious hip-hop and big-band songs to a mix for transgender and nonbinary children, releases during the pandemic have something for everyone.
lead_paragraph: Music for children is often dismissed as either simple and silly or simple and soporific. It doesn’t have to be. A whole world exists beyond “The Wheels on the Bus” and “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star,” and it has expanded during the pandemic, as musicians have found themselves at home with ample recording time. One artist released an album offering a vicarious global voyage, while others undertook projects with their own housebound families.

headline: What Are Your Reactions to the Storming of the Capitol by a Pro-Trump Mob?
abstract: What did you feel, notice and wonder as you heard about this news? What does it say about the strength of American democracy?

headline: $200,000 Settlement for Texas Man Pepper-Sprayed While Recording Son’s Traffic Stop
abstract: An alleged racial profiling of a Latino man quickly escalated and led to the demotion of a police sergeant.
lead_paragraph: A city in Texas has agreed to a $200,000 settlement of a lawsuit alleging civil rights violations and police brutality brought by a man who was pepper-sprayed twice while recording his son during a traffic stop over the summer.

headline: Corky Lee, Who Photographed Asian-American Life, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Lee was determined to correct history that left out Asian-Americans, and to document their present-day lives and struggles. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: Corky Lee, a photographer who was determined both to restore the contributions of Asian-Americans to the historical record and to document their present-day lives and struggles, especially those living in New York, died on Wednesday in Queens. He was 73.

headline: Trump Loyalists Arrested and Charged With Involvement in Capitol Siege
abstract: A well-known conspiracy theorist who entered the Capitol shirtless, wearing a fur headdress with horns, was among those arrested.
lead_paragraph: A man who was photographed carrying the lectern of Speaker Nancy Pelosi during the rampage in the U.S. Capitol this week and another who roamed through the halls of Congress while wearing a horned fur headdress have been arrested and charged, the Justice Department said on Saturday.

headline: Kentucky’s Team Took a Knee. Some in the State Were Taken Aback.
abstract: The Wildcats’ decision to kneel during the national anthem before a game at Florida has produced a backlash in their conservative state.
lead_paragraph: A decision by Kentucky men’s basketball players and their coach, John Calipari, to kneel during the national anthem before a game over the weekend has set off a backlash in the conservative state, which voted, 62 percent to 36 percent, for President Trump in the November general election.

headline: Bomb Explodes at California Church Known for Hateful Views
abstract: Officials said no one was injured in the attack. The church had been the target of protests over its messages against women, Jews, L.G.B.T.Q. people and the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. and local authorities are investigating a bombing on Saturday morning at a church in Los Angeles County that had recently been the target of protests for its extremist views against L.G.B.T.Q. people, women and the Black Lives Matter movement.

headline: 5 Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Our critic recommends travel photography, a philosophical comic strip, a chronicler of Black life and the funerary monuments of old New York.
lead_paragraph: What better time for practicing optimism than the start of a new year? With that in mind, this list of recommended Instagram feeds focuses on travel photography both geographic and psychological; a brilliant philosophical comic strip; a chronicler of Black life; a talented young accordionist; and the glorious funerary monuments of old New York. We hope they’ll help get you through the long post-holiday winter.

headline: The 51st State? Washington Revisits an Uphill Cause With New Fervor
abstract: District of Columbia statehood has long been out of reach. Proponents hope Democratic control of the federal government and the security issues raised over the past week could change that.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the day after a mob rampaged through the halls of Congress, the mayor of Washington, D.C., Muriel E. Bowser, heaped praise on the Metropolitan Police Department officers who had rushed to restore order after the Capitol’s police force was overwhelmed.

headline: Racial Double Standard of Capitol Police Draws Outcry
abstract: Black Lives Matter activists said the tepid response from law enforcement officers to mostly white protesters stood in stark contrast to the aggressive tactics they have endured for years.
lead_paragraph: While protesting the police killing of a Black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., several years ago, Johnetta Elzie said she was manhandled by officers. She said they pointed rifles at Black women who were pushing toddlers in strollers and cursed at them to turn around.

headline: ‘I Know I’m Not Alone’: The Importance of Mentors Right Now
abstract: Most mentoring programs have moved online, but some wait lists are long and the rare person-to-person connection is sorely missed.
lead_paragraph: Last May, a 17-year-old from Queens lost his father, an essential worker, to Covid-19. For six months, the shy and soft-spoken teenager, whose name is Ansh and whose last name is being withheld for privacy, hardly left the one-bedroom apartment he shares with his mother in Astoria.

headline: The Smithsonian Is Collecting Objects From the Capitol Siege
abstract: Curators are gathering posters and banners from the riot and the protests that preceded it to “help future generations remember” Jan. 6, a museum director says.
lead_paragraph: A sign that reads, “Off with their heads — stop the steal” and a small handwritten poster with the words “Trump won, swamp stole” are among dozens of objects and ephemera from pro-Trump rallies and the Capitol takeover Wednesday that are heading to the National Museum of American History, collected by curators from the division of political and military history.

headline: The Composer Tyshawn Sorey Enters a New Phase
abstract: The Newark native has long been lauded for his brilliant abstractions. Lately he’s writing about something more concrete — and producing his most powerful music yet.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: How Republicans Are Warping Reality Around the Capitol Attack
abstract: Loyalists to President Trump are increasingly relying on conspiracy theories and misinformation, drawing false equivalence with last summer’s racial protests and blaming outside agitators.
lead_paragraph: Immediately after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, all corners of the political spectrum repudiated the mob of President Trump’s supporters. Yet within days, prominent Republicans, party officials, conservative media voices and rank-and-file voters began making a rhetorical shift to try to downplay the group’s violent actions.

headline: A Polarizing Canadian ‘Messiah’ Shows How Pandemic Is Shaking Up Culture
abstract: The coronavirus, a force of death and destruction, is also pushing artists and musicians to be more creative.
lead_paragraph: As the camera pans over a pristine landscape in Alberta, Jesus is reimagined as an Indigenous person who embodies both male and female spirits and is fighting big oil interests.

headline: Books Are Back in the White House — And One of Them Is by Angie Thomas
abstract: The best-selling author just found out that her debut novel is soon to be on the first lady’s bedside table.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY Angie Thomas has had a few peak experiences in her career, and one occurred right before a phone interview to discuss what it’s like to have two books at the top of the best-seller list at once. (Her new novel, “Concrete Rose,” is No. 1 on the young adult hardcover list and her debut, “The Hate U Give,” is No. 4.)

headline: Republicans Reel as Democrats Seethe
abstract: Recrimination, resignations and removal talk in Washington: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: A day after professing his “love” for them, Trump condemns the supporters who ransacked the Capitol. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: A leader of the Proud Boys was arrested over his role at the Capitol riot.
abstract: Joseph Biggs, a leader of the far-right nationalist group the Proud Boys, was charged on Wednesday in connection with the riot at the Capitol, as prosecutors said he led dozens of the group’s members in an angry march toward — and into — the halls of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Biggs, a leader of the far-right nationalist group the Proud Boys, was charged on Wednesday in connection with the riot at the Capitol, as prosecutors said he led dozens of the group’s members in an angry march toward — and into — the halls of Congress.

headline: With whataboutism, denial and excuses, Trump’s allies are still defending him.
abstract: Even as scores of President Trump’s usually unfailing loyalists condemned him for failing to call off the swarm of lawless demonstrators storming and ransacking the Capitol, many of his most vocal and visible defenders still could not bring themselves to fault the president for the surreal and frightening attack carried out in his name.
lead_paragraph: Even as scores of President Trump’s usually unfailing loyalists condemned him for failing to call off the swarm of lawless demonstrators storming and ransacking the Capitol, many of his most vocal and visible defenders still could not bring themselves to fault the president for the surreal and frightening attack carried out in his name.

headline: Why the Capitol Riot Reminded Me of War
abstract: I watched the video with my heart in my throat — the rage, the chaos and destruction for the sake of spectacle. It reminded me of battle.
lead_paragraph: Ever since I returned from our wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, people will from time to time casually ask me what combat is like. Typically, I’ll direct them to films like “Full Metal Jacket” and “Black Hawk Down,” which, in my opinion, do a pretty good job of capturing something of the experience. Now I have another film I might recommend.

headline: My Ears Have Been Opened by the Audio Play Explosion
abstract: Short, sharp and often funny, the work featured in the “Playing on Air” series can even make vacuuming a pleasure.
lead_paragraph: Until a few weeks ago, I never listened to podcasts. I haven’t listened to the radio since my preteen Radio Disney years. I’m not even a big fan of music — I turn to the same small playlist of songs, but even then, more than anything, I’m a fan of silence.

headline: 13 New Books to Watch For in February
abstract: Show-business biographies of Mike Nichols and Tom Stoppard, environmental treatises by Bill Gates and Elizabeth Kolbert, debut novels of life online and more.
lead_paragraph: Soon after graduating from college, Jaouad received an alarming diagnosis: Her unexplained rashes and fatigue were the result of an aggressive type of leukemia. Jaouad documented much of her chemotherapy and treatment in a column for The Times, and her book reflects on life after remission. A cross-country trip allowed her to meet people who had written to her during treatment — and figure out what kind of life she wanted to lead.

headline: Lil Wayne and Kodak Black Among 4 Hip-Hop Figures Trump Pardoned
abstract: An executive from Jay-Z’s Roc Nation and a founder of Death Row Records also received pardons or commutations, capping a long, strange relationship between the former president and the rap world.
lead_paragraph: In late October, just days before the presidential election, and almost a year after federal authorities had seized a handgun from his private plane, the rapper Lil Wayne spent nearly an hour with Donald J. Trump at the president’s Doral Golf Club in Miami.

headline: Inside a Deadly Siege: How a String of Failures Led to a Dark Day at the Capitol
abstract: Poor planning among a constellation of government agencies and a restive crowd encouraged by President Trump set the stage for the unthinkable.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Huddled in a command center on Wednesday afternoon, Mayor Muriel Bowser of Washington and her aides saw a photograph of blood stains on the temporary grandstands at the Capitol, a makeshift structure built for the inauguration of a new president in two weeks.

headline: Gaze at the Night Skies and Unwind With a Yoga Class
abstract: This week, learn about the history of vaccines, explore Mammoth Hot Springs or learn to code.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Why Is Big Tech Policing Speech? Because the Government Isn’t
abstract: Deplatforming President Trump showed that the First Amendment is broken — but not in the way his supporters think.
lead_paragraph: In the months leading up to the November election, the social media platform Parler attracted millions of new users by promising something competitors, increasingly, did not: unfettered free speech. “If you can say it on the streets of New York,” promised the company’s chief executive, John Matze, in a June CNBC interview, “you can say it on Parler.”

headline: How to Pretend You’re in Cartagena Today
abstract: The Colombian port city, home to the trademark sounds and dances of the region, is so full of magic that it has inspired entire books by Gabriel García Márquez.
lead_paragraph: On a clear day, from the 17th-century La Popa Convent on the crest of a 500-foot hill, the view of Cartagena can trigger mild vertigo. Slowly, using the skyline as your guidepost to the Colombian port city, you can begin to get your bearings. That improbable cluster of skyscrapers is Bocagrande, a neighborhood where beach resorts share space with gleaming office towers. Next in the panorama is the walled old city, where narrow alleyways connect colonial-era churches with brightly colored shops and restaurants. In between the two neighborhoods is another: Getsemani, unremarkable from afar but, on closer inspection, a veritable street art gallery exploding with creative energy.

headline: Russia Protesters Defy Vast Police Operation as Signs of Kremlin Anxiety Mount
abstract: Tens of thousands took to the streets across Russia to show support for the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny. The police were out in force and reports of brutality flared.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Kremlin mounted Russia’s most fearsome nationwide police operation in recent memory on Sunday, seeking to overwhelm a protest movement backing the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny that swept across the country for a second weekend in a row.

headline: We Worked Together on the Internet. Last Week, He Stormed the Capitol.
abstract: At BuzzFeed, we followed the signals of social media. A young employee followed them all the way to Charlottesville and Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Chris Rock Re-edits a Special, and the Result Is Fascinating
abstract: With “Total Blackout: The Tamborine Extended Cut,” the comic effectively erases the stamp of the original director, Bo Burnham, and turns in a less intimate show.
lead_paragraph: In film, directors have all the power, less so in theater. But they are omnipotent compared with the director of the stand-up special, who, to borrow a metaphor from Chris Rock’s already essential 2018 special, “Tamborine,” has not traditionally led the band so much as stood on the side and played the tambourine.

headline: Larry Fink’s New Climate Goal
abstract: The BlackRock chief plans to pressure companies to do more to cut carbon emissions, using the weight of his firm’s $9 trillion in assets.
lead_paragraph: The BlackRock chief’s annual letter to C.E.O.s is going out this morning and Andrew has a copy, which he writes about in his latest column. Mr. Fink’s letter has driven the conversation inside corporate America’s boardrooms for years — such as his proclamation that companies must have a purpose beyond profit, which preceded the Business Roundtable’s statement on stakeholder capitalism, and his call for corporate climate disclosures, which was followed by a raft of climate pledges by companies.

headline: Entrepreneurs Bet Big on Immersive Art Despite Covid-19
abstract: For-profit experiential art centers are investing hundreds of millions of dollars in a business where audiences have evaporated because of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Even as the pandemic takes its toll on tourism, immersive museums and experiential art centers are expanding to new cities and wooing investors willing to gamble on the future of the emerging industry.

headline: The Far Right Told Us What It Had Planned. We Didn’t Listen.
abstract: Wednesday wasn’t Trumpism’s “last gasp.” It was the manifestation of a long-held fantasy. And most perpetrators walked away, uncuffed, to fight another day.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Preserving New York’s Ties to the Underground Railroad
abstract: Safe houses and other structures used in the fight against slavery were often clandestine, and survivors today can be difficult to document. But there’s a 19th-century house in Washington Heights …
lead_paragraph: Are landmarks that celebrate Black history given proper consideration by city government? That is a question hovering over two threatened antebellum houses once owned by abolitionists, one in Brooklyn and one in Manhattan, that have come before the Landmarks Preservation Commission in recent months.

headline: Trump supporters gather in Washington to protest the certification of Biden’s victory.
abstract: Under a dreary winter sky, defiant but downbeat Trump supporters began gathering in downtown Washington on Wednesday morning to celebrate a defeated Republican president who suffered a final humiliation in the Georgia Senate runoffs with one declared Democratic victory and the second race with the Democratic candidate maintaining his lead.
