lead_paragraph: Under a dreary winter sky, defiant but downbeat Trump supporters began gathering in downtown Washington on Wednesday morning to celebrate a defeated Republican president who suffered a final humiliation in the Georgia Senate runoffs with one declared Democratic victory and the second race with the Democratic candidate maintaining his lead.

headline: What Was Donald Trump’s Twitter?
abstract: “I’m going to be very restrained, if I use it at all,” Donald Trump told us in 2016. Something else happened.
lead_paragraph: Each of the big social platforms handled the challenges of the Trump presidency in its own unique way, scrambling to address or neutralize various urgent and contradictory concerns from users, advertisers, lawmakers and occasionally the president himself.

headline: They’re Breaking Glass and Criticizing Biden. From the Left.
abstract: As President Biden calls for unity and calmer rhetoric, his presidency began with burned flags and federal agents deployed once again into the streets.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — In the hours after President Biden’s inauguration on Wednesday, hundreds of people gathered for a series of events across the liberal city of Portland, Ore. — not to celebrate, but to mobilize for the struggles to come.

headline: Listen to Rudolph: A New Year Is Both a Comfort and a Fiction
abstract: A 1976 TV movie that imagined years as people is a helpful reminder that a new page on the calendar is an arbitrary creation.
lead_paragraph: If 2020 were a person, what would it look like? I imagine someone tired, ravaged, beaten down by illness and police brutality, and weary from trying to stay afloat in a sinking economy. We’ve personified 2020 in articles and memes and GIFs, speaking of it as though it were a living, breathing antagonist in our collective story. And this past New Year’s celebration was not so much about the birth of a new year as about the death of an old one that no one asked for.

headline: Proud Boys Leader Secretly Cooperated With F.B.I. and Police
abstract: Enrique Tarrio, the chairman of the far-right nationalist group, which is under increasing scrutiny for its role in the Capitol riot, helped to convict more than a dozen people.
lead_paragraph: Enrique Tarrio, the chairman of the Proud Boys, a far-right nationalist group that is a major target of the sprawling investigation into the riot at the Capitol this month, has a history of cooperating with law enforcement, according to court records and a former prosecutor.

headline: For These Classical Musicians, It’s Always Been About Racial Equity
abstract: The work now being taken up by large institutions has long been the purpose of many smaller ones. We spoke with seven of them.
lead_paragraph: Last year was different. Black Lives Matter, in the national psyche for nearly a decade, crested with the killing of George Floyd and weeks of widespread demonstrations that could no longer be ignored — even by classical music. Orchestras and opera companies posted statements of solidarity, however platitudinous, denouncing racism and promising a more equitable future for an industry that has historically been led by white administrators and designed to maintain a status quo that gives white artists the advantage over their underrepresented peers.

headline: Donald Trump’s Last Picture Show
abstract: The Capitol mob had reason to believe the president would be watching them. For the rest of us, it was a horror story.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll be watching,” the president said.

headline: New & Noteworthy, From ‘Faust’ to Life in Lockdown
abstract: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: HOMO IRREALIS: Essays, by André Aciman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) In this collection, the author of “Call Me by Your Name” and other novels contemplates the life of the imagination, and the ability to hold competing realities simultaneously in mind.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Will the Capitol riot become a super-spreader event?
lead_paragraph: We may never know for certain without effective contact tracing — which the U.S. largely lacks — and because most of the rioters who stormed the Capitol yesterday are unidentified, tracing them would be difficult.

headline: Officers Who Handcuffed Black Family Won’t Be Charged, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The encounter with the Aurora, Colo., police in August was recorded on a widely shared video that showed four children lying on the ground in a parking lot, crying and screaming as several officers stood over them.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Colorado said this week that they would not charge two police officers who drew their guns and handcuffed a Black family, including two girls, after suspecting them of riding in a stolen car.

headline: ‘He Was Just Everywhere’: A Tired Country After Four Years of Trump
abstract: Some Americans are eager for a break from the constant news produced by President Trump. Others said his term had only inspired them to be more involved in activism.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — For four years, David Betras has been unable to escape Donald J. Trump. The president has visited Youngstown, Ohio, the seat of Mr. Betras’s home county. So have the president’s children. People Mr. Betras had known for years became in thrall to Mr. Trump. There was no getting away on Facebook, on Instagram, at the local bar.

headline: Groups Put French State on Legal Notice Over Police Racism
abstract: In a first, six nongovernmental organizations are taking legal steps to force an overhaul of the country’s policing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Six nongovernmental organizations put the French state on notice on Wednesday to force it to address “systemic discriminatory practices by the police,” a rare collective legal action that will take the government onto uncharted grounds.

headline: A Riot Amid a Pandemic: Did the Virus, Too, Storm the Capitol?
abstract: Some scientists fear that the mayhem on Capitol Hill may prove to have been a so-called super-spreading event.
lead_paragraph: The mob that stormed the Capitol on Wednesday did not just threaten the heart of American democracy. To scientists who watched dismayed as the scenes unfolded on television, the throngs of unmasked intruders who wandered through hallways and into private offices may also have transformed the riot into a super-spreader event.

headline: Police Failures Spur Resignations and Complaints of Double Standard
abstract: The chief of the Capitol Police indicated he would resign after an angry mob of Trump supporters stormed past officers and into the legislative chambers.
lead_paragraph: Six days before a raucous rally of President Trump’s supporters in Washington, Representative Maxine Waters anxiously grilled the chief of the Capitol Police about his preparations for various scenarios: Were the rooftops secured? Would streets be blocked off? Did he know that violent groups like the Proud Boys and the Oath Keepers were vowing to stir up chaos?

headline: Dutch Police Clash With Protesters Denouncing Lockdown Measures
abstract: Police officers in riot gear used water cannons to disperse demonstrators in the center of Amsterdam opposed to government measures to contain the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people, some throwing fireworks and stones, joined an unauthorized protest against the Dutch government’s coronavirus restrictions in Amsterdam on Sunday, and riot police officers used water cannons, batons, attack dogs and horses to disperse the crowd.

headline: Teaching Resources to Help Students Make Sense of the Rampage at the Capitol
abstract: Dozens of lesson plan ideas, activities and Times materials for exploring the causes and consequences of this assault on democracy in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Not since the War of 1812, when British forces set fire to the Capitol, have the halls of power in Washington been overtaken by violent intruders as they were on Jan. 6, writes The Times.

headline: In Capital, a G.O.P. Crisis. At the R.N.C. Meeting, a Trump Celebration.
abstract: Party members at a gathering of the Republican National Committee endorsed President Trump as the man to lead the party forward, ignoring the turmoil in Washington.
lead_paragraph: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla. — In Washington, Republicans were dealing with a burgeoning crisis in their ranks, with high-profile resignations and bitter infighting over how to deal with an erratic and isolated president. But at the Republican National Committee’s winter meeting on Friday, most party members were operating in a parallel universe.

headline: Why T-Shirts Promoting the Capitol Riot Are Still Available Online
abstract: Merchandise with phrases like “Battle for Capitol Hill Veteran” could still be purchased on major e-commerce sites, a sign of how the platforms have struggled to remove the goods.
lead_paragraph: The day after the violent attack on the Capitol, Shopify declared that it had removed e-commerce sites affiliated with President Trump, including his official campaign store. The sites had violated a policy that prohibited the support of groups or people “that threaten or condone violence to further a cause.”

headline: Patriots’ Belichick Declines Honor From Trump
abstract: President Trump had planned to give Bill Belichick the Presidential Medal of Freedom, but the coach cited last week’s violence at the Capitol in a statement announcing that he would not receive it.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Brown vs. Chiefs and Buccaneers vs. Saints coverage.]

headline: The Maker of the Aeron Chair Grapples with Politics and the Pandemic
abstract: As the C.E.O. of Herman Miller, Andi Owen has had to navigate a polarized work force while thinking about the future of the offices her company makes furniture for.
lead_paragraph: When Andi Owen took over the furniture company Herman Miller, in 2018, she didn’t expect to get caught up in politics. But these days, it seems no chief executive is safe from the culture wars.

headline: Don’t Let Trump’s Second Trial Change the First Amendment
abstract: The House was right to impeach the president, but the legal definition of incitement shouldn’t give way in the process.
lead_paragraph: As the country reels from the spectacle of a Capitol overtaken and top U.S. officials scrambling for their lives, the House voted on Wednesday to impeach President Trump for, among other things, “inciting violence against the government of the United States.” Lawmakers are right to insist that Mr. Trump pay the highest price for fomenting a deadly assault on democracy; he should be convicted and banned from holding public office.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Ode to Moving On, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Barry Gibb and Dolly Parton, Rhye, Tim Berne and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: How Wall Street Reflects the Economy Biden Inherits
abstract: Big banks are sending mixed signals.
lead_paragraph: America’s biggest banks have all now released their financial results for the past year, data that reflect the strange economic situation facing President Biden and his new administration. Parts of the economy are booming, others are at a standstill and the outlook is extraordinarily uncertain.

headline: ‘Year of the Reveal’: Runoffs Follow Pandemic, Protests and a Test of Atlanta’s Promise
abstract: The high-stakes Senate contests come after months of tumult and activism in a city often seen as both resolutely Southern and somehow distinct from the rest of the region.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Like Atlanta itself, the rapper T.I. has known both defeat and a long twisting road toward redemption and prosperity.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the Riot at the U.S. Capitol
abstract: We invited teenagers to share what they were feeling, noticing and wondering about the shocking and chaotic events as they unfolded. Here is what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the attack on the U.S. Capitol last Wednesday, we asked students “What Are Your Reactions to the Storming of the Capitol by a Pro-Trump Mob?” We hoped to give students a place to share what they were feeling, noticing and wondering about the shocking and chaotic events as they unfolded.

headline: It’s a Fateful Day in Georgia
abstract: Who will control the Senate? The answer is set to finally arrive. This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Voters are headed to the polls in Georgia, where control of the Senate hangs in the balance — and with it, much of Biden’s agenda. It’s Tuesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Attend a Jazz Festival and Take a Superhero Yoga Class
abstract: This week, celebrate Martin Luther King’s Birthday, revisit “The West Wing” and explore a new exhibit from the National Museum of Women in the Arts.

headline: New York Police Arrest Dozens as M.L.K. Day Marchers Gather Near City Hall
abstract: The confrontation came days after the state’s attorney general sued the New York Police Department for its handling of protests following the death of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people were arrested on Monday night in Lower Manhattan as hundreds participated in a march on Martin Luther King’s Birthday organized by Black activist groups, according to the police and witnesses.

headline: Children Need to Be Back in School Tomorrow
abstract: Teacher resistance is a disaster for the most vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: There’s a wave of anti-intellectualism sweeping America. There are people across the country who deny evidence, invent their own facts and live in their own fantasyland. We saw it in the Republicans who denied the reality of the Biden election victory and we see it now in the teachers unions that are shutting down schools and marring children’s lives.

headline: Congress’s Sergeants-at-Arms Face Scrutiny After Siege
abstract: The House and Senate sergeants-at-arms, who have resigned, now face questions about why they failed to do more to deter the Trump loyalists who swarmed the Capitol last week.
lead_paragraph: Both men had similar backgrounds, working for years as Secret Service agents but considered more skilled in navigating the agency’s political infighting than as experts in protection. Both went on to land plum assignments: the sergeants-at-arms of the Senate and House.

headline: Police Chief and Officer Ousted After Racist Remarks Caught on Body Camera
abstract: The remarks by the chief and patrolman in Hamilton, Ga., were discovered after a city worker found the footage on a camera that had been thought to be malfunctioning.
lead_paragraph: A police chief and a patrolman from a small city in Georgia were ousted from their positions after body camera footage was discovered in which the pair made racist comments about slavery and Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms of Atlanta.

headline: Leader of Proud Boys, a Far-Right Group, Is Arrested as D.C. Braces for Protests
abstract: About 340 National Guard troops are expected to deploy in support of local law enforcement before demonstrations against the election results.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The leader of the Proud Boys, a far-right group that has vocally supported President Trump’s efforts to overturn the election results, was arrested on Monday in Washington as Mayor Muriel Bowser requested support from the Army National Guard before expected protests of the November vote in the nation’s capital.

headline: How Trump’s Allies Are Still Defending Him: Denial, Deflection, Disinformation
abstract: They falsely claimed President Trump had no role in spurring the assault on the Capitol. They resorted to false equivalencies. Some even questioned whether the mob was an anti-Trump “false flag.”
lead_paragraph: This was one mob they found a way to excuse.

headline: ‘A Total Failure’: The Proud Boys Now Mock Trump
abstract: Members of the far-right group, who were among Donald Trump’s staunchest fans, are calling him “weak” as more of them were charged for storming the U.S. Capitol.
lead_paragraph: After the presidential election last year, the Proud Boys, a far-right group, declared its undying loyalty to President Trump.

headline: Trump’s ‘Law and Order’: One More Deceptive Tactic Is Exposed
abstract: The president’s response to the riot at the Capitol underscored the ways he has twisted the phrase “law and order” over the past four years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, the phrase rolled off his tongue in times of strife, a rallying cry to his predominantly white base.

headline: ‘2020 Has Been a Wake-Up Call’: Reflections on Our Civil Conversation Challenge
abstract: Teenagers posted over 12,000 comments in response to our invitation to talk about politics across divides. We loved the results.
lead_paragraph: Please note: As this piece publishes — and as the United States heads toward the inauguration of a new president even as the current president is impeached for the second time — we are also publishing a summary of the 1,200-plus teenage reactions to our Jan. 6 Student Opinion question, What Are Your Reactions to the Storming of the Capitol by a Pro-Trump Mob? Though that forum focused on individual response rather than conversation, many of the positive qualities we identify below are on display there as well. Thank you, students, for raising your voices.

headline: Do We Ask Too Much of Black Heroes?
abstract: Every year for a month, we celebrate the heroes of Black history. But these stories can obscure how change happens and who gets left behind.
lead_paragraph: This is the first piece in “Black History, Continued,” a series that will explore pivotal moments and transformative figures in Black culture and examine how the past shapes the present and the future.

headline: In Georgia, Pro Teams Dive Into Senate Races With Different Playbooks
abstract: The W.N.B.A.’s Atlanta Dream backed a candidate for the Senate running directly against a co-owner of the team; the N.F.L.’s Atlanta Falcons promoted voter participation in general.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s runoff election on Tuesday will have dramatic consequences, deciding whether Republicans or Democrats control the Senate. In an environment of heightened civic engagement for athletes, two of Atlanta’s pro teams have been rallying voters there in starkly different ways.

headline: How Mayor de Blasio Plans to Lead the City Out of the Pandemic
abstract: The mayor announced an ambitious plan to help New York City recover, including vaccinating five million residents by June.
lead_paragraph: In his final State of the City address, Mayor Bill de Blasio offered a sprawling vision of New York City’s recovery from a pandemic that has taken tens of thousands of lives and destroyed the city’s economy.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Capitol Breach Puts the Police Under Scrutiny
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 8, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “No one can tell me that if it had been a group of Black Lives Matter protesting yesterday, they wouldn’t have been treated very, very differently than the mob of thugs that stormed the Capitol.”

headline: Trump. Twitter. QAnon. Who’s to Blame?
abstract: Wednesday was a dark moment in American history. We look at the forces that led us here.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: John Thompson Was More — Much More — Than a Basketball Coach
abstract: In his autobiography, “I Came as a Shadow,” Thompson recalls his childhood in segregated Washington, D.C., and his decades as both an athletic and a cultural force.
lead_paragraph: I CAME AS A SHADOW An AutobiographyBy John Thompson with Jesse Washington

headline: Nigerian President Ousts Military Chiefs Who Failed to Quell Violence
abstract: With just two years left in President Buhari’s tenure, can a new approach defeat the militants and bandits who are killing, kidnapping and traumatizing Nigeria’s people?
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — When a former military ruler, Muhammadu Buhari, was first elected president in 2015, many Nigerians thought he would deliver on promises to defeat Islamist militants in the country’s northeast and ratchet down the violence.

headline: A Nation in Pain: ‘The Daily’ Covers the Effects of Centuries of Systemic Racism in the U.S.
abstract: Listen to a collection of episodes on “The Daily” that examine the public reckoning with racial injustice in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Against the backdrop of a pandemic and economic crisis, the summer of 2020 became a season of protest after the killing of George Floyd and other Black Americans by the police. “The Daily” shared with its listeners the voices of people who rose up in anger and anguish as the country grappled with the legacy of police brutality and racial justice.

headline: Movies to Stream for Martin Luther King Jr. Day
abstract: Seven recent films help commemorate King’s legacy in fighting for racial justice.
lead_paragraph: With each year since it was designated as a holiday in 1983, Martin Luther King Jr. Day has carried new yet immovable significance. It did so the year following Rodney King’s 1991 assault. It did so in the years following the deaths of Oscar Grant, Trayvon Martin, Michael Brown and Freddie Gray. And now, following the past year’s deaths of Representative John Lewis and the Rev. C.T. Vivian, the killings of Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, the arrival of the summer’s Black Lives Matter protests, the November presidential election and this month’s storming of the Capitol by a pro-Trump mob, the holiday carries that much more meaning. In our government, in our elections, and in our law enforcement the signs of racism still lurk.

headline: Videos Show How Rioter Was Trampled in Stampede at Capitol
abstract: Rosanne Boyland died after losing consciousness in the crush of a pro-Trump mob as it surged against the police. Here’s how it happened.
lead_paragraph: Rosanne Boyland, a 34-year-old Trump supporter from Georgia who died during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, appears to have been killed in a crush of fellow rioters during their attempt to fight through a police line, according to videos reviewed by The Times.

headline: For Diversity Leaders in the Arts, Getting Hired Is Just the First Step
abstract: Cultural institutions are recruiting people of color to direct their transformation efforts. But bringing in one manager doesn’t mean the work is done.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in a working class family in Lawrence, Mass., Rosa Rodriguez-Williams said “museums were not part of my experience.”

headline: D.C. braces for two days of protests as the leader of the Proud Boys, a far-right group, is arrested.
abstract: The leader of the Proud Boys, a far-right group that has vocally supported President Trump’s efforts to overturn the election results, was arrested on Monday in Washington as Mayor Muriel Bowser requested support from the Army National Guard before expected protests of the November vote in the nation’s capital.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the Proud Boys, a far-right group that has vocally supported President Trump’s efforts to overturn the election results, was arrested on Monday in Washington as Mayor Muriel Bowser requested support from the Army National Guard before expected protests of the November vote in the nation’s capital.

headline: Are We Stuck With Trump in the White House?
abstract: Let’s talk about options to remove him, and to change norms.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember Martin Gugino? He was the 75-year-old man who in June was peacefully supporting a Black Lives Matter protest in Buffalo when police officers shoved him to the ground, cracking his skull and damaging his brain.

headline: Pixar’s ‘Soul’ Has a Black Hero. In Denmark, a White Actor Dubs the Voice.
abstract: The casting has fueled a debate about racism and fanned anger about stereotyping and prejudice in European-language voice-overs, even when films have main characters of color.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Like most of their counterparts around the world, Danish film critics initially greeted “Soul,” Pixar’s first animated feature to focus on Black characters and African-American culture, with rapture, hailing its sensitive, joyful portrayal of a jazz musician on a quest to live a meaningful life.

headline: Police Chief Who Resigned After Fatal Shooting Will Lead Louisville Department
abstract: Erika Shields, who stepped down after the killing of Rayshard Brooks in Atlanta, will arrive in a city still gripped by the fatal police shooting of Breonna Taylor, which led to national cries for accountability.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The Atlanta police chief who resigned last year after a high-profile police shooting has been hired to run the department in Louisville, Ky., a city still reeling from its own prominent shooting that helped fuel the outcry for police reform that became a defining factor of 2020.

headline: Some Republicans have turned to conspiracy theories and misinformation to explain the Capitol attack.
abstract: Immediately after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, all corners of the political spectrum repudiated the mob of President Trump’s supporters. Yet within days, prominent Republicans, party officials, conservative media voices and rank-and-file voters began making a rhetorical shift to try to downplay the group’s violent actions.
lead_paragraph: Immediately after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, all corners of the political spectrum repudiated the mob of President Trump’s supporters. Yet within days, prominent Republicans, party officials, conservative media voices and rank-and-file voters began making a rhetorical shift to try to downplay the group’s violent actions.

headline: The Former Youth TV Star on a Mission to Transform the BBC
abstract: June Sarpong has been a familiar face on British screens for two decades. Now, she’s in charge of bringing greater diversity to the country’s public broadcaster.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When June Sarpong was 21 and an up-and-coming presenter on MTV in Britain, she walked past a newsstand and saw a magazine in its racks. On the cover was a story about successful women at the music station.

headline: How Armed Protests Are Creating a New Kind of Politics
abstract: Americans have often ignored the political implications of the country’s enormous arsenal of privately owned, military-style weapons. Did Jan. 6 change that?
lead_paragraph: Americans have often ignored the political implications of the country’s enormous arsenal of privately owned, military-style weapons. Did Jan. 6 change that?

headline: The Year in Illustration 2020
abstract: The most memorable illustrations of the year, as chosen by art directors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The most memorable illustrations of the year, as chosen by art directors at The New York Times.

headline: A Canadian ‘Buy Local’ Effort Fights Amazon on Its Own Turf
abstract: A website called Not Amazon was created to drive sales to more than 4,000 independent stores in four cities. The initiative aims to keep expanding.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The snow was falling outside Ali Haberstroh’s apartment in late November when the idea came to her.

headline: This M.L.K. Day, America Has a ‘Long Road Ahead’
abstract: White supremacy was built on lies. In a reality-denying age, it follows that racism has flourished.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 5, exactly 10 days before what would have been the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s 92nd birthday, the Rev. Raphael Warnock, the senior pastor of King’s former church, won election to become Georgia’s first Black senator.

headline: A Trip Into the Otherworldly With Adrienne Kennedy as Guide
abstract: A digital four-play retrospective, capped by a world premiere, illuminates this writer’s fascination with doubling, violence and Black identity.
lead_paragraph: Have you experienced the familiar unfamiliarity of dreams? That quixotic sense of déjà vu that comes from snippets of memory, stray thoughts, recurring images stolen from the day or drawn wholly from the imagination — all jigsaw-puzzled together to form a portrait of a feeling, a sensation, a belief or fear.

headline: A Covid-19 Relief Fund Was Only for Black Residents. Then Came the Lawsuits.
abstract: Oregon earmarked $62 million to explicitly benefit Black individuals and business owners. Now some of the money is in limbo after lawsuits alleging racial discrimination.
lead_paragraph: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: The Capitol Police Had One Mission. Now the Force Is in Crisis.
abstract: The department’s performance during the rampage at the Capitol has cast a harsh light on an agency that has been unused to public scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: As old as the Capitol itself, the Capitol Police began in 1801 with the appointment of a single guard to oversee the move of Congress from Philadelphia to Washington, D.C. His task, according to a court filing, was to “take as much care as possible with the property of the United States.”

headline: Honor and Learn This Black History Month
abstract: More than ever, this month is a welcome time for the education and celebration of Black American culture.
lead_paragraph: It’s not an understatement to describe the events of the past year as historic, and particularly for Black Americans. The nation elected its first Black vice president, a woman and a graduate of a historically Black university, and Georgia send its first Black senator to the Capitol. (Both of these realities were possible through the tireless organizing efforts of women like Stacey Abrams of Fair Fight and LaTosha Brown of Black Voters Matter.)

headline: Trump Incites Rioters
abstract: The president may use the language of patriotism, but these are the actions of Benedict Arnold.
lead_paragraph: “If the Democratic Party wants to stand with anarchists, agitators, rioters, looters and flag burners, that is up to them. But I as your president will not be part of it. The Republican Party will remain the voice of the patriotic heroes who keep America safe.”

headline: For Far-Right Movements, Ashli Babbitt Is Now a ‘Rallying Cry’
abstract: Far-right and white nationalist groups online are holding up Ms. Babbitt’s death as proof that they have been wronged.
lead_paragraph: — Seyward Darby, author of “Sisters in Hate: American Women on the Front Lines of White Nationalism,” referring to Ashli Babbitt

headline: Capitol Attack Could Fuel Extremist Recruitment For Years, Experts Warn
abstract: An ideological jumble of far-right extremists and hate groups flourished under President Trump and claimed new energy after the attack on the Capitol. Now they are debating their next moves.
lead_paragraph: Overthrowing the government. Igniting a second Civil War. Banishing racial minorities, immigrants and Jews. Or simply sowing chaos in the streets.

headline: For Pro Athlete Leading Social Justice Push, a Victory and Uncertainty
abstract: Elizabeth Williams of the Atlanta Dream helped galvanize opposition to one of her team’s owners, Senator Kelly Loeffler, who has criticized Black Lives Matter. But the Capitol riot underscored the work ahead.
lead_paragraph: The challenge seemed simple and direct.

headline: Martin Luther King Jr. Day: 9 Ways to Honor His Legacy
abstract: Marches and parades are on pause this year. But streamed events and exhibitions are still commemorating King’s achievements.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Day, observed this year on Jan. 18, became a national holiday in 1983, 15 years after the death of the civil rights leader. Because the arc of history has a few kinks in it, some states declined to celebrate it until 2000 or adopted names that dilute King’s import. (Alabama and Mississippi observe it in conjunction with Robert E. Lee Day, a symbolic swipe)

headline: Trump’s New Civil Religion
abstract: The storming of the Capitol is a creation myth for a political movement.
lead_paragraph: Since the presidential election was called for Joe Biden on Nov. 7, President Trump has cultivated the myth that the election was stolen. Despite his claims of voter fraud and election mismanagement after dozens of courtroom losses, it’s become clear over the past few months that there is no real legal basis for contesting the election results.

headline: A Democratic Triumph in Georgia, Overshadowed by Right-Wing Violence in Washington
abstract: One January day encapsulated the politics of progress and grievance that have defined the presidency of Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Democrats gained control of the Senate on Wednesday by winning both of Georgia’s runoff races, an electoral repudiation of President Trump that will give the incoming Democratic administration broader policy latitude even as the victory was temporarily overshadowed by a violent mob storming the United States Capitol in the name of the ousted incumbent.

headline: Impeachment Is a Call for ‘Moral Clarity’
abstract: We must clear an ecosystem of mass delusion spread by Fox News and many Republicans.
lead_paragraph: President Trump wanted to make history, and he has, plunging to new depths of ignominy. He has become the first president to be impeached twice.

headline: Washington girds for a pro-Trump rally, as local officials warn of possible violence.
abstract: Thousands of President Trump’s supporters are expected to gather in Washington on Wednesday to hear him rehash false claims of voter fraud in the November election, just as Congress begins formally counting the Electoral College vote.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of President Trump’s supporters are expected to gather in Washington on Wednesday to hear him rehash false claims of voter fraud in the November election, just as Congress begins formally counting the Electoral College vote.

headline: A Final Interview With Hank Aaron: ‘I Recognized That I Had a Gift’
abstract: No matter what happened in America, his greatness still shone.
lead_paragraph: I was born in Atlanta in 1960, and when the Braves moved to town from Milwaukee after the 1965 season, Hank Aaron became my all-seasons hero.

headline: Georgia Votes
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Will the United States spend tens of billions of dollars over the next few years to slow climate change?

headline: Appeasement Got Us Where We Are
abstract: It’s time to stand up to the fascists among us.
lead_paragraph: So, is it finally OK to use the F-word?

headline: How White Evangelical Christians Fused With Trump Extremism
abstract: A potent mix of grievance and religious fervor has turbocharged the support among Trump loyalists, many of whom describe themselves as participants in a kind of holy war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before self-proclaimed members of the far-right group the Proud Boys marched toward the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, they stopped to kneel in the street and prayed in the name of Jesus.

headline: Two Artists, Continents Apart, and a Shared Language of Struggle
abstract: The Australian painter Gordon Hookey and the Los Angeles artist Gary Simmons found they had many things in common. Sports is just one of them.
lead_paragraph: In the small, sun-scorched town of Cloncurry, Australia, the artist Gordon Hookey grew up very much aware of Madison Square Garden. “It was in the psyche of most Aboriginal people, because of boxing,” says Hookey, 59, who belongs to the Waanyi people. “In the early days, boxing was a means for young Aboriginal men — an opportunity for achievement against the background of racism and inequalities.”

headline: Why Emptier Streets Meant an Especially Deadly Year for Traffic Deaths
abstract: In New York City, at least 243 people died in crashes in 2020 — the most since Mayor Bill de Blasio introduced his signature street safety plan in 2014.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic hit New York City, cars seemed to disappear from many streets as the lockdown brought urban life to a halt and drivers stayed home.

headline: In Photos: Crowds of Police Couldn’t Quell Russia’s Pro-Navalny Protests
abstract: More than 4,000 people were detained, but allies of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny called Sunday's demonstrations a success.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people turned out across Russia on Sunday for a second consecutive weekend rally in support of a jailed opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny. But where the protesters went, so did the police, meeting them in sometimes brutal clashes.

headline: The Talk of the Super Bowl Is Quarterbacks, Except One
abstract: The N.F.L. has tried to move on from the controversy over Colin Kaepernick, but recent events suggest his critique of America’s racial climate has remained relevant.
lead_paragraph: Kap was right.

headline: As Trump Reels, Fox News Has a Message for Viewers: Stick With Us
abstract: As allies abandon the president, his favorite network revives familiar villains for the Biden era. And the prospects for a Trump TV media venture are “greatly diminished.”
lead_paragraph: His president reeling, his cable network at a crossroads, Tucker Carlson began his show on Thursday night asking a question that has echoed for weeks among anchors and producers at Fox News: “What is life going to be like for us on Jan. 21?”

headline: On King Holiday, New York’s Mayoral Hopefuls Vie for Attention
abstract: With the Rev. Al Sharpton playing host in Harlem, the crowded field of Democratic candidates tried to sell themselves and inspire a battered city.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Capitol Rioters Walked Away. Climate Protesters Saw a Double Standard.
abstract: “There’s two worlds,” said one community activist who has been arrested several times at nonviolent protests. “And we’ve got to fix that.”
lead_paragraph: The relatively small number of arrests after a mob stormed the Capitol left many environmental activists shaken on Thursday — and wanting answers. Why did so many people who brought destruction into the home of American democracy simply walk away after doing so much damage, not just to a building but to the nation’s sense of itself?

headline: Making Sense of the ‘Mob’ Mentality
abstract: Why do some mass gatherings turn violent? Experts in crowd behavior say there’s still much to learn.
lead_paragraph: The reign of King Louis Philippe, the last king of France, came to an abrupt and ignominious end on Feb. 24, 1848, after days of increasingly violent demonstrations in Paris and months of mounting agitation with the government’s policies.

headline: Sergeants-at-arms face questions about a failure to do more to protect Congress.
abstract: Both men had similar backgrounds, working for years as Secret Service agents but considered more skilled in navigating the agency’s political infighting than as experts in protection. Both went on to land plum assignments: the sergeants-at-arms of the Senate and House.
lead_paragraph: Both men had similar backgrounds, working for years as Secret Service agents but considered more skilled in navigating the agency’s political infighting than as experts in protection. Both went on to land plum assignments: the sergeants-at-arms of the Senate and House.

headline: Raphael Warnock, From the Pulpit to Politics, Doesn’t Shy From ‘Uncomfortable’ Truths
abstract: He first wanted to run for office years ago. Now Stacey Abrams, the Democratic Party and the Rev. Raphael Warnock all believe that the time is ripe for Georgia voters to send a Black Baptist preacher to Washington.

headline: Democrats Win Both Georgia Races to Gain Control of Senate
abstract: Victories by Jon Ossoff and the Rev. Raphael Warnock, which were overshadowed by violence from Trump supporters in Washington, will reshape the balance of power in Congress.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Jon Ossoff completed a Democratic sweep of Georgia’s Senate runoffs on Wednesday, a striking political validation for his party in a state that has been challenging for Democrats for most of the last two decades.

headline: At Biden’s Inaugural Events, the Music Was Earnestly Reassuring
abstract: Artists including Bruce Springsteen, Demi Lovato and John Legend tried to bring together an America that couldn’t gather in person, and irony and bombast were banished.
lead_paragraph: Throughout President Biden’s inauguration, music sent every possible signal of unabashed earnestness. Irony was banished; so were arrogance, bombast, triumphalism and confrontation. Echoing the Biden campaign, and tightly coordinated with the speeches and imagery of his first day in office, the music insisted on unity after division, hope after pain.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 31, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 31, 2021.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the drama “The Dig” referred imprecisely to the helmet shown. It was a reconstruction of what the original Anglo-Saxon helmet might have looked like, not the original.

headline: Kodak Black Celebrates Clemency From Trump, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by FKA twigs, Jupiter & Okwess, Prettymuch and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: The Capitol Was Just the Start
abstract: It was a showdown between reality and dark digital fantasy. Fantasy didn’t lose.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Assault on the Capitol: America’s ‘Dark Night of the Soul’
abstract: Readers urge that President Trump be removed from office or prosecuted, assess blame, and wonder why a mob was able to storm the Capitol unimpeded.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Kids of Survival Are Middle-Aged — and Transforming Yet Again
abstract: Studio K.O.S. continues the legacy of the ’80s art collective that grew up, entered museums and regrouped in Hoboken.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J.— As their name suggests, the Kids of Survival have been through plenty before there was ever a pandemic. Surmounting obstacles is what they do. Except now they are not kids anymore.

headline: Amazon Union Drive Takes Hold in Unlikely Place
abstract: Workers at a warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., are to vote next month on whether to unionize, the largest and most viable effort of its kind involving the technology giant.
lead_paragraph: The largest, most viable effort to unionize Amazon in many years began last summer not in a union stronghold like New York or Michigan, but at a Fairfield Inn outside Birmingham, in the right-to-work state of Alabama.

headline: Suzi Analogue Wants Black Women in Experimental Music to Never Compromise
abstract: She couldn’t find a label that understood her work, so she started her own. Now she’s doubling down on her mission to provide a home for others who want to create with total freedom.
lead_paragraph: The Black Lives Matter protests of 2020 put renewed pressure on the music industry to scrutinize its long-troubled relationship with race. It’s a business that has relied on Black talent onstage without investing in Black executives behind the scenes; a space where Black artists have been nudged into specific genres and ways of creating; a place where women and L.G.B.T. people of color have been even further marginalized.

headline: By the People, for the People, but Not Necessarily Open to the People
abstract: “It breaks my heart”: Increased security in the capital over the years has made public spaces less public, and the storming of the Capitol means that will probably continue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The seven-foot-tall metal fencing that has sealed the perimeter of the U.S. Capitol grounds and fortified the Supreme Court across the street is temporary. But it portends lasting change likely to come: In the capital city, there will be more hardening, more barriers, less openness, less access.

headline: Jennifer Lopez sang classic tributes to America at the inauguration
abstract: The singer was a Biden campaign supporter.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lopez, the singer and actress, sang the folk song “This Land Is Your Land” and “America the Beautiful,” with a brief snippet of her hit “Let’s Get Loud,” at the inauguration of Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday.

headline: Denzel Washington, Man on Fire
abstract: The actor never leans in — he’s all in. And in his latest, “Macbeth,” conjured by Joel Coen, he is as sharp and deadly as a dagger.
lead_paragraph: When Denzel Washington and Frances McDormand began rehearsing to play the Macbeths, he asked her how she thought the couple had met.

headline: What Made Black History in 2021?
abstract: After the tumult and triumphs of 2020, here are the achievements that shaped the first year following the country’s racial reckoning.
lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday morning in January, Kamala Harris became the first Black woman — and the first woman of color — sworn into the office of Vice President of the United States.

headline: Where Is the Forgiveness and Grace in Cancel Culture?
abstract: Contemporary activists can benefit from Tutu’s ideas about restorative justice and strengthen their quest for fundamental fairness.
lead_paragraph: The words of the Rev. Anthony Thompson in 2015 were all but unthinkable to many Americans, after the ghastly crime that led to his proclamation. “I would just like him to know,” Mr. Thompson said, “I forgive you, and my family forgives you.”

headline: Robberies. Drought. Tent Camps. Los Angeles’s Next Mayor Faces a Litany of Crises.
abstract: The city’s unease could prove pivotal next year, when Los Angeles will elect a new mayor in a contest that civic leaders say will have the highest stakes in decades.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Peter Nichols has lived for 22 years in a two-bedroom Cape Cod in the Fairfax District, in the flat, bungalow-lined midsection between the east and the west sides of Los Angeles. His block used to make him proud, with its neat lawns and palm trees: Crime was low. Streets were clean. When a problem arose — drug use in the park, traffic from the nearby Melrose Avenue shopping district — the city seemed to know how to address it.

headline: New York’s Next Police Boss, a Queens Native, Comes ‘Full Circle’
abstract: Keechant Sewell, chief of detectives in Nassau County, will become the city’s 45th police commissioner after she impressed Eric Adams with “emotional intelligence.”
lead_paragraph: It was only an exercise, but the scenario was painfully familiar: A white police officer had just killed an unarmed Black man, and now the candidates to become New York City’s next police commissioner needed to show how they would address the media.

headline: Self-Proclaimed Proud Boys Member Gets 10 Years for Violence at Portland Protests
abstract: Prosecutors called Alan Swinney, 51, a “white nationalist vigilante cowboy” who shot a man in the eye with a paintball gun.
lead_paragraph: A self-professed member of the Proud Boys from Texas who traveled to Portland, Ore., to confront protesters there last year was sentenced on Friday to 10 years in prison for shooting a man in the eye with a paintball gun, spraying people in the face with bear mace and aiming a loaded handgun at a crowd, prosecutors said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Asian and Black Leaders Unite to End Hate but Split on Policing
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 20, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “We all come together for something major, and then we go off and do our own separate things, unfortunately.”

headline: Rev. C. Herbert Oliver, Civil Rights Activist, Dies at 96
abstract: He helped focus the nation on bombings and police abuse in Alabama in the 1960s and, later, on problems with the education of Black students in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. C. Herbert Oliver, a civil rights apostle who confronted the segregationist police commissioner Bull Connor in Birmingham, Ala., and challenged the way the public school system in New York City educated Black children, died on Nov. 30 in Brooklyn. He was 96.

headline: Behind Low Vaccination Rates Lurks a More Profound Social Weakness
abstract: Vaccine hesitancy reflects a transformation of people’s core beliefs about what we owe each other.
lead_paragraph: Robert Steed knew the toll Covid-19 had taken on the South Bronx, where he’d lived most of his life. There were the ambulances that would pull up to the drab brick apartment buildings of St. Mary’s Park Houses, the public housing complex where he’d grown up. There were longtime tenants who’d succumbed to the disease. There were posters pasted near the elevators, urging residents to get vaccinated. But he wouldn’t go near the vaccine.

headline: Redistricting Makes California a Top House Battlefield for 2022
abstract: As legislators across the country draw House maps to protect incumbents, a nonpartisan commission of California citizens is drafting one that will scramble political fortunes for both parties.
lead_paragraph: Follow live California special election results.

headline: Teen Who Sought New Life Found Death at Hands of the Police, Father Says
abstract: The family of Valentina Orellana Peralta described the terrifying moments before the 14-year-old girl, who had recently moved to Los Angeles from Chile, was killed by a stray bullet fired by a police officer.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — She had been in the United States for less than a year, but already her principal at a tech-focused charter school in Los Angeles knew her as a strong student in math and physics.

headline: A Murder, Gold Bars, a Jailbreak and Questions About Justice
abstract: Was the 1993 killing of a woman near Buffalo committed by a prison escapee? Was the detective who solved the case involved? Is there anything straightforward about this crime?
lead_paragraph: The two men were in the yard at the state prison in Dannemora, N.Y., when Richard Matt brought up an old murder.

headline: Didion’s Prophetic Eye on America
abstract: Didion always knew something was out of sync in this country.
lead_paragraph: Joan Didion was a writer uniquely attuned to the disorder and fragmentation of our times, the dizzying changes overtaking America since the 1960s, when, as she wrote in “Slouching Towards Bethlehem,” lines from Yeats’s famous poem “The Second Coming” reverberated “in my inner ear as if they were surgically implanted there”:

headline: ‘I Got Them Off the Hook by Winning’
abstract: Lee Elder forced golf forward by winning his way into the Masters tournament in 1975, the first Black player to do so, laying a path for Tiger Woods and others.
lead_paragraph: How do we measure athletic greatness? By the number of big wins and unforgettable championships?

headline: Will Jussie Smollett Be Sentenced to Prison for Lying to the Police?
abstract: The actor who was found guilty of falsely telling the police he was the victim of a hate crime faces a possible sentence of up to three years, but experts disagree on whether the judge is likely to incarcerate him.
lead_paragraph: The discussion in the case of Jussie Smollett, the actor convicted on Thursday of falsely reporting he was the victim of a racist and homophobic attack, has turned to whether the he will receive prison time when he is sentenced in several weeks.

headline: Best of Late Night in 2021: Trump’s Never-Ending Swan Song
abstract: A late-night target throughout his time in office, the former president remained a favorite subject, along with Covid’s ongoing impact and President Biden’s first year in the White House.
lead_paragraph: Despite Donald J. Trump’s loss to Joseph R. Biden in the presidential election of 2020, late-night hosts still couldn’t shake the former president in 2021.

headline: In 2021, Black Boyhood Got More Complex on TV
abstract: Shows like “The Wonder Years,” “Swagger” and “Colin in Black and White” offered Black coming-of-age narratives that challenged longstanding TV stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: “Most men have no idea about the female sex drive,” Lillian Williams (Saycon Sengbloh), the middle-aged African American mother on “The Wonder Years,” warns her nerdy 12-year-old son, Dean (Elisha Williams). “I don’t want you to turn out like them.”

headline: ‘I Look Like the Strategy’: Winsome Sears Wants Black Voters to Rethink the G.O.P.
abstract: The incoming lieutenant governor of Virginia was an unlikely candidate: a deeply conservative Black woman, and an immigrant, who supports Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — On a December afternoon, Winsome Sears, Virginia’s lieutenant governor-elect, stood at the podium in the State Senate chamber where she will soon preside. It was empty but for a few clerks and staffers who were walking her through a practice session, making pretend motions and points of order. Ms. Sears followed along as the clerks explained arcane Senate protocols, though she occasionally raised matters that weren’t in the script.

headline: Video Shows Chaos and Violence at Scene of Los Angeles Police Shooting
abstract: Body camera and surveillance footage shows a man attacking holiday shoppers before police officers opened fire, killing him and a 14-year-old girl who was in a dressing room.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A woman clutched at her bloodied face in an aisle splotched with red as she scrambled away from a man who had been pummeling her with a bike lock. A frightened employee at the Burlington clothing store told Los Angeles police officers that a man was “going crazy” in the store.

headline: What Can You Learn from a Celebrity Masterclass on Empathy?
abstract: Pharrell Williams is joined by a chorus of famous people whose lessons about feeling for others strangely highlight their personal achievements.
lead_paragraph: Each online course from Masterclass begins with the same introduction. Heels click purposefully into a room. A piano lid is confidently opened, a marble slab floured, a knife honed. Lighting pools warmly amid expensive-looking wood. Swells of music coalesce into momentary silence; something of quality is about to start.

headline: With Armory Show, the World Is Catching Up to Carrie Mae Weems
abstract: “The Shape of Things” confronts current issues of identity and injustice that the artist has been exploring throughout her 40-year career.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, amid a spate of violence against Black men around the country, including Rodney King, the artist Carrie Mae Weems made a decorative dinner plate that read, “Commemorating Every Black Man Who Lives to See Twenty-One.”

headline: Can We Help the Homeless?
abstract: Why it’s so difficult to find viable solutions for California’s homelessness crisis.
lead_paragraph: In the last edition of this newsletter, I wrote about the proliferation of tiny-home villages for those living on the streets. Today, I will be focusing on what it is like to live in one and why there are no easy fixes.

headline: Victory Speech (Hillary’s Version)
abstract: Hillary Clinton delivered an unused election speech. Jennifer Aniston cried at Central Perk. It was a year for watching celebrities reinhabit their past selves.
lead_paragraph: MasterClass, an online platform where you can watch famous people deliver video tutorials for $180 a year, recently debuted a course on the topic of resilience. It begins with a close-up shot of a weathered oval desk. We hear papers shuffling, birds chirping, the voices of an ethereal choir. A woman’s hands drift across a policy document. As white light flares through a garden window, Hillary Clinton appears. She wears a serene smile and a magenta blouse. It feels like she’s back from the dead.

headline: In Fight Against Violence, Asian and Black Activists Struggle to Agree
abstract: Calls for unity have ebbed over disagreements on one main issue: policing.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — This spring, Black political leaders and civil rights activists delivered a message to Asian Americans: We stand with you.

headline: The Students Returned, but the Fallout From a Long Disruption Remained
abstract: “They’re like, ‘The world’s out of control, why should I be in control?’” the principal of Liberty High School in Bethlehem, Pa., said of some of his struggling students.
lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — Three hours into a recent Monday morning, blood had already been spilled in a hallway at Liberty High School. With his walkie-talkie in hand, the principal, Harrison Bailey III, called on the custodial staff to clean up the remnants of a brawl while hurrying to the cafeteria in hopes of staving off another.

headline: Fox News Hosts Take the Offensive About Texts to Meadows
abstract: Stars of the most-watched cable channel continued to downplay the Jan. 6 attack and back Donald J. Trump while criticizing the investigation of the Capitol siege.
lead_paragraph: The Fox News hosts Sean Hannity and Laura Ingraham vociferously defended themselves for sending text messages on Jan. 6 that urged Mark Meadows, the last White House chief of staff under Donald J. Trump, to persuade the then-president to take action to stop the Capitol attack.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Our newest picks include a good cop-bad cop revenge thriller starring Donnie Yen, a high-tech animated take on Hansel and Gretel, and more.
lead_paragraph: For action fans seeking out new movies on streaming, there are plenty of car chases, explosions and fist fights to sift through. We help by providing some streaming highlights.

headline: The Rise of Eric Adams and Black New York
abstract: Eric Adams’s winning coalition shows how the city’s power structure has changed.
lead_paragraph: It was winter in Black New York, and the last thing Eric Leroy Adams wanted to do was join the New York Police Department.

headline: Epidemics: A Force for Life-Changing Innovation
abstract: “Design and Healing” at the Cooper Hewitt shows adaptations to disease through history that shaped health care, behavior and the form of buildings.
lead_paragraph: Before I entered the Cooper Hewitt’s new exhibition, “Design and Healing: Creative Responses to Epidemics,” I wondered if the most emblematically museum-worthy object from Covid-19 would be a bloodstained hospital “gown” made up of trash bags and a shower cap.

headline: Texas Board Withdraws Clemency Recommendation for George Floyd
abstract: The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles said it had made “procedural errors” when it issued a recommendation that Mr. Floyd be posthumously pardoned for a 2004 drug conviction.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles has withdrawn a recommendation that George Floyd be granted a posthumous pardon for a 2004 drug conviction in Houston, citing “procedural errors” in the recommendation.

headline: The Show Will Go On, Thanks to Them
abstract: The latest Covid surge has highlighted the essential skills provided by Broadway’s swings and understudies.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at the swings and understudies who have been vital to Broadway during the Omicron surge. We’ll also examine why Mayor-elect Eric Adams may have held off on naming a former high-ranking police official to a City Hall post. And we’ll run the Metropolitan Diary item that readers chose as the best of the year.

headline: What’s Better Than Charity?
abstract: Mutual aid fulfills needs, but it also builds stronger, more resilient communities.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Holiday Giving Guide 2021. For other ideas on where to donate this year, please see the rest of our guide here.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the Parents’ Role in a Recent School Shooting
abstract: Teenage comments in response to a question about this and two more writing prompts — and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: This week on The Learning Network, one of our writing prompts asked teenagers if parents should ever be held responsible for a school shooting. Over 100 weighed in with thoughtful responses.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Commissioner and First Deputy File for Retirement
abstract: Commissioner Dermot Shea and his first deputy, Benjamin Tucker, each served in the Police Department for more than two decades.
lead_paragraph: The New York City police commissioner and his top deputy have both filed papers to retire at the end of the year, after long careers that will end during one of the most tumultuous periods in the department’s history.

headline: The Breakout Stars of 2021
abstract: In a year that offered glimmers of hope across the world of arts, these performers and creators rose to the occasion.
lead_paragraph: The cultural world began to sputter back to life this year, and in turn, so did many of us — slipping out of our sweats and into movie theaters, clubs and Broadway shows. Even for those who were less confident rubbing (or bumping) elbows in public, artists brought us plenty of joy in the safety of our home. It may not have been the beforetimes, but in 2021, these artists and creators from across the arts gave us a fresh outlook.

headline: 6 Numbers That Reveal Bill de Blasio’s Legacy on Inequality
abstract: Police stops are down, but homelessness endures. Schools remain segregated, but there are 60,000 prekindergarten slots.
lead_paragraph: When Bill de Blasio first ran for mayor in 2013, he pledged to reduce inequality in an increasingly opulent New York City where he argued poor residents were falling behind.

headline: ‘Reopening Night’ Review: The Show Goes On
abstract: This HBO documentary goes behind the scenes of the Public Theater’s post-shutdown, modern adaptation of “The Merry Wives of Windsor,” featuring an all-Black cast.
lead_paragraph: Rudy Valdez’s documentary, “Reopening Night,” takes viewers behind the scenes of “Merry Wives,” the Public Theater’s first production after the coronavirus pandemic shut down Broadway and other venues until earlier this year.

headline: Gillian Laub’s Divided House Is Still Standing. What About Yours?
abstract: “Family Matters” at the ICP captures the inevitability of families fractured over politics.
lead_paragraph: Someone has left in a hurry. The signs are there in the photograph: the open drawers, the improperly rolled tissue paper, the white electric cable peeking out from underneath the counter. The walls and floors are covered with marble — reflecting light, intensifying the room’s emptiness. Through the window, outside, tall slim trees give the house a sense of scale and location — it is easy to imagine that this is an outsize property in an area far from where everyday people live.

headline: They’ve Got Game: New Sports Books
abstract: The season’s latest releases take up the New England Patriots, the origin story of Giannis Antetokounmpo — and the role of discrimination, protests and money in the world of athletics.
lead_paragraph: Sports fans can easily forget or dismiss a clear reality about the games they love: They are a form of entertainment, a business endeavor competing among many options for emotional and financial attention.

headline: Meet the Next Big Fashion Group
abstract: Kerby Jean-Raymond has spent the last year and a half secretly trying to change the game for minority designers.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, when the United States was being roiled by the aftermath of the George Floyd murder and businesses of all kinds were coming face to face with their own systemic racism, Kerby Jean-Raymond, the founder and designer of Pyer Moss, who has used his brand to shed light on Black history as well as police brutality, began to get a lot of calls.

headline: The Seattle Seahawks’ Boom Is Busted
abstract: The bold energy that defined the Seattle Seahawks is gone. What will replace it?
lead_paragraph: Remember the Seattle Seahawks?

headline: The 10 Best Podcasts of 2021
abstract: Shows about Chippendales, a notorious Hollywood bomb, the search for the perfect pasta shape and the immediate aftermath of 9/11 are among those worthy of your attention.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: WTA Suspends Tournaments in China Over Treatment of Peng Shuai
abstract: Steve Simon said Wednesday that the women’s tennis tour would not stage tournaments in China, including Hong Kong, because he has been unable to communicate with Peng despite repeated attempts.
lead_paragraph: The women’s professional tennis tour announced Wednesday that it was immediately suspending all tournaments in China, including Hong Kong, in response to the disappearance from public life of the tennis star Peng Shuai after she accused a top Communist Party leader of sexual assault.

headline: A Harvard Scam and the Best Podcasts of 2021: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: How Eric Adams Picked a Police Commissioner
abstract: The selection process included a mock news conference. What Keechant Sewell said got the incoming mayor’s attention, and she got the job.
lead_paragraph: It’s Thursday. We’ll look at the moment when Eric Adams, the incoming mayor, found his police commissioner. We’ll also see why Thursday will be a big day for two city parks.

headline: Sherrilyn Ifill: ‘There Is No Guarantee We Make It Out of This Period as a Democracy’
abstract: After almost a decade at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Ifill explains why advocacy is an essential part of her legal work.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted on all charges related to the shooting of two people at a Black Lives Matter protest in Kenosha, Wisc. Before, during and after the trial, journalists and pundits broke down the most sensational moments on the stand, and many tried to discern what Rittenhouse’s not-guilty decision meant about the country at large. People were eager to draw direct connections between the arguments used in court and the inequities that are seen in the country on a daily basis.

headline: The Year in 41 Debates
abstract: Look back on the most important — and absurd — questions of 2021.
lead_paragraph: Look back on the most important — and absurd — questions of 2021.

headline: The Year in Pictures 2021
abstract: While many people, fearing the virus, continued to stay close to home, photographers traveled the world, documenting the world’s turmoil and triumphs.
lead_paragraph: While many people, fearing the virus, continued to stay close to home, photographers traveled the world, documenting the world’s turmoil and triumphs.

headline: History Can Be Erased. It Often Has Been.
abstract: I see Republicans trying to alter our perception of the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. I do not take that lightly.

headline: In Antitrust Trial, Tim Cook Argues Apple Doesn’t Hurt App Makers
abstract: The chief executive of Apple, which was sued by the gaming company Epic, said his company had invested heavily on security and had lowered some fees in its App Store.
lead_paragraph: Tim Cook, testifying on Friday in a trial that could undermine Apple’s efforts to fend off growing scrutiny of its power, defended his business from accusations that it hurt app makers while on the hunt to expand its profits.

headline: A Timeline of What Has Happened in the Year Since George Floyd’s Death
abstract: A look back at what has transpired in the year since Mr. Floyd’s murder reveals a country both struggling to confront it history of racial division and continuing to succumb to it.
lead_paragraph: George Floyd, a 46-year-old African-American man, is killed on a street corner in Minneapolis after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by Derek Chauvin and other officers responding to a forgery call. Darnella Frazier, a 17-year-old, turns on her cellphone to capture video of Mr. Chauvin, who is white, using his knee to pin Mr. Floyd by his neck. Mr. Floyd is heard repeatedly saying, “I can’t breathe.”

headline: Who’s the ‘Comeback’ Candidate? 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race.
abstract: Two leading candidates wanted to hold a huge party to celebrate New York City’s revival from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Gaza Conflict Stokes ‘Identity Crisis’ for Young American Jews
abstract: A new generation is confronting the region’s longstanding conflict in a very different context, with very different pressures, from their parents’ and grandparents’ generations.
lead_paragraph: Dan Kleinman does not know quite how to feel.

headline: N.Y.C. Pride Will Take Steps to Keep Police Out of Parade and Events
abstract: L.G.B.T.Q. police officers will not be allowed to participate as a group in the annual march, and organizers said they will rely on private security for their events.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s annual Pride celebration, which began 51 years ago as a defiant commemoration of an anti-police uprising and has evolved into a city-sanctioned equality jamboree, will take steps to reduce the presence of law enforcement at its events.

headline: Uncovering the History of America’s First Koreatown
abstract: Friday: A Korean-American professor discusses the most gratifying research of his career, into Riverside’s Pachappa Camp.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Eric Adams Says He Has Something to Prove. Becoming Mayor Might Help.
abstract: Mr. Adams is a top fund-raiser in the New York City mayoral race, with key endorsements and strong polling, but he still faces questions about his preparedness for the job.

headline: A Year After George Floyd: Pressure to Add Police Amid Rising Crime
abstract: Los Angeles, like other cities across the nation, is facing a rise in gun violence. And the police budget is growing.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Helen Jones grew up in Watts in a time of gang wars and a crack epidemic, when the police used battering rams to knock down the walls of suspected drug houses and Black people were routinely profiled or beaten by street cops.

headline: House Republicans Have Had Enough of Liz Cheney’s Truth-Telling
abstract: G.O.P. House members are plotting a fresh bid to dethrone Ms. Cheney from her leadership post. Her transgression: continued repudiation of Donald J. Trump and his false election claims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first time defenders of Donald J. Trump came for Representative Liz Cheney, for the offense of having voted to impeach him, fellow Republicans closed ranks to save her leadership post, with Representative Kevin McCarthy boasting that their “big tent” party had enough room for both the former president and a stalwart critic.

headline: Looking for Bipartisan Accord? Just Ask About Big Business.
abstract: In surveys and political discourse, Republicans are increasingly critical of corporations, but not for the reasons Democrats have long held that view.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in Washington and around the country have soured on big business, joining Democrats in expressing concern that corporations wield too much influence. The shift has left corporate America with fewer allies in a tumultuous period for American society and the global economy.

headline: Maya Wiley Has ‘50 Ideas’ and One Goal: To Make History as Mayor
abstract: Ms. Wiley has unveiled an array of policies to fight inequality as she seeks to become the first woman elected mayor of New York. Can she break out of the pack?
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Olivia Laing’s Latest Subject Is Bodily Integrity
abstract: In “Everybody,” the author draws on a chorus of voices to investigate the physical meaning of freedom.
lead_paragraph: EVERYBODY A Book About Freedom By Olivia Laing

headline: She Built a Baltimore Restaurant Empire, but She Still Works the Stove
abstract: Cindy Wolf is a rarity — a seasoned chef focused on her flagship and a style of white-linen dining that’s been endangered by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — In July of 1999, Cindy Wolf cooked lunch for Julia Child at Charleston, her restaurant on the city’s downtown waterfront. At the end of a five-course meal that included fried oysters with cayenne-lemon mayonnaise and pan-seared sweetbreads, Ms. Wolf went out to the dining room to meet the cooking legend.

headline: 2 Men Charged in Killing of 1-Year-Old Boy at Brooklyn Cookout
abstract: Investigators believe the men charged in the death of Davell Gardner, the city’s youngest gun violence victim last year, were part of a deadly feud between gangs in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: It was a heart-rending killing in a summer of overwhelming grief: Davell Gardner, a 1-year-old boy sitting in his stroller last July during a nighttime barbecue in Brooklyn, was shot in the stomach after two gunmen hopped out of an SUV and opened fire on the gathering.

headline: The Netherlands’ Eurovision entry featured a Black Lives Matter moment.
abstract: Jeangu Macrooy, the Netherlands’ entry, takes the stage to sing “Birth of a New Age,” a song penned in response to the police killing of George Floyd and the subsequent resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Jeangu Macrooy, the Netherlands’ entry, takes the stage to sing “Birth of a New Age,” a song penned in response to the police killing of George Floyd and the subsequent resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement worldwide.

headline: How Privilege and Capital Warped a Movement
abstract: Acknowledging people's humanity is interesting. It’s not necessarily justice. Improving their lives, keeping them alive, may be.
lead_paragraph: On a humid, windless night several years ago, I was driving my parents’ S.U.V. through the oak-covered back streets of my hometown with four teenage friends. At an empty intersection, I reflexively began turning left before spotting the no-left-turn sign on the traffic light above. I jerked the wheel right, crossed the intersection and headed for the U-turn lane.

headline: Justice Clarence Thomas, Long Silent, Has Turned Talkative
abstract: The Supreme Court’s orderly telephone arguments, prompted by the pandemic, have given the public a revealing look at its longest-serving member.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Clarence Thomas, who once went a decade without asking a question from the Supreme Court bench, is about to complete a term in which he was an active participant in every single argument.

headline: An ‘Army of 16-Year-Olds’ Takes On the Democrats
abstract: Young progressives are an unpredictable new factor in Massachusetts elections. They’re ardent, and organized, and they don’t take orders.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Dana Depelteau, a hotel manager, had just gone public with a long-shot candidacy for mayor in Boston when he noticed that someone in city politics was going after him online.

headline: ‘You’ve Lost Your Sparkle’: What to Do When Burnout Hits
abstract: Dr. Yumiko Kadota, a surgeon in Sydney, and the author of “Emotional Female,” on stress, burnout and toxic work environments.
lead_paragraph: — Yumiko Kadota, the author of “Emotional Female”

headline: Shaun Donovan Has the Résumé and the Money. He Just Needs the Votes.
abstract: In running for mayor of New York, Mr. Donovan is arguing that his leadership experience offers what the city needs in a time of crisis.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Northwestern Athletic Director Resigns Amid Backlash Over Harassment Case
abstract: Mike Polisky, who held the position for about 10 days, stepped back under mounting concerns about his past handling of complaints of racist and sexist policies in the university’s cheer program.
lead_paragraph: Erika Carter breathed a small sigh of relief when she learned that Mike Polisky had resigned as the Northwestern University athletic director after about 10 days in the role.

headline: ‘Social Media Is the Mass Protest’: Solidarity With Palestinians Grows Online
abstract: As Israeli airstrikes pummel Gaza, the reaction from Arab capitals has been muted and protests scattered. But the voices on social media have been loud and clear.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The video traveled at 4G speed, leapfrogging across international borders, social media platforms and social justice movements: a young Palestinian woman in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah, shouting in furious English at a Jewish man, “You are stealing my house!”

headline: Leaders Position House G.O.P. Against Independent Accounting for Jan. 6 Riot
abstract: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the top House Republican, said he would oppose the independent commission, and urged the party’s rank and file to do the same.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top House Republicans urged their colleagues on Tuesday to oppose bipartisan legislation creating an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, positioning their conference against a full accounting of the deadly riot by a pro-Trump mob.

headline: From Colombia to U.S., Police Violence Pushes Protests Into Mass Movements
abstract: In Colombia, and many other countries, security forces’ attacks on protesters have led to nationwide reckonings with injustice.
lead_paragraph: When the history of this global moment is written, there will need to be an entire chapter on police forces’ spectacular own goals as force for change.

headline: Times Square Shooting Suspect Arrested in Florida
abstract: The police said Farrakhan Muhammad opened fire during an argument with his brother, shooting bystanders including a 4-year-old girl.
lead_paragraph: A four-day search for a man wanted in a weekend shooting in Times Square that injured two women and a 4-year-old Brooklyn girl ended on Wednesday when the suspect was arrested in Florida, the police said.

headline: Judge Drops Murder Charges Against Two Officers Accused of Body-Slamming Man
abstract: Officers Desmond Barney and Lincoln Lampley were charged last year with killing George Robinson, 62, in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Mississippi on Thursday dismissed second-degree murder charges against two police officers who were accused last year of body-slamming and then beating a 62-year-old man, prosecutors said.

headline: A Year of Protest. But What About Progress?
abstract: For 11 months, players across England have taken a knee to highlight racial injustice. But some fear the leagues who endorsed the protests will move on without making meaningful changes.
lead_paragraph: Michael Oliver blew his whistle, but nothing happened. The Premier League had been waiting for three months for this moment, forced into unwilling suspension by the coronavirus pandemic. This was its grand return, the first game back, a late spring evening at Villa Park last June. And yet there was no sound, no fury.
