headline: Frieze New York, First Live Art Fair in a Year, Kicks Off at the Shed
abstract: Our critics toured more than 60 booths — a sight for art-starved eyes. Here are 16 highlights to catch, in person or virtually.
lead_paragraph: The colossal white tent on Randalls Island — the one that occasionally threatened to uplift and blow away — is gone, along with the frenetic ferry rides up and down the East River. But Frieze is back, the first live art fair returning to New York after more than a year.

headline: He Wanted to Reform the N.Y.P.D. from Within. Now He Wants to Be Mayor.
abstract: A former police officer, Eric Adams is running as a blue collar New Yorker focused on public safety.
lead_paragraph: A former police officer, Eric Adams is running as a blue collar New Yorker focused on public safety.

headline: Look, Just Keep Filling the Chocolate Dish
abstract: A reminder to mind your own business and know your worth.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: I Needed to Lead My City. But I Needed to Apologize First.
abstract: Confederate monuments no longer define our city. But we must build something new in their place.
lead_paragraph: As I stepped outside City Hall, several thousand people were waiting for me.

headline: How New Yorkers Marked the Anniversary of George Floyd’s Killing
abstract: Demonstrations across the city took on varied tones throughout the day, a mix of frustration, celebration and sadness.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Amid Signs of Trouble, Can MOCA Find Its Footing?
abstract: The year has been bumpy for this Los Angeles museum, with Covid-19, questions about diversity and a leadership reorganization. But its director, Klaus Biesenbach, says, “every day is a chance to improve.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Klaus Biesenbach strutted through the Geffen Contemporary, the Museum of Contemporary Art’s warehouse exhibition space recently, stylish in his signature midnight blue suit and black ankle boots. Talking about plans to reopen on June 3 and recent building improvements he has made as director, he came across like a guy with his hands on the steering wheel.

headline: Basquiat and Other Artists of Color Lead a Swell of Auction Sales
abstract: As live auctions resumed at Sotheby’s on Wednesday night, bidders there and at Christie’s the previous night welcomed a shift toward diversity in the contemporary art market.
lead_paragraph: Just as the art market withstood the trauma of the Sept. 11 attacks and the economic plunge of 2008, so did the purchasing of high-priced paintings prevail at Sotheby’s on Wednesday during the first live contemporary auction since the onset of the pandemic in March 2020.

headline: The Murder of George Floyd, One Year On
abstract: Times Opinion is publishing a special series on George Floyd and America, a year after his death.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

headline: The Woman Behind Iconic Beyoncé Looks and ‘Black Owned Everything’
abstract: Zerina Akers wants widespread interest in Black brands to be more than a trend.
lead_paragraph: The costume designer and wardrobe stylist Zerina Akers does not want people to think that her life is picture-perfect, even if she spends her time making sure that her clients are.

headline: A Misstep by the Organizers of Pride
abstract: Barring police and corrections officers from participating in Pride events shows a lack of farsightedness at a critical moment for L.G.B.T.Q. rights and support.
lead_paragraph: Ana Arboleda always makes sure her police uniform is crisp and clean when she leaves home — but never more so than on New York’s annual Pride celebration, when two parts of her identity converge.

headline: A Protest Moment I’ll Never Forget
abstract: Last year, more than 30 Times reporters across the country covered the demonstrations after George Floyd’s death. Here, 10 of them reflect on the sights and interactions that have stayed with them.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: ‘You Can Feel the Tension’: A Windfall for Minority Farmers Divides Rural America
abstract: A $4 billion federal fund meant to confront how racial injustice has shaped American farming has angered white farmers who say they are being unfairly excluded.
lead_paragraph: LaGRANGE, Mo. — Shade Lewis had just come in from feeding his cows one sunny spring afternoon when he opened a letter that could change his life: The government was offering to pay off his $200,000 farm loan, part of a new debt relief program created by Democrats to help farmers who have endured generations of racial discrimination.

headline: Israel Ground Forces Shell Gaza as Fighting Intensifies
abstract: The surge in fighting left Israel in an unprecedented position — fighting Palestinian militants on its southern flank as it sought to head off its worst civil unrest in decades.
lead_paragraph: Israel launched an intense air and ground assault on the Gaza Strip early Friday, pounding targets with warplanes, artillery and tank fire in the largest single operation of a four-day conflict with Palestinian militants that had been waged by airstrikes from Israel and rockets from Gaza.

headline: For Chakaia Booker, Whose Medium Is Tires, the Art Is in the Journey
abstract: First things first: “I sculpt myself every day,” says Booker, who appears swathed in yards of textiles, from headdress to sneakers.
lead_paragraph: ALLENTOWN, Pa. — Chakaia Booker’s studio here is 20,000 square feet of unheated space, with a roof that leaks and a squirrel problem. Its floor is grooved in places with tracks from its past life as a trolley maintenance shed.

headline: Biden will meet with George Floyd’s family on the anniversary of his death.
abstract: The George Floyd Justice in Policing Act is languishing in Congress, but the White House is optimistic that legislative talks will help move it forward.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will meet on Tuesday with relatives of George Floyd to mark the anniversary of his death and the start of a nationwide racial reckoning against police brutality.

headline: Roman Protasevich: A Belarus Activist Who ‘Refused to Live in Fear’
abstract: Disgusted by the brutality of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, Mr. Protasevich bravely embarked at 16 on a life in opposition.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Since his teenage years as a rebellious high school student in Belarus and continuing into his 20s while in exile abroad, Roman Protasevich faced so many threats from the country’s security apparatus — of violent beatings, jail, punishment against family members — that “we all sort of got used to them,” a fellow exiled dissident recalled.

headline: New Yorkers Are Crazy About Roller-Skating (Again)
abstract: The Roxy might be long gone, but skating meet-ups are everywhere. And some of them predate the pandemic by decades.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this spring, a party raged on the third floor of Showfields, an experiential retail store in Manhattan. To get there guests rode in an elevator lined with gold tinsel and a mirror.

headline: It’s My Job to Watch. With George Floyd’s Death, I Had to Look Away.
abstract: Devastated by the Rodney King verdict decades ago, our critic refused to view the video of Floyd’s murder. But she found solace in the art it inspired.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never watched the video of George Floyd’s murder. My decision wasn’t premeditated or preordained, but rather an improvised refusal. I did not want to be another spectator of that oldest of American rituals: the killing of a Black person in public.

headline: Eric Adams Mayoral Endorsement Interview
abstract: Eric Adams is the Brooklyn borough president. He was a police officer, and he founded the group 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement Who Care.
lead_paragraph: Eric Adams is the Brooklyn borough president. He was a police captain, and he founded the group 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement Who Care.

headline: Recovery, Recall and Record Revenue: What’s Driving Newsom’s Budget
abstract: Tuesday: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s $267.8 billion budget proposal reflects the wish list of a state “just flush with cash.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: April 2021
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Here is the April edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.

headline: A Police Shooting in Hawaii Has South Africans Demanding Justice
abstract: A Black man from South Africa was shot and killed in an encounter with the police in his adopted home, Hawaii. His countrymen want answers.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A plane from Honolulu landed in Johannesburg earlier this month and offloaded a plastic-wrapped coffin carrying the body of Lindani Myeni, a South African rugby player, aspiring singer and father.

headline: ‘I’m Speechless.’ We Asked Law-Enforcement Officers Around the World How American Policing Looks From Abroad.
abstract: How did it go? Well, you might say that American law enforcement didn’t exactly win any fans.
lead_paragraph: American law enforcement is facing an intense — and long-overdue — public reckoning.

headline: Recasting ‘Riots’ as Black Rebellions
abstract: “America on Fire,” by the Yale University scholar Elizabeth Hinton, connects the unrest of the civil rights era to shifts in social policy authorizing aggressive police tactics whose destructive repercussions are evident today.
lead_paragraph: AMERICA ON FIREThe Untold History of Police Violence and Black Rebellion Since the 1960sBy Elizabeth Hinton

headline: ‘I Knew That I Couldn’t Stay Quiet’
abstract: Millions of Americans took part in street demonstrations after the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis. A year later, first-time protesters reflect on what happened — and what is next.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, millions of Americans took to the streets after the killing of George Floyd at the hands of the Minneapolis police, taking part in what would become the largest protest movement in U.S. history. Many participated in marches and demonstrations for the first time in their lives. From eight first-time protesters, here are reflections on what they did last summer, how this has affected them in the year since and what lies ahead. Their interviews have been edited and condensed.

headline: How New York City Is Saving Its Local News Outlets
abstract: City agencies are spending at least half of their ad budgets on local newspapers and websites.
lead_paragraph: At a time when newsrooms nationwide are laying off reporters and some are closing down, a program begun by Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration has been helping to sustain small, independent media outlets in every corner of the city.

headline: Kathryn Garcia Mayoral Endorsement Interview
abstract: Kathryn Garcia is a longtime civil servant who served as commissioner of New York City’s Sanitation Department.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Garcia is a longtime civil servant who served as commissioner of New York City’s Sanitation Department.

headline: Pride Said Gay Cops Aren’t Welcome. Then Came the Backlash.
abstract: Just as L.G.B.T.Q. visibility reached a new peak, splinter groups are re-examining the annual parade. Is Pride too corporate? Should police officers be allowed to march? Is it a revolution, or is it a party?
lead_paragraph: It was two weeks before the start of Pride month, and the organization that runs New York’s Pride march was fighting about cops. The leadership had just announced that officers could no longer take part in the march, including a contingent of L.G.B.T.Q. officers that has marched in uniform since 1996.

headline: Gaza, George Floyd, Eurovision: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Old Songs in the Public Domain Get Makeovers With a Purpose
abstract: The producer Ray Angry and the visual artist Katherine McMahon lead a project that reimagines songs freely available for public use for the current moment.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday in April, at a Manhattan recording studio strewn with antique lamps and masked technicians, the singer Liv Warfield’s face was clouded in concentration as she layered harmonies into the outro of a rousing soul number. She noodled for a while, trying to work out which notes to add next. “We might have to go to the rafters,” she concluded.

headline: The Way of the Conscientious Objector
abstract: A philosophical and moral conversion led this Marine to leave the military. Why don't more take this path?
lead_paragraph: It was a book of Buddhist parables that put Michael Rasmussen over the edge. In March 2017, Mr. Rasmussen was living near a naval base in Japan, six years into training as a Marine pilot, reading and experimenting with meditation.

headline: Rethinking What It Means to Be a Philadelphia Artist
abstract: In a major interior expansion directed by Frank Gehry, the Philadelphia Museum of Art opens new spaces and invites new artists in.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on reopening, reinvention and resilience.

headline: These N.B.A. Playoffs Burst 2020’s Bubble
abstract: The confined, roiled 2020 N.B.A. playoffs reflected their times. So, too, do this year’s celebratory games.
lead_paragraph: Last August, as the N.B.A. began its 2020 postseason in the confined bubble of Walt Disney World in Florida, the coronavirus pandemic raged, a vaccine was nothing but a dream and the battle for racial justice stood firmly at the forefront of every game.

headline: After Tragedy, an Indianapolis Theater Stages a Comeback
abstract: Bryan Fonseca, the founder of a notable company, died of complications from Covid-19. But at the theater named for him, the show goes on.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — On a breezy, 80-degree evening, the sun still in the sky, the actor Chandra Lynch walked to the center of the Fonseca Theater Company’s outdoor stage-in-the-round. At her back was a semicircle of oversized blocks, each with printed words that together formed the sentence “Blackness iz not a monolith.”

headline: Derek Chauvin’s Lawyer Asks for a New Trial After Guilty Verdict
abstract: The expected legal motion came on the same day that one of the jurors was being criticized for his participation in the March on Washington last year.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer for the former Minneapolis police officer convicted of murdering George Floyd filed a motion on Tuesday asking for a new trial on several grounds, including jury misconduct.

headline: Federal Judge Bans Tear Gas on Nonviolent Protesters in Columbus
abstract: In a scathing opinion, Judge Algenon L. Marbley temporarily barred the Columbus police from using an array of tactics on nonviolent protesters and said officers had “run amok” with power.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has ordered the police in Columbus, Ohio, to stop using tear gas, pepper spray, batons and rubber bullets against nonviolent protesters, writing a scathing 88-page opinion that grapples with hundreds of years of police tactics and that says officers had “run amok” with power.

headline: What the Extended Eviction Moratorium Means for New York
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of tenants are still struggling to pay rent.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: How big is India’s true Covid toll?
lead_paragraph: Last week, India recorded the largest daily coronavirus death toll for any country during the pandemic — a figure that most likely is still an undercount. The Times consulted more than a dozen experts to arrive at several possible estimates for the true scale of devastation from Covid-19 in the country.

headline: Pentagon Chief Feared ‘Coup’ Accusations if He Deployed Troops to Capitol Riot
abstract: Christopher C. Miller, the acting defense secretary on Jan. 6, plans to defend the Pentagon’s actions before and during the violence when he testifies before a House panel on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Christopher C. Miller, who was the acting defense secretary when rioters attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6, plans to testify before Congress on Wednesday that he worried that sending troops to the complex would contribute to perceptions of a “military coup” under President Donald J. Trump.

headline: A ‘Community for All’? Not So Fast, This Wisconsin County Says.
abstract: In Wausau, Wis., the county board has debated a resolution aimed at embracing inclusion for nearly a year, with no agreement. Racial tensions that had simmered beneath the surface are now roiling the community.
lead_paragraph: WAUSAU, Wis. — A standing-room-only crowd packed a drab courthouse meeting room one recent night and tried to resolve a thorny, yearlong debate over whether Marathon County should declare itself “a community for all.”

headline: What 14 Trump Voters Think About George Floyd’s Legacy
abstract: Trump voters discuss race  in America.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of the first anniversary of George Floyd’s death on May 25, my Times Opinion colleagues and I began planning articles from civil rights leaders, academics and others to explore Mr. Floyd’s legacy, the impact of the Black Lives Matter movement and race in America. We also asked younger people to tell us, in their own words, what changed — and didn’t — after his death.

headline: At His Moment of Triumph, Arthur Jafa Is Looking for Trouble
abstract: With a survey in Europe and stark new sculptures in New York, he is bringing to the fore darker, more personal themes. “I’m an undertaker,” he said. “I don’t do the uplift thing.”
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Arthur Jafa won the Golden Lion award for best artist in the Venice Biennale for “The White Album.” A collage of found and original video, it mapped the psychology of Black-white relations in America today — the brutality, awkwardness and sometimes care. “Just as the film critiques a moment fraught with violence, in tenderly portraying the artist’s friends and family, it also speaks to our capacity for love,” the jury concluded.

headline: She Gained a National Following on MSNBC. Now She Wants to Run New York City.
abstract: A former civil rights lawyer, Maya Wiley is running as a progressive but who has distanced herself from her former boss, Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: A former civil rights lawyer, Maya Wiley is running as a progressive but who has distanced herself from her former boss, Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: Who Should Lead New York City?
abstract: Here are the mayoral candidates in their own words, so voters can make up their own minds.
lead_paragraph: Here are the mayoral candidates in their own words, so voters can make up their own minds.

headline: 12 Moms on Their Secret Strengths
abstract: Moms spend a lot of time cataloging their failures. This Mother’s Day, revel in your talents.
lead_paragraph: Moms spend a lot of time cataloging their failures. This Mother’s Day, revel in your talents.

headline: New York Demonstrators Detained After Blocking Holland Tunnel
abstract: A small group of Black Lives Matter protesters was arrested on Tuesday, including the mayoral candidate Shaun Donovan, after blocking the Holland Tunnel in a march on the one-year anniversary of the police killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: A small group of Black Lives Matter protesters was arrested on Tuesday, including the mayoral candidate Shaun Donovan, after blocking the Holland Tunnel in a march on the one-year anniversary of the police killing of George Floyd.

headline: National Gallery of Art Reopens With a New Vision: ‘For All the People’
abstract: The museum has a new logo and mantra as its director, Kaywin Feldman, moves to diversify the collection and the staff.
lead_paragraph: When the doors reopen at the National Gallery of Art on Friday, visitors may be surprised by new changes to this Washington museum’s look. Some 20 clashing typefaces and confusing signage have been gradually disappearing from the building, replaced by a new logo visible inside and out, and a new mantra — “Of the nation and for all the people”— that will appear on its website and be shared with staff. The museum says this vision statement, developed through meetings with employees, symbolizes a renewed commitment to diversity, inclusion and excellence.

headline: Kathryn Garcia for Mayor
abstract: The editorial board’s endorsement for the Democratic mayoral primary.
lead_paragraph: The mix of optimism and anxiety that New Yorkers feel as the coronavirus is beaten back in the five boroughs highlights the extraordinary challenges facing the city and its next mayor in the coming months and years.

headline: George Floyd’s Family Meets With Biden Amid Push for Police Reform
abstract: The family said the president vowed to pass a police reform bill and promised justice not only for Mr. Floyd but for a nation still reeling from a year of killings and protests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a private meeting at the White House on Tuesday, President Biden renewed the promise he made to the family of George Floyd just hours after a Minneapolis police officer was convicted of murder in his death.

headline: Support for Black Lives Matter Surged Last Year. Did It Last?
abstract: The topline numbers hide important trends by race and political party.
lead_paragraph: The moment was called “a racial reckoning.” Multiracial crowds of protesters took to the streets to call for racial justice. Books about racism soared to the top of best-seller lists. And surveys suggested that white Americans, many of whom had long opposed efforts to advance the goals of racial equality, were having a change of heart.

headline: Hollywood Might Not Want to Save the Golden Globes
abstract: A comeback may prove difficult to mount, and the Critics Choice Awards or the SAGs could take their place.
lead_paragraph: The party’s over for the Golden Globes, at least for now.

headline: W.N.B.A. Braces for ‘Fierce Competition’ in New Season
abstract: A wave of talented rookies could make for tense battles as new faces like Aari McDonald and Charli Collier take on perennial all-stars like Diana Taurasi and Candace Parker.
lead_paragraph: Buzzy rookies, reshuffled stars and new interest in women’s basketball after a thrilling N.C.A.A. tournament have positioned the W.N.B.A. to open its 25th season this week with a captive audience as it continues to lead in social justice efforts among professional sports leagues.

headline: Is Wokeness ‘Kryptonite for Democrats’?
abstract: Republicans sure seem to think so. They are not alone.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans well know, Democrats are divided on a host of volatile racial, cultural and sexual issues.

headline: N.J. Teacher Suspended After Calling George Floyd a ‘Criminal’
abstract: The New Jersey high school teacher, Howard Zlotkin, has been suspended with pay after appearing to target Black students in an online class.
lead_paragraph: Students at a New Jersey high school logged into their remote landscape and design class on Wednesday morning expecting their teacher to lead a discussion about climate change. Instead, the teacher went on an expletive-filled, racist rant against Black Lives Matter and George Floyd, the man murdered by a Minneapolis police officer.

headline: Candidates Clash Over Future of New York in First Mayoral Debate
abstract: The eight Democrats competing to win the June 22 primary presented divergent views on how to lead the city in a sometimes acerbic debate.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Brooklyn Museum Employees Take Steps Toward a Union
abstract: The new union would include curators, conservators, gift shop workers and others, as part of the U.A.W.
lead_paragraph: Employees at yet another of New York City’s major museums have taken steps to form a union.

headline: The Many Facets of Wokeness
abstract: Readers react to a critique of wokeness by David Brooks. Also: A controversy over a hand gesture on "Jeopardy!"
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘We Still Aren’t Safe’: 6 Young Americans on George Floyd’s Death
abstract: Readers share the effects of George Floyd’s death on their perceptions of race and racism.
lead_paragraph: The nationwide protests that followed George Floyd’s death last May hinted at a possible turning point in the way many Americans confront issues of racial injustice. How much has really changed, though?

headline: Israel, Masks, Triple Crown: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Just How Far Will Republican Attacks on Institutions Go?
abstract: For the G.O.P., overturning Roe v. Wade is a live possibility. Taking Jan. 6 seriously is not.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, as you know, I have a long history as a pro-choice conservative, going back to my days at The Wall Street Journal.

headline: McCarthy opposes Jan. 6 commission because it would not study ‘political violence’ by the left.
abstract: Representative Kevin McCarthy said he would oppose the independent body, but his Senate counterpart, Mitch McConnell, said his conference was open to it.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the top House Republican, said on Tuesday that he would oppose an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, denouncing the proposed bipartisan inquiry into the deadliest attack on Congress in centuries because it would not examine unrelated “political violence” associated with the left.

headline: Fox News Intensifies Its Pro-Trump Politics as Dissenters Depart
abstract: Donna Brazile, a Democratic analyst, has left the Murdoch-owned network as some hosts and journalists who questioned Donald Trump have exited or been sidelined.
lead_paragraph: Fox News once devoted its 7 p.m. and 11 p.m. time slots to relatively straightforward newscasts. Now those hours are filled by opinion shows led by hosts who denounce Democrats and defend the worldview of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Scott Stringer Mayoral Endorsement Interview
abstract: Scott Stringer is New York City’s comptroller. He previously served as an assemblyman and the borough president of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Scott Stringer is New York City’s comptroller. He previously served as an assemblyman and the borough president of Manhattan.

headline: May 25 Should Be a Day of Mourning for George Floyd
abstract: There is an intimate yet still unexplored relationship between mourning and democracy.
lead_paragraph: When the protests started in the streets of Denver last spring, days after George Floyd was killed in Minneapolis, I watched dozens of people marching with anguish and affliction on their faces. Several of them were crying, or clearly had been. When I watched the video of the final moments of Mr. Floyd’s life, I myself felt the telltale symptoms of grief: a clenched stomach; a surge of adrenaline; and an overwhelming sense of powerlessness.

headline: Youngest U.K. Lawmaker Takes a Break, Citing PTSD
abstract: Nadia Whittome said that it was important to be honest about her mental health struggles in the hope that it would normalize talking about the issue.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The youngest member of Britain’s Parliament, Nadia Whittome, said she would take several weeks off on the advice of her doctor after being diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder, in a candid statement that has shined a spotlight on mental health issues.

headline: How a Genetic Trait in Black People Can Give the Police Cover
abstract: Sickle cell trait has been cited in dozens of police custody deaths ruled accidental or natural, even though the condition is benign on its own, a Times investigation found.
lead_paragraph: When they carried the body of a 32-year-old Black man named Lamont Perry out of the woods in Wadesboro, N.C., there were no protests over his sudden death in police custody.

headline: DMX’s Posthumous All-Star Track, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Griff, Kidd G, Masayoshi Fujita and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: 100 Years After the Tulsa Massacre, What Does Justice Look Like?
abstract: In 1921, a white mob attacked the Greenwood district of Tulsa, killing hundreds of Black people and destroying the neighborhood. Justice has never been served. Can it still be today?
lead_paragraph: As dusk was falling on Sept. 16, 2016, callers began dialing 9-1-1 to report that a Lincoln Navigator had been abandoned on 36th Street North in Tulsa, Okla.

headline: Let’s Hear What High Schoolers Think
abstract: The winners of our student letter-writing competition offer opinions about anti-Asian bias, police brutality, financial literacy, meatless meat and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Second Time Lucky? Eurovision Hopefuls Try Again.
abstract: Eurovision acts are known for being one-hit wonders. Can this year’s contestants, most returnees from the canceled 2020 event, break the stereotype?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the Eurovision Song Contest was canceled last March because of the coronavirus pandemic, Vasil Garvanliev, North Macedonia’s entry, was distraught.

headline: Shootings and Subway Attacks Put Crime at Center of N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race
abstract: Rising concerns over crime have led candidates to issue strong appeals for public safety, less than a year after the city was under pressure to defund the police.

headline: ‘On the Ashes of Tragedy’: Mixed Emotions on Anniversary of George Floyd’s Death
abstract: The crowds that gathered in Minneapolis and elsewhere reflected on what has changed, and what has not, in America since Mr. Floyd was murdered by a police officer.
lead_paragraph: [Follow live news coverage of Derek Chauvin’s sentencing hearing.]

headline: New Zealanders Are Flooding Home. Will the Old Problems Push Them Back Out?
abstract: More than 50,000 have escaped the pandemic by moving back, offering the country a rare chance to regain talented citizens. But they are confronting entrenched housing and employment challenges.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Like many New Zealanders before her, Cat Moody chased the broader horizons of life abroad, unsure if she would ever return to a homeland she saw as remote and limiting.

headline: How Naomi Osaka Became Everyone’s Favorite Spokesmodel
abstract: From the Met Gala roster to your lunchtime salad bowl, the tennis champion is suddenly ubiquitous.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In today’s world of celebrity branding, captions speak louder than words. But Naomi Osaka’s are decidedly understated.

headline: End the Court Doctrine That Enables Police Brutality
abstract: The courts created qualified immunity for police. Reform means getting rid of it.
lead_paragraph: When a Minneapolis jury last month convicted the former police officer Derek Chauvin of murdering George Floyd on May 25, 2020, many Americans celebrated. At last, a moment of accountability, if not quite justice, in the face of persistent police brutality.

headline: 2 Oklahoma Boys Pulled From Class for ‘Black Lives Matter’ T-Shirts
abstract: In addition to the disciplinary action they have faced, the boys’ mother said that at least one of her three sons has been bullied because of the shirts.
lead_paragraph: Two brothers, 8 and 5, were removed from their Oklahoma elementary school classrooms this past week and made to wait out the school day in a front office for wearing T-shirts that read “Black Lives Matter,” according to the boys’ mother.

headline: Sculpted in Metal, Stories of History and Identity Take Shape
abstract: Works by Melvin Edwards are celebrated in a survey at City Hall Park in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The sculpture, made of red stainless steel and chains, rocks and sways. The lengths of links — some rusted, some the bright silver of galvanized steel — ripple in the wind. Nearby, a very different sculpture also takes the form of a chain, this time represented on a massive scale, its links severed and scattered.

headline: Liz Cheney takes on Trump anew, saying his false claims are ‘poisoning our democratic system.’
abstract: Ms. Cheney’s comments on Twitter escalated her feud with the former president — and, by extension, dozens of her fellow House Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, the No. 3 House Republican, repudiated former President Donald J. Trump’s false claim that the 2020 election was stolen, accusing him on Monday of “poisoning our democratic system.”

headline: The Evictions Surprised Trailer Park Residents. The Protest Stunned Officials.
abstract: An uproar in the hills of eastern Kentucky has raised questions about what a city owes to those dislodged by its growth — and how to govern in an age of social media and protest.
lead_paragraph: MOREHEAD, Ky. — Under a slate-colored sky, the holdouts gathered in what remained of the North Fork Mobile Home Park. Around them it looked as if a hurricane had blown through, leaving scattered cinder blocks, capsized sofas and porches affixed to thin air. The small circle — among them single mothers, a factory worker, a retiree, two community organizers — sat on kitchen chairs discussing their next move: recruiting for a boycott.

headline: Six Ways to Learn About Stonewall Using The New York Times
abstract: Activities to help students learn about a significant moment in L.G.B.T.Q. history using contemporary articles, videos, photographs and The Times’s archive.
lead_paragraph: Next month is the 52nd anniversary of the Stonewall uprising. On June 28, 1969, police officers raided the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar in New York City, with the stated purpose of reprimanding unlicensed bars that were illegally selling alcohol. Police raids on gay bars at the time were routine; the raid on that evening in 1969, however, incited a protest that galvanized the modern gay rights movement.

headline: How Plywood From Last Year’s Protests Became Art
abstract: During the George Floyd marches last year, businesses boarded up. This year, hundreds of those boards will be displayed in exhibitions in Minneapolis, New York and Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The morning in April before a Minneapolis jury found the former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty of murdering George Floyd, Leesa Kelly woke up from a nightmare. As she had done many times over the past year, she cried out feelings of anger and hopelessness.

headline: Republicans Rewrite History of the Capitol Riot, Hampering an Inquiry
abstract: Republicans in Congress are insisting that any investigation into the Jan. 6 attack include an examination of left-wing violence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four months after supporters of President Donald J. Trump stormed the Capitol in a deadly riot, a growing number of Republicans in Congress are mounting a wholesale effort to rewrite the history of what happened on Jan. 6, downplaying or outright denying the violence and deflecting efforts to investigate it.

headline: A Cry of ‘I Can’t Breathe’ United a Generation in a Gasp for Justice
abstract: Emmett Till’s death helped inspire America’s Second Reconstruction. George Floyd’s galvanized the third.
lead_paragraph: In Elizabeth City, N.C., the morning after a jury in Minneapolis found the former police officer Derek Chauvin guilty of the murder of George Floyd, a unit from the county’s Sheriff’s Department dressed in tactical gear arrived at the home of Andrew Brown Jr. They were there to serve drug-related arrest and search warrants.

headline: The New York Police and the Gay Pride Parade
abstract: Readers disagree about whether the decision to bar police groups from New York’s Pride celebration was the right move.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Piece of Music Will Speak Once More. For 26 Hours.
abstract: “I am sitting in a room,” Alvin Lucier’s classic work of sound art, will be performed by 90 artists in honor of his 90th birthday.
lead_paragraph: It was a snowy night in March 1970 in Middletown, Conn. But the composer Alvin Lucier turned off the heat, wanting it quiet in his apartment. He sat in his living room with two tape recorders, a microphone, a single loudspeaker and an amplifier.

headline: Andre Hill’s Family Reaches $10 Million Settlement With City of Columbus
abstract: Mr. Hill, 47, was fatally shot by a police officer in December while he was in a garage. An agreement announced on Friday paves the way for the city’s largest settlement.
lead_paragraph: City officials in Columbus, Ohio, have agreed to pay a $10 million settlement to the family of Andre Hill, a Black man who was fatally shot by a police officer in a garage in December.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews James Forman Jr.
abstract: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with James Forman Jr. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with James Forman Jr. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Andrew Brown’s Family Is Shown More Video of His Killing by Deputies
abstract: The family was able to view about 20 minutes of footage from dash and body cameras that has not been made public. They said it did not show Mr. Brown threatening, or even making contact with, officers.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Family members of Andrew Brown Jr., the Black man fatally shot last month by North Carolina sheriff’s deputies, on Tuesday were given a second opportunity to view body and dash camera footage of his killing.

headline: One Year Later
abstract: On the anniversary of George Floyd’s murder, we examine its legacy so far.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after 8 p.m. on May 25, 2020, Derek Chauvin, a Minneapolis police officer, placed his knee on George Floyd’s neck and kept it there for more than nine minutes. None of the three other officers standing near Chauvin intervened. Soon, Floyd was dead.

headline: The Captain of Everything
abstract: Liverpool’s Jordan Henderson has not played in months. But the art of being a captain is not limited to soccer, and for Henderson, leading is not limited to his team.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — Jordan Henderson had plenty of things on his mind. First and foremost, there was the wound on his thigh, a legacy of the surgery he had undergone a few weeks earlier, and which was not yet properly healed. Until it had, he could not do much beyond change his bandages, and wait. The problem, he would admit, is that he is not much given to waiting.

headline: A Year After George Floyd, Los Angeles Confronts Its Future and Its Past
abstract: Tuesday: Los Angeles has been struggling to respond to both calls for racial justice and a surge in gun violence.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Ex-Commish With the Dish
abstract: America's top cop on better policing, race relations, Chauvin, Biden, Rudy and Andrew.
lead_paragraph: Cops have never been so blue.

headline: Tensions Among Democrats Grow Over Israel as the Left Defends Palestinians
abstract: Divisions within the party have burst into public view, with the party’s ascendant left viewing the Mideast conflict as a searing racial justice issue that carries echoes of U.S. politics.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, when James Zogby, the founder of the Arab American Institute, pushed Democrats to include a mention of Palestinian sovereignty in their platform, party leaders responded with a clear warning, he recalled: “If the P-word is even in the platform, all hell will break loose.” Eager to stave off an angry confrontation at the convention, the issue was shelved without a vote.

headline: At MassMoCA, Art and the Struggle for Equality
abstract: Black Lives Matter and the Troubles of Northern Ireland meet at a Massachusetts institution.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on reopening, reinvention and resilience.

headline: Woodbury, Conn.: Peace and Rustic Beauty, With a Sense of History
abstract: Settled in the late 1600s, this Litchfield County town is more densely populated than its neighbors, with a quaint downtown and more full-time residents.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before the pandemic, Brad and Courtney Akin began hunting for a weekend getaway from their two-bedroom rental in Queens. It wasn’t long before they fell in love with a converted barn and grain silo, built in 1800, in the town of Woodbury, Conn., on the southern edge of Litchfield County. By the time they closed on the property, Covid-19 was raging, so they crammed what they could carry from their apartment into a U-Haul and drove with their son, who was almost 2, to their new home. And that’s where they’ve spent much of their time since.

headline: A Simple Exercise For Encouraging Independent Reading
abstract: Four teachers across the U.S. challenged their students to choose two Times pieces — one on a topic within their comfort zone, another on a topic outside it — and read both. It was a success everywhere.
lead_paragraph: Before you read any further, try a quick experiment:

headline: Democrats Move Closer to Setting Up Jan. 6 Commission, With or Without G.O.P.
abstract: House Democrats plan to vote on a bill to create an independent commission to investigate the Capitol riot, but whether Republican leaders would support it was unclear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats pressed ahead on Friday with a bipartisan proposal to create an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, after reaching agreement with a key Republican to drop his party’s demand that it look at left-wing violence unrelated to the assault.

headline: County Reaches $10 Million Settlement in Jailed Black Man’s Death
abstract: Officials in Charleston County, S.C., unanimously approved a settlement with the family of Jamal Sutherland, who died in January after sheriff’s deputies used pepper spray and Tasers on him.
lead_paragraph: A county in South Carolina agreed on Tuesday to pay $10 million to the family of a Black man who died in January after sheriff’s deputies used pepper spray and Tasers on him in a jail cell as he told them, “I can’t breathe,” officials said.

headline: ‘A Dozen Dreams’ Review: Eerie Memories Bring Magic to the Mall
abstract: Twelve exquisitely designed installations capture the fears, hopes and reveries shared on audio by 12 women playwrights.
lead_paragraph: A dark room with a naked bulb hanging over a headless, but dressed, seated mannequin. A nightmare room of shattered glass. A room of Tetris-ed cardboard boxes. A wishful room of sunrise or sunset, depending on your disposition.

headline: What History Can Teach Banks About Making Change
abstract: Financial institutions have a unique power to contribute to social movements — if they choose to use it.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: The Broad Museum Reopens With a Celebration of Basquiat
abstract: A presentation of all 13 works in the collection, together for the first time and delayed by the pandemic shutdown, attests to the Broads’ early and abiding interest in the artist.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest special report on Museums, which focuses on reopening, reinvention and resilience.

headline: 8 Ways a Modern Civil Rights Movement Moved the Culture
abstract: From music to movies, canceled podcasts to toppled monuments, our writers take stock of the culture we shared in the year after George Floyd’s murder.
lead_paragraph: On May 25, 2020, George Floyd was murdered under the knee of a white police officer, who is now in prison. Even so, a year later — after Americans protested and posted black squares on social media; after calls for the convictions of the officers who killed Breonna Taylor and other Black Americans went unanswered — the question remains: After the most significant civil rights movement in the lifetime of many of us, how much has changed? When the dust settles, what of the uprising persists?

headline: Unearthing the Roots of Black Rebellion
abstract: In “America on Fire,” the historian Elizabeth Hinton offers a sweeping reconsideration of the racial unrest that shook American cities in the 1960s and 70s.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — For her first book, “From the War on Poverty to the War on Crime,” the historian Elizabeth Hinton spent years digging through government archives, piecing together how bipartisan tough-on-crime federal legislation had funded an expansion of policing and set the stage for the mass incarceration we live with today.

headline: ‘Pass Over,’ About Black Men Trapped by Dread, Heads to Broadway
abstract: The play, by Antoinette Chinonye Nwandu, has previously been staged at several prominent theaters and filmed by Spike Lee for Amazon.
lead_paragraph: “Pass Over,” a searing play about two Black men trapped by existential dread in a world where too many of their peers have been killed by police, is coming to Broadway.

headline: Rescuing Artists of Vision
abstract: The unrivaled Art Preserve in Sheboygan, Wis., opening soon, is collecting and showing artist-built environments found along rural byways, in city lofts — and even at Manhattan’s Chelsea Hotel.
lead_paragraph: SHEBOYGAN, Wis. — Charles Smith preaches with sculpture, hundreds of hip-height figures that he’s been reworking, repainting and rearranging for decades, first at a small house in Aurora, Ill., and now at his homestead in Hammond, La. Every time this self-taught artist repositions his work he testifies anew to the unfolding history of racial violence in the United States, connecting it to personal traumas, including what he believes was the racially motivated murder of his father when he was 14, and his own combat experiences in Vietnam.

headline: How to Turn Protest Power Into Political Power
abstract: Two civil rights activists and organizers in St. Louis lay out their tactics and tools for pursuing electoral justice.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Last year, the world watched for nine minutes and 29 seconds as a video showed the final moments of George Floyd’s life. We all heard Mr. Floyd plead with the police as he gasped for enough air to repeat the words “I can’t breathe” more than 20 times. In the weeks that followed his death, as many as 26 million people took to the streets in defense of Black lives.

headline: Progressives’ Urgent Question: How to Win Over Voters of Color
abstract: A yearslong challenge for the left was starkly illustrated this week as its hopes faded in the New York mayor’s race.
lead_paragraph: Can progressives win broad numbers of the Black and brown voters they say their policies will benefit most?

headline: Medical Journals Blind to Racism as Health Crisis, Critics Say
abstract: As a prominent editor steps down, the influential JAMA journals promise changes regarding staff diversity and more inclusive research.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated with a statement by JAMA on Thursday outlining an editorial plan for greater diversity and inclusion in the journal’s staffing and published research.

headline: Progressive groups step up calls for Justice Breyer to retire.
abstract: Justice Breyer, 82, has been adamant that politics should play no role in judges’ work
lead_paragraph: Progressive groups are stepping up calls for Justice Stephen G. Breyer to “immediately” retire from the Supreme Court and allow President Biden to nominate a successor while Democrats control the Senate, which approves judicial nominees.

headline: This Is the Summer the Youth Own New York
abstract: For decades, certain corners of the city were so smoothed by money they seemed off-limits to those just starting out as adults. But for one brief shining moment, it all belongs to the young.
lead_paragraph: Walking around Lower Manhattan on a recent weeknight, a middle-aged, slightly graying man wasn’t sure if it was he who had changed or New York. True, he hadn’t been out much lately … but something was different.

headline: Woman Dies After Driver Hits Crowd in Minneapolis
abstract: The group was gathered on Sunday night to protest police brutality. Three other people were injured, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A woman was killed and three people were injured in Minneapolis late Sunday after a man drove a car into a group of people who had gathered for a vigil against police brutality, the police said.

headline: Judge narrows lawsuits over clearing of protesters before a Trump photo op.
abstract: The judge said that federal officials had immunity, and that claims of a conspiracy to clear Lafayette Square for President Donald J. Trump’s walk across it were “simply too speculative.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday partly dismissed claims filed by Black Lives Matter, the American Civil Liberties Union and others accusing the Trump administration of abusing its power to violently disperse a protest outside the White House last year.

headline: Two Team Photos, One Difference: The Cheerleader With Down Syndrome
abstract: A junior high cheerleading team took nearly identical photos with and without Morgyn Arnold. The school called the publication of the photo without her a mistake that is under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Morgyn Arnold is a natural cheerleader. She grew up supporting her six older siblings at sporting events in Utah and followed in her father’s and sister’s footsteps by becoming a cheerleader herself.

headline: ‘Keep an Eye on This Guy’: Inside Eric Adams’s Complicated Police Career
abstract: Mr. Adams’s police credentials have helped him rise to the top of this year’s mayoral field. But his relationship with the department is complex.
lead_paragraph: As Eric Adams lined up for graduation at the New York City Police Academy in 1984, he congratulated the cadet who had beaten him out for valedictorian, only to learn that the other recruit’s average was a point lower than his own. Mr. Adams complained to his commander about the slight.

headline: South African Opera Star Says She Was Mistreated by French Police
abstract: Pretty Yende, an acclaimed soprano, says she was forced to submit to a body search at a Paris airport. “I felt stripped of my human dignity,” she said.
lead_paragraph: The South African soprano Pretty Yende expected her visit this week to France, where she is starring in a production of Bellini’s “La Sonnambula,” to be relatively uneventful.

headline: Surprise: Women and Minorities Are Still Underrepresented in Corporate Boardrooms
abstract: The latest version of a multiyear analysis of Fortune 100 and 500 companies found that white women made some gains but that true representation is decades away.
lead_paragraph: — Linda Akutagawa, chair for the Alliance for Board Diversity and chief executive of Leadership Education for Asian Pacifics

headline: Biden Promises Tulsa Massacre Survivors Their Story Will Be ‘Known in Full View’
abstract: The president, who has made racial equity and justice central themes of his administration, was in Tulsa, Okla., to commemorate a painful part of the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A century after a white mob destroyed a vibrant African American community in Tulsa, Okla., torching hundreds of homes and indiscriminately shooting people in the streets, President Biden told a crowd of survivors and their families that the story of the massacre “will be known in full view.”

headline: The Cost of Being an ‘Interchangeable Asian’ and How to Advocate for Your Well-Being at Work: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Pulitzer Prize: 2021 Winners List
abstract: From reporting on the coronavirus pandemic to an investigation of China’s internment of Uyghurs, here’s the full list of winners and finalists.
lead_paragraph: The Pulitzer committee honored The New York Times with the prestigious public service award for its “prescient and sweeping” coverage of the Covid-19 pandemic, particularly for filling “a data vacuum that helped local governments, health care providers, businesses and individuals to be better prepared and protected.” Read the coverage here.

headline: Black Campus Police Officers Say They Suffered ‘Unbearable’ Racism
abstract: Police officers at the University of Washington in Seattle, regarded as one of the nation’s most progressive cities, said they were the target of racist insults and harassment.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Earlier this year, as Officer Russell Ellis neared the end of his late shift at the University of Washington’s campus police department, one of his superiors offered him an energy drink. The sergeant was laughing, Mr. Ellis said, noting that the beverage was flavored like watermelon.

headline: Specialized Experiences Offer Fresh Looks on Paris
abstract: As visitors trickle back into the city after a heavy year, walking tours and other experiences that emphasize seldom-told stories about local life and history are taking on new resonance.
lead_paragraph: As the second-most visited city in the world (that is, prepandemic), Paris has always meant brisk business when it comes to guided tours and excursions for travelers. From historical walks and cooking classes to outings that grant exclusive access to artists’ workshops, museum archives and private mansions, there are activities for almost any interest.

headline: Garcia and Wiley Try to Shift Momentum From Adams as Primary Draws Near
abstract: A week before the primary and a day before the final debate, Kathryn Garcia and Maya Wiley vied to be seen as the strongest alternative to the race’s front-runner, Eric Adams.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Maya Wiley Takes Credit for Daniel Pantaleo’s Firing. Is That Justified?
abstract: When she was the head of the Civilian Complaint Review Board, Ms. Wiley was criticized for not being more aggressive in pursuing discipline against officers.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live NYC mayors race coverage.]

headline: N.Y.C. Mayoral Candidates on Police Reform
abstract: We interviewed the eight leading Democratic candidates for mayor about the biggest issues facing the city. Here’s what they said.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Surviving the Pandemic and Finding Their Tribes
abstract: Marcus Samuelsson, a chef, and Maya Haile Samuelsson, a model, felt the need for community during the pandemic more than ever.
lead_paragraph: The chef Marcus Samuelsson would not have made it through the pandemic without the help of his community.

headline: He’s a Former Officer. She’s ‘Had Enough’ of the Police. Who Will Come Out Ahead?
abstract: In Tuesday's primary for mayor of New York City, Democrats have a choice between two distinctly different paths on policing, crime and civil rights.
lead_paragraph: An urgent debate is playing out right now in the Democratic Party about policing as cities see sharp rises in violent crime. The fight to control that disorder is also a battle for the direction of the party — do police departments need more resources to fight crime? Do they need to be restrained, given a long record of abuses and policies like stop-and-frisk? How do the police earn more trust from Black and brown residents? Which tactics are right, and which tactics violate our rights?

headline: Read the report
abstract: Three prominent Democratic groups, Third Way, the Collective PAC and the Latino Victory Fund, conducted a review of the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Three prominent Democratic groups, Third Way, the Collective PAC and the Latino Victory Fund, conducted a review of the 2020 election.

headline: New York Is Back. Now It Has a Second Chance.
abstract: America’s greatest city is beating the pandemic. Can it also recover from decades of division and neglect?
lead_paragraph: America’s greatest city is beating the pandemic. Can it also recover from decades of division and neglect?

headline: The New York Mayoral Candidates’ Closing Arguments
abstract: Here is how the leading Democratic candidates for mayor are pitching themselves to New Yorkers in the final stretch.
lead_paragraph: Here is how the leading Democratic candidates for mayor are pitching themselves to New Yorkers in the final stretch.

headline: The Amazon That Customers Don’t See
abstract: Each year, hundreds of thousands of workers churn through a vast mechanism that hires and monitors, disciplines and fires. Amid the pandemic, the already strained system lurched.
lead_paragraph: Each year, hundreds of thousands of workers churn through a vast mechanism that hires and monitors, disciplines and fires. Amid the pandemic, the already strained system lurched.

headline: Black Lives Matter Has Grown More Powerful, and More Divided
abstract: Since the murder of George Floyd, the racial justice movement has received millions of dollars in donations. But some chapters have questioned how those funds are spent.
lead_paragraph: In the year since George Floyd was murdered, racial justice organizations across the country have been inundated with millions of dollars in donations and thousands of eager new activists. They have earned a prominent platform that puts them on the front lines of political and social battles.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Sarah Schulman
abstract: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sarah Schulman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sarah Schulman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Policing and the New York Mayoral Race
abstract: As voters head to the polls, we talk to two registered democratic voters about an election that is testing the city’s values.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Celebrity Dating Game’ and a Father’s Day Special
abstract: “The Dating Game” gets a celebrity revival, “Rick and Morty” returns and Oprah Winfrey hosts a Black Father’s Day special with Sterling K. Brown.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 14-20. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: The World’s Dictators Exploit America’s Racism
abstract: They are not completely wrong.
lead_paragraph: Any Americans who believe that this country’s race problem stops at the water’s edge should disabuse themselves of the notion.

headline: Artwork Ranking Women by Their Looks Sets Off a Furor in a Changing China
abstract: Critics called the piece, which shows thousands of unsuspecting college students, a misogynistic affront, eight years after it was on display in a different museum to little reaction.
lead_paragraph: To the artist’s critics, it was bad enough that he had secretly filmed thousands of female students on a Chinese university campus.

headline: Should I Hang Out With Someone Whose Political Views I Hate?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether it’s hypocritical for a liberal to socialize with an increasingly extreme conservative.
lead_paragraph: I am a liberal in a blue city in a red state. One of my friends is married to a man who has become increasingly conservative over the past year (an “anti-Black Lives Matter, anti-abortion, Democrats are all idiots and socialists are taking over the country” mind-set), and his posts on social media are becoming more and more extreme. We occasionally socialize as couples. When we are together, I am friendly with him, and we avoid overt political talk, but as his social media becomes more and more extreme, I feel conflicted about continuing to accept invitations to socialize with them. Is it hypocritical of me to socialize with them when I find his personal political views so abhorrent? Name Withheld.

headline: An Accusation Blew Up a Campaign. The Media Didn’t Know What to Do.
abstract: Handling a delicate allegation of sexual misconduct is a lot more challenging than covering a horse race.
lead_paragraph: Two days after coming in fifth in the election night count of votes for New York mayor last week, Scott Stringer was sitting in a high-polish diner in TriBeCa, drinking his second bottle of Sprite and trying to figure out what had happened.

headline: A Covid Update
abstract: We have the latest on the Delta variant.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for one of this newsletter’s occasional updates on the state of the pandemic. The brief version: The situation continues to look reassuring for anybody who is vaccinated — but has become more worrisome for anybody who is not, largely because of the Delta variant.

headline: House panels open an inquiry into the health effects of tear gas used by police.
abstract: The Democrats leading the investigation are seeking to determine whether the federal government has done enough to ensure that the substance is safe to use on humans.
lead_paragraph: A year after racial justice protests around the country touched off violent clashes between activists and law enforcement, House Democrats on Thursday opened an investigation into the health effects of the use of tear gas by police.

headline: Tensions Rise in Memphis as Slave Trader’s Remains Are Removed
abstract: The remains of Nathan Bedford Forrest, a slave trader and leader of the Ku Klux Klan, will be moved from Memphis to a Confederate museum 200 miles away.
lead_paragraph: Traditionally, Memphis residents celebrate Juneteenth at Robert R. Church Park, named for the city’s first Black millionaire.

headline: Video of Montreal Police Kneeling on Black Teenager Spurs Outcry
abstract: Outrage over the video comes as Canada undergoes a national awakening about institutional racism, including among police forces.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — For some Canadians, the 90-second video evoked memories of George Floyd: A white police officer appears to be kneeling on the neck of a Black teenager who is face down on the ground on a Montreal street.

headline: Movie Museum Rethinks Exhibitions in Response to a Changing World
abstract: The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures, opening in September, has redesigned its galleries amid social movements like Black Lives Matter.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — How do you make a museum about an industry even as that industry is changing? How do you represent a history when that history is full of omissions?

headline: Why the Latest Republican Assault on L.G.B.T.Q. Rights Is Different
abstract: Unprecedented legislative attacks aimed at trans people are underway. People in power need to defy these anti-L.G.B.T.Q. laws.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Gov. Bill Lee of Tennessee signed into law a discriminatory bill to prevent transgender people from using restrooms aligning with their gender identity at any business or place of public accommodation. A few days earlier, Governor Lee signed an anti-transgender student bathroom bill, too. These are the first bathroom bills to be enacted since North Carolina’s notorious HB2 in 2016.

headline: N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race: Residency Questions and an Endorsement
abstract: The residency of Eric Adams and his fitness for office came under fire as the contest barreled toward the start of early voting.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Pride Parties and Protests Bring Excitement Back to N.Y.C. Streets
abstract: After a more cautious Pride last year, many New Yorkers were eager to be together again: “Bro, the energy is amazing.”
lead_paragraph: New York’s Pride celebrations and protests came back with a vengeance over the weekend, after a muted celebration last year because of the pandemic.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be Crowned ‘Miss Juneteenth’?
abstract: For contestants, it’s a pageant, yes, but also a place to celebrate Black sisterhood and promote a deeper understanding of a complex holiday.
lead_paragraph: In the month of June, as celebrations to commemorate the Juneteenth holiday begin, dozens of Black girls and women across the country will be competing for a singular title: Miss Juneteenth.

headline: How Big Tech Allows the Racial Wealth Gap to Persist
abstract: Tech companies talk a big game about racial equity. But inside their offices it’s a different story.
lead_paragraph: Since President Biden signed a law last week making Juneteenth a federal holiday, there has been no shortage of corporate displays of good will. Google devoted its famous “doodle” to the holiday, and many companies have declared that they will observe Juneteenth as a paid holiday.

headline: As Military Addresses Diversity, Republicans See Culture War Target
abstract: The Pentagon’s leadership is taking steps to promote inclusion in the military, prompting a political backlash.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At Fort Bragg, one of the nation’s largest military installations, plans are afoot for its first commemoration of Juneteenth, highlighting the role of the Union Army in emancipation.

headline: How India Walton Pulled It Off in the Buffalo Mayoral Primary
abstract: Ms. Walton, 38, a democratic socialist who has never held political office, defeated Byron Brown, a four-term incumbent.
lead_paragraph: India B. Walton knew her bid to unseat the entrenched 16-year mayor of Buffalo was a long shot.

headline: Review: Martha Washington, Hilariously Haunted by Her Slaves
abstract: James Ijames’s amusingly cynical and eclectic new play, “The Most Spectacularly Lamentable Trial of Miz Martha Washington,” is at the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival through July 30.
lead_paragraph: On an evening train back from the Hudson Valley last weekend, I overheard two drunken friends — one white, one Indian American — having a loud, expletive-ridden debate two rows behind me.

headline: A Gay N.F.L. Player Broke a Barrier. Will Other L.G.B.T.Q. Athletes Follow?
abstract: The number of publicly out athletes in men’s biggest pro leagues lags far behind that in women’s sports. Will Carl Nassib’s announcement change that?
lead_paragraph: Congratulatory posts flooded social media on Monday when Las Vegas Raiders defensive lineman Carl Nassib announced on Instagram that he is gay, becoming the first active N.F.L. player to do so.

headline: A Guide to Theater Festivals in New York and the Berkshires
abstract: From the Williamstown Theater Festival to New York Stage and Film, theatergoers can experience world premieres, concerts and more.
lead_paragraph: Most summers, as tourists pour into New York City to see theater, New Yorkers pour out to see theater elsewhere. This summer, though, they may do so with extra ardor. As the pandemic lifts, the pent-up demand for live, in-person theater is first being met in the Berkshires and in the mid-Hudson region, where companies are putting up tents, arranging outdoor immersive experiences and welcoming audiences to buildings that have been empty for too long.

headline: Derek Chauvin, held in solitary confinement, returns to the courtroom to learn his fate.
abstract: Mr. Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer, may choose to speak at his hearing. He could face decades in prison.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — For the past two months, Derek Chauvin has been held in solitary confinement as lawyers and investigators have been busy with the next phase of his case: determining the length of his punishment for the murder of George Floyd.

headline: Martina Navratilova Has Plenty to Say
abstract: One of the most dominant players in tennis history, Navratilova was a cultural pioneer when the world wasn’t prepared for an outspoken lesbian. Finally, the world is catching up, and she’s still here.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Martina Navratilova sat at a dockside restaurant in Florida this spring, wearing worn-out jeans, a denim button-down shirt that hung loosely at her waist and a 1619 cap that one of her five dogs had gnawed on. It’s her favorite hat these days.

headline: Law Schools Scramble for Deferrals
abstract: In the most competitive year in recent memory, some schools are offering incentives to ease their over-enrolled classes.
lead_paragraph: Many law schools across the country are trying to thin their swollen classes, and MacKenzie Scott gave millions to colleges serving students in need.

headline: Dianne Morales Faced a Campaign Uprising. Will It Matter to Voters?
abstract: Ms. Morales is running for New York City mayor on a platform of tackling inequality and shifting resources away from policing. But her campaign has been marred by defections and dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Baseball Reference Adds Negro Leagues Statistics, Rewriting Its Record Book
abstract: M.L.B. is still working to incorporate Negro league statistics, but a popular website now lets fans put some of the numbers in context.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Baseball Reference, the go-to source on the internet for such matters, would have told you that Stan Musial led the major leagues with a .357 batting average in 1943. It also would have said numerous pitchers took a turn leading the majors in strikeouts per nine innings between 1927 and 1945, and that the top three batters in career adjusted on-base-plus-slugging percentage were Babe Ruth, Ted Williams and Barry Bonds.

headline: George Floyd Statue in Brooklyn Is Defaced With Hate Group’s Symbol
abstract: The vandalism came just days after the statue was unveiled, and only a day before the officer who killed Mr. Floyd was to be sentenced.
lead_paragraph: A statue of George Floyd that was installed in Brooklyn less than a week ago was spray-painted and marked with a white supremacist group’s logo in an act of vandalism that the police were investigating as a hate crime, officials said on Thursday.

headline: In N.Y.C., Black Is Back
abstract: Black candidates are leading in this New York City election. Can they avoid the pitfalls?
lead_paragraph: New York City — the nation’s largest city — held its widely watched primaries for city officials on Tuesday. It is broadly believed that whoever wins the Democratic primary in this heavily Democratic city will win the general election.

headline: Fireworks-Related Injuries and Deaths Jumped During Pandemic, Report Shows
abstract: Eighteen people in the U.S. died in 2020 after episodes involving fireworks, compared with 12 people the previous year, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
lead_paragraph: Fireworks-related injuries and deaths in the United States jumped in 2020 compared with the previous year, according to a report that cites the pandemic as a likely factor in the increase.

headline: Where Flying the Pride Flag Wasn’t So Simple
abstract: Thursday: The debate over flying the Pride flag in the Central Valley.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Challenges Aplenty Onstage in London, With Some Fun Along the Way
abstract: As London venues reopen, theatergoers can choose to reckon with works like “The Death of a Black Man” or enjoy frothier fare from George Bernard Shaw.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Intimations of mortality have weighed heavily on our minds during the pandemic, so what better work to reanimate the National Theater than “After Life,” a play set in a mysterious space between this world and the next?

headline: Nearly 70 Years Later, ‘Invisible Man’ Is Still Inspiring Visual Artists
abstract: Ralph Ellison’s classic 1952 novel has influenced not just writers but photographers, sculptors and painters, all grappling with what it means to be seen.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of T’s Book Club, a series of articles and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation about “Invisible Man,” to be led by Adam Bradley and held on June 17.

headline: A Requiem, Derailed by the Pandemic, Arrives When It’s Needed Most
abstract: Courtney Bryan’s Requiem, premiering Thursday after its original date was canceled last year, now follows a time of loss and upheaval.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard a story like this before. Courtney Bryan’s Requiem was set to premiere with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in late March 2020. In a time of incalculable loss, her music became part of another kind of casualty: the sounds that vanished from stages around the world.

headline: Eric Adams Leads in the Mayor’s Race. Here’s What to Know About Him.
abstract: Mr. Adams, a moderate Democrat whose campaign focused on crime and public safety, has a long history in New York politics and has faced scrutiny over his ethics.
lead_paragraph: Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, had a solid advantage on Wednesday in the Democratic primary for New York mayor, leading his closest competitors, Maya Wiley and Kathryn Garcia, by a sizable margin.

headline: Lawmakers Sue N.Y.P.D., Saying They Were Beaten With Bicycles at Protest
abstract: State Senator Zellnor Myrie and Assemblywoman Diana Richardson say they were assaulted and pepper-sprayed by the police during last year’s Black Lives Matter protests.
lead_paragraph: Two New York lawmakers who said they were surrounded, beaten with bicycles and pepper-sprayed by the police during a Black Lives Matter protest in Brooklyn last year filed a federal civil-rights lawsuit against the city on Monday, adding to the blizzard of litigation over the Police Department’s conduct during the protests.

headline: I Write About the Law. But Could I Really Help Free a Prisoner?
abstract: For years as a journalist, I’ve covered attempts to exonerate incarcerated people. But a letter from Yutico Briley led to a different kind of story.
lead_paragraph: It all started with an email I received from a retired librarian in Oregon. “Dear Ms. Bazelon,” Karen Oehler wrote in July 2019. “I correspond with an inmate, Yutico Briley, at Dixon,” a prison in Jackson, La. For a couple of years, Oehler and Briley had been writing to each other through a support program for incarcerated people. She wanted to let me know that Briley was trying to reach me. “In his last letter to me, he said he’d written to you at The Times but wasn’t sure if you received the letter,” Oehler explained.

headline: Biden Signs Law Making Juneteenth a Federal Holiday
abstract: The law went into effect immediately, making Friday the first federal Juneteenth holiday in American history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden signed legislation on Thursday to make Juneteenth a federal holiday, enshrining June 19 as the national day to commemorate the end of slavery in the United States.

headline: Whose Park Is It? Residents and Revelers Clash Over Washington Square.
abstract: As the pandemic eases, the park has attracted crowds of young people who regard it as a place to let loose. Residents say the scene is out of control.
lead_paragraph: Erika Sumner stood on the steps of her house this month with her pet parrot perched on her head and surveyed the scene across the street, the entrance to Washington Square Park, as if assessing the damage left by a tornado.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes it hurts too much to tell the truth.” That line is spoken by the protagonist of Martha Southgate’s 2005 novel “Third Girl From the Left,” trying to explain why her mother rarely talks about her experience surviving the 1921 Tulsa race massacre in Oklahoma, and it’s a sentiment that reverberates through the character’s family and the rest of the novel and indeed through the whole of American society, which for too long has averted its eyes from the scene of the crime in Tulsa. But there’s reason to hope things are changing on the truth-telling front, as detailed in Scott Ellsworth’s new book about the massacre, “The Ground Breaking,” which is one of our recommended books this week, 100 years after the events it describes.

headline: Tenement Museum Makes Room for Black History
abstract: Reopening after a tumultuous year, this Lower East Side institution is addressing the omissions and erasures in the neighborhood’s history — and its own.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of ghosts at the Tenement Museum, which for nearly three decades has explored issues of immigration, home and belonging through tours of the meticulously recreated apartments in its five-story building on the Lower East Side. But in recent years, the story of one particularly ghostly presence has lingered in the background.

headline: With ‘Dave,’ Lil Dicky ‘Achieved My Destiny’
abstract: In an interview, Dave Burd (better known as the rapper Lil Dicky) and other creators and stars of his surprise hit comedy discuss the show’s new season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Like the semisatirical rap career of the grown man known as Lil Dicky, “Dave,” his autobiographical comedy series, started with a lot of crude jokes about sexual inadequacy and insecurities.

headline: In New York City, Democracy Is a One-Party Affair
abstract: The Republican Party isn't a factor in  politics here. That's a problem.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s local elections are in full bloom, and all through town, Democrats are having a rollicking time.

headline: Obamacare, Juneteenth, Comedies: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Pandemic Bakers Are Going Pro
abstract: Once again, a period of turmoil has generated a new wave of professional bakers.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, Max Kumangai spent his Saturdays singing and dancing his way through back-to-back performances of “Jagged Little Pill,” a rock musical on Broadway.

headline: How Public Letters Became Companies’ Favorite Form of Activism
abstract: Chief executives have signed countless statements in support of social causes over the last few years. Do they make a difference?
