lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: A bill to make Juneteenth a federal holiday clears the Senate.
abstract: Many states have recognized Juneteenth for decades, but only some observe it as an official holiday. The first was Texas, where the celebration originated.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Tuesday passed a bill to recognize Juneteenth, which commemorates the emancipation of slaves in the United States, as a federal holiday.

headline: Israeli Officer Who Killed Autistic Palestinian Man Charged With Manslaughter
abstract: The indictment came more than a year after the fatal shooting. The family of the victim protested the charges as too lenient, calling them “unjust” and “unacceptable.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A police officer who fatally shot an unarmed Palestinian man with autism was charged with manslaughter on Thursday, in a case that brought attention to the issue of police brutality.

headline: Making Every Second Count in Plays Too Short to Miss
abstract: Theater shrank to tiny proportions during the pandemic. Sometimes that’s a big plus.
lead_paragraph: Forever ago, in March 2020, a press agent handed me tickets before a show and said, “Ninety minutes, no intermission, thank God.”

headline: 6 Men Said to Be Tied to Three Percenters Movement Are Charged in Capitol Riot
abstract: The indictment marks the first charges lodged against conspirators linked to the radical gun rights group or involved with planning any of the political events held the week of the attack.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors filed a wide-ranging conspiracy indictment on Thursday accusing six California men said to be connected to a radical gun rights movement called the Three Percenters with plotting to assault the Capitol on Jan. 6, in the first charges lodged against anyone involved with planning any of the political events held the week of the attack.

headline: Time to Get Some Ranked-Choice Voting Results
abstract: Primary Day may have been one week ago, but many races across the city are still not decided because of ranked-choice voting.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Thousands Rally in Brooklyn to Protest ‘State of Emergency’ for Trans Youth
abstract: The Brooklyn Liberation march took place amid a wave of legislation targeting transgender children and violence that disproportionately affects Black trans women. “We are here to claim space,” one speaker said.
lead_paragraph: When thousands gathered in Brooklyn last summer to participate in a march for Black trans lives, Shéár Avory was at home, helping to care for their family in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic. But Mx. Avory, who is transgender and nonbinary, was heartened by what they saw online: images and videos of a sea of people, dressed in white, rallying for their community.

headline: After a Year of Protests, Portland Is Ready to Move On. But Where?
abstract: The demonstrations that swept the country after George Floyd’s death lived on for much of the year in Portland, a city now engaged in finger-pointing and a debate over what comes next.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Defund the police? City leaders in Portland tried it. A unit in the fire and rescue bureau, one of the first of its kind in a major city, began this year taking some 911 calls about people in crisis, especially those who are homeless.

headline: Rising From Pandemic, New York Seeks a New Mayor to Face Looming Crises
abstract: Eric Adams is considered the front-runner in Tuesday’s Democratic primary, but the race is fluid enough that another candidate may win.

headline: Curator Joy Bivins Is Named New Director of the Schomburg Center
abstract: As the center moves beyond the pandemic, Bivins plans to add more items reflecting the African diaspora and make those materials more accessible.
lead_paragraph: Joy Bivins, who joined the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem last year, has been named director of the center.

headline: With Healing in Mind, Stage Collaborators Take a Dip Together
abstract: The playwright Lynn Nottage chose to share her Signature Theater residency with other artists rocked by 2020. The immersive result: “The Watering Hole.”
lead_paragraph: Before everything that happened happened, the playwright Lynn Nottage had a plan for wrapping up her three-show residency at Signature Theater. It would be the Off Broadway premiere of a new comedy — a play that was titled “Floyd’s” when it was first staged in Minneapolis in 2019.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Never Forget Me’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Black ink streaked Renny’s soggy poster, blurring the letters in “Black Lives Matter.” After a period of distance, we had reunited in his condo, making posters on top of the bed we used to share. It was raining that day in Toronto. Hundreds of feet sloshed in the puddles on Yonge Street. People chanted, “No justice, no peace.” Renny chanted with me. He will never understand what it is like to live in my skin. But that day, for that protest, he marched next to me. He marched for me. — Daniel Reale-Chin

headline: As Israelis Await Netanyahu’s Fate, Palestinians Seize a Moment of Unity
abstract: Seeing little hope for major change from a new Israeli government, Palestinians are focused on an internal generational shift toward a campaign for rights and justice.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When Israelis opened their newspapers and news websites on Tuesday, they encountered a barrage of reports and commentary about the possible downfall of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the country’s longest-serving leader.

headline: This TikTok Star Is Turning the Tables on Microaggressions
abstract: Clare Brown uses the platform to share satirical videos in which white people are treated as a minority.
lead_paragraph: Name: Clare Brown, a.k.a @clarabellecwb

headline: Five Ways to Learn About Juneteenth With The New York Times
abstract: Via photographs, recipes, art, a podcast interview and more, students use The Times to explore the history, traditions and significance of the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Are you looking for ways for your students to learn more about Juneteenth? Below we offer five teaching ideas for exploring the holiday and its significance via a variety of media, including photographs, recipes, art and a podcast interview.

headline: ‘The Legend of the Underground’ Review: Gay Activism in Nigeria
abstract: In this stylish documentary, young men discuss their country’s laws criminalizing gay sex.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “The Legend of the Underground” captures queer Nigerian activists as they discuss their country’s laws criminalizing gay sex. Together, they lament unjust arrests and police brutality. But they are not aiming for either martyrdom or altruism — instead, their goal is to improve the circumstances of their own lives.

headline: Pulitzer Prizes Focus on Coverage of Pandemic and Law Enforcement
abstract: The annual awards recognized journalism on the murder of George Floyd, including a special citation for Darnella Frazier, the teenager who filmed the killing. The public service prize went to The New York Times for Covid coverage.
lead_paragraph: Pulitzer Prizes were awarded on Friday to news organizations that provided in-depth coverage of the dramatic turns of 2020, a year dominated by a pandemic that left millions dead and a national conversation on race after the murder of George Floyd.

headline: A Brooklyn Ice Cream Shop and the Make-or-Break Summer Ahead
abstract: Crème and Cocoa Creamery survived the pandemic. But like many small businesses in New York, its future is hardly secure.
lead_paragraph: It is here at last, the summer of possibility. New York City has been flung open. The evenings have grown long and sultry. Block parties are happening, sidewalks are buzzy. Joy subsists on the chance to roam, to linger.

headline: Runners-Up From Our 8th Annual Student Editorial Contest
abstract: Periods, prisons, political division and poetry. Teenagers tackle these issues and more in these 16 runners-up essays.
lead_paragraph: Here are the 16 runners-up in our Eighth Annual Student Editorial Contest. They join 10 winners and 26 honorable mentions as our favorite essays of the 11,202 we received this year.

headline: Scholars at Oxford University Refuse to Teach Under Statue of Colonialist
abstract: A statue of British imperialist Cecil Rhodes at Oxford University has drawn criticism for decades. Now some academics said they would refuse to teach at the college where the statue sits.
lead_paragraph: A long-running controversy at Oxford University over a statue of Cecil Rhodes, the British imperialist seen by many as an architect of apartheid in South Africa, gained new momentum this week after more than 150 academics said they would refuse to teach students of the college where the monument sits.

headline: It’s Not Too Late to Discover Louise Meriwether
abstract: The author, 98, wrote one of the classic novels of Depression-era Black life, “Daddy Was a Number Runner,” and its themes still resonate today.
lead_paragraph: When Louise Meriwether reflects on her childhood in Harlem, she remembers running around, jumping rope and hanging out with her friends on rooftops, where they would occasionally dare one another to leap from building to building.

headline: Los Angeles Just Elected a Liberal D.A. He’s Already Facing a Recall Effort.
abstract: George Gascón is facing an intense backlash for enacting the sorts of policies demanded by protesters after the killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From inside the walls of Folsom State Prison, the two inmates, one a convicted murderer, clinked their cups of prison moonshine in a toast to the new district attorney of Los Angeles, George Gascón.

headline: Yang and Garcia Announce Plans to Campaign Together
abstract: Their plan to appear together over the last weekend before the primary, appears aimed at creating a bloc against the presumed front-runner, Eric Adams.

headline: France Is Becoming More Like America. It’s Terrible.
abstract: Culture wars, fueled by Fox News-style provocation, have arrived in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s become a familiar refrain in French political life. From President Emmanuel Macron and his cabinet to the far-right opposition, from print columnists to talking heads, “Americanization” is increasingly held responsible for a whole set of social ills ailing the nation.

headline: How the World Learns About Bosses Behaving Badly
abstract: One firm is guiding employees through the process of going public with stories that companies go to great lengths to keep private.
lead_paragraph: The last thing Debbie Kosta wanted was to talk to a reporter. The past year had already upended her life, with the coronavirus putting her in a coma for nearly a month. When she tried to ease back into her job as a saleswoman at Robbins Research International, the company run by the motivational speaker Tony Robbins, she said she found that the company had locked her out of its systems.

headline: Is Bill de Blasio Secretly Backing Eric Adams for Mayor?
abstract: The mayor is not making a public endorsement in the primary race, but he is believed to favor Mr. Adams, the Brooklyn borough president.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: From Nobel Hero to Driver of War, Ethiopia’s Leader Faces Voters
abstract: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed plunged Ethiopia into a war in the Tigray region that spawned atrocities and famine. On Monday, his country goes to the polls.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — As war raged in northern Ethiopia, and the region barreled toward its worst famine in decades, a senior American envoy flew to the Ethiopian capital last month in the hope of persuading Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed to pull his country out of a destructive spiral that many fear is tearing it apart.

headline: The Bishops Betray a Faithful President
abstract: The efforts by conservative bishops to arbitrate who receives communion reinforce why the American bishops so often stand alone.
lead_paragraph: The last time I took communion was in El Salvador, not long before the pandemic. As a Roman Catholic, I enjoy exploring how Mass is experienced and enriched by different cultures. But I had a more urgent reason for searching out this ritual abroad. It provided my only chance to take the Eucharist, because I quietly decided 10 years ago that I could not in good conscience do so under the auspices of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops.

headline: In a speech to a New Hampshire G.O.P. group, Pence calls systemic racism a ‘left-wing myth.’
abstract: Mike Pence also distanced himself from President Donald J. Trump, saying of the Capitol attack, “I don’t know if we’ll ever see eye-to-eye on that day.”
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence on Thursday described systemic racism as a “left-wing myth” during a speech hosted by a Republican group in New Hampshire, adopting the racial politics of his former boss, President Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Human Toll of Bearing Witness
abstract: Smartphone videos are tools for bearing witness and holding the powerful to account. But they come at a cost.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Giuliani embraces Eric Adams days before the primary. Adams says no thanks.
abstract: Mr. Adams did not seem particularly pleased and suggested it was an attempt by the former mayor to sabotage the campaign of a sometimes former critic.
lead_paragraph: Eric Adams may not want Rudy Giuliani’s support, but he got it anyway on Friday when the former mayor of New York City said that if he were a Democrat he would back Mr. Adams in the mayoral primary.

headline: Confronting the Threat of QAnon
abstract: Mia Bloom and Sophie Moskalenko’s “Pastels and Pedophiles” looks at a dangerous movement that is growing in power.
lead_paragraph: PASTELS AND PEDOPHILES Inside the Mind of QAnonBy Mia Bloom and Sophie Moskalenko

headline: We Cannot Fight Anti-Asian Hate Without Dismantling Asian Stereotypes
abstract: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Madison Xu, age 16.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Madison Xu, age 16, from Horace Mann School in the Bronx, N.Y., is one of the Top 10 winners of The Learning Network’s Eighth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 11,202 entries.

headline: His, Hers, Everyone’s: Gender-Equal Underwear Goes (Slightly More) Mainstream
abstract: For years underwear has been strictly gendered. The co-founders of Play Out Apparel are reimagining it for all gender identities.
lead_paragraph: — Abby Sugar, co-founder and chief executive of Play Out Apparel

headline: A Quiet Demonstration and a Long Shadow
abstract: Few noticed Wyomia Tyus’s subtle gesture in support of human rights at the 1968 Olympics. But her act is part of a rich history of athlete protest.
lead_paragraph: To stay loose for the women’s 100-meter sprint at the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City, Wyomia Tyus danced the “Tighten Up” before settling into her starting blocks. The dance song was an early funk classic by Archie Bell and the Drells, a Houston band that proclaimed with jaunty assurance, “We don’t only sing, but we dance just as good as we want.”

headline: Garbage’s Shirley Manson Thrives on Unapologetic Heroines
abstract: The musician chats about weeping to Patti Smith, getting goose bumps from Yoko Ono and freeing her mind via Louise Bourgeois as her band releases its seventh album.
lead_paragraph: Back in the ’90s, Shirley Manson never expected Garbage would still be making music together nearly 30 years later, and she suspects no one else did, either. “We’re outliers,” the fiery Scottish frontwoman said, referring to bandmates Butch Vig, Duke Erikson and Steve Marker. “We don’t fit into any hip scene. We’ve always done our own thing. I think that’s really rare.”

headline: Most Americans Know Little or Nothing About Juneteenth, Poll Finds
abstract: Academics believe that increases in the number of Americans familiar with the holiday, which commemorates the end of slavery in the U.S., may be a result of last summer’s protests against racism.
lead_paragraph: More than 60 percent of Americans know “nothing at all” or only “a little bit” about Juneteenth, the holiday celebrating the end of slavery in the United States, according to a new Gallup survey.

headline: Angélique Kidjo Connects With Africa’s Next Musical Generation
abstract: The artist from Benin showed African songwriters how to reach the world. Now they’re repaying the favor.
lead_paragraph: Angélique Kidjo, the singer from Benin who has been forging Pan-African and transcontinental hybrids for three decades, didn’t really need another Grammy.

headline: Board Approves Removal of ‘Negro’ From 16 Place Names in Texas
abstract: An Interior Department committee’s decision to allow the renaming of the sites comes nearly 30 years after Texas lawmakers first voted to change the names.
lead_paragraph: A federal board on Thursday approved the renaming of 16 sites in Texas whose names include the word “Negro,” a change long sought by politicians and activists in the state, but one that will affect only a small fraction of the hundreds of racist names of towns and geographical features that remain in the United States.

headline: Life Gets Hectic Fast for a Heroine and Her Newfound 12-Year-Old
abstract: The title character of Mia McKenzie’s novel “Skye Falling” wants to avoid chaos and human connection. Too bad for her.
lead_paragraph: SKYE FALLINGBy Mia McKenzie

headline: Whose Pride Is It Anyway?
abstract: The decision to bar uniformed police officers from Pride marches has drawn cheers — and criticism. A gay officer and a New York parade organizer talk through the fallout.
lead_paragraph: It’s Pride Month, which means cities across the country will be having parades and other festivities, albeit scaled-down versions. In New York and several other cities, parade organizers have said uniformed police officers may not march as a group. Organizers say the move acknowledges that a Pride march isn’t just a celebration and that it began as a statement about police violence against L.G.B.T.Q. people at the Stonewall Inn.

headline: Battle for Black Voters in N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Centers on Policing
abstract: As New York’s Democratic primary nears, Black voters appear torn between Eric Adams and Maya Wiley and their divergent views on balancing public safety and civil rights.
lead_paragraph: [Live N.Y.C. mayoral race primary results.]

headline: Driver Who Plowed Into Protesters in Minneapolis Is Charged With Murder
abstract: Nicholas Kraus of St. Paul, Minn., was drunk at the time of the crash, the authorities said. Deona Marie Erickson, 31, a social justice advocate, was killed in the episode.
lead_paragraph: The drunken driver who plowed a sport-utility vehicle into a crowd of protesters in Minneapolis on Sunday night, killing a woman and injuring several other people, was charged on Wednesday with intentional second-degree murder, the authorities said.

headline: Inside the Capitol Riot: An Exclusive Video Investigation
abstract: The Times analyzed thousands of videos from the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol Building to understand how it happened — and why. Here are some of the key findings.

headline: The Cost of Being an ‘Interchangeable Asian’
abstract: At some top companies, Asian Americans are overrepresented in midlevel roles and underrepresented in leadership. The root of this workplace inequality could stem from the all-too-common experience of being confused for someone else.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: F.B.I. Is Pursuing ‘Hundreds’ in Capitol Riot Inquiry, Wray Tells Congress
abstract: In two separate hearings, the F.B.I. director and Pentagon officials answered questions about the failure to adequately prepare for and respond to the Jan. 6 attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. is pursuing potentially hundreds more suspects in the Capitol riot, the agency’s director told Congress on Tuesday, calling the effort to find those responsible for the deadly assault “one of the most far-reaching and extensive” investigations in the bureau’s history.

headline: What I Saw in My First 10 Years on Testosterone
abstract: Whether we asked for the job or not, trans people are playing a key role in shaping the future of gender for everyone.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago this month, on an otherwise ordinary lunch break from my job as an editor at a local newspaper, I received my first testosterone injection from a no-nonsense doctor at a hospital in Boston. I was 30 years old and desperate to be known.

headline: ‘Take the Ship’: Conservatives Aim to Commandeer Southern Baptists
abstract: The insurgents, some adopting a pirate motif, believe that the denomination has drifted too far to the left on issues of race, gender and the strict authority of the Bible.
lead_paragraph: Allen Nelson IV walked to the front of his small church in central Arkansas, stopped in front of the communion table with three large crosses behind him, and unfurled a giant black flag with a white skull and crossed swords.

headline: Eric Adams Is Awful. I’m Putting Him on My Ballot.
abstract: He'll be bad for progressives but still better than Andrew Yang.
lead_paragraph: A primary aim of American progressive politics is assembling multiracial working-class coalitions. One candidate in New York City’s Democratic mayoral primary appears to be doing that. He is, unfortunately for the left, Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams, an ex-cop and former Republican who defends the use of stop-and-frisk, supports charter schools and is endorsed by Rupert Murdoch’s New York Post.

headline: Naomi Osaka and the Power of ‘Nope’
abstract: The power balance has changed among public figures, the journalists and publications that cover them and the companies that they do business with.
lead_paragraph: When Naomi Osaka dropped out of the French Open on Monday, after declining to attend media interviews that she said could trigger her anxiety, she wasn’t just protecting her mental health. She was sending a message to the establishment of one of the world’s most elite sports: I will not be controlled.

headline: Elizabeth Martínez, Voice of the Chicana Movement, Dies at 95
abstract: Through her writings, she inspired, provoked, educated, strategized, organized and built cross-racial and cross-ethnic alliances, all in pursuit of social justice.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Martínez, a feminist, writer and community activist who helped organize the Chicana movement, which sought to empower people, like her, who were of Mexican descent and born in the United States, died on Tuesday in San Francisco. She was 95.

headline: Artists on Artists to Watch, and Maybe Even Collect
abstract: We asked 16 established names to suggest a fellow talent they feel should be better known.
lead_paragraph: The best direction one could give to someone interested in expanding their knowledge of contemporary art is to pay attention to what artists are paying attention to; artists always know before everyone else does. With this in mind, we asked 16 established artists from all over the world about a young or underappreciated artist whose work resonates with them. They spoke about why these talents deserve more attention than they’re getting, and why readers should take time to explore their oeuvres, which inspect, among other things, issues of identity, race, material culture, social justice, climate change and how we live.

headline: Quinta Brunson’s Viral Fame Knows No Bounds
abstract: The comedian’s first book, “She Memes Well,” balances jokes, autobiography and serious thoughts about the state of the country.
lead_paragraph: When she began drafting her first collection of essays, Quinta Brunson wasn’t sure she had anything meaningful to say.

headline: Once a Bastion of Free Speech, the A.C.L.U. Faces an Identity Crisis
abstract: An organization that has defended the First Amendment rights of Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan is split by an internal debate over whether supporting progressive causes is more important.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be the celebration of a grand career, as the American Civil Liberties Union presented a prestigious award to the longtime lawyer David Goldberger. He had argued one of its most famous cases, defending the free speech rights of Nazis in the 1970s to march in Skokie, Ill., home to many Holocaust survivors.

headline: Everyone’s Moving to Texas. Here’s Why.
abstract: We studied 16,847 places to find out why Dallas is so popular.
lead_paragraph: The traumas of the past few years have rearranged all of our lives. Many Americans have new needs, new desires, new possibilities and new priorities. They’re looking for bigger homes, second homes or any home at all. They’re searching for work — or trying to escape work. Some fear encroaching heat, fire or flood. Others are repulsed by bitter local politics. Many simply hear the distant siren of a better life elsewhere.

headline: Kenosha, Portland, and the Lies We Must Leave Behind
abstract: What I saw in Portland and Kenosha has convinced me: We must stop tearing ourselves apart so that we can build.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 25, 2020, violence was exploding on the streets of Kenosha, Wis., two days after the police shooting of Jacob Blake. Anyone who had been paying attention since the killing of George Floyd by the police in Minneapolis on May 25 most likely had one of two reactions: “Why is this happening? It’s unjustifiable” or “Of course this is happening, it’s completely justifiable.”

headline: ‘It’s good to see racism lose’: Guilty verdicts are hailed in the Arbery case.
abstract: The murder convictions of three white men in the death of Ahmaud Arbery were praised by many as a just outcome in a case that could have stoked racial divisions.
lead_paragraph: From the moment the first guilty verdict was uttered inside a Georgia courtroom, a cascade of tears and shouts of vindication coursed across the country. Black parents called their children, weeping. Activists choked up, embracing what they called a rare instance of justice.

headline: School Nurses Feel Like ‘The Enemy’
abstract: Partisan fights over Covid-19 have made life harder for overstretched school nurses and spawned waves of school board fights.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus hasn’t gone away. Neither have school staffing problems. And parent protests against pandemic restrictions have only grown stronger.

headline: 18 Warm-Up Activities to Engage Students Before They Read Nonfiction Texts
abstract: Here is a collection of our favorite “bell ringers,” “do nows” and “hooks” to grab students’ attention, along with examples from dozens of our daily lessons.
lead_paragraph: How can you get your students interested in reading informational texts, whether the topic is Syria or sneakers, space exploration or statistics, surfing, superheroes or “the souls of Black girls”? How can you help them make connections between unfamiliar topics and their own lives? How can you scaffold complex ideas to make them accessible for a wide variety of learners?

headline: Preparing for the Society of the Future
abstract: To thrive in the future, companies must rethink their growth strategies accordingly. A select group of companies Accenture calls Forerunners recognizes that emerging lifestyle shifts amongst consumers and investors will impact business in the future.
lead_paragraph: Episode Transcription

headline: Protesters Rally Outside Courthouse in Support of Arbery’s Family
abstract: Black Lives Matter supporters marched around the Glynn County Courthouse in Brunswick, Ga., as both sides in the Ahmaud Arbery murder trial gave their closing arguments.
lead_paragraph: Black Lives Matter supporters marched around the Glynn County Courthouse in Brunswick, Ga., as both sides in the Ahmaud Arbery murder trial gave their closing arguments.

headline: What the Arbery and Rittenhouse Verdicts Couldn’t Tell Us
abstract: We must stop tying our hopes for justice to high-profile criminal cases.
lead_paragraph: When public defenders go to court, we represent people who are routinely referred to as “bodies” and, just as often, treated as such. Many of us wish that the public could witness the degradation and absurdity of everyday legal proceedings.

headline: House Panel Investigating Capitol Attack Subpoenas Proud Boys and Oath Keepers
abstract: Investigators believe three militia or paramilitary groups have information about the deadly siege on Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Capitol attack issued subpoenas on Tuesday to three militia or paramilitary groups, including the Proud Boys and the Oath Keepers, that investigators believe have information about the deadly siege on Jan. 6.

headline: An Art Fair Meets a Pent-Up Demand
abstract: This year’s edition of Art Basel Miami Beach brings collectors back while welcoming a more diverse group of gallery owners.
lead_paragraph: Art Basel Miami Beach has twice been disrupted by seismic world events. In 2001, what was to be the inaugural edition of the art fair was postponed a whole year in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. Last year, the coronavirus pandemic was the culprit, though the live fair was replaced with an online viewing room.

headline: ‘It’s about time’: Voters reflected on electing N.Y.C.’s second Black mayor.
abstract: New York has had 109 mayors, only one of whom, David Dinkins, was Black. Many voters said Eric Adams’s likely victory felt personal.
lead_paragraph: As New Yorkers cast their ballots on Tuesday, a broad range of issues, from public safety to education, were top of mind. But some said what was most significant about the current moment was its potential to usher in history.

headline: Why Are More Black Kids Suicidal? A Search for Answers.
abstract: Mental health experts assumed that people of all races had the same risk factors for self-harm. Emerging evidence suggests that is not the case.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: An Indigenous Canadian Director Channels Traumatic Memories Into Film
abstract: Tracey Deer based “Beans” on her experiences as a child during the 1990 Oka crisis, a confrontation between the Mohawk people and the government.
lead_paragraph: Tracey Deer can still remember the sound of rocks hitting the car, her panicked mother’s orders to “Get down!” and the loud smash as a back passenger window shattered, showering glass over her screaming little sister.

headline: Four Years After ‘Unite the Right,’ Charlottesville Still Struggles to Move On
abstract: Many residents hoped the town would become an example of racial reconciliation. It hasn’t happened.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA. — On a recent Monday night, portions of the virtual meeting of the Charlottesville City Council felt more like angry exchanges of shouting and broadsides than a consideration of city business.

headline: The Truth About Kyle Rittenhouse’s Gun
abstract: Kyle Rittenhouse’s semiautomatic rifle endangered everybody around him —  and himself.
lead_paragraph: Update: A Wisconsin jury on Friday acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse of homicide and other charges.

headline: Thandiwe Newton Feeds Her Soul With Critical Race Theory and Cleo Sol
abstract: The “Westworld” actress talks about her new Audible recording of Tolstoy’s “War and Peace” and why too much entertainment can be bad for you.
lead_paragraph: For Thandiwe Newton, recording an audiobook isn’t merely sinking into a comfy chair in front of a mic and trying not to trip over the words. Especially when it’s a literary behemoth like Tolstoy’s “War and Peace.”

headline: Should I Try to Save a Child From Her Adoptive Mom’s Bad Race Politics?
abstract: There’s one big thing to remember before your kids hang out.
lead_paragraph: I live in Alabama where it has become quite common for white families to adopt Black children. I feel like many of them believe that this action absolves them of any accusation of racism. Personally (I’m Black) I disagree and believe they have an obligation to actively engage in dismantling racist systems and practices on behalf of their child, rather than merely assimilating the child into their families and social circles, which inevitably reflect these same racist systems and inequitable outcomes. The issue is that one mom whom I know through my community activities has pushed for friendships between her children — one of her girls in particular — and my 9-year-old daughter. But from what I’ve seen on social media she is a Trump supporter, has anti-immigrant views and has an “all lives matter” approach to police violence. I would normally not leave my daughter in the care of adults with these values or become “mom friends” with them. But do I have an obligation to get closer to the family for the child’s sake?

headline: Alice Childress Finally Gets to Make ‘Trouble’ on Broadway
abstract: Her prescient 1955 play about racism in the theater world is reaching the big stage. And it’s anything but a period piece.
lead_paragraph: Wiletta Mayer walks into the theater already knowing how things will go. Smartly dressed, attractive and middle-aged (don’t ask for a number, because “a woman that’ll tell her age will tell anything”), she is a veteran actress who’s played maids and mammies and knows how to cater to white directors and producers. You can call it “Uncle Tomming.” Or you can call it plain common sense. Either way, it’s a living.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: This week’s recommended books include a couple of biographies of the civil rights leader Fannie Lou Hamer, along with memoirs by the celebrated movie director James Ivory and the Kenyan activist Nice Leng’ete. There’s also a new biography of Robert E. Lee, an insider’s account of Trump-era Washington and an essay collection about antisemitism and the hazards of Jewish memory. In fiction, Jocelyn Nicole Johnson’s debut collection joins new novels by the heavyweights Louise Erdrich, Elizabeth Strout and Amor Towles.

headline: Rittenhouse and the Right’s White Vigilante Heroes
abstract: The great threat is that there are young men out there who watched the verdict and now want to follow Rittenhouse’s lead.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Rittenhouse, the 18-year-old who shot and killed two men and wounded a third last year during protests of the police shooting of Jacob Blake, was found not guilty Friday of all charges by a Wisconsin jury.

headline: To Paramilitary Groups, Rittenhouse Verdict Means Vindication
abstract: His acquittal has reinvigorated support on the right for armed responses to racial justice protests and unrest.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, as Kyle Rittenhouse stood in a courtroom in Kenosha, Wis., awaiting the verdict in his trial, a large bald man with mutton chop sideburns sat in a pew several rows behind him. As a court clerk announced Mr. Rittenhouse’s acquittal on all charges, a faint smile passed across the man’s lips.

headline: How Hanif Abdurraqib Cuts Through the Noise
abstract: He is a National Book Award finalist for “A Little Devil in America,” but he has more books to write, more projects to take on and more s’mores to research.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Jennifer Packer: Painting as an Exercise in Tenderness
abstract: In a virtuosic solo show at the Whitney, the artist finds her subjects’ complex humanity, and offers a new way forward for representation.
lead_paragraph: Portraiture is everywhere at the moment, in painting and photography alike, and some of the best of it has a specific aim: to make those who have been rendered invisible — on museum walls, in public culture, in political discourse — visible. This drive to honor and dignify people through representation comes at an ethical cost that often goes unremarked, though: Does exposing your sitters to the viewer’s gaze turn them into things to be looked at, emptied of their hidden complexities? Can you paint someone’s portrait while still insisting that vision cannot — perhaps even should not — capture all there is to know?

headline: Eric Adams Is Elected Mayor of New York City
abstract: Mr. Adams, a Democrat and former police captain, will be the second Black mayor in the city’s history.
lead_paragraph: Eric Leroy Adams, a former New York City police captain whose attention-grabbing persona and keen focus on racial justice fueled a decades-long career in public life, was elected on Tuesday as the 110th mayor of New York and the second Black mayor in the city’s history.

headline: Powell’s Books Survived Amazon. Can It Reinvent Itself After the Pandemic?
abstract: As much as any city, Portland, Ore., has been through hell. Its landmark store, Powell’s Books, must finally build a viable online business while recapturing its downtown success.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Nigerian Army Killed Unarmed Protesters, Report Finds
abstract: The incident in October 2020 could be “equated with a massacre,” a government panel said, refuting the army’s claim that soldiers only fired blanks.
lead_paragraph: The Nigerian Army shot and killed at least 11 unarmed, peaceful protesters and wounded dozens of others during a demonstration last year, in an incident that can be labeled a massacre, a government panel has found.

headline: He’s Remaking Criminal Justice in L.A. But How Far Is Too Far?
abstract: To keep people out of prison, George Gascón is risking everything: rising violent crime, a staff rebellion and the votes that made him district attorney.
lead_paragraph: Last December, when George Gascón took over the largest local prosecutor’s office in the country, he made a complete break from the past. His inaugural speech as district attorney of Los Angeles County at once thrilled progressive activists and alienated many of the lawyers sizing up their new boss. Standing alone at a lectern as a pandemic precaution, Gascón put his hands to his forehead and half-bowed, yogi-style, to thank the judge who swore him in over a video connection. He flashed a smile and spoke in Spanish, his first language as a child growing up in Cuba, to honor his mother, who fled Fidel Castro’s Communist rule with his father and Gascón when he was 13.

headline: Can Self-Defense Laws Stand Up to a Country Awash in Guns?
abstract: The Kyle Rittenhouse and Ahmaud Arbery cases raise intriguing legal questions about people who take the law into their own hands and then claim self-defense when someone dies.
lead_paragraph: As two closely watched murder trials played out in two different states this past week, juries heard strikingly similar stories: men took up guns in the name of protecting the public, and when they wound up killing unarmed people, they claimed self-defense.

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center Reopens, With Four Young Players in the Spotlight
abstract: The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra returned to indoor performance with “Wynton at 60,” a program featuring Marsalis originals and a quartet of up-and-coming trumpeters.
lead_paragraph: The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra was amused as four trumpet players, all but one under the age of 30, took their position in the rehearsal room late Tuesday morning.

headline: How to Teach a Little Girl to Love Her Brown Skin
abstract: “I don’t like my skin color,” my beautiful, brown-skinned daughter told me. “I wish my skin was lighter. It’s prettier.”
lead_paragraph: My 5-year-old daughter, Nusayba, twirled around in her princess dress, fixing her silver tiara and checking out her newly applied eye shadow and red lipstick in the bathroom mirror. Then she examined her beautiful, brown skin.

headline: Tony Kushner, Oracle of the Upper West Side
abstract: When Steven Spielberg asked Kushner, America’s most important living playwright, to take on ‘West Side Story,’ he thought, ‘He’s lost his mind.’ But he dared.
lead_paragraph: “MY FAVORITE QUOTE,” Tony Kushner says, “is from an American anarchist named Voltairine de Cleyre.”

headline: He Escaped Prison in 2015. Did He Kill a Young Mother Decades Before?
abstract: A bid to exonerate two men in a Buffalo-area murder centers on the possible role in the crime of Richard Matt, a notorious New York killer.
lead_paragraph: TONAWANDA, N.Y. — In February 1993, Deborah Meindl walked into her house in this working-class Buffalo suburb on a blustery Wednesday afternoon, and never left.

headline: As Youngkin Tries to Finesse Trump, McAuliffe Conjures His Comeback
abstract: Barnstorming Virginia, the candidates for governor hammered away at their core arguments. For the Republican: parents’ involvement in schools. For the Democrat: Trump redux.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFAX, Va. — In the final hours of campaigning on Monday to become Virginia’s next governor, it was Glenn Youngkin offering an optimistic vision for the future while Terry McAuliffe delivered harsh warnings about ghosts of the past.

headline: BIPOC or POC? Equity or Equality? The Debate Over Language on the Left.
abstract: For those pushing for changes in society on race and other issues, words matter. They can also muddle.
lead_paragraph: In California, a Black college freshman from the South is telling a story about his Latino friends from home when he is interrupted by a white classmate. “We say ‘Latinx’ here,” he recalls her saying, using a term he had not heard before, “because we respect trans people.”

headline: What Students Are Saying About Gen Z’s Values, Thrift-Shopping, and Beloved Family Members
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our recent writing prompts.

headline: The Manny Diaries
abstract: Chapter 1: This job is hard. Chapter 2: Leaving it is harder.
lead_paragraph: I was 24, relatively new to New York City, working a day job I hated, waiting tables at night, and writing plays in my bedroom during any spare moment. But money was getting tight, and so were my jeans, as I ended most of my serving shifts by scarfing down high-calorie pub food. With few options left, I decided to fall back on the one job I knew would be a sure thing: babysitting.

headline: Our Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest
abstract: We invite students to write opinion pieces on the issues that matter to them. Contest dates: March 2 to April 13, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Update, June 16: Winners have been announced!

headline: Can Democrats Win in Rural America?
abstract: Readers discuss a news article analyzing the Virginia governor’s race and a column by David Brooks. Also: The censure of Rep. Paul Gosar; Covid strategies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Do Generations Matter? Well, Maybe.
abstract: Emma Goldberg recently wrote about the tension between Gen Z employees and millennial bosses. The article sparked spirited — and sometimes, heated — debate online. Here, she explores the need to categorize ourselves into generations.
lead_paragraph: When I started middle school, the quiz-industrial complex was booming, which meant I spent much of sixth grade mulling over a set of complex questions: If I were a Hostess snack, which one would I be? Pasta shape? Dog breed? Character in “Full House”? Which house would I have landed in at Hogwarts?

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Weighs In on the Kyle Rittenhouse Verdict
abstract: This weekend’s broadcast, hosted by Simu Liu, also included some helpful Thanksgiving tips and, uh, Dog Head Man.
lead_paragraph: About a half-hour into this weekend’s broadcast, “Saturday Night Live” would devote an entire sketch to a character with a dog’s head and neck attached to a human body. But first, the show addressed the acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse.

headline: A Rare ‘Othello’ Puts the Spotlight on Race
abstract: With a Black-led production of Shakespeare’s play, an Austrian theater hopes to jump-start a conversation about racism and the need for diversity on the country’s stages.
lead_paragraph: ST. PÖLTEN, Austria — “Speak of me as I am,” Othello urges in the wrenching final scene of Shakespeare’s tragedy. Yet for centuries, those words — a plea for accurate representation — were spoken, by and large, by white actors.

headline: Threats of Violence in Today’s Political Discourse
abstract: Readers discuss the rise in death threats and calls for bloodshed. Also: Senator Sinema; gerrymandered districts; immigration; Somalia.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting Racism, Quietly
abstract: The Ahmaud Arbery trial offers lessons for American politics.
lead_paragraph: The most effective way to achieve racial justice can sometimes be to downplay race.

headline: Kamaru Usman Wants U.F.C. Glory but to Still Live Normally
abstract: Content to hang out with his daughter mostly unbothered, Usman, the U.F.C. welterweight champion, does not aspire for the fame of Conor McGregor. But he does have his eye on something big.
lead_paragraph: Kamaru Usman, one of the fiercest men on the planet, is content with the level of fame he has achieved in this bloody sport of mixed martial arts.

headline: Transcript: Nicole Hemmer Interviews Kathleen Belew for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
abstract: A conversation with the historian
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest hosted by Nicole Hemmer and featuring Kathleen Belew. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: ‘Sooryavanshi’ Review: Cops on a Crusade
abstract: The latest in Rohit Shetty’s Bollywood cop franchise is both overstuffed and paper-thin.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, the Bollywood director Rohit Shetty has built a flamboyant Cop Cinematic Universe with crowd pleasers — “Singham,” “Singham Returns,” and “Simmba” — about righteous policemen with anger issues and physics-defying stunt capabilities. Shetty’s latest installment tries to up the ante (a fool’s errand, given how over-the-top each of the prior movies already is) by smushing them all together: The movie’s titular Anti-Terrorism Squad officer, played by the action veteran Akshay Kumar, is joined by the supercops of the previous films (Ajay Devgn and Ranveer Singh) for a bullets-and-brawn extravaganza.

headline: Black Man Stomped by South Carolina Officer Will Receive $650,000 Settlement
abstract: When the man did not lie on the ground quickly, because he has metal rods and pins in his leg and hip, a police officer stomped on the back of his head.
lead_paragraph: After being stopped by the police in South Carolina in July, a Black man was ordered to lie on the ground. When he did not do so quickly, because he has metal rods and pins in his leg and hip, an officer stomped on the back of his head.

headline: Outside the courthouse, supporters of Ahmaud Arbery’s family keep watch.
abstract: Supporters said that they were anxious but optimistic that the jury would find the three defendants guilty of murder.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of the Arbery family who had gathered outside the courthouse in Brunswick, Ga., during closing arguments in the trial on Monday said that they were anxious but optimistic that the jury would find the three defendants guilty of murder.

headline: Robert Battle on Running Ailey: ‘This Is My Choreography Now’
abstract: Celebrating 10 years as the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Battle says he is most proud of the chances he has taken.
lead_paragraph: Robert Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, sitting in his office at the company’s headquarters recently, pointed to a photo on the wall.

headline: A Tech Whistle-Blower Helps Others Speak Out
abstract: Ifeoma Ozoma, who accused Pinterest of discrimination, has become a key figure in helping tech employees disclose, and fight, mistreatment at work.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed a bill to expand protections for people who speak up about discrimination in the workplace.

headline: Anxiety About Wokeness Is Intellectual Weakness
abstract: Embracing intellectual diversity means being brave enough to consider ideas and practices that might inspire you to change your life.
lead_paragraph: Last week news outlets and social media were abuzz with the announcement of plans to establish a university dedicated to the “fearless pursuit of truth” and “forbidden courses.” The new school, the University of Austin — not to be confused with the fully accredited public University of Texas at Austin — is being created by a group of moderate and conservative intellectuals and writers who are frequently critical of what they see as groupthink on college campuses. Higher education, they argue, has been broken for a long time, and this school is an attempt to begin to fix it.

headline: Democrats Thought They Bottomed Out in Rural, White America. It Wasn’t the Bottom.
abstract: Republicans ran up the margins in rural Virginia counties, the latest sign that Democrats, as one lawmaker put it, “continue to tank in small-town America.”
lead_paragraph: HOT SPRINGS, Va. — The increasingly liberal politics of Virginia had been a sore spot for residents of this conservative town of 499 people nestled in the Allegheny Mountains. But this past week, as Republicans stormed to marquee victories powered in part by turnout in rural areas like Bath County, local voters cheered.

headline: Aida Rodriguez Wants You to Laugh at the Pain
abstract: The Dominican American comic hopes to broaden the way Latinos are represented in comedy. She’s finally getting her chance.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — “I didn’t know I was half Dominican until I got older,” the comedian Aida Rodriguez said from the stage at the Stateside Theater. “They broke it to me like it was bad news.”

headline: Transcript: Rogé Karma Interviews Patrick Sharkey for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
abstract: A conversation with the sociologist.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest hosted by Rogé Karma and featuring Patrick Sharkey. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: The fatal encounter at the center of the Arbery hate-crimes trial was captured on cellphone video.
abstract: The final minutes of Ahmaud Arbery’s life were captured in a cellphone video taken by one of three men now facing federal hate-crime charges after being convicted of murder in state court last year.
lead_paragraph: The final minutes of Ahmaud Arbery’s life were captured in a cellphone video taken by one of three men now facing federal hate-crime charges after being convicted of murder in state court last year.

headline: A Curator Makes Room for Big Ideas and Big Art
abstract: The Mexico City curator Magalí Arriola will again assemble Meridians at Art Basel Miami Beach, a diverting lineup of hard-to-fit pieces.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Art Basel had practical purposes in mind when it introduced the Meridians section to its sprawling Miami Beach marketplace in 2019. The oversize exhibition space was meant to make room for large-scale objects and performance pieces that galleries could not fit in their standard fair booths.

headline: The Superheroes From House of Slay Are Here to Stay
abstract: How five fashion friends got a starring role fighting discrimination and hate in a new comic book series.
lead_paragraph: One evening, just before Halloween, a party was held at Chinese Tuxedo, a trendy Cantonese restaurant in Chinatown in Manhattan. Attendees entered through a back alley lit by yellow lanterns, past graffitied walls covered in posters of superheroes. Inside they sipped Champagne while Asian drag queens, West Dakota, Panthera Lush and Dynasty, writhed around the restaurant’s poles. The evening’s invitation had dictated: “Dress to Slay.”

headline: Police Officer Stabbed on French Riviera, Authorities Say
abstract: Gérald Darmanin, France’s interior minister, said an assailant had stabbed an officer in Cannes. The motive for the attack was not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French police officer was attacked and stabbed as he sat in his patrol car early Monday morning in the city of Cannes, on the French Riviera, according to the French authorities.

headline: What Can Older Generations Learn From Gen Z?
abstract: What is unique about your generation? What attitudes about fashion, work-life balance or political activism might benefit older generations?
lead_paragraph: What is unique about Gen Z? What are some of the qualities — good and bad — that define your generation? Have you found older generations accepting of those qualities?

headline: Everything You Think You Know About the Suburbs Is Wrong
abstract: Understanding diversity in the suburbs is a key to winning elections.
lead_paragraph: The suburban school is an imagined space that invites an unhealthy amount of hyperbole, misinterpretation and fear. All-white classrooms with a few token Asians, expansive, well-kept playing fields and pickup circles filled with Volvo S.U.V.s driven by anxious, potentially reactionary mothers might still exist in small pockets of the country. But even many of those privileged spaces have likely seen significant demographic change over the past few decades.

headline: China’s Influence Looms Over Blinken’s Africa Visit
abstract: On a stop in Nigeria, the secretary of state said the U.S. would no longer treat African countries as pawns in a global game. But American competition with Beijing was hard to overlook.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — When Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken drove into Nigeria’s capital Abuja from the airport on Thursday, his motorcade zoomed past the China Chamber of Commerce in Nigeria building, a domed, almost palace-like structure along the expressway.

headline: I Was Told I Have Career Advantages ‘as a Black Woman.’ Here’s How I Replied.
abstract: At this point in my career, as a senior leader, I welcome it when people engage me on the topic of race in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: For senior company executives, appointments to public boards are one way to ease into retirement with purpose and prestige. But in a recent conversation I had with a 60-something white man, he lamented that the board opportunities he had expected and looked forward to are unlikely to materialize for him.

headline: Jurors Who Convicted Derek Chauvin Are Identified for First Time
abstract: A judge also released questionnaires that the jurors had filled out before they were selected for the trial, which ended with Mr. Chauvin being imprisoned for murdering George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — More than six months after a jury found the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin guilty of murdering George Floyd, the identities of the 12 jurors whose verdict sent Mr. Chauvin to prison were released on Monday for the first time.

headline: Afrofuturist Room at the Met Redresses a Racial Trauma
abstract: “Before Yesterday We Could Fly,” a novel approach to the period room, threads together past, present and future. It focuses on Seneca Village, a Black community whose erasure still reverberates.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after the racial reckoning, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has created one of its most thoughtful reparations projects yet.

headline: In Minneapolis Schools, White Families Are Asked to Help Do the Integrating
abstract: In a citywide overhaul, a beloved Black high school was rezoned to include white students from a richer neighborhood. It has been hard for everyone.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — When Mauri Friestleben learned that Minneapolis was rolling out a new school integration plan — and that the school she led, a predominantly Black, low-income high school, would soon include white students from some of the wealthiest neighborhoods in town — she looked around and proudly considered all that her school had to offer.

headline: Transcript: Rogé Karma Interviews Sarah Jaffe for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
abstract: A conversation with the journalist.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest hosted by Rogé Karma and featuring Sarah Jaffe. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: White Men on Trial
abstract: Race hangs heavy over cases featuring white male defendants accused of everything from murder to insurrection.
lead_paragraph: There is quite the convergence at the moment of race and justice as cases featuring white male defendants accused of everything from murder to insurrection dominate news coverage.

headline: The Enduring Influence of Fannie Lou Hamer, Civil Rights Advocate
abstract: Two new biographies, “Walk With Me,” by Kate Clifford Larson, and “Until I Am Free,” by Keisha N. Blain, recount Hamer’s struggle to open up voting to Black people in Mississippi and argue for the continued relevance of her tactics.
lead_paragraph: WALK WITH MEA Biography of Fannie Lou HamerBy Kate Clifford Larson

headline: How Xenia Rubinos Freed Herself on a New Album, ‘Una Rosa’
abstract: On her third LP, the singer-songwriter brings her brassy vocals to a surreal, electronic universe.
lead_paragraph: Xenia Rubinos stuck her head inside a white, doughnut-shaped couch, trying to get a better feel for the furniture’s globular shape. Earlier, she had plastered her face on an oblong, clear sculpture made out of plastic, smushing her right cheek up against the material.

headline: Roger Goodell’s Pay for Two Years Reached Nearly $128 Million
abstract: The N.F.L. commissioner’s compensation for 2019-20 and 2020-21, bolstered by bonuses for closing labor and media rights deals, was disclosed to team owners in a private meeting.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell’s pay for the past two fiscal years totaled almost $128 million, bolstered by bonuses for helping the league’s owners clinch a new 10-year labor deal with the players and secure media contracts worth more than $100 billion over the next decade.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: The geopolitical risks of climate change.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration released several reports about the risk of climate change to national security, laying out in stark terms the ways in which the warming world is beginning to significantly challenge stability worldwide, through developments such as worsening international conflict and increased dislocation and migration as people flee climate-fueled instability.

headline: A Sweeping New History Looks Back at 100 Years of Black Filmmaking
abstract: Wil Haygood’s “Colorization” feels crisp and urgent while covering a lot of ground: from the earliest pioneers to the careers of Sidney Poitier, Lena Horne, Spike Lee and many others.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Whose Promised Land?A Journey Into a Divided Israel
abstract: Two Times journalists drive the length of Israel to discover what it means to be Israeli today. They meet a kaleidoscope of people, searching for belonging but far apart on how to find it.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Transcript: Ross Douthat Interviews Sohrab Ahmari for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
abstract: A conversation with the conservative writer.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Ross Douthat and featuring Sohrab Ahmari. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Victims of Charlottesville Rally Argue the Violence Was Planned
abstract: The civil trial that starts Monday will examine whether the far-right organizers had plotted to foment violence. They have countered that bloodshed stemmed from self-defense.
lead_paragraph: The violent rally started with a mob of men brandishing burning torches in the heart of an American city while chanting racist, antisemitic slogans, and it ended with a woman murdered, scarring a nation. Now, more than four years later, a civil trial starting on Monday in Charlottesville, Va., will revisit those unsettling events.

headline: Bubba Wallace Gets a Breakthrough NASCAR Victory at Talladega
abstract: Wallace’s NASCAR Cup win was the first by a Black driver since 1963 and also the inaugural victory in the sport’s top series for Michael Jordan, the co-owner of Wallace’s team.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a year after almost single-handedly forcing American auto racing to confront the sport’s longstanding issues with racism, Darrell Wallace Jr., known as Bubba, became just the second Black winner in NASCAR’s top series, finishing first at a rain-shortened event at Talladega Superspeedway on Monday afternoon.

headline: A Last-Chance Mayoral Election Guide
abstract: With the New York City election just days away, we cut through the personal attacks to show where the main candidates, Eric Adams and Curtis Sliwa, stand on the issues.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of N.Y.C. elections.]

headline: ‘Insecure’ Broke Ground by Embracing Imperfection
abstract: The show, which ends this season, depicted its characters as authentically flawed. “True representation is the ability to show your vulnerability,” said the co-creator and star Issa Rae.
lead_paragraph: “Insecure” begins its final season by looking backward.

headline: Confessions of a Curator: ‘I Can’t Live Without Sculpture’
abstract: Clare Lilley, the woman behind this year’s Frieze Sculpture, talks about the passions that fuel her work and her choices.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Behind every great exhibition, chances are there’s a great curator. But what does a curator actually do?

headline: For This Artist, the Medium Is the Body
abstract: Cassils adds a dance piece to a body of multidisciplinary work that interrogates gender and the treatment of transgender people.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Rolling, scrubbing, shoving and stroking: The dance piece “Human Measure,” which premiered here earlier this month, is filled with bodies touching.

headline: The Creative Collectives Finding Strength in Numbers
abstract: Born out of the American civil rights movement, Black artists’ coalitions thrived in the 1960s and ’70s. Now, a new generation is discovering their power.
lead_paragraph: THE POET SONIA Sanchez can’t recall the man’s name, but she knows that in 1971 he was 85 years old, two years younger than she is today. A Black man born near the close of the 19th century, little more than two decades removed from slavery, his life had seen its share of struggle. His hands told the story: swollen knuckles and chafed skin, hands used to lift and to heave and to haul. Now they held a pencil and the bound journal in which he composed his measured lines each week in advance of Sanchez’s Thursday evening workshop at the Countee Cullen Library on West 136th Street in Harlem. He wrote poems about God and nature and other grand things befitting, he believed, the stately tenor of verse. His workshop companions were high school and college students; a mother who brought her restless child along, equipped with crayons and a coloring book; young professionals coming directly from downtown jobs — all Black and brown women and men, some 50 strong, for whom poetry was an unruly thing that could break lines, hold picket signs, make love and cuss.

headline: Kyle Rittenhouse and the New Era of Political Violence
abstract: What brought the teenager and so many others to the streets of Kenosha, Wis., equipped for war?
lead_paragraph: [On Nov. 19, Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted of intentional homicide and other charges. This story appeared in The New York Times Magazine on Oct. 31.]Practically all of it happened on camera — many cameras, on phones held aloft like candles through the tear gas and firework smoke, feeding fragments of footage and livestreams to the many platforms.

headline: Chronicling the Black Lives Matter Movement, for Kids
abstract: “Call and Response: The Story of Black Lives Matter” is a visually focused book by New York Times journalists that documents the transformative summer of 2020. Here’s how it came together.
lead_paragraph: It was a daunting place to start: Thousands of photos. Hundreds of articles. Protests that stretched not only from coast to coast, but also around the world.

headline: The candidates clashed over questions of public safety and the future of policing.
abstract: The New York Police Department is dealing with a crisis of public confidence, and pressure has mounted to scale back its reach.
lead_paragraph: The next mayor will inherit the New York Police Department at one of its most critical junctures in recent history. And questions over how the force — the nation’s largest — will operate were central throughout the first debate in the general election.

headline: Getting By With a Little Help From Her Friends
abstract: Jayne Allen’s debut novel, “Black Girls Must Die Exhausted,” introduces a Los Angeles reporter who is enduring more than her share of worries.
lead_paragraph: BLACK GIRLS MUST DIE EXHAUSTEDBy Jayne Allen

headline: Review: ‘Thoughts of a Colored Man’ Preaches to the Choir
abstract: Keenan Scott II’s play, incorporating slam poetry, prose and songs, aspires to be a lyrical reckoning with Black life in America.
lead_paragraph: Seven Black men step onto the stage in the opening of Keenan Scott II’s “Thoughts of a Colored Man.” Over the course of the play, each will reveal a personality and history, but not a name, though later they will introduce themselves as Love, Happiness, Wisdom, Lust, Passion, Depression and Anger. Wearing different combinations of black, gray and red, they stand staring at a hulking billboard that reads “COLORED” in declarative black caps.

headline: Facebook Wrestles With the Features It Used to Define Social Networking
abstract: Likes and shares made the social media site what it is. Now, company documents show, it’s struggling to deal with their effects.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2019, Facebook researchers began a new study of one of the social network’s foundational features: the Like button.

headline: Why the Vampire Myth Won’t Die
abstract: Bloodsucking monsters are avatars for our cultural anxieties. Especially now.
lead_paragraph: Have you heard that the Covid vaccine turns you into a vampiric monster — and that the proof is right there in the 2007 Will Smith movie “I Am Legend”?

headline: ‘Fiscal Justice Ratings’ Fight Police Brutality With Finance
abstract: A new project aims to incorporate the cost of lawsuit settlements and inequality when rating municipal bonds.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Video Shows Louisiana Sheriff’s Deputy Slamming Black Woman to the Ground
abstract: The A.C.L.U. said that the Jefferson Parish Sheriff’s Office had opened an investigation into the violent encounter. The woman was treated at a hospital, and no charges were filed against her.
lead_paragraph: The video is short but harrowing. The camera lens quickly zooms past a car and focuses on the scene behind it: A sheriff’s deputy in Louisiana, who towers over a small Black woman, is slamming her onto the ground.

headline: What Gruden’s Emails Tell Us About the N.F.L.’s Hypocrisy
abstract: As the league is trying to send a signal about inclusion and diversity, hate-filled correspondence between football power brokers reveals entrenched values.
lead_paragraph: Jon Gruden’s resignation from the Las Vegas Raiders, after stunning revelations about his history of racist, misogynistic and homophobic emails, points to a deep truth about the National Football League: The league can write as many antiracism slogans in end zones and add as many rainbows to its social media accounts as it wants, but its hypocrisy is evident in the actions of its decision makers.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Eric Adams
abstract: A conversation with the Democratic nominee for New York mayor
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Eric Adams. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Should Greek Life on College Campuses Come to an End?
abstract: Do you think sororities and fraternities should be banned because of reports and allegations of sexual assault involving their members? Or do you think Greek life is a healthy way to support young people navigating college?
lead_paragraph: Do you have siblings or other relatives who are, or once were, members of sororities and fraternities? Is Greek life something you’ve always imagined you’ll be a part of when you attend college?

headline: Why Many Police Traffic Stops Turn Deadly
abstract: Officers, trained to presume danger, have reacted with outsize aggression. For hundreds of unarmed drivers, the consequences have been fatal.
lead_paragraph: “Open the door now, you are going to get shot!” an officer in Rock Falls, Ill., shouted at Nathaniel Edwards after a car chase.

headline: Curtis Sliwa Has New York’s Attention Again. Was That Always the Point?
abstract: The founder of the Guardian Angels has sought the spotlight for decades. With his long-shot bid to become the city’s next mayor, he has found it again.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of N.Y.C. elections.]

headline: Ozy Shows That Serious Black Media Needs a New Business Model
abstract: Advertisers want to say they support Black-run media, but they’re terrified of serious topics.
lead_paragraph: Like many others in the media business, I couldn’t look away from the drama that unfolded last week around Carlos Watson and his company Ozy Media. Once a Black-run media darling among investors and advertisers, it’s now at least temporarily shuttered after a New York Times column exposed its inflated audience metrics, a fraud allegation and other concerning business practices.

headline: A Sea of White Faces in Australia’s ‘Party of Multiculturalism’
abstract: A young daughter of Vietnamese refugees was set to run for Parliament. Then she was passed over for a white insider, and a debate over cultural diversity flared into the open.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — She seemed an ideal political candidate in a country that likes to call itself the world’s “most successful multicultural nation.”

headline: He Read All 27,000 Marvel Comic Books and Lived to Tell the Tale
abstract: In “All of the Marvels,” Douglas Wolk went down a very deep rabbit hole to find the essence of what he calls the “epic of epics.”
lead_paragraph: ALL OF THE MARVELSA Journey to the Ends of the Biggest Story Ever ToldBy Douglas Wolk

headline: 5 takeaways from the second N.Y.C. mayoral debate.
abstract: In the final contest before Election Day, Eric Adams and Curtis Sliwa traded insults and sketched out starkly different visions for the city.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of N.Y.C. elections.]

headline: Bubba Wallace Is Ebullient, Defiant and Comfortable
abstract: After his breakthrough win in NASCAR’s top series, only the second such victory by a Black driver at that level, Wallace talked about learning to shut out ugly noise and to focus on what matters most.
lead_paragraph: Bubba Wallace’s fiancée, Amanda Carter, supplied the positivity. Their Aussiedoodle, Asher, brought the joy. Denny Hamlin and Michael Jordan put Wallace in a fast car, and on Monday he joined Wendell Scott, becoming the second Black driver to win a race at NASCAR’s highest level.

headline: What’s Next for SoHo?
abstract: The pandemic has left SoHo the hardest-hit commercial district in the hardest-hit city, at least in the United States.
lead_paragraph: It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at SoHo as an indicator of economic damage to retailing and real estate in the pandemic. We’ll also splash around in a new pool in the Bronx.

headline: ‘Long Overdue’: Liberal Voters Hold Firm to Biden’s Stronger Safety Net
abstract: In the deep-blue Seattle district represented by Pramila Jayapal, a leading progressive in Congress, voters see the Democrats’ left wing as ascendant and want it to play hardball against moderates.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In the bluest congressional district in the Pacific Northwest, Democrats range from liberal to even more liberal.

headline: Finalists Announced for This Year’s National Book Awards
abstract: Five books are now shortlisted for each of the five categories: fiction, nonfiction, poetry, translated literature and young people’s literature. Winners will be named in November.
lead_paragraph: A food memoir that examines a mother’s schizophrenia. A novel about an author’s book tour, and about growing up as a Black boy in the rural South. Poetry honoring migrants who drowned while trying to cross the Rio Grande.

headline: After Rape Accusations, Fraternities Face Protests and Growing Anger
abstract: At big universities with powerful fraternity cultures — like UMass, Northwestern, Nebraska and Iowa — many students are demanding an end to Greek life.
lead_paragraph: At the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, hundreds of students protested outside a fraternity house in August after a student reported a sexual assault by one of its members to the police.

headline: The 37-Year-Olds Are Afraid of the 23-Year-Olds Who Work for Them
abstract: Twenty-somethings rolling their eyes at the habits of their elders is a longstanding trend, but many employers said there’s a new boldness in the way Gen Z dictates taste.
lead_paragraph: As a millennial with a habit of lurking on TikTok, Jessica Fain understood that skinny jeans and side parts were on the steady march toward extinction. But when Ms. Fain, who works as a product manager at a large tech company, heard that some of her favorite emojis might also be confronting retirement — namely that laughing-sobbing face — she decided to seek the counsel of her junior colleagues.

headline: In Love and Recovery
abstract: Lauren Sabbath had considered herself too damaged to be in a healthy relationship. David Clayton Jr. proved her wrong.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Sabbath wasn’t sure how much of her past she should divulge on her first date with David Clayton Jr., whom she met on the dating app Bumble, in September 2017.

headline: A Show With Its Host City, New Orleans, as the Protagonist
abstract: The contemporary art triennial Prospect New Orleans looks at the city’s cyclical history of challenges.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Fine Arts & Exhibits special report, about how art institutions are helping audiences discover new options for the future.

headline: Photography That Focuses on Those Who Are Often Not Seen
abstract: From New York to Los Angeles, Black, L.G.B.T.Q., Native American and women artists are exhibiting works that highlight their communities and personal perspectives.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our latest Fine Arts & Exhibits special report, about how art institutions are helping audiences discover new options for the future.

headline: A Year in the Life: Who Gets a Master’s Degree in the Beatles?
abstract: In Liverpool, England, a postgraduate program aims to turn Beatles fans into serious students of the band’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — On Wednesday morning, as a new semester began, students eagerly headed into the University of Liverpool’s lecture theaters to begin courses in archaeology, languages and international relations.

headline: Lovely Warren, Troubled Rochester Mayor, to Resign in Plea Deal
abstract: Ms. Warren will leave office early as part of a plea deal on campaign finance violations. The deal also resolves gun charges against her.
lead_paragraph: Lovely Warren, the embattled Democratic mayor of Rochester, N.Y., agreed to resign on Monday as part of a plea deal on several state criminal charges, capping a swift and staggering fall for a politician once considered a rising star in the state Democratic Party.

headline: Jury Acquits Protester Accused in Assault on Wisconsin Lawmaker
abstract: Kerida O’Reilly, 34, had been accused of attacking State Senator Tim Carpenter at a Black Lives Matter protest, prompting others nearby to attack him.
lead_paragraph: A Wisconsin jury on Tuesday found a woman not guilty of charges that she had beaten a state senator who was recording video of protesters at a Black Lives Matter demonstration last year.

headline: The Flea Announces New Resident Company and a Focus on Black and Queer Artists
abstract: The Off Off Broadway theater, which ended programs for emerging artists in December, will return next year with a model that centers the work of underrepresented artists.
lead_paragraph: The Flea, a notable Off Off Broadway company that discontinued its most prominent programs for emerging artists in December, effectively eliminating dozens of positions and provoking the ire of resident artists, announced a new model for its future and a new show. That model, unveiled on Thursday, focuses on supporting the work of underrepresented artists via self-contained, self-programming resident companies.

headline: Hey, Parler, My Blue City Isn’t Turning Red
abstract: Nashville may be having an identity crisis. But our moral commitment to equality will never change.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When NPR’s tech reporter, Bobby Allyn, tweeted last week that the social media site Parler was moving its headquarters from Nevada to Nashville, a single word came to my mind — a word this newspaper will not publish, no matter that it is the only word in the English language truly appropriate to the situation.

headline: The Visionary Community of the Harlem Y.M.C.A.
abstract: In the early 20th century, the building became a meeting place for many of the writers, artists, actors and activists who defined a new and vibrant Black culture.
lead_paragraph: THE MOST PROMINENT building on West 135th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem is not an elaborate church or a stately apartment building but the 90-year-old Y.M.C.A. But despite its bulk, the edifice — with its brick facade, 14-story tower and tall sign with the letters “Y.M.C.A.” blazing in red neon each night — can be easy to overlook: It’s been a mainstay of the neighborhood for so long that its residents sometimes forget to notice it.

headline: Trauma of Charlottesville Rally Is Soundtrack to Start of Civil Trial
