lead_paragraph: On Monday, President Trump is to bestow on Tiger Woods the Presidential Medal of Freedom. They have long been friendly. They have golfed together and Woods is designing a course for a Trump property in Dubai.

headline: William Barr, Joe Biden, India: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Dermot Shea Appointed New N.Y.P.D. Commissioner as O’Neill Resigns
abstract: Commissioner James P. O’Neill rose from the ranks to lead the country’s largest police force for three years.
lead_paragraph: When James P. O’Neill became New York City’s police commissioner in 2016, his challenge was clear: continue to shift the department away from aggressive policing tactics, including the “stop-and-frisk” practice, while maintaining historically low crime rates.

headline: Former Georgia Officer Is Sentenced to 20 Years in Killing of Unarmed Black Man
abstract: The officer shot a man who was wandering naked outside an apartment complex in suburban Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — A photograph of Anthony Hill, smiling in his United States Air Force uniform, loomed above his mother in the courtroom as she described his talent for music, his ambitions and how he had lived the words of his grandfather, which he had tattooed on his chest: “Be sensible.”

headline: These 7 Million Young People Can Beat Trump
abstract: They will have turned 18 by Election Day. And they are more numerous and more liberal than swing voters.
lead_paragraph: They will have turned 18 by Election Day. And they are more numerous and more liberal than swing voters.

headline: Looking for Frederick Douglass in Savannah
abstract: Savannah, Ga., is a pilgrimage destination for those interested in the abolitionist’s life, with artists interpreting his legacy in riveting shows and a film.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Frederick Douglass passed through this elegant Southern city only once, for the briefest of visits — a half-hour whistle-stop on his rail journey to a speaking engagement in Jacksonville, Fla.

headline: Revisiting Jason Reynolds and Brendan Kiely’s ‘All American Boys’
abstract: In 2015, Kekla Magoon wrote for the Book Review about “All American Boys,” a Y.A. novel written by Jason Reynolds and Brendan Kiely about a black teenager and a white teenager grappling with an instance of police brutality.
lead_paragraph: Nalini Jones reviews Jason Reynolds’s latest book, “Look Both Ways,” in this week’s issue. In 2015, Kekla Magoon wrote for the Book Review about “All American Boys,” a Y.A. novel that Reynolds wrote with Brendan Kiely about a black teenager and a white teenager grappling with an instance of police brutality.

headline: How to Talk to Kids About Homelessness
abstract: Parents and teachers weigh in.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Meet 5 of Hong Kong’s Newest Politicians
abstract: The pro-democracy camp’s stunning victory in citywide district elections means a younger class of political neophytes will soon take office.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s district council election saw the pro-establishment camp have one of its biggest defeats since the territory returned to Chinese control 22 years ago, as dozens of seasoned politicians were replaced with a crop of newcomers, many of whom were inspired to run by the antigovernment protests.

headline: British Movie Theaters Pull Gang Film After Violence at Screenings
abstract: Two chains canceled future screenings of “Blue Story” after incidents this weekend. Critics accused the chains of being “cowardly” and “racist,” but the theaters said they were worried about safety.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two British cinema chains have faced widespread criticism after they pulled a film about gang violence from their screens.

headline: Hong Kong Election Results Give Democracy Backers Big Win
abstract: A surge in voting, especially by young people, allowed democracy advocates to win many more seats on local councils.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy candidates buoyed by months of street protests in Hong Kong won a stunning victory in local elections on Sunday, as record numbers voted in a vivid expression of the city’s aspirations and its anger with the Chinese government.

headline: Obama’s Very Boomer View of ‘Cancel Culture’
abstract: Old, powerful people often seem to be more upset by online criticism than they are by injustice.
lead_paragraph: When Barack Obama talks, everyone listens.

headline: ‘Crown Vic’ Review: A Cop Thriller Abounding in Cliché
abstract: The film, about a jaded veteran officer and his rookie partner, plays like an amalgam of the tropes of numerous TV and movie police procedurals.
lead_paragraph: “Crown Vic” begins in the midst of a kinetic shootout, the camera zipping back and forth as a pair of masked robbers careen away from the L.A.P.D. in a car. But the writer-director Joel Souza soon dissipates the adrenaline rush of this opening into a verbose, hackneyed thriller about a night in the lives of a veteran patrol officer and his trainee.

headline: ‘We’re Just So Angry’: Australians Protest Police Killing of Aboriginal Teenager
abstract: After initially saying the 19-year-old had lunged at the police with a weapon, the authorities later charged an officer with murder and opened an investigation.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Thousands of Australians have taken to the streets this week to protest the police killing of an Aboriginal teenager in a remote community, a case that has added fuel to long-simmering anger over the government’s behavior toward the country’s Indigenous people.

headline: Addressing Audience: Two Book Reviews
abstract: Lessons in having a conversation with your readers, with help from a Times review of “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows” and a student review of “Counting Descent.”
lead_paragraph: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

headline: A Former Fox News Executive Divides Americans Using Russian Tactics
abstract: An investigation found that several sites owned by Ken LaCorte push inflammatory items — stories, petitions and the occasional conspiracy theory — to the public.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At first glance, the websites Conservative Edition News and Liberal Edition News have only one thing in common: Both have been carefully curated to inflame America’s culture wars.

headline: Can Hong Kong’s Courts Save the City?
abstract: Don’t count on it.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It both comforts and depresses me, as a lawyer who has practiced for four decades, that every day over the past few months I have been besieged on Facebook by anxious Hong Kongers urging me to take legal action to help protesters.

headline: The Hoodie Enters the Museum
abstract: Few items of clothing are as politically and socially loaded as the hoodie. A new exhibition in Rotterdam tries to explain why.
lead_paragraph: There are few items of clothing as politically, socially and racially charged as the hoodie.

headline: Father of Atatiana Jefferson, Victim of Fatal Police Shooting in Texas, Dies
abstract: “I can only sum it up as a broken heart,” a family spokesman said of Marquis Jefferson’s death.
lead_paragraph: He lost his daughter to a fatal police shooting almost a month ago. Now, he’s gone, too.

headline: White Alabama Officer Guilty of Manslaughter for Killing Black Man
abstract: The officer shot Greg Gunn after initiating a stop-and-frisk encounter as the unarmed man was walking home from a card game in 2016.
lead_paragraph: An Alabama jury found a white police officer guilty of manslaughter on Friday in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man in Montgomery in 2016, the latest case in which an officer has been held to account for using lethal force.

headline: ‘The Witches Are Coming’ by Lindy West: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “The Witches Are Coming,” by Lindy West.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, my husband was at a bar in Chicago. A friend had told him to check out this particular bar because it’s a cool dive run by queer people of color, with dancing and cheap drinks and a good vibe. So he was sitting there, having a beer, and after a while a guy came in and sat down next to him. White guy, late forties. Polo shirt. Mustache probably. Khaki shorts. Standard random white guy. The guy—his name was Larry or Barry or something, so for the purposes of this story let’s call him LarryBarry— struck up a conversation with my husband, asked him if he was having fun. My husband said, “Yeah, this is a fun bar! People are dancing. It’s cool.” And the guy got a real sad look on his face and said, “Yeah, this is one of my favorite songs. I wish I was dancing right now.” So naturally my husband asked, “Well, why don’t you go dance?”

headline: Race/Related: Are Extremists Hijacking the Internet?
abstract: An interview with Andrew Marantz, the author of “Antisocial: Online Extremists, Techno-Utopians, and the Hijacking of the American Conversation.”
lead_paragraph: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read provocative stories on race from The Times, sign up here for our weekly Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: News or ‘Trauma Porn’? Student Journalists Face Blowback on Campus
abstract: Incidents at Northwestern and Harvard reveal a growing tension between traditional journalistic practices and the demands of student activists.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — Jeff Sessions, President Trump’s former attorney general, was speaking to a packed lecture hall on Northwestern University’s campus last week, but the real action was unfolding offstage.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates: The Cancellation of Colin Kaepernick
abstract: “Cancel culture” has always existed — for the powerful, at least. Now, social media has democratized it.
lead_paragraph: We are being told of the evils of “cancel culture,” a new scourge that enforces purity, banishes dissent and squelches sober and reasoned debate. But cancel culture is not new. A brief accounting of the illustrious and venerable ranks of blocked and dragged Americans encompasses Sarah Good, Elijah Lovejoy, Ida B. Wells, Dalton Trumbo, Paul Robeson and the Dixie Chicks. What was the Compromise of 1877, which ended Reconstruction, but the cancellation of the black South? What were the detention camps during World War II but the racist muting of Japanese-Americans and their basic rights?

headline: Trump’s Election May Have Been the Shock We Needed
abstract: American political history suggests that an age of renewal lies ahead.
lead_paragraph: As impeachment mania grips Washington, it is easy to descend into an ever-deepening political pessimism. But as odd as it may seem, for the first time in years, I’m optimistic about the future of American democracy. It might be because I’ve been reading more history and less news. And from the long arc of American political history, I see the bright flashing arrows of a new age of reform and renewal ahead.

headline: Colin Kaepernick’s Workout Derailed by Dispute With N.F.L.
abstract: Kaepernick moved his tryout at the last moment amid a disagreement with the N.F.L. over media access. Few team scouts followed.
lead_paragraph: RIVERDALE, Ga. — Colin Kaepernick’s long journey from Super Bowl quarterback to N.F.L. exile to media machine made a pit stop at Charles R. Drew High School south of Atlanta on Saturday.

headline: To Take on the Religious Right, We Need a Religious Left
abstract: My faith shapes my progressive politics. I wish this were true of more liberals.
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time I encountered God.

headline: Hong Kong Court Reinstates Mask Ban Before Citywide Election
abstract: The ruling came just days before a vote that is being seen as a referendum on the protest movement in the semiautonomous territory.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong court on Friday temporarily reinstated a ban on wearing face masks that targeted antigovernment protesters, after an earlier ruling found the law unconstitutional in what had been a rare victory for pro-democracy activists.

headline: ‘Busted in New York: And Other Essays,’ by Darryl Pinckney: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Busted in New York: And Other Essays,” by Darryl Pinckney
lead_paragraph: When James Baldwin died in 1987, at the age of sixty-three, he was seen as a spent force, a witness for the civil rights movement who had outlived his moment. Baldwin didn’t know when to shut up about the sins of the West, and he went on about them in prose that seemed to lack the grace of voice that had made him famous. But that was the view of him mostly on the white side of town. Ever-militant Amiri Baraka, once scornful of Baldwin as a darling of white liberals, praised “Jimmy” in his eulogy as the creator of a contemporary American speech that we needed in order to talk to one another. Black people have always forgiven and taken back into the tribe the black stars who got kicked out of the Man’s heaven.

headline: ‘Queen & Slim’ Could Be One of the Great Love Stories of All Time — if You Let It
abstract: The film is a rare portrayal of black people in our fullness — angry and frightened and hurt, euphoric and loving and free.
lead_paragraph: The person I love and I were among the first members of the public to see the new film “Queen & Slim.” Early in September, we watched it alone on an upper floor of a nondescript office building in downtown San Francisco. It was a phenomenally isolating experience. We sat in a screening room accompanied by two affable white P.R. people and a black security guard who said nothing. The room was otherwise empty. It was 11 a.m.

headline: We Put Hong Kong on the 52 Places to Go List. Things Got Complicated.
abstract: The planned stops on the 52 Places Traveler’s trip around the world included a mainland China ski area, and the vibrant former British colony. Neither was quite as expected.
lead_paragraph: Our columnist, Sebastian Modak, is visiting each destination on our 52 Places to Go in 2019 list. His last dispatch was from Japan’s Setouchi Islands, where he took in a once-every-three-years art extravaganza.

headline: Teacher Threw Away Students’ Black Lives Matter Posters, A.C.L.U. Says
abstract: A California school district said it was investigating and apologized if students felt “discomfort” about what happened.
lead_paragraph: A school district near Sacramento, Calif., said it is investigating an episode in which a teacher threw away student posters related to the Black Lives Matter movement.

headline: Could These Teams Use a Quarterback Like Colin Kaepernick?
abstract: The 32-year-old, who hasn’t played in the N.F.L. since the 2016 season, is expected to work out for teams on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Quarterback Colin Kaepernick has been invited to work out for N.F.L. teams this weekend, possibly a step toward a return to the N.F.L. for the first time since the 2016 season.

headline: The 72-Hour War Over Christmas
abstract: The mayor of Charleston, W.Va., wanted her city to be more welcoming to all faiths and people, so she changed an annual celebration to the ‘Winter Parade.’ It didn’t last long.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The first shot was fired in the middle of the afternoon in early October, back when the Appalachian leaves had barely turned orange and store shelves were lined with Halloween candy.

headline: 13 Plays and Musicals to Go to in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: The Subway Is in Financial Crisis. Are 500 More Police Officers Needed?
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants to spend more than $50 million a year on new police officers, even though the transit agency is facing a financial crisis. Opponents say the system is already overly policed.
lead_paragraph: More than 2,500 police officers patrol New York City’s subway, where crime is down sharply from the era of rampant violence and graffiti three decades ago.

headline: Hong Kong Election Landslide Signals More Frictions With Beijing
abstract: Democracy supporters were emboldened by capturing most of the seats in local elections, but Beijing and its allies are reluctant to compromise.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the run-up to local elections in Hong Kong on Sunday, Beijing and its allies in the city were portraying the vote as a way to hear the voice of a silent majority after nearly six months of increasingly violent antigovernment protests.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Dickinson’ and ‘American Son’
abstract: A new series tells a coming-of-age story based loosely on the life of Emily Dickinson. And an adaptation of a recent Broadway play hits Netflix.
lead_paragraph: DICKINSON Stream on Apple TV Plus. Emily Dickinson is imbued with teenage angst and a vocabulary that includes words like “dude” and “sick” in this series debuting Friday as one of the first shows on Apple’s new streaming service. “Dickinson,” which stars Hailee Steinfeld as a version of the 19th-century poet, reimagines Dickinson as a patriarchy-fighting millennial who throws ragers, relentlessly pursues her creative impulses and hangs out with a personification of death played by the rapper Wiz Khalifa. She also rebels against her overbearing father and has a romance with her future sister-in-law. In a recent interview with The New York Times, the show’s creator, Alena Smith, described “Dickinson” as “a coming-of-age story about a radical young female artist who was ahead of her time.” The tone calls to mind teen dramas like “Riverdale.” Part of the idea, Smith said, is to consider Dickinson through a modern lens. “If she wasn’t that well understood in her time,” Smith asked, “can we understand her better in ours?”

headline: Impeachment Hearing, Plague, Colin Kaepernick: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Death of Colombian Teenager Drives Protesters Back to Streets
abstract: Dilan Cruz, 18, died after being struck by a police projectile. Activists call him a symbol of “a generation that was robbed of its rights.”
lead_paragraph: Two days after a police projectile sent 18-year-old Dilan Cruz to the hospital, his sister spoke at his high school, pleading for peace in Colombia after five straight days of anti-government protests.

headline: If Protests Are an ‘Infection,’ What Is China’s Cure?
abstract: Escalating rhetoric reveals how seriously Beijing views the unrest in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: In a week when Hong Kong’s universities became tear-gas-scented battlegrounds, the escalating violence has been matched by an intensifying spiral of rhetoric from the governments of Beijing and Hong Kong. Words have always been weapons in conflict, but in the social media age, their potential as tools of mobilization is exponentially multiplied, and the terminology used to describe protesters seems like a signal of tough action ahead.

headline: Donald Trump, George Soros and Your Local Elections
abstract: Monday: Two very rich, prominent figures are looming over contests in New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Close Election in Kentucky Was Ripe for Twitter, and an Omen for 2020
abstract: As hyperpartisan activists, trolls and bots spread unfounded claims of voter fraud, a contested governor’s race is a preview of what many fear for the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: A few hours after polls closed in Kentucky last Tuesday, a Twitter user writing under the handle @Overlordkraken1 posted a message to his 19 followers saying he had “just shredded a box of Republican mail-in ballots.”

headline: On the Scoreboard: The Home Team, the Visitors and Trump
abstract: The president’s visit to the University of Alabama, in the thick of an impeachment inquiry, was not without the usual controversy over whether he’d be booed or not.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump attended Game 5 of the World Series in the nation’s capital, chants of “lock him up” rang out as booing rose from the depth of Nationals Park. When the president attended an Ultimate Fighting Championship bout at Madison Square Garden, supporters and critics spent days fighting over the exact proportion of boos to applause he drew.

headline: Black Voters to Black Candidates: Representation Is Not Enough
abstract: Joe Biden leads with black voters, and Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders are making better inroads with younger ones than Kamala Harris and Cory Booker. In interviews, voters rejected the idea that racial representation equated to change.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Chyna Hester knew what she was supposed to say.

headline: After ‘Us,’ Jordan Peele Crosses Over to ‘The Twilight Zone’
abstract: Peele, the comedian turned Oscar-winning horror filmmaker, overcame initial reservations to remake Rod Serling’s classic series for CBS All Access.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The woman in the black-and-white program on the flat-screen TV was teetering on the brink of madness, delivering a disjointed monologue about parallel worlds and the possibility that our own physical duplicates might walk among us. As the camera hovered above her troubled face and the decades-old audio crackled with the sound of a persistent rainstorm, Jordan Peele sat captivated on a nearby couch. “Beautiful shot,” he said with quiet awe.

headline: A Year After Her Killing, Marielle Franco Has Become a Rallying Cry in a Polarized Brazil
abstract: Last year’s killing of a black, feminist gay council member in Rio de Janeiro has galvanized activist movements and propelled more black women to elected office.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The question hangs heavily over this city: “Who killed Marielle Franco?”

headline: Word + Quiz: persona non grata
abstract: This term has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Black Editor Who Took Over Alabama Newspaper That Called for K.K.K. to ‘Ride Again’ Steps Down
abstract: The new editor said her predecessor, who wrote the incendiary editorial, was still interfering with the publication of The Democrat-Reporter.
lead_paragraph: When a white newspaper editor in Alabama drew widespread condemnation for an editorial that called for the Ku Klux Klan to ride again, only to be replaced by a black woman who hoped to take the newspaper in a new direction, it seemed like a symbolic moment.

headline: Generation Z: Who They Are, in Their Own Words
abstract: They’re the most diverse generation in American history, and they’re celebrating their untraditional views on gender and identity.
lead_paragraph: [For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

headline: Mammy Jars Mock Black People. Why Are They Still Collected?
abstract: Racist objects, created as propaganda tools during the Jim Crow era, reflect ugly stereotypes about black people. Yet some people see nostalgia, not dehumanization, in the memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: In a Black History Month roiled by tone-deaf scandals in politics and fashion involving blackface, shoes and balaclavas, you may have missed the one about mammy jars.

headline: White Officer Placed on Leave After Detaining Black Man Picking Up Trash in Front of His Building
abstract: The man, who was holding a trash clamp, repeatedly told officers in Boulder, Colo., that he had been picking up trash in front , the police said.
lead_paragraph: A white police officer in Colorado has been placed on leave while the authorities investigate why he detained a black man holding a trash clamp in front of the man’s home.

headline: Even in Grief, I Still Have Pride
abstract: Being part of the disability community means constantly losing friends and allies. I don’t expect that to change.
lead_paragraph: “Kristen has passed away.” I’ll never forget learning that my best friend died. I was only 11 years old. We lived in the same town and attended school together. She had spina bifida as well as problems with her kidneys. After years of dialysis, it was kidney failure that ultimately killed Kristen.

headline: 12 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: Trump’s Black Supporters: Inside a Small and Divided World
abstract: Most black voters are Democrats, but even among the tiny collection of Mr. Trump’s dedicated black supporters, there are factions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The surprise hits of the annual gathering of right-wing activists in Washington were appearances by three black women. Lynnette Hardaway and Rochelle Richardson, better known as Diamond and Silk, thanked the organizers for inviting them — “two conservative black chicks” — before mocking reparations. Candace Owens, the fiery young YouTube sensation, called on black people to escape from the country’s liberal ideology.

headline: ‘Newark’s Original Sin’ and the Criminal Justice Education of Cory Booker
abstract: Mr. Booker’s road from enforcer to reformer began with rocky oversight of the Newark Police Department.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — After football practice one summer evening in 2008, a Pop Warner league coach and two of his players were driving through the Clinton Hill section of Newark when a car swerved and blocked their path. Suddenly six police officers emerged from unmarked vehicles and forced them out of their car at gunpoint.

headline: Looking for Details on Rogue N.Y. Police Officers? This Database Might Help
abstract: The Legal Aid Society has created a searchable database of lawsuits filed against the police since 2015 to help identify problematic officers and units.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: ‘She Had a Poor Choice of Words’: Ilhan Omar’s Constituents Grapple with Her Remarks
abstract: In Minnesota’s Fifth Congressional District, voters who overwhelmingly elected the first Somali-American congresswoman were conflicted over her comments.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — When Mohamed Ahmed’s third-grade daughter was assigned a school report about an African-American she admired, she chose to study her newly elected congresswoman, Ilhan Omar.

headline: How Trump’s Brand of Grievance Politics Roiled a Pennsylvania Campaign
abstract: After a state election defeat, Republicans in the Scranton area complain the country is being overtaken by undeserving outsiders and the Democrats who represent them.
lead_paragraph: OLD FORGE, Pa. — The news came at 9:41 p.m. Tuesday: Frank Scavo III had lost. Again.

headline: Trump Says He Will Sign Free Speech Order for College Campuses
abstract: The president said he planned to issue an executive order that would help guarantee free speech on college campuses by putting their federal aid at risk.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — President Trump said on Saturday that he planned to issue an executive order that would help guarantee free speech at colleges and universities by putting their federal aid at risk if they do not protect the viewpoints of students of all political stripes.

headline: Keeping Up With the Kardashian Cash Flow
abstract: Are Kourtney, Kim, Khloé, Kendall and Kylie America’s savviest C.E.O.s?
lead_paragraph: Even when bad things happen to the Kardashians, they still make money.

headline: Ex-Officers Arrested in Killing of Marielle Franco, Brazilian Politician and Activist
abstract: The arrests suggest that Ms. Franco, an activist against police brutality, was targeted by members of a criminal underworld run by former and current law enforcement officials.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Law enforcement officials on Tuesday morning arrested two former police officers suspected of executing a Rio de Janeiro councilwoman — a breakthrough in a brazen political assassination that has haunted Brazilians for nearly a year.

headline: The Tragedy of Baltimore
abstract: Since Freddie Gray’s death in 2015, violent crime has spiked to levels unseen for a quarter century. Inside the crackup of an American city.
lead_paragraph: This article is a collaboration between The Times and ProPublica, the independent nonprofit investigative-journalism organization. Sign up here to get ProPublica’s latest investigations.

headline: Papa John’s Founder, John Schnatter, to Leave Board After Nasty Leadership Fight
abstract: Mr. Schnatter, who resigned as chairman last July after a report that he used a racial slur, has agreed to give up his board seat in exchange for getting a say in choosing an acceptable successor.
lead_paragraph: A rancorous fight between John Schnatter, the former chairman of the Papa John’s pizza chain, and the company he founded appears to have been resolved, with Mr. Schnatter agreeing to give up his board seat after he helps choose an acceptable successor.

headline: Obama-Era Oil Leases Broke the Law by Not Assessing Climate Impact, Judge Rules
abstract: The decision could present a threat to President Trump’s agenda to quickly expand oil and gas drilling by offering opponents a roadmap to legal challenges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration violated federal law by failing to adequately take into account the climate change impact of leasing public land for oil gas drilling in Wyoming, a federal judge ruled Tuesday.

headline: What Students Are Saying About: Leaving a Legacy, Fighting for a Cause and Looking at the Stars
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts — and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: If you read our Current Events Conversation regularly, you know that one thing we love to see is students talking to each other in the comments section. It’s an excellent way to practice your civil discourse skills, learn about people who are different from you and connect with other teenagers from all over the world.

headline: Are You ‘Virtue Signaling’?
abstract: Probably. But that doesn’t mean your outrage is inauthentic.
lead_paragraph: Expressions of moral outrage are playing a prominent role in contemporary debates about issues like sexual assault, immigration and police brutality. In response, there have been criticisms of expressions of outrage as mere “virtue signaling” — feigned righteousness intended to make the speaker appear superior by condemning others.

headline: An Insider’s View of Joy and Beauty in Africa’s Biggest Shantytown
abstract: Through Kibera Stories, Brian Otieno looks beyond the stark realities that have defined his hometown’s visual narrative to photograph innovative fashion, art and everyday life.
lead_paragraph: As Brian Otieno was waiting to start college six years ago, he spent his days snapping pictures with his phone as he wandered the unpaved streets and alleyways of Kibera, a sprawling shantytown on the outskirts of Kenya’s capital, Nairobi. Often referred to as Africa’s largest slum, Kibera is home to up to a million people living side by side in ramshackle homes. Poverty, crime and hardship have long defined its visual narrative.

headline: How the Battle Over Israel and Anti-Semitism Is Fracturing American Politics
abstract: The growing prominence of the B.D.S. movement — and the backlash to it — is widening fault lines from college campuses to Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: On June 9, 2016, the committee tasked with drafting the new Democratic Party platform held its second day of hearings at the Omni Shoreham Hotel, in the upscale Woodley Park neighborhood of Washington. The platform, which is rewritten every presidential-election year, is meant to express a consensus among Democrats on the major issues of the day. The afternoon session, on “America’s role in the world,” included discussions of platform language on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. At stake was whether Democrats would reaffirm the party’s strongly pro-Israel position or make some concessions to the Palestinians.

headline: No Charges in Sacramento Police Shooting of Stephon Clark
abstract: Mr. Clark was killed in his grandmother’s backyard by officers responding to a vandalism complaint. For nearly a year, activists have demanded police accountability.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two Sacramento police officers who shot and killed an unarmed black man in his grandmother’s backyard last year will not face criminal prosecution, the Sacramento County district attorney announced on Saturday, stirring fresh outrage in a city roiled by protests over the killing.

headline: A Gift From the N.F.L. Ignites a Firestorm Over Dreadlocks
abstract: The founder of a Chicago youth group, who shared a photo of herself cutting off a boy’s dreadlocks in 2016, says she meant no disrespect.
lead_paragraph: For several years, a small nonprofit operating out of a church on the South Side of Chicago has tried to reduce gang violence by getting kids involved in boxing, music and other programs.

headline: Colin Kaepernick ‘Dream Crazy’ Ad Wins Nike an Emmy
abstract: The spot surprised the public, revealing that Nike extended its contract with the quarterback known for protesting social issues. Still, it’s unclear how much more there is to the partnership.
lead_paragraph: When Colin Kaepernick starred in a brash Nike ad campaign last fall, it featured all of the sportswear company’s hallmarks.

headline: Americans Trust Police More Than Congress, Study Finds
abstract: The most trusted leader of them all? The public school principal, according to a Pew Research Center study on Americans’ faith in powerful people and institutions.
lead_paragraph: Americans trust police officers, military leaders and local public officials more than members of Congress, tech leaders and journalists, according to a study published by the Pew Research Center on Thursday.

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Hurl Gasoline Bombs at Government Offices
abstract: A day that began with a peaceful, if unauthorized, march by tens of thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators quickly descended into pitched street battles.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Black-clad protesters hurled gasoline bombs at government offices in central Hong Kong on Sunday, as a day that began with a peaceful march by tens of thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators descended into clouds of tear gas deployed by the police and ugly brawls between civilians.

headline: ‘E for Effort’: Can Bernie Sanders Pass the South Carolina Test in 2020?
abstract: The state, where black voters dominate the Democratic electorate, delivered a huge setback to Mr. Sanders in early 2016. He knows things need to be different this time.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Clutching a cup of tea to soothe his hoarsening voice, Senator Bernie Sanders took the stage at the College of Charleston this week with a familiar message for anyone who had been following him since 2015, inveighing against the economic system (“grossly unfair”), political system (“corrupt”) and health care system (“insanity”).

headline: Hong Kong Students Begin School Year With Gas Masks, Class Boycotts and Protests
abstract: After a summer of demonstrating in the streets to demand greater rights, students brought their activism to school.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — High school students in Hong Kong starting the new school year on Monday arrived to class wearing gas masks and joined hands to form human chains. University undergraduates held a strike, waved flags and chanted protest slogans.

headline: Modernism Reboots at the Museums
abstract: Our critic hails the return of MoMA, and nine ambitious autumn art shows.
lead_paragraph: This autumn the excavation, reconstitution and globalization of 20th-century modernism continues apace. And that’s not just because the new, improved Museum of Modern Art is reopening next month, although let’s not minimize the significance of the main birthplace of modernist linearity seriously rearranging its brain cells. Nearly all the shows here contribute in some way, from a show about New York’s first female gallerist at the Jewish Museum, to a “second-tier” French painter at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the redeployment of the Modern’s famed “Americans” exhibitions, which originated at an upstart museum in Florida.

headline: What Draws Atheists, Jews and Catholics to a Presbyterian Church
abstract: At Rutgers Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, social justice and environmental issues unite the congregation. There’s Bible stuff, too.
lead_paragraph: Observant Presbyterians are always part of gatherings at Rutgers Presbyterian Church. But much of the time, so are Roman Catholics and Jews, as well as a smattering of people who consider themselves vaguely spiritual. Valerie Oltarsh-McCarthy, who sat among the congregation listening to a Sunday sermon on the perils of genetically modified vegetables, is, in fact, an atheist.

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Return to Streets After Leader Announces Concessions
abstract: The city’s leader promised to withdraw unpopular legislation that ignited protests in June, but demonstrators’ demands have expanded since then.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong clashed with the police for a second straight day on Saturday, despite a concession on Wednesday from the city’s embattled leader.

headline: Tracing Disinformation With Custom Tools, Burner Phones and Encrypted Apps
abstract: As the 2020 race heats up, here’s how Matthew Rosenberg, a politics reporter, is preparing for an onslaught of intentional falsehoods.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Matthew Rosenberg, who covers political disinformation and is based in Washington, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline: ‘Trust Me’: Kamala Harris Makes Big Play on Criminal Justice Reform
abstract: In an interview, Ms. Harris sought to paint her prosecutorial career as a reason voters should rely on her to deliver a criminal justice overhaul. But her critics say she has been part of the problem.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kamala Harris of California released a sweeping proposal on Monday to overhaul the criminal justice system, vowing to end mass incarceration and revamp police practices through a progressive wish list of policies, including some ideas Ms. Harris previously rejected during her years as a district attorney and state attorney general.

headline: What to Watch as the N.F.L. Begins a New Season
abstract: Who will break out? Will rules changes help settle officiating arguments? Don’t bet on that — but note that more Americans can legally gamble as this season starts.
lead_paragraph: More so than most American sports leagues, the N.F.L. makes news all year. But in the final three months of the year, it cranks up a notch. With the 2019 season getting underway this week, we’ll be checking our fantasy teams, speculating if the New England Patriots will win another Super Bowl and waiting to see which players and teams will make the wrong kinds of headlines.

headline: Climate Protesters Snarl Traffic but Washington Still Goes to Work
abstract: A coalition of climate protesters tried to shut down the streets of Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Climate activists had pledged to bring the nation’s capital to a standstill Monday morning. That did not quite happen, but the blockades of major intersections, street dances and a smattering of arrests continued the effort by protesters to raise the profile of climate change as a political issue.

headline: Theater This Season: A Show (or 10) for Every Mood
abstract: Our list of coming performances includes the topical, the true, the trippy and the timeless.
lead_paragraph: Dates are subject to change.

headline: C.E.O.s Are Not Here to Save Us
abstract: Their message was inspired. Their returns, not so much.
lead_paragraph: One wanted to “elevate the world’s consciousness.”

headline: Toronto Raptors Introduce Branded Hijabs
abstract: The hijabs were inspired by a group based in Toronto that promotes Muslim women in sports.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Raptors have introduced a new line of team-branded hijabs in an effort to be more inclusive to fans of all cultures.

headline: Carrie Lam Comes Face to Face With Angry Hong Kong Residents at Town Hall
abstract: Mrs. Lam met with 150 people on Thursday inside a heavily guarded stadium. She said she wanted to heal divisions and hear “constructive suggestions.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After months of public unrest and criticism that she was ignoring the demands of protesters, Hong Kong’s embattled leader, Carrie Lam, came face to face on Thursday with the fury and frustration coursing through the city during a question-and-answer session billed as a community dialogue.

headline: Working Families Party Endorses Elizabeth Warren. Here’s Why It Matters.
abstract: The progressive group, whose electoral influence has grown since it backed Bernie Sanders four years ago, is now supporting Ms. Warren for the Democratic presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: The Working Families Party, the labor-aligned progressive group whose electoral influence has grown since the 2016 election, has endorsed Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts for the Democratic presidential nomination, a boon to her candidacy as she attempts to position herself as the main challenger to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Hong Kong, Carrie Lam Didn’t Do It for You
abstract: The city’s leader finally makes a concession — caving to Beijing and big business.
lead_paragraph: At long last, on Wednesday Carrie Lam, the leader of Hong Kong, announced, along with a few other largely symbolic measures, the formal withdrawal of the contentious extradition bill that set off a summer of protests. But this is a totally unacceptable response to the crisis facing the city. And no less than her earlier steadfast refusal to concede anything to the protesters, the gesture — so minor and coming so late — only confirms what many of us suspected are the interests she really serves.

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Squeeze Access to the Airport
abstract: A day after clashes between the police and protesters, including inside a subway car, demonstrators tried to disrupt service at a critical Asian travel hub.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong began a new campaign on Sunday to squeeze access to the airport, hours after one of the most tumultuous days since protests in the city began in June.

headline: Young Black Voters to Their Biden-Supporting Parents: ‘Is This Your King?’
abstract: An organic effort by black millennials and Gen Z-ers to influence older family members against Mr. Biden may be important in the Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A groan erupted at a debate watch party at Texas Southern University last week as former vice president Joseph R. Biden Jr. got a question about slavery and racism and gave an answer about Venezuela and record players.

headline: Hong Kong’s Protests Could Be Another Social Media Revolution That Ends in Failure
abstract: Building a movement was easier than finding a way to negotiate a compromise without leaders.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pay attention to Hong Kong. The three months of protests here speak volumes about the state of democracy today — how the human quest for freedom can’t be snuffed out, even by the most powerful autocratic systems, and how hard it is to turn that quest into lasting change in the age of Twitter when everyone is a leader, a follower, a broadcaster and a critic, and compromise becomes nearly impossible.

headline: The Only Way to End ‘Endless War’
abstract: First, America has to give up its pursuit of global dominance.
lead_paragraph: “We have got to put an end to endless war,” declared Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., during the Democratic presidential primary debate on Thursday. It was a surefire applause line: Many people consider “endless war” to be the central problem for American foreign policy.

headline: Hong Kong’s Status as Neutral Ground at Risk as China Asserts Power
abstract: The territory’s traditional role as a gateway is under assault from President Trump’s trade war and a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: In a part of the world familiar with conflict, dislocation and ruthless ideological extremism, Hong Kong has long beckoned as an oasis of stability.

headline: Three Leaders of Women’s March Group Step Down After Controversies
abstract: The departures come after years of discord and charges of anti-Semitism and at a time the group is gearing up for political engagement in the 2020 elections.
lead_paragraph: Three leaders of the Women’s March on Washington who helped organize one of the largest mass mobilizations in United States history following the inauguration of Donald J. Trump have stepped down from the organization’s board after years of controversy.

headline: For Second Time in 2 Weeks, Trump Awards Medal of Freedom to an Ex-N.B.A. Star
abstract: The awards to two white stars of a bygone — and far less racially diverse — basketball era are notable in light of Mr. Trump’s hostile relations with some of today’s N.B.A. stars.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump awarded the Medal of Freedom to the former N.B.A. great Jerry West on Thursday, the second time in two weeks that the president has honored a long-retired standout from a league whose current generation of stars is known for refusing to visit his White House.

headline: The Dolphins Are Awful. Brian Flores Is Fine.
abstract: Brian Flores, one of the few N.F.L. coaches from New York City, is trying to revive the sinking Miami Dolphins. It’s not going well.
lead_paragraph: DAVIE, Fla. — Before agreeing to become the head coach of the Miami Dolphins last winter, Brian Flores consulted his former high school coach in Brooklyn. The response was, sure you’ll have to face New England twice a year, but even Bill Belichick has to retire at some point.

headline: A Mosaic of Groups Competes in Israel’s Election
abstract: Israeli politics can be tribal, with loyalties to ethnic groups, religious factions and ideologies as strong a factor in voting as views on particular issues. Here’s a guide in words and pictures.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Tuesday’s do-over election in Israel may not, by itself, decide who will be the next prime minister. That could take weeks of arduous coalition negotiations.

headline: Lock-Ins and Walkouts: The Students Changing City Schools From the Inside
abstract: Teenagers are helping to lead integration efforts, protesting against discrimination and demanding more inclusive curriculums.
lead_paragraph: They have locked themselves inside school buildings for days on end to protest discrimination.

headline: How Fan Culture Is Swallowing Democracy
abstract: Politicians have become pop icons, and constituents their fans. What does that mean for our politics?
lead_paragraph: Politicians have become pop icons, and constituents their fans. What does that mean for our politics?

headline: 13 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: Joan Jones, 79, Force Against Racism in Nova Scotia, Dies
abstract: In the 1960s, she and her husband galvanized black residents, who were underrepresented in politics and saw high rates of incarceration and unemployment.
lead_paragraph: Joan Jones, a low-key but determined crusader for racial justice and equality in Nova Scotia, whose black population has faced discrimination and hostility for centuries, died on April 1 in Halifax, the capital of the province. She was 79.

headline: Your Average American Joe
abstract: Biden is not an individualist.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s father led the high life as a young man: yachts, fast cars, polo. But his fortunes ran out, thanks to a few bad business deals.

headline: Pete Buttigieg Faces Scrutiny Over ‘All Lives Matter’ Remark in 2015
abstract: Mr. Buttigieg said Thursday that he had not understood at the time that the phrase had become a sort of counter-slogan to the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: It was March 2015, and Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., recognized that the country was having what he called a “painful dialogue” about how people of color and law enforcement were coexisting in their communities. The Black Lives Matter movement was growing in influence after several high-profile killings of black men by police officers.

headline: How These Black Playwrights Are Challenging American Theater
abstract: Jackie Sibblies Drury, Jeremy O. Harris, Antoinette Nwandu and Jordan E. Cooper, on influences, gatekeepers and helping “the young black theater nerd find work that looks like them.”
lead_paragraph: They are the talk of the theater world: a generation of black playwrights whose fiercely political and formally inventive works are challenging audiences, critics and the culture at large to think about race, and racism, in new ways.

headline: Healing the Divisions in Our Country
abstract: Arthur C. Brooks, in “Love Your Enemies,” offers advice on how to restore civility to American politics.
lead_paragraph: LOVE YOUR ENEMIES How Decent People Can Save America From the Culture of Contempt By Arthur C. Brooks

headline: What John Singleton Accomplished With ‘Boyz N the Hood’
abstract: One of the seminal films of its era, it was cinema’s answer to the Rodney King story.
lead_paragraph: “Boyz N the Hood” was John Singleton’s debut film. It came out in 1991 when he was just 23 years old. The director, who died yesterday at the age of 51 after suffering a stroke, went on to make several great films but none rival his first, one of the seminal films of its era.

headline: In ‘Magical Negro,’ Morgan Parker’s Poems Challenge White Ideas of Blackness
abstract: Parker’s third collection provides its audience a space to celebrate black excellence and black joy as well as to commiserate about injustice.
lead_paragraph: MAGICAL NEGROPoemsBy Morgan Parker

headline: The Mueller Report and the Danger Facing American Democracy
abstract: A perceived victory for Russian interference poses a serious risk for the United States.
lead_paragraph: The report of the special counsel Robert Mueller leaves considerable space for partisan warfare over the role of President Trump and his political campaign in Russia’s interference in the 2016 election. But one conclusion is categorical: “The Russian government interfered in the 2016 presidential election in sweeping and systematic fashion.”

headline: Inequality Fuels Rage of ‘Yellow Vests’ in Equality-Obsessed France
abstract: France’s so-called Yellow Vest protesters are animated by more than anger at the rich: They seek a protected and expanded social safety net.
lead_paragraph: BOURGES, France — In a world seething with anger over the widening gap between the rich and everyone else, France stands out as a country elaborately engineered to protect social peace.

headline: Kyler Murray Makes N.F.L. Draft History at No. 1
abstract: The Oklahoma quarterback was taken by the Arizona Cardinals with the first pick. No team has ever invested so much in a quarterback of his size.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Kyler Murray completed his unlikely transformation on Thursday night, evolving in less than a year from a college backup planning a career in baseball to a Heisman Trophy-winning No. 1 overall pick in the N.F.L. draft and a prospective franchise quarterback for the Arizona Cardinals.

headline: Is the U.S. a Democracy? A Social Studies Battle Turns on the Nation’s Values
abstract: Michigan spent five years debating how to teach American history. One of the biggest questions was how to describe the nation’s government.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — Bruising political fights are usual business in Becky Debowski’s eighth-grade social studies classroom. From a model Constitutional Convention to a bare-knuckle debate in Congress over slavery, she regularly has students assume roles of partisans throughout American history, like Abraham Lincoln and John C. Calhoun.

headline: Bret Easton Ellis Takes On ‘Generation Wuss’
abstract: Ellis, perpetual bad boy and avatar of Generation X, delivers in his first nonfiction book, “White,” a series of rants against the politics of the young and woke.
lead_paragraph: WHITE By Bret Easton Ellis

headline: His Punch Lines Cross Moral Lines. Anthony Jeselnik Gets Away With It.
abstract: The comedian says he can say very dark things because audiences and social media followers understand that he’s not a monster — his character is.
lead_paragraph: In his ruthlessly funny new special, “Fire in the Maternity Ward,” which debuts on Netflix on Tuesday, the stand-up comic Anthony Jeselnik muses nostalgically that you never forget the first time you had sex.

headline: Overlooked No More: Martin Sostre, Who Reformed America’s Prisons From His Cell
abstract: The lawsuits he filed from behind bars in the 1960s and ’70s challenging harsh prison conditions laid the groundwork for prisoners to defend their rights even today.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. The project began in 2018 with a focus on women, but it’s widening its lens this year.

headline: A ‘Glitch’ Left Young People Off the Jury Rolls. Does That Violate the Constitution?
abstract: Computer glitches have compromised jury selection processes across the country. More trouble surfaced recently in a death penalty case in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — The Louisianans who were summoned to decide whether Grover Cannon killed a police officer were Asian, black, Hispanic and white. They were caregivers and engineers, state workers and self-employed.

headline: Trump’s Other Base
abstract: In preparation for 2020, the president is focused on the minority vote.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s dogged, Captain-Ahab-like obsession with immigrants and asylum seekers crossing the southern border is many things.

headline: A ‘Women’s New Deal’
abstract: A trio of high-profile leaders — Cecile Richards, Alicia Garza, Ai-jen Poo — introduce Supermajority, a group that wants to guide millions of American women toward political activism.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading In Her Words, where women rule the headlines.

headline: Nick Bosa Comes With the Kind of Baggage That Doesn’t Matter
abstract: Nick Bosa has been scrubbing his Twitter account ahead of the N.F.L. draft. But will teams care what he has said when he can rush the quarterback so well?
lead_paragraph: [N.F.L. Draft Live 2019: Click here for pick-by-pick updates and analysis]

headline: How Tough-on-Crime Prosecutors Contribute to Mass Incarceration
abstract: “Charged,” by Emily Bazelon, argues that prosecutors have far too much power over the outcomes of criminal cases and lays out a path for urgent reform.
lead_paragraph: CHARGED The New Movement to Transform American Prosecution and End Mass Incarceration By Emily Bazelon

headline: The Devastating Consequences of Being Poor in the Digital Age
abstract: When someone who is living paycheck to paycheck falls victim to an online fraud or a breach, the cascade of repercussions can be devastating.
lead_paragraph: One of the tragic ironies of the digital age is this: Despite the fact that low-income Americans have experienced a long history of disproportionate surveillance, their unique privacy and security concerns are rarely visible in Washington and Silicon Valley. As my colleague Michele Gilman has noted, the poor often bear the burden of both ends of the spectrum of privacy harms; they are subjected to greater suspicion and monitoring when they apply for government benefits and live in heavily policed neighborhoods, but they can also lose out on education and job opportunities when their online profiles and employment histories aren’t visible (or curated) enough.

headline: The Battle Hymn of the Postmillennials
abstract: Michael R. Jackson’s original song cycle “The Kids on the Lawn,” inspired by photographs by Virgil Abloh, written for T’s Culture issue.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Jackson’s original song cycle “The Kids on the Lawn,” inspired by photographs by Virgil Abloh, written for T’s Culture issue.

headline: Part 3: The Future of Fox: An Even More Powerful Political Weapon
abstract: The Disney deal left the Murdochs with a media empire stripped to its essence: a hard-core right-wing news machine — with Lachlan in charge.
lead_paragraph: The Disney deal left the Murdochs with a media empire stripped to its essence: a hard-core right-wing news machine — with Lachlan in charge.

headline: Barr Says Communities That Protest the Police Risk Losing Protection
abstract: The attorney general’s comments drew criticism that he was conflating objections to police misconduct with a disrespect for the police.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr warned that communities and critics of policing must display more deference or risk losing protection, a stark admonition that underscored the Trump administration’s support for law enforcement amid an ongoing national conversation about police brutality against minorities.

headline: As Protests Rage on Citizenship Bill, Is India Becoming a Hindu Nation?
abstract: Several people have been killed as unrest spreads to new corners of the country. Many see the passage of a new law as anti-Muslim.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government has rounded up thousands of Muslims in Kashmir, revoked the area’s autonomy and enforced a citizenship test in northeastern India that left nearly two million people potentially stateless, many of them Muslim.

headline: The Decade Tech Lost Its Way
abstract: An oral history of the 2010s
lead_paragraph: An oral history of the 2010s

headline: Neil deGrasse Tyson: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: Much of the natural world is beautiful — but what else is out there?
lead_paragraph: Much of the natural world is beautiful — but what else is out there?

headline: Massimo Bottura: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: Building a community can be transformational.
lead_paragraph: Building a community can be transformational.

headline: Joy Harjo: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: A tale of creation and beauty, told through poetry.
lead_paragraph: A tale of creation and beauty, told through poetry.

headline: Cristina Mittermeier and Paul Nicklen: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: Achieving a higher purpose is what fills our lives with beauty.
lead_paragraph: Achieving a higher purpose is what fills our lives with beauty.

headline: Reshma Saujani: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: The bravery of Greta Thunberg, Isra Hirsi and other young women is both beautiful and inspirational.
lead_paragraph: The bravery of Greta Thunberg, Isra Hirsi and other young women is both beautiful and inspirational.

headline: André Aciman: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: The moments in which we are one with the world are the best that life has to offer.
lead_paragraph: The moments in which we are one with the world are the best that life has to offer.

headline: Zac Posen: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: My life’s work has centered on expressing beauty and meaning.
lead_paragraph: My life’s work has centered on expressing beauty and meaning.

headline: What Happened to Kamala Harris?
abstract: The rise and fall of a former top contender.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Hong Kong Protest, Largest in Weeks, Stretches Several Miles
abstract: Throngs of people poured into major thoroughfares for a march marking Human Rights Day.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hundreds of thousands of protesters, basking in a recent election victory by Hong Kong’s pro-democracy camp, poured onto the city’s streets on Sunday in one of the largest marches in weeks to pressure the government to meet demands for greater civil liberties.

headline: Violent Protests and Free Speech: Who’s to Blame for an Officer’s Injuries?
abstract: The A.C.L.U. asked the Supreme Court to hear an appeal from DeRay Mckesson, a Black Lives Matter activist sued by a Louisiana police officer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The lawsuit, a federal judge found, bordered on the delusional. A Louisiana police officer injured in a protest tried to sue the hashtag #BlackLivesMatter, which amounted, wrote Judge Brian A. Jackson of the Federal District Court in Baton Rouge, to picking a fight with an idea. “A hashtag,” Judge Jackson wrote, “is patently incapable of being sued.”

headline: This Decade of Disillusion
abstract: Why and how the young rule our time.
lead_paragraph: There are eras in history, like the 1950s, when older people set the cultural and moral terms for the young. And there are eras, like the 1960s, when it’s the other way around.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Reparations, What They Want to Learn in School, and Individuality
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked young people to weigh in on whether the United States owes reparations to the descendants of slaves, tell us what they wished they could learn in school, and reflect on their identities.

headline: How Is What You Are Studying in School Relevant to Your Life and the Larger World?
abstract: How much do you see the things you care about reflected in what you learn?
lead_paragraph: Note: This question is inspired by our Connections and Analysis Unit and related contest, in which we invite teenagers to connect anything they’re studying in school with the world today. If you are participating in the contest, we invite you to use this as a kind of “rehearsal space” to post ideas and see how others respond.

headline: I Worked for Alex Jones. I Regret It.
abstract: I dropped out of film school to edit video for the conspiracy theorist because I believed in his worldview. Then I saw what it did to people.
lead_paragraph: On Election Day 2016, I sat in the passenger seat of Alex Jones’s Dodge Hellcat as we swerved through traffic, making our way to a nearby polling place. As Jones punched the gas pedal to the floor, the smell of vodka, like paint thinner, wafted up from the white Dixie cup anchored in the console. My stomach churned as the phone I held streamed live video to Facebook: Jones rambling about voter fraud and rigged elections while I stared at the screen, holding the camera at an angle to hide his double chin. It rarely worked, but I didn’t want to be blamed when he watched the video later.

headline: India Awakens to Fight for Its Soul
abstract: Authoritarian and divisive polices of the Modi government have pushed Indians across the country to the streets in protest.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and his Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party government have deployed propaganda very successfully since coming to power in 2014. So much so that numerous egregious decisions the government has made — demonetization, electoral bonds allowing secret donations to political parties, a flawed citizens registry in the state of Assam, revoking the autonomy of Jammu and Kashmir — were accepted by a majority of people.

headline: Did Pete Buttigieg Help Black People in South Bend?
abstract: The mayor of South Bend, Ind., has some local black leaders vouching for him. But that hasn’t stopped his opponents from criticizing his record.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Pete Buttigieg is rarely home these days as he scoots from South Carolina to New Hampshire to Iowa in pursuit of primary voters.

headline: The ‘Infinity War’ in the Streets of Hong Kong
abstract: The rise of China threatens the free world.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Carrie Lam, the lame-duck Beijing-backed ruler of Hong Kong, is unhappy that Christmas has been “ruined by a group of reckless and selfish rioters.” Joan Shang, who works in sustainable development and has joined the pro-democracy protests, takes a different view. “It’s an ideological war and we are at the center of it,” she said of the near-seven-month campaign. Such struggles do not take a break for Santa.

headline: The Decade in Pictures
abstract: The New York Times pored over 10 years of images, of moments both fresh and faded, to tell the story of the past decade.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times pored over 10 years of images, of moments both fresh and faded, to tell the story of the past decade.

headline: Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: Beauty is physical, creative and deeply spiritual.
lead_paragraph: Beauty is physical, creative and deeply spiritual.

headline: Elizabeth Blackburn: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: The universe is mysterious, but also intricate and elegant.
lead_paragraph: The universe is mysterious, but also intricate and elegant.

headline: Constance Wu: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: We are most alive when enjoying and expressing beauty.
lead_paragraph: We are most alive when enjoying and expressing beauty.

headline: Jameela Jamil: Why Beauty Is So Important to Us
abstract: Let’s stop glorifying impossible ideals.
lead_paragraph: Let’s stop glorifying impossible ideals.

headline: Best Theater of 2019
abstract: Shows that defied categorization offered a stark choice: Escape an angry world, or face up to its travails. Beyond Broadway, writers explored race, inequality and addiction.
lead_paragraph: Escape or confront? In a year when news of an angry, snarling nation seemed way too much with us, 24 hours a day, the New York theater served up both forget-your-troubles fantasies and magnifying mirrors to a world seriously out of joint.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Embrace of Black Players Has Always Been Conditional
abstract: A new guard of black quarterbacks is leading the N.F.L. but as 100 years of history have shown — from Fritz Pollard to Colin Kaepernick — the league has always needed a push to make progress.
lead_paragraph: The explosion of young black quarterbacks with phenomenal athletic ability and passing acumen has become the rage of the N.F.L. As defenses in the league have become more athletic, offenses have made an adjustment at the sport’s most important position.

headline: At Alvin Ailey, a Quiet Disrupter With No Time for Tears
abstract: Jamar Roberts, the company’s first resident choreographer, wants to bring the world into his dances.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes riding the subway has its upside. It affords time to think — and, in the case of Jamar Roberts, to choreograph. Recently, as he headed to the final working rehearsal for “Ode,” his new dance at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, he had to think about what it was missing: an ending.

headline: What to Do About Racism in Opera?
abstract: Readers discuss how today’s audiences should view classic operas from another era that have offensive stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Thrilling Shock of ‘Queen & Slim’
abstract: Who says pop culture has become too safe?
lead_paragraph: I left a recent matinee of “Queen & Slim,” the mesmerizing new outlaw romance directed by Melina Matsoukas, astonished on two levels. The film itself kept me rapt; I cried through the end and left the theater with the dazed, disoriented feeling you get when a movie makes you momentarily forget everything else in your life. But as amazed as I was by the experience of watching the film, I was equally amazed that it got made at all.

headline: The Decade We Changed Our Minds
abstract: America in the 2010s saw significant cultural and political shifts that pushed us forward.
lead_paragraph: America is always in a state of flux. The country is an eternal experiment, aiming at evolution, betting on its own betterment.

headline: How This Con Man’s Wild Testimony Sent Dozens to Jail, and 4 to Death Row
abstract: Paul Skalnik is a grifter and criminal. Now a man may be executed because of his dubious testimony. Why did prosecutors rely on him as an informant?
lead_paragraph: This article is a partnership between ProPublica, where Pamela Colloff is a senior reporter, and The New York Times Magazine, where she is a staff writer.

headline: At ‘Black Out’ Performances, the Power of Healing Through Community
abstract: Special screenings and performances of black films and plays tailored for black audiences can feel especially welcoming.
lead_paragraph: A handful of playwrights, directors, filmmakers and film lovers have created spaces for black audiences to crack jokes and clap back without apology and, afterward, process complex, nuanced race-related issues.

headline: The New Pop Culture Optimism
abstract: More movies and shows are imagining worlds where prejudice is seemingly nonexistent and everyone is accepted.
lead_paragraph: When I contemplate what my ideal world might look like, I imagine one in which everyone just minds their business and does their own thing, so long as they aren’t causing any harm — directly or indirectly — to others. That doesn’t mean there isn’t conflict or that bad things never happen: Humans will still annoy one another and argue, many marriages will still end in divorce, studio execs will still make up excuses to tell the same story about Batman or Batman-adjacent characters for the hundredth time.

headline: The Sexual Predator’s TV Wife
abstract: Harassment has long been a hurdle on the anchorwoman’s rise to the top. New projects, like “The Morning Show” and “Bombshell,” examine what she has to do to stay there.
lead_paragraph: “The Morning Show” begins with a wake-up call. Mitch Kessler (Steve Carell), the Matt Lauer-ish co-host of a “Today” show-ish program, answers the phone at 3 a.m. to learn that he has been fired over allegations of sexual misconduct. When his co-host, Alex Levy (Jennifer Aniston), reports to a chaotic pre-dawn set, her producer, Chip (Mark Duplass), says something sycophantic about how much America needs her, and she snaps. “Don’t drag America into this,” she says. “This affects me.”

headline: After Rikers Island Closes, What Will Jail Look Like?
abstract: With plans to shutter Rikers, the city will build four new jails, a chance to address penal reform and make jails safer. But leadership and design excellence are key.
lead_paragraph: Just before Thanksgiving 18-year-old Nicholas Feliciano became the latest casualty of Rikers Island. Mr. Feliciano, who had a history of suicide attempts, got injured in a fight with other inmates and was transferred to a unit where guards watched for seven minutes — and did nothing — while he tried to kill himself. He ended up in a medically induced coma.

headline: Don’t Think Sanders Can Win? You Don’t Understand His Campaign
abstract: There was a time in America when being called a socialist could end a political career. Not anymore.
lead_paragraph: As the Democratic primary elections get closer, the party leadership has begun to fret in public about universal health care and other ambitious proposals. Even former President Barack Obama tried to assuage donors’ fears in November when he said that the “average American” doesn’t think we need to “tear down the system and remake it.” His comment captured the essence of tensions that have roiled the party for months. Party elites believe focusing squarely on President Trump’s record will end his presidency, while others counter that the Democrats also have to champion bold policies.

headline: Trump’s Order to Combat Anti-Semitism Divides Its Audience: American Jews
abstract: Jewish communities across the country viewed the order, which is aimed at college campuses, in competing and discordant ways.
lead_paragraph: Amir Kashfi felt a sigh of relief when he heard that President Trump had signed an executive order to combat anti-Semitism and the burgeoning anti-Israel movement on college campuses.

headline: Beijing Backs Hong Kong Leader Despite Election Setback
abstract: China’s president endorses Hong Kong’s embattled leader, Carrie Lam, despite the rout of her political allies in local elections three weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s top leader backed Chief Executive Carrie Lam of Hong Kong on Monday despite the monthslong protests that have rocked the city and the recent landslide defeat in local elections of political parties aligned with her.

headline: The Process. The Decision. The Big Three. They Changed the N.B.A.
abstract: The league has been upended in fundamental ways over the past decade, from how teams see players to how players see themselves.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is reflecting on the past decade in the N.B.A., which has evolved perhaps more than any other major sports league.

headline: 9 Ways New York Changed That We Didn’t See Coming
abstract: As we look back at the past decade, the city that always changes still managed to surprise us.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s transformation during the past 10 years has been profound. Not everything was so predictable, although predicting a Mike Bloomberg presidential campaign would have probably been a safe bet.

headline: A Movie Torn From the Pages of His Life
abstract: Ladj Ly started with videos of police confrontations with his friends in Paris’s immigrant suburbs. Now, his wrenching film “Les Misérables” is up for an Oscar.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — From barren territory on the outskirts of Paris, Ladj Ly hit movie theaters last month with an urgent message: Multicultural France is here, it is real and it is not in good shape.

headline: Boeing, Jamal Khashoggi, Fukushima: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: With Rise of Far-Right Extremists, N.Y.P.D. Creates Special Unit
abstract: Threats from far-right and neo-Nazi organizations, including groups like The Proud Boys, will be investigated.
lead_paragraph: For almost two decades, the intelligence bureau of the New York Police Department has built a security apparatus designed to track international terror groups like Al Qaeda and the Islamic State.

headline: She’s 16 and Wants to Be President: Meet the Teenagers Planning Their Campaigns
abstract: Research shows that Generation Z is the first in which women are more likely than their male peers to be engaged in politics. Here’s what some of them told us.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Abby Cumming-Vukovic is going to be a state representative. You can quote her on that.
